HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Vice Chairwoman's Comments Calm Wary Investors

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Interest rate increases by several European central banks, led by the Germans, sent Treasury securities tumbling early yesterday before they rebounded on remarks by Alice M. Rivlin, vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve.
After a big drop in the market on Wednesday, when the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, warned that inflation might be on the horizon, Ms. Rivlin managed to soothe the bears. Mr. Greenspan's comments had raised concern that there might be an interest-rate increase in the United States, too, but Ms. Rivlin provided a calmer, gentler outlook on Fed policy in a CNBC interview, according to Timothy Rogers, managing economist at Technical Data of Boston. She indicated that the Fed did not want to slow the economy unnecessarily but that price pressures needed watching, given the strong pace of the economy. 
 The 30-year bond was up 6/32, to a price of 100 10/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.35 percent, from 6.36 percent.
The dollar fell against the German mark after the Bundesbank raised the rate it charges banks to borrow money to 3.30 percent from 3 percent. The repo rate, as it is called, is comparable to the Federal funds rate in the United States.
Traders and investors were concerned that foreign investors, whose purchases of American Government securities over the last year have helped support bond prices, might start reducing those purchases with more competitive interest rates now available elsewhere.
The German rate increase was surprising because of the sluggishness of European economies, and some analysts said it made it more likely that the Fed would now follow suit.
"With many European central banks raising short-term rates, it has become clear to investors that if they can do it, with softer economic growth rates, then it's quite clear that the Fed chairman's comments cannot simply be dismissed as a crying wolf attempt to moderate the gains in the financial market," said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio. "If the U.S. doesn't follow in the same direction, the risk is that the dollar will weaken, thereby adversely impacting the very same factors that have helped keep inflation at bay." With a weaker dollar, imported goods cost more in the United States, contributing to price pressures.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that with inflation clearly the focus of attention, market participants are now eagerly awaiting today's Producer Price Index report for September. Most forecasts look for an increase of two-tenths of a percent or three-tenths of a percent, but the range is rather wide.
"However, while the P.P.I. is an extremely important inflation indicator, it does not include the service sector, and the bond market's direction and behavior will likely be more heavily influenced by both the retail sales and Consumer Price Index statistics being released next week," Mr. Fine said.
"After Chairman Greenspan's statement Wednesday," Mr. Fine said, "it is clear the Federal Open Market Committee would not hesitate to lift the Federal funds rate a notch and tighten monetary policy at the slightest hint of inflationary pressures."
On Monday, the Government securities markets will be closed in observance of Columbus Day. The Bond Market Association has recommended a 2 P.M. close for the Government securities market today, while the Chicago Board of Trade said it planned to close trading in its financial and insurance contracts at 1:10 P.M., though other contracts will observe the normal schedule.

HEADLINE: Markets Shake Off Turmoil But Finish the Day Mixed

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market shrugged off early worries about rising interest rates yesterday and helped push some broad indexes to record highs, but overall results ended mixed.
The losses came at the opening as traders began selling on news that all the major European markets had tumbled after the German central bank raised interest rates for the first time in five years. 
 But losses in the stock and bond markets were trimmed later in the day, another indication of how resilient the United States financial markets remain.
In early trading, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 92 points, then quickly bounced back. At the close, the Dow was down 33.64 points, to 8,061.42. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed down 3.22 points, to 970.62.
Broader indexes fared much better. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 4.08 points, to 1,745.85, its sixth straight record high. The Russell 2000 index of smaller company stocks gained 0.89 point, to 464.55, also a record.
"The will to believe and the desire to believe still remain stubbornly powerful," said Eric Miller, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in San Francisco. "The demand for stocks is simply greater than Wall Street can throw at investors."
A day earlier, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, rattled the markets by saying inflation might be looming. But even though investors have softened their bullish stance in the last two sessions, the selling has not been widespread.
"The market gave a good account of itself today," said Eugene E. Peroni Jr., director of technical analysis at Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia. "We certainly didn't see any emotional or panic-driven selling."
Indeed, Mr. Peroni said the market was only temporarily disrupted by Mr. Greenspan's remarks. Short of a policy move such as a change in interest rates, Mr. Peroni said, he does not expect the market to suffer any great losses.
The reason, he said, is that interest rates have been steadily lower this year, making stocks relatively more attractive, and early indications are that third-quarter earnings will be robust. As a result, Mr. Peroni said, few investors were overly troubled by Mr. Greenspan's remarks.
In fact, Alice M. Rivlin, the vice chairwoman of the Fed, suggested yesterday that the central bank was not preparing to raise interest rates. "Nobody wants to slow down the economy unnecessarily," she said on CNBC.
Investors may have also cheered a strong earnings report from General Electric, a Dow component stock. Shares of G.E. rose 1/8, to 70 5/8, after the company reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings.
Within the Nasdaq, shares of Cisco Systems rose 11/16, to 81 7/8. Novell Inc. rose 1, to 10, and Worldcom gained 5/16, to 37 1/8. Shares of oilfield service companies were also buoyant. The S.& P. Midcap Energy index rose 3 percent yesterday on optimism about third-quarter earnings. This year, the index is up 51.2 percent, easily outperforming the broader market. Analysts said that coming earnings reports could further bolster the market. The S.& P. 500 is up 31 percent this year, and the Dow is up 25 percent.
 But Ralph J. Acampora, director of technical analysis at Prudential Securities, said he was already wondering what to do when the stock market reached his bullish target.
At a luncheon meeting yesterday, Mr. Acampora -- who had earlier predicted the Dow would reach 10,000 by June 1998 -- said he was starting to think about when he is going to advise investors to start scaling back, even though his target date is still nine months away.
One reason he is concerned about getting out before the top is that he expects an ensuing drop to take the major indexes down by as much as 25 percent, which means some stocks could fall much more.
"I think it's foolhardy to catch the absolute top," he said. "So we will have to scale out of this."

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN FINANCE: THE VOTERS;
The Buzz in the Capital Brings a Yawn in Peoria

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 9

 BODY:
As Washington was buzzing this week with talk of campaign finance scandal at the White House, Butch Long was pushing a heavy wheelbarrow on a dusty construction site here along the Illinois River.
Not once, he swore, did thoughts of campaign finance cross his mind. 
 "I'm bored with it," said Mr. Long, a 40-year-old concrete worker and Reagan Democrat who voted twice for Bill Clinton. "Can't they find something else to talk about out there?"
To put it mildly, people in this small Midwestern city are something short of alarmed about the tempest in the capital over money-begging phone calls, the curious generosity of foreign zillionaires and White House kaffeeklatsch videos that surface, by accident or design, with distinct tardiness.
"This does not top my list of national concerns," said Jan Pippin, 51, a secretary for the Salvation Army. "I'm less worried about how politicians raise their money than how they spend ours."
If the scandal off in Washington is not playing here, as dozens of interviews with Democrats and Republicans in this quintessential Middle American city seem to indicate, it is not because ordinary Joes and Janes simply cannot solve the arcana of a complicated case. Most people have a good grasp of the basics (although it is the rare bird, to be sure, who can distinguish "hard money" from "soft").
Nor does the absence of indignation mean that people have lost their appetite for a good partisan scrap or a juicy political scandal.
They just do not seem to think that this one measures up.
"The Republicans ought to just lighten up and let Clinton and Gore do their jobs," said Dave Dubicki, a 46-year-old lawyer who said he usually sided with the Republicans.
Mr. Dubicki said "some of these guys in Congress" reminded him of the police official in "Casablanca" who was "shocked, shocked," to find gambling going on in Rick's Cafe.
"I've noticed that George Bush isn't speaking out about how awful all of this is," he said. "Makes you think this has been a common way of doing things for a long time.
"Besides that, people really like Clinton. He seems like a good guy with a friendly smile. Nothing sticks to him. He's the Democrats' answer to Reagan."
Mr. Dubicki, in shirt sleeves on a glorious autumn afternoon, also noted that economic sunshine tended to put people in a more forgiving mood.
"If we had high unemployment and Jimmy Carter interest rates," he said, "we'd all be saying, 'Clinton's a bum, and we can see right through that shallow smile of his.' "
Even as it is, the Democrats in the White House are not without critics when it comes to fund-raising.
"I don't care if the law seems silly or nit-picky," said Chris Hamilton, a 35-year-old legal assistant. "In my business we're expected to do things exactly by the book, or we're in big trouble. Why shouldn't the same standards apply to the President and Vice President?"
But the concerns voiced by Mrs. Hamilton sound a bit faint in a time of so much exulting here about plentiful jobs and a stock market that has been headed for Pluto. One Republican, Dan Son, a 36-year-old deliveryman for the United Parcel Service, succinctly summarized many Peorians' view about any budding campaign finance scandal: "Big whoop."
Indeed, in these days of peace and prosperity, President Clinton's job approval rating nationally has remained strikingly healthy, rivaling that of Ronald Reagan at the corresponding point of Mr. Reagan's second term.
Peoria, hometown of Betty Friedan and Richard Pryor, is a Democratic-leaning city in a Republican-leaning Congressional district. The area is conservative on social issues, with a streak of populism and a solid core of unionized workers. The Congressional district was represented until 1995 by Robert H. Michel, a House Republican leader known for his genial bipartisanship and centrist instincts.
The city is still haunted by memories of economic disaster in the early 1980's, when the double wallop of a Rust Belt recession and a Farm Belt crisis left 1 in every 5 Peorians jobless. Big factories like those of Pabst and Hiram Walker shut down, and Caterpillar, the farm machinery giant based here, endured plummeting demand for its products.
In those days, some bumper stickers declared the sense of defeat: "Would the last person leaving Peoria please turn out the lights?"
But good times have returned to Peoria, where a vibrant Midwest economy has produced new businesses and cut the unemployment rate to about 4 percent.
Representative Ray LaHood, the Republican who succeeded Mr. Michel in Congress, acknowledges that the economic boom has wrapped Mr. Clinton in a stainless-steel suit of political armor.
"I have never, at any town meeting, had anybody come and say, 'Congressman, I want you to do something about campaign finance,' " Mr. LaHood said. "If people are earning a good wage and can afford to take the kids on vacation once a year, they're happy. And that's why Clinton is so popular in Peoria County."
Indeed, people like Mr. Long, the riverside construction worker, who went without a job for six months one year during the downturn of the 80's, can put in overtime these days. He is now working on a part of the huge Peoria riverfront redevelopment, a project worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
"This is as good as it's been," said Mr. Long, a tall man with a wide smile, happy to have sweat on his brow. "Don't change a thing."
Contrary to Mr. Clinton's popularity here, Vice President Al Gore seems to get a much cooler reaction. And the possibility of fund-raising violations by Mr. Gore, a matter still under the scrutiny of Attorney General Janet Reno, does not seem to be his biggest problem.
Even loyal Democrats like Carol Thomas, a 34-year-old secretary who would sooner chew nails than bolt to the Republicans, confess that it is awfully hard to get excited about a Gore candidacy for President in 2000. Daniel Buchanan, 27, a sculptor who supports himself by working as a waiter at Steak-n-Shake, could summon nothing at all, good or ill, to say about Mr. Gore, who, he said, simply does not stir the blood.
The Vice President does have the support of Patricia Shernak, 57, a retired secretary who volunteers for the Salvation Army. She sees in him "a nice, well-meaning young man."
Like most other people on the sidewalks of Peoria, Ms. Shernak did not seem to give a hoot about this campaign finance business.
Mr. Dubicki, the lawyer, said Republicans should stick to economic issues, giving up the fund-raising scandal, as a way to slay Democrats.
"There isn't any hay to be made on this thing," Mr. Dubicki said resolutely. Then he added, with a smile, "Course, I said the same thing about Watergate."

HEADLINE: Industry Disputes U.S. Study On Profits in Tobacco Accord

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Tobacco companies today challenged a Government study that projected soaring industry profits from the proposed settlement of tobacco litigation.
Four of the nation's major cigarette makers said in a report issued today that the Federal Trade Commission used faulty economic analysis as the basis for its assertion that the industry would reap windfall profits of as much as $123 billion from the 25-year settlement as proposed. 
 The companies said cigarette consumption was falling much more rapidly than the commission assumed. In addition, they said, the Government's calculations of the profits the companies make on each package of cigarettes were "simplistic at best."
The result, the companies said, was a "seriously flawed" picture of the industry's financial future.
The report was prepared by economists for Philip Morris Inc.; the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, a subsidiary of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation; the Lorillard Tobacco Company, a subsidiary of the Loews Corporation, and United States Tobacco, a subsidiary of UST Inc. The other major United States tobacco maker, the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, a subsidiary of B.A.T. Industries is preparing a separate study.
The companies were responding to a request from a Senate Democratic panel on tobacco. But the study was designed as well to counter the trade commission study, which received wide publicity when it was released late last month.
The reports by the industry and the commission are both attempts to analyze the $368.5 billion proposal announced in June by cigarette makers and state attorneys general to settle dozens of liability suits against the industry. President Clinton has since rejected major elements of the plan, but it remains the basis for debate on how to resolve tobacco-related legal, regulatory and health issues.
Cigarette makers said market forces and the terms of the proposed settlement would drive cigarette prices up by $1.50 a pack over the next 10 years. That figure is, coincidentally, the same number the Clinton Administration advocates as the price increase necessary to meet the public health goal of reducing smoking by teen-agers by 60 percent over 10 years.
But the companies said that very little of the $1.50 would go to industry profits, as the commission assumed. Rather, the industry said, the money would pay the legal settlement's cost of $15 billion a year, as well as distribution expenses and local, state and Federal taxes.
The cigarette companies said that price increases of that size would reduce overall American tobacco consumption by as much as 43 percent over the next decade, roughly four times as great a reduction as the commission estimated.
But neither Mr. Williams nor the study provided an estimate of the industry's future profits if the current settlement were adopted.
Robert Pitofsky, chairman of the trade commission, acknowledged in an interview that it was difficult to predict prices and profits 25 years in the future.
"They can quarrel with lots of things," Mr. Pitofsky said, "but the important thing is that the debate is now out in the open. It is clear that there is a lot of money left on the table if prices go up $1.50 a pack."

HEADLINE: From Science to Fiction;
Military and Entertainment Industries Swap Expertise

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9

 BODY:
From the time he was a boy, Mike O'Neal wanted to "put something on another planet." He earned degrees in aerospace engineering and then worked for eight years at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, helping design the Mars Pathfinder.
But by the time the spacecraft touched down on the Red Planet in July, Mr. O'Neal, 31, had quit NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory and joined a movie special effects company where his skill in computer-aided design has been applied to tasks like simulated lava flows in "Dante's Peak" and a shipwreck for "Titanic." 
 Call it the military-entertainment complex. The aerospace and entertainment industries, which in the past inhabited parallel universes even as they sat side by side in Southern California, are starting to cross-pollinate, bringing a new level of technology to entertainment and perhaps returning dividends to the Pentagon as well.
With the sharp cutback in military spending since the end of the cold war, some aerospace companies and individual aerospace engineers are seeking their fortunes in the entertainment business. They are applying their expertise to areas like movie special effects and rides for theme parks, casinos and shopping centers.
The flow of engineers, while small, reflects a much larger shift in the Southern California economy. Since 1988, the aerospace and electronics equipment industry -- once the region's largest -- has lost 135,000 jobs in Los Angeles County alone. In the same period, the county's entertainment industry has added 144,000 jobs and become the area's biggest employer. Abandoned aircraft hangars throughout the region are being converted into sound stages.
Another lure is that entertainment technology has become, in some respects, as sophisticated as that in the aerospace industry. Mr. O'Neal noted that a few movies now cost almost as much to make as spacecraft like the $250 million Pathfinder.
A flow in the other direction, though still a comparative trickle, is under way, too, as the Pentagon looks to the entertainment industry for low-cost technology.
The Marine Corps, for example, is beginning to use shoot-'em-up computer games like Doom to help in training. The Metavision Corporation of Burbank, Calif., which sells giant-screen video projection systems to theme parks and theaters, spun off a company to sell the products for military simulators and war rooms.
"Off my desk suddenly went Rolling Stone and Variety and onto my desk came Defense News Weekly," said Theo Mayer, who heads the spinoff, Panoram Technologies Inc. "It was a real culture shock. I'm an ex-hippie."
The National Research Council issued a report late last month saying that the entertainment and defense industries share many technologies related to computer models and simulation and could benefit from greater cooperation.
"You have two different communities that almost never talk to each other," said Anita Jones, a professor at the University of Virginia and a former director of research and engineering for the Department of Defense. "I think it's an exciting juncture."
The trend, however, has its down side for the Pentagon. There is a concern that the nation's brightest minds will be lured away from military work by the excitement of Hollywood.
"If you are a young computer programmer interested in doing state-of-the-art image-processing work, you would probably go to a Disney or a Pixar or a Microsoft rather than a Boeing or Lockheed or General Dynamics," said Bran Ferren, a top research and development official at the Walt Disney Company.
Mr. O'Neal, for instance, is one of four engineers from the Jet Propulsion Laboratory who have joined Digital Domain in Los Angeles in the last two years, frustrated by the shrinking budget and the slow bureaucracy at NASA.
Entertainment work also does not involve making tools of destruction and can offer more glory. Daryll Strauss, a Digital Domain computer programmer, said that at his previous job with a military contractor some projects were so secret he could not breathe a word about them. "It's very different now to have friends say, 'I saw your name in the credits on a film,' " he said.
Much of the technology being exploited by the entertainment industry -- from the Internet to the computer graphics used to make "Toy Story" -- began as university research sponsored by the Pentagon and trickled down over a long time. And there have long been some industry crossovers like the billionaire Howard Hughes, who made movies and started an aerospace company. But such cases were rare.
Now the flow of people and technology is becoming more direct, though it is still far from a mass migration. "I think there is a limited number of people, but the aerospace infrastructure is beginning to serve the entertainment people," said Joel Kotkin, an expert on the Southern California economy at Pepperdine University.
Making the transition is difficult, and some aerospace companies and engineers have found the grass is not always greener in entertainment. For instance, the Hughes Electronics unit of General Motors and Lucasfilm Ltd. abandoned a venture to make theme park attractions based on military simulators when costs became too high.
Some of the areas to which aerospace people are flocking, like virtual reality entertainment and special effects, are not growing as fast as expected and are experiencing business failures. Indeed, two of the four people from the Jet Propulsion Lab who joined Digital Domain lost their jobs Wednesday in a big layoff.
But a larger problem than economics is culture. Military contractors have had a hard enough time moving from making widgets for tanks to making widgets for trucks, let alone to making movies. It is hard to imagine two industries more different in culture and business practice, though both do have a tendency for projects that are late and over budget.
"Even though the technology may be the same, the way the technology is used is so different," said Eric Haseltine, who worked at Hughes Electronics and is now at Disney heading projects developing virtual reality attractions. "One is about storytelling and emotion, and the other is about killing people."
Even though he came from a military contractor, Mr. Haseltine said he was "kind of skeptical when I see an aerospace resume because I know what happens in aerospace companies."
Military contracting has always emphasized capability over affordability. Its detailed specifications and procedures also do not fit well with the more informal Hollywood.
"We needed to teach these folks how to communicate other than by writing mega-documents," said Eddie Ackerman, president of Absolute Post, a post-production company, who trained a dozen laid-off aerospace workers to be television technicians. Mr. Ackerman's solution was ingenious: He took his students to comedy improvisation clubs.
Hollywood workers can have as much trouble going into military contracting. "You can't take a military guy out for a hamburger without breaking the law," said Matt Walton, vice president of Illusion Inc., a company with ties to both both sectors.
Not surprisingly, most of the successful transitions so far are in developing technology, not producing programs. Hughes Electronics established DirecTV, the satellite broadcasting service. Gemstar International, whose VCR Plus system makes video recorders easy to program, was started by engineers who left TRW. Image circuitry developed by Lockheed Martin is used in the Sega Saturn video game machine.
McFadden Systems of Santa Fe Springs, Calif., which makes hydraulic systems that provide motion to simulators, has quadrupled its annual sales to about $10 million by selling to theme parks in addition to the military, said its president, Larry Hayashigawa.
The clash of cultures can be seen at Illusion, a company in Westlake Village, Calif., that was started by former military contractors to pursue entertainment work. On Friday, a simulated Grand Prix racing game designed by the company, in which 24 drivers will race against one another on a computer-simulated virtual track, will open at the Sahara Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev.
Bob Jacobs, the president, worked at Hughes and then at Perceptronics, another military contractor. In the 1980's, he was a key developer of Simnet, a network that ties together hundreds of military simulators around the world over a network so that all participants can take part in the same virtual battle.
It was not long before Dr. Jacobs realized that what he had was good fun as well as good training. At Fort Knox, Ky., servicemen would come back when they were off duty to play some more.
So Dr. Jacobs and Jim McDonough, a colleague at Perceptronics, started Illusion in Mr. McDonough's house in 1989.
At first, Illusion tried to team up with a big aerospace company to build rides. "The chairman of the board listened and asked: 'Where is the system specification for this? Where is the request for proposal?' " Dr. Jacobs recalled.
So Illusion decided to go it alone. But to get more entertainment industry experience, it merged with another start-up company founded by by Peter Beale, a longtime movie executive, and Mr. Walton, a former management consultant. Illusion employees nearly revolted, summoning Dr. Jacobs and Mr. McDonough to a heated meeting after work to question why such Hollywood types were needed.
Executives now say they have merged the two cultures. Borrowing from aerospace, the company uses detailed charts to show the project's timetable. But to assemble the racing cars, it hired movie production assistants, who know how to put together temporary teams to get a job done quickly.
The Sahara attraction is derived from Simnet technology. In front of each car is a huge screen presenting a unique view to each driver. If the blue car passes the yellow car, the yellow car driver will see the blue car pulling away. The cars have hydraulic systems made by a military contractor to provide a realistic feeling of acceleration.
And guess what? The Pentagon has already come calling, wondering whether military simulators could be based on the casino attraction.

HEADLINE: In Answer to Whisper Campaign, Castro Talks for 7 Hours

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Oct. 9

 BODY:
It wasn't so much what Fidel Castro had to say. It was how long he took to say it that has turned out to be the biggest surprise so far of the Cuban Communist Party's first congress in six years.
Since the spring, Cuban exile groups in Miami and diplomats here have been speculating about the supposedly precarious state of Mr. Castro's health. His infrequent public appearances and apparent loss of weight merely added to those rumors, which culminated, to the irritation of the Cuban authorities, in reports in late August that he had died. 
 But on Wednesday morning, afternoon and evening, as if to answer his enemies, Mr. Castro answered the international whispering campaign by delivering a 6-hour, 43-minute extemporaneous opening speech to the party congress.
Then, after a short break that enabled more than 1,500 delegates to catch their second wind, he and they came back and talked some more, well into the night.
In his younger days, Mr. Castro, who turned 71 in August, was famed for making long and dramatic speeches on occasions like May Day or the July 26 anniversary of the founding of his guerrilla movement. His performance on Wednesday harkened back to that period and left many Cubans searching their memories to recall the last time their "maximo jefe" had been so loquacious.
"It was vintage Fidel," a Latin American diplomat here said today, chuckling at the unspoken message Mr. Castro sent about his stamina and concentration. "The dramatic pauses for effect, the pensive look and turn of the head, the way his voice rose and fell to emphasize the points he wanted to make, all the hallmarks of his oratory style were there."
The substance of the speech offered little that was new. Mr. Castro gave few indications of where the party will head, preferring instead to review the tribulations Cuba has experienced since the collapse of the Soviet Union plunged the country into economic crisis. He blamed the United States for most of Cuba's problems.
Since foreign reporters were excluded from the opening speech, exactly what else Mr. Castro had to say is thus far known to few people other than Communist Party delegates. State television has been showing edited excerpts from his speech in delayed broadcasts, and the official Communist Party newspaper Granma today published a three-page, paraphrased version of his remarks.
The party congress, the first since 1991, was scheduled to coincide with the 30th anniversary of the death of Che Guevara, the Argentine-born guerrilla who was executed by Bolivian soldiers on Oct. 9, 1967.
Speaking beneath a banner adorned with portraits of Marx, Lenin, Jose Marti and Guevara, Mr. Castro invoked the example and memory of his former comrade without really referring to his ideas, which are largely in eclipse here.
Guevara and the Cuban Revolution are "the same thing," Mr. Castro said. "I am sure that Che would feel proud of the merits and virtues of the Revolution and feel proud of the bravery and heroism of this, his people," Mr. Castro was quoted as saying in Granma.
At its session today, the congress moved on to consider pressing economic issues, again behind closed doors. Some young technocrats within the party are said to have been urging Mr. Castro to formally embrace and extend some forms of private employment, property and enterprise, but their proposals are reported to have met resistance from so-called historicos, old-line revolutionaries who fought with Mr. Castro.
In one sign of the difficulties with which the party is grappling, Vice President Carlos Lage Davila, the country's top economic official, acknowledged in his presentation to the congress today that economic growth will barely reach 2 percent this year.

HEADLINE: H.M.O. Switches to Flat Fee For Treatment by Specialists

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
One of the country's biggest health maintenance organizations has signed up hundreds of medical specialists to diagnose and treat expensive medical conditions for set fees, rather than piecemeal payments. The move is a sharp departure from industry practice.
Until now, most H.M.O.'s have been billed for each visit and procedure required in the treatment of everything from hip replacement surgery to heart bypass operations, plus additional amounts for diagnostic tests, hospital services and blood-laboratory reports, as well as follow-up care like physical therapy. 
 H.M.O.'s have tried to hold down costs by requiring the specialist to get prior approval at several stages in the treatment and to follow strict guidelines or risk denial of payment. Some H.M.O.'s pay a set monthly fee for each insured member, whether sick or healthy, to California specialty groups and national cancer-center chains.
But now, in a move that industry experts across the country said was a first, Oxford Health Plans, the Norwalk, Conn., giant of managed health care, said it had contracted with more than 700 specialists to take full charge of cases from start to finish. They will be paid a set fee for each case, with added payments as the treatment continues according to an agreed-upon schedule. Oxford will also pick up the costs of extra care if complications develop, the company said. Oxford counts nearly 1.9 million members, mostly in the New York City metropolitan region.
Economists and health care experts said the new approach was the latest development in a trend to give more authority to doctors and replace managed-care restraints that have enraged many doctors, frustrated patients and spurred lawmakers to scrutinize the industry's billing practices.
Critics, however, say the change is a potential threat to the quality of care and could push physicians into a bidding war.
Paying flat fees is supposed to save money without compromising the quality of care, because the specialists will have a reason to be efficient, for example, to eliminate duplicative tests. And indeed, while Oxford is apparently the first to embrace the practice on a large scale, other health care players have been experimenting with it.
The Federal Government, meantime, is exploring the approach. "They hope to do this in a big way with Medicare," said Peter Kongstvedt, a health care expert with Ernst & Young, a consulting firm. Already, Medicare announced last month that it would try out flat fees with six hospital-physician coalitions in New York, New Jersey and southeastern Pennsylvania, including St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J., and Newark Beth Israel Medical Center.
Oxford expects to reduce its costs and it predicts that the system will prod doctors to become more efficient in providing high-quality care. The H.M.O., which enjoys a reputation for health care innovations that have attracted both publicity and new members, plans to use the program as a selling point with customers as well as hospitals and doctors.
Stephen F. Wiggins, chairman of Oxford, said that under the first contracts, the overall payments to specialists would average 15 percent less than the H.M.O. had been paying for similar cases on a fee-for-service basis.
"We designed this new model in response to our physicians' clear desire for more clinical autonomy and less intrustion of the health plan," Mr. Wiggins said.
Later, when the H.M.O. has contracts with more of its 25,000 specialists, the specialty groups will be bidding against each other for Oxford's patronage. "This is a gesture toward managed competition," said an approving Uwe E. Reinhardt, an economics professor at Princeton University. "It's an ingenious alternative."
Some doctors are delighted with the change. "I don't have to get pre-approval if the patient needs additional views or additional study," said Dr. Gillian M. Newstead, director of breast imaging at New York University Medical Center and head of a medical group that has signed up with Oxford. "I can do whatever I think is necessary. It speeds up the patient's treatment and decreases her anxiety."
But others in the medical establishment were sharply critical of the idea, saying it posed a potential threat to the quality of care. "They'll say to doctors in those specialty areas, 'This is all we're going to spend, and you guys have to stay within that fixed sum,' " warned Dr. Charles N. Aswad, executive vice president of the New York State Medical Society.
Moreover, he predicted, going to flat fees was likely to push physicians into a bidding war. "That's a huge issue," he said. "Is this a bottom-line decision by insurance companies with a group of physicians or hospitals, with the care going to the lowest bidder?"
Oxford said its members would still have primary-care doctors, who are paid on the traditional fee-for-service basis, as their advocates. The members can still go to any doctor, including those outside the Oxford network, if they are willing to pay extra. Eventually, Oxford said, employers may offer incentives that would push their people toward the new program.
Many patients might be attracted to the notion that the specialists they are seeing will call all the shots. Under current practices, they are often kept in the dark about who is making decisions, and might not realize that the specialist is repeatedly second-guessed by the health plan on decisions about their care. A breast-cancer patient, for example, may not suspect that her oncologist typically has to request permissions and follow strict guidelines for standard cancer procedures like CT scans, sonograms, surgery, chemotherapy and radiation.
Mr. Wiggins, who recently resigned as chief executive to work on the new payment system, said Oxford had been working on the project for two years. The H.M.O. paid experts like the N.Y.U. Medical Center's Dr. Newstead to define the components and length of each type of case, which it calls an "episode of care."
With the help of computer software programs and outside consultants, Oxford determined the combined dollar amounts it had been paying for each such episode. Todd S. Farha, who is chief executive of the Oxford Specialty Management unit, said the company helped prospective bidders to streamline their organizations and come up with a bid.
For example, he said, Oxford advised breast cancer specialists on the relative cost implications of various types of biopsies. "We don't tell them what the mix should be," Mr. Farha said.
If a patient has several serious medical problems, he or she might choose to go to more than one specialty group. The patient's primary- care doctor would be expected to keep all the doctors informed and to continue to provide care for routine matters and chronic conditions, Mr. Wiggins said.
Oxford controls a bit more than 20 percent of the managed-care market in the metropolitan area, but the specialists it has signed up represent only a fraction of tens of thousands in the region. Doctors are considered specialists if they have advanced training in the diagnosis and treatment of conditions like stroke, hip-and-knee problems, prostate cancer, mental disease, alcohol and drug addiction, blocked heart arteries, kidney disease, and maternity care.
Oxford, which was criticized by a number of hospitals and medical groups earlier this year when it delayed payment on millions of dollars of charges, has since kept competing H.M.O.'s off-balance with a barrage of new types of coverage. For example, it offers coverage of acupuncture and yoga lessons, for groups willing to pay for it.
Many managed-care companies already pay an all-inclusive price for a few types of cases. Aetna U.S. Healthcare, for example, has long had single-price deals with a number of transplant centers across the country, including a year or more of follow-up care. Dr. Arthur Leibowitz, chief medical officer, said Aetna also had two "significant" single-price contracts for hip and knee replacement surgery and was considering "other types of procedures."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Germany Raises Rate, Rattling Financial Markets
Germany's central bank raised a key interest rate for the first time in five years, deflating stocks in Germany, France and other European nations and hurting the dollar.
 
 Though worries about inflation were a factor, economists said Germany had been driven largely by the need to align its relatively low rates with the higher ones in most other European countries as currency union nears. The increase led to similar moves by some of Germany's partners in the currency plan. Page A1.
 
Stocks fell early in American markets, too, but recovered to end mixed as concerns about rising rates in the United States eased. The Dow industrials were down 33.64 points, to 8,061.42, but the Nasdaq composite rose 4.08 points, to 1,745.85. D6.
 
A Poor Month for Retailers
Retailers reported some of the weakest monthly sales of the year, leaving analysts wondering whether bullish predictions for the holidays should be tempered. D2.
 
Healthy Quarter for G.E.
General Electric's third-quarter earnings rose 13 percent, better than expected, on a strong performance by most of the diversified giant's businesses. D6.
 
Campbell Soup in French Deal
Campbell bought Liebig, a French soup brand, for $170 million, part of its strategy to expand overseas. The deal was part of a grocery business divestiture by Danone, France's largest food company. D2.
 
A Break From H.M.O. Fee Practice
Oxford Health Plans has signed up hundreds of medical specialists to diagnose and treat expensive medical conditions for set fees, rather than piecemeal payments, a sharp departure from industry practice. A1.
 
Top Editors at 2 Papers Step Down
Management changes were announced at two big newspapers. The editor of The Los Angeles Times, Shelby Coffey 3d, resigned, to be replaced by a team that will further erode the wall that has traditionally separated the news and business sides at most newspapers. D5.
 
At The Philadelphia Inquirer, Maxwell E. P. King, left, the editor and executive vice president, said that he would resign those posts to become an editorial writer. Mr. King has taken The Inquirer through sometimes painful steps to raise profitability while reversing a downward trend in circulation. D5.
 
N.A.S.D. Proposes Central Market
The N.A.S.D. suggested creating a central market for customer orders in an attempt to generate more competition on the Nasdaq market, a plan that has been criticized by brokerage firm trade groups, which fear that it will narrow dealers' profits and reduce trading volume. D6.
 
Bear Stearns Changes 10-K Filing
Bear Stearns has filed an amended 10-K report with the S.E.C., which differs from the original report in discussing investigations of the A. R. Baron brokerage firm, for which Bear Stearns had cleared trades. D2.
 
Jury Award Against Eddie Bauer
A jury ordered Eddie Bauer to pay $1 million in damages over an incident in which three young black men were detained on suspicion of shoplifting. A16.
 
Jobs May Make It Permanent
Steve Jobs, the Apple co-founder who is currently the struggling company's interim chief executive, said that he was considering dropping the "interim" in his title. D4.

HEADLINE: Top Aides Urge Clinton to Ease Global Warming Emission Goal

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
To the dismay of environmentalists seeking swift action to toughen the international treaty on climate change, President Clinton's senior economic and environmental advisers are urging him to delay until the year 2010 and beyond the time when the United States and other industrial nations must achieve deep new reductions in the pollution that may cause global warming.
Assuming that international negotiations produce such a treaty this year to help control climate change, Mr. Clinton's advisers are warning him not to present it for the Senate's approval unless developing countries first agree, in a separate pact negotiated within the next few years, to control their own emission of greenhouse gases. 
 The advisers' recommendations were described by leaders of several environmental organizations who said they had been briefed on the proposals. White House officials involved in the discussions today refused to discuss their recommendations, which are in an options paper that they expect to give the President as early as Friday.
The options were pieced together after strenuous debate between environmental advisers and economic advisers, who expressed reservations about the potential cost of controlling emissions too quickly.
Among the staff who put together the policy options are Gene Sperling, the President's economic policy assistant; Kathleen McGinty, the head of the Council on Environmental Quality; Todd Stern, a senior aide who is coordinating the policy discussions; and Lawrence Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary.
Outside environmental advocates, including leaders of the Environmental Defense Fund, the Union of Concerned Scientists, the Sierra Club, and the Environmental Information Center, responded to what they heard by warning the White House that they would actively oppose any agreement along the lines that were being recommended.
"It's clear that the President's men have blinked," said Carl Pope, the executive director of the Sierra Club. "It remains to be seen if the President will blink."
Phil Clapp, executive director of the Environmental Information Center, said that for President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore to accept long delays after campaigning against global warming for years would "create severe credibility problems for them on almost any environmental issue."
On the other hand, powerful industry groups have long urged the Clinton Administration to defer action, saying that not enough is yet known about how the climate might change to justify the potential costs in money and jobs that they contend an all out commitment to reduce emissions would require.
For their part, the President's advisers say they are determined to offer a plan that is realistic politically and economically, not just attractive on the environmental merits.
The most aggressive option before the President would call on industrial nations to reduce emissions of the greenhouse gases by 2010, without requiring further reductions. Other options would take even longer to stabilize emissions.
In a treaty signed five years ago in Rio de Janeiro, the United States and other industrial nations said they would try to get emissions reduced, back to the level that existed in 1990, by the year 2000. Most now acknowledge they will not meet that deadline. The United States' emissions are now projected to be 13 percent above 1990 levels by 2000.
Recognizing that the Rio goals were not sufficient to end the rapid accumulation of greenhouse gases that many scientists say threatens to significantly change the earth's climate in the coming century, the nations that signed that treaty have been trying for two years to negotiate a tougher pact that would set new, binding targets and timetables. The negotiations resume in Bonn on Oct. 20 and are supposed to be completed in Kyoto, Japan, in December.
The recommendations to President Clinton come a few days after Japan proposed a schedule that would cut emissions 5 percent below 1990 levels by 2010. The European nations have called for reductions of 15 percent below 1990 levels by that time, and some nations have sought even deeper emissions.
The White House has said it wanted to pursue reductions that would be binding, politically realistic and technically achievable. But so far it has not spelled out specific goals.
One global warming expert who is close to the Administration said there are three main options on the table: one to stabilize emissions at 1990 levels by 2010, one to do so by 2015 or 2020, and one to gradually reduce the growth rate of emissions and to freeze them some day.
But the environmental groups said these options do not represent a binding commitment, because they include an escape mechanism that would limit the amount of money American companies would have to spend to meet any emission targets.
The Administration favors allowing companies to buy and sell emission permits for carbon dioxide, an approach that advocates say would effectively create a marketplace for pollution control ideas and help keep compliance costs down. Companies that come up with cheap controls could sell their permits for a profit.
But out of fear that emissions controls would be prohibitively expensive, the Administration now is considering putting a cap on the price of the permits and guaranteeing to sell additional permits at that price.
"This would spoil the market mechanism and remove the incentives to produce innovations," said Fred Krupp of the Environmental Defense Fund, who favors trading in emissions permits but joined other environmentalists in denouncing the White House's latest options.
"That's absolutely bananas," retorted Raymond Kopp, an analyst at Resources for the Future, an environmental policy center that supports capping the prices of the permits. "It is a way of capping the upper limit on the cost of any policy you might come up with."
Environmental groups who have been calling for steeper reductions on a faster timetable said that they were "increasingly concerned" by reports that the President's aides were recommending further delays.
"Such policies would be totally inconsistent with the gravity and urgency of the global warming threat," said the leaders of 17 environmental organizations in a letter to Mr. Clinton written Wednesday, after White House aides informed them of the options under consideration.
They said they would be "compelled to oppose" a policy that "simply seeks to freeze emissions at 1990 levels by 2010 or later, or that includes a treaty-busting escape clause."

HEADLINE: Two Views of New York

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and his Democratic opponent, Ruth Messinger, defined their basic disagreement last night with perfect clarity. Ms. Messinger sees the glass as half-empty. Mr. Giuliani sees it as pretty much full already. Their debate was a useful portrait of two contrasting analyses of the state of New York City. But it was not the kind of debate likely to drive voters from one candidate to another, and since Mr. Giuliani began in the stronger position, he had more reason to smile at the end.
In this campaign's first mayoral debate, Ms. Messinger repeatedly described a city in which the schools were terrible, the homeless were being ignored, unemployment was endemic and city services were deteriorating. Mr. Giuliani saw a city where crime was plummeting, where services were being delivered more efficiently and where the welfare rolls were shrinking. By listening carefully, voters could actually glean sharp distinctions in the way the two candidates would approach the challenges of the future. 
 On the tactical level, Ms. Messinger's strongest moments came very early. She opened with an attack pointed at the incumbent's greatest vulnerability, his reputation as a mean-tempered autocrat. Later she followed up with a pithy summary: "You do not need to be mean to be tough."
Mr. Giuliani, his famous temper well in check, counterattacked with surprising smoothness, saying that in repeatedly labeling him a "bully" Ms. Messinger was practicing the "name-calling" she condemned in others.
If Mr. Giuliani's prickly personality is his greatest weakness, his record on crime is his armor, and Ms. Messinger had less success there. Challenged about her share of the blame in past Democratic administrations, she wavered. Mr. Giuliani accused her of trying to bury her record while he embraced his. "I believed the city was heading in the wrong direction," he said. "I turned it around."
Mr. Giuliani's weakest response came on the matter of ethics, in which he defended collecting huge amounts of money for his campaign from people doing business with the city and the lobbying activities of key advisers. He blamed his problems with the Campaign Finance Board on legalisms. His argument that in his administration no one needs lobbyists to get the ear of City Hall was disingenuous at best.
For her part, Ms. Messinger struggled to make headway on her key issue of educational quality. She repeated her calls for far more spending on education. Mr. Giuliani said there was already enough money being spent on the schools, and that with his help, it was being redirected from administration to the classroom. He got Ms. Messinger in a box by challenging her to promise to retain the popular Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew.
Ms. Messinger may have made up some of that ground by highlighting Mr. Giuliani's stubborn refusal to endorse the Mollen commission's recommendations for an independent monitor to look at police corruption. Mr. Giuliani indicated he thought the police should police themselves.
It was, on balance, a solid evening of earnest civic work by a worthy challenger facing a strongly positioned incumbent. Ms. Messinger certainly did herself no harm, but as a self-described underdog, she still faces the formidable task defined by an interviewer who asked if life in her neighborhood had improved under Mr. Giuliani. She demurred, but the moment was awkward for her.

HEADLINE: New York Punishes Swiss Bank Over Nazi Gold

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
New York City quietly administered a major sanction against the Union Bank of Switzerland last week by barring it from participating in a billion-dollar bond offering, a move meant to underline disapproval of the way the bank has responded to the investigations into dealings with Nazi Germany, city officials said yesterday.
The action by New York City's Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, was immediately criticized by the State Department, which is attempting to coax Swiss banks to make larger contributions to humanitarian funds for Holocaust survivors and their heirs. 
 Stuart Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of State for economic affairs, said in an interview from Egypt yesterday that New York's action could "further inflame passions in Switzerland" and insisted that "confrontation with the banks will achieve far less than cooperation."
Nonetheless, Mr. Hevesi, who is running for re-election with only token opposition next month, said he would not let Union Bank profit from expanded dealings with the city while its top Swiss officers remain unapologetic for the bank's response to the widening Nazi gold investigations.
New York's action was prompted by a routine request by the city for bids from global banks to handle a $1.075 billion revenue anticipation note, money that the city borrows in anticipation of receiving state and Federal aid for education and welfare expenditures.
The winning bidder was a syndicate of banks led by UBS, which Wall Street experts said would have garnered nearly half of the $1 million fee New York ordinarily pays for "letters of credit" from the banks.
"We were faced with the decision of whether to go ahead and do business as usual, or send a message to Union Bank of Switzerland," said Mr. Hevesi, who protested led the protests earlier this year when the bank dismissed a guard who revealed that the bank's archivist was shredding World War II-era documents, but refused to dismiss its honorary president, who said he thought a Jewish conspiracy lay behind American-led revelations about the banks.
"We decided it would be sending the wrong message to accept the bid," said Mr. Hevesi, who added that the Giuliani administration "had no objection" to excluding UBS.
So before the winning bid was announced, Mr. Hevesi's office approached the second bank in UBS's syndicate, Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, and asked it, Mr. Hevesi said, to "reconfigure the team of banks to exclude UBS." It immediately complied, city officials said, replacing UBS with National Westminster Bank of Britain and Societe Generale of France.
The chief operating officer of UBS Americas Region, Richard C. Capone, who met with Mr. Hevesi late last month in an effort to avoid the sanction, was traveling yesterday, and the company said he was not available to discuss the issue.
But in a statement, Mr. Capone said: "We respect the position of the Comptroller even though we do not agree with it. We are proud of the fact that the Swiss banks are working extremely hard and providing leadership in resolving the World War II dormant account issue fairly, and with sensitivity. We understand it is an emotional and complex issue, and we are committed to understanding the truth and doing what is right."
Mr. Capone also noted that his bank aided the city "in its darkest hour" during the 1975 fiscal crisis.
For months now, New York City and the State Department have been sparring over sharply differing approaches in dealing with the Swiss.
Mr. Hevesi, whose family included a number of Holocaust victims, has repeatedly pressed Swiss firms to declare how much they are contributing to the Holocaust funds and has criticized UBS in particular for its continuing refusal to release copies of the documents rescued by the guard.
Those documents apparently include records of "forced sales" of properties held by Jews in Germany. Swiss prosecutors last week ended the investigation into the actions of the dismissed guard, Christof Meili, who was recently granted permanent residency in the United States to escape what he said were death threats in Switzerland. The prosecutors also ended their investigation into the archivist who ordered the shredding.
The State Department, however, has tried to calm the furor caused by the blistering report it issued in April. That historical study, led by Mr. Eizenstat, documented how Swiss financial cooperation with the Nazis prolonged World War II, and charged that Switzerland knowingly violated a 1946 agreement to turn over billions of dollars in assets that Nazi Germany looted during the war.
Since issuing the report, Mr. Eizenstat has been accentuating the positive, arguing that "sanctions are not justified by the objective steps that Switzerland has taken." In yesterday's interview from Cairo, Mr. Eizenstat said, "I don't question the motives of New York City, but I am concerned that its approach will be counterproductive."
He was referring to the effort by the Swiss Government to get a majority of the public to vote in a national referendum to create a multibillion-dollar humanitarian fund. Polls indicate that the more the Swiss bridle at the criticism focused on their country, the more likely they will defeat the referendum.
While the New York financing deal represents an extremely small percentage of the Union Bank of Switzerland's overall business, the precedent of punishing one of the banks for its response to the Nazi gold investigations is bound to provoke a reaction among the Swiss banks. Mr. Hevesi has been urging financial officers around the country to also focus on Switzerland's actions.
All three major banks have contributed to a "Special fund for Needy Victims of the Holocaust." But they have resisted calls for restitution and particularly objected to suggestions that a 1946 accord requiring the banks to turn over Nazi assets now worth billions, should be enforced a half-century later.
The Union Bank has been targeted because its honorary president, Robert Holzach, told The New Yorker magazine this spring that Jews have long been excluded from top posts in most Swiss banks, and that he suspected that a Jewish conspiracy lay at the heart of the relentless revelations about how the banks dealt with the Nazis. The bank later told Mr. Hevesi it was "distancing itself" from Mr. Holzach's remarks, but the bank took no public action against him.

HEADLINE: Meredith F. Burrill, 94, Expert On World Geographic Names

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Meredith F. Burrill, a toponymist's toponymist who made a name for himself as the world's foremost authority on what people variously -- and sometimes perversely -- call the earth's lakes, rivers, mountains, seas, cities, towns and other physical features and political subdivisions, died on Sunday at a hospital in Washington. He was 94 and had spent 30 years as executive secretary of the United States Board on Geographic Names.
If it seems appropriate that a man named Meredith but called Pete (from the French petit) would master the often confusing world of geographic nomenclature, it was not his idea. 
 Indeed, until he was in his 40's, Dr. Burrill's major claim to fame was that he had been in all 254 Texas counties, a feat he accomplished while assisting Federal efforts to resettle Dust Bowl refugees in a decade he spent teaching geography at Oklahoma A & M University.
The resettlement work led to a job in Washington in 1940 as an economic geographer for the old General Land Office in the Department of Interior, which is where the Secretary of the Interior, Harold L. Ickes, found him happily at work in 1943.
With the war against Japan raising the prospects of large-scale Asian operations, it had fallen to Mr. Ickes to solve a daunting problem: converting thousands of place names listed only in Japanese, Chinese or other unfamiliar scripts into the Roman alphabet for military maps.
Mr. Ickes got the job because his department supervised the Board of Geographic Names, a sleepy little office that had virtually withered away since it was founded in 1890 to standardize American place names.
Dr. Burrill got the job as the beefed-up board's executive secretary because he was the only qualified geographer in the Interior Department.
Not that Dr. Burrill was especially qualified in the study of place names, or toponymy, a field, to be sure, that barely existed before he came along.
A peripatetic school superintendent's son, he was born in Houlton, Me., and grew up in a series of Maine towns, without any particular interest in geography.
Indeed, he set out to study history and government, but at Bates College an inspiring teacher who took his students on field trips discoursing on the origin of various rocks and mineral deposits, left Dr. Burrill with such a passion for knowing everything there was to know about the earth that he switched to geography.
At Clark University in Worcester, Mass., he got a master's and doctorate, studying at the feet of the master, Wallace Atwood, who had transformed Clark into a world renowned center of geographic studies.
If Dr. Burrill had not paid much attention to place names before 1943, he did not waste much time in becoming the world's leading expert.
Under his direction a staff of 175 experts in geography, linguistics, languages and map-making identified and translated some two million Asian place names. After the war, Dr. Burrill supervised a board of experts from nine Federal agencies charged with establishing standard names for all Federal maps and publications.
Seeing the importance of common international standards, Dr. Burrill helped persuade the United Nations to establish a series of international conferences to prod countries to standardize their own place names, a task whose complications were underscored when the first conference was held on Lake Geneva, a body of water with four official names.
Even after he retired in 1973, Dr. Burrill represented the United States at the United Nations and continued one of his cherished projects, analyzing the distribution of 2,000 generic names applied to a handful of geographic features on American maps. In a world where one man's brook is another woman's creek, Dr. Burrill traced entire ethnic migrations simply by plotting which terms were used where, finding, for example, Louisiana-style bayous in Indiana.
Although much of his work focused on established names, Dr. Burrill got a chance to do a little naming himself in Antarctica. He was thwarted when he tried to name a sea after President Roosevelt and a mountain range after Secretary Ickes, but he managed to leave his mark, anyway. There is a Mount Burrill in Antarctica, though his friends can be forgiven if they call it Pete.
Dr. Burrill, whose first wife died in 1978, is survived by his wife, Betty Didcoct Burrill of Bethesda, Md.; a son, Robert, of Pensacola, Fla.; a daughter, Elizabeth Allard of Newburyport, Mass.; two grandsons and five great grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Meredith F. Burrill.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Lighter Side Of the Mayor: Can It Last?

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
DURING the summer, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sent over a photo after this column had suggested that he give himself and everyone else a break by taking a few days off, for a change. To show that he does know how to enjoy himself, he had a messenger (not to be confused with a Messinger) deliver a photo of him with his Parks Commissioner at the newly restored Astoria Pool in Queens.
There they were, grinning widely, leis around their necks, and hands gripping a large drink with a little umbrella. "Having a great time," the Mayor wrote in bold ink. "Wish you were here with us." 
 It was a nice touch, and it showed that he does have a sense of humor, as people who have spent private time with him say. But it also raised a question, and not for the first time: Why does this puckish side rarely surface in public?
That might not seem like the most pressing issue as Election Day nears. But it touches on an aspect of this Mayor that has long unsettled New Yorkers, including many who plan to vote for him. It came up right away in the first mayoral debate last night, when his Democratic challenger, Ruth W. Messinger, wasted no time calling him a bully and someone who "tears people apart."
SHE knew that this was one of his weak spots. New Yorkers may respect the Mayor and may feel that on the whole he has done a good job. But an awful lot of them also do not like him one bit.
The highly regarded Quinnipiac College Polling Institute surveyed New Yorkers in the last days of September and reported that this race is in the bag for him. Voters pronounced themselves satisfied with the way the city is going, and by a vast majority they described him as someone who can get things done.
But when asked whether they thought that the Mayor had "a likable personality," more than half said no, a result consistent with the findings of a poll in The New York Times earlier this year. More often than not, voters also faulted Mr. Giuliani for not working well with other political leaders, a matter of significance for someone whose success may depend on the kindness of strangers in Washington and Albany.
The personality issue hovered relentlessly in the air in the debate last night.
Sure, the dominant matters were crime, public schools, economic development and the like. But the Mayor clearly felt that he had to show he can be an ordinary Joe and not just a verbal abuser. He has hardly softened his image with campaign commercials and pronouncements that all but call Ms. Messinger a porno queen and a coddler of killers. Just the other day, he stopped a step short of blaming her for the Dodgers' having skipped town in 1957, when she was a teen-ager.
Instead, the Mr. Giuliani that New York 1 viewers got to see last night was gentler, if not always kinder. He did not put down questions as hopelessly silly. His usual tendency in news conferences is to wave off almost any challenge as something that could be spawned only by a person who is corrupt, politically backward or plain dumb.
LAST night, though, he was a study in calm, refusing to rise to Ms. Messinger's bait as she described the difference between them this way: "I listen. He bullies."
He managed to tell a joke or two, and even kidded with an El Diario reporter whom he had wanted bounced from a panel of journalist questioners.
Bully? That, he said, is something that his opponent "consistently calls me and then claims that I call names."
It is hard to imagine that Mr. Giuliani can keep his abrasive side in check forever. It is also arguable how much should be made of it. But it is hard not to wonder how long voter good will toward him will last if the crime rate starts nudging back up or if Wall Street's boom goes bust, proving that New York's economy is every bit as fragile as Ms. Messinger has warned all along.
Because term limits will force Mr. Giuliani out by 2002, no matter what, unlikability may not catch up with him right away. But he is presumed to be interested in higher office. And character has a way of becoming destiny. He might consider what can happen to a politician when things suddenly go wrong and people remember that they never cared much for him to begin with. Richard M. Nixon comes to mind.
"Likability matters to politicians," said Maurice Carroll, the Quinnipiac polling director. "They all like to be liked."
By the way, about that photo at the Astoria Pool? It probably should have been mentioned that the Mayor went there in a dark business suit.
Guess he has a way to go before he entirely loosens up.

HEADLINE: Muslims Win Vote in Town That Serbs 'Cleansed'

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
In a result from municipal elections last month that could complicate Western peacekeeping efforts, Bosnian Muslims won political control of Srebrenica, the town in eastern Bosnia where thousands of Muslims had been expelled and massacred in one of the darkest episodes of the Balkan war, election monitors announced yesterday.
Voting nearly exclusively by absentee ballots, the Bosnian Muslims elected candidates from the governing coalition led by the Bosnian Muslim Party for Democratic Action, outvoting Bosnian Serbs who moved into the area over the last two years. The party's candidates won control of 24 of the 46 seats on the ruling town council in Srebrenica, the election monitors said. 
 Under the terms of the 1995 Dayton peace accord, the Bosnian Muslim party should now be able to choose a new town mayor and to assume full control of the municipal government.
Officials of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which oversaw the elections, have said in the past that local authorities who refused to put into effect the result of the elections would be denied economic aid.
But Western observers said that enforcing the election victory -- which would mean the Bosnian Serbs giving up control of a town they took by force -- would be close to impossible, barring a strong show of force by NATO troops responsible for overseeing the peace accords. The area around Srebrenica is patrolled by American forces.
Before the outbreak of the 3 1/2-year war in Bosnia, Srebrenica's population was 70 percent Muslim and 30 percent Serbian. As many as 7,000 Muslim men are believed to have died in ambushes and mass executions carried out by Bosnian Serb soldiers in July 1995.
Srebrenica is now inhabited by only Serbs and local Serbian leaders who have vowed to violently block efforts by Bosnian Muslims to return to their homes.
Srebrenica was the only municipality in Serb-controlled territory where Muslim parties managed to gain a majority, according to the election results.
Muslim parties won a plurality of the vote in the northwest town of Prijedor, the wartime site of Serb-run detention camps where Muslim prisoners were systematically tortured and executed. Serbian parties could yet control the Prejidor council if they agree to form a coalition, Reuters reported.
Momcilo Cvjetinovic, leader of the nationalist Serbian Democratic Party in Srebrenica, pledged before the election not to allow Bosnian Muslims to regain control of the town, Agence France-Presse reported yesterday.
"If they come back," Mr. Cvjetinovic said, "the first night we'll fight."
Mr. Cvjetinovic's party won 12 city council seats in the municipal elections, according to press reports. The Serbian Radical Party won eight.
Srebrenica itself has become a symbol of the failure of the United States and its Western allies to carry out the Dayton peace accords. Two years after the town fell to Bosnian Serbs, Western officials have yet to exhume about two-thirds of the mass graves that surround the town and that are believed to hold the bodies of thousands of Muslim men.
The delays in the exhumations have been attributed to the slow pace of donations from Western countries to finance them, and to bureaucratic snagsat the International War Crimes Tribunal.
The former Bosnian Serb President, Radovan Karadzic, and the former Bosnian Serb Army commander Ratko Mladic, who were indicted by the War Crimes Tribunal for carrying out the Srebrenica executions, remain at large. Srebrenica's local Serbian leaders are believed to be tightly controlled by Dr. Karadzic.
