HEADLINE: RACE FOR CITY HALL: THE OVERVIEW;
Sharp Exchanges Pepper Debate Between Giuliani and Messinger

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger battled last night about where New York City has been during the last decade, its current condition, and where the next Mayor should lead it. The 90 minutes of often harsh exchanges gave voters the first opportunity to measure the two candidates on the same stage.
The Republican Mayor and his Democratic challenger -- in the first of two debates before the Nov. 4 election -- used the televised forum on New York 1 to sum up for voters the cases they have been making against each other for nearly a year. In the process, they offered a sharp contrast in both style and ideas.
Ms. Messinger turned nearly every question into an assault, repeatedly criticizing Mr. Giuliani as she tried to focus the debate on what she described as the failings of his first four years, while also describing some of her proposals. Excerpts, page B4.
"Rudy and I are different in more ways than you can count," she said. "I will fix our schools; he cut them. I will build our health care system; he tried to sell it off. I worked to write this city's campaign finance laws; he breaks them. I will give our teachers a fair wage first; he gave pay raises to himself and his staff first."
Mr. Giuliani was studious and good humored, for the most part following the advice of his staff as he laughed off harsh questions and compared the current state of the city to its condition four years ago, linking Ms. Messinger at every opportunity to the man he replaced, David N. Dinkins.
"Ruth Messinger prefers the policies of the Dinkins administration, of the four years before I came into office: wants to go back to most of them," he said. "I prefer the progress that we've made together as a city, that now is having us written about as a national model rather than the rotting apple."
Even with such exchanges -- and there were many -- the candidates covered a fairly large amount of policy ground, laying out dramatically different visions of the condition of New York City today.
Ms. Messinger painted a picture of a city in disrepair, pointing to schools that are overcrowded, children who are not learning, poor people who are not being fed, and homeless people who are still living in the street.
Mr. Giuliani portrayed a city that had, under his stewardship, recovered from a Democratic era in which its streets were plagued with crime, and when jobs and the middle class were fleeing. Mr. Giuliani said that his emphasis on crime prevention and restoring the city's fiscal health had led to the recovery, and warned that bad times could return if Democrats retook City Hall.
Both Ms. Messinger and Mr. Giuliani gave even, measured performances. But the debate was peppered with often sharp exchanges, and there was no warmth apparent between the two main contestants in what has been one of the less suspenseful New York mayoral contests in a decade. The candidates did not even shake hands at the end.
As a matter of history, debates tend not to affect the outcome of elections, and there was apparently nothing about last night's event to suggest that this one would break that pattern.
The debate at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem was arranged by the Campaign Finance Board. The candidates are required to participate in two debates as a condition of receiving public funds from the board. A third candidate, Olga Rodriguez of the Socialist Workers Party, who is also participating in the public financing program, took part as well.
Throughout the debate, Ms. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, turned frequently to the Mayor, who was seated at her left, to try to engage him in discussion. She even tried to ease the obvious tension with a joke at her own and his expense: "One thing is for sure: When you look at the two of us, you know this election isn't a beauty contest."
It did not work. Mr. Giuliani for the most part avoided Ms. Messinger's gaze, playing to the panelists and the camera more than to his opponent, thumbing through papers, writing notes to himself and smiling frequently, again taking his counselors' advice. While Ms. Messinger called her opponent "Rudy," he referred to her formally as "Ms. Messinger."
Ms. Messinger went on the attack from her opening statement, describing Mr. Giuliani's tenure as flawed and his programs as damaging to the city's homeless, its poor and its schoolchildren. She called him a bully, a Republican -- she meant it as an insult -- and, at one point, paranoid.
"I listen, he bullies," Ms. Messinger said. "I bring people together. He tears people apart. I care about people. He cares a lot more about himself."
She added: "You don't have to be mean to be tough. A lot of times, Rudy, I don't think you know the difference. I do care. And he doesn't."
That was perhaps the only time that Mr. Giuliani turned to his opponent. "This is an important discussion of the future of New York City," Mr. Giuliani said. "And I'm going to try to keep it on issues and I'm going to try to keep it on the things that are really important to people -- rather than personal, negative attacks."
The Mayor rattled off statistics about the decrease in crime as he tried to warn that Ms. Messinger "represents really a kind of way-out fringe of the Democratic Party."
"The fact is that she does prefer the policies and programs of the prior administration -- the Dinkins administration -- over the policies and programs of this administration," he said. "If you want to turn back, fine. But don't pretend you want to move to the future."
Ms. Messinger called the attacks on her past irrelevant. "He talks about the past; I'll talk about the future," she said.
The extent of their different views of the world came when Ms. Messinger, who lives in an apartment on Central Park West, said in response to a question that her quality of life today had gotten no better in the last four years.
Mr. Giuliani's eyebrows shot up. "Well, it has for most other people in New York," the Mayor said.
The two candidates introduced a few new issues in this forum. Mr. Giuliani spoke of Ms. Messinger's opposition to the death penalty, asking if she would -- as he had -- urge judges to impose executions in cases of the murder of a police officer.
Ms. Messinger replied: "I support life in prison without parole for criminal offenses of that nature. I am morally opposed to the death penalty. I believe it is wrong for the state to take another person's life."
Mr. Giuliani seemed to acknowledge one of Ms. Messinger's main complaints about the city, saying that the unemployment rate was too high. "Do I think that 9 1/2 percent is healthy?" he asked. "Do I look crazy? No, of course I don't think it's healthy."
But as he did repeatedly throughout the night, he said the blame lay not with him, but with his Democratic predecessor: "The fact is that unemployment was higher, however, before I came into office."
The two candidates disagreed about Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew as they questioned each other during the debate. "I would ask Ms. Messinger whether she would make the commitment to keep on Rudy Crew and support him," the Mayor said.
Ms. Messinger said: "My beef is not with Rudy Crew's performance. It is with Rudy Giuliani's performance in education." Ms. Messinger said she needed to know whether Dr. Crew would support her educational proposals, including measures to reduce school overcrowding and set performance standards for teachers, principals and students.
"And because you do not allow anyone who works for you to say anything to anybody without your permission," Ms. Messinger said to snickering from the audience, "I need to wait until I can have a conversation with Rudy Crew to know where he stands on that."
Mr. Giuliani turned to the camera: "One of the reasons why people in this country distrust politicians is because they don't answer questions. And that isn't an answer to the question. Rudy Crew has been the Chancellor for two years. We know what he is doing."

SECTION: Section B; Page 4; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1674 words

HEADLINE: RACE FOR CITY HALL;
Candidates in Mayoral Race Touch on Education, Gangs and Unemployment

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks made in a debate last night by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his Democratic challenger, Ruth W. Messinger, as transcribed by The New York Times.
 
Opening Statements
 
 MESSINGER When you look at the two of us, you know this election isn't a beauty contest. It is seriously a contest between two candidates with different styles and different priorities. You'll see a lot of evidence of that tonight. I listen, he bullies. I bring people together. He tears people apart. I care about people. He cares a lot more about himself. 
 Rudy Giuliani is actually a man who fired his Police Commissioner because he was getting too much credit for the city's drop in crime. I'd have given Bill Bratton a medal. Rudy gave him the boot. You don't have to be mean to be tough. A lot of times, Rudy, I don't think you know the difference.
 
 GIULIANI This is an important discussion of the future of New York City, and I am going to try to keep it on issues, and I am going to try to keep it on the things that are really important to people, rather than personal negative attacks. Four years ago, I ran for mayor of New York City because I thought this city was in a crisis. We had gone through a period of time in which we had more murder each year than at any other prior year in the history of this city. We were averaging 2,000 murders a year. We had lost 320,000 private sector jobs; jobs were hemorrhaging out of the city. And our school system was in a crisis. . . .
I believe that we have made a turnaround. I believe that New York City in a number of areas is now showing remarkable success. That doesn't mean that we have solved all problems. That doesn't mean that we still don't have horrendous and very difficult problems to face. But I think that we face it from success, not trying to destroy the city, or to destroy the success that it has, for partisan political reasons.
 
On the Past
 Mr. Giuliani said that you share the blame for the city's problems under past Democratic administrations. Do you?
 
 MESSINGER This election is about the future and not the past. It's not which issues I took what position on in the time that I was privileged to be in the City Council or serve as Borough President. It's what I will do to address the problems that are not yet getting nearly sufficient attention in this city.
We have a million schoolchildren in this city, reading -- more than half of them -- not at grade level. We have schools that have become grossly overcrowded because of this Mayor's $6 billion cut. What we need to worry about is what positions each of us will take to solve those problems that plague us for the future. . . .
 
 GIULIANI Well, it seems to me that Ms. Messinger didn't answer the question. And the fact is that she does prefer the policies and programs of the prior administration, the Dinkins administration, over the policies and programs of this administration. You have a right to have that view, people do. She's running away from it. And to say that your record is not up for examination on what you have done in the past when you run for mayor is really entirely unrealistic. . . .
 
On School Crowding
 
 MESSINGER I have indicated very clearly that I believe my top priority is education. My first priority will be to go school by school and district by district to reduce school overcrowding. And I have identified where there is a $1 billion saving in operating the government of this city to fund the additional teachers, the additional lease space, the additional construction space that we need to give our children a fair start in developing the skills they need, which I promise you they are not getting today in many -- too many -- schools in this city.
 
 GIULIANI What we will do to lower class size is to continue, as we move to school-based budgeting, to get the money to the classrooms and the schools. There's enough money in the school system. There always has been. Nine billion dollars is a lot of money. The problem with the school system was the need to restructure it. The money wasn't going to the students. The money wasn't going to the teachers. The money was going to the out-of-control bureaucracy. Part of my frustration with the first Schools Chancellor when I was in office was that he wasn't doing enough to change it.
 
On the Schools Chancellor
 
 GIULIANI I would ask Ms. Messinger whether she would make the commitment to keep on Rudy Crew and support him. I think that Rudy Crew is doing an excellent job as the Chancellor of the City of New York. I think that the school system needs continuity. And when I listen to her answer this question, I hear her talk about interviewing him and trying to figure out what his policies and programs are. They are pretty apparent. So I would like to see her support Rudy Crew as the Chancellor, to keep him on, to keep him for the next three to four years, whatever the term is that he has, at least so that there can be continuity in the school system.
 
 MESSINGER My beef is not with Rudy Crew's performance. It is with Rudy Giuliani's performance in education. In fact, it is the case that reading scores are unfortunately more than a percentage point lower now than when you came into office. In fact, it is true that we have a severe overcrowding problem. . . . What I want is a Chancellor who will implement the plan that I've laid out, point by point: the plan to reduce overcrowding, the plan to do a pilot project in year-round schooling, the plan to set standards for kids and principals and teachers, and hold them accountable to those standards, the plan to invest real dollars in the professional development of our teachers.
And because you do not allow anyone who works for you to say anything to anybody without your permission, I need to wait until I can have a conversation with Rudy Crew to know where he stands on that.
 
On Crime and Street Gangs
 
GIULIANI The fact is there is a very big difference between my opponent and me on dealing with crime. It was illustrated just yesterday when I described a massive program to deal with the youth gangs, criminal youth gangs in the city. She criticized me because she said that we should have more youth programs. Well, maybe she really doesn't understand who these youth gangs are. I don't think that youth programs will help the Bloods, the Crips, the Latin Kings, the Zulu Nation, MS13. These are gangs that begin in jail and in prison. These are violent repeat career criminals and I don't think that giving them sewing lessons is going to help.
So we have a major disagreement about how you approach crime. I believe that social programs are important: they are valuable, they can help. But when you are dealing with hardened criminals like the members of the Bloods, the Crips, the Latin Kings and the Zulu Nation, it is almost an inappropriate thing to start talking about youth programs for them.
 
 MESSINGER The Mayor's comments are trivial and deliberately designed to misrepresent my position. His police initiative against gangs make sense. But the gangs are preying on our young people, they are recruiting among 300,000 kids who have been pushed out of after-school programs. If you travel the whole city and listen and talk to parents as I do, that's what they tell you. "What are we going to do about these gangs that are showing up in my playground, in my kid's school and telling my kid, 'here's something you can do after school'?"
Last week the Mayor went to Boston to talk about his fight against drugs. Last week, for kids who might be moved into the drug life, additional after-school programs made sense. Apparently it makes sense when he proposes it but not when I propose it.
 
On Unemployment
 Ms. Messinger said that you thought 9.5 percent unemployment was a sign of the city's economic health. Do you? And why is the city's rate twice the national average?
 
 GIULIANI Do I think that 9 1/2 percent is healthy? Do I look crazy? No, of course I don't think it's healthy. The fact is that unemployment was higher, however, before I came into office. It was 10.5 percent, 11 percent, 11 1/2 percent and there are things that are happening that are rectifying that. We went through a disaster between 1989 and 1993: we lost 320,000 private sector jobs. We hadn't had a job loss like that since the Depression. We have made up 170,000 of those jobs. Just to get back to where we were, there's 150,000 more jobs to go. And we lost those jobs because of policies and programs that were antibusiness, that were antijobs, that drove jobs out of this city.
We turned that around. This year we have gained more jobs than at any time in the last 13 years. We have gained more jobs in the last four years in the private sector than at any time in the history of this city, but we are coming out of a big hole. And I want to be mayor for the next four years because I am not going to rest until we get every single job back that we lost during the Dinkins administration.
 
 MESSINGER Let's be clear. The Mayor and his First Deputy Mayor both said rising unemployment is a sign of economic optimism. But in New York State and in the United States, where employment numbers are going up, unemployment is not, so the problem is specific to the City of New York. We have another specific unemployment problem -- two-thirds of the private sector jobs that have been created have gone to people from the suburbs, because New Yorkers turn out not to have the skills that are needed because they are being mis-educated in our schools and in our colleges. This city needs a mayor now, in 1997, with an economic development program that is more than just corporate welfare, a program, like the one I laid out yesterday, that will target small businesses, that will build job linkages for those businesses that are receiving city contracts, that will cut some business taxes, that will supply some easier access to credit.

HEADLINE: Israelis, Arafat and Jordanian King Feuding

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 9

 BODY:
The aftermath of a bungled assassination attempt in Jordan continued to send shockwaves through Israeli politics today, with Foreign Minister David Levy saying he had considered resigning, and Yasir Arafat complaining that King Hussein was meddling in Israeli-Palestinian affairs.
But there were also signs that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's early morning meeting with Mr. Arafat on Wednesday, their first since February, had injected some new life into the moribund negotiating process. 
 A joint Israeli-Palestinian committee on economic cooperation held its first meeting today in seven months; the committee is one of several that were revived in the wake of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's intervention last month.
There were also reports, unconfirmed by Israel, that Mr. Netanyahu was prepared to release the remaining $50 million in withheld taxes owed the Palestinian Authority. Israel froze the funds, which account for the bulk of the Authority's income, after a suicide bombing in Jerusalem on July 30. Responsibility for the bombing was taken by the militant Islamic group Hamas, which Mr. Netanyahu said the Palestinian authority had not done enough to restrain. The release of the money was one of the gestures Mrs. Albright pressed for during her visit.
The actual content of the Netanyahu-Arafat meeting was not made public. Dennis Ross, the American mediator who arranged it and also sat in on part of the session, said before leaving Israel that the Israeli and Palestinian leaders saw their meeting as a "new beginning for the process."
Israeli attention, however, remained riveted on the fallout of the botched attempt by a Mossad hit squad to kill a Hamas leader in Amman. The operation compelled Israel to release the most senior figure in the militant Islamic movement, Sheik Ahmad Yassin, and a host of other Palestinian prisoners, to secure the release of two Mossad agents captured by Jordan.
Foreign Minister Levy, who was briefly hospitalized with chest pains on Tuesday, publicly assailed the operation in a radio interview, and declared that he had seriously considered resigning over this and a growing list of other complaints against Mr. Netanyahu.
"If I had been consulted, I would not have let it happen," he said. Already before the fiasco, Mr. Levy was infuriated when Mr. Netanyahu released news of a pending agreement with the Palestinians to reopen the talks while Mr. Levy was still in New York negotiating the deal.
Mr. Levy has repeatedly expressed frustration over Mr. Netanyahu's forays into foreign policy behind the Foreign Ministry's back, and he has hinted at resignation more than once before. As head of the small Gesher party, he controls seven seats in the ruling coalition.
Mr. Netanyahu maintained the aggressive stance he has taken since the latest crisis broke, displaying no remorse over the bungled operation and insisting such methods will continue. "The war against terrorism is not a war of arguments while sitting at home," he told followers in the Likud party in Tel Aviv. "It is a very difficult war with risks and casualties."
In Amman, King Hussein just as forcefully insisted, "We won't accept this form of behavior ever." In a speech before leaders of his Government on Wednesday, the King challenged Mr. Netanyahu's statement that he would not apologize for the operation, revealing that the Prime Minister himself had come to Amman on the night of Sept. 28, three days after the assassination attempt, with Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai and Infrastructures Minister Ariel Sharon.
King Hussein refused to meet with Mr. Netanyahu, and sent Crown Prince Hassan instead. "They arrived full of regret and upset that Jordan had been treated this way, and promised that such a thing would never happen again," the King said. Mr. Sharon subsequently returned to seal the exchange of Sheik Yassin for the captured Mossad agents.
King Hussein also said that two days before the Israeli operation, he had forwarded what he described as a cease-fire proposal from Hamas to the Israelis. Officials in Mr. Netanyahu's Government said they received the message only the day after the attack.
There were reports that King Hussein's role in the entire affair had angered Mr. Arafat, who has always viewed the Jordanian monarch as a rival for authority over the Palestinians. Addressing a closed meeting of the Palestinian Legislative Council in Ramallah, Mr. Arafat was reported to have alleged that King Hussein was seeking to forge an alliance with Hamas, and to "interfere" in Palestinian negotiations with Israel.

HEADLINE: Greenspan's Jawing Gets The Job Done For the Fed

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
The economy would seem to be right where Alan Greenspan wants it. Growth, while still robust, shows signs of moderating. Unemployment is low. Inflation is almost nonexistent.
Yet Mr. Greenspan, who as chairman of the Federal Reserve helped create those conditions, felt compelled on Wednesday to peddle some gloom. In testimony to the House Budget Committee, he warned that a resurgence in inflation might be lurking just around the corner if strong growth drives unemployment lower and pushes wages up. And he gave Wall Street a kick in the teeth, proclaiming that the bull market of the last few years cannot last forever. 
 He got support for his warning on inflation today from a Government report that new claims for unemployment insurance were lower than expected, fueling concerns that the pool of available workers had gotten so small that companies could soon have trouble filling positions, causing wages to rise. And the decisions today by central banks in Germany, France and other European nations to raise interest rates despite having economies far weaker than the United States showed that policy makers worldwide are deeply worried about inflation.
Still, Mr. Greenspan seemed intent on accomplishing goals far more specific than just giving voice to a central banker's ingrained pessimism. His comments, analysts said, were designed to talk down stock prices, talk up interest rates and reassure his colleagues on the Federal Reserve that he remained the nation's most vigilant inflation fighter.
Mr. Greenspan's primary goal, analysts said, was to let some air out of the stock market, which by some measures had been hitting new highs in the days before his testimony and seemed poised to shoot up higher. After sliding on Wednesday after his remarks, stocks were mixed today.
Although stock prices do not directly affect the economy, most economists believe that a bull market makes people feel wealthier and encourages them to spend more. With unemployment already low at 4.9 percent, economists said that any further pickup in demand caused by a booming market could tilt the economy into an inflationary danger zone.
"This unfettered financial market optimism began to worry him," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey Lanston & Company, a securities firm. "If you get too much optimism in the financial markets it puts additional wind at the back of the real economy, and that's dangerous when it happens at a time of full employment."
But in raising the specter of inflation, Mr. Greenspan may have been speaking as much to the bond market as to the stock market. The Fed chairman is a proven master at convincing the bond market to do some of the Fed's work by pushing up market-based interest rates even when the Fed is not raising the official rates it controls.
After a series of economic reports last week showed that the economy was cooling off slightly from its torrid 4 percent growth rate of the first half of the year, investors had concluded that there was little possibility of any rate increase by the Fed at least until next year -- and that there was even some possibility that the Fed's next move might be to lower rates.
As a result, bond prices jumped, pushing market-determined interest rates -- which move inversely with bond prices -- down to their lowest levels since early last year. Mr. Greenspan, economists said, wanted to halt the slide in interest rates, or better, to push rates higher at a time when the Fed is concerned about inflation but has no political cover or strong economic case for tightening monetary policy on its own.
"He's trying to get the market to do the Fed's work because the Fed doesn't have the provocation or the latitude to tighten on their own," said Roseanne M. Cahn, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston.
The bond market responded to Mr. Greenspan by sending rates up sharply on Wednesday, although rates declined a bit today on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond after the Fed's vice chairwoman, Alice M. Rivlin, said the central bank did not yet know whether it would need to raise rates.
Within the Fed, Mr. Greenspan remains by far the dominant voice on monetary policy. The central bank's policy-making committee has backed Mr. Greenspan's unwillingness to be bound by the longstanding assumption that unemployment below about 5.5 percent combined with growth in excess of about 2.2 percent is a sure-fire recipe for inflation.
Mr. Greenspan has been proved right so far, since inflation is nowhere to be found. And his willingness to take the risk has underscored the belief that Mr. Greenspan believes the economy's capacity for noninflationary growth is being improved, albeit haltingly, by huge investments in technology and an attendant improvement in productivity, or the output of a worker for a period of time worked.
But Mr. Greenspan's flirtation with the idea of a "new era" economy has put him in a different camp from the economic traditionalists within the Fed, led by Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor. The traditionalists continue to believe that unemployment below 5.5 percent or so, combined with strong growth, will lead to an upturn in inflation.
In his testimony Wednesday, Mr. Greenspan made clear that while he might not agree with the traditionalists in every detail, he continued to accept the core of their argument: that the current combination of low unemployment and strong growth would ultimately send wages and prices higher, and that it remained unclear whether the economy was slowing sufficiently on its own to avoid such an outcome.
Some analysts said it was possible that Mr. Greenspan had decided to show his more hawkish side on inflation to avoid finding himself out of step with the traditionalists if signs of rising prices do begin appearing in coming weeks and months. The next test will be Friday when some economists expect the Producer Price Index for September to show some evidence of inflationary pressures.

Jobless Claims Fall
 (By The Associated Press) -- The number of new claims for jobless benefits remained below 310,000 last week for a fourth straight week, the longest such string in nearly nine years, the Labor Department reported yesterday. Claims unexpectedly fell by 5,000 -- analysts had expected an increase of 2,000 -- to a seasonally adjusted 304,000, the lowest in more than two months. The four-week average of claims fell by 2,000, to 306,750.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chrysler Profit Down 35%, A Little Better Than Feared

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation's earnings fell 35 percent in the third quarter, to $441 million, as the company prepared for the introduction of several new models while running out of the old ones.
The earnings were slightly better than analysts had feared. Chrysler further cheered Wall Street by announcing today that it would buy back an additional $2 billion of its stock by the end of next year. 
 The No. 3 auto maker's earnings of $441 million, or 65 cents a share, came on $13.2 billion in sales in the third quarter, down from $680 million, or 93 cents a share, on $14.4 billion in sales in the quarter a year earlier. Wall Street had expected Chrysler to earn 58 cents a share in the third quarter, according to a survey of analysts by First Call Inc. The earnings were dampened by a $41 million pretax charge for discontinuing the Eagle line at the end of the 1998 model year.
Just this week, Chrysler began selling its new sport utility vehicle, the Dodge Durango, which is expected to prove popular because of its aggressive design and size -- it is larger than the Ford Explorer and the Jeep Grand Cherokee. Two redesigned sedans, the Dodge Intrepid and the Chrysler Concorde, go on sale this fall. Dealers have been running short of the 1997 Intrepid and Concorde in the meantime. Chrysler is also selling a new four-door Dodge Ram pickup truck, and a new luxury version of the Jeep Grand Cherokee.
Analysts are counting on Chrysler's new cars and trucks to increase profit. "The new products will add $1 a share" to Chrysler's earnings next year, said Scott F. Merlis, president of Merlis Automotive International, an independent automotive research firm in Westport, Conn. Each Durango the company sells should bring in thousands of dollars in profit.
Third-quarter earnings were also hurt by the costly rebates and subsidized lease offers that Chrysler and most other auto makers have been using to keep sales strong. Chrysler's incentives reached $1,140 for each vehicle in the third quarter, up from $685 in the corresponding period a year earlier.
Gary C. Valade, the chief financial officer, said he expected incentives to remain in the $900-to-$1,100 range for some time, and noted that the increase in incentive spending accounted for about 40 percent of the third-quarter earnings decline.
Even today, Chrysler announced additional rebates intended to spur slow sales of its 1998-model mini-vans and small cars. The Dodge and Plymouth Neon now carry $1,500 rebates, and the mini-vans, rebates of $750 to $1,000.
Some auto analysts were cautious about the company's prospects in the fourth quarter. "They do have some very strong new products coming, but the market is getting more competitive," said Wendy Beale Needham of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Chrysler said its new share-repurchase plans signaled its confidence in the future. "We expect the industry, the economy and consumer confidence to remain strong through 1998," said Robert J. Eaton, the company's chairman and chief executive. "We believe we are well positioned to meet the competitive challenges of the market, and we remain committed to returning solid value to our shareholders." Since 1995, Chrysler has bought back nearly $5 billion of its stock.
Chrysler's shares rose on the earnings and buyback news, ending the day up 93.75 cents at $35.375.
Also today, the company's finance arm, the Chrysler Financial Corporation, reported net earnings of $111 million for the quarter, up from $94 million in the quarter last year.

HEADLINE: Autocratic Kazak Leader Ousts His Reformist Premier

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The autocratic leader of Kazakstan removed his reformist Prime Minister today, prompting worry about investment in the Central Asian republic, which is rich in oil deposits.
The collapse of the Government of Prime Minister Akezhan Kazhegeldin had been a subject of rumor for about two years. 
 But some Western business people were surprised by the choice to replace him, a comparatively conservative technocrat who is a close ally of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
The nation of 17 million people on the Caspian Sea has staked its future on billions of dollars in American and other foreign investment in its huge untapped oil fields.
In three years as Prime Minister, Mr. Kazhegeldin, 45, was responsible for much of the investment, conducting what was widely regarded as the swiftest industrial privatization in the former Soviet Union. In addition, last month he signed a $9.5 billion oil deal with China.
But Mr. Kazhegeldin, while popular with Western diplomats and business people, irritated many of the Soviet-era officials who administered the enterprises he worked to privatize. He also developed a high political profile, which Western diplomats and business people had predicted Mr. Nazarbayev would not tolerate for long.
Mr. Kazhegeldin left Kazakstan last month for Switzerland for treatment of a blood clot in his lungs, and it was not clear when he would return.
Most experts saw his removal as a power grab by the President, who has gradually reclaimed most of the sweeping powers he enjoyed as Kazakstan's Communist leader before the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991.
Mr. Nazarbayev sought to allay fears about his new Prime Minister, Nurlan Balgimbayev, 49, a former oilman who once worked for the San Francisco-based Chevron Oil Company. "I should pay tribute to the current Government, which worked energetically in difficult conditions," Mr. Nazarbayev said in a speech. "But at the same time the strategy of the President in the economy has not been implemented in full. Reforms have been insufficient and in some aspects have not yielded expected results."
Mr. Balgimbayev had been head of the state-run energy company, Kazakoil, and an intimate of Mr. Nazarbayev. Western experts said that the new Prime Minister's broad economic views were not known but that, as head of Kazakoil, he had displayed a preference for state control of energy enterprises -- the source of much of the skittishness generated by today's announcement.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
'The Bell Curve,' Revisited by Scholars

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
"The Bell Curve" inflamed readers when it was published three years ago by arguing that economic and social success in America had become largely a matter of genes, not education, environment or other factors over which society might exert control. The chilling genes-are-destiny thesis, laced with racial overtones, was greeted with furious criticism. But much of the initial criticism was ill informed and driven by ideology.
It could hardly have been otherwise. The book's authors, Richard Herrnstein and Charles Murray, did not release their statistical findings -- the only important original contributions in the book -- for formal review by scholars before publication. Their runaround obstructed response by other social scientists, who needed time to appraise hundreds of pages of statistical analysis. Now, three years later, scholars have caught up, shattering the book's core claims. 
 Messrs. Herrnstein and Murray use statistical tools to determine whether differences in intelligence or environment better explain, for example, which individuals commit crimes, drop out of high school or wind up poor. The authors find that, in their all-white sample, low intelligence leads to social pathology. High intelligence leads to success. Family background plays a secondary role. That suggests that compensatory education and training are almost certain to fail.
That core finding would be devastating if true. But other scholars have now decisively shown that the book's evidence is riddled with mistakes. Two stand out.
The first error flows from biased statistics. The book tries to determine whether I.Q. or family background is a better predictor of success. I.Q. is easily measured. But family background is not. The authors' simplistic index incorporates parental income, education and job prestige, but leaves out numerous components of a child's upbringing.
That creates a statistical mirage, or bias, because statistical tests inevitably underestimate the impact of factors that are hard to measure. Mistakes in measuring family background obliterate the ability of statisticians to detect its impact on future success. Thus, as James Heckman of the University of Chicago has convincingly argued, the book's finding that family background is a weak precursor of success reflects its biased methods rather than the workings of American society.
Also compelling is evidence about the second notable error -- that the authors' measure of intelligence is by no means immutable, as their thesis requires. Prof. Derek Neal of the University of Chicago and Prof. William Johnson of the University of Virginia have shown that scores on the measurement used by Mr. Herrnstein and Mr. Murray, the Armed Forces Qualification Test, depend on how much schooling individuals have completed. Put simply, the more students study in school, the better they do on the test. So what the authors call immutable intelligence turns out to be what others call skills -- indeed, teachable skills.
This mistake turns the message of the book on its head. Instead of its sighing surrender to supposed genetic destiny for poor children, there's a corrected message: Teach them. MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

TITLE: BELL CURVE, THE (BOOK)

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Exceed Forecast With 0.5% Rise

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The Government reported today that producer prices rose at an unexpectedly steep rate in September, but analysts said the increase was mostly a result of temporary factors and did not necessarily portend a resurgence in inflation.
The Producer Price Index, which measures the prices paid to manufacturers and other producers of goods, increased five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said. That was the biggest jump since December and more than twice the increase that most economists had predicted. 
 Much of the rise came from a 1.5 percent increase in energy costs, which climbed after crude oil prices rebounded over the summer.
Excluding food and energy, both of which tend to jump around for reasons having little to do with the strength of the economy, the so-called core index rose four-tenths of 1 percent, its highest rate since November 1995.
But the increase last month in the core index was misleading, analysts said. Much of the rise was driven by higher costs for new cars and for tobacco, and neither of those categories is likely to show any substantial increases in prices this month, they said.
Still, the figures amounted to enough of an inflation scare to send shudders through the financial markets, which were already jittery after statements on Wednesday by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. Mr. Greenspan said then that the combination of strong growth and low unemployment had put the economy on an "unsustainable track."
The Dow Jones industrial average fell nearly 60 points before recovering to close at 8,045.21, down 16.21 points for the day. Bond prices also fell, pushing the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond up to 6.42 percent, from 6.35 percent on Thursday.
Analysts said that because of all the quirks in today's price report, the figures would not be viewed by the Fed as evidence of a broad-based pickup in inflation. Financial markets have been increasingly concerned that the Fed might raise interest rates as soon as its next meeting, on Nov. 12, if the economy shows any signs of incipient inflation.
"It's obviously had an impact because Greenspan has put the markets on heightened alert," said Bill Dudley, an economist with Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York. "But in terms of this telling us inflation has now arrived, the evidence just isn't there."
September was the second consecutive month in which the index rose, following seven straight months of declines in producer prices. As a result, producer prices so far this year have fallen at a 1.4 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate.
Economists said that a look into measures of inflation farther back on the production chain also showed no evidence of mounting price pressures. The index for intermediate materials, supplies and components rose three-tenths of 1 percent in September, but was flat after factoring out food and energy. The index for crude materials rose six-tenths of 1 percent in September, but actually fell 1 percent after factoring out food and energy.
"This is not the smoking gun," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist with Paine Webber. "There is nothing in here that should be upsetting to people at the Fed. Greenspan certainly knows how to distinguish a blip from a trend, and this is just a blip."
Mr. Harris said the rise in car prices was a statistical fluke caused by seasonal adjustments.
Before seasonal adjustment, the index for passenger cars fell 1.8 percent last month to a level 2.1 percent below where it stood a year earlier. But after seasonal adjustment, the index showed a 1.4 percent rise in car prices -- a finding that might make statistical sense but does not fully reflect what is happening in the real world.
Analysts said the surge in the Producer Price Index, however misleading about inflation trends, suggested that the Consumer Price Index for September, which will be released on Thursday, would also probably show a spike.
Economists had been forecasting that the September consumer index would show a rise of about three-tenths of 1 percent, but they said the index could be pushed even higher by the surge in tobacco prices, as well as rising air fares, gasoline prices and clothing prices.

RUTH W. MESSINGER
Outside Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx, referring to Thursday night's debate:

Because I think what people find is if you do that, it hurts you."

HEADLINE: Messinger Fights to Stir Women;
Tepid Support by Her Base Is Seen as an Ominous Sign

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
When Ruth W. Messinger rose to speak about domestic violence at the Y.W.C.A. in midtown Manhattan the other morning, it marked the fourth time in 24 hours that the Democratic mayoral candidate had campaigned before an audience of women. The room was half-filled, and as Ms. Messinger methodically laid out her program, several women dozed off while a few others slipped out the door.
Ms. Messinger's intense and increasing focus on women in recent weeks reflects the belief of many political analysts that female voters will be crucial to her prospects of defeating Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani next month. Even when speaking to a mostly male audience at a fund-raiser with Vice President Al Gore on Thursday, Ms. Messinger referred to herself as "a daughter, a mother, a grandmother and a wife." 
 But the fact that the Democratic mayoral candidate needs to tend these political vines less than a month before Election Day -- and that she has encountered the kind of desultory reaction she found at the forum organized by women at the Y.W.C.A. on Tuesday -- suggests that female voters have not emerged as the powerful source of support Ms. Messinger had expected in her effort become the first woman to run the nation's largest city.
For all the potential significance of her challenge to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, women have yet to embrace Ms. Messinger as a symbol of political advancement, in the view of academics, pollsters and even some of Ms. Messinger's supporters. Ms. Messinger's candidacy has not become for women the sort of rallying point that David N. Dinkins's campaign was for many black voters in 1989, when he was elected the city's first black Mayor. And that is a matter of growing concern among some of her female supporters.
"One would expect Ruth to have been able to develop in this campaign strong support among women," City Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, one of Ms. Messinger's supporters, said. She added, "I think there's still time for that to happen."
Assemblywoman Catherine T. Nolan of Queens, another Messinger supporter, said, "I think her candidacy is symbolic -- it could be symbolic, and it can be symbolic.
"Up until now, the campaign has perhaps not done as well as they should. Because she's a women, sometimes in a campaign there's a tendency to say, 'That speaks for itself.' "
From a national perspective, some experts say, the election is emerging not as a milestone for women, but as the latest sign that female candidates are no longer the novelty they once were. The excitement that was once stirred by the prospect of a woman running for prominent office is no longer automatic.
"Voters are kind of going ho-hum," said Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster who has studied women's campaigns across the nation. Debbie Walsh, the acting director of the Center for American Women and Politics at Rutgers University, said the Messinger campaign is the latest indication that women, both as candidates and as officeholders, "are becoming more familiar to voters."
This could be an ominous development for Ms. Messinger, whose sex had been viewed by Democrats and Republicans as one of her most potent political advantages. The view among many New Yorkers that Mr. Giuliani has done a good job -- especially on the issue of crime, which some pollsters argue is more important to women than to men -- may trump whatever advantage Ms. Messinger sought in the potential symbolism of her candidacy.
Women made up 57 percent of the turnout in the 1993 New York mayoral contest, exit polls at the time found. They are also more likely than men to be Democrats and more likely than men to vote, and they voted against Mr. Giuliani in both 1989 and 1993 -- all of which should be encouraging news for Ms. Messinger.
What is more, there has been repeated evidence over the last 20 years of what is called a gender gap, a measurable difference in the way men and women vote. Since women vote more heavily than men, that has tended to make the female vote especially sought after. President Clinton, for example, enjoyed a strong lead among women during last year's presidential election, but he trailed Bob Dole among male voters.
Ms. Messinger argued that the same phenomenon would be evident in the weeks ahead because she has addressed issues -- in particular, education and domestic violence -- of concern to women voters. "Because I am raising those issues, there is likely to be a gender gap in this election -- that is, a different pattern of voting between women and men," Ms. Messinger said, sitting next to Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, who had come to to New York to appear at what Ms. Messinger had billed as a National Women's Power Breakfast. And moments earlier, before a boisterous crowd of about 300 women, Ms. Messinger declared, "This campaign will be decided by women."
But so far, private and public polls suggest, the gap only means that Ms. Messinger is doing less poorly among women than among men. "There clearly is, in the public polls, a gender gap," Jim Andrews, Ms. Messinger's chief campaign consultant, said. "It's basically a tie among women, when it's not with men."
Mr. Andrews argued that this would change in the remaining weeks of the campaign, particularly as Ms. Messinger emphasizes issues that they believe help her among female voters. But Mr. Giuliani's political advisers, and some independent pollsters, said they believed that women would if anything turn even more toward Mr. Giuliani as Election Day approaches. "For some reason, her message -- or more accurately, her candidacy -- does not seem to be resonating with women," said Frank Luntz, who is Mr. Giuliani's pollster.
There are some analysts who suggested that Ms. Messinger's candidacy had not yet become a rallying cry for women because she had not really tried to make it one. She entered politics in 1974, at a time when the profession was overwhelmingly male, but has never defined herself primarily in terms of a feminist agenda.
Now she is tending this part of her political base that some political analysts suggested she might have taken for granted. "It has not been as large an issue as it could be," Ms. Nolan said. She said the fund-raiser with Ms. Landrieu signaled a new phase for the campaign.
But Mr. Giuliani's supporters say Ms. Messinger's position among women is a reflection of her overall position in the race, as well as Mr. Giuliani's political strength. The Mayor's campaign, which has always been concerned about Ms. Messinger's potential appeal to women, has made an aggressive effort among those voters, including running advertisements attacking Ms. Messinger for opposing his proposal to ban pornography stores in certain city neighborhoods.
"The average female voter in New York is more concerned about safe streets, clean neighborhoods, and economic security than they are about electing a female Mayor," Fran Reiter, Mr. Giuliani's campaign manager, said. "I give Ruth credit for trying. But the Mayor's job approval is just too high."
Mr. Luntz, the campaign pollster, said: "I know that women were even more down on the city in 1993 then men. So for them to say that the city is heading in the right direction required a massive turnaround in perception."
Ms. Messinger said she would continue to try to make inroads among these voters by talking about issues of particular concern to women where, she argued, Mr. Giuliani has done a poor job. But Ms. Messinger received a reminder of how difficult this was the other night after finishing a 45-minute talk to a professional women's group at Julie's, a bar on East 52d Street, in which she talked about these issues, such as domestic violence, education and health care.
"Are there any other questions?" Ms. Messinger asked.
"Crime!" responded Catherine Anello, an office manager in Brooklyn, to a murmur of approval. It was the one issue Ms. Messinger had not discussed, and the one issue, pollsters find, that men and women consistently say male elected officials handle better.
Ms. Messinger gave her standard answer on the subject, which is that she shared Ms. Anello's concern and thought there was still room for additional improvement. But after she left, Ms. Anello, a Democrat who had applauded warmly as Ms. Messinger spoke, was not persuaded.
"I'm probably going to vote for Giuliani," Ms. Anello said. "I guess I feel safer than I did four years ago."

HEADLINE: At the Heels of Bull Elephants;
Nimble, Small Stocks Chase Big Blue Chips And Lately That Means Bigger Gains

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

 BODY:
Glenn Fogle could feel his investors' pain early this year. Through several mutual funds that he manages, the investors had loaded up on the shares of smaller companies, only to watch in dismay as their prices sank while those of blue-chip stocks like Coca-Cola and Gillette kept soaring.
Many of his clients bolted, cashing out at the punishing rate of $2 million a day and giving him some black and blue marks of his own. 
 "It was like being beaten up by a schoolyard bully," Mr. Fogle said in a telephone interview from his office at American Century Investments in Kansas City, Mo.
That was then, when the elephant-size blue chips were leading the stock market higher in a narrow advance that gave some analysts the jitters. But instead of diving into an abyss or at least slowing down, as so many pundits have long been predicting, the market has been broadening out in recent months, pushing up the prices of a herd of nimbler small and midsize companies, too. "We haven't been paid back yet for all the pain we endured, but there's been a real bounce," Mr. Fogle said.
The market expansion reflects a growing confidence by investors in the economy as a whole, analysts say. Smaller companies have more potential for growth than big, mature businesses do, but they also present more risks, drawing those who are willing to give up the relative safety of bigger stocks. That vote of confidence, in turn, is a strong signal that the market's remarkable run of the last three years may have plenty of life left in it, the analysts add.
"It's generally presumed that if the market broadens out like this, it's not going to roll over and die," said William E. Rhodes, an investment strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company. "This is a real sign that the market can go higher."
It is also the reason why analysts are less worried now by a comparison of this year's stock market with the ill-fated market of 1987, which did not broaden out before crashing almost exactly 10 years ago. The current market, many experts say, looks a lot more like the one in 1995, which was marked by such a broad advance that it kicked the bull market into high gear.
"There's a very high correlation between 1995 and 1997," said Laszlo Birinyi, president of Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn. "You could run a railroad over them -- they're very parallel."
To be sure, anything can happen in a stock market like this one, which has also become markedly volatile in recent months. Just this week, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, rattled the market -- though not many smaller stocks -- with a warning that it was unrealistic to expect the huge stock gains of recent years to continue. American investors also watched nervously this week as Europe was jolted by Germany's decision to raise interest rates and Southeast Asia coped with a spreading financial crisis.
Making things even more problematic is the fact that a broadening of the market is sometimes a bad thing: as when it gains because of a speculative buying frenzy that bids up the prices of even the most marginal companies, which can turn into a selling panic at the first sign of trouble. Yet few experts see this happening now.
Instead, the new rush to smaller companies has the bulls feeling more bullish and the bears entertaining a lot of second thoughts.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the strategist at Goldman, Sachs, who has been one of the market's biggest boosters, has just raised her forecast for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, in part because of the broadening of the market.
"When investors have confidence that inflation is under control and economic and profit growth will continue, that's when they're willing to broaden out their portfolios," Ms. Cohen said. "When you don't have that confidence, you focus on the bigger companies because they tend to have more consistent results."
And Steven Leuthold, an analyst at the Leuthold Group, who had predicted a 30 percent fall this year for the Dow Jones industrial average, now says that the appetite for small-company stocks has changed his mind. While still contending that this is the "most overvalued market in history," Mr. Leuthold says it could take until next year before it "peaks out."
What the bulls, of long standing or not, are focused on is the tale of the tape. While the Dow -- the most widely followed index -- is up 24.8 percent this year, broader measures are up even more. For instance, the Wilshire 5000 -- an index of all United States equities -- has risen 30.7 percent.
For the last three years, the market had been dominated by big-name stocks with strong earnings gains, like Travelers Group Inc. and General Electric. These stocks helped spark a buying frenzy for index funds, mutual funds that mimic indexes like the S.& P. 500, which tracks the largest companies.
But in recent months, after several blue-chip companies warned of slowing earnings prospects, investors began bidding up shares of smaller companies, many of which had strong second-quarter profits and relatively low price-to-earnings ratios. As a result, the Russell 2000 index of smaller-company issues gained 14.5 percent in the third quarter, while the Dow rose just 3.6 percent, and the S.& P. 500 gained 7 percent.
Usually, analysts say, smaller companies outperform bigger ones coming out of a recession, when growth is expected to be strongest. And so this year's broad gains this late in a bull cycle seem odd. "It's almost like the bull market started all over again," said Melissa Brown, director of quantitative research at Prudential Securities.
If the smaller issues continue to outperform the large ones, they will regain their historical position as market leaders, for in the long run, smaller stocks tend to do better. One reason, according to Mr. Rhodes at Merrill Lynch, is that smaller issues are primarily growth stories, part of the American dream. Everyone is trying to find the next big growth stock.
"This is what money managers get paid to do, to find companies that have good prospects," Mr. Rhodes said. "And there have been some classic American tales. There was the one about the little typewriter company that became I.B.M. And one about this clodhopper who rode around in a pickup truck in Arkansas. He had a great idea for retailing, and that became Wal-Mart. And then there were these three refugees from the Fairchild Company, and they started this little five-letter company named Intel. These are all stories about visionary managers, being in the right place at the right time."
If investors really are broadening their basket of stocks by searching for good buys, and not simply speculating, then the worries about parallels with 1987 should diminish, analysts say, particularly with regard to a late-year selloff. In 1987, a 44 percent rise in the Dow through August was whittled down to a year-end gain of just 2.3 percent, in large part because of the crash on Oct. 19.
Unlike 1987, when the market depended on a blue-chip advance, this year's gains recall those of 1995, when the Dow, S.& P. 500 and Nasdaq composite index of generally smaller stocks all gained better than 30 percent -- a sign that bullish sentiment was widespread. And this year, Mr. Birinyi said, investors have been similarly optimistic.
Even during downturns this year, investors have quietly snapped up equities, ignoring the dire predictions of a coming collapse, he said. And of the late summer selloff that saw the Dow lose 7.7 percent from its Aug. 6 high, Mr. Birinyi was simply dismissive. "The bulls were ahead 9 to 1 and the bears outscored them in the sixth inning," he said. "It wasn't that big a deal."
That kind of optimism has catapulted the market ahead, again and again. Success has bred more success. While there are no guarantees about where the market is headed, one thing is clear: almost every time the market has broadened out in recent years, there have been gains in the following months.
For instance, when the Russell 2000 index, which dates back to 1979, has gained better than 20 percent in a given year, the average rise in the following year is 14.9 percent. Only once, in 1984, did the index lose ground after a 20 percent gain.
Of course, much of the market's rise can be attributed to the continued enthusiasm for stocks in general, the belief that equities remain the best single investment. This is particularly the case for the 76 million baby boomers, who are worrying about retirement and have been flooding stock mutual funds with billions of dollars each month.
That sentiment has been buttressed by a healthy economic environment, marked by low inflation and plentiful profits. American technological might is creating new markets, and fostering greater efficiencies. The cold war is over, and capitalism is on the march.
"We have unprecedented international conditions, and that's one reason people are bidding up stocks to these prices," said Jeremy J. Siegel, a professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. "We don't have the same instability we had years ago, and so stocks are worth more because what you're doing is taking a lot of the old-fashioned risk out of them."
Even micro-cap funds, which track the tiniest of public companies, are up 41.6 percent this year. And when the market broadens, the average mutual fund (which tends to be diversified) also gains, as does the average investor.
Take Gerald Garry, a retired marketing executive who lives in Chappaqua, N.Y. Mr. Garry once had to count on blue-chip issues for all his gains. But recently, his diversified portfolio has begun to show signs of life. A fund dedicated to small-company stocks surged in the third quarter, rewarding Mr. Garry with a 22.8 percent gain -- the best small-cap gain he has seen in his four years of investing.
"It all came together in the third quarter -- I did very well," Mr. Garry said in a telephone interview from his home. "This is a real plus for the small investor, who can go with any sector and not be worried about picking the wrong segment."
Analysts and academics alike, not to mention Mr. Greenspan, worry that small investors like Mr. Garry are being lulled into a false sense of security by the bull market's persistence.
This has been a period of truly outsized gains. Since 1982, the point at which many analysts say the bull market began, the compounded annual return on stocks has been about 16.8 percent -- twice the historical average.
"Success has fed on itself and that's a worrisome prospect," Professor Siegel said, "because people's expectations are not grounded in long-term history. Fifteen years may seem like a long time, but it's not long in financial history."
But Peter J. Canelo, a market strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, said investors have had few alternatives that would cause them to turn their backs on such a splendid bull run.
"Why in the world," he asked, "would anyone want to buy a bond?"

HEADLINE: First Thing We Do, Let's Pay All the Lawyers

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The $49 million in legal fees and costs resulting from a tobacco litigation settlement today in which the plaintiffs received no money was criticized by some legal scholars.
Others, though, said large fees allowed lawyers to take difficult cases. 
 "It appears that what you have here is an awful lot of money -- $49 million -- for the lawyers, which is probably many times more than what their legal work on the case was worth," Prof. George Priest of Yale University Law School said. "It has all the earmarks of a settlement motivated by attorneys' fees rather than the members of the class bringing the suit."
The agreement, in which four of the largest tobacco companies agreed to spend $300 million on research into smoking-related illnesses, came in a class-action lawsuit by flight attendants who said smoking by others on their airplanes made them ill.
Individual plaintiffs in the case settled today are to receive no money but the tobacco companies will pay $49 million in fees and costs to the flight attendants' lawyers, Stanley and Susan Rosenblatt, who filed the lawsuit in 1991. The pact also involves agreements on possible future lawsuits by individual flight attendants or their survivors.
Mr. Priest, the John M. Olin Professor of Law and Economics, is regarded as a leading conservative scholar, but Prof. Susan Koniak of Boston University Law School, a noted liberal, expressed almost identical concerns.
"The only ones who got rich here are the lawyers," said Professor Koniak, who has written extensively about jury awards.
Ms. Koniak said that if she were a plaintiff and her lawyer told her that at the end of the effort the lawyer would get a handsome fee while a larger amount of money would go to benefit society, and she would get nothing herself, she would say, "Are you insane? Why would I possibly agree to that?"
The legal fees collected by the Rosenblatts are about 16 percent of the $300 million donation to research, which Prof. Lester Brickman of the Cardozo Law School of Yeshiva University said was an acceptable range in a class-action suit. Professor Brickman is generally critical of large fees but said they were sometimes necessary to provide an incentive for lawyers to take such a case in the first place.
In a contingency fee arrangement, a lawyer agrees to undertake a case without charge but to take a percentage of the award if the suit is successful.
"The traditional phrase is that a contingency fee is the key to the courthouse for most Americans and that is true," Mr. Brickman said. "Given the extremely high cost of litigation today, very few Americans can get to court without this."

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Take Steep Fall On Rise in Producer Costs

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday as a surprisingly strong report on producer prices stoked worries over inflation that had been raised by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
Bonds sold off immediately after the Labor Department's report showing a jump of five-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index for September. Analysts had been expecting a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent. While bonds bounced back, they never fully recovered in the pre-holiday shortened session. 
 The 30-year Treasury bond fell 30/32, to a price of 99 12/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.42 percent, from 6.35 percent on Thursday and back to where it was nearly a month ago. Trading ended yesterday at 2 P.M. The Treasury market is closed on Monday in observance of Columbus Day.
The sharp rise in producer prices, however, came largely on a 1.5 percent increase in energy costs, an often volatile category. And even when food and energy costs had been excluded, the four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the so-called core rate of producer prices was driven largely by higher costs for new cars and tobacco, price gains that are unlikely to be sustained.
Still, the report shook investors already jittery about inflation. On Wednesday, Mr. Greenspan warned that a resurgence in inflation might be lurking just around the corner if strong growth drove unemployment lower and pushed wages higher. And interest rate increases by a number of European central banks on Thursday showed that policy makers worldwide were also concerned about inflation.
"The market is taking a knee-jerk reaction to the data," said Jack Ablin, executive vice president and head of the fixed-income department at Barnett Capital Advisers Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla. "By combining Greenspan's statement this week with today's large number, the market has conluded that the Fed will tighten at the November Federal Open Market Committee meeting."
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, an economic consulting and forecasting firm, said: "After Fed Chairman Greenspan's warning on Wednesday, this data could be viewed as the beginning of an argument for the need to raise interest rates in the next few months. But we think that this would be reading too much into both the Fed's chairman's remarks and the September P.P.I."
Mr. McCarthy said he thought Mr. Greenspan was telling the financial markets that the Fed was not going to ease rates any time in the forseeable future, not that he was about to raise rates.

HEADLINE: Judge Rules City Hall Must Surrender Records to State Comptroller in an Audit Fight

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
A State Supreme Court Justice ruled yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani must turn over city records that State Comptroller H. Carl McCall had requested in his effort to audit city agencies.
City officials immediately vowed to fight the decision and said they would not comply with the judge's order until an appeals court had reviewed the case. 
 Mayor Giuliani and Mr. McCall have been fighting for months over the Comptroller's right to investigate certain city agencies. Last spring the Mayor ordered city officials to evict state auditors who were trying to review documents at two city agencies. The Mayor accused Mr. McCall of ordering audits that were politically motivated and were intended to embarrass him during his re-election campaign.
Mr. McCall countered that the Mayor was acting illegally and said that his refusal to cooperate raised questions about whether the Mayor was trying to hide something.
The Republican Mayor and the Democratic Comptroller had negotiated a short-lived truce, but Mr. McCall ultimately issued 17 subpoenas to try to obtain records from six city agencies.
Justice Phyllis Gangel-Jacob of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that Mr. McCall had the authority to request the information from the agencies, and ordered the city to comply with Mr. McCall's subpoenas. "The audits at issue are within the powers granted to the Comptroller," she wrote in her opinion.
Mr. McCall applauded the decision and said it would enable him to do his job as the state's chief fiscal monitor "without unnecessary interference from those who would seek to hide from proper oversight." He also criticized the Mayor's attempt to stop his auditors from doing their work, calling the dispute "a sideshow from the proper activities of an effective, responsible government."
Paul A. Crotty, the city's Corporation Counsel, said the city would not allow the audits to take place, saying that the judge had failed to distinguish between a financial audit and a performance audit. The city had argued that while Mr. McCall has the authority to look at the books and accounts of city agencies, he does not have the right to review the way city agencies actually perform.
As an example, Mr. Crotty said the Comptroller could review overtime costs at the Police Department, but did not have the right to review how many police officers are on the streets and how they are deployed.
"The judge's decision misses the whole distinction that we were trying to draw," Mr. Crotty said.
The subpoenas were directed at the city's Finance Department, Police Department, Human Resources Administration, Taxi and Limousine Commission, Department of Health and Administration for Children's Services. The Comptroller had hoped to review issues like the training of caseworkers at the Administration for Children's Services, the adequacy of the Police Department's system for reporting arrests, and the effectiveness of economic development and tax incentive programs.
When told that the city would continue to fight the audit attempt, Steven Greenberg, a spokesman for Mr. McCall said, "It really is outrageous that the city continues to believe that the city is above the law."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Cutbacks at Westinghouse Eliminating 2,000 Jobs
Westinghouse said it would cut 2,000 jobs, or 13 percent of the work force, in its industrial group as part of a previously announced plan to divide into media and industrial companies.
 
 The reductions will be felt at Westinghouse's headquarters in Pittsburgh, where George Westinghouse founded the business more than a century ago. Page D2.
 
Archer Whistle-Blower in Plea Deal
Mark E. Whitacre, the Government informant who exposed a price-fixing scandal at his former employer, Archer Daniels Midland, pleaded guilty to 37 criminal charges under a plea bargain that could result in a six-and-a-half-year prison term. D2.
 
Chrysler Earnings Fall
Chrysler said third-quarter earnings fell 35 percent. But the results were better than expected, and its stock rose. Investors were also heartened by the announcement of a $2 billion share buyback. D2.
 
Saturn and Chevrolet said they were reducing prices on some 1998 models and mailing reimbursement checks to customers who had already purchased the vehicles. D2.
 
Dow Is Down for a Third Day
Another spasm of inflation anxiety rippled through the stock market after the Government reported unexpectedly high prices paid in September by manufacturers and other producers, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average down for the third straight day and leaving it barely changed for the week. Most broader stock indexes also weakened. D4.
 
Treasury bonds fell sharply, raising yields on the benchmark 30-year issue from 6.35 percent Thursday to 6.42 percent, nearly back to its level of a month ago. D14.
 
Secondhand-Smoke Suit Settled
The major tobacco companies have agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit over the effects of smoking on nonsmokers by spending $300 million for the study of tobacco-related diseases The class action represents 60,000 former and current flight attendants and their survivors. The industry did not acknowledge that secondhand smoke was harmful. A1.
 
Big Cutbacks at Montgomery Ward
Montgomery Ward, the nation's largest privately owned retailer, said it would close 48 stores as part of an effort to cut costs and emerge from bankruptcy protection. The closings could result in as many as 3,800 layoffs. D3.
 
Clinton's Plan for I.R.S.
President Clinton outlined proposals to make the Internal Revenue Service gentler to taxpayers and more efficient. The plan is an effort to forestall more radical measures being considered in Congress. A9.
 
Japanese Bet on Britain
Nomura International is buying William Hill, one of Britain's biggest gambling businesses, two weeks after the Japanese investment bank became the top British independent pub owner by purchasing Inntrepreneur. D2.
 
A Hidden Monopoly
Buried in a military appropriations bill President Clinton signed this week was a provision that would give Sam Zell, the Chicago investor, left, a monopoly on the cruise business in Hawaii. In exchange, he must promise to buy two American-built cruise ships for $400 million each. Critics describe the provision as little more than a stealth deal to protect a business from competition. A1 .
 
New Term for S.E.C. Chief
President Clinton has decided to renominate Arthur Levitt Jr. to another five-year term as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the agency said through a spokeswoman. Mr. Levitt's term expires next June. D2 .

HEADLINE: 3 Weak Days Trim Week's Gain in Dow

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING

 BODY:
Stocks slipped yesterday, their third consecutive decline, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average with little to show for the week.
Stocks started the week on track toward new highs, and on Tuesday the Dow reached 8,178.31, just 81 points away from its peak, touched on Aug. 6. 
 But remarks on Wednesday by the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, interest rate increases in Europe on Thursday and an unexpected rise in September producer prices reported yesterday caused stocks to swoon.
Yesterday, stocks were initially jarred by a stronger-than-expected gain of five-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index, but they later recovered. The Dow, after falling nearly 60 points, at one point, closed at 8,045.21, off 16.21 points. For the week, the Dow was up 6.63.
Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks lost 3.64 yesterday, closing at 966.98, up 1.95 for the week.
But the Nasdaq composite, which lost 6.82 yesterday, ended the week nearly 1.4 percent higher, at 1,739.03.
And the Russell index of 2,000 smaller companies posted a 1.2 percent gain for the week, adding 0.48 point yesterday, to 465.03, another high, as investors continued to plow cash into the sector.
"Greenspan and the P.P.I. basically took a lot of momentum out of the market," said Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Smith Barney. "A week ago, the Dow was on a tear, then Greenspan threw cold water on the bonds and ultimately the stock market."
The stock market eventually shrugged off the sharp rise in producer prices because it was fueled largely by a 1.5 percent rise in energy costs, an often volatile category.
And excluding food and energy costs, the four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the so-called core rate of producer prices was driven largely by higher costs for new cars and tobacco, price gains that are unlikely to be sustained, noted Peter Cardillo, chief strategist at Westfalia Investments. In addition, the P.P.I. fell in seven of the eight previous months this year, he added.
"I think people are saying after seven months of declines and you get one fairly high number, it's a one-time situation," Mr. Cardillo added.
Stocks climbed back from their lows because equity investors seem to have a more sanguine view of inflation and are waiting for visible signs of an increase, analysts said.
In addition, investors are optimistic that most third-quarter earnings reports will be positive, Mr. Acuff said.
Still, that optimism has not translated into blind euphoria, analysts said, as investors penalized companies that had missed earnings forecasts or could be hurt by a rise in inflation.
As a result, interest-rate-sensitive banking and financial services stocks like Chase Manhattan, BankAmerica, J. P. Morgan and American Express finished lower yesterday.
Regional and money center banks also accounted for more than 36 percent of the declines in the S.& P. 500 yesterday.
Waste Management fell 3 1/8, to 30 5/8, after the company said third-quarter earnings would fall short of analysts' forecasts.
In the currency market, the dollar fell against the yen after some tough comments from United States officials on Japanese auto trade practices. But the dollar gained against the mark.
In New York, the dollar settled at 119.78 yen, down from 121.10 yen on Thursday, and at 1.7486 marks, up from 1.7439 marks. The pound fell to $1.6223 from $1.6244.
