HEADLINE: Giuliani and Messinger Keep Slugging on Day After Debate

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger each took time out yesterday to disparage the other's performance in Thursday night's mayoral debate in Harlem.
Ms. Messinger said the Mayor had been "demeaning" and "insulting" in his response to her suggestion during the debate that after-school programs reduce gang activity. Mr. Giuliani, in his own post-mortem, expressed shock at what he called Ms. Messinger's "harshness" and "personal invective." 
 The two candidates are not scheduled to appear together again until the second and final debate on Oct. 29. As they maneuvered for advantage yesterday, Mr. Giuliani and Ms. Messinger both said that each had presented the clearest vision of how the city should be governed during next four years.
"I tried to outline our plans for the future," Mr. Giuliani said. "What that's going to be, what it's going to be based on. Increasing the crime reductions, improving the quality of life for the future, for the next two, three, four years, reinvesting more and more in the growth of the city."
The Mayor accused his Democratic rival of resorting to personal attacks. "I was somewhat surprised at the harshness and the personal invective from my opponent," he said after the ceremony that marked the opening of the replanted Great Lawn in Central Park. "I didn't think it would be at that level. But you know everybody makes the choice as to how they're going to present themselves."
And in a twist, Mr. Giuliani, whose aggressive style has prompted Ms. Messinger to refer repeatedly to him as a bully, said Ms. Messinger ought to change her style. "People change their styles and I would imagine in the next debate that my opponent will not be as personal, won't call names as often," he said. "Because I think what people find is if you do that, it hurts you."
For her part, Ms. Messinger said that Mr. Giuliani had failed to defend his record during the debate. "For the first time, the Mayor actually sounded like he didn't think every problem in the city had been solved," she said while campaigning yesterday in the Bronx. "He said he knew that there were substantial problems in the school system that still need to be addressed. He denied that he had ever said that rising unemployment was a sign of economic health."
Ms. Messinger, who has accused the Mayor of using sexist language during the campaign, said she was insulted by his response to her proposals for after-school programs, which she suggested would reduce gang activity and which the Mayor said would not be of interest to hardened gang members.
"I thought it was a demeaning comment on the extraordinary programs that are run around the city of which there were many, many more before Rudy Giuliani cut $15 million from the budget of the Department of Youth Services," Ms. Messinger said. "I think it's insulting to dramatize for the television audience that the lead organizer of the Bloods or Crips who has probably spent some time in jail won't be helped by a sewing circle," she said, adding that she saw "the combined insults in those remarks."
Carrying out a promise he made during the debate, Mr. Giuliani yesterday released a letter he wrote to a Federal judge on behalf of William D. Fugazy, the businessman and lobbyist, who was convicted of perjury during a bankruptcy proceeding and sentenced to two years probation in late September.
Ms. Messinger demanded to know why the Mayor, who she said is known for his law-and-order toughness, would come to the aid of Mr. Fugazy, who she noted was a contributor to the Giuliani campaign.
Mr. Giuliani said he wrote the letter seeking leniency for Mr. Fugazy because of Mr. Fugazy's long history of community service in New York City. Mr. Giuliani accused Ms. Messinger of politicizing a rare negative incident in the life of a generous community volunteer.

HEADLINE: THE FINE PRINT: Of Arms and Cruise Ships;
In a Bill's Shipbuilding Provision, Some See a Floating Pork Barrel

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Tucked inside a military appropriations bill signed by President Clinton this week was a provision that would give a billionaire investor a 30-year monopoly on the cruise business in the Hawaiian islands.
In return, the company controlled by the investor, Sam Zell, must commit to buying two American-built cruise ships for about $400 million apiece. 
 Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, the ranking Democrat on the Defense appropriations subcommittee, said the monopoly -- although he prefers the term "preference" -- was necessary to get Mr. Zell's company, American Classic Voyages, to shoulder the financial risk of buying the vessels. It was a small concession, he added, for a measure that would bolster Hawaiian tourism, jump-start an industry that has not built a large cruise ship in this country in more than 40 years, and reduce those shipyards' dependence on Federal funds.
"This project is a milestone for our U.S.-flag cruise ship industry," Senator Inouye said.
Others, however, describe the provision as little more than a stealth deal to protect a key business in the Senator's state from competition. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, a vocal critic of the provision, said there was "no compelling reason" to give American Classic a monopoly.
"I'm sure that many businesses would like to reduce their cost of capital to replace their infrastructure by convincing their lenders that their company is protected from any competition in its market," Mr. McCain said.
He also objected to a provision allocating $250,000 from a Defense Department program for initial design, but not construction, of the ships. The program is intended to develop technology for maritime uses.
"It is purely and simply an example of pork-barrel spending that has nothing to do with defense," Senator McCain said.
Although the provision has been passed by Congress, and President Clinton signed the Defense appropriations bill Wednesday, he has until Tuesday to exercise his line-item veto power. Mr. Clinton has used his line-item-veto power twice this year to cut projects from spending bills. On Monday, he struck 38 spending provisions worth $287 million from the military construction budget.
The President can use his line-item veto power to reject individual items of spending or tax legislation within one week of signing the legislation. The line-item veto was unsuccessfully sought by Presidents for more than a century before the Republicans included it in their 1994 Contract With America and enacted it in 1996.
A White House spokesman said the President had not yet received a memorandum from his staff regarding the possible use of the line item veto on the Defense appropriations bill. A spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget said yesterday that its staff had not yet completed scrutiny of the bill.
The cruise-ship provision, however, is about more than pork-barrel politics. Its mere proposal illustrates the constraints placed on companies like Mr. Zell's by the Jones Act -- a 77-year-old law that requires companies to use United States-built ships to transport passengers or goods between two United States ports. Most companies in the rapidly growing cruise industry buy ships built in foreign countries that have long subsidized their shipyards. Although cruise ships operated by these companies often stop at United States ports to board American passengers, they must visit a foreign port in between those stops to bypass the Jones Act.
There is support from many quarters for Senator Inouye's provision. Executives at American Classic Voyages, which is based in Chicago and operates ships on the Mississippi River and in Hawaii, said they wanted to expand in Hawaii but were uneasy about purchasing the first new United States cruise ships in decades.
Specifically, they said they were concerned about paying higher costs typically associated with a first-time venture. If they bought the first two ships, they said, a potential competitor might buy a third and fourth ship more cheaply and enter the Hawaiian market.
American Classic has never had direct competition since it started offering cruises in Hawaii in 1982. But the company said that barring rivals for the life of a new ship -- a minimum of 25 years -- would lower the risk of such an investment and create jobs in Hawaii and the United States shipbuilding industry.
If the provision were vetoed, American Classic would not buy the ships, said Philip C. Calian, the company's president.
"We're not asking for any government money," Mr. Calian said. "This is an exciting piece of public policy."
Navy officials and United States shipbuilders that proposed the provision said if the United States wanted to maintain dominance on the seas, shipbuilders needed more customers than the Navy.
"It is in our nation's interest for us to build commercial ships," said Cynthia Brown, president of the American Shipbuilding Association, which represents the country's six largest shipyards.
Shareholders in American Classic also appear hopeful the provision will pass. Analysts who follow American Classic's stock said its 70 percent rise since August was due in large part to Congressional passage of Senator Inouye's proposal.
But Mr. McCain is not alone in criticizing the prospect of granting a lengthy monopoly to a company. Lawrence J. White, professor of economics at the New York University Stern School of Business and former chief economist in the antitrust division of the Justice Department, said Mr. Inouye's provision was symptomatic of the protectionist nature of the Jones Act, which he called outdated in a global and deregulated economy.
"This is a terribly inefficient way for a dynamic U.S. economy to be behaving in world markets," Mr. White said.
Senator Inouye has said his provision will offer a preference, not a monopoly, to American Classic because the company will face competition from other forms of tourism in Hawaii, including cruises on foreign-built vessels that stop only once in Hawaii en route to a foreign port.
Mr. Zell and his company have donated $3,500 to Mr. Inouye's campaign in recent years, and Federal records show Mr. Zell tends to give relatively small amounts to candidates of both parties.
Although Mr. Inouye's provision does not name American Classic, it clearly states the company need not worry about a direct competitor for decades.
The proposal states that a company operating cruises among the Hawaiian islands on the date of enactment will commit to buying two United States-built cruise ships. It adds that the first ship will be delivered before 2005, and the second before 2008. It also states that another company may not operate any cruise ship accommodating at least 275 passengers among or between the Hawaiian Islands for the life of the ships, which is at least 25 years.
It further provides for a waiver from the Jones Act to allow the company to operate a foreign-built ship until 24 months after the second American-built ship is delivered. For that two-year period, American Classic could be operating as many as four ships in Hawaii.
Ms. Brown of the American Shipbuilding Association said that four of its members would be most likely to bid for the contract to build the two ships: Avondale Industries in New Orleans; the National Steel and Shipbuilding Company in San Diego; Newport News Shipbuilding in Newport News, Va., and the Ingalls Shipbuilding division of Litton Industries, based in Pascagoula, Miss. Ingalls would certainly have the political edge, given that Mississippi is the home state of Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader.
If the provision is not vetoed by Mr. Clinton, Mr. McCain would introduce legislation next year to overturn Mr. Inouye's provision, according to an aide in Mr. McCain's office.

HEADLINE: U.S. Has Training Shortage, Not Labor Shortage

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Norbert Walter argues that because the United States has a shortage of skilled labor, and Western Europe has a surplus, greater immigration is the solution (Op-Ed, Oct. 4). 
 But there is a huge underutilized capacity in the millions of untrained Americans struggling to make an honest living or relegated to a life of crime and drugs. More than seven million are officially counted as unemployed. Twice that number are in dead-end temporary or part-time jobs, or, after being out of work more than 26 weeks, are no longer counted.
Europeans long ago realized government must play a creative role in developing citizens' skills. In Germany and France, per capita government spending on education and training has far outpaced spending in the United States. Instead of further undermining the security of workers, we should question the wisdom of letting the Federal Reserve raise interest rates at the first signs that real living standards may finally be rising.
 
TIMOTHY A. CANOVA
Miami, Oct. 7, 1997
 
The writer teaches business law at St. Thomas University School of Law.

HEADLINE: U.S. Has Training Shortage, Not Labor Shortage;
Missing Money

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Norbert Walter's suggestion that the United States become an employer of last resort for Europe's unemployed (Op-Ed, Oct. 4) rests on a questionable presumption. If there is a major shortage of high-skilled workers in the United States, one could expect significant increases in their salaries. Such is not the case. 
 Mr. Walter cites a shortage in computer workers, but according to Bureau of Labor Statistics figures, salaries for computer analysts and programmers, adjusted for inflation, have been level for five years.
If shortages do arise, they can be addressed best by employers who fully utilize available human resources, more appropriately reward workers who are responsible for their current prosperity, and invest in training to the high level of European competitors.
 
JACK GOLODNER
President, Dept. for Professional
Employees, A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Washington, Oct. 7, 1997

HEADLINE: U.S. Has Training Shortage, Not Labor Shortage;
Help Workers Succeed

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The suggestion that the United States import skilled labor from Europe is appalling (Op-Ed, Oct. 4). We must take advantage of our prosperity to help those with low skills move into jobs with good pay and benefits. 
 The Education Department's National Adult Literacy Study found, in 1992, that almost 40 million adults had extremely low literacy and math skills. The way to increase productivity, and contain inflation, is to give workers a chance to improve skills, enter vocational training or community college, and then succeed at high-skilled jobs.
 
JOHN P. COMINGS
Cambridge, Mass., Oct. 6, 1997
 
The writer is director of the National Center for the Study of Adult Learning and Literacy at Harvard.

HEADLINE: When Bad Economic Theory Threatens Good Times

BYLINE: By Robert Eisner; Robert Eisner, professor emeritus at Northwestern University, is the author of the forthcoming "The Great Deficit Scares: the Federal Budget, Trade and Social Security."

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
Just when we thought Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, had settled into a wise laissez-faire approach to our surging economy, he warned this week that we may soon be tasting some foul medicine.
Why? Because we are doing too well. Unemployment has been at or below 5 percent for six months and below 6 percent for three full years. And the growth in our gross domestic product has been running at 3 percent for the last four years, instead of the roughly 2 percent that many thought was the best we could do. 
 The conventional wisdom has long been that such figures could not be achieved without accelerating inflation. Yet inflation and even prices themselves have been falling, and Mr. Greenspan seemed to have abandoned this conventional view.
Until this week, that is, when he unexpectedly declared that wages may rise unless the recent two-million-plus annual rate of job creation is cut to the million a year that would be consistent with population growth.
When we're shrinking unemployment, why stop now? We even have a legislated target, in the old Humphrey-Hawkins Full Employment and Balanced Growth Act of 1978, of 4 percent unemployment. In fact, Mr. Greenspan is required to testify regularly before Congress about policies to meet that target.
Might 4 percent unemployment bring some increase in wages? It might, after years of decline in real wages. When few people are unemployed, employers have to bid higher to find workers.
But with profits at record highs, productivity rising, the dollar strong and international competition brisk, companies have little reason to increase prices, even if they give employees modest wage increases. And there is certainly no excuse for the peremptory strike of raising interest rates to slow the economy, a move that -- thanks to Mr. Greenspan's remarks -- Wall Street now fears when the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee meets Nov. 12.
More fundamentally, there is no reason to hold employment growth to the long-term rate of population growth, as Mr. Greenspan suggested. There are millions of black Americans and Hispanic Americans, as well as women, youths and elderly people of all races and ethnic groups, who would take jobs if they could get them.
In some cases putting these people to work would require more and better education and training, but in all cases it would require a brisk, growing economy. This employment growth will not occur if Mr. Greenspan follows through on his implicit threat to hold the economy down.
The underlying culprit in all this, openly espoused within the Federal Reserve Board, is the dogma that there is an unemployment rate below which inflation goes crazy (a "non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment," or Nairu, in the economist's jargon). Until recently the idea that there is such a magic number was widely accepted by liberal and conservative economists alike, liberals putting it at 6 percent and conservatives at 6.5 or 7 percent.
Whatever the figure -- and recent work has indicated increasing doubt as to just what it is, if it exists at all -- unemployment below these rates would do more than simply generate higher inflation, the believers say. It would give us continuously accelerating inflation -- that is, inflation that would get higher and higher: 2 percent, 5 percent, 10 percent, 20 percent and so on. Who would dare risk letting this genie out of the bottle?
I have been pointing out for years that the theory simply does not hold up to evidence, and other economists have increasingly been agreeing. Really high unemployment, as might be expected, has reduced inflation. In the Depression, inflation turned negative. And in the recession of 1982-83, with unemployment approaching 11 percent, inflation slowed markedly.
But the critical fact is that unemployment and inflation are not linked so tightly. Relatively low unemployment for whatever reason -- increasing productivity may be one -- has simply not been associated with either higher or rising inflation.
So Mr. Greenspan should resist the Nairu dogma. And he certainly shouldn't follow his counterparts in the German Bundesbank, who have just announced an increase in an interest rate even though unemployment there is more than 11 percent.
Mr. Greenspan should aim for maximum employment, maximum growth and real wages that befit our mighty economy. He shouldn't even threaten to shoot at inflation until he sees the whites of its eyes.
 
Maureen Dowd is on vacation.

HEADLINE: Word & Image; Why So Foreign?

BYLINE: By Max Frankel

 BODY:
Here is the world around Us, as Brokaw, Jennings, Rather and less mobile anchors have portrayed it for Americans in the autumn of 1997:
 England: A fairy-tale kingdom whose streets are strewn with flowers and whose venerable cathedrals reverberate with the croonings of Elton John. The brave English people have once again earned our gratitude, this time for wresting the image of a beautiful princess from the clutches of the degenerate Royals and electing a handsome new Prime Minister, who taught the Queen to curtsy to the crowds.
 With only dozens of camera crews at their disposal in London and just hundreds of hours on the air, America's newscasters obviously lacked the resources and the time needed to explain the function of royalty in England or examine the new Prime Minister's other policies and politics. They also had no time for the Irish troubles, the Scottish and Welsh disaffections and the Tories' torments about belonging to Europe. 
 France: A sunny Mediterranean playground for the rich governed by grim Parisian bureaucrats who seem unable to enforce the speed limits and seat-belt regulations in their capital's dangerous streets and tunnels.
 With all their Paris cameras trained on a single auto accident, the newscasters obviously lacked the means and the time needed to inquire into other Franco-British affairs or the storms kicked up by the Franco-German campaign to create a new Euro currency. 
 (Germany, like Russia, Italy and other relics of various hot and cold wars, seems to offer nothing of interest in these tepid times. There are, presumably, plans to mention the Germans again at the millennium, in pictorial reviews of the 20th century.) 
 Latin America: A dark, unexplored landmass situated south of the Caribbean, one of whose playgrounds for the middle classes has been smothered by the ashes of an unrelenting volcano. Also bordering the Caribbean is Mexico, a country awaiting a United States ambassador while it sends us drugs and immigrants in exchange for job-creating factories.
 The telegenic eruptions of Montserrat's mountain and North Carolina's Senator Jesse Helms were so absorbing that no anchor dared to interrupt to explain why the public should give a hoot about former Gov. William Weld's next job or the United States' next embassy chief in Mexico City. No newscast ever mentioned James Jones, our most recent ambassador there, or, come to think of it, the deeds of any ambassador anywhere. 
 China: An Asian sweatshop that manufactures highly attractive and desirable sportswear and launders contributions to America's politicians. The Chinese gifts, bundling the nouveau riches of Hong Kong with old wealth from Taiwan, were traded for photographs that certify the donors as most-favored visitors at the White House coffee bar.
 Television coverage of the Senate's pursuit of the Beijing connection left no time for covering Beijing itself, where Government leaders revealed a daring plan to privatize 300,000 state enterprises, to flush out their inefficiencies and rid them of tens of millions of surplus workers. The party congress at which this mother of all Initial Public Offerings was announced must have been mistaken at the networks for a Communist gathering or a dismal economics seminar best left to C-Span. 
 India: The burial site of the future Saint Teresa, who ministered here to the world's greatest concentration of poor and was worshiped in the United States for greeting a tardy princess in the Bronx. Also known as the world's largest democracy, India boasts a Government that can count 350 million ballots faster than New York City's can count 200,000.
 The cameras and casts covering Mother Teresa's funeral were deployed far from anyone who could explain why Calcutta needed so much saintly charity or how hundreds of millions of other once-poor Indians came to eat so well in off-camera locations. Strangers in Asia, the American television teams understandably flew clear past unremarkable places like Indonesia. 
 To be sure, and fair, last month's network newscasts did include a few reports about land mines in Africa and Bosnia that were more than illustrations of the humanitarian impulses of the Princess of Wales. But the pathetic films of the injured that she inspired dominated the tube and made short shrift of President Clinton's case for refusing to give up his mines immediately. In any event, the broadcasters' interest in military affairs soon drifted from underground weapons to a series of aerial mishaps, which produced new scenes of distraught mourners. 
 No network bothered, of course, to let its coverage of military mines and planes blossom into meaningful scrutiny of the still-growing arsenal of American weaponry or the foreign perils it is designed to defeat. Although every television anchor is deemed qualified to cover a funeral, television news seems unwilling to afford the expertise needed to tackle the instruments of death and their procurement or the deadly competitions of foreign nations. 
 It is perfectly true, as our most famous anchors argue in their programs' defense, that when they feature the Princess of Wales or Mother Teresa, the crowds will come, whereas coverage of Presidents Jiang, Yeltsin, Chirac and even Arafat chase their viewers to ''Seinfeld'' reruns. But even the best sitcoms need to be expensively plotted, cultivated and promoted before they find a sustainable audience. To dismiss the affairs of the world as either too boring or complicated for most Americans is to insult not only the audience but also the talents so regularly on display in most television commercials. 
 Surely an industry that dares each night to explore some new pharmacological achievement can learn to discover news of interest in alien cultures. Surely a medium that can find drama in a speech by Queen Elizabeth can find excitement in the Great Hall proclamations of Jiang Zemin. The people who make bankable international stars of Brokaw, Jennings and Rather should know how to get us to watch anything.

HEADLINE: The People's Raj

BYLINE: By John F. Burns; John F. Burns is the New Delhi bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:

India
 From Midnight to the Millennium.
 By Shashi Tharoor.
 362 pp. New York:
 Arcade Publishing. $25.95. 
 At the core of the debate stirred by India's 50th anniversary of independence is a paradox: How is it that this vast country, accounting for a sixth of humanity, has done so much less than many other developing nations to relieve the poverty, illiteracy and disease that afflict so large a portion of its population, when its celebrated system of parliamentary democracy places political power in the hands of the people?
In a decade that has seen a striking expansion of democracy in Eastern Europe, as well as in previously unpromising regions of Africa, Asia and Latin America, something like a consensus has emerged, at least in the Western world, about democracy being the surest foundation for prosperity. But if democracy is the way forward, there is a need to understand why India, endowed with a political system that makes its rulers accountable, has not better served the needs of its people.
A 1993 survey cited by Shashi Tharoor, the Indian-born author of "India: From Midnight to the Millennium," an affectionate but unsparing chronicle of India's woes, found that 58 percent of the respondents in the country's leading cities thought their problems could best be tackled by dictatorship. Anybody with experience of India will recognize a sentiment commonly voiced in certain quarters of India's elite, whose faith in democracy seems, paradoxically, less firm than among the poor, who have so little to show for their votes.
Tharoor recounts in his introduction how he endured his own crisis of confidence as he left India for postgraduate study in the United States in 1976, the year after Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declared an emergency, suspended civil liberties and arrested thousands of opponents. For 21 months, until she called a general election and lost it, it was a dark hour for India's democracy, and for Tharoor, who wrote an article at the time condemning the political apathy -- he warned his readers about "Indians who are not involved in India" -- which he believed had made the dictatorship possible.
After graduating from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy in Boston, Tharoor himself chose not to return to what he calls "my beloved and impossible homeland," except for vacations and a journey in 1996 in his capacity as an official of the United Nations in New York, where he is the executive assistant to the Secretary General. In the book, he acknowledges that this has caused some people to accuse him of the lack of commitment for which he excoriated other Indians 20 years ago. "I am, indeed, often asked," he says, "how I can reconcile my passionate faith in India with my internationalist work for the United Nations."
With a touch of self-righteousness, he tells us that there is "no contradiction" since, he says, India shares so much with the United Nations, both being places that bring together "human beings of different ethnicities and religions, customs and costumes, cuisines and colors, languages and accents." True as this is, it would not be the first explanation of most of the Indians of Tharoor's generation -- a million now living in the United States alone -- who left India mainly to pursue living standards that became virtually impossible to achieve in the stagnant, socialized economy at home.
Still, Tharoor uses his book, the third he has written during his United Nations career, to show an encyclopedic command of what has gone wrong with Indian democracy over the past half-century. Few books in recent years, if any, offer such a comprehensive overview of what ails India, its politicians and its people; and few writers, apart from Nirad Chaudhury and V. S. Naipaul, benefit so obviously from the perspective Tharoor offers, that of an Indian with a profound empathy for his native culture, combined with the insight made possible by following India's progress from afar.
Even though he has kept in touch with matters at home, supplementing his visits by exhaustive reading, especially of Indian, American and British newspapers, his book is deprived of the firsthand authenticity that infuses home-grown writings. This, in fact, is its main weakness, an absence of the scene and color and feel that make India, with all its problems, such a compelling place. Lacking that, Mr. Tharoor's writing too often assumes the tone of an academic treatise.
The Olympian style can be jarring. As he showed in a previous work, "The Great Indian Novel," Tharoor is a fluid and powerful writer, one of the best in a generation of Indian authors (including Vikram Seth and Arundhati Roy, among others) who have seized the attention of the literary world. But too often Tharoor gets carried away with his evident mastery of his topic, to the point that he can appear less intent on illuminating India's problems than on demonstrating his formidable intellectual prowess.
Readers are led through a parade of references to the intellectual and pop-culture icons of the age, from Octavio Paz to Steven Spielberg, from George Steiner to Patrick Swayze. In the realm of language, too, Tharoor sometimes appears to be reaching for effect. When he writes of Indians having a collective dream about the Nehrus and the Gandhis, the political dynasty that ruled for more than 40 of the 50 years since 1947, shouldering much of the responsibility for the country's failures, he tells us that Indians have a habit of lapsing into "oneirodynia."
I, for one, was stumped. A Concise Oxford Dictionary did not help, since the word does not appear in its pages. Tharoor's point, that Indians have a habit of slipping into a state of willful forgetfulness about the failures of their most famous political leaders, is an important one, casting light on the continuing obsession many Indians have with Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born matriarch of the surviving Gandhis -- but the reader might have been better served if Tharoor had said so in plainer English.
Still, against the sweep of all that Tharoor can tell us about India, these are quibbles. Unlike many Indians, who approached the 50th anniversary in a mood of despondency, Tharoor emerges as an optimist, setting out economic and political prescriptions whose adoption, he believes, can help India to "make the 21st century her own." Given the vast distance the country has to make up between itself and the most advanced nations of the earth, and even between it and some of its own near neighbors, and given the evidence Tharoor himself cites, this has to be taken as a triumph of hope over experience.
But at least Tharoor has not given up on democracy, despite the chronicles he offers of a political overclass mired in "venality, bigotry, dishonesty, incompetence and just plain criminality." Like many others, he sees evidence of real change in the turn during the 1990's toward a market-based economic system, with the effect that has had of stripping powers away from corrupt politicians and bureaucrats; and in the shift in power away from New Delhi to the Indian states, characterized by the emergence of the current Government of Prime Minister I. K. Gujral, which is not much more than a coalition of regional power blocs.
Beyond this, Tharoor sees the need for sweeping constitutional change, the abandonment of the current parliamentary system in favor of something more like the American and French systems, with an elected president directly accountable to the voters. But it is a solution that seems highly unlikely to be adopted by the current generation of politicians, who, as Tharoor has amply shown, have expended much of their effort in recent decades bankrupting the democratic system deeded to them by the generation of leaders who won the country's freedom.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 29; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: The High Cost of Owning

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle; Louis Uchitelle reports on economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:

HOUSING PARTNERSHIPS
 A New Approach to a Market at a Crossroads.
 By Andrew Caplin, Sewin Chan,
 Charles Freeman and Joseph Tracy.
 265 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 The MIT Press. $35. 
 America is, as everyone knows, a nation of homeowners. Nearly 66 percent of all householders own their own homes; as sociologists will tell you, homeowners make better citizens than renters, being more engaged in their communities. But home prices are rising faster than most incomes. And as they do, proposals emerge to help people find a way to buy houses who could not afford them under the present system. One approach gaining ground seems as improbable as the 30-year mortgage must have seemed in its early days.
The 30-year mortgage came into being in the Depression, when house prices were falling and banks refused to renew the five-year loans that were the traditional means of paying for a house. Today, the crisis is affordability, not credit. Fewer people under the age of 40 own homes than in the 1970's and 80's. Mortgages are easy enough to get, but paying them off consumes ever-increasing portions of family income.
So why not devise a system in which the homeowner is still the master of his domain but pays only 50 or 60 percent of a house's price? A limited partner, presumably a professional investor, shows up at the closing and pays the rest. That cuts the homeowner's cost in half -- to only $50,000 or $60,000 for a $100,000 home. Naturally, the mortgage is scaled back proportionately. Young families could save enough to afford homes sooner, and they would commit less of their monthly incomes to mortgage payments.
The limited partner gets his payoff when the house is eventually sold, presumably at a much higher price. And if the investor does not want to wait for the family to sell, or thinks home prices might go down instead of up, he can always sell his limited partnership on a newly created exchange, as if it were a share of stock. That new marketplace would probably need Government sponsorship, just as 30-year mortgages came into existence only after the Federal Government told banks that for qualified applicants it guaranteed repayment of the mortgages.
Housing partnership is not a new concept. As a perk, for example, some universities put up part of the money and retain partial ownership of a home purchased by a newly recruited professor. A few organizations construct single-family houses and then retain part ownership so the purchase price and carrying charge can be lowered for a family that otherwise could not afford a home.
Now, in a book titled "Housing Partnerships," three economists and an investment banker offer a detailed description and analysis of how a national system, open to everyone, might work in this country. The authors -- Andrew Caplin and Sewin Chan, economists at New York and Rutgers Universities, respectively; Charles Freeman, a vice president of Chase Manhattan Mortgage Corporation; and Joseph Tracy, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York -- are clearly evangelists. And even they point out that housing partnerships, however logical, might not work in practice, or even get into the discussion stage. "One of our deepest causes for concern," they write, is lack of a "political climate conducive to rational discussion of reform."
Nevertheless, this book has great value as an eye-opener, since it explains why home ownership in America is at another of those historic moments requiring innovative change. Whatever the political hurdles, the new direction appears to be toward some system of home ownership for people who do not pay the full price of the home.
Affordability is the catalyst in this process. Citing a great variety of statistics and studies, the authors note that the gap between home prices and incomes is growing at an accelerating rate. Young families buy homes at a later age than their parents because saving for a down payment takes longer. And, the authors say, as current trends continue, "a significant portion" of Americans may never have the means to own a house.
Mortgages are so front-loaded with interest payments that the slightest downturn in home prices leaves a family owing more than the house is worth. A $5,000 down payment on a $100,000 house means annual carrying charges of about $12,000 a year, including taxes and insurance. That is a considerable bite for the 60 percent of American households with incomes of less than $50,000 a year. Right now, the net worth of most couples consists mostly of their homes, leaving them short of money for retirement.
Reverse mortgages, in which banks send out monthly payments and are repaid with interest when the house is finally sold, have failed so far to catch on as a solution, either with the banks or the elderly. Housing partnerships might also meet resistance, particularly if the Federal Government failed to help in the creation and support of a market for trading the partnerships. And in some communities, these authors say, the Government might have to subsidize limited partners, who otherwise would be reluctant to invest. The payoff for the Government would be that the promotion of home ownership would resuscitate these communities, preventing their deterioration.
As for homeowners, the authors lay out a dozen reasons that they should welcome limited partners, not only for their investment but for their expertise. The limited partners could be particularly valuable in dealing with real estate agents, home inspectors and mortgage appraisers, who protect the interests of sellers rather than buyers under the present system. "The need to face the financially powerful and well-informed limited partner's scrutiny might greatly discipline" these agents, the authors argue in a frightening description of the home buying process that portrays the buying family as hopelessly vulnerable.
That chapter is easy reading. The rest of the book is not. It is pitched at the public but written as if it were a research paper. The charts are often hard to decipher, and the sentences too frequently slip into language, and algebraic symbols, familiar only to experts.
Skip these paragraphs, skip whole pages, but keep reading. Enough is understandable to make you come away converted, if not to housing partnerships, then to the realization that home ownership, to survive as a democratic institution, must somehow be recast.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Student Travel: The First Step

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
IT is shopping season for high-school student travel overseas for next summer. These days, it is also shopping time for children as young as sixth grade. Catalogues and applications arrive and are perused. Notices appear on school bulletin boards. Meetings are held. Families call other families about their experiences.
Parents have good reason to be concerned with good references. Unlike a summer camp, which you can visit, organizations that sponsor student travel may be just an amorphous 800 number. Adults may be unsure whom they are dealing with, even if a familiar teacher has signed on as a tour leader. Frequently, as families learn, a teacher is signing up after hearing from a colleague about a good experience a year, or even years, before. 
 But a company that got good reports on its trips may be taken over. So some trade organizations, including the new Student and Youth Travel Association of Sacramento, Calif., require applicants to show stable ownership over three years.
A rare resource for parents of high school students is the Advisory List published by the Council on Standards for International Educational Travel, an independent nonprofit organization set up at the behest of the State Department in the 1980's. The 13th edition of this booklet, just published, lists 64 organizations, both nonprofit and profit-making, that sought endorsement. All paid $1,100 to $13,000, depending on size, for evaluation. The council has rejected applicants, or given a provisional listing pending changes.
Seven listings were new this year. The majority of the groups sponsor foreign students on visits to the United States, some sponsor students' trips overseas and some do both.
Some exchange organizations are big, for example, A.F.S.-U.S.A., formerly the American Field Service, in New York, which operates in 62 countries and has been sponsoring exchanges since 1947. It sponsored almost 4,000 students in the last year. Other groups are tiny, for example, the Association for Teen-Age Diplomats in Rochester, which sponsored about 40 students traveling to and from Rochester last year. Some small groups use a listing in the book as an economical way to tell parents what they do, while demonstrating that they are accredited.
But the book also prints the standards by which programs are judged; this chapter can help parents appraise programs that may never have sought the organization's approval. The most crucial question is who has direct, hands-on control: Who will be responsible for the well-being of the children. Frequently, a sponsoring group uses a commercial operator to conduct the actual trips, and this is vital information. Parents need to be tough in questioning people who will take charge of their children on a trip that will inevitably involve the unexpected.
The advisory list is available by mail from the council, 212 South Henry Street, Alexandria, Va. 22314, for $15, which includes postage, plus 4.5 percent sales tax for Virginia residents. Phone inquiries, but not orders, may be made to (703) 739-9035.
 
The A.F.S. Program
In its 50 years, A.F.S. has placed more than 200,000 students and teachers with families in 80 countries. Sarah Morse, who worked for the organization for 15 years, said the organization and its vast volunteer network engender the sort of lifelong loyalty that colleges can. "When people see one of our A.F.S. T-shirts in an airport," Ms. Morse said, "they are willing to speak to utter strangers."
The organization runs semester, academic-year and summer programs. In the summer, there are basic home-stay programs, where young people 15 to 18 are placed with a family and, in the words of Janet Stark, a spokeswoman, "just hang out." Then there are four- to eight-week programs in which the visitors study the language, and six- to eight-week stays during which they also take an adventure trip -- camping, bicycling, rock-climbing.
The Americans do not travel in groups. Ms. Stark says the students are even discouraged from going with a friend, although sisters and brothers have gone together. The work in the host towns is carried on by community-based volunteers, although A.F.S. has a paid staff in New York.
Ms. Morse said her own experience as an exchange student in high school led her to work for the organization, which she still refers to as "we," although she is now an admissions officer for a school in Baltimore. "I stayed with a family in Belgium," she said. "They had a gas station. My parents thought I would be visiting the Louvre, but I was pumping gas. You learn a lot."
She said the growing-up on A.F.S. trips surpasses that on usual student tours because students get past the "everything is wonderful and new" stage and learn how to manage when things are difficult simply because it's not home. She said tests had shown that A.F.S. students became less materialistic and developed skills at thinking critically.
Last summer, 600 students participated in the summer programs in 20 of the organization's 62 host countries. The cost for the coming summer will be $3,000 to $3,900, including international transportation.
A.F.S.-U.S.A. has a Web site at www.afs.org/usa. Catalogues can be obtained from the organization at 198 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016; (212) 299-9000.
 
A Group Program
In contrast, the People to People Student Ambassador Program of Spokane, Wash., sends its students out in groups of about 30. They may be all from the same area, or if the numbers require it, from a couple of areas: say, students from Philadelphia and Boston. It has the largest number of outbound students in the Advisory List: it sent 11,000 students overseas last summer.
Over its history, starting in 1963, it has sent out 80,000 students. Doug Neil, head of the student program and director of marketing for both the adult and student ambassador programs, said that in the early years, the organization sent out only a few hundred yearly. Things began to boom 15 years ago.
The Student Ambassador Program has programs for children as young as sixth grade. Mr. Neil says that these programs involve more physical activity that those for older students: A trip to Sherwood Forest instead of a museum, for example.
One important aspect is a request to teachers and alumni to recommend students for inclusion, although this is not required. Recommended students get letters saying they have been nominated, with a quote from President Clinton about the student ambassador program. Mr. Clinton, like eight Presidents before him, is honorary chairman of People to People International, a nonprofit affiliate of all the People to People Ambassador programs, which touch many adult professions, teaching and the law, for example.
One parent who wanted to remain anonymous to protect her 13-year-old son's privacy, described his invigorating 21-day trip to Britain this summer. She said the "nomination" letter, which arrived unexpectedly, made a crucial difference. Her son, normally not a participator, was tremendously excited and the mother said she stifled her concerns. They attended regional meetings with their student team and leader, a youth worker in his late-30's from a local church who impressed the parents with his knowledge and travel experience.
The trip, in July, was a fabulous rite of passage for the youth, his mother said, although she wished there had been more home-stay opportunities. Generally, there are a few nights on the trip when the students stay with families with children, and may even attend school with them. Mr. Neil said the program changed destinations to avoid wearing out the Americans' welcome.
On the basis of a three- or four-page summary of the trip, which is sent to Eastern Washington University in Cheney, Wash., high school students can get credit for the trip.
The prices include air travel from the East or West Coast, housing in hotels or universities, plus brief home stays, three meals a day, bus travel from place to place, teacher leaders on the basis of 1 to every 10 students, local guides, health insurance and educational material. The total depends on destination and age, and ranges from $4,140 for a high school student going to Australia for 20 days to $2,990 for a sixth-grader going to Hawaii for 14 days. Cancellation insurance is extra.
The student program is a for-profit subdivision of Ambassadors International, a company headed by Peter and John A. Ueberroth that made a public stock offering in July 1995 and is now traded on Nasdaq. Most of the members of the new student travel trade association are also profit-seeking companies, and Mr. Neil said that he expected his organization would soon join.
A vice president of the new association, Earl M. Grossman, said that when it came to evaluating companies, an annual report to stockholders was good information, just as a nonprofit company's 501(c)3 data were. He said the ones he worried about were the companies that reported to no one and submitted no applications to trade associations.
Information on the Student Ambassador Program is available at www.studentambassadors.org or by writing to People to People Student Ambassador Program, Dwight D. Eisenhower Building, 110 South Ferrall Street, Spokane, Wash. 99202; (509) 534-0430.

LENGTH: 993 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Capturing the Flow of Life In War and in the Depression

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

 BODY:
AN exhibition at the Yale Center for British Art, "Humphrey Spender's Humanist Landscapes: Photo-Documents 1932-1942," charts the inexorable daily grind that can wear people down. Elsewhere in the New Haven museum the three large canvases that encompass the 19th-century painter John Martin's "Vision of the Biblical Flood" show humanity's dramatic trial by water.
The years encompassed by Spender's exhibition are, of course, years of economic depression and war. The photographer doesn't even attempt to glamorize these facts of existence. His photographs are so unrelievedly black and white that they seem almost sooty. But Spender's concern isn't the obvious plight of people. He searches out patches of sunlight. 
 His own emotional attitude toward his material doesn't really matter, the current demand that the British show their feelings notwithstanding. He aimed for objectivity, and in that regard he worked most of the time as a photojournalist.
Beginning in 1937 he joined Mass-Observation, a largely volunteer project whose aim was achieving an "anthropological study of our own situation." The immediate impetus was the national crisis of confidence caused by the abdication of King Edward VIII in 1936. M-O, as the project was called, was intended to help the British public regain its bearings through a presentation of facts gathered by watching people in all their activities. As time went on, the organizers of M-O inevitably came to disagree on what constituted facts.
The towns of Bolton and Blackpool, near London, were the site of most of Mr. Spender's Mass-Observation pictures. Some of them are of the smoky panorama of factory chimneys relieved by an occasional church steeple, but Spender evidently would rather mingle with the populace and catch the flow of life. Not much got past him. He recorded everyone, at home or at play, or doing chores. He documented people going to work, and unwinding after work, but he let others document the factory work itself. Sometimes he resorted to being a sort of spy, as with the diverse line-up of people at the bar in "Lambeth Walk, Feather's Pub"; one disdainful patron catches him taking the picture, but in another pub photograph a drinker waves at the camera.
Humphrey Spender is the younger brother of the poet and prose writer Stephen Spender, and was part of a group that included W. H. Auden and Christopher Isherwood. In their writing they were attempting to widen the circle and include broader social concerns in their stories or poems of personal drama.
While the other three men became major creative artists, Humphrey Spender applied the group's broad outlook to his pioneering of the documentary movement in Britain. But a strong fine art component often appears in Spender's work. It is an exhilarating sensation when a picture rises above gritty realism and become surreal. "Wash on the Lines, Bolton" is such a picture; billowing clothes, especially the plump pillowcases, become stylized clouds. Other photographs contain discrete words or phrases, parts of signs, that are at odds with the bleak scene.
The exhibition, organized by the independent curator Deborah Frizzell, includes much supplementary material, including paintings from the period, many by other members of Mass-Observation, that betray the same social awareness. One painting by Spender, of the foundations of a building, is surreal in its feeling of limitless monotony.
His wartime photographs are rather few in this show, but they naturally have a wider scope. In these heroic pictures, too, Spender favors the off moment, such as sailors acting boisterously in a pub and airmen between raids catnapping in armchairs.
The British Art Center will be closed throughout 1998 for repairs to its roof. It's tempting to think this action may be a reaction to John Martin's "Vision of the Biblical Flood" played out in three paintings exhibited together for the first time in this show organized by the Fine Arts Museum of San Francisco. That museum owns the becalmed third painting in the series, "The Assuagement of the Waters," while the portentous opener, "The Eve of the Deluge" belongs to Queen Elizabeth II. "The Deluge" itself, the middle work, is Yale's.
It was a 19th-century custom to present works of extraordinary size and with large themes like theatrical events and charge admission to view them.
The British Art Center reprises this in a teasing way: the paintings are in a room fronted by a red velvet curtain, and a dollar is charged -- but for the exhibition brochure. Viewing is free. A spectator will notice that there is no animal-filled ark; Martin concentrates on the unfortunates.
But his real subject was an acknowledgment of then-evolving discoveries in paleontology and geology and their possible agreement with the biblical story. Martin played the romantic artist to the hilt, yet he had rational underpinnings.
The wine-dark "Deluge," was painted first in 1834. The central drama is turbulence in the sky and on the land that is rapidly becoming sea. Humanity is subordinate to this, at least visually. If Martin was the de Mille of his day, as is often said, he favored the long shot. It is also said that he couldn't draw people, and most of the time he is content to sketch them in. One tantalizing incident in "The Deluge" is a snake and human body intertwined, reminiscent of Hieronymus Bosch. The stranded crowd are reminiscent of the survivors in Delacroix's "Raft of the Medusa."
The flanking paintings were done in 1840, and show the influence of Turner, particularly in their roseate skies. In "The Assuaging of the Waters" the viewer's eye rides easily on the creamy expanse of blue and white waves. Martin's abstract side -- catch the jagged lightening bolt in "The Deluge" -- might be his strongest.
"Humphrey Spender's Photo-Documents" continues through Nov. 9 while John Martin's "Vision of the Biblical Flood" ends Nov. 30.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Lambeth Walk, Feather's Pub," left, and "Bolton: Catapult Kids," above, are among photographs in an exhibition of Humphrey Spender's work in the Mass-Observation project. Bolton and Blackpool, near London, were the site of many of the pictures. (Yale Center for British Art); "Banana Frame Pyramid" by Julie An is part of Smithtown Township Arts Council's Asian Artists in America show.

HEADLINE: Benefit Events Gained Huge Sums

BYLINE: By RICK MURPHY 

 BODY:
THE dust from the benefit circuit in the Hamptons has finally cleared, and the results are in: the wildest, most successful season ever, proving again that the word nonprofit can be a misnomer.
"It was wild," said Ed Knight, an owner of Water Mill Party Rental, which handled a slew of affairs. "Everybody and their brother had their hands out." 
 "I call it 'The Checkbook Hamptons,' " said Joan Jedell, a photojournalist. "If you're not invited to one, you feel like you're not part of the 'in'crowd." For the guests, it may be a chance to schmooze and be seen, but for the organizations that are hosts to them, the benefits are a vital cog in their financial wheels. John Haigney, a vice president for the Long Island Association for AIDS Care, said fund-raising provided 25 percent of his organization's budget.
The success of the association's annual summer event, "Take Off," held at the East Hampton Town Airport, has stunned even the most jaded partygoers. More than 2,000 people paid up to $200 a ticket to dine in an airplane hanger and dance under a 14,000-square-foot tent to the sounds of the disco queen Gloria Gaynor.
"It's an enormous amount of work," Mr. Haigney said. "The thing that enabled us was the volunteer staff -- we had 150 people working. And the town was extremely cooperative." Though the association's party drew the largest crowd, Southampton Hospital may have won the award for the most funds raised -- $1.5 million.
The evening of dinner and dancing was called the Summer Party because "it's the party of the summer," said Mary Lynch, a coordinator of the event. "But it started back in January," after Lynette and Howard Gittis agreed to be co-chairs of the party, Ms. Lynch said. Ms. Gittis has wide-ranging charitable interests, and her husband, a Revlon Group executive, has wide-ranging social and business contacts.
"They had a party in New York, then in April Mr. Gittis had friends in West Palm Beach host another," Ms. Lynch said. With the contacts made at those events added to the list of regulars from previous years, "we knew we were going to sell out," Ms. Lynch said. As it turned out, 1,425 people paid $250 each to have cocktails under one huge tent and dinner under another, record numbers for the 37th running of the benefit. Ads in the Journal, which was underwritten by the Gittises, also swelled the proceeds.
"People have been very loyal to the hospital," Ms. Lynch said. Having Jean Remmel Little on the board of directors also helped. Ms. Little is well known as a highly successful fund-raiser for Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital and had been a mainstay of the Southampton Hospital efforts for a dozen years.
Scores of events were held last summer, and there will undoubtedly be even more next year. The Animal Rescue Fund, Guild Hall in East Hampton, assorted village improvement societies, the "All for the Sea" concert at Southampton College, opening benefits at the Elaine Bensonart gallery and dozens more all drank from the seemingly bottomless well.
The Water Mill "think tank" created by Robert Wilson had Lou Reed performing at a fund-raiser; Jerry Della Femina and his wife Judy Licht were hosts for a party for the East Hampton Day Care Center with a performance by dancers from "Forever Tango," a Broadway musical, in which Tito Puente and his band played. The Della Feminas were also hosts for an AIDS benefit for God's Love We Deliver, a food-delivery service in New York City, an event begun by the late James Revson. And the ringmaster from the Barnum and Bailey circus served as a master of ceremonies for a luncheon at Kay LeRoy's Amagansett house for the Pediatric Dental Fund, perhaps the most apropos appearance of them all.
When a group of Westhampton Beach residents formed at the beginning of the year to discuss creating a performing arts center there, they also found a community more than willing to aid them financially.
"Fund-raising is based on personal connections and tapping into certain circuits," said Len Conway, a vice president of the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center. "We got together and began phoning friends, and they started phoning their friends." The goal was to purchase an abandoned movie house and convert it into a venue for live events.
By spring, 80 people had agreed to become benefactors at a cost of $500 each. By May, 125 had signed on. By the beginning of the summer, there were 300. "It's important, and people are getting involved because they realize the only way it will happen is if they make it happen," Mr. Conway said.
Mr. Conway believes that second-home owners, many of whom are wealthy, are spending more and more time at their vacation homes, and thus are more aware of what is going on in their communities. Like others involved in fund-raising, he feels the robust economy plays a part. "We're having positive financial times and that often translates into greater generosity," he said.
Ms. Jedell travels the benefit circuit in search of celebrities to photograph. Familiar faces abound, some over and over. The actors Ben Gazzara, Roy Scheider and Billy Baldwin were regulars, she said, as was China Phillips and Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross. "People like her; she's very sociable," Ms. Jedell said. Donald Trump also made several appearances in the Hamptons, and Ronald Perelman, who once shunned such affairs, was seen quite a bit as well.
Linda Shapiro is a licensed fund-raiser and a special events coordinator. Needless to say, she had a busy summer. She said the trick to a successful fund-raiser was an integrated guest list. "It's not like eenie, meanie, mieny, mo," Ms. Shapiro said. "You try to find synergy between the sponsor, the event and the celebrities."
Ms. Shapiro has witnessed the scene take off over the years. "On any given Saturday night there were 10 benefits," she said. "We've grown out of yard sales. The elegant cocktail party is a bygone era. The smaller organizations must be sharp and trendy to stay competitive --- you have to do theatrical events."
Mr. Knight started out providing silverware, china, napkins and so on. "We don't even do tents now; we farm the whole thing out," he said. People want weird, and if it's weird we have it, everything from Clydesdale horses to fairytale type carriages." He recently did a wedding where the mother of the bride -- an actress -- had him erect huge see-through plastic sheets so guests could see the ocean without having to deal with the wind.
"I don't want to tell you what we charged her," he said. "We have a whole slew of trucks now. We go in at midnight and put the whole thing up and tear it down two days later." Among his clients: the Hamptons International Film Festival and the Bay Street Theater.
A whole closet industry has emerged -- waiters and busboys, bartenders, caterers, manual laborers, parking lot attendants and, of course, as Ms. Jedell said, "check writers."
While some annual events, like the Parrish Art Museum's "Midsummer Gala," reported record crowds, others, like the Rogers Memorial Library (both are in Southampton) opted to forgo a benefit this year.
"We concentrated on the passage of the bond vote," said Lyn Ashe, the director, referring to financing for a new library building that had become a controversial matter, failing to get the voters' nod on its initial go around. It passed this time, d, and Ms. Ashe said the library's gala was likely to return next summer. "We have a fun enterprise, and our basic price, $150 a ticket, isn't so high that local people can't come, but we also appeal to people in the social circle," she said.
The Parrish Museum charged anywhere from $250 to $600 a ticket, and also brought in a "significant" amount of silver benefactors, at $5,000 a person, and golden benefactors, at $10,000. "It was delightful," said Anke Jackson, an aide at the museum. "It was wildly successful. People care about our institution, they understand it's important, and they have fun." Next year, the museum's centennial, promises to bring "something special" to the benefit table, Ms. Jackson said.
The annual Back to the Ranch rock concert in Montauk did not materialize this year. The event, which has drawn as many as 10,000 people, was tabled after the Nature Conservancy, its chief benefactor, pulled out as sponsor. Though organizers vow to return next year, Conservancy members said privately that there was uneasiness over the discrepancy between the amount brought in and the amount dispensed to it and other nonprofit organizations.
There is a misconception that money raised at nonprofit events all goes to charity. Many organizations pay generous salaries to its administrators and hire professional fund-raisers who get a percentage of the money collected. Some event organizers said that caterers had made fortunes providing food to such events. Their donation, if any, may be 10 percent off their normal fees, they said.
Despite the success of "Take Off," Mr. Haigney said the event might not be repeated. Instead, the Long Island Association for AIDS Care is planning a 100-mile bicycle ride from Manhattan to Southampton next year. "It's important to change," Mr. Haigney said. "We want to go out on a high note. People get tired and want something new."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/West Chelsea;
Ex-Garages Attracting Art Galleries From SoHo

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE gritty industrial neighborhood of West Chelsea between 10th and 11th Avenues and from 20th to 26th Streets is sporting a new look these days. New owners are taking unused former garages and warehouses and converting them into art galleries in hopes of luring buyers from more established gallery locations.
Many of the galleries are moving northwest from their previous locations in SoHo. They are following a predictable economic cycle: artists needing space and light take over old industrial buildings whose days as manufacturing facilities are over. Galleries, which also need space and light, follow, changing the tone of the neighborhood to artsy from industrial. 
 With affluent art collectors walking the streets, restaurants start to open, attracting more people who may not collect art but like trying new restaurants. Then the mom-and-pop stores start to disappear and are replaced by brand-name retailers, who often combine several old store spaces into a one bigger store.
Competition among retailers for street level space drives rents up beyond the ability, or inclination, of gallery owners to pay. The galleries then have to decide if the location is so good that they can survive on the upper floors of a building or whether it is time to move.
So far, 39 galleries have set up shop in West Chelsea, mostly between 20th and 24th Streets. As many as 50 are expected within the next year or so.
Barbara Gladstone is a gallery owner who decided to move. She shifted her operation from Greene Street in SoHo to 515 West 24th Street. "My lease was coming to an end in SoHo and it did not make sense to stay there for another 10 years," she said.
She said the same problems that had driven her from 57th Street a decade ago had developed in SoHo. "I left 57th Street because it was too crowded and it was difficult finding places for trucks to park," she said. "It's the same way in SoHo now."
The new home of the Barbara Gladstone Gallery is in a converted garage building with garage-style doors in front, which makes it easy to move big works of art in and out. (It is also next to a working garage, Adolph's Trucking, which Ms. Gladstone said was convenient for having her car repaired.) Ms. Gladstone bought the building with Metro Pictures and Matthew Marks, each of which has 50 feet of street-level frontage in the 150-foot-wide building. The galleries opened late last year.
One of the attractions of the old garage buildings, which once serviced the trucks that made deliveries to and from a largely vanished garment manufacturing industry, is the wide expanses of column-free space.The first floor of the Gladstone Gallery is mostly open space, well lit by natural night coming through the glass-paneled doors. There is also an interior space for viewing video art.
On the second floor are offices, the gallery's library, a screening room for special clients and kitchen facilities.
"These are solid industrial buildings with integrity in their space, so we did not have to do much," Ms. Gladstone said. "We kept the facades intact and just sealed the floors."
JUST down the block is another old garage building that is about to be converted into space for the Luhring Augustine and Andrea Rosen Galleries. If the starkly finished Gladstone Gallery illustrates what can be done with garage buildings, the structure at 525-531 West 24th Street shows what the owners have to start with.
The concrete floors there are still stained and a loading dock dominates the back of the building. The skylights still have wire mesh glass that reflects the building's 1930's roots.
Nevertheless, Roland Augustine, a partner in Luhring Augustine, pronounced himself delighted with the structure, whose steel truss roof makes it possible for the interior space to be completely free of columns. As with the Gladstone building, the two galleries will split the frontage, and the loading dock will be removed so a mezzanine level can be built in the back.
In Mr. Augustine's side of the building, the mezzanine level will house offices, a conference room and a video display room, all divided by a wall from the main gallery. "We have learned that you need space that is separate from the main exhibition space," he said.
The old roll-up doors will be replaced by pivoting doors that will flip up as canopies over the sidewalk. Mr. Augustine said plans were to move the galleries into the building next April and to open in May.
Mr. Augustine said he was pleased to have street-level exposure, unlike his second-story location in SoHo, and to be away from what he considers to be the overcommercialization of that area. "There is so much bad, schlock art on the market there," he said of SoHo.
Indeed, brokers said that many of the gallery owners were tired of swarms of what are derisively referred to as "bridge and tunnel people" crowding the streets of SoHo during weekends. "The tourists go into the galleries, laugh at the art and don't buy anything," said Ruth Barone, a senior vice president with The Carlton Group Ltd. who has represented several gallery owners who have moved to West Chelsea. "They are, in effect, providing free entertainment, which real collectors don't need."
Ms. Barone said most galleries moving to West Chelsea were buying their buildings because the single-story garages were far more affordable than the multistory, cast-iron structures common in SoHo. Nevertheless, she said, prices were shooting up because of the increased interest in the area. "Single-story buildings are selling for $150 to $200 a square foot, depending on the condition of the building and the location," she said. Two years ago, before it became obvious that a critical mass of galleries was going to move to the neighborhood, sales prices ranged from $50 to $70 a square foot, she said. In SoHo, the buildings are usually so large that gallery owners generally cannot afford to buy them, brokers say.
In spite of rising prices in West Chelsea, Ms. Barone said, gallery owners continue to put together partnerships to buy buildings, rather than rent space. "The rental market has not caught up with the investment market," she said. "There has been very little leasing activity."
THE zoning of the area, which was formerly an adjunct of the garment district, has also been helpful, Ms. Barone said. Garment manufacturers were permitted to have showrooms in their buildings and art galleries qualify as showrooms.
The herd instinct appears to be at work as well among gallery owners, brokers said. "When Matthew Marks and Paula Cooper and Bonin Alexander moved in, they set off a land rush in the area," said Jed Garfield, who is with Leslie J. Garfield & Company. "A lot of people in SoHo saw these guys moving and decided they had to follow."
Most gallery owners agree that being in a location with many of their peers does boost traffic. But some say the neighborhood has advantages beyond the availability of ground-floor space at reasonable prices. "This is a nice walking area," said John Cheim, a partner in the Cheim & Read gallery on West 23d Street. "The streets are wide and you can see the sky instead of being buried in a canyon."
Jonathan P. Switzer, a senior managing director with the Winoker Realty Company, also attributed the outflow of galleries from SoHo to Chelsea to the fact that SoHo had become increasingly crowded and expensive. Mr. Switzer handles leasing for 568/578 Broadway, at the northeast corner of Broadway and Prince Street in SoHo.
"Prices are up 25 percent in the past two years," he said. "What had been a $14-to-$15-a-square-foot neighborhood has become a $19-to-$23 neighborhood."
He said that galleries selling mainstream art were generally still able to hold onto their ground-floor locations in SoHo but that others selling less widely accepted contemporary art were being squeezed out.
Mr. Switzer said Soho had the advantage of being near several major subway lines while West Chelsea was not well served by public transportation. But some of the relocated gallery owners in West Chelsea see this as a benefit, rather than a problem."Being away from the subways means the area is not conducive to retail," Ms. Gladstone said. "That way, the neighborhood will keep its character."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barbara Gladstone, left, in her gallery. She moved it from SoHo to converted garage at 515 West 24th Street, above. (Barbara Alper for The New York Times)
