HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
For Tinton Falls, a Vast Continuing-Care Complex

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
CONSTRUCTION of one of the state's largest retirement communities is to begin later this month in Tinton Falls. It will eventually turn 134 acres into a complex of 1,786 residences that will offer people 62 and older meals, services and health care at each stage of aging.
The first phase of the project, known as Seabrook Village, involves 92 residences and a 60,000-square-foot community center. They will be joined over the next four to six years by 1,694 more residences and two other community centers, which collectively will include six dining rooms and a medical center. There will also be a 240-bed nursing home and amenities, ranging from a health club to computer and crafts rooms to continuing-education classes and shops. 
 Seabrook Village will have 1,650 independent-living apartments, where residents capable of living on their own will get such services as housekeeping, transportation, social activities and one meal a day. There will also be 136 assisted-living units for residents who need help with daily living. They will receive all the services plus three meals a day. For those who need more medical attention there is the nursing home.
As is typical of many continuing-care retirement communities residents at Seabrook Village will pay an entrance fee that will entitle them to access to a1l levels, as well as a monthly service fee.
The fees are being targeted to middle-income residents "which is a solid and definitely underserved market," said Daniel Rexford, vice president of marketing at Senior Campus Living, in Baltimore, the developer. Financing for the $300-million project is coming from the company and its financial partner, a division of LenLease, an international developer based in Sidney, Australia.
Two years after the initial wave of independent-living units is built construction will start on the health-care component, either the assisted-living apartments or the nursing home, said Mr. Rexford, adding that since marketing began in April deposits had been taken on 85 percent of the first 92 units.
Elda and Benjamin Pinz, who have two grown daughters, reserved one of the initial units. The couple -- she is 72, he is 80 -- say they are ready to surrender the maintenance and chores tied to their single-family home in Marlboro. "We want to be independent," said Mrs. Pinz. "This is a way to leave our care to someone else rather than our children."
The Pinzes are among the growing number of older people who are seeking an alternative to nursing homes that offers care as they age, but avoids the regimentation of a medical setting. Stoking the trend are demographics and the desire by the aging to stay close to their families and friends.
With nearly 1.1 million of its 8 million residents age 65 and older, New Jersey has the ninth-largest aging population in the nation. The fastest growing segment of that population is people 75 years of age or older.
Those demographics attracted Senior Campus Living, which hopes to open up to five communities in New Jersey as part of its 10-year expansion program. The company is negotiating to build a second continuing-care development, a 1,400-unit project in Pequannock, in Morris County.
Seabrook Village is getting under way at a time when a spate of varying kinds of specialized housing for the elderly is also advancing in the state. The big surge is in assisted-living complexes, a relatively recent alternative to nursing homes. Beyond such services as dining and housekeeping, these complexes have staff on hand to help with daily needs like dressing and bathing and taking medications.
Since 1994, when the state started licensing assisted-living communities, 36 have been built and licensed and 234 more are in various stages of the approval or application process, according to state figures.
UNLIKE continuing-care retirement communities -- there are 21 in the state and two more are planned -- assisted-living projects do not offer three levels of care or guarantee access to each. But an entrance fee is not required.
Some communities that offer all levels of care, such as the Windrows at Princeton Forrestal in Plainsboro, also do not require entrance fees. Windrows is structured as rentals and a condominium "so residents have control of their assets while maintaining a continuum of care," said Michael Zaccaro, executive vice president at Care Matrix of Needham, Mass., the developer.
The project, which will have a medical as well as a community center, is rising on 45 acres in Princeton Forrestal Center, the mixed-use complex developed by Princeton University. It contains 180 nursing beds and 83 assisted-living units, with monthly rents, including all meals and services, of $2,350 to $4,000. There will also be 294 independent-living residences priced at $174,900 to $444,900. Monthly fees of $1,135 to $2,268 will cover all services and 30 meals a month.
Because of the rising number of options the growth of continuing-care retirement communities, which surged during the 1980's, has leveled off, said Barbara Kleger, president of Senior Living Associates, a Philadelphia-based marketing firm. "But the ones being developed tend to be well-planned and cater to certain niche markets," she said.
At Seabrook Village, the entry fee will be 100 percent refundable upon death or departure after the unit is reoccupied. The fees, which will range from $107,000 to $312,000, will be used to pay off construction costs and, later, to finance improvements.
There will also be a monthly fee of $1,167 to $1,172 for the studio to 2-bedroom independent units, which will have 625 to 1,414 square feet of space. For a second person there is an added $554 fee. For the 550-square-foot assisted-living units the fee wi1l be $2,200. The monthly fees will cover everything but advanced medical care, which residents will pay for as they need it, Mr. Rexford said. Those entering the nursing home will pay a "competitive" daily rate, he added, noting that it was too early to give exact figures.
"It is very reasonable for what the community is providing," Mr. Pinz said of the monthly fee, which he said was slightly more than what he and his wife pay per month to maintain their home. "But I will not have to worry about the washer or some other appliance breaking down."
Having so large a project allows the company to achieve certain economies of scale. But the size was a tough sell in Franklin Lakes and Wayne, where the company advanced earlier development plans that were derailed by local concerns.
But the Monmouth County community of Tinton Falls welcomes Seabrook Village, which will rise on Essex Road, a mile east of a point between Exits 100A and 102 the Garden State Parkway. "It is a self-contained community that will have little impact on municipal services, especially schools," said Anthony J. Muscillo, the township's Business Administrator.
From 1985 to 1995 the population of Tinton Falls rose to 15,000 from 8,000, prompting the expansion of three elementary schools. But the township did not see corresponding commercial growth, Mr. Muscillo said, adding that "this project will go a long way to keep real estate taxes stable."
Mr. Rexford said his company had bought the site, which was rezoned from office use, because of its size and highway access. Moreover, he said, a market study showed that 22,258 people age 75 or older live within a 10-mile radius of the site.
The independent-living units will be in 12 residential buildings laid out in 3 neighborhoods, each with 4 buildings around a community center. The assisted-living units will be in a separate structure, as will the nursing home. All the buildings as well as the community centers will be linked by enclosed walkways. Initial occupancy is scheduled for next fall.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Jersey City;
Now as Then, a Place for New Beginnings

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
FOR nearly two centuries, Jersey City, a short boat ride from Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, has served as a first American home for hundreds of thousands of immigrants. More than a fourth of its residents are foreign born, with large numbers from the Arab world, the Philippines, South America and the Dominican Republic.
But Thomas Gallagher, director of the city's Department of Housing, Economic Development and Commerce, notes that there has also been an influx of urban professionals. 
 "They take the PATH train from Exchange Place, near the waterfront, and are at the World Trade Center in Manhattan in two minutes," he explained.
Among those new residents are John and Kathleen Robinson and their 14-month-old son, John Jr. Two years ago the couple moved from a 3-bedroom, $2,100-a-month rental in Brooklyn Heights to a similar-sized apartment here renting for $1,300.
"That savings allowed Kathy to stay at home with our son," said Mr. Robinson, a lawyer who works in lower Manhattan.
A year later the Robinsons paid $208,000 for a renovated four-story brownstone in the upscale Hamilton Park area. But the Robinsons plan to leave the city before their son reaches school age, reflecting a concern over the troubled 32,000-student school system.
The system was taken over by the New Jersey Department of Education in 1989 following disclosures of widespread political nepotism in the appointment of teachers and supervisors. At the time, the city's elementary school pupils had placed 29th in the state's 8th-grade Early Warning Test for New Jersey's Special Needs Districts, 28 impoverished urban school districts designated by the State Supreme Court as having special needs. Those needs must be financed by the state.
"We have made progress, but still have a long way to go," said Dr. Richard A. DiPatri, the state-appointed District Superintendent of Schools for all of Jersey City. "We are now 14th among the Special Needs Districts. Our attendance rate has risen from 87 percent in 1989 to 91.4 percent last year."
Mayor Bret Schundler says conditions in other areas have also been improving throughout the city over the last four years. The unemployment rate has fallen by 3 percentage points to 11 percent, he said, and the number of jobs has climbed from 50,000 to 63,000, mostly in financial services and retail. And the city has bought a 26-block stretch of Martin Luther King Drive, the main thoroughfare cutting through some of the city's poorest neighborhoods, and leveled more than 100 boarded-up buildings.
IN their place, a new business and residential district called the Hub is to be built, with construction to start next month on a 50,000-square-foot supermarket and a post office. The cost of the whole project, expected to be completed by 2001, is estimated at $60 million in Federal, state and local funds.
Jersey City is a state-designated Urban Enterprise Zone, which means that shoppers pay half the normal 6 percent state sales tax. The tax revenue is returned to the city for the improvement of its business districts. Last year alone, the city received $18 million in sales-tax revenue, part of which is being used to redo sidewalks, street lighting and facades.
"Every major commercial area in town is now being renovated or is slated for major infrastructure improvement," said Nicolas C. Fargo, the Mayor's chief of staff.
Jersey City has long been a gateway to Manhattan. In 1804, Robert Fulton built his shipyard at Green and Morgan Streets and later established a 14-minute steamboat ferry service to Manhattan. In 1836, the Morris Canal was extended to Jersey City, bringing coal from Pennsylvania to fuel a growing industrial base. By the turn of the century, Jersey City was a booming industrial city of 206,000, with four railroad terminals -- the Erie, the Pennsylvania, the Lehigh Valley and the Jersey Central -- and a fresh crop of immigrants who had fled revolution in Germany and the Irish Potato Famine. In 1927, the Holland Tunnel was opened, giving the city a vehicle link to Manhattan.
Among the modern-day immigrants here is Adnan Kwara, a native of Syria who owns a small Middle Eastern restaurant and pastry shop in a century-old building on Grove Street with an original tin ceiling.
"My customers are as diverse as this city," said Mr. Kwara. "There are Arabs, Jews, Indians, Hispanics and other Americans." His wife, Amal J. Awad, a lifelong resident, likens Jersey City to a university.
"A walk down the street opens your mind," she explained. "I love it."
Minds are also opened at two public colleges -- Jersey City State College and the Hudson County Community College -- and the coed Jesuit St. Peter's College.
The 1990 census found that Jersey City had 90,723 housing units, most built before 1940 and fewer than a third owner-occupied. The most expensive area is Port Liberte, a 363-unit gated condominium complex on a finger of land that juts into Upper Newark Bay.
Laura Skolar, manager/broker at Century 21 Plaza Realty, said a 4-bedroom, 3-bath luxury town house there with a private boat slip recently sold for $425,000. One-bedroom units can be had for $110,000.
Close to Port Liberte is the 1.8-million-square-foot Harborside Financial Center on the site of a former rail terminal and Newport, a huge mixed-use complex that includes two office towers, a mall and five residential buildings with a total of 1,500 rental units and 445 condominiums. When completed, the riverfront complex with its views of Downtown Manhattan will include 9,000 residential units.
SOME of the better residential areas surround Hamilton and Van Vorst Parks and the Paulus Hook Historic District, where the first permanent white settler, Michael Paulusen, a Dutch trader, built his home in 1633 and started trading with the Communipaw Indians. One-family brick or brownstone rowhouses range in price from $125,000 to $170,000, according to Ms. Skolar.
A couple of blocks from the parks, housing prices decline sharply, with some single-family homes selling for as little as $75,000. Two-family houses in the three prime areas start at about $140,000. One recently sold for $264,000. Three- and 4-family houses start at $170,000 and range up to $300,000.
Ms. Skolar said most of the rentals are in small multifamily dwellings. One-bedroom apartments in prime areas command monthly rents of about $925, with some 2-bedrooms going for as much as $1,200. In other parts of the city, rents can be as low as $300 for a 2-bedroom apartment.
One- and two-family frame dwellings that practically touch each other in the Jersey City Heights, Journal Square and West Bergen sections are considered the middle of the market. Single-family dwellings in those areas range from $70,000 to $110,000, with two-families going for about $40,000 more.
In poorer areas, such as the Greenville and Bergen/Lafayette Section, abutting the 1,122-acre Liberty State Park, many new immigrant families are buying their first homes for as little as $40,000 for a one-family and $65,000 for a two-family.
Condominium apartments in small, converted rental buildings are bargains, Ms. Skolar said, noting that she had recently sold a 2-bedroom, 1-bath condominium apartment in Jersey City Heights for $40,000. She said the owner had paid $124,000 in 1987 when housing prices peaked.
Jersey City has a host of fine restaurants, including Casadante (Italian) on Newark Avenue in Journal Square, Laico's (Italian) on Pavonia Avenue, Komegashi (Japanese) on Montgomery Street and the Iron Monkey on Green Street, which serves a mixture of Continental and Asian food from a rooftop terrace overlooking Manhattan.
AS for the educational system, Superintendent DiPatri said 10 of the 30 elementary schools were outstanding and 9 perform dismally, despite the fact that spending per pupil is comparable to that of much wealthier districts.
As an example of an excellent school, Dr. DiPatri cites School 27, in which 100 percent of last year's eighth graders passed their Early Warning Tests in reading, writing and math. But School 27 has 28 students per classroom -- 6 above the state average -- and more than 70 percent of the students come from low-income households.
"I've made the principal of School 27 my executive assistant and started a no-holds-barred campaign to bring all of our schools up to her standards," Dr. DiPatri declared. "We will withhold salary increments from teachers and principals who don't improve the academic performance of their students. The parents of every at-risk student are being told that there will be no promotions for students who do not attend special summer programs."
The district's five high schools offer 16 advanced placement courses. The highest-rated secondary is the Ronald McNair Academic High School, which accepts the top 100 graduates from the city's elementary schools each year. Its dropout rate is zero and all but two of last year's 98 graduates went on to four-year colleges. On the SAT tests McNair's students had combined verbal and math scores of 1,104, which is 100 points above the state average.
A more typical Jersey City high school is the William L. Dickinson High School, which had a 14.3 percent dropout rate and average combined SAT scores of just 791.
The largest county-owned park here is the 273-acre Lincoln Park, with a multitude of playing fields and 21 tennis courts. The most widely used city-owned park is the eight-square-block Pershing Field off Central Avenue. It contains an ice skating/roller hockey rink, an Olympic-sized swimming pool, a jogging trail, four tennis courts, two basketball courts, two baseball fields and a refurbished playground.

About 3.5 million people visit the park annually. The major attraction is the $68 million Liberty Science Center, which has an Imax theater with a 125-foot screen and three floors of exhibits on the environment, health and inventions.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Hiring A Cleaning Service

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
MANY people who have read the notes tacked on the local supermarket bulletin board have considered hiring a cleaning person or cleaning service to help with household chores.
Unlike plumbers, electricians, exterminators and reputable home-improvement contractors, however, local house cleaners and cleaning services are generally not licensed and rarely belong to a trade association that can refer consumers to qualified practitioners and businesses. 
 As a result, hiring someone to help around the house is usually a hit-or-miss proposition. The best method, of course, is to ask someone you know to refer someone they know. Failing that, the options left are to consult the local Yellow Pages, keep an eye on the classified ads in the newspaper or read the notes tacked on the supermarket bulletin board.
"If you're looking in the Yellow Pages, the easiest thing to do is check the size of the ad," said Chris McLaughlin, vice president of McMaid Manhattan, a New York City cleaning service in business since 1971.
While such advice may sound simplistic and rather unreliable, Ms. McLaughlin said, it is at the very least an indication of how serious a company is about being in business.
"Those ads can get pretty expensive," she said, adding that a good advertisement will also contain information about services that are available and whether the company guarantees its work.
"You want to be sure you're dealing with a reputable business," Ms. McLaughlin said, adding that one way to determine that is to ask whether the company is insured and its employees are bonded. "It doesn't hurt to ask for a copy of their insurance certificate," she said, adding that for those who live in apartments, information about cleaning services working the building might be available from neighbors, front-desk personnel or the managing agent.
Another important piece of information to elicit from a cleaning service is the nature of its relationship with its employees.
"The first question you should ask is whether the company pays the employee and takes out taxes or whether it's your responsibility," said Martha Bourbeau, president of Custom Maid, another Manhattan cleaning service.
Some companies, Ms. Bourbeau said, are essentially employment agencies that provide independent contractors to customers. Generally, she said, the company is paid a fee for providing the cleaning person, but it is up to the customer to pay the worker. That, Ms. Bourbeau said, may be more trouble than it is worth for many people because of the tax issues involved.
"We think the customer is better off when the company pays the employees and takes care of things like taxes and Social Security payments," Ms. Bourbeau said. "I'm not saying there's anything wrong with companies that do it the other way, but who wants to be responsible for dealing with somebody else's taxes?"
When a new customer calls, most cleaning service companies will interview the customer over the telephone to determine what services are going to be required and how long it will take to perform them.
"I usually ask the size of the house or apartment, how many beds and baths, and whether there's laundry or ironing to be done on a regular basis," Ms. Bourbeau said, adding that the minimum charge for a one-time cleaning is $58.50. The charge is based on a three-hour minimum, she said, and should cover most studio and one-bedroom apartments.
Michael Podell, the owner of Maid to Order Cleaning and Maintenance in Jersey City, said that before he takes on a new customer, he prefers to see a house or apartment in person so he can give an accurate price quote. "I like to walk around the house with clients so I can show them what we'll be doing and what kind of work it will entail," Mr. Podell said.
"Usually, the initial cleaning is going to be a little more intense," he said, adding that he generally charges about $22 an hour for "standard" cleaning chores such as sweeping and washing floors, dusting tables, bookshelves, paintings, blinds and furniture, and cleaning kitchen appliances and bathroom fixtures. "And there's a difference between a cleaning and an organization," Mr. Podell said, explaining that customers can economize on cleaning service costs if the cleaning person does not have to spend time picking up clothes, stacking papers, reshelving books and moving objects from one place to another to clean under them.
Mr. Podell said that for most of his customers -- typically, homeowners in Hudson, Essex and Bergen Counties -- an average cleaning of an average house on a weekly contract takes about two hours because in most cases, employees are sent out in pairs.
One of the most significant concerns for those hiring a cleaning service is security. Indeed, that is why it is considered so important to hire a company that provides bonded employees.
Ms. McLaughlin of McMaid Manhattan explained that a bond is essentially an insurance policy that provides coverage for the illegal acts of an employee.
"If something is missing from your apartment, you want to know that somebody is going to be responsible for it," she said. In addition, Ms. McLaughlin said, customers should never be required to give a key for an apartment to a cleaning person or to the company itself.
On the other hand, she said, customers who do choose to provide keys should insure that the keys will be kept in a safe place at the company when not needed by the cleaning personnel. "When we hold keys to an apartment they're coded and secured in a safe," Ms. McLaughlin said, explaining that coding keys involves marking the key with assigned words or numbers and then keeping the customer's name and address in a separate secure location.
Ms. Bourbeau of Custom Maid said that customers in apartments who feel uncomfortable giving their keys to the cleaning service can usually leave the keys with the doorman or at the front desk when they are not going to be home. And some customers who have two or more locks on their door, she said, can give a key for just one lock to the cleaning service.
"You just have to make sure to leave the other locks unlocked on the day the cleaner is scheduled," she said.
Of course, not every cleaning service is willing to tackle everything.
Mr. Podell, for example, said that in most cases, he'll pass on doing laundry. "And ironing is a definite no-no," he added.
Ms. McLaughlin said that McMaid Manhattan bristles at doing windows. "We pride ourselves on doing esthetic cleaning," she said. "We like to do fine detail cleaning, like $45,000 tables and original Monets."
Ms. Bourbeau said her company would not only do laundry and ironing, but windows too. But there is a point where Custom Maid has had to draw the line. "One customer asked if we could wash his pet rabbit," Ms. Bourbeau said. "I had to tell him we don't do pets."

HEADLINE: Connecting Hartford and Its Neighbors

BYLINE: By STEPHEN L. PURDY 

 BODY:
CONTRACTORS have been chiseling out a new food court in the century-old Richardson Building on Main Street in downtown Hartford. Down the block, Fleet Bank and Aetna have renovated office space. Nearby, Main Street Market hums with vendors, farmers and entertainers, especially in milder weather.
Hartford -- having barely survived the 80's real estate collapse, a shift in store locations and the defection of a National Hockey League team -- is showing signs of repair. Still, many residents are cautious about the latest fixup's significance. 
 They remind themselves that Main Street Market stands on land where the Society for Savings bank demolished a landmark building in 1989, then scrapped their plans to put up a Cesar Pelli-designed skyscraper.
Many residents and businesses, arts and entertainment groups, government and regional councils want this revival to be the real thing.
For Connecticut's capitol city, traditionally ill-defined and caught in the shadow of New York City and of Boston, the key, they suggest, is that significant projects connect themselves to a region, with a core city at its center.
"When we talk about Hartford," says Joe Marfuggi, the executive director of Riverfront Recapture in Hartford, "we are talking about this region." Phil Dal Ponte, manager of Main Street Market, founded in 1992, and recently reorganized, said that as of late August the market was 85 percent rented and an incubator for small businesses. Its vendors sell food, clothing and flowers, and its farmers accept Federal nutrition coupons.
A West Indian food business called Apron Strings, which began in a stall and is still doing well, recently opened a restaurant nearby. Pat Evans, owner of Elma's Tropical Market, is encouraged. "Things are not as bad as they were a couple years ago."
And Leonid Natapov, a Russian immigrant who runs Market Flowers, says, "A lot of people want to come downtown, and it's because of the market." Meanwhile, farmers debate their success. Andy Caruso, of the Upper Forty Farm in Cromwell, says that, with Main Street Market as well as theaters and bars, Hartford is in an upturn with all its suburbs involved. He adds that among his customers are workers moving into Aetna's new office space across the street at State House Square.
Barbara Lerner, chairwoman of Business for Downtown Hartford and a board member of the newly-formed Main Street Market Corporation, says she feels the market serves city residents mostly, but the Deputy City Manager, Patricia M. Williams says the farmers make a connection between the region around the city and the city's residents. Since the market is at the hub of the regional transportation system, she said it would see increasing traffic.
This automatically places the market on one of the Capitol Region Council of Government's welfare reform initiatives: to carry city residents to jobs in the suburbs. Richard J. Porth, the council's executive director, says his council, which represents the 29-town capitol region, has been pro-Hartford and works on the whole region's concerns with the state legislature.
Mr. Dal Ponte says that the success of a mixture of customers is evident. At any time, he says, visitors will see city residents and suburbanites side by side.
With the summer's daily entertainment paid for by sponsors and running in about two or three sets every day on an outside stage, many customers would buy food from vendors and sit down in market chairs or benches.
Two city workers who said they visited the market three or four times a week, said they enjoyed lunch and the music there. On a wet day, a group of construction workers from State House Square were disappointed that the outdoor entertainment they enjoyed had been rained out.
Night life in the city is also far improved, Mr. Dal Ponte says, "So many people are down here."
More workers downtown are, in part, the result of Aetna's purchase last year of U. S. Healthcare. A spokesman for Aetna, Fred Laberge, said the company decided the first two floors of State House Square, which it had owned since its completion in the early 90's and whose mortgage it took back in 1996, was ideal for the overflow of employees from its Middletown office.
Mr. Laberge said that Aetna sees downtown Hartford as strong for employees' business and personal needs, for restaurant and banking services.
Consolidation of the retail portion from the first two floors to ground level was a related priority for Aetna; its grand reopening was Sept. 29. Now the shops are visible from the street, clustered together and more attractive to walk-in traffic.
George Kearnes, of the Natural Health Food Restaurant, agrees with the change and says it can only mean more customers. Sonia Baez, the manager at Nicky's News, says, "Actually, we've seen quite a few new faces." Aetna has moved in about 650 employees, with 100 more expected.
Philip Schonberger and Sam Fingold regard their renovation of the Richardson Building as another aspect of the block's renaissance. Mr. Schonberger says he sees an upturn in downtown Hartford's economy -- though not necessarily in construction -- and he thinks this project is still a worthwhile step. "Our goal was to be sure that one of the city's most spectacular buildings is preserved, in a useful state, for the long haul."
Mr. Schonberger is known for his caution. "He gives a unique perspective," says Steven D. Park, a member of the Hartford City Council and chairman of its planning, development and zoning committee. "Not only does he do business all around the United States, he now has invested in some major buildings here in Hartford."
Mr. Fingold says the Richardson Building reminds skeptics that such work can be done. "Hartford hasn't had a lot to be positive about in the last couple of years. You do these very small projects and hopefully it'll build momentum."
Indeed, the Hartford Stage's managing director, Stephen Albert, thinks downtown real estate may be turning a corner, though there is much work to be done. With a theater telemarketing operation already installed in the Richardson Building, he said the company was considering permanent rehearsal space in the building.
Mr. Albert thinks that arts are, indeed, one of the main reasons people are seeing Hartford more as regional. "What they're doing on a monthly basis is bringing hundreds of thousands of people to downtown. They're creating energy and economic development, including jobs."
Fleet Bank officials hope that repairs of a more practical nature at its 777 Main Street office, will also be appreciated. A Fleet spokesman, Jim Schepker, said the company has taken up sidewalk surfaces to stop water from seeping into the building, then put in newly-designed and landscaped sidewalks. Mr. Schepker, whose office overlooks Main Street Market, says he thinks big changes are happening in the neighborhood and city.
"This summer has been particularly exciting there," he says, pointing to the market. "The crowds are larger, the entertainment's more diverse, and there's just generally a feeling of Big City." He said he was encouraged by the food court and office space at State House Square. "That building is going to be very occupied," he said.
Regardless of Main Street's view of itself and its importance to the region, most involved in its development agree that the now-emerging Riverfront Park System, centered just east of downtown on the banks of the Connecticut River, is the strongest symbol of the city's revival, and most connected to regional initiatives.
The system, created by Riverfront Recapture (a nonprofit corporation supported by a public/private partnership), is a mixture of parks and riverwalks, cruises and rowing, adventure training and fishing, concerts and festivals. The park system's director, Mr. Marfuggi, sees the river, as a critical link rather than part of a barrier between Hartford and East Hartford and to surrounding towns as well.
"We're now bringing in at least one major national sporting event a year," he said. He cites the U.S. Rowing Association's 1997 national convention and a championship bass fishing tournament.
Barbara Lerner, of Business for Downtown Hartford, says she feels the leadership "clicked in" when Michael P. Peters was elected Mayor in 1993. Ms. Lerner says Mr. Peters made the critical connection with people. "We have a mayor now," she says, "who made it clear, during his first year in office, that he was interested in having a more regional view. He went out to Jaycees, Rotaries, morning talk groups in all the surrounding communities, saying, 'You all have to be a part of Hartford.' "
The Mayor's office agrees. Paul Shipman, Executive Assistant, says Mayor Peters's approach is to invite people to come and enjoy the city, while simultaneously educating governments to accept the concept of regional cooperation.
"You can have a concert on the green in your town," Mr. Shipman says, zeroing in on the Mayor's energy toward arts in the city. "But do you have 20 venues that you can pack together and people can actually walk to?" Urban and regional development requires a commitment to education as well. The Hartford Consortium for Higher Education's goal is to create a downtown collegiate center, anchored by Capital Community-Technical College and combining resources with at least 10 other institutions. A principal recommendation by a mayoral task force on higher education was to increase interaction among higher education and the business, health care and arts sectors of the region.
What the region needs, says P. Anthony Giorgio of the Capitol Region Growth Council, is an overall plan for development, especially in the area of building the economy.
The Growth Council, which is private and nonprofit, is supported by each of the 29 towns in the capitol region, large and small companies, and local chambers of commerce. The council has developed the MetroHartford Millenium Project, which sets out to develop a strategic direction for the capitol region. "We will have a universally accepted direction," says Mr. Giorgio.
The Growth Council's concern about an active plan is corroborated by Robb Hankins of the Greater Hartford Arts Council, creator of the arts arm of the Millennium Project. "To effect change," Mr. Hankins says, "we're going to stay focused on the five or six major initiatives that come out of Millennium."
At the very least, Hartford appears to be moving. James P. Denno, the owner of DJ's Deli at State House Square, echoes the universal hope: "We're looking forward to it happening, big time."

HEADLINE: In the Workplace, Power and Sex

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS 

 BODY:
SEXUAL harassment is an old story to several women who gather every other week in the office of a psychologist, Dr. Barbara Moynihan, in Branford. They talk about incidents that have left them feeling abused, angry, and, in many cases, unemployed.
The women say they are victims of sexual harassment and they are suing companies where they have worked for 8 to 15 years. Though such harassment affects both men and women, overwhelmingly it is women who are subjected to unwanted comments about their bodies as well as to jokes, touching or advances sexual in nature. And the Yale study makes a point of the detrimental effects of even seemingly minor incidents. 
 Sexual harassment is an abuse of power that is expressed sexually. As defined by law, it must affect the complainant's pay, benefits, working conditions or work environment.Various polls and studies indicate that between 44 percent and 68 percent of women report being sexually harassed on the job; the latter figure came from interviews with 300 female employees at Yale University, in a study made public last month.
According to a 1991 study by the Connecticut Women's Education and Legal Fund, 21 percent of women complainants in Connecticut quit their jobs; 19 percent were fired or laid off, and 30 percent took sick leave. A 1992 study by the National Organization for Women found that 90 percent of the victims were unwilling to take action against their harassers for fear of retaliation and loss of privacy.
Those fears are well founded, the women in the support group say. That's because, unlike the progress made in court proceedings by rape survivors over the past few decades, victims of sexual harassment have no such protection in court. The private lives of rape victims, including past behaviors and mode of dress, can no longer be brought up by defense attorneys in an attempt to discredit the accuser.
The women in the support group say they have found that when they take an alleged harasser to court, their entire lives and the lives of their families become public. That, they say, is a powerful deterrent to filing charges.
Last year the Connecticut Women's Education and Legal Fund published a 44-page booklet called "Sexual Harassment in the Workplace." It includes statistics, myths about harassment, a description of the pertinent state and Federal laws, and how victims of harassment can get help.
The Connecticut Human Rights and Opportunities Act prohibits sex-based employment discrimination and the law applies to all employers with three or more workers. It requires companies with 50 or more employees to provide supervisory workers with training on the laws regarding sexual harassment and the remedies available to victims.
Federal civil rights laws also apply. Under the Civil Rights Act of 1991, victims may sue for back pay, compensatory and punitive damages, and may demand a jury trial.
Dr. Moynihan says she started the support group in 1993, "based on the calls I was getting about sexual harassment." She continued: "A woman continues on the job almost as a hostage, because she never knows when her harasser will make a move. The fear of harassment and the harassment itself affect her performance. It's relentless, it's coercive, so it begins to chip away at self-esteem, competence, the ability to eat and sleep.
"The frequency and the trauma associated with it is so significant that I thought it would help reduce the women's sense of isolation and create a safe place to share their stories, to share resources and be there for each other."
One member of the support group told how she'd worked as a senior product manager for a manufacturing company for seven years, getting bonuses and commendations for her efforts, when the harassment occurred. "In my case," she said, "a stupid conversation carried on by a vice president at a sales meeting was extremely embarrassing for me. A week later he started penalizing me. I was told by the harasser in my review that it was my fault, that I had made 10 men uncomfortable."
She said that when it became obvious that her boss wanted to get rid of her, she went to the president of the company and to a human resources manager and tried, for more than two years, to work things out before consulting a lawyer. Waiting that long was a big mistake, she says now. "Retaliation has been the worst part: creation of a hostile environment," she said. The woman also said she blamed the company more than the harasser: "You will always run into jerks," she said, "but they would have no power if the companies didn't back them."
In Connecticut, sexual harassment complaints are filed with the Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities. Between 1990 and 1994, the percentage of sexual harassment complaints nearly doubled, to 10.4 percent of all employment complaints.
But the women in the support group are unanimous in saying that the commission is not an advocate for them. "It seems the C.H.R.O. is there to minimize the risk to the companies," said one woman. "We cannot file a lawsuit until we have gone through C.H.R.O. I filed a complaint and 18 months later they had done nothing.
"There are no advocates for us except for ourselves and our therapists," she continued. "The companies want us to disappear. Our families and friends want us to minimize our pain and walk away from this. Our lawyers want to get this over quickly and minimize their work, so they push for low settlements. If we publicize this we will never be hired by another company again."
If a woman sues for emotional distress, the company's lawyers can ask questions about her or her family's life that most people would regard as too personal. "The companies' defense against us is that we are sluts, nuts or golddiggers," says another member of the group. "The system helps them by allowing the companies to question every aspect of our personal lives -- our medical histories, our sex lives, our finances -- things which have no bearing on the crime committed against us. After being mentally, financially and physically abused on the job we are subjected to further abuse in depositions and on trial. The process goes on for years until we are drained."
One of the most frustrating aspects of filing a complaint, many of the women say, is that lawyers for the companies and company representatives deny any harassment took place. And in a company's defense, the women say, representatives repeat myths like women having no sense of humor or misinterpreting behavior meant as a harmless joke, or that women make false charges to get even or to get ahead.
It's taken five or six years for most of the cases in the women's support group to go to trial. In that time many have strained their emotional and financial resources to the breaking point. "I have been to foreclosure court three times since I was fired in 1993," says one woman. "I have been on welfare and food stamps. I have sold family heirlooms."
One woman who wants to go public said she hoped her story would be a cautionary tale for other women. Fatima Silva, of Monroe, sued her employer after she was fired for insubordination, as a result, she says, of blowing the whistle on fraudulent sales practices and then resisting her boss's sexual attentions. She says the harassment made her suicidal. "I went to Portugal with my daughter. I was going to explain to her to be careful. Then I was going to put her on a plane and I was going to commit suicide." She returned and filed a complaint with the Human Rights Commission against her former boss and the company, New York Life Insurance Company, charging wrongful termination, retaliation and defamation. A lawyer in New Haven representing the insurance company, George O'Brien, says: "There was no retaliation against her, and the proceedings of the C.H.R.O. clearly established that. She has brought four Federal lawsuits in Connecticut. They are consolidated and are proceeding. She also has a state lawsuit against New York Life, which is pending in State Superior Court. In addition she has filed complaints with the State Insurance Commission, the State Labor Department and the C.H.R.O., and she has filed other lawsuits in New York. She is engaged in a broad vendetta against the company which has nothing to do with the facts of her case."
All the women in the support group are pursuing legal claims against their employers or former employers. Both state and Federal law require that complaints be filed within six months.
Dr. Moynihan, who works with survivors of sexual assault and domestic violence, says "the Yale study supports what we already knew -- that most women who work in institutions that have traditionally been male-dominated experience sexual harassment."

LENGTH: 1070 words

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:

Cash Keys for Meters
Borrowing a page from New York City's book, White Plains now has a version of E-Z Pass, the electronic toll collection system, for parking meters. 
 Under the cash key system, which is being used by 13 other cities in the country, drivers will not have to use quarters to park in metered spaces when they shop or catch the train to Manhattan. The city, the first in the New York metropolitan region to introduce the system, expects to have some meters outfitted for cash keys this month and others by early next year.
"This is the future of money in the parking industry," said Albert T. Moroni, executive director of the White Plains Parking Authority. "There's no need to carry cash."
A cash key is a special debit key resembling a car key, and drivers will be able to prepay from $10 to $125 worth of meter time.
Mr. Moroni estimated that it would save the city's Parking Authority as much as $30,000 a year in reduced labor costs for handling coins and maintaining meters. Collectors now take in $4.6 million in coins -- about 120 tons -- a year. Of the city's 11,500 parking spaces, 8,000 are metered. Of those, 1,500 have new electronic parking meters, which will accept cash keys. The city will eventually replace all of its older mechanical meters with the electronic ones.
 
Health Center Cuts Ties
The Greenburgh Neighborhood Health Center has chosen to operate independently of the county, a move that its board of directors expects to lead to more and better services for its 12,000 patients. In addition, the health center has teamed up with the Mount Vernon Neighborhood Health Center to combine purchasing, billing and other services.
The Mount Vernon clinic, which separated from the county about 12 years ago, has since tripled the size of its staff and the yearly number of patient visits.
Robert Mauro, chairman of the Greenburgh clinic's board of directors, said a freestanding health center would be able to become part of a variety of managed-care plans. As a county agency, it was limited to two plans approved by the county's Department of Health.
"We can now accept all third-party payers for the first time and hope to attract new patients by offering competitive costs for basic services," Mr. Mauro said.
The clinic receives about $700,000 a year in Federal funds, about one-fourth of its $3 million annual budget. In addition, the county will continue its annual $1.2 million in aid to the clinic for another year.
The center has been providing primary and preventive health care for the working poor, the uninsured, Medicare and Medicaid recipients, the unemployed and the homeless since 1972.
 
More Minority Officers
Under pressure, Police Commissioner Donald P. Christopher of Yonkers has announced a drive to recruit more women and minorities.
Last month, when it hired 35 officers and only one was black and another Hispanic, the Yonkers Guardians Association, a 24-member group representing black police officers, objected, Detective Vincent Tilson, vice president of the organization, said.
And because some of the recruits were relatives of former and current police officers, several of those who were not accepted on the force complained of favoritism, a charge the department denied.
The Commissioner has appointed a recruitment team of seven minority and two non-minority officers, said Lieut. Lorenzo Paul, a department spokesman. Mr. Christopher has also appointed a minority civilian advisory board -- a rainbow coalition, Lieutenant Paul said -- to help the recruitment drive.
Both boards will encourage minority candidates to take a Dec. 6 Civil Service test. There are 566 officers in the police department, of whom 467 are white men.
 
New Trailway Center
The county has announced plans to open a recreation center at the site of an abandoned stone restaurant along the Saw Mill River Parkway in Arsdley next to Woodlands Lake and the old Putnam Railroad right of way. County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Planning Department and the Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation plan to use the stone structure -- which was built in the 1920's -- as a cafe and rental outlet for boats, bikes, in-line skates and fishing gear.
The $1.6 million project also includes a proposal to connect the center with the proposed South County Trailway, which will run along 5.6 miles of the right of way.
The site was formerly occupied by the Cantina and Roadhouse restaurants, which have closed. But as Mr. O'Rourke said, "Over the past several years there has been a growing concern about the viability of a restaurant on this site because of the difficult vehicular access from the Saw Mill River Parkway." He said an alternate route to the site would be developed along the trailway.
A paved terrace for family picnics will be built at the former restaurant site, and picnic tables will be installed. The plan also calls for a food concession. Woodlands Lake will be dredged for boating, fishing and nature studies, and there will be a nature and hiking trail around it.
 
Flu Vaccines
Flu vaccines are available at 43 clinics in the county through Nov. 12. With three strains of flu expected this year, the Health Department is recommending the vaccine for those who may be at high risk of complications from the flu, including residents older than 65, people with chronic diseases and employees of health care institutions.
The vaccine is aimed at combating the A/Johannesberg, A/Nanchang and B/Harbin strains of flu, the department said.
Dr. Ada Huang, the county's Deputy Commissioner for Disease Control, said the following people should consult their doctors before receiving the vaccine: those who are pregnant, are allergic to eggs, have a history of serious allergic reactions to the flu vaccine, have an acute febrile illness or have had attacks of Guillain-Barre Syndrome or of other neurological illnesses.
"Now is the best time to schedule your influenza immunizations, well before the flu arrives in Westchester," Dr. Huang said, explaining that the vaccine takes a few weeks to reach its full protective effect.
The flu season usually begins in late October and runs through April.
The shots are covered by Medicare; otherwise there is a $10 fee. Information on clinic dates and sites is available from the the county's Office of Citizen Services, 285-2170. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: The View From: Norwich;
A New Beginning For an Old Port City

BYLINE: By STACEY STOWE 

 BODY:
THE specter of Norwich's 18th- and 19th-century past, when the city bustled with merchant ships bound for the West Indies and hummed with textile mills, dwells in the minds of people eyeing its future.
From Ron D. Aliano, who spent more than $12 million transforming the city's harbor from an abandoned coal distribution point into a marina and recreation area, to two elderly sisters who own Fagan's, a closet-sized newsstand on Main Street, the city reflects its glory days. 
 Perhaps it is because the architecture of the city has been largely untouched. Many of its streets are lined with once majestic Victorian buildings and stately private homes, the legacies of its prosperous native sons who centuries ago made their names and their fortunes from Norwich.
A few years ago, people in the city said there was a palpable sense the past was all Norwich had. After World War II, mill operators started moving South and prosperity began to slowly slip away.
By the 1960's and 1970's, the city had become a hub for the disenfranchised and impoverished; patients released from the Norwich State Hospital, a center for the mentally ill, often settled in the city. The hospital, which once served 3,000 people, closed in 1996.
But Norwich is now in the midst of an intense revitalization effort with its main focus aimed at increasing tourism. As part of a a $230,000 streetscape project, sidewalks are being bricked and old-fashioned street lamps installed. Antiques shops and restaurants are moving into the empty Victorian buildings downtown. Hotels and apartments are being built.
Two museums and a botanical garden are planned. A 44,000 square foot ice skating rink was built. A high-speed ferry service between New York City and Norwich may be operating soon.
Why the current burst of activity for a city that has been flagging for close to 50 years? City officials and residents agree it certainly has something to do with Foxwoods and Mohegan Sun, two casinos a few miles from downtown. Hundreds of thousands of people pass through Norwich on their way to gamble. But there is also a strong sense that the city could be more than just a stop on the way somewhere else.
The Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, which owns Foxwoods in Ledyard, is building the Sassacus, the ferry that will twice a day bring passengers from New York to Norwich in two and a half hours before they are bused to Foxwoods. Casino employees are trained in the Lightolier Building in the Norwich Industrial Park.
The tribe is also poised to spend $20 million downtown, building the Mercantile Exchange, a 150,000-square-foot commercial and retail building that will also contain apartments. A block-long stretch of buildings will be razed to make way for the project but the tribe plans to replace them with period-style architecture and perform an archeological dig at the site prior to excavation, said Bruce MacDonald, a spokesman for the tribe.
In the late 1980's, Mr. Aliano, who owns an ambulance company, decided to invest in the city's harbor, citing the site's potential and its history as a shipping center in the 19th-century. "I looked out the window and saw a wasteland," he said. "It was a travesty when you consider the history, what Norwich was."
Mr. Aliano has built boat slips, a banquet site, restaurant and miniature golf course that includes a 40-foot erupting volcano, and he said he was considering a hotel and footbridge from the marina to the city's downtown.
Norwich has recently finished a $1.2 million facelift of the exterior of the city hall, which dates to 1873. An interior renovation is now underway.
"It's a long process to redefine your image," said Margaret Malmborg, the city's director of tourism. She said the new projects and street improvements would create a sense of charm that should cause people to linger in the city.
The Konover Hotel Corporation is planning to restore the Wauregan Hotel, a 60,000 square- oot building that dates from the mid-1800's. Once an elegant, luxury structure, it served until five years ago as housing for people on welfare, until it was condemned by the city as a fire hazard, according to Colin P. Brogan, coordinator of economic development for Norwich. Faded murals advertising the Wauregan still adorn the brick sides of some buildings downtown. (The renovation is expected to create between 50 and 75 jobs.) Three other hotel projects have been built or are under consideration.
The prospect of more jobs from the development pleases Beverly Goulet, the director of social services for the city since 1984, but she says she is concerned about the ability of $6- and $8-an-hour service jobs to support families who once held jobs with the area's military contractors that paid between $18 to $22 an hour.
"Southeastern Connecticut was the most defense dependent part of the state," she said. "We're seeing enormous stresses on families who, when they do find employment, need to work two and three jobs just to keep their heads above water."
Ten years ago, 18,500 people worked in the Groton shipyard of Electric Boat, the submarine builder; today 8,500 are employed, said Neil Ruenzel, spokesman for the company.
The unemployment rate in Norwich hovers at about 6 percent, higher than the state average of 5.2. Some 5,000 Norwich families live at or below the poverty level, Ms. Goulet said.
Despite being ranked among the poorer cities in the state, Norwich students have scored at or above state averages on the Connecticut Mastery Tests for at least the past two years. Suzanne Murphy, curriculum director for Norwich Public Schools, said that about 44 percent of the 4,300 students in kindergarten through eighth grade receive free or reduced-price lunches.
"America's Living Time Capsule," is the working name for a 44,000-square-foot museum proposed for downtown. The $9 million building will trace the history of the world from the geological land formations to the present day using Norwich as its model, said Margaret S. Wilson, a local historian and one of 17 civic leaders developing the museum. A state grant for $2 million was secured to renovate the two historic buildings, which were donated by the city and are between Main and Water streets.
Ms. Wilson, who has encyclopedic knowledge of the city's history and enjoys ticking off the long list of its famous natives (from Samuel Huntington, first president of the Continental Congress to William Darrow, who isolated the AIDS virus) believes the city's revitalization will be as an arts and cultural center.
"I never thought it would come back as a shopping center," said Ms. Wilson, who was born and raised in Norwich and who, like the two women who own Fagan's newsstand, remembers when the streets downtown were so crowded that one had to step off the sidewalk to avoid the bustle. Bookstores, antiques shops, art galleries, restaurants, a movie theater and toy store are the businesses she believes will ultimately thrive downtown.
In capturing tourist trade, Norwich's advantage is its authenticity, according to Ms. Malmborg. Because much of the development over the years bypassed the city, Norwich retained much of its original architecture.
"Mystic and Sturbridge are wonderful re-creations of period villages but in Norwich we're not copying or re-creating something. You see it as it looked," Ms. Malmborg said. "It's not all shiny and clean but it's real. You see the dirt under the fingernails in a town like this."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Renovations will preserve a city's architecture. Left, "Norwich Now" sets the tone. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
A Leasing Pickup on the Brooklyn Waterfront

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
LARRY FOX, the owner of a small Brooklyn company that distributes paper products to party-supply stores, grew up in Flatbush but until recently had not been near the waterfront in Sunset Park in 10 years. He had been storing goods in Kearny, N.J., although he garaged his trucks on Neptune Avenue in Brooklyn, and he was looking for a place in which to consolidate operations.
"The last thing I remembered about the area was gangs," he said. "But I came on a Saturday and I was amazed at the amount of business coming in." 
 Now Fox Paper is part of the quiet, steady transformation that has brought broad occupancy gains to the industrial property on the three-mile stretch from 17th Street to 65th Street, between the Gowanus Expressway and Upper New York Bay, which has been designated the Sunset Park In-Place Industrial Park. The recession in the early 90's had put many smaller companies out of business or into bankruptcy.
There is an estimated 75 million square feet of space in the area's industrial buildings, much of it in major properties like Industry City at Bush Terminal, which Irving T. Bush developed as Bush Terminal between 1910 and 1922, and the Brooklyn Army Terminal, which the city now owns and operates.
But for a sense of how small or even start-up companies are using the area, there is no better place to turn than the property where Fox Paper took 35,000 square feet in December. The property is called Harborside -- a million square feet mainly in four large buildings on 90 acres between 42d and 50th Streets from First Avenue to the water.
Once the property was part of the Bush Terminal operation, but about 30 years ago the operating company at Bush Terminal turned over its uneconomic, dilapidated piers and their support facilities to the city, which has owned them ever since. For the last decade, Dominick Massa, a trucking company owner who is the former chairman of the Southwest Brooklyn Industrial Development Corporation, has operated the onshore property associated with the now-defunct pier operation through the Harborside Management Corporation on a long-term lease from the city.
Both Mr. Massa's parents worked for the Ann Page division of of A.&P. 45 years ago, which made private label products for the store chain and was a major tenant at Bush Terminal. Two of the products were chocolate and macaroni. "My father worked in starch," Mr. Massa said. "My mother was in chocolate."
Occupancy was "almost zero" in the city-owned buildings when he took them over, Mr. Massa said. It reached about 45 percent a little over two years ago and is now at 85 percent. Rents are about $3 to $3.50 a square foot a year.
The biggest factor in the recent upsurge was the elimination of the city's tax on commercial tenants, which was 6 percent of their annual rent, Mr. Massa said. The Giuliani administration eliminated the tax in 1995 for all parts of the city except most of Manhattan south of 96th Street. As of June 1, it was eliminated in Manhattan as well for tenants paying under $100,000 a year. For those paying more than $100,000 (after allowable adjustments), the tax is 4.5 percent.
"For a 50,000-square-foot tenant, it was a lot of money," Mr. Massa said. "Ninety percent of the tenants I spoke to used to wind up in Jersey because they refused to pay the tax."
Another improvement in the last few years has occurred in the private carting business, Mr. Massa said. "The carters used to come in here and tell me, 'Here's your charge,' " Mr. Massa said. "And the pickups were sloppy. Now there's competition. There are 15 carters, not one. I get bids. I negotiate prices. The streets are cleaner."
There are still vacancies, mainly on the upper floors of the large multistory buildings that account for 800,000 square feet of Mr. Massa's space. But Harborside was the locale chosen by Borough President Howard Golden in August after he decided to spend $300,000 of his budget allocation to create a "Brooklyn Garment Manufacturers Incubator."
A section of the fourth floor of a Harborside building at 43d Street and First Avenue, with 30,000 square feet of space, will be renovated into modern space for garment tenants starting next month. "It's not for startups and they don't have to be operating in Brooklyn," said Kenneth Adams, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, which is managing the program. The base rent will be less than $2.50 a square foot, Mr. Massa said, though tenants will pay additional amounts for special financial, technical and computer services.
At the Brooklyn Army Terminal property farther south, tenants are somewhat larger and pay more rent. But there, too, occupancy is up. In Building B, with two million square feet of space, it is at 90 percent, higher than at any time since the building opened in 1987, the city's Economic Development Corporation says. Asking rents are about $4.75 a square foot for upper floors.
THE first two floors of Building A, with 400,000 square feet of space, were rehabilitated in a subsequent construction phase and were ready for occupancy in 1994. They are fully leased. The rest of the million-square-foot building has yet to be renovated. "Many tenants left or went out of business in the early 90's," said Leo Greco, the leasing manager, echoing Mr. Massa. "From 1993 on, there has been a gradual increase in arrivals."
One recent arrival is American Documents Security, which Mr. Greco said took 27,300 square feet of space in Building A. The company collects and shreds corporate documents and trucks them to recycling stations. It employs 20 to 30 people, Mr. Greco said. Throughout the facility, about 3,000 jobs have been created in 2.1 million square feet of leased space, 1,200 of them in the last four years, according to Charles Millard, president of the Economic Development Corporation. The ratio of 1.4 jobs for every 1,000 square feet leased is a bit better than the rule-of-thumb standard of one job per 1,000 square feet in industrial real estate.
Then there is Industry City at Bush Terminal, the name for the four million square feet in 10 industrial buildings between 37th and 32d Streets just off the Gowanus Expressway. They were managed by Helmsley-Spear Inc. after Harry B. Helmsley and his partners bought them in 1964, but they were sold to an investment group called Industry City Associates in 1986.
There was 70 percent occupancy at the time, said Bruce B. Federman, director of real estate for the owning partnership, but after a rebound beginning in 1993 occupancy now stands at 98 percent. "We have garment manufacturers, import-export businesses, furniture manufacturers, many startups," Mr. Federman said. "We have relocatees from the West Side of Manhattan, from Queens, from New Jersey."
About 5,000 people work at Industry City, and some of the manufacturing businesses that operate there expanded this year. For example, the A.J.V. Prime Source Corporation, a cabinet manufacturer, expanded to 25,000 square feet from 10,000 and has increased its employment to 45 from 15, Mr. Federman said. At the same time, fewer businesses seem to be failing.
"In the late 80's and early 90's, we had 10 or 15 business failures, through bankruptcies, default or closure," Mr. Federman said. "That has been reversed."
One consequence is a rise in asking prices in the sales market. Mr. Federman estimated that about two million square feet of property could be enhanced with new ownership and management.
What the area does not have, and is unlikely to get, is the large manufacturers with thousands of employees who once traipsed to a busy waterfront with ship as well as truck traffic. The shift is principally to distribution or small businesses, or retailing, as in the arrival of a new Costco store near the 39th Street exit of the Gowanus Expressway.
But Mr. Massa noted that with garment manufacturing, he could have 300 or 400 people working in his incubator space. "I've got a silk screen printer with 35 or 40 people in 22,000 feet," he said. "I've got a guy who prices and packs towels with 25 people in 17,000 feet. We've got 700 people working here. Ten years ago, we had zero."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dominick Massa, left, president of Harborside Management, and Kenneth Adams, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, outside a building soon to house several garment companies. (Steve Hart for The New York Times)
