SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2247 words

HEADLINE: For Family (Tax) Shelter, The Rules Have Changed

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
ACCORDING to estimates by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, there are approximately 65 million homeowners in the United States. For many, the purchase of a home was the most significant investment of a lifetime. For some, that investment has proved fruitful indeed: It is not uncommon for a house bought for $50,000 a quarter century ago to have grown -- through appreciation, a series of sales and purchases, or a combination of both -- into an asset worth several hundred thousand dollars. The equity in the family home often represents a major portion of the total estate to be passed from one generation to another.
For many, though, a home's value is measured not just in dollars and cents but in memories that span a lifetime. The decision to sell a home and move -- or to keep it and leave it to the children -- typically involves balancing emotional, economic and practical considerations. Such decisions can become more difficult later in life when the empty nest becomes a cherished gathering place for children and grandchildren scattered by time and individual fortunes. 
 Earlier this year, however, such decisions were made easier for some -- and more difficult for others -- with the passage of the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997. The act produced significant changes in the way gain on the sale of a principal residence is taxed -- or not taxed -- for virtually every homeowner in America. Under the new law, which applies to sales after May 7, 1997, profits on the sale of a home are not subject to tax unless they are over $250,000 for an individual, or $500,000 for a couple who file joint tax returns; an interval of at least two years must take place between sales. Tax planners and real estate lawyers say the change was so significant it is likely to have a profound impact, not only on the purchase and sale of residential real estate, but on the role of such property in tax planning, estate planning, divorce and the distribution of marital assets.
"The impact of the new tax law is going to be nothing less than extraordinary," said Gary Schatsky, a Manhattan lawyer and financial consultant. "Average homeowners now have a tax loophole they can drive a truck through."
Tax planners and lawyers have long devised various strategies, primarily of use to the wealthy, to help their clients avoid -- or at least minimize -- the taxes imposed when assets are passed from one generation to another.
Typically, Mr. Schatsky said, only relatively large estates are subject to Federal estate taxes. Under current Federal Gift and Estate Tax law, individuals can pass to heirs or beneficiaries upon death a lifetime total of up to $600,000 in assets without the transfer being subject to Federal tax. With a little planning, Mr. Schatsky said, married couples can effectively transfer up to $1.2 million in assets free of Federal taxes. The new tax law is even more generous, Mr. Schatsky said, and provides gradually increasing exemptions over the next nine years. By 2006, he said, individuals and married couples will be able to transfer tax-free up to $1 million and $2 million in assets, respectively.
And though New York imposes an inheritance tax on property that passes at death to anyone but a surviving spouse, the amount of the estate exempt from taxation -- now $115,000 -- will be increased to $300,000 on Oct. 1, 1998, and increased again on Feb. 1, 2000, to match the Federal exemption, which will be $675,000 at that point. Connecticut is also phasing out inheritance taxes on transfers to children (there are none on transfers to spouses), which at present are imposed on amounts over $250,000, and will have no such taxes after Jan. 1, 2001. New Jersey imposes no inheritance taxes on transfers to a spouse or children.
Even though most homeowners have not had to worry about estate or inheritance taxes when deciding whether to sell their home or let it pass through their estate, other tax considerations often factored heavily in such decisions.
"The old tax law encouraged people to hold onto their house until they died," said James Chesterton Jr., a certified financial planner with Brighton Financial Planning in Clinton, N.J. The tax act of 1997, on the other hand, Mr. Chesterton said, should have the opposite effect.
Many homeowners, he explained, have accumulated significant equity in their homes over the years. Under prior tax law, he said, the payment of tax on that gain could be avoided if the profit from one house was rolled over into another principal residence of equal of greater value. When a taxpayer turned 55, the law provided for a one-time exemption of $125,000 -- resulting in tax liability on any gain that exceeded that amount.
In many cases, however, particularly in the metropolitan area, where property values have increased significantly in the last 20 or 30 years, an exemption of $125,000 would often leave hundreds of thousands of dollars in accumulated value subject to taxation. That resulted in even average taxpayers employing a rather basic estate-planning strategy to avoid paying taxes on the gain.
When a house passes through an estate, Mr. Chesterton explained, the heirs receive what is known as a "step-up" in basis. When a child inherits a $400,000 house that his parents originally bought for $50,000, the child's tax basis is $400,000. The child can then sell the house for $400,000 and no tax would be due from the child (the $400,000, however, is included in the estate for estate-tax purposes). On the other hand, if the parents had sold the house for that amount, and had not rolled over the profit into a replacement dwelling, they would have had to account for $225,000 in gain after taking into account the $125,000 "over-55" exemption -- if they had been old enough to qualify for the exemption at the time of sale.
In many cases, the most economical, practical and emotionally acceptable option is to leave the house to a child or children. And while leaving a house to an only child presents few problems, leaving property to two or more children is another matter entirely.
"There's nothing like dividing up an estate to bring out the worst in a group of siblings," said Charles D. Whelan 3d, a New Brunswick, N.J., lawyer who specializes in trusts and estates. Frequently, Mr. Whelan said, parents who think they are doing their children a favor by passing the family home to them upon their death are actually setting the stage for a sibling civil war.
"I've seen situations where brothers and sisters haven't spoken for years," Mr. Whelan said. "One of the kids wants to move into the house and the other wants to sell it. It can get really very ugly."
Generally, Mr. Whelan said, he has advised clients who want to leave a house to their children to put specific language in their wills instructing the executor to sell the house as soon as possible and then divide the proceeds among the children.
And while parents may still choose to leave a home to their children and let the children decide how the property is to be divided, the new tax law provides most homeowners with additional options.
Mr. Schatsky, the Manhattan lawyer and financial consultant, explained that under the new tax law, individual taxpayers can realize up to $250,000 in tax-free gain on the sale of a principal residence. For married taxpayers who file jointly, the exemption is $500,000. "That means that the average couple can do just about whatever they want with their home," Mr. Schatsky said. A couple with a built-in $350,000 gain in a principal residence, for example, can sell the house without having to worry about paying tax on any of the profit.
"Many people with grown children have much more house than they need," Mr. Schatsky said. "Now they can buy a smaller house, or rent an apartment, and, if they want to, they can still give $10,000 a year, tax-free, to each of their children."
The new capital-gains tax exemptions, Mr. Schatsky pointed out, are available on any property that has been used as a principal residence for at least two of the five years preceding the sale. Moreover, he said, unlike the one-time, over-55 exemption of the former tax law, the current exemptions can be used over and over. That means that homeowners who have vacation homes that have appreciated in value can sell those homes and pay no tax on the gain merely by using the vacation home as a principal residence for at least two years.
THE new tax law may also contribute to a lessening of the emotional and economic stresses that often accompany a divorce.
"For years, one of the greatest problems encountered in a divorce has been the sale of the marital home," said John P. Paone Jr., a matrimonial lawyer in Woodbridge, N.J. "Usually, a divorce triggers the recognition of a capital gain because neither party is in a position to roll over the gain into a new house."
An additional problem under prior law, Mr. Paone said, arose from the fact that husbands who agreed to allow a former spouse and children to remain in the house -- with the understanding that the house would be sold when the children were grown -- would usually have to pay capital-gains tax on half the profit at the time of the sale because at that point, the house was no longer the husband's principal residence.
Under the new law, however, not only will both parties be able to avoid being taxed on up to $250,000 each in gain in the event of an immediate sale, but the two-out-of-five-year provision allows the parties up to three years to sell the property -- and still obtain the exemption -- even though one former spouse no longer resides there.
"It doesn't solve everything, but it should make reaching a settlement a whole lot easier," Mr. Paone said. "And it will make the sale of the home a little less traumatic."
IN fact, while the new tax law should prove to be beneficial to most homeowners, it could result in making sales more traumatic for those with gains that exceed the allowable exemptions.
Martin Shenkman, a Teaneck, N.J., tax lawyer who has written several books on real estate taxation, explained that while the new tax law allows for exemptions every two years, it no longer allows property owners to avoid taxes on the sale of a principal residence by rolling over their gain into a replacement dwelling of equal or greater value. It has also eliminated the over-55 exemption of $125,000 in profit.
"If the gain on the sale of a home exceeds $250,000, or $500,000 for a couple filing a joint return, then a significant capital-gains tax could be incurred," Mr. Shenkman said. And even though the capital-gains tax rate itself has been reduced under the new tax law -- from 28 percent under the former law to about 20 percent now -- there is no longer any way to avoid payment.
So, Mr. Shenkman said, while the new tax law may encourage sales by those with gains less than the maximum exemption, it could discourage sales by those with bigger gains. Moreover, he said, those with such significant gains are also more likely to have estates that exceed the Federal Gift and Estates Tax Unified Credit -- now $600,000 for an individual Such people, Mr. Shenkman said, typically require more sophisticated tax planning strategies, the most common of which is the Credit Shelter Trust.
With such a trust, Mr. Shenkman said, a married couple can insure that they obtain the full benefit of both spouses' unified credits. The spouses indicate in their wills that assets representing the maximum available credit at the time of the first spouse's death should pass to a trust -- the beneficiaries of which are typically the children -- instead of to the surviving spouse. By doing that, Mr. Shenkman said, the estate of the second spouse to die does not include assets from the first spouse that could have otherwise escaped taxation.
Taxpayers with estates that exceed the combined unified credit of both spouses can use an additional estate planning tool called the Qualified Personal Residence Trust.
Such a trust -- referred to by its acronym, "QPRT" (pronounced "Cue-pert") -- allows a homeowner to give a principal residence or a vacation home as a gift to a trust established for a specific term. Though the gift reduces the individual's Federal Gift and Estates Tax Unified Credit, the value assigned by the tax law to the property that is conveyed to the trust is discounted considerably.
For example, Mr. Shenkman said, a $1 million property placed in a QPRT for a term of 15 years is valued for tax purposes at only $280,780.
That means that if the owner survives the term of the trust -- as is required -- he or she will have transferred a $1 million asset, plus any appreciation over the 15 years, while using up only $280,780 of the unified credit.
Mr. Shenkman said that all estate-planning strategies have distinct advantages and disadvantages that vary according to an individual's financial situation. Accordingly, he said, those who believe they may benefit from any of the devices should consult a tax adviser.
One adviser -- Mr. Schatsky, the Manhattan lawyer and tax consultant -- offered some advice he said should apply to every homeowner.
"When dealing with a personal residence," he said, "you should decide what you would do with it if there were no income taxes, there were no estate taxes and there were no children to leave it to. Because if you don't do that first, you're letting the tax tail wag the dog."

HEADLINE: SETTING THE STAGE;
A Moment of Pause Between a Bleak Past and a Hopeful Future

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
What comes next? And how soon?
These are impatient questions, without immediate prospect of answers. But they will be asked over and over here with increasing interest and urgency for at least a generation as Newark's leaders in business, education and politics look for ways to capitalize on the new Performing Arts Center, whose own success will not be gauged for some time. 
 With less than a week to go before the first audience hears the first note of music in Prudential Hall, there is a great intake of breath and an audible pause here. The people in a position to talk about what's next are upbeat but circumspect, eager to praise the present, but careful not to predict the future, as if wishing out loud might annoy the gods of renewal enough to make them lose interest in a place that has needed serious attention -- if not divine intervention -- for more than 30 years.
The future ceased to be encouraging a long time ago as Newark's downward slide into an urban reservation for the poor seemed unending. The calendar moved forward, but the future did not always come with it.
Yet now, on the edge of the single most significant change in Newark since the 1967 riots, it seems no one is fully prepared (nor, perhaps, should be) to discuss the most impatient question of all: Will the arts center lead to a renewal big enough to spawn new market-rate residential housing in the center of Newark, together with a revival of its shriveled retail trade?
Will a development impresario -- someone with the muscle and pizazz of Donald Trump -- come riding into the city with an open checkbook and a plan? Is the city prepared to work with outsiders to make the deals it needs to make? And will further development gradually help improve the schools and standard of living for the thousands of Newark residents who still need jobs, or the hope of getting them? In other words, will Newark become an Atlantic City without the gambling, or will the middle class come back?
Those questions have been waiting for answers since long before the urban wars of the 1960's. And the answer was almost always that better luck was just around the corner. That kind of big-time luck is a tall order, and it takes time.
But now more than just the hope of real change downtown, particularly along Broad Street, Newark's main boulevard, has begun to take shape. These are physical changes, some visible at street level, some not. Some are cosmetic; some go deeper. The future has finally arrived, on the 12-acre arts center site and elsewhere, and it is palpable, even quantifiable.
"Certainly the potential is there, if done right," said Dr. James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "Newark is at the core of the fifth largest metropolitan market in the country. There is enough potential support to make the center a success in and of itself."
Over the last 15 years, he said, north central New Jersey has evolved into a much more self-contained economy despite a continuing link to New York.
"It was a non-player in the regional office market in 1980," he said. "Today it has over 180 million square feet of office space, just behind New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco." But, he added, "the spillover effects are going to take an enormous amount of time."
Drawing a comparison with Lincoln Center's role in revitalizing the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Dr. Hughes said: "For 10 to 15 years afterward, we saw very little change in land use. The area was barren for a long time. Only in the boom years of the 1980's did we get a whole range of restaurants and other things."
He warned against the danger of impatience: "If we don't see something happen immediately, we claim it a failure as an economic development tool."
Broad Street north of Market, its major cross street, is still home to some of the largest empty buildings in town -- the old Hahne's Department Store and the Griffith Piano Building, to name two. In recent years, they were acquired by Miles Berger, a Newark developer who says he intends to turn some of his holdings into parking lots, retail space and, perhaps, residential or office space.
Beneath Military Park, a swath of green along Broad Street, is a vast parking garage that until recently was a dungeonlike maze of gray concrete, as desolate as the nighttime streets above. Now, because of the arts center development, it has been thoroughly renovated.
"It's now the sexiest garage in New Jersey," said Lawrence P. Goldman, president and chief executive of the center. "We've got Beethoven coming through the speakers."
The city has made good on its pledges to repave streets in and around the arts center. For the first time, hundreds of signs pointing drivers to Newark have gone up on the highways that border it, and scores more are hung around town, calling attention to historic sites and the large and growing campus complex on both sides of Broad Street. These include Seton Hall University Law School, the New Jersey Institute of Technology, and Rutgers's Newark campus and law school, which is putting up a new $55 million building. Close by, too, is the sprawling campus of the University of Medicine and Dentistry and other medical institutions.
The arts center plan, presented almost a decade ago, included a master plan for all of downtown, drawing together Newark's various campus centers. How to do that and how to pay for it remain to be discussed. "The hope is to be able to use the arts center to provide the linkage to these other circles, rather than have it just be another circle itself," said Marilyn Taylor, a partner at Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the Manhattan architectural firm that helped produce the master plan and the arts center.
"All healthy places are a walk," she said. "They are a string of destinations, not just a destination. So when you go downtown to buy a dress, stopping for a cup of coffee seems like a good idea, and so does a movie."
The original site proposed for the arts center was on Broad Street, but eventually planners and civic leaders agreed to move it closer to the Passaic River, Ms. Taylor said. The point, she added, was to try to make yet another link, this time with the waterfront.
Sharpe James, the city's Mayor since 1986 and its most tireless booster, said last week that in advance of any major new initiatives, the city has already undertaken these:
* Establishment of a special improvement district downtown that will involve store owners in sidewalk and facade beautification projects, increase police presence and chase peddlers away.
* A new minor-league baseball and soccer complex off Bridge Street, within walking distance of the center.
* Plans to complete waterfront development near the arts center.
* Plans, now before New Jersey Transit officials, to complete a rail link between Lackawanna Station, the arts center and Pennsylvania Station.
Next week, a $1 bus service called the Loop will connect Penn Station with important locations downtown, including the arts center. "Things are already happening," the Mayor said. And then he recalled a conference in Virgnia not long ago at which other mayors told him, "You know, Sharpe, the best thing that ever happened to Newark was the development and growth passed you by for two decades."
Why is that? Mr. James asked.
"You won't make all the mistakes," he said they told him. "You'll do it right."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Route 21, at lower left, circles the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, under construction in July 1996. Leaders hope that success will promote urban vitality by helping link other vibrant sectors of the city. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
A Man of Particular Passions

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
THE president and chief executive of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center is a slender, intense, impeccably dressed, graying 51-year-old who looks as if his name would be something imposing and formal. And it is, on his official biography, the one that says Lawrence P. Goldman has a Ph.D. from Princeton University and notes that his responsibilities include overseeing the design, construction and operation of the imposing new $200 million center.
But those who know him even a little don't call him Mr. Goldman, or Lawrence. It's Larry. 
 He's the kind of charismatic visionary who might have been invented for the task of turning the arts center from a dream of urban renewal to the brick colossus at One Center Street, a pragmatic idealist who came of age in the civil rights era and, looking for a solution to race problems, turned to urban planning.
But he is also the kind of manager who wanders through his giant work in progress at every opportunity, chatting up the construction workers and picking up errant pieces of tape on the carpet. The kind of boss who remembers birthdays, gives presents in the holiday season, gets mad at his secretary if she doesn't tell him that an employee has a sick relative -- and pops through his office door dozens of times a day with sudden, urgent imperatives. "Somebody want to pick that up?" he'll say if a phone rings more than four times.
He is also the kind of third baseman, he notes ruefully, who can field but not hit. "There was a time when a great deal of my sense of identity came out of baseball," he says. A devoted player in college at Colgate, he now plays on an over-40 league: "That's very important to me."
The arts center is very nearly complete, but a few giant walls of glass are still waiting to be installed. Pickup trucks and vans are parked all over the grounds. Cranes here and there poke toward the sky.
Mr. Goldman speaks to workers on the supposition that they know who he is. Sometimes they don't know exactly who he is, but they always know he's the boss. One reason they know him is that he spoke at the recent Hard-Hat Concert.
"When we got started," Mr. Goldman said, "we told the construction workers the very first event here would be for them. We wanted them them to feel they have a personal relationship with their work. We're all in this together."
The only child of a haberdasher in Larchmont, N.Y., Mr. Goldman has a blend of altruism, confidence and single-mindedness that underlies his professional achievements. "I've been so fortunate," he said. "Look at my career. I've been involved of three of the great urban transformation programs in the region: Roosevelt Island, the most ambitious community planning ever. Carnegie Hall, which, when I was there, seemed like the center of the universe. You couldn't walk out the door without some press person grabbing you." And now the Performing Arts Center, which he watches over like a new mother waiting for baby's first smile.
That's the exact quality for which he was hired, although he also had longstanding ties to Newark, from his years studying urban issues at Princeton. Raymond G. Chambers, a foundation head who is now a chairman at the arts center, said Mr. Goldman's energy was crucial to turning the dream of an arts center into reality.
Their first contact was in the late 1980's, when Mr. Goldman was overseeing the redevelopment of Carnegie Hall, including the construction of a Cesar Pelli tower.
"It was the recognition of his passion, more than anything else, that was compelling," Mr. Chambers said.
"We initially retained him as a consultant to help us think through the feasibility of the performing arts center. And we were immediately so impressed with his background as matching the needs of the art center. But my best recollection is that we knew he was the right person when he displayed his passion, not just for a building or performing arts center, but for the people of Newark, and the hope that this world-class performing art center could bring to those people."
That interest started long before. Mr. Goldman still has an aging copy of a paper he wrote at Princeton, dated March 1969, titled "Black Mayoral Politics in Newark: Getting It Together for 1970." In a characteristically advantageous turn of fate, that paper introduced Mr. Goldman to Ken Gibson, who in 1970 was elected the first black Mayor of Newark, the first black Mayor of any major American city.
At Princeton, Mr. Goldman also met Paul Ylvisaker, the legendary state Commissioner for Community Affairs, who ran down the streets of Newark after the riots to stop armed National Guardsmen from performing threatening house-to-house searches. "He was as close to a saint as any man I ever met," Mr. Goldman said.
He keeps a picture of his mentor, who died in 1992, on his desk, along with a collection of shots of his three children and his wife, Laurie Chock, a documentary film maker.
They met 20 years ago, he said. He was wandering around, an odd August Friday night with nothing to do, and for the first time in his life he went into a restaurant to have dinner alone. He happened into Marvin Gardens, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, and saw "three attractive women having dinner." He asked if he could join them. They were Ms. Chock, her sister and a friend.
"Now, there's no important decision I make that I don't discuss it first with her," he said.
Mr. Goldman didn't have a chance, though, on Wednesday. She was in Portugal filming when his assistant, Olga Rivera-Ayala, opened his office door and announced that President Clinton, on his way to the Metropolitan Baptist Church and an appearance with the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, State Senator James E. McGreevey, might be stopping by.
Mr. Goldman paused only briefly.
"How do you know?" he asked. "Why would he be coming here?"
It was a false alarm. "He's not coming here," Ms. Rivera-Ayala said. "He's driving by. But you might see him."
Dryly, he responded, "That'd be great."
Anyone else's pulse might have risen. But not Mr. Goldman's. "We've never been shy about the idea of getting national and international attention, though it would be arrogant to say that the day we open, we'll be the equal of Kennedy Center and Lincoln Center," he said. "Still, with time, I expect that there will be many Presidents here. We've already had a prime minister."
ALONG with Presidents, the arts center is meant to attract members of the black middle class who, like their white counterparts, fled Newark after the riots. And he is convincing when praising the corporate leaders who gave money and support to the arts center, whom he calls "truly enlightened."
Not only do they understand that this area must offer a good quality of life for them to attract and retain employees, he says, but they also grasp a basic piece of urban reality: "Suburban Northern New Jersey can't sustain long-range health if New Jersey's largest city isn't healthy."
"In other words," he says, "they get it. You can't turn your back on it."
The opening is Saturday, but Mr. Goldman frequently reminds himself and his staff that the mad scramble to have the building ready in time is "a race to the starting line." In terms of his own long-term ambitions, he intends to run the race.
"People have to feel so damned good about being here," he said, pumping his fists. "There has to be a total attention to detail -- in the parking, the ushering, the dining. Everything about this has to be upbeat."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
New Jersey, Healthy for All, Aiming at Health of the Elderly

 BODY:
New Jersey residents lead healthier lives than those in three-fourths of the nation, according to a survey released last week.
New Jersey ranks 12th from the top when all of the factors considered by the Reliastar Financial Corporation of Minneapolis in its annual evaluation are combined. The survey considered such seemingly diverse factors as a state's unemployment rate because that has a bearing on a person's ability to obtain health insurance; the rates of heart disease, cancer and infectious diseases like AIDS; the mortality rate; job-related fatalities, and motor vehicle deaths. 
 Minnesota, the home state for Reliastar, a life insurance, employee benefits and mutual funds holding company, comes in first with the healthiest residents followed by New Hampshire, Hawaii, Massachusetts and Wisconsin. Louisiana and Mississippi tie for last place.
"This is a general survey, not something that is necessarily precise," said Leah Ziskin, deputy commissioner of the state Department of Health and Senior Services, "but I think our concerted effort to reduce youthful smoking and to promote the use of seat belts and reduce the number of drunken drivers contributed to our high ranking."
Residents of nursing homes or those 65 and older being discharged from hospitals will be offered influenza and pneumonia vaccinations under regulations being drafted by the state Department of Health and Senior Services.
Thirty-seven percent of New Jersey residents 65 and older now get flu shots, compared with 41 percent nationally, and 13.5 percent get pneumonia shots, vs. 16 percent nationally. The new requirements for nursing homes and hospitals are designed to reduce the 2,000 deaths among New Jersey seniors that are caused each year by the two diseases, Len Fishman, state health and senior services commissioner, said in announcing the program Thursday.
Until the regulations are changed, the health department is asking hospitals and nursing homes to begin immediately to offer the shots voluntarily, which are covered by Medicare. There are slightly more than one million New Jersey residents over the age of 65.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Nipping at the Hand That Has Long Fed Him

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
To hear Murray Sabrin tell it, government should limit its role to helping individuals defend themselves from force and fraud.
Mr. Sabrin, the Libertarian Party's candidate for governor, does not think taxpayer dollars should be spent on much else. He wants to abolish the income tax, and most other state taxes, for that matter. 
 If elected, he vows to dismantle state government, eventually eliminating virtually all state agencies and programs, with the exception of the prison system, the State Police and the court system.
He promises to take state dollars and state regulations out of public education, leaving local residents to pay for schools and giving them the option of deciding what education the schools should offer.
"We must slash government spending by billions of dollars to restore constitutional government in New Jersey," he says.
Mr. Sabrin may not sound like your typical candidate, but he shares a common trait with some other politicians: he says one thing yet does another.
Although he has embraced the anti-government philosophy of the Libertarian Party for almost two decades, Mr. Sabrin, 50, who lives in Leonia, has personally benefited from government largess for most of his life.
Take his campaign for governor. He began his radio and television advertising campaign late last week, urging voters not to waste their votes on "Whitman or McGreevey." Even though he says he does not believe that taxpayer dollars should be used to cover the cost of campaigning, he is using taxpayer dollars -- about $330,000 worth -- to help finance the media spots and his campaign.
As a child growing up in New York City, he attended public schools in the Bronx. He earned a bachelor's degree in history, and later a master's degree in social studies education at Lehman College. He did not have to worry, as most young people today do, about graduating with thousands of dollars in college loans. There was no tuition for students at Lehman College, now part of the City University of New York. Tuition was covered by city taxpayer dollars.
Even when he decided to pursue his goal of becoming a college professor, after four years as a public-school teacher in New York City, he attended a university subsidized with state tax dollars. He earned his Ph.D. from Rutgers in economic geography.
Over the years, he has held a few jobs in the private sector. He is host of his own radio and cable television program, "On the Money," on which he discusses financial matters. In the 1980's, he worked in sales and marketing for two years, and as a staff economist for the American Institute for Economic Research for three years, and as a senior investment analyst for American Investment Services in 1981 and 1982.
But for the last 12 years, he has been paid with state taxpayer dollars for his work as a college professor. Mr. Sabrin now earns $63,000 a year as a professor of finance in the school of administration and business at Ramapo College in Mahway. .
Mr. Sabrin defends his decision to take taxpayer dollars to help wage his campaign. And he defends his decision to oppose government spending for everyone else, even though he makes his living today at an institution financed by state taxpayers.
"We are playing by the rules that have been established by the government establishment," he explained. "We did not create these rules. We would not have created these rules. We believe that peaceful change is the best way to achieve the Libertarian goals for New Jersey: limited government, personal responsibility and home rule."
It is under New Jersey's taxpayer-financed system of paying for gubernatorial campaigns that Mr. Sabrin is able to get his message across. He is the first third-party candidate to qualify for public money and to earn a place at the televised gubernatorial debates. To qualify for matching funds, he raised $233,000 from friends and Libertarian Party supporters across the country.
Of course, Mr. Sabrin says that if elected he will abolish public financing of political campaigns in the state. But it is the one thing that violates Libertarian Party principles that he might want to keep.
After all, public financing is giving him a chance to voice his ideas this year. Or maybe, if he is elected, then he will share another common trait with incumbents, which is to do everything possible to keep the job.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Rickel Home Centers Will Go Out of Business

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
Forty-four years after brothers Mort, Al and Bob Rickel opened their first store on Route 22 in Union, Rickel Home Centers said last week it would go out of business and lay off all 2,700 employees, including 2,000 in New Jersey. Rickel, based in South Plainfield, will close its 38 New Jersey stores and 11 others in New York, Pennsylvania and Delaware by Dec. 31, said Greg Hanselman, vice president for marketing. Rickel overexpanded by acquiring the Channel Home Centers chain in November 1994, Mr. Hanselman said, then fell into bankruptcy 14 months later and failed to attract badly needed investors despite a streamlining plan to boost profits. "Basically, we just ran out of cash," he said. 
 Brian Burns, a spokesman for the state Department of Labor, said the department would help Rickel employees preregister for unemployment insurance and apply for tuition grants under state and Federal retraining programs. STEVE STRUNSKY

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mercedes-Benz ML320;
Star of Sport Utilities Is Suddenly 3-Pointed

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
BEST you think the new ML320 "all activity vehicle" is not a true Mercedes-Benz, check out the big, bold three-pointed star embedded in the plastic grille. The badge is a whopping eight inches in diameter, just so no one misses the point: although this is a different kind of vehicle for Mercedes, and it comes from Tuscaloosa, Ala., instead of Stuttgart, Germany, it is a Mercedes nonetheless.
A week at the wheel convinced me. Even without the star, there would be no doubt that the ML320 is pure Mercedes. 
 The ML320 is the first of Mercedes's new family of M-Class sport utility vehicles (320 refers to its 3.2-liter V6 engine) and it is the first product built at the company's new Alabama assembly plant. It is also a standout among several new vehicles from the company, which has moved quickly and skillfully in recent years to expand on its prior reputation for well-engineered but very conservative and expensive cars.
Mercedes advertising has become clever -- cool, even -- and cars like the C-Class sedan, the SLK roadster and the new CLK coupe are putting the three-pointed star within the grasp of younger buyers. In Europe, the avant-garde A-Class subcompact and the soon-to-come Smart city car make the company seem more friendly and more environmentally aware.
If the "old" Mercedes had created a sport utility, it would likely have aimed at the top of the market -- at vehicles like the $60,000 Range Rover and $50,000 Lexus LX 450. (Indeed, the company builds the $130,000 Gelandewagen in a joint venture in Austria, but that military-design vehicle is sold in the United States only through an independent distributor, Europa International.)
Instead, the newly aggressive Mercedes-Benz is taking on the heart of the midsize sport utility market, a segment dominated by the Ford Explorer and the Jeep Grand Cherokee. Mercedes figures that many Americans who appreciate the ruggedness and cargo capacity of those truck-derived sport utilities would prefer a more comfortable ride, more carlike handling, extra safety features and better fuel economy.
The ML320's rounded silhouette contrasts with the boxy shapes of the Grand Cherokee and especially the Explorer. In fact, the ML320's aerodynamics are the best in the segment, which results in a respectable mileage rating of 21 miles per gallon on the highway. Up front, the gray bumper and that wide grille with the big star are prominent. But the homely back end looks like the rump of a mini-van.
During my week-long test drive, the ML320 drew surprisingly little reaction, though I was often asked "What is that?"
The ML320 is wider and taller than the Explorer and Grand Cherokee. The wheels are pushed toward the corners, minimizing the front and rear overhang to lend an aggressive look and make the interior more spacious.
Inside, the instrument panel, from the type face of the numerals to the layout of the dials, is pure Mercedes. A large speedometer is prominent.
Two familiar Mercedes features were missing. Instead of a single windshield wiper, like the one in Mercedes cars, the M-Class has two wipers. And where were the familiar seat adjusters? Seat-shaped controls, placed on the doors of Mercedes autos, were absent. Instead, the test vehicle (with only basic equipment, including a cloth interior) had six-way manual controls on the front and side of the bottom cushion.
The center of the dash is clean, simple and logical. The audio system is situated just below three big air vents and above large rotary climate-control dials. Other controls are minimal: buttons for the air-conditioner and four-wheel-drive low range, and toggles for the optional seat warmers and the standard rear window wiper and defroster. The power window switches are on the center console and there is an extra 12-volt outlet.
Beyond the glove box, which can hold little more than the leather-encased owner's manual, storage is bountiful. All four doors have pockets. An optional, lockable drawer pulls out from beneath the front passenger seat. A garage-door opener fits into an overhead compartment. The center armrest covers a deep bin. In the cargo area, which comes with a privacy screen, another bin kept my purse out of sight while I picked apples at an orchard.
The cup holders, which fold down from each end of the dash and from the back of the center console, are neatly designed but accommodate only cups sized just so.
The cargo area is deceptively large. The hatch opens upward and the liftover is low, so it is easy to slide groceries forward. I handily hoisted in a child's bike; an adult model would not fit without folding the second row of seats. (One, two or all three of those seats fold to create a flat cargo floor.)
The ML320 accommodates five people, and a third-row seat will be offered later as an option. Seating is comfortable, with plenty of leg room and head room in every position. My children ranked the ML320 one of their favorite vehicles because of the high seats and expansive view through lots of glass. The large doors and low step-in height were also a plus, and the children got in easily without assistance.
We were disappointed, however, that safety-conscious Mercedes had not installed a shoulder-lap belt in the middle rear seat, a feature now found in less expensive cars like the Chevrolet Prizm. Still, I felt extremely safe, almost invulnerable. The ML320 has dual front air bags, side air bags in the front doors, emergency seat-belt tension retractors and anti-lock brakes. It is also constructed with a steel safety cage around the passenger compartment.
The stiff body structure benefits handling, which along with the comfortable ride sets the ML320 far above the competition. Many sport utilities promise carlike attributes, but no one else has delivered them to such a degree. The ML320 rides like a luxury sedan and grips curving roads like a sports coupe.
Acceleration from the new V6, rated at 215 horsepower, is surprisingly quick. (And if it isn't enough for you, a V8 will arrive in a year.) The five-speed automatic transmission, which adapts to one's driving style, shifts imperceptibly. The brakes are beefy.
The ML320 is equipped with an innovative full-time four-wheel-drive system that requires no action from the driver. It electronically senses wheel slippage and applies the brakes to the slipping wheels while delivering just the right torque to the tires with grip -- even if only one has traction. A low gear range, for low-speed hill climbing, can be engaged with the push of a button.
The ML320 comes with a long list of equipment. Options are grouped in five packages, with leather seats, walnut trim, CD changer and cellular phone included in the top-of-the-line package; separate available items are limited to a sunroof, metallic paint and a premium audio system. Dealer-installed options include a navigation system.
Then there's the price. Starting at about $35,000 and topping out at $41,000, the ML320 seems a bargain compared with luxury versions of the Explorer and Grand Cherokee, which move into similar territory once a few options are checked. Lucky for Ford and Jeep that ML320 production will be limited to 70,000 a year, with half for export.
Given the choice, which sport utility would I buy? The ML320, hands down.
Plus, it's a Mercedes.
 
INSIDE TRACK: The head of the class.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Portfolio Prescriptions

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
State Street Global Advisors, which runs the SSgA family of funds, is leading the way for large mutual fund companies into the new world of medical savings accounts.
Medical savings accounts became available in January as a kind of medical I.R.A. They are intended for the self-employed and the employees of small companies and are packaged with high-deductible health insurance to cover serious illness. Contributions to the accounts are tax-deductible, and interest earned on the savings is tax-exempt, as long as all the money withdrawn from the account is used for medical expenses. At age 65, account holders can withdraw the money for any purpose without penalty. 
 For its medical savings accounts, State Street is offering investment options in 15 of its no-load mutual funds. An investor can put money in any combination of funds, as long as the $1,000 initial minimum per fund is met. Its best long-term performers are its domestic equity funds, including SSgA Small Cap and SSgA S.& P. 500.
So far this year, the bulk of these accounts have been created by insurance companies, including Mutual of Omaha and New York Life, and by a sprinkling of banks, including Mellon and Wells Fargo, according to the Council for Affordable Health Insurance, a nonprofit group in Alexandria, Va. But Kelly A. McCarthy, the council's director of public affairs, said she expected that to change.
"Now that the learning curve is over and people know what M.S.A.'s are, the types of companies that offer them will start to diversify," she said. Among mutual fund companies, only Mennonite Mutual Aid, which manages about $135 million in three MMA Praxis mutual funds, offers these accounts so far, according to the council.
With the universe of providers expanding, how should consumers choose where to set up a medical savings account?
It comes down to convenience versus return, Ms. McCarthy said. "It's more convenient to get high-deductible insurance and the medical savings account in one place at an insurance company," she said, "but if you get it from a mutual fund company, you can hope for a higher return on your investment."
Medical savings accounts can be set up by self-employed workers and people at companies that have 50 or fewer employees. For an individual to qualify, the deductible on his or her health insurance plan must be $1,500 to $2,250; for family coverage, it must be $3,000 to $4,500. Employer contributions are deductible by the company and are tax-free to employees. The maximum annual contribution is 65 percent of the deductible for individuals, or $1,462; for families, it is 75 percent, or $3,375.
 
Cutting Fees At Heartland
Fund investors who keep a sharp eye on expenses may like what they see at the Heartland funds of Milwaukee.
In a bid to draw new money, management is subsidizing all fees for the Heartland Large Cap Value fund, whose normal expense ratio is 2.12 percent, and is reimbursing Heartland Mid Cap Value so that its total annual expenses do not exceed 1.25 percent of assets, down from 1.46 percent.
Small, young equity funds often waive fees to build assets quickly. Both funds started last October.
"We believe that the fee waivers and reimbursements, combined with the first-year record, will make the funds attractive to investors," said Mitchell Kohls, chief operating officer for Heartland Advisors.
Large Cap Value, which holds $7 million in assets, returned 33.6 percent for the 11 months ended Sept. 30, compared with 32.5 percent for its large value peers, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund trackers. Mid Cap Value, which holds $33 million, gained 37.2 percent in that time, compared with 35.5 percent for its group.
"Also, by building assets, we seek to achieve economies of scale that would benefit all shareholders," Mr. Kohls said.
Heartland Advisors said that all or a portion of the fees for both funds might be reinstated at any time. No target date has been set; Mr. Kohls said the arrangement would be reviewed regularly.
Heartland also announced last week that two other funds -- Small Cap Contrarian and Value -- would close to new investors on Oct. 31. Existing shareholders on that date will still be able to add to their accounts.
The 13-year-old Heartland Value, with $2.3 billion in assets, beat other funds that invest in small value stocks by about four percentage points a year, on average, for the five years through September, according to Morningstar. Small Cap Contrarian, which started in April 1995 and has $339 million in assets, rose 26.6 percent for the 12 months through September, compared with 41.1 percent for its small-cap value peers.
 
New Funds
Flex-Partners International Equity aims for long-term growth by investing at least 70 percent of its portfolio in equity securities in developed countries and up to 30 percent in emerging markets.
Phoenix Growth and Income is managed by Steven Colton, who most recently ran American Century Income & Growth, and Dong Hao Zhang, former manager of American Century Equity Growth, using a value investment approach. Phoenix Core Equity will buy large, high-quality companies with reasonable valuations that its managers believe have the best potential to outperform the market.
 
Merger
Muir California Tax-Free has been merged into the Citizens Income fund. Both funds are members of the Citizens Trust family.
 
New Fund
Compass Capital International Small Cap Equity will use a value approach to picking stocks with market capitalizations of $100 million to $1 billion in developed and emerging markets. The maximum initial sales charge is 5 percent.
 
In Brief
Towneley Capital Management's Web site, www.towneley.com, offers various data on the four Eclipse funds: Balanced, Growth and Income, Equity and Ultra Short Term Income. The site includes monthly and quarterly performance, risk and other statistics, portfolio characteristics and prospectuses.
Dreyfus Small Company Value will close to new investors when assets reach $500 million. The fund currently has $341 million.
A 12-page booklet explaining how the new tax act affects mutual fund investors is available free from the Vanguard Group by calling (800) 523-8552, or through its Web site at www.vanguard.com. Vanguard also has a new 30-page booklet that discusses financing a child's college education. It is available free by calling (800) 523-7725.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By PATRICK J. LYONS

 BODY:

MARKETS
Tilting at Exuberance Again
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, was wearing his Cassandra hat in public again last week. In testimony before Congress, Mr. Greenspan returned to the themes of his famous December "irrational exuberance" speech, calling any hopes that the stock market will continue to roar upward at its recent pace unrealistic and warning that inflation remained a looming threat. As usual, he avoided saying definitely whether an interest-rate increase was in the offing, but investors took his remarks to heart and pushed stock and bond prices down.
 
MORE IS MORE
Buying the Competition
Federal Express struck a deal to expand into trucking and logistics by agreeing to buy Caliber for $2.7 billion, thereby also acquiring RPS, a big competitor in the business-to-business end of the speedy delivery market. One reason Caliber may have looked especially tempting to the generally acquisition-shy Fedex: Like Fedex (but unlike U.P.S.), Caliber is nonunion. . . . Not long ago, the North Fork Bancorporation had a half-dozen branches and a chairman trying to control costs by telling workers to make do with one pen and one pencil apiece. With a deal last week to buy New York Bancorp for $800 million, its ninth acquisition in as many years, North Fork will become the biggest bank on Long Island, and a serious competitor in the retail backyard of the giant New York City banks -- maybe serious enough to get itself bought in turn.
 
LESS IS MORE
Addition by Subtraction
Fed up with trying to persuade the market that its highly profitable finance arm ought to make its stock worth a lot more, the Ford Motor Company decided to hand over its 80.7 percent stake in Associates First Capital to Ford shareholders. The almost $18 billion spinoff accounts for nearly a third of Ford's market value but less than one-twelfth of its second-quarter profits. . . . Champion International also felt the urge to become a purer play, saying it would sell off roughly a quarter of the company to concentrate on coated papers, unbleached paperboard, softwood timberland and distribution. Analysts said Champion could net about $1.1 billion, including the sale of 325,000 acres of timberland, much of it in the environmentally and politically sensitive Adirondack Park in upstate New York.
 
TECHNOLOGY STOCKS
Sell on 'Oops,' Buy on Thud
A tale of two losses: On Monday, Silicon Graphics brought investors up short with word that it expected to report a loss for the quarter ended Sept. 30. The market, noting that the company's previous quarter was gangbusters and its competitors in the client-server business are thriving, reacted by hacking a third off its share price. On Tuesday evening, the chip maker Advanced Micro Devices reported an even bigger loss than analysts had been expecting since the company gave warning a month ago. Did the market mind? Not for long. After a rough morning, the stock rallied to close higher and rose again the next day.
 
SAFETY
Lock and Unload
The stories are heartbreakers: Children find their parents' handgun in the dresser drawer, they play with it and one winds up maimed or dead. Those stories ought to be growing rarer by the end of next year, when the manufacturers of most handguns made in the United States say they will be shipping all new handguns with a child-safety lock. . . . Chrysler continues to be haunted by allegations of defective rear door latches in the 4.1 million of its mini-vans built before 1996. A Federal jury in Charleston, S.C., awarded $262.5 million to the family of a six-year-old boy thrown from a mini-van in a 1994 traffic accident. Chrysler has a program to replace the latches but has not formally recalled the mini-vans. The company says it will appeal the verdict.
 
CURRENCY UNION
The Euro's Bitter Medicine
Getting Europe's economies synchronized for the introduction of the planned common currency in 1999 is proving painful. Germany's central bank felt compelled to head off any hint of inflation with a surprise interest-rate increase, its first tightening in more than five years, despite slow growth and record unemployment rolls. Five neighboring countries swiftly followed suit. In Italy, the center-left coalition Government of Romano Pradi, struggling to trim its too-big-for-the-Euro budget deficit, found itself cutting social welfare spending too deeply for the Communist Party to tolerate. Loss of the Communists' votes in Parliament brought down the Government.
 
SOUTHEAST ASIA
Indonesia Calls for Help
Long discredited in geopolitics, the domino theory seems to be reappearing in geofinance. Some of the same pressures that toppled the Thai baht over the summer have since set Indonesia's currency to teetering. Indonesia still has substantial reserves of foreign exchange, but the writing on the wall looked dire enough last week to prompt a request for standby aid from the International Monetary Fund to help stabilize the rupiah. Two more hard-hit currency dominoes, the Malaysian ringgit and Philippine peso, managed gains last week.
 
ACCUSATIONS
All the Way to the Top?
The senior F.B.I. agent in the investigation of possible fraud at Columbia/HCA, the nation's biggest hospital chain, called what the Government has uncovered so far a "systematic corporate scheme" perpetrated by senior executives -- and not an isolated error or aberration. The chain's billing and accounting practices may not ultimately prove to have been criminally improper, analysts said, but at the least, the company's defenses against pending shareholder lawsuits appear badly undermined by the contents of a 75-page affidavit partly unsealed last week. Neither the company nor its battered stock showed much reaction.
 
COINCIDENCES
There's That Word Again
What's hot, black, caffeinated and seemed to figure in every other headline last week? In politics, the long-running Washington donnybrook over campaign finance flared up when videotapes, shot at the famous White House coffees for high-rolling contributors, materialized belatedly. In Silicon Valley, Sun Microsystems sued Microsoft and threatened to yank its license to use Sun's Java programming language on the assertion that Microsoft had twisted Java into another way to seal the hegemony of its Windows operating system. In media, the editor of The Los Angeles Times, Shelby Coffey 3d, resigned, denying that he was driven out by corporate plans to give marketing executives unprecedented sway in the newsroom. Even in the weather report, a hurricane bearing down on Mexico's coffee country made commodity traders jittery at midweek. The storm devastated the coast but largely spared the crop; by Friday the futures pits had calmed down and so had prices, closing up mere pennies from a week earlier and still far below their May peak.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1299 words

HEADLINE: Whip Deflation Now?;
Two Cheers for Inflation, Given the Alternative

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
INFLATION made headlines last week. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned that labor shortages could lead to rising prices. The German central bank raised a key interest rate, citing as a reason the need to prevent inflation. And the Labor Department reported that an index that measures the prices of goods as they leave American factories jumped sharply in September. But for all the focus on inflation as a big threat to the economy, Wall Street analysts, economists and investors talk increasingly about its opposite -- deflation -- as the potential source of the next crisis.
Deflation, last experienced in the Depression, means falling prices across the economy. That is not even close to happening now. But just as Wall Street has worried over a rising inflation rate long after it stopped rising, now it begins to speak of deflation as the direction prices could easily take if the economy weakens. 
 "Deflation is a word that has two meanings on Wall Street right now," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a bond firm. "One is the good meaning: that companies are more efficient, so they can lower prices and still make good profits. The other is the bad meaning, that companies can produce much more than people will buy and prices will tumble."
Two recent developments, both bad, are encouraging the almost casual use of the word deflation, a descriptive noun shunned for its scary connotations or confined to tales of the Depression, when prices and wages fell and unemployment shot up. One is the unusual spectacle of a falling inflation rate -- it is now just over 2 percent annually as measured by the Consumer Price Index -- in the midst of a strong economy. Since the 1960's, inflation has risen sharply during economic expansions and more slowly during most recessions. The concern today is that, during a downturn, the already-low inflation rate could slip below zero.
 
Zero for the Year
 One inflation measure, the Producer Price Index, measuring what manufacturers and other producers charge wholesalers and retailers for their goods, has actually fallen most of this year. A jump of five-tenths of a percent in September, reported on Friday, brought the annual rate up to zero. "That jump was clearly due to temporary factors that will disappear," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch.
The other concern is overcapacity. Just when factories are opening or expanding around the globe, the booming Asian countries -- big importers from the United States and other industrial nations -- are cutting back on purchases, raising the specter of too many goods chasing too few buyers. That is a recipe for falling prices.
"I was describing the Asian situation in a luncheon speech at the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations this week," said David Hale, chief economist at Zurich Kemper Investments. "I said the result could be more disinflation, by which I meant that prices could rise even more slowly than they are now. And a money manager in the audience got up and said, 'Why do you talk of disinflation? Why don't you say deflation?' "
The anecdote illustrates, Mr. Hale says, that Wall Street is relaxing a little about inflation. Stock and bond traders have traditionally put great pressure on the Federal Reserve to fight inflation, existing or expected, by raising interest rates to slow economic growth. The majority still do. But a shift in mood, reflected in the growing references to deflation, has diluted that pressure.
The Fed itself seems caught between concern that inflation will rise and the fact that the actual inflation rate is declining. Mr. Greenspan's comments have reflected the uncertainty.
In speeches and testimony over the last six months, Mr. Greenspan has suggested that the United States might have entered a new era of rising productivity that helps companies hold down prices -- the good deflation -- and still keep profits growing. And he has suggested that job insecurity may be inhibiting wage demands.
But on Wednesday Mr. Greenspan argued that the strong economy is using up the nation's labor supply and that worker shortages must inevitably push up wages and then prices, despite the improvement in productivity.
"It is clear that the Fed chairman on Wednesday took strong issue with the deflationist minority," Mr. Jones said.
The deflation-inflation debate divides executives even within Wall Street firms. Stephen S. Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, for example, is an inflation hawk, and he applauded Mr. Greenspan's freshly stated view that rising inflation is the big risk.
"Very bluntly, the deflation talk is in the market because it is bullish," Mr. Roach said. "If you can make a case for deflation, the Federal Reserve won't raise interest rates, and in doing so end the stock market rally. These deflationists are just talking their book."
But Barton Biggs, Morgan Stanley's chief strategist for global equities, worries about deflation. "I am not saying deflation is going to happen," he said. "I am saying we could be in an environment where prices are as likely to go down as they are to go up. We are involved in investing in companies all over the world, and it is just stunning to hear the managers of these companies talk about how they can't raise prices. And frankly, it frightens me."
Partly because of such fears, long-term bond yields have fallen in anticipation of harder times. Interest rates on mortgages and car loans have fallen in tandem. And stock prices have risen sharply, in part because stocks seemed to offer a better return than Treasury securities and bonds, with their falling yields.
"The chairman was concerned that the combination of rising stock prices and falling interest rates would then, unintentionally, be the stimulus for a fresh surge of economic growth that would finally be inflationary," Mr. Jones said. Since Mr. Greenspan's testimony, stock prices have fallen and bond yields have risen.
The new circumstances are markedly different from the ones that got people using the word deflation in the past. The word surfaced briefly after the 1987 stock market crash, but quickly disappeared. In the post-Civil War decades, prices fell as industrialization and rising productivity flooded the nation with goods.
Mass production and new technology kept the prices of these goods falling, much as technology breakthroughs keep computer prices falling today. But a growing, ever more prosperous population absorbed the flood of goods and the nation entered a golden era, although falling food prices hurt farmers and fomented Populism. In the 1930's, a different deflation struck. With banks failing and stocks plunging, people stopped buying and prices and wages fell drastically. Debts became hard to pay, and consumers made matters worse by putting off purchases, waiting for prices to fall even more.
Some on Wall Street today use deflation to mean a version of the post-Civil War golden era. Mr. Steinberg at Merrill Lynch is in this camp. "The term deflation makes people nervous," he writes, yet "costs have declined faster than prices" and profits have risen. Others, like Mr. Biggs, see in the growing overcapacity a deflation closer to that of the Depression era, although much milder. And a third, majority group, represented by Mr. Roach, insists that rising inflation is the issue.
The Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, which compiles the Consumer Price Index, sees mainly disinflation. It reports that prices have been rising much more slowly for many items, including medical care and new autos. "The result," said Patrick Jackman, chief of the Bureau's C.P.I. division, "is an inflation rate this year that has not been lower in two decades."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Depression was the last time prices fell. Shopping in 1938, Marshalltown, Iowa. (Arthur Rothstein, from "The Depression Years")(pg. 5)
 
Graph: "Going Down"
Inflation usually rises sharply at the end of an economic expansion; it rises more slowly as a recession takes hold, a phenomenon known as disinflation. In the last year, however, the inflation rate has dropped by nearly a percentage point despite a strong economy, raising the possiblity that in the next recession it may slip below zero, into inflation. HEADLINE: Jeeves, Shred This;
Luxury Is a Car You Can Work In

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
BACK in 1923, Rolls-Royce accessorized a stately Silver Ghost with a gun rack, a large spotlight and a Gatling gun so its owner, an Indian prince, could hunt tigers.
But as membership in the world's upper crust has changed, so have cars. In 1995, a Silver Spur was created for a businessman who wanted all the comforts of the office when he was on the road. The car had a fold-out fax machine and printer, a walnut case for a laptop and slots in the ceiling for filing paperwork. 
 For nearly a century, luxury cars have been barometers of the world's upper classes -- and their tastes. These days, a growing proportion of the buyers of Rolls-Royces, Aston Martins, Porsches and other extravagant cars are businessmen.
Since what passes for luxury in the 1990's is the ability to work all the time, many Rolls-Royces are being designed as portable offices, not just portable bars. Younger magnates are ordering theirs with five phone lines as well as a fax and an outlet to plug in a computer for the Internet, CD-ROM equipment and computerized navigation systems.
Are luxury cars becoming remotely practical? Not quite.
"In one sense, the businessman justifies to himself why he's spending so much," said Clive Chajet, a New York City consultant on corporate identity. Yet turning a Rolls-Royce into a mobile office makes it more of a status symbol in the workaholic 90's. "You're signaling that not only are you successful but, boy, are you busy," Mr. Chajet said.
More businessmen can afford these luxury cars since their salaries have swelled to fortunes -- last year's top-earning chief executive officer, Lawrence M. Coss of Green Tree Financial, was paid $102 million.
That kind of money comes in handy for putting a hold order on Aston Martin's cheapest car, which is $125,000. A specialized Porsche can cost $100,000; Rolls-Royce prices start at about $150,000 but can escalate to $2 million or more for owners insisting on bomb-proofing or on gold plating on its hood ornament, the Flying Lady.
Executives have become less shy about indulging their wealth lately, what with the economy growing and fewer companies wracked by downsizing. "You can't lay off 30 people and then drive to the office in a brand-new Rolls," said Daniel J. Phillips, publisher of the Robb Report, a monthly magazine for the rich.
While luxury car companies have always had their share of celebrity clients -- from old Hollywood to arriviste sports stars -- Rolls-Royce buyers are more and more often "self-made people who have been extremely successful because of their hard work," said Graham J. Morris, the chief executive of Rolls-Royce Motor Cars P.L.C., which began building cars in 1905. The world's riches, he says, are increasingly going to a business class, not to nobility.
"Despite our customers being very wealthy, they demand an absolute value for their money," Mr. Morris said. "They didn't become wealthy by throwing their money away." Microsoft's Bill Gates, who drives Porsches and not yet Rolls-Royces, is famous for flying economy class.
"They really want to know what the car will do and how it will handle," said Roger J. Miller, general manager of Rolls-Royce of Beverly Hills, where sales to executives -- largely those from computer companies -- are up 30 percent from a decade ago.
The boom in business buyers isn't just in this country. One of the best markets for Rolls-Royce has been Hong Kong, where sales have been strong all year. "A lot of rich and influential Chinese are coming over the border," Mr. Morris explained. "Long may that go on."
Indeed, some say the changing tastes in cars may reflect democracy's triumph over communism. "The fundamental change is the victory of capitalism and the respectability that financial success has gained," said Mr. Chajet. "Capitalism has really won."
Perhaps that depends on how you measure it. The 1961 Rolls-Royce Phantom that belonged to Hong Kong's former colonial Governor, Chris Patten, is on its way back to the United Kingdom. At best, it will be relegated to a museum. At worst, it will be sold as a used car.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Republican Remedies;
Speak Less Loudly And Stop Calling the Speaker 'Newt'

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AFTER the election of 1994, President Clinton sank into despair as Republicans took control of Congress. But ever since a resurgent Mr. Clinton won re-election last year, it is the Republicans who have been suffering through a crisis of confidence.
Now self-flagellation is practically their favorite sport. For a year, debate has reverberated through the party ranks and the conservative intelligentsia: Was the loss of 1996 the fault of an uncompromising right wing? Was a tongue-tied, aging, Establishment candidate the problem? Was the party outmaneuvered by a Democratic President who stole its issues? Maybe moderates were to blame. Or how about the tide of history, which left conservatives looking for a new rationale after the cold war? 
 At least one Republican strategist thinks it's time to move on. Several months ago, Frank Luntz, the wunderkind consultant who helped draft the "Contract With America," sent Republicans in Congress an unsolicited, 222-page advice manual-cum-pep talk that began, "For all those who have complained that we have no 'message,' this book was written for you."
Here are excerpts from the prologue of his treatise, "The Language of the 21st Century," instructing Republicans on how to connect with the American public. ALISON MITCHELL
When I was a child, my mother had a Portuguese maid named Maria who came to clean our house once a week. She was a strong, kindly woman who never missed a day of work and really loved my family. The only problem was, she didn't speak a word of English.
For 10 years I witnessed the same routine every Tuesday morning. She would arrive at 7 A.M. sharp. My mom would meet her at the door and explain in English exactly what she wanted done. Maria would look at her quizzically and shrug her shoulders, prompting my mom to repeat her words exactly as before -- only much louder. This would go on week after week, until finally I said, "Mom, she's not deaf. She just doesn't understand English."
The Republican Party in 1997 is just like my mom. Every time Republicans get into a conflict with the President, you begin to shout, mistakenly believing that if you speak loudly enough, your message will get through. But the American people aren't deaf. They simply don't understand what you're saying or understand its relevance to their day-to-day lives.
You have suffered through communication disaster after communication disaster, and nothing ever seems to change. Task forces, rapid response teams, truth squads and other structural fixes have not addressed the more fundamental and potentially fatal problem: Linguistically, you are out of touch with the American people. They really think Bill Clinton feels their pain, and they really think you feel nothing.
To make his point, Mr. Luntz cited the spring standoff in which Republicans attached miscellaneous political measures to a disaster relief bill, prompting Mr. Clinton to veto aid to flood victims. Hurt by the ensuing public uproar, Republicans backed down and passed the relief bill unencumbered:
The disaster relief disaster was just the latest wake-up call. Telling everyone you failed to communicate effectively is not effective communication. A thorough change in language and emphasis is long overdue. The following should help you communicate in language that is soothing to the American ear.
Mr. Luntz then lists a dozen points:
1. Principles are more important than policy or politics. The hallowed halls of Washington echo with the sounds of Republican actors and activists clamoring for a new agenda. Yet in my weekly forays into real America, I have found that average Americans could not care less about agenda politics. Americans aren't searching for an agenda. They're looking for principles and the politicians who exhibit them. The way to convince a cynical populace that you deserve their support is to demonstrate that you are standing up for principle, not that you are loyal to a cause.
2. Try going five minutes selling Republican ideas and principles without criticizing Bill Clinton or the Democrats. Sure it's more fun to attack the opposition, particularly when they are so wrong, but the American people have had enough of all the bickering. . . . Remember, mud splatters, and every time you attack, you soil yourself as well.
3. Stop overselling your achievements. You may not want to hear this, but almost no one outside of the Beltway (or on Capitol Hill for that matter) thinks the recent budget and tax agreements are home runs. Why are you selling them that way?
4. Stop being defensive. Instead of talking about recent strategic failures, talk about the principles you have attempted to defend. For example, if the topic is your attempt to avoid a Government shutdown, ONLY talk about "getting your message across," "end games" and "doing a better job explaining things" IN PRIVATE. In public, you should instead talk about the PRINCIPLES of "working together," "listening to the people," "making the government run more effectively and less expensively" and so on. Americans want to know your motives. Only journalists want to know your tactics.
5. Appeal directly to the voter. You know just how overtaxed Americans feel they are. . . . You know how much money Americans feel is wasted by Washington. Appeal to that emotion. Republican leaders have to attack the President from time to time, but if you want to be effective, get the American people on your side rhetorically BEFORE you launch.
6. Embrace the moral agenda. Four out of five Americans believe that our country is facing a moral crisis, yet too many Republicans judge the health of America by the Dow Jones Industrial Average. They are missing the sickness in the soul of our nation. You cannot shy away from discussing values. In fact you should embrace them. . . . America is in danger of winning the whole world -- economically, militarily, ideologically -- and losing her soul.
7. Abolish the National Endowment for the Arts. This makes sense for strategic reasons as well as on principle. Napoleon spoke of the importance of feeding your army if you expect your soldiers to go off to battle. You must deliver some nourishment to the true believers. The budget and tax agreements aren't going to drive social conservatives to the polls on Election Day. You need a symbol that both differentiates the two parties and stirs up the troops. If you truly believe in shrinking Washington and returning power (and money) to local authorities, start with the arts.
8. Start a national-local education partnership. Newt Gingrich's greatest accomplishment in the 104th Congress was shepherding welfare reform through Congress. Without the support, participation and political capital of the 32 Republican governors, welfare reform would still be on the shelf. The Speaker and the Senate majority leader need to adopt the same strategy in the education reform effort and that requires turning over the education debate to the governors.
9. End Washington-mandated affirmative action now. If welfare reform was the Speaker's crowning achievement, his unwillingness to abolish Federal affirmative action laws has been his biggest mistake.
10. If you want to focus on policy rather than politics, stop talking about politics. The only people who follow the internal struggles of the Congressional leadership are the players themselves. If you don't want the media to focus on internecine warfare, stop answering questions on the subject. Better yet, change the subject.
11. Stop calling the Speaker "Newt." The elected office generally holds a greater deal of respect than the man or woman who is temporary custodian of that title. That's why you never hear Bill Clinton's advisers or Cabinet officers referring to him by name (much less his first name). It's always "the President." If you really want to help restore Newt Gingrich's credibility, start referring to him by his title.
12. Stop stacking votes. For three straight years, Republicans have missed countless opportunities to receive deserved credit for passing popular legislation because they have held multiple high-profile votes in the same week. Take a lesson from Presidents Reagan and Clinton. Any more than one theme -- or one major vote -- at a time will be lost on the American people.
Before he launched into pages more of advice, Mr. Luntz said: "We don't need a Contract II or an Agenda 2000. We simply need to stop the name-calling and talk about principles."
