HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Maybe a Bankrupt Nation Isn't The Worst Thing in the World

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN political systems collapse, the United Nations now routinely arrives to glue things together and organize or monitor elections, whether the problem erupts in Cambodia, Angola or Mozambique. When currencies collapse, the International Monetary Fund shows up. Its team of experts parachutes in, often followed by billions in loans to restore the confidence of international investors who suddenly discovered, to their shock, that last week's emerging market is this week's submerging one.
Mexico was the patient two years ago, but the lessons of its debacle never fully sank in around the globe. This summer the Philippines and Thailand got the treatment, and last week Indonesia became the latest to call for help. Lost in all the headlines about rescue packages, though, is a question that many American officials are quietly raising around the world: Does it always make sense to save countries and their investors from dumb mistakes? Put another way, has the knowledge that the world will not let countries fail actually encouraged investors to lend their money cheaply to almost anyone, even to countries that overbuild, overspend and, in cases like Mexico and Indonesia, make corruption a national sport? 
 "This may be the toughest issue we face today, and we're wrestling with it every day," Stanley Fischer, the No. 2 official at the I.M.F., said the other day between meetings about how to prop up Indonesia's fragmenting banking system.
 
World to the Rescue
 Naturally, politicians hate coming to the I.M.F. for help. Not only is it embarrassing, but the aid usually comes with strings attached, forcing the countries to reveal uncomfortable financial details and to discipline their economies.
But investors, even small investors who funnel cash into developing-country mutual funds, "probably take some comfort from the possibility that if in trouble, countries can borrow from the I.M.F.," Mr. Fischer said.
That is a polite way of saying that every time the world saves a country -- not just from huge crises like the one that hit Mexico but also from milder growing pains like those that took the roar out of the Asian tigers -- it also saves the big-time investors from paying a steep price for putting their money in the wrong place. The austerity program the Mexican Government put in place when its economy faltered was a devastating blow to the country's working poor, but the big investors emerged largely unscathed. The immediate goal of the United States and the I.M.F., which together led the $50 billion bailout plan, was to insure that the Mexicans did not default on their debts -- so that one day soon they could once again borrow on world markets. That day arrived quickly, and the country has repaid most of its loans.
So by most measures the Mexican bailout was such a success that, perversely, it sent the wrong message to international investors. "Would I have liked to figure out a way to save Mexico and still make the investors take a haircut?" Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin asked rhetorically not long ago. "Yes, I would have. The problem is, we have not figured out an effective way to do that yet."
Investors, however, have not been spared all the pain. If your broker suggested a few mutual funds last year that buy up the stocks of Malaysian and Thai firms, you definitely winced as their currencies dropped in value by a third. But the big investment houses that lent money to those countries' wildly overextended and underregulated banks have barely suffered at all. Nations don't like their banks to fail, so they bail them out, as the United States did in the savings and loan scandals, and as Japan did when its inflated property market was found to be built like a house of cards.
Part of the problem is that far more countries can borrow money on international markets than ever before. Lawrence Summers, Mr. Rubin's deputy, noted in a speech recently that five years ago only 16 countries could borrow money on the global capital markets. Today, 56 countries can, and "that has spurred much of the rapid growth seen around the world," Mr. Summers said. The question, he added, is "whether borrower and lenders recognize that returns do not come without risks."
 
An Energetic Tango
 Look at Argentina, which President Clinton will visit this week to celebrate the sweep of capitalism and democracy throughout Latin America. For most of the past half century, Argentina was a hyperinflating wasteland. In the last six or seven years, it has been a success story; such a success story that when Argentina issues a 10-year global bond these days, which is the standard way of borrowing money from investors around the world, it offers to pay them an interest rate that is only two-and-a-quarter points above what investors receive for comparable United States Treasury bonds. Not only Argentina delights in borrowing cheaply. So does Russia -- and so does Albania.
Those interest-rate differences -- what investors call the spread between United States Treasury bonds and those issued by another nation -- represent the market's risk assessment of whether the country will pay up. And over the past few years, the size of those spreads has gradually diminished, a sign that investors think the risk is also diminishing. Partly, that is the I.M.F. effect. And it has its costs: When countries can borrow cheaply, they are less likely to reform their economies.
This could be more evidence, of course, of worldwide prosperity, and confidence that it will continue. But it may also be a sign of what Alan Greenspan called irrational exuberance, applied on a global scale. One day, a rescue plan may fail.

HEADLINE: Tighter Borders Also Keeping Illegal Immigrants in the U.S.

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11

 BODY:
A study of California's agricultural communities concludes that illegal immigrants working in the United States stay in this country instead of returning to their homelands because of fears about tightened security at the Mexican border.
The study, titled "Poverty Amid Prosperity," was released on Thursday by the Urban Institute, a research group in Washington. 
 It found that the illegal immigrants make up 40 percent of the California farm work force today, compared with under 10 percent in 1990, after the amnesty program of the late 1980's. The percentage continues to grow, the study found.
"People are still getting in through the border, and because it's tougher to get back in once they leave, they're staying longer," said a co-author of the study, Philip L. Martin, an economist at the University of California at Davis.
In the past decade, the Federal Government has more than doubled Border Patrol forces at the border while using more enforcement money and hardware than ever before, from the Pacific Ocean to the Gulf of Mexico. But increased enforcement has driven prices charged by smugglers higher while pushing illegal immigrant traffic away from thoroughly policed hubs like San Diego to the deserts and mountains to the east, where Border Patrol ranks are stretched thin.
Some officials concede that the building pressure has served to turn temporary illegal immigrants into permanent residents.
"It's a predictable response," said Eric Andrus, spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, who considered the phenomenon evidence of success at the border. "This is another sign that our efforts to control the border are working."

HEADLINE: Critics Say Clinton Panel About Race Lacks Focus

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Three months after President Clinton appointed a seven-member advisory board to help develop a national dialogue on race, the initiative is being criticized for its slow start and lack of focus. Some critics say the board's desultory beginning even raises the question of whether the White House is using the panel to duck, rather than confront, the country's thorny racial issues.
Advocates, writers and academics involved in race relations issues -- both on the right and on the left -- have in recent days expressed disappointment with Mr. Clinton's Initiative on Race and Reconciliation. They say that the panel has already frittered away a quarter of its yearlong deadline and has yet to decide which of the myriad issues that deal with race it will tackle. 
 "It's rudderless," said Ward Connerly, a member of the University of California Board of Regents who has emerged as a leader in the fight against race-based preferences.
"There is a shared sense that it's got to have some focus and take on some of the tough issues in the area of race," said Hugh Price, president of the National Urban League. "It's got to aim to do something."
Conservatives say that by avoiding affirmative action the panel is sidestepping the most explosive racial issue. And some liberals say that the panel's slow start is giving an impression that the body is little more than a veneer to cover White House indifference to racial issues.
Roger Wilkins, a professor of history at George Mason University, said the President's greatest risk is to start an effort and then not follow through. "If that happens," he said, "then people will say, even on race, where he is supposed to have some genuine feeling, when the rubber hits the road, Bill Clinton wasn't serious."
Members of the advisory board and its staff acknowledge the effort's slow start and the criticism it has drawn. "I am not surprised there is a degree of impatience about what we're doing and how fast we're doing it," said Judith Winston, the board's staff director.
While saying that the criticism is premature, some board and staff members also acknowledge that they have been hampered by a lack of direction from the Administration.
"We are dependent on direction from the White House as to where we should be going," said Thomas H. Kean, a board member and former Republican Governor of New Jersey. Conservatives who disagree with Mr. Clinton on hot-button racial issues like affirmative action tend to be much more dismissive, pointing out that the panel's makeup does not include people who question race-based preference programs.
"If you want to do a serious commission, you need to get a variety of voices," said Abigail Thernstrom, a co-author with her husband, Stephan, of "America in Black and White: One Nation, Indivisible" and a critic of affirmative action. "It's monologue. Let's have a dialogue."
But liberals, who were hopeful that the panel's work would lead to better race relations, say its lack of focus reflects a lack of commitment by Mr. Clinton. They compare the board's work with the Administration's sharp focus on issues like free trade agreements with Latin America. "I think what people are sensing now is a lack of energy," Mr. Wilkins said.
White House officials recently have taken steps to try to better coordinate the panel's efforts. On Friday Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, convened a meeting with senior members of the President's staff to urge them to take the matter more seriously. At the meeting, it was decided that people like Gene Sperling, head of the National Economic Council; Bruce Reid, a senior adviser to the President; Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, and others would begin to work regularly with the staff of the advisory board.
Though Mr. Clinton announced the formation of the board, headed by John Hope Franklin, in a speech in San Diego in mid-June, the White House did not have a staff ready to step in to do the nitty-gritty research that such an effort requires. Indeed, the board's staff director, Ms. Winston, was not appointed until the first week in August and has only in the last few weeks assembled a staff.
Aware that the work has gotten off to a slow start, White House officials now say that the one-year deadline could be extended.
Ms. Winston said that staff and board members are starting to work more efficiently. Individual board members have been looking at places that are successfully grappling with racial issues and hope to be able to recommend to Mr. Clinton ways those efforts can be duplicated.
"It's not how you start, it's how you finish," Ms. Winston said. "I think that on this issue to have a series of false starts would be more damning than starting slow and doing it right."

HEADLINE: Dairy Farmers' Woes Grow by the Gallon;
Milk Producers See a Way of Life Threatened by Lagging Prices and Rising Costs

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

DATELINE: CANAJOHARIE, N.Y.

 BODY:
As it often does in the fall, the price of milk at the grocery store is going up by as much as 25 cents a gallon in some parts of the New York metropolitan area.
That ought to be good news in the rolling hills of dairy country west of Albany. Instead, here, as in dairy areas across New York State, New Jersey, Connecticut and much of the rest of the nation, dairy farmers are saying that what little they will see of the money will be too little and too late. 
 The price farmers are paid for their milk is as low as it was a decade ago. But the cost of running a dairy farm has climbed. The result, according to government and private estimates, is that an average dairy farmer in the New York region is now paid less for a gallon of milk than it costs to produce that amount.
That money-losing formula means that in places where dairy farming is not just the biggest industry but a way of life, people are beginning to speak of a new farm crisis. In dairy areas like this one in Montgomery County, merchants and bankers say a ripple effect of farm failures and faltering local economies is worse than anything they have seen in decades, even though people in urban America have not seemed to notice.
Donald R. Davidsen, New York State's Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, said the financial stresses could force as many as 1,000 of New York's 9,000 dairy farms out of business. In New Jersey, Art Brown Jr., the Secretary of Agriculture, said the state could lose 50 of about 215 remaining dairy farms.
Shirley Ferris, the Commissioner of Agriculture in Connecticut, did the math. "Dairy farmers are getting the same amount for their milk as they did 10 years ago, but the cost of everything they have to buy has quadrupled," she said. "I don't need to say any more."
Dairy farms have been vanishing for much of this century, and farmers' complaints are so familiar that some milk distributors and consumer advocates dismiss the current anxiety as little more than a new round of lobbying for higher prices.
But government and academic experts say the financial crisis in many dairy regions is more urgent than it has been in years. "Farmers are feeling powerless to do anything about it," said Andrew Novakovic, an expert on dairy issues who is chairman of the agricultural, resource and managerial economics department at Cornell University.
Estimates of farm production costs by farm credit agencies so far this year suggest that the average dairy farm in New York and New Jersey has lost about 14 cents for every gallon of milk. Connecticut farmers have lost about 3 cents.
Here in Montgomery County, where the 237 dairy farms are important institutions in the lives of its 50,000 residents, the mood among farmers is desperate. "I don't think people understand, and I don't think they care as long as there's milk on the shelf when they go into the store," Christine Nellis said as she took a break from the 5 A.M. to 7 P.M. schedule she keeps on the dairy farm she works with her husband.
To nods of agreement from other dairy farmers around a neighbor's kitchen table, Mrs. Nellis said she once believed that sophisticated management would allow good farm managers to prevail. Now, she said, as every gallon she sells increases her losses, she no longer believes that. After a year of backbreaking labor, she said, she and her husband broke even last year.
The price that farmers are paid for their milk fell this summer partly because of an oversupply of milk nationally and partly because of new Federal policies intended to remove Government price supports. Agricultural experts say the prices paid to farmers are likely to remain low.
Commissioner Davidsen of New York said increased dairy farm failures could shift one of the region's oldest industries to other parts of the country. But perhaps of broader interest, he said, is that dairy farm failures would open to development vast new tracts of farm land that have provided a bucolic buffer around the region's cities. The number of dairy farms in New York State has slipped to 9,000 from 14,500 in 1987.
One effort at easing dairy farm distress is the Northeast Dairy Compact, a federally approved program in the six New England states: Connecticut, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont. The Federal law permitting the compact allows a commission to set a milk price that is higher than the price farmers would receive otherwise. Without the compact, the farm price is set according to a formula that links the price of milk to the price of cheese.
In Connecticut, farmers received an additional 11 cents a gallon in July, the first month the compact was in force. Some farmers here in eastern New York State who ship their milk to New England are receiving the higher price.
Critics call the compact a legal cartel. State officials in Connecticutcalculate that it has cost consumers at least 20 cents a gallon because the higher prices were passed on to consumers. In September, the average price of a gallon of whole milk was $2.90 in Connecticut. In the New York City area, it was $2.53. In northern New Jersey, it was $2.70.
Some farmers are pressuring New York State to join the compact. Farmers are sharply divided on the issue, however, with some saying they would fight any new form of regulation. The State Legislature, which would have to vote on the compact, has not been enthusiastic about the proposal in the past.
But even among farmers in Connecticut and those here in eastern New York who have been receiving the additional 11 cents a gallon, the compact has hardly been greeted as the solution to their problems. Many say it is little more than a Band-Aid that perpetuates an image of dairy interests squeezing consumers.
Some farmers who have been receiving the additional 11 cents say it is not enough to make them solvent. Eleven of Connecticut's 270 dairy farms have folded this year.
In Canajoharie, David Caldwell, 55, is lucky. His 35-cow farm sells to a distributor that ships milk to New England, so he has been getting the extra 11 cents.
The added money, he said, helps but is not enough to stop the financial drain. Mr. Caldwell said his finances have deteriorated every year since he moved to the farm with his wife and four children in 1981. Last year, he said, he declared a gross income of $6,000 on his tax return. "Any other investment you can sell," he said. "What do you do, put an ad in the paper: 'Losing Farm for Sale'?"
Such stories do not move everyone. In Brooklyn, Henry Beyer, president of a milk wholesaler in New York City, Beyer Farms Inc., said that even if the region's smaller farmers were losing their place to bigger producers outside the region, that was only economics at work.
"If they're inefficient and they're small and they're going to go out of business, that doesn't mean the consumer should subsidize them," said Mr. Beyer, who is a spokesman for New York State Dairy Foods Inc., a trade group of milk wholesalers and processors.
But around the kitchen table at Mike Cole's dairy farm here, farmers made dire predictions. "I can't make ends meet," Mrs. Nellis said as other farmers agreed. "And that will catch up with me and it will be devastating."
Many in Montgomery County are convinced of the dairy farmers' predicament and its effect on them.
Donald L. Brass, the chief executive of Central National Bank of Canajoharie, said rising costs and sliding milk prices have caused great anxiety for the farmers and the bank. He said the bank, which has been a major farm lender for more than a century, had never seen so many of its customers so close to being unable to repay their loans.
At Randall Implement Company, which sells dairy farm machinery here, the owner, Robert Freeman, said that in 31 years in business he had not seen so many customers late with their payments or in default. One salesmen, he said, used to call on 40 dairy farms. Of those, he said, 8 folded this summer.
Mr. Freeman said he had seen many ups and downs for dairy farmers. But now, he said, "I think the spirit's broke. Or it's bent awfully bad. And that's the scary part. Farmers are resilient. But I've never seen it as bad."

HEADLINE: Report Says Health of Society Lags Behind That of Economy

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
An annual analysis of 16 social indicators shows the nation's social health is improving, but noted that this was only the second time in seven years that such an improvement has been seen.
The analysis, the Index of Social Health, is produced by the Fordham Institute for Innovation in Social Policy in Tarrytown, N.Y. It is constructed on the model of the Dow Jones Industrial Average, combining statistics from a number of areas, from drug abuse to average wages. 
 "Although any improvement is a good sign," said Marc L. Miringoff, the institute's director, "the overall picture in the 1990's is not very encouraging. Of the eight worst years since 1970, six have been in this decade. The social health of the nation has not kept up with the recovery of the economy."
The first such report, produced in 1985, used statistics dating to 1970 and found that the nation's best year during that period was 1973, with an index of 77.5 out of a possible 100. Since then, the worst year has been 1994, when the index hit 37.5. This year's report analyzed figures from 1995, yielding an index of 40.
The six indicators from 1995 that showed improvement were the percentage of children in poverty, unemployment, poverty among the elderly, homicides, the gap between rich and poor, and alcohol-related traffic fatalities. Those worsening were health insurance coverage, drug abuse, average wages, the percentage of high school dropouts and food stamp coverage.
Indicators that remained about the same were teen-age suicide, out-of-pocket health costs for the elderly, access to affordable housing, infant mortality and child abuse.
In a special section, the report analyzed long-term trends in two indicators: wages and health insurance coverage. Average weekly pay hit a peak, in constant dollars, of $315 in 1973, and was $256 in 1996.
"From the end of World War II to 1973, American wages increased virtually every year," the report said. "From 1973 to the present, wages either declined or stagnated."
And the report put the number of Americans without health insurance at 40.6 million, an increase of 41 percent since 1976.
"These trends in wages and health insurance tell us much about our basic condition," Mr. Miringoff said. "Like poor test results from the doctor, they are a warning sign."
The United States, the institute says, is the only industrialized nation that does not officially monitor overall social progress, although economic analysis is comprehensive.
The report took special note of the growing gap between the nation's economic and social well-being. "The fact that trends in Gross Domestic Product and social health, once so similar, have consistently diverged for so long a period of time supports the idea that the Gross Domestic Product along does not tell as much as it once did about the condition of the nation," the report concluded.

HEADLINE: Golf Is Carving a Place in Colorado's Ski Country

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: CARBONDALE, Colo.

 BODY:
With a perfect swing, Jack Nicklaus recently sent a golf ball arcing through the thin mountain air, past a sylvan backdrop of golden aspen leaves, a languid trout stream and the granite mass of Mount Sipris.
"When I first came up here, in 1975, there was basically one public golf course in the Vail valley and another in this valley," said Mr. Nicklaus, the golf professional and golf-course architect, after inaugurating Aspen Glen, a course in the Aspen valley. "Now I have two in each valley." 
 In Colorado's high country, golf is experiencing in the 1990's the kind of explosive growth that skiing had in the 1960's. Though no new ski areas have opened in Colorado since 1982, the number of golf courses in the Vail and Aspen valleys has quadrupled, to 20 from 5. Along Aspen's 42-mile-long river valley, golf courses are opening at the rate of one a year.
Critics say this march of the golf courses is accentuating class divisions. As real estate prices soar, workers face longer and longer commutes to jobs in the gold-plated resort towns. In addition, most of the new courses are private, doing little to lure vacationers who could help the ski-town hotels fill rooms in the summer and fall.
But with private golf clubs charging initiation fees of up to $100,000 and greens fees as high as $195 a round, the demand for memberships has led developers to plan a total of 10 more private courses in both valleys in the next decade.
Only 2 of Vail valley's 11 courses are open to the public. The rest are private centerpieces of luxury second-home developments like Aspen Glen, a former 964-acre cattle ranch where empty quarter-acre lots on the Roaring Fork River sell for $575,000.
"There are days when we will turn away more golfers than we will take in," said Ken Everett, director of the Snowmass Lodge and Club, a public course near here.
In addition to trying to balance summer-winter resort economies, the mountain golfing boom has been attributed to the aging of baby boomers, the longer golfing seasons in the mountains and the fact that golf balls travel about 12 percent farther at 6,000 feet than at sea level.
In the old days, the 1970's, golfing seasons ran from Memorial Day to early October, and the courses were mostly at the bases of ski areas like Aspen, Copper, Keystone and Vail.
But the new courses are being built in the "banana belts" -- the valley areas that are often 1,500 feet lower than the ski towns. The dream of Colorado's amateur athletes -- ski in the morning, golf in the afternoon -- is now a springtime reality in the Rockies.
"We are almost 100 days longer in terms of golfable days than they are at the Vail golf courses," said Fred Kummer, who is planning a development with 36 holes of golf about 40 minutes west of Vail. "The lower we get in elevation, the longer the seasons we can have."
The experience of Mr. Kummer, the owner of Colorado's largest hotel, the Adam's Mark of Denver, is an example of Colorado's gradual shift in resort development to golf from skiing.
Almost 30 years ago, he started petitioning the Forest Service for a permit to build a ski area on Federal land adjoining 5,000 acres he owned. Although the permit was issued in 1981, wrangling with environmentalists and having to get more government approvals delayed the project until Mr. Kummer finally gave up last May.
Now, building only on his own land, Mr. Kummer said he hoped to start construction in a year on a development with three golf courses, a 125-room hotel and 1,270 houses.
"The difference is that the golf courses are all built on private land," Mr. Kummer said of the boom in the number of courses. In Colorado, almost all ski areas are built on Forest Service land. Though no new ski areas have opened in Colorado in the last 15 years, the acreage of ski slopes increased by 43 percent and the number of days spent skiing in the state increased by 56 percent.
Colorado's rush to the greens can be seen in Carbondale, once a gritty coal miner's town, 30 miles from Aspen.
"In two months, we sold 36 lots, with only 10 left to go," said David A. Burden, president of The Melrose Company/West, the developer of Aspen Glen. When completed, the community will hold 630 luxury homes.
Charles L. Cunniffe, the lead architect for houses in Aspen Glen, said of the buyers: "They are coming from everywhere. England, Belgium, across the United States."
As a reflection of how the Colorado Rockies are now part of the world economy, the initiation fees charged by some private golf clubs are more than double the fees charged by the Denver Country Club, the most exclusive golf club in the state's largest city.
"The market is there," said Richard A. Kirk, president of the Denver Country Club. "They can charge that amount." A weekend resident of Carbondale, Mr. Kirk owns a lot at Aspen Glen.
But the exclusivity bothers some Coloradans.
"The average family does not have access, so we only mention golf in passing in our summer marketing," said M. Ross Boyle, chairman of the Vail Valley Marketing Board, a regional promotional group.
More public golf courses should be the next step in the Rockies, argued Warren Simmons, executive director of the Colorado Golf Association, a private group that represents state golfers and golf courses.
"We don't necessarily need to build these heroic monuments to the golf architects," Mr. Simmons said. "They probably have pretty well tapped the existing high rollers. Affordable golf in the mountains need not be an oxymoron."
Another line of criticism comes from residents who say that the hundreds of millions of dollars being funneled into gated golf-course developments are widening income disparities.
In Carbondale, once considered a working-class satellite of Aspen, the average price of a single-family home has jumped to $220,000 from $90,000 in a decade. When Aspen Glen and a second golf community here, Roaring Fork, are completed, they will add about 1,250 houses with an average price of nearly $1 million to this town of 3,500 people. In addition, the communities will contain about 65 houses for lower- and middle-income families.
"Wages are not keeping up with living costs," said Mike Chamness, a Carbondale bartender and artist who is also chairman of the Green Party of Colorado. "What we need around here is more employee housing, more affordable housing in general."
But as developers scout nearby mesas for more golf courses, they seem confident that the nation's demographics are on their side. Members of the baby boom, a generation of unprecedented affluence, are moving through middle age.
Still spry after 18 holes of golf at 6,200 feet, Mr. Nicklaus, 57, expressed his generation's growing wariness of skiing: "I can't afford to be laid up for six months. I don't want to break bones."

HEADLINE: Cuba's Communists Peer Ahead, Then Opt to March in Place

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Faced with the uncomfortable options of moving ahead or turning back, Cuba's Communist Party has seemingly opted to do neither.
At a three-day party congress that ended here late Friday with chants of "Fi-del! Fi-del!," President Fidel Castro and his advisers and followers endorsed policies intended to maintain the status quo for as long as possible. 
 Since the party hierarchy last gathered, in 1991, sheer necessity has forced Mr. Castro to seek foreign investment in state companies, allow some limited self-employment and permit the use of the dollar as a parallel currency. The party congress approved all of those moves, but balked at taking further steps that might open up the economy or reduce Government control.
"The state continues having the guiding capacity in directing the economy, and under any formula, therefore, its interests will be adequately represented," proclaims the economic policy statement the congress approved. The document, in its draft form, also supports "space for the functioning of market mechanisms under state regulation" and speaks of the need to "avoid monopolistic prices and unjustifiable profits" that might result from a faster economic opening.
Since returning from a visit to China late in 1995, Mr. Castro has spoken admiringly to visitors about the results of economic changes there and the prosperity they have generated.
But in his closing address to the congress here, he made it clear that he opposed privatizing state enterprises, a step ordered by the Chinese party at its congress last month, or allowing workers who might lose jobs by such an action to set up businesses of their own.
"We have no reason to create millionaires, to create enormous inequalities," Mr. Castro said. As Marxist-Leninists, he added, "we fight not to create individual millionaires, but to make the citizenry as a whole into millionaires."
At a news conference the day before the congress opened, Esteban Lazo Hernandez, the party secretary for Havana and a member of the Politburo, said Cuba could not take the same path as China because "conditions are completely different" here. The Chinese have "an economy based in the countryside," he said, and "there is also a difference of magnitude" that permits China more latitude to experiment economically.
"If we take these steps, how can we keep health, education and public welfare free?" Mr. Lazo asked. "That comes out of the profits of state enterprises."
In addition, he said, China does not have to contend with the hostility of the United States. While some economic experimentation is worth considering, he said, "the blockade and the effort to drown us don't permit that right now."
In Washington, James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said the tone of the party congress here conveyed "a sense of a certain time warp." Mr. Rubin told reporters who inquired about Mr. Castro's address, which lasted 6 hours and 43 minutes, that "no matter how many times you play the same old movie, it's not going to change the desires and the needs of the people of the modern world."
Despite growing concerns outside Cuba about a lack of mechanisms to groom possible successors to Mr. Castro, the party proved nearly as cautious on matters of personnel and leadership as in dealing with the economy.
Though eight people were dropped in the reshaping of the Politburo, the party's most powerful deliberative body, its ideological composition and balance of power remain largely unchanged, political analysts here said.
Most of those removed are members of the generation that took power with Mr. Castro in 1959, so-called "historicos" like Vice President Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, who is 84, and Osmany Cienfuegos, another longtime associate.
But also stripped of their posts were Nelson Torres, who as Minister of Sugar is regarded as responsible for the failure of this year's harvest, and Jorge Lezcano, party secretary in Havana when the rafter refugee crisis erupted in 1994.
The six new members include several such technocrats and party bureaucrats. Jorge Luis Sierra, a 40-ish provincial party secretary who was among those promoted, described the final result as "a mixture of generations." But a diplomat here noted that the authority of all of the newcomers "derives directly from Fidel" and predicted they would be followers rather than innovators, at least initially.
Mr. Castro also made a point of reaffirming that his younger brother, Raul, 66, the Minister of Defense and the party's longtime No. 2 leader, remains his designated successor. The continued presence of Raul Castro, whom he described as his "backup" or "relief pitcher," "gives us great tranquillity and continuity," he said.
In a somewhat surprising move, the party's Central Committee was reduced from 225 members to 150. Raul Castro explained the streamlining, which diplomats said would enhance the power of the Castro brothers, by saying that membership in the body should be based "not only on representativeness but skill."
But the younger Mr. Castro also expressed concerns about ideological purity. It was necessary, he said, to "elect a Central Committee that will keep the revolution immune from ideological viruses" so what occurred in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe in the late 1980's would not be repeated here.

INTERNATIONAL 3-15
 
Two Orthodox Churches Fight for Place in Russia
Russia is undergoing a religious war, pitting the Russian Orthodox Church, the dominant faith in Russia and an ally of the Yeltsin Government, against the small breakaway Free Orthodox Church, which describes itself as the true heir of Russia's religious legacy. At issue is control over churches, seminaries and schools. 1 
 
Cuba Toes Communist Line
Meeting for the first time in six years, Fidel Castro and the Communist hierarchy rejected China's model of economic liberalization and endorsed policies to maintain the status quo for as long as possible. 10 

Slovakia Plan to Redraw Border
Slovakia is viewed as Central Europe's outcast, and now its leader has begun to talk about rewriting its border with Hungary, to exchange hundreds of thousands of ethnic Slovak and Hungarian minorities. Hungary's Prime Minister said he reacted indignantly to the idea. 3
 
Chinese Bishop Is Missing

75 Dead in Crash in Uruguay

Rate of Property Crimes Is at a 17-Year Low in U.S.
With little public notice, property crime in the United States has fallen sharply since 1980, data from the Federal Bureau of Investigation show, with burglary rates down by almost half. That gives New York a lower burglary rate than London, and Los Angeles fewer burglaries than Sydney, Australia. 1

HEADLINE: Search for Libyan's Fate Leaves Wife in Disbelief

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Libya's leading dissident, Mansour Kikhia, was by all accounts in a pretty good mood on the night he disappeared nearly four years ago.
A scholar and former diplomat, Mr. Kikhia was in Cairo to attend a meeting of an Arab human rights group he helped found. He was four months away from getting his American citizenship and, at 62, was looking forward to abandoning political work for a life of comfortable serenity in Washington. 
 That much his wife, Baha, knows. She also knows that he drank coffee with a Libyan emissary in the plush lobby of Al Safir Hotel, where he was staying, and that he left the leafy Cairo neighborhood with an unidentified man for a meeting with a Libyan ambassador. A diabetic, her husband intended to return soon; he had left his insulin-injection kit by his hotel bed.
Since that night, on Dec. 10, 1993, Mrs. Kikhia, who is an American citizen, has relentlessly tried to track the other facts surrounding her husband's disappearance in a search that has taken her to three continents.
The pursuit has included meetings with President Clinton and his national security adviser at the time, Anthony Lake; with her husband's nemesis, the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and with scores of senior intelligence and State Department officials in Washington, as well as top Egyptian, French and Libyan decision-makers in Cairo, Paris and Tripoli.
But after almost four years of searching, Mrs. Kikhia contends, she has learned only one thing for sure: she is getting the runaround.
The Governments of the United States, Libya, Egypt and France, all acting out of competing interests, she says, know a lot more about what happened to her husband than they are willing to tell.
"I just want to know the truth," she said on Thursday in an interview, which she said was intended to pressure all the parties to reveal what they know. "I don't want to play politics any longer."
"I don't care how it happened as long as I find out what happened," she said. "But the Egyptians are lying about their role, the Americans are telling part of the truth and trying not to embarrass their Egyptian allies, and the French intelligence tells me he was, until 1995, alive and had several meetings with Qaddafi. The Libyans say they know nothing about the whole thing."
"All these stories are not convincing. I would like now for the law to take its course," she added, and said that she was planning to file suit.
Mr. Kikhia served Colonel Qaddafi as a trouble-shooter, Foreign Minister and United Nations delegate, until he broke with the regime in 1981 and led the opposition to the Colonel.
Having just returned from her fifth visit to Libya, Mrs. Kikhia said she is convinced that her husband is alive and remains under detention there.
She prefers to remain hopeful, she said, despite a visit to her home in Vienna, Va., on Aug. 26 by two State Department officials who delivered parts of a four-month investigation by the Central Intelligence Agency. The report concluded that Mr. Kikhia was abducted in Cairo with the help of Egyptian agents, who turned him over to Libyan counterparts, and that he was executed in 1994, shortly after his forced return to Libya.
"We learned this summer and developed credible information that Mr. Kikhia is dead and was murdered in Libya," the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said when asked about the report.
"We so informed his family and raised the matter with the Egyptian Government, because we had some indication of involvement by Egyptian officials in the matter," he said. "We are insisting on a full investigation by the Egyptians and we are determined to get to the bottom of this case."
Revealing the conflicting pressures placed on her by the many governments who have competed to promote their own interpretation of the disappearance, Mrs. Kikhia said that she was pressured by the State Department to publicize the C.I.A. report at a news conference, but that she resisted. The United States, she said, wanted to take advantage of the report to press its point that Libya sponsors terrorism.
"I just don't want to be used by anyone and certainly do not want to do further harm to Mansour if he is alive," she said in the interview.
She said the two State Department officials told her that if she failed to publicize the C.I.A. report it would end up in The Washington Post. And indeed she discovered last month, while in Libya, that details of the report had been published in the newspaper.
"I don't want to blame anyone," she said. "If he is dead, I have not seen enough evidence to confirm it. The way information is communicated to me seems designed to serve political purposes, not to relay facts. But what we know is the end, not the beginning or what happened in between -- the names, the people involved -- we know nothing about all this."
She said she had been shown only parts of a faxed document and given no details except that the information came from a reliable agent in Libya. "The manner of presentation -- it was not even an official letter -- was not convincing," she said. "Eventually the State Department sent me a letter of condolences, but I am not persuaded."
A State Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said it would be unusual for officials notifying a family of a death to even discuss the issue of publicity, let alone pressure a family member to publicize the event. "We were informing her of her husband's death, not to publicize it, but to do the right thing and inform a family member of what we knew," one official said.
What the C.I.A. report did succeeded in doing, however, was to provoke a diplomatic scuffle between Egypt and its principal Western ally, the United States. The claim that Egyptian agents may have taken part in Mr. Kikhia's disappearance infuriated President Hosni Mubarak and triggered an attack on the United States in the Egyptian press.
"What are they up to here?" a visibly angry Mr. Mubarak said of the United States to reporters in Cairo on Wednesday. "If they have new evidence, the Americans can get in touch with the public prosecutor. But to distribute unfounded accusations and to say people took him out of Egypt without evidence will not do. Anyone who has names or something new to add can get in touch."
Mr. Mubarak pointedly noted that when the North Korean Ambassador to Cairo defected to the United States a few weeks ago "the C.I.A. knows very well how he left."
Mr. Mubarak also said that details of the report had been released now in an attempt by the United States and Israel to pressure Egypt to release a convicted Israeli spy who was sentenced last month to 15 years in prison.
"We regard President Mubarak's comments as surprising, and we can't quite understand why he would even suggest American involvement in this," said Mr. Rubin, the State Department spokesman. "It's illogical. Nevertheless we are determined to continue to work this case at the highest levels and get to the bottom of this."
The dispute was only the latest between the two allies. Egypt has long insisted that its shared economic, strategic and political interests with Libya are too important to jeopardize in the service of America's feud with Colonel Qaddafi. Libya employs Egyptians and invests heavily in Egypt, and both Governments have a common stake in combating Islamic militants.
Last month, to the irritation of the United States, Egypt and other Arab League countries voted to defy the civilian flight ban that has been imposed on Libya for years by the United Nations. And the last few months, Egyptian editorial writers and politicians have become far more sensitive to the assumption that their country will do America's bidding.
Indeed, Mrs. Kikhia said the tensions were vividly displayed in a meeting she had at the White House with Mr. Lake, the former National Security Adviser, when he seemed to indicate that United States officials assumed that Egypt would readily respond to American pressure, given Egypt's enormous dependence on the $2 billion a year in aid it receives from Washington.
She said Mr. Lake asked her what she wanted the United States to do about her husband.
"I said, 'Pressure Egypt if you cannot pressure Libya,' " she recalled. " 'This is where he disappeared.' So he answers: 'That is very easy. We have two buttons here: one says Egypt come, and the other says Egypt go.' "
At the time, Mrs. Kikhia was having trouble arranging a meeting with President Mubarak. "Obviously he called, and the next thing I knew I had a meeting set up in Cairo with President Mubarak's senior policy adviser, Osama el-Baz," Mrs. Kikhia said. "He did not tell me anything, but he met with me and was very nice."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Baha Kikhia remains unconvinced by any of the official stories she has been told about the fate of her husband, Libya's leading dissident. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Man's Goal Is to Rid Town of Tobacco

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG

DATELINE: WINTHROP, Mass., Oct. 7

 BODY:
From this well-worn seaside town beneath the planes roaring into the nearby Boston airport, 74-year-old Ralph Sirianni watched the unveiling of the tobacco industry settlement this summer with mounting discontent.
He also watched teen-agers continue to light up their illicit afternoon smokes not 20 feet from school. 
 The proposed $368 billion settlement did not go far enough to stop Americans from smoking, he said, because the deal makers seemed to care more about money than saving the lives of millions of children.
So Mr. Sirianni, a retired state lawmaker, decided to do something about it. And he has.
In the last two weeks he has turned this town of 18,000 people into a new front in the tobacco wars with a proposal that officials from both the American Cancer Society and the Tobacco Institute said they believed had never been made before.
Just as many American towns and counties have voted to become "dry," banning the sale of all alcohol within their borders, Mr. Sirianni argued, Winthrop should become tobacco-free, forbidding the sale of all tobacco products here.
As one of the three members of the Winthrop Town Board of Health, Mr. Sirianni put forth the proposal last month and received hearty initial approval from his colleagues -- and a response of pure joy from some anti-smoking groups.
"Everybody was pretty excited and surprised," said Lori Fresina, the coordinator of grass-roots advocacy for the state office of the American Cancer Society. "It's a social experiment the whole country will be watching. More power to them."
Many townspeople, however, are less than thrilled. "I think this is one of the craziest things they've ever wanted to do in this town," said Patsy Cimino, owner of the Meat Market near Town Hall. "All small businesses survive on selling cigarettes," though Mr. Cimino said he did not sell them himself.
"Some people don't like to smoke and drink but you have to respect other people's rights," he added.
One local merchant, the owner of the White Hen Pantry convenience store, got so upset that in an interview with the local newspaper, The Sun Transcript, he called the move unconstitutional and asked whether the Board of Health was taking up where Hitler had left off.
Convenience stores get about 27 percent of their sales from cigarettes, said Walker Merryman, vice president of the Tobacco Institute, an industry-financed group.
"I don't know what this is going to do aside from put some businessmen out of business," he said. "This kind of thing is just tailor-made for encouraging surreptitious black market smuggling of cigarettes."
Some anti-smoking advocates have also remained cautious about the Winthrop initiative, saying they believe more in the gradual route of education and dissuasion than in outright bans.
With so many people addicted to them, "I don't think we have enough science in our hands right now to support prohibition of cigarettes," said Gregory Connolly, director of Massachusetts' state tobacco control program. "We need a lot more scientific investigation on developing less harmful sources of nicotine."
But others point out that anti-smoking measures have long tended to come about locally rather than in state legislatures and Congress, where tobacco lobbyists ply their craft. They say Mr. Sirianni's move is only the latest step in the spread of local bans on smoking in restaurants, buildings and public places.
"Most of the activity that needs to go on over the next few years is on the local level," said Dr. Blake Cady, a leading opponent of smoking in Massachusetts. "It makes the tobacco companies gnash their teeth. They control the Senate and the House in Washington and they can work their magic through money, but they have a difficult time combating these brush fires on the local level."
The Winthrop initiative would also conform to a Massachusetts tradition of setting anti-smoking trends.
Just this week, the Legislature became the first in the country to require the state's pension fund to divest itself of all tobacco stocks in its portfolio. Massachusetts was also the first state to require that cigarette makers disclose all additives and total nicotine content on labels in their products sold here. And in 1992, a referendum drive led by Dr. Cady resulted in a 25-cent-a-package tax on cigarettes to finance anti-smoking education.
Still, Mr. Sirianni, who, as a State Representative for 10 years in the 1960's and '70's learned how to maneuver through the political system, has no doubt that he has a major fight ahead of him.
Rather than try to have the Board of Health impose the ban unilaterally, Mr. Sirianni, who smoked two packs a day from the time he was 15 until he was 50, proposed that the ban be discussed at a hearing on Oct. 15 and be voted on by a general Town Meeting, expected to be held in November.
How that vote would go remains to be seen. In general, about 25 percent of the American population smokes, Mr. Merryman of the Tobacco Institute said, but the proportion tends to be higher in populations with large numbers of blue-collar workers and low-income families.
Winthrop, though a beach town, is not Malibu. It is not even Sharon, the middle-class Massachusetts town that gained some national attention in 1995 when its Town Meeting voted 196 to 149 to ban smoking in any municipal recreation area. Winthrop's median household income is only $37,240, compared with Sharon's $61,692, according to a Boston Magazine compilation of census data.
But Mr. Sirianni already has backing from the town selectmen -- the town has no mayor -- and is trying to draft support from the state's active anti-smoking forces.
Once passed by the Town Meeting, Mr. Sirianni said, his ban on tobacco sales would also have to be approved by the State Attorney General, Scott Harshbarger. There, by all preliminary indications, it would be likely to get a sympathetic hearing: Mr. Harshbarger, who is now running for governor, was a prominent player in the proposed tobacco settlement negotiated by state officials, lawyers, health advocates and representatives of the tobacco industry.
"Our view is this," said Ed Cafasso, Mr. Harshbarger's spokesman: "There are communities in Massachusetts that are dry communities, that have decided not to allow the sale of alcohol within their borders. Our view is that state and local governments have the right to choose to ban the sale of products within their borders."
The settlement proposal was reached in June and would require cigarette companies to pay $368.5 billion over 25 years in compensation for smoking-related illnesses, to finance anti-smoking programs and underwrite health care for uninsured children, among other things. The proposal has stalled, with Congress and President Clinton objecting to some points. Mr. Clinton has proposed stiff penalties on the tobacco companies if steps to reduce teen-age smoking by 60 percent in 10 years fail to meet the goal.
 Under pressure, the major tobacco companies on Friday, settled a class-action lawsuit filed by flight attendants over the effects of secondhand smoke by agreeing to spend $300 million for the study of tobacco-related diseases. The settlement was the first by the industry in a case filed by private citizens.
As anti-tobacco efforts inch forward on the national level, Mr. Sirianni dreams of setting off an anti-tobacco chain reaction in towns across Massachusetts.
"I'm hoping this will start at the grass roots, as a lot of things do, and mushroom outward," he said at his paper-strewn dining room table.
And if legal challenges to tobacco bans also mount, he said, he will not be surprised if they make their way up to the Supreme Court -- where, he believes, his reading of the Constitution must prevail.
"I can't imagine anyone with any intelligence can say they put economics and money over public health and the welfare of the people," he said. "I just can't imagine it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ralph Sirianni proposed a ban on tobacco sales in Wintrop, Mass. (Kirsten Elstner for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1525 words

HEADLINE: Memento Mori -- but First, Carpe Diem

BYLINE: By Margaret Atwood; Margaret Atwood's most recent novel is "Alias Grace."

 BODY:

TOWARD THE END
 OF TIME
 By John Updike.
 334 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $25. 
 "Toward the End of Time" is John Updike's 47th book, and it is deplorably good. If only he would write a flagrant bomb! That would be news. But another excellently written novel by an excellent novelist -- what can be said? Surely no American writer has written so much, for so long, so consistently well. Such feats tend to be undervalued. They shouldn't be. Walking across Niagara Falls blindfolded on a tightrope for the 47th time is certainly as remarkable as having made it across the first time, more remarkable, perhaps; but the viewer's response is all too likely to be not a delighted "How praiseworthy!" but a jaded "What else did you expect?" And at 65, Updike isn't even old enough to be told he's performed very well for his age.
Age is nevertheless the burden, this time, of his song. The title's "end of time" may be that of the United States of America -- the book is set in the third decade of the 21st century, after a devastating war with China has disassembled the great Republic, which nobody seems to miss much. The almighty dollar has been replaced by a local scrip, economic refugees are now sneaking into Mexico instead of out of it, sci-fi creatures called metallobioforms roam loose in the shrubbery, devouring life like army ants, and the independent country of Texas is busily taking over adjacent states, but the book doesn't concern itself overmuch with such details. The important things are still in place: automobiles have roads to run on, the electric lights work, Fedex is operating and the mail and newspapers continue to be delivered, at least in semirural Massachusetts, where the book's protagonist, Ben Turnbull, can still thankfully play golf.
Or the "end of time" may be the end of the earth's time, as there are rumors of possible drastic cosmic events. Or it may be the end of the notion of linear time itself, as Ben Turnbull's consciousness takes startling sideways leaps into the ancient past and the possible future, into the land of what might have happened instead of what did. Or it may be the end of the personal time on earth of Ben himself, who becomes, in the course of the narrative, by no means a well person. His gradual disintegration is the novel's most compelling theme.
Turnbull, a 66-year-old retired investment adviser, is the book's single narrator, and like the earliest European inhabitants of Massachusetts, those voluminously self-searching Puritans, he keeps a spiritual journal -- spiritual not because it's holier than thou, but because it's concerned with the state of what would once have been called his soul, a soul in muted torment, living from hand to mouth and from day to day. The book's underlying structure is linked to the changing seasons, and its method is that of a sinister "Year in Provence," or, more accurately, of a "Walden" gone haywire. Indeed, if Nathaniel Hawthorne was the great-grandfather of "The Witches of Eastwick," Thoreau is the great-grandfather of "Toward the End of Time." Thoreau and Turnbull both live in their isolated and outwardly tranquil houses in the country while the world goes to ruin elsewhere, though Turnbull's well-kept bourgeois mansionette is not exactly a hut. They make similar meticulous and frequently breathtaking observations of nature, they share the tendency to combine the grubbily mundane with the airborne metaphysical, they both indulge in track-jumping digressions and in mordant philosophical observations; but the innocent gaze of the young Thoreau has been transmuted by the aging Turnbull into the gritty-eyed squint of a battle-hardened cameraman. Ben Turnbull is a Thoreau run through the meat grinder of the 20th century, world warfare, economic warfare, racial warfare, sexual warfare and all, and spat out the other end of it covered with blood.
And yet, within the stringent parentheses he's set for himself, Updike manages an amazing range of moods with his usual grace and dexterity. Turnbull's annus horribilis begins on a day in November -- the month of Scorpio, sex, death, regeneration and Thanksgiving, which pretty much covers all the bases. It's the day of the first snow; he hopes for childhood exhilaration but gets none, only "an unfocused dread of time itself, time that churns the seasons and that had brought me this new offering, this heavy new radiant day like a fresh meal brightly served in a hospital to a patient with a dwindling appetite." Yet within an hour he's happily clearing off the porch, delighted by his new orange plastic shovel and hymning the praises of the snow itself. "Does the appetite for new days ever really cease?" he asks. Not for Ben Turnbull it doesn't, and through all the tribulations that beset him it's this appetite -- his ability to be surprised, his childlike curiosity in himself and in what may happen next -- that keeps him going.
He was once married to a woman named, tellingly, Perdita, but his wife of the moment is a vigorous, practical, superficially optimistic woman called Gloria -- surely a relative of Gloria Mundi, the medieval church's much distrusted "glory of this world." Gloria too is aging, despite fresh wardrobes and trips to the hairdresser's for dye jobs, but the process seems only to invigorate her. As the book opens, she's obsessed with the deer that's eating her hedge, and wants Ben to shoot it. Ben secretly sides with the deer, and has become afraid of Gloria. "My wife is a killer," he says. "She dreams at night of my death." The unvoiced power struggle between Ben and Gloria, each civil and affectionate on the surface, each watching the other like a hawk to see which will display the telltale symptoms of croaking first, is one of the best things in the book. As Ben wanes, Gloria waxes; she's even got her natty widow's outfit together beforehand. Nevertheless she tends Ben, nagging him into shape and mothering him relentlessly. "To Gloria I am a kind of garden," he muses, "where she must weed, clip, tie, deadhead and poison aphids."
Gloria isn't the only female threat around. There's also Deirdre, who may be the deer of the book's first section metamorphosed into the paid working-class slut of the second, or may on the other hand be a superheated fantasy of Ben's. A rollick of complicated sex ensues -- Updike is funny and brutally observant on this subject -- as the two bend each other's bodies and heads into ever more twisted positions. If Gloria inspires fear, Deirdre inspires lust, contempt, hatred, guilt and a mournful longing for lost youth. After Deirdre departs, having cleaned out the valuables in the house -- or perhaps not -- Gloria returns, having either been dead or, on the other hand, merely at a conference.
The third in Updike's Gravesian trio of crone, Venus and maiden is Doreen, the barely nubile sidekick of a gaggle of juvenile extortionists who have moved into the woods on Ben's property and are running a small-time protection racket, targeting him and his neighbors. (This is the future, and the police are useless.) Ben gets a perverse kick out of turning himself into their fatherly business counselor, advising the killing of pet cats and the burning down of beach houses in return for a percentage -- retirement hasn't suited him, after all -- while exchanging cash for touching-only privileges with Doreen. He's afraid of Doreen too, but she arouses mostly wistfulness. Through her he has access to the lost prepubertal inexperienced self he once was, for whom he feels a tense nostalgia.
Disaster strikes the young racketeers. Then disaster strikes Ben, in the form of an illness that cripples the part of himself that has meant the most to him. Like many late-20th-century writers, Updike is fascinated with bodily goo, and by things that go yuck in the night. The verbal pleasure he takes in describing the exact nature and texture of Ben's searing and dribbly symptoms rivals Cormac McCarthy on exploding skulls or Patricia Cornwell on decaying corpses. As a commentator, Ben is nothing if not ruthless; but he's as ruthless with himself and his own body as he is with everyone else, and with everyone else's body. Alongside the ruthlessness he does manage, from time to time, a sort of wry tenderness. "To be human," he says, "is still to be humbled by the flesh, to suffer and to die."
It's finally Ben's evenhandedness that confers on "Toward the End of Time" its eerie ambiance, its ultrarealism, its air of a little corner of hell as meticulously painted as a Dutch domestic interior. The light of his intelligence falls alike on everything: on flowers, animals, grandchildren, corpses, copulations; on ancient Egypt and plastic peanuts; on memory, disgust, dread, lust and spiritual rapture. The brilliant metaphors -- and they are almost always brilliant -- are applied, like Whitman's, to everything from the cosmic to the scatological. As a writer, Updike can do anything he wants, and what he's wanted this time is quintessence of mortality. As memento mori and its obverse, carpe diem, "Toward the End of Time" could scarcely be bettered.

HEADLINE: Of Megatrends and Giveaways: Some Thoughts and Regrets of Chairman Hundt

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
In his four years as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Reed E. Hundt has presided over the most tumultuous era in the F.C.C.'s history, a period during which change -- economic, political and technological -- washed over the communications industry like a tidal wave and made this relatively sleepy regulatory agency one of the most powerful forces in Washington.
Mr. Hundt, who is leaving the F.C.C. soon, says much of the change was a result of converging circumstances -- most notably, the computer industry's emergence as a global economic force. 
 But Mr. Hundt's recognition of changing trends and his attempts to manage their repercussions made him probably the most influential F.C.C. chairman in years. "You know what they say about surfing," Mr. Hundt said. "Some of it's the wave, some of it's the board, and some of it is you."
Under Mr. Hundt's often combative leadership, the F.C.C. held auctions that raised more than $20 billion, on paper, for the Government by auctioning parts of the radio spectrum -- for cellular phones, pagers, satellite TV and other services -- that had previously been given away.
Several bidders in the largest-grossing auction, however, are proving unable to raise the cash to pay what they had promised. It is likely to be up to Mr. Hundt's successors to figure out either how to get the money or retrieve the licenses for resale.
And Congress did not heed Mr. Hundt's plea to make broadcasters bid at auction for their share of the greatly expanded spectrum made possible by digital television. He still hopes that they will be required to provide specific public-service benefits, like free commercial time for political candidates, in return for their digital spectrum.
In an interview on the eve of his departure, Mr. Hundt reflected on his tenure. Excerpts follow.
 
ON HIS PHILOSOPHY
The traditional old Democratic view is, 'We like monopolies, and we regulate the heck out of them.' That view was spawned in the New Deal, which enshrined monopolies and created commissions to regulate them. . . . The new Democratic view is to replace the old regime of regulated monopoly with a new paradigm of sound, pro-competitive economics. . . .
On the second front, the public-interest agenda, our goal of advocating vigorously for a broad distribution of public benefits from technology has been specifically illustrated . . . by requiring some education television for children, for free, over the broadcast airwaves and . . . ordering communications companies to pay for connections of computers -- the information highway -- to every single classroom in the country. . . .
I don't think these goals are contradictory as much as they represent a holistic vision. On one hand, you want the bulk of the economy to be competitive and deregulated. On the other hand, you have to recognize that market values are not family values, that markets will leave you a little bit short of certain things.
 
ON HIS GOALS
When we got here four years ago, two great megatrends were occurring globally. The first was the computer becoming a communication tool. The second was the American information economy being exported globally.
The personal computer back then was an unconnected freestanding object; it was an uncommunicating object. . . . Now, the PC connects you and everyone. It's your window on the world, and it's the world's way to get to you. The World Wide Web was invented while I was in this job. And it has changed everything. "One thing we did was to understand this was happening, and to bring the computer industry people into the fray, to listen to their ideas . . . and to solicit their participation. . . .
The second thing is, on the public policy front, the building of communities through technology. . . . When we got here, 3 percent of all classrooms had some kind of communications hookup, and now it's 11 percent and climbing. It needs to be 100 percent. . . .
Third is the three-hour rule on children's educational television. Americans don't want be told there's no market for educational TV. Whether there is a market for it or not, it's positively a good thing to have, because you'll have some millions of kids in your audience.
 
ON HIS BIGGEST REGRETS
(Mr. Hundt here refers to the transfer of spectrum to television broadcasters for high-definition broadcasts or other digital services.)
We tried to wake people up to the fact that this was a giveaway of historic proportions, in return for something that was really nothing. Something huge for something small, maybe you could live with that, but to give away billions of dollars worth of spectrum in return for nothing leaves you aghast. In the end, Congress ordered us to do the giveaway. But whether there will be a 'get back' is not decided yet, and it can still happen. . . . Congress can be obliged by public opinion, I believe, to create reasonable access to the airwaves for all candidates.
What kind of world is it where ABC or NBC can take billions of dollars of its own time to advertise itself, in promotional spots, but finds it inconceivable that a mere $100 million might be set aside every even-numbered year to have a political debate occur? I hope the next commission will muster the votes to do what President Clinton wants, which is have the F.C.C. open an inquiry on free time. . . .
 
ON HIS PLANS
I'm definitely going to write a book. It's going to be called "You Say You Want a Revolution." It shouldn't take too long to write; I've been giving the oral version of it for about four years.

HEADLINE: American Orders For Machine Tools Increased in August

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
American orders for machine tools rose 10.2 percent in August from the month before, lifted by purchases by the auto parts and aerospace industries, according to a survey by two trade groups.
Orders from American companies for domestic and foreign-produced machine tools rose to an estimated $703 million in August from a revised $638 million in July, according to the report, to be published on Monday by the Association for Manufacturing Technology and the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association. 
 "The impact of spending by the automotive supply chain as well as the boom in aerospace investment has resulted in continued growth for machine tool orders," the Association for Manufacturing Technology's president, Albert W. Moore, said.
August's total also brought orders up 17 percent to $5.6 billion in the first seven months of this year compared with the corresponding period a year ago.
Estimated orders climbed 38.4 percent this August from $508 million in August 1996.

HEADLINE: Albert Blumberg, 91, Philosopher and Communist

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Albert E. Blumberg, an idealistic philosophy professor who fought for economic and social reforms as an oft-harassed Communist Party official in the 1940's and 50's, then continued the fight with somewhat more success as a Democratic Party district leader in Manhattan, died on Wednesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center near his home in upper Manhattan. He was 91.
To the Congressional committees and Justice Department officials who hounded him over two decades, Dr. Blumberg's professed interest in improving the plight of workers and minority groups was a sham. 
 As they saw it, his work as secretary of the Communist Party in Maryland and the District of Columbia, and as the national party's legislative director, was a cover for his role in a Stalin-directed conspiracy to overthrow the Government.
To those who knew him during his years as a respected philosophy professor and department chairman at Rutgers University and as a Democratic leader in New York, his commitment to helping others was real.
Among other things, since settling in northern Manhattan in 1965, he organized and led numerous community organizations, served as president of the Audubon Reform Democratic Club and of the Congress of Senior Citizens of Greater New York and became an adviser to officials like City Councilman Stanley E. Michels, Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., State Senator Franz S. Leichter and Mayor David N. Dinkins, who named him chairman of the senior citizens advisory panel.
A native of Baltimore whose parents were immigrants from Lithuania, Dr. Blumberg was a brilliant student who graduated from Johns Hopkins University before going off on a grand academic tour, picking up a master's from Yale, studying at the Sorbonne and receiving a doctorate from the University of Vienna, where he was attracted to the Vienna circle of logical positivists.
In recent years, Dr. Blumberg talked so little about his past that it is hard to know just how or why he became involved with the Communist Party, but a nephew, recalling his uncle describing campaigns against Jews in Vienna in the 1930's, suggested that, like many European Communists of the day, he came to see Soviet Communism as an antidote to Nazism.
Whatever the initial attraction, Dr. Blumberg and his Baltimore-born wife, Dorothy Rose, quickly became prominent in party circles.
In 1940, for example, he was cited for contempt for refusing to identify party members to the House Un-American Activities Committee, but apparently did not learn the intended lesson: in 1957, he refused to answer similar questions before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.
By then, Dr. Blumberg had become one of the first Communists convicted under a provision of the 1940 Smith Act equating party membership with conspiring to overthrow the Government.
Despite that 1956 conviction, Dr. Blumberg did not go to prison. In 1957, while his appeal was pending, the Supreme Court declared the provision unconstitutional. (His wife, convicted earlier under a different section, served a three-year term.)
For Dr. Blumberg, the victory was a hollow one. Although he had taught philosophy at Johns Hopkins in the 1930's, he could not get a teaching job and worked in a bookstore until he was hired by Rutgers in 1965.
There he helped organize Livingston College, the university's first residential college for men and women; served as chairman of its philosophy department; wrote an acclaimed textbook, "Logic: A First Course," and was repeatedly elected president of the faculty governing body. As a colleague, Dr. Peter Klein, recalled on Friday, Dr. Blumberg was a master synthesizer who would often astound his colleagues by tapping his gavel during a rancorous dead-end debate, declaring, "I think I hear a consensus," then articulating an inspired compromise.
After retiring in 1977, he stepped up his political activities in New York. By then he had become such an established figure in the local Democratic Party that he won a 1977 election as leader of the 71st Assembly District even though his opponent had tried to use his Communist past against him.
As district leader, Dr. Blumberg was chairman of the county committee's policy committee and worked to bring his upper Manhattan neighborhood's growing Dominican population into the party's inner circles, succeeding so well that he lost his post to a Dominican rival in 1985.
Dr. Blumberg, whose wife died several years ago, is survived by a brother, Harold, of Boston.
