PUB-DATE: October 13, 1997

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 2166 words

HEADLINE: Pride and Privacy Are Submerged in Workfare Evaluation

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
The welfare recipients in the overcrowded waiting rooms of H.S. Systems on West 45th Street are called by number, not by name. Ordered to the Manhattan clinic so the city can determine whether they are too sick or disabled to work for their benefits, they sit or stand with their canes, walkers and braces, waiting to be examined. To keep crowding down, the city tells them they must come alone. Some must hold on to urine samples while waiting.
One morning, a woman furtively filled out the psychological portion of her medical questionnaire, unable to shield one answer -- "attempted suicide" -- from the man next to her. In a public hallway, women stood waiting for their physicals, their handbags tearing at their paper gowns, leaving them partly exposed. 
 The day's traffic was heavy: 15 doctors examined about 350 welfare recipients, in theory reviewing medical records and questioning people with lengthy, imperfectly documented histories. An additional 375 recipients gave blood and urine samples.
The stakes were serious -- the doctors deciding who was well enough to clean the city's streets or public toilets, the welfare recipients aware that they would lose their benefits, including medical coverage, if they were ordered to work and did not.
"It is humiliating and sad," said Nemrod Shayne, adding that he was at the clinic because his back had been seriously injured in an elevator accident in 1994. "But there is no option."
Health Services Systems, a private, for-profit clinic, is an essential part of the city's aggressive effort to require able-bodied people on welfare to work for their benefits. The administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani says that using a single, city-financed operation is necessary to discourage fraud and inconsistency in evaluating welfare recipients, and that it is pleased with the performance of H.S. Systems. The clinic -- the only place in the five boroughs where such evaluations are conducted -- receives $6 million a year from the city.
But interviews with recipients, advocates for the poor, government welfare workers, mental health professionals and others, as well as an examination of state records, reveal many troubling aspects of the city's evaluation system:
*Officials with H.S. Systems say every recipient is given an evaluation of at least 20 minutes, but numerous recipients say theirs lasted only 2 to 5 minutes, that doctors regularly disregard the medical information recipients offer, and that language problems can make basic communication impossible. H.S. Systems says its 15 doctors conducted 80,200 examinations of welfare recipients last year.
*Two staff doctors at H.S. Systems have at one time been placed on probation by state authorities. One was found guilty of "inappropriately prescribing controlled substances" and the other was cited for "patient neglect" at a nursing home. A third physician, who still works at H.S. Systems as a consultant, was placed on probation last year for what the state called "gross negligence" in treating two emergency room patients.
*When recipients appeal to state officials to challenge the city's determination that they are fit to work, the city's decisions are overturned or withdrawn in 40 percent to 50 percent of cases. These recipients, who can have their benefits extended during the hearing process, are either granted new examinations or exempted altogether from their work assignments.
*Medical oversight of H.S. Systems is minimal. The New York State Department of Health has not conducted a comprehensive review of the company in more than a decade, even though it has occasionally been cited by the state for faulty operating procedures, improper infection control and inadequate record keeping.
*The city, citing crowding concerns, instructs recipients not to bring a relative, nurse, counselor or others to the examinations, and several people who went to help recipients said they had been ordered out of the clinic by doctors and staff. Initial interviews of recipients with psychological problems are conducted in public spaces, and not by doctors. Recipients are not given the results of their exams unless they specifically request them.
*Welfare recipients found by H.S. Systems to be "employable with limitations" -- cleared, for instance, to do only indoor work because of severe asthma -- repeatedly wind up having to do inappropriate or even dangerous assignments, according to a lawsuit brought by the Legal Aid Society.
This is partly because H.S. Systems fails to specify what those limitations are, said a lawyer for the Society, whose suit accuses the city of wholesale violations of Federal and state laws protecting the rights of the disabled. Relatives of a woman who died while at her workfare job, as well as a man who claims to have been left disabled as a result of having to work for his benefits, have also sued the city and H.S. Systems.
"If people, including poor people with multiple medical problems, must be made to work, this system is the antithesis of how it should be done," said City Councilwoman Mary Pinkett of Brooklyn, who conducted public hearings in August into the performance of H.S. Systems. "All the administration wants H.S. Systems to do is move people along the line, and get doctors that will help move those people without asking too many questions."
Officials with H.S. Systems declined to be interviewed for this article, as did officials with the Human Resources Administration, the city's welfare agency.
But the clinic's president, Yvonne M. Jones, testifying before the City Council in August, defended its treatment of welfare recipients. She insisted that the examinations were as thorough as necessary, and she emphasized that H.S. Systems had no "stake" in their outcome.
 
City Is Hamstrung By Sheer Numbers
Nationally, states that require welfare recipients to work have adopted varying policies for those claiming to be physically incapable. Like recipients here, those in Massachusetts are evaluated at a contracted medical center. But in Virginia, recipients seeking an exemption because of health problems are allowed to produce evidence from their own doctors.
But New York City's experience is unusual because of the sheer numbers of recipients. Thus the scene inside the H.S. Systems office -- not unlike that in a neglected public hospital's emergency room -- is daunting, as more than 700 people are processed daily.
Marlene Schonbrun, a mental health counselor with a New York hospital, once accompanied a client, a paranoid schizophrenic, to his appointment at H.S. Systems. "It was dismal, confusing, kind of like a mill or a factory," Ms. Schonbrun said. "He was asked questions that he totally misunderstood. He couldn't register what they were saying. I do not know what he would have done had he been alone."
Joe Rivera, 25, was alone at H.S. Systems earlier this year. Mr. Rivera, suffering from clinical depression, an anxiety disorder and hallucinations, was a psychiatric patient at the Gouverneur Hospital. He said he took a note from a senior psychologist at the hospital with him when he reported to H.S. Systems, but was never seen by a psychiatrist there, was determined to be "employable with limitations," and was cut off from his benefits after not reporting to his janitorial assignment in a city building.
Months later, after a hearing, state officials restored Mr. Rivera's benefits, noting that the city and H.S. Systems had made no specific finding about Mr. Rivera's psychiatric problems.
"They look at you; they don't examine you," said Mr. Rivera, who prevailed only after getting the help of an advocacy organization, the Urban Justice Center.
 
Crowds and Long Waits At Only Exam Site
Many of the recipients who go to H.S. Systems say they are offended by the clinic and its surroundings. The entrance is next to a storefront peep show, and there is no special access for the disabled.
Inside, waits are long, tempers short. People are moved in bunches by security guards through the crowds, off to have their blood drawn. One morning, the receptionist was observed openly mocking Spanish speakers.
In her testimony before the City Council, Ms. Jones of H.S. Systems said that the center had six psychiatrists, that half the staff was bilingual, and that recipients were treated with "dignity."
Sarah Ramirez does not remember it that way.
She worked for 10 years for the city's Department of Health before she accepted a buyout package several years ago. She eventually wound up on public assistance. She was an outpatient at Long Island College Hospital, being treated for coronary heart disease, when she was ordered to work.
"I brought my documentation to the examination, but the doctor threw the papers on the desk and said he could not be guided by the information I gave," Ms. Ramirez said. "He asked me questions, then didn't wait for answers."
Ms. Ramirez, 55, was classified as employable with limitations. She appealed the finding at a state hearing and was declared exempt from her work assignment.
 
Determining Limits For Disabled Workers
Last year, 33,952 recipients were classified as "employable with limitations." The Legal Aid Society's lawsuit centers on the claim that those recipients are systematically assigned to jobs that are physically inappropriate, even perilous.
"These recipients are never told what the findings at H.S. Systems are, and when H.S. Systems tells the welfare agency that a recipient is employable with limitations, they never tell the welfare workers what the limitations are," said Helen Lee, a Legal Aid lawyer.
Three veteran caseworkers from the city welfare agency's office at H.S. Systems confirmed that they often do not know what a recipient's particular limitation is when they hand out workfare assignments. The forms the workers get concerning the recipients can typically say nothing more than: "light work."
The caseworkers say they have no choice but to give every recipient his or her computer-generated workfare assignment, whether or not it appears that they can do the job.
"We get the paperwork saying these people are employable, but we can tell by looking at them that it is a joke," said one caseworker, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Their bodies are swollen or broken. The recipients can wind up doing any sort of job."
Another city worker said, "It's like three different operations -- the doctors, us, the people at the work sites -- working together, but not really working together at all."
Others charge that the mistakes have produced consequences both great and invisible, from death to scores of people quietly losing benefits after opting not to risk doing the workfare jobs.
Relatives of Marsha Motipersad, a 50-year-old woman with a history of serious heart disease, sued the city and H.S. Systems after she died of a heart attack last June during a lunch break from her workfare job in Coney Island. Doctors at H.S. Systems knew about the woman's heart problems, but ultimately cleared her as employable, sending her to fill out time sheets in a sub-basement office in a public restroom.
Mikhail Fridman has also sued the city and H.S. Systems. In July 1996, he said in a sworn statement, he went to H.S. Systems, explained that he was being treated for hypertension, but was not given a full exam by Dr. Aurelio Salon Jr. He was found employable with limitations, but was sent to work in a Sanitation Department garage. He suffered a heart attack that August and was recently declared permanently disabled by the Social Security Administration. A 47-year-old Bronx man, who provided details of his case only on the condition that his last name not be used, was found employable with limitations by H.S. Systems last spring. But despite serious respiratory problems resulting from a 1994 car accident, he was assigned to cut grass in a public park. He suffered a respiratory attack and was admitted to North Central Bronx Hospital.
Gloria Jimenez, 51, worked for 22 years in a belt factory. But suddenly unemployed when the factory closed, otherwise unskilled and suffering from severe arthritis in her hands, she wound up on welfare. After her examination at H.S. Systems -- conducted in English despite her ignorance of the language -- she was found to be employable with limitations. But she was ordered to sweep the streets. She missed a day when the pain in her hands was too great, she said, and lost her benefits. She said she had to sell her personal belongings to pay the rent.
"I had worked all my life, and then I was forced to work at something I couldn't do," Ms. Jimenez said in Spanish. "The doctor never even looked at my hands."
Officials with H.S. Systems, after listening at the City Council hearings to a day's worth of personal accounts of mistreatment by recipients who had undergone examinations, said they were disturbed by the reports, and that they would investigate.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Commercial Construction Up

BYLINE: By JESSE MCKINLEY

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Nonresidential construction, which has lagged for several years, increased by 58 percent during the first half of the year in New Jersey, state officials announced last week. 
 Municipal construction officials authorized $2.17 billion in nonresidential building between January and June, compared with $1.37 billion during the same period last year, according to a report released on Thursday by the State Department of Community Affairs. George R. Nagle, executive director of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisors, attributed the increase to a wave of casino expansion in Atlantic City and a strong demand for office space.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Science Desk

LENGTH: 1895 words

HEADLINE: Nimble Deal-Maker For Stars Of Science

BYLINE: By JAMES GORMAN

 BODY:
A FEW months ago, a group of authors gathered at a country house in Connecticut for a weekend, taking walks in the meadows and woods, dining alfresco and talking about their work. They did not, however, discuss movie rights, the fate of the novel or the current rash of memoirs. They talked about multiple universes, the philosophy of mathematics and the nature of consciousness.
This was a pastoral salon in which cosmologists, cognitive scientists, linguists and invertebrate paleontologists could discuss the evolution of the the universe and the problem of whether 1+1=2 is a tautology, a logical formula with relevance only to itself, or whether it has a necessary connection with the physical world. It was a meeting at which the authors could consider the question of whether there are questions that are unanswerable, in principle. 
 All the authors are scientists, and all except one are clients of their host, John Brockman, the literary agent whose house they were visiting and who presided over the occasion with his wife and business partner, Katinka Matson. Mr. Brockman, of Brockman Inc., with a penthouse office in Manhattan just off Fifth Avenue, may have more scientists as clients than any other literary agent. The Independent newspaper in England recently paid him the backhanded compliment of turning his name into a verb, suggesting that there are telltale signs when a scientist is "Brockmaned," one of them being a six-figure advance. His client list reads like a university's interdepartmental committee on evolution, computer science, consciousness and the fate of the cosmos.
At the gathering in Connecticut, for instance, were Steven Pinker ("How the Mind Works"), Lee Smolin ("The Life of the Cosmos"), Daniel Dennett ("Consciousness Explained"), Alan Guth ("The Inflationary Universe"), Nicholas Humphrey ("A History of the Mind"), Niles Eldredge ("Reinventing Darwin," "Dominion") and Frank Sulloway ("Freud," "Biologist of the Mind"), who is not a client, at least not yet.
Mr. Brockman also represents journalists, a number of them employees of The New York Times. But it is as an agent of scientists that Mr. Brockman has made his mark. He is known for striking quickly and treating publishers as adversaries in a contest for money. He sells foreign rights to books himself, rather than letting publishers reap those profits, and prides himself on working a global market.
He sold the just published "How the Mind Works" to W. W. Norton for $500,000 to $600,000, said an editor who was involved in the auction for the book but did not buy it. And he just struck a deal for another book by Dr. Pinker for a larger sum, the author said. "Ten years ago," Mr. Brockman said, scientists writing for a popular audience "would go to Basic Books or M.I.T. Press and get paid a modest advance and give up world rights." Today, they may think about $1 million.
"Scientists are getting what celebrities got 10 years ago -- well, actually, they're getting as much as celebrities in many cases," Mr. Brockman added.
And why not, he asks. "To me," he said, "the people that I work with are the glamorous people. They're the beautiful people. Is there something wrong with an evolutionary biologist being paid as much as a rock star?"
Editors and other agents who deal with Mr. Brockman or compete with him, complain, off the record, about quickie book proposals, overblown advances and books that do not come in on time or in good shape.
Unlike most agents, he submits proposals to a number of publishers at the same time, rather than dealing with them one at a time. "He's always looking for huge money," one editor said, and he does not wait for the scientists to decide that it is time to review their careers and write for the ages. He recruits professors who have received good press for their work the way another agent might recruit actors or quarterbacks.
Acting as a book packager, something between an agent and a publisher, he created a Science Masters series of short, reader-friendly books by scientists like Dr. Pinker and Dr. Dennett and others who are not clients, like the paleontologist Stephen Jay Gould. He has sold the rights for this series worldwide.
Popular books about science have always been around. But an editor at Free Press (owned by Simon & Schuster) who has bought a number of books through Mr. Brockman, Susan Arellano, said, "I don't think they had the visibility that John has given them." He has raised the size of advances for books about science to a new level, she said, and Mr. Brockman agrees. "I had something to do with that," he said.
Of course, Mr. Brockman does not create the books. Jonathan Segal, an editor at Knopf, said that "there are a lot of good books out there in science," and that they are out there because of scientists' research and writing. And Mr. Segal pointed out that no one had to participate in a Brockman auction. "It's not John making us bid, it's us," he said.
Mr. Brockman says much the same. "It's the people writing the books that matter," he said. "The publishers that will fall all over me to buy book A won't take my calls for book B." In his characteristic conversational mix, stirring business, philosophy and a big name together in the same elliptical breath, he continued: "What I'm saying is the concreteness, in the Whitehead sense, lives with the manuscript and the author. It's not the agent, believe me." That's Alfred North Whitehead, by the way, the English mathematician and philosopher who wrote "Principia Mathematica" with Bertrand Russell. "I'm only as strong as the book I'm representing at that moment," he said, then paused. "Well, to some degree."
Mr. Brockman, 56, did not begin with books. After getting his M.B.A. from Columbia University, he moved almost immediately into Manhattan's downtown art world as an orchestrator of the avant-garde. In the 1960's, he put on multimedia events. He worked with Andy Warhol. He worked in Hollywood. And he wrote books himself, essays in which he reflected on subjects like cybernetics, the comparative study of brains and computer systems. His first was called "By the Late John Brockman" (Macmillan). By his account, he has now written, edited or been a co-author of about 18 books.
He started his literary agency in 1973 and, in the early 80's, had a flurry of success selling computer software and computer books. One of his first big books was "The Whole Earth Software Catalog," sold to Doubleday for $1.3 million. The computer world is still, in some sense, his home. He lives on E-mail and has just set up a Web site, accessed only with passwords, on which he posts proposals for books he is selling. He need only call a publisher or send E-mail to let an editor read a proposal immediately, with no printing or mailing costs for Brockman Inc.
One of the books Mr. Brockman wrote caused him a great deal of grief. It was titled "Einstein, Gertrude Stein, Wittgenstein & Frankenstein," and he had to tell Viking to pull it off the market in 1986 after James Gleick, then a reporter for The New York Times, noticed that sections of it strongly resembled an article he had written for The New York Times Magazine. This was a particularly serious crisis for a literary agent, whose livelihood is the word as property. The book was already in stores.
It was the worst moment of his life, Mr. Brockman said, acknowledging that there were sections in his book that should have been attributed to Mr. Gleick. He said the mistake had been made by a young assistant to whom he had farmed out some of the books' chapters to finish.
He has continued to write and edit and to organize intellectual salons, both live and virtual. The first was The Reality Club, which he started with the late Heinz Pagels, a physicist, as a way for researchers from different disciplines to get together and talk about their work. He now has a site on the World Wide Web for such discussions, with many of his clients and others talking about cosmology, consciousness and computer science. Reviews of the site are mixed. Murray Gell-Mann, a Nobel laureate in physics and another Brockman client, said that some of the discussion was good, some not. It contains, he said, "a considerable amount of nonsense."
The selling of Dr. Gell-Mann's book "The Quark and the Jaguar" has brought Mr. Brockman criticism. His handling of that book was excoriated in an article in The New Republic as typical of his approach to selling science books. Mr. Brockman was reported to have sold the book to Bantam for $550,000 and topped $1 million with foreign rights.
But Dr. Gell-Mann had great trouble writing the book and went through several collaborators, finally turning in a partial manuscript that Bantam rejected. Mr. Brockman then resold the book to W. H. Freeman for $50,000. Dr. Gell-Mann had to return his advance from Bantam, but he said in an interview that he was happy with Mr. Brockman as an agent. "I made a lot of money on the book," Dr. Gell-Mann said.
Alan Guth is another scientist and Brockman client who had a book, "The Inflationary Universe," that ran into problems. After an initial burst of enthusiasm and a hefty advance, Dr. Guth went through three publishers before his book saw print. He does not blame Mr. Brockman, although he does say, sounding bemused rather than resentful, "I would almost go so far as to say he tricked me into writing the book."
In January 1991, Dr. Guth related, one of those times when the Big Bang theory was being called into question and his work on an expanding universe was receiving attention, a front-page interview with him appeared in The Wall Street Journal. He received a good deal of publicity elsewhere as well.
Mr. Brockman seized the moment. He called Dr. Guth and told him that he could get a big advance if Dr. Guth would agree to write a book. Dr. Guth agreed, and Mr. Brockman sold the book to Bantam for $250,000. But Dr. Guth said the pressure of other work and his own perfectionism had slowed his progress. "The Inflationary Universe" was finally published by Addison-Wesley (the third of Dr. Guth's publishers) for considerably less than Bantam had agreed to pay.
Of course, some Brockman clients publish their books with no trouble, or even with high-flying success. And, as he and book editors also point out, it is an agent's job to get large advances for his clients. Both Dr. Gell-Mann, who had a world of trouble with his book, and Dr. Pinker, for whom all is going smoothly, say they have been quite satisfied with him as an agent.
Mr. Brockman thinks of himself not only as a deal-maker, but as a writer and a traveler in the world of ideas. What draws him to his work, he said, is "the idea of exalting ideas." Perhaps the best description of Mr. Brockman's relationship to science and scientists is that he is a fan, the sort who knows the ins and outs of the game, the hot subjects, the players, the coaches, the statistics and, of course, the salaries, bonuses and intricacies of free agentry. He is a fan who knows the game so well that he has been able to make it his business.
Being able to work with people he admires, promote important ideas, and, along the way, "make a fine living for myself" makes it, Mr. Brockman said, "the best of all possible worlds." He added: "What can I say? It's a great life."

SECTION: Section E; Page 2; Column 3; The Arts/Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 975 words

HEADLINE: Arts in America;
Despite the Boom, a San Francisco Museum Struggles

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
These are palmy days for art museums. With the economy in a spectacular boom, people have the money and the inclination for culture, and many museums have seized the day, expanding their buildings, their collections, their programs and their publics. What, them worry?
Someone apparently forgot to tell San Francisco. 
 The M. H. de Young Memorial Museum, damaged by the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake, sits surrounded by trusses in Golden Gate Park, unable to forge a consensus either for rebuilding itself there or for moving its collection of Western art out of the park. Some exhibitions have been moved elsewhere to insure their safety. The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, meanwhile, is happily ensconced in its two-year-old building, but it remains collection-poor and is struggling to attract the visitors it needs every day to make the move pay.
In the worst position of all is the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco, which has been trying to move to larger quarters since the 1970's. The museum's board and administrators are so fixated on relocating that they have spent little energy building the collection or organizing major exhibitions. Yet with interest in all things Asian at an all-time high, museums around the country are vying assiduously for art from Korea, China, Indochina, Japan and the rest of Asia. The Asian Art Museum would have to run pretty hard just to stay in place, and it isn't even doing that, critics say.
"It's tragic that they haven't capitalized on the whole museum movement and the fact that they have such an extraordinary collection," said Walter Shorenstein, a prominent San Francisco real estate developer who, with his late wife, Phyllis, was a major donor to the museum. "They haven't been in the market buying to maintain its position."
The situation is alarming because the Asian Art Museum is the one uncontested art jewel in San Francisco, which for all its own eye-pleasing charms has never really been a place to view world-class art. Only in Asian art could San Francisco compete with the best, thanks to Avery Brundage, the late millionaire builder from Chicago who also headed the International Olympic Committee.
Beginning in the mid-1930's, Brundage succumbed to "the collecting disease," as he put it, amassing a matchless Asian art collection that encompassed bronzes, ceramics, scrolls, ivory and virtually everything except Chinese paintings. Twenty years later, he decided to donate the works. He smiled on San Francisco, which he called "the gateway to the Orient," when the Art Institute of Chicago, which had started its own Asian collection, wanted only some of his treasures.
San Francisco built a new wing on the de Young, and on June 10, 1966, more than a thousand politicians, foreign dignitaries and members of the city's social elite previewed the galleries at a gala involving what The New York Times called "an apparently unlimited supply of California champagne." The next day, the public got its first look at a collection then valued conservatively at $30 million, or about $146 million in today's dollars.
But the museum was never big enough. Ten years ago, its trustees agreed to a plan to turn the city's historic Old Main Library (which departed to a modern building) into the New Asian Art Museum at a projected cost of $110 million.
The plan uncorked a stream of critics. To some, the Beaux-Arts library seemed an incongruous home for Asian art, especially when a brand-new, more appropriate museum could be built for less (the Modern, which was built on land given to it by San Francisco, cost about $63 million). Then the museum discovered it had responsibility for 14 historic Italian panel paintings flanking the library's grand staircase that were not supposed to be altered. When the Asian proposed relocating them, an uproar ensued that still has not been resolved. And art experts have complained about the library's challenging design features, like high ceilings. "It is a curatorial nightmare," said Clarence Shangraw, the museum's former chief curator.
All the while, the Asian's popularity has been sinking. Emily J. Sano, the director, estimates attendance at 225,000 to 250,000 a year and said, "I don't know how it compares with the past." But Mr. Shangraw said there were 650,000 visitors in 1992, the year he left.
A new building and a strong program may bring people back, but acquisitions are more problematic. With just $250,000 a year to spend on purchases, "we don't acquire a lot," Ms. Sano admitted. "We're focusing mainly on the building right now." Some $51 million was raised in a bond issue, and the museum has gathered $41 million from donors, Ms. Sano said. That leaves about $20 million to go in the capital campaign before acquisition money could even be discussed.
The trouble is, the great quest for Asian artworks may be over by the time the Asian Art Museum is ready to get back in the game.
To critics, the remedy for the museum's sorry state begins with the board. "Funding is a major problem for that institution because board members don't give money," Mr. Sangraw said. "The board should face up to the major responsibility of giving money."
One trustee, Chong-Moon Lee, did step forward with a $15 million gift, but it promptly caused another stir. Mr. Lee's name, not Avery Brundage's, will be engraved in the new museum's facade, causing not a few jaws to drop.
"You have to get a more effective board, because they think they're doing fine," Mr. Shorenstein said, though he admits he has no reason to believe that will happen.
For her part, Ms. Sano is sure the museum will move on schedule in 2001. And she has written a different happy ending for the Asian. "When a museum builds a new building, it's an occasion for a lot of gifts," she said. "So I foresee that the collection will grow."

HEADLINE: Jobs Mean Less Crime

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Property Crimes Steadily Decline, Led by Burglary" (front page, Oct. 12), many explanations are given for the welcome changes. Curiously, the dramatic decrease in unemployment, especially since the early 1990's, when the most marked declines occurred, is not among them. 
 Research has shown a clear relationship between unemployment and crime. For example, a 1 percent rise in unemployment is followed a year or so later by an almost 6 percent rise in homicides.
Criminal behavior is too complex to be explained by a single cause. However, by recognizing the important role of employment, we may be more inclined to invest in creating jobs than in building prison cells.
 
MILTON SCHWEBEL
Piscataway, N.J., Oct. 12, 1997
 
The writer is professor emeritus of psychology at Rutgers University.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Largely Higher In Light Holiday Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was higher against most leading currencies in a quiet session yesterday after Japan said its trade surplus grew less than expected in August, reducing worries about trade tension between the United States and Japan.
Dealings were light as the Columbus Day holiday left many trading rooms empty or sparsely staffed. 
 "It was basically a nothing day," said Enrico Caruso, a vice president at the Dresdner Bank in New York.
Late in New York, the dollar was quoted at 120.80 Japanese yen, up from 119.78 late Friday. The dollar rose to 1.7508 German marks from 1.7486 marks. It eased against the British pound, which fetched $1.6234, compared with $1.6223 on Friday.
Early yesterday, Japan reported that the surplus in its broadest measure of trade rose 77.7 percent in August; analysts had expected an even bigger jump. The report lessened concerns that United States officials might seek a weaker dollar to slow Japanese export growth. American officials have complained in recent weeks about Japan's rising trade surplus, which is spurred by a weak yen that makes Japanese goods cheaper abroad and American products more expensive in Japan.
The yen was also hurt as traders sold it for marks after Germany's central bank raised a money market rate last week. Higher interest rates tend to increase demand for a country's currency, and Japanese interest rates are at record lows.
The mark's strength against the yen helped bolster the German currency against the dollar early in the session. But the dollar reversed course and emerged higher on signs of political stability in Italy after Prime Minister Romano Prodi resigned last week. Yesterday, Italian Communists began talks with leaders of Mr. Prodi's coalition partners, in a move expected to restore Mr. Prodi to power.
The mark had gained from Italy's turmoil as traders thought the problems could deter Italian participation in the planned European common currency, which many felt would strengthen the currency.
Traders also awaited American economic reports this week, including retail sales and consumer prices, in search of any inflationary hints that might move the Federal Reserve to raise rates.

PUB-DATE: October 14, 1997

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 512 words

HEADLINE: Crime Is Down All Over

 BODY:
Crime rates have declined for the fifth consecutive year. F.B.I. statistics show that violent crimes fell 6 percent in 1996 from 1995, and national murder rates reached the lowest level since 1969. Property crime rates continue to fall steadily, with burglary down by nearly half since 1980. In New York City, Mayor Rudolph Guiliani has taken credit for a reduction in crimes, large and small. This year homicides in the city are projected to drop to 779, fewer than even the 986 killings recorded in 1968.
Criminologists offer many guesses for why crime is dropping, but in this field where sociology, economics, community attitudes and policing strategies all come into play, few agree on which factors have the biggest impact or how long the trend can last. 
 Most experts say that demographics plays a role. A drop in the number of people in their late teens and early 20's, the age group most likely to commit crimes, has meant fewer potential lawbreakers. But that is about to change. The number of teen-agers is expected to start growing by 1 percent a year for the next 15 years.
Stabilization in the illegal drug markets and fewer turf wars among heavily armed teen-age dealers may also have led to the drop in murder rates. The average age for crack users is going up, perhaps creating a less violent market for the drug. Gun-control laws, community mediation for gangs and law enforcement with zero tolerance for small-time lawbreakers may be changing the atmosphere of casual violence in urban centers. Longer sentences and a near-doubling of the number of inmates in the nation's prisons over the last decade have also kept more career criminals off the streets. A strong economy could be causing some would-be criminals to seek legitimate employment.
But inquire into some of these reasons, and contradictory evidence shows up. Much has been made of New York's success in heading off more serious crimes by cracking down on minor offenses. Yet cities such as Los Angeles that have not embraced this approach have also seen big drops in murder rates in the past five years. Wildly different incarceration rates among states with comparable demographics have not produced dramatically different crime rates.
Historically, urbanization, poverty, family breakdown and changes in social ethos are big determinants of crime. There is no indication that those factors no longer matter. Some even say the latest downswing may be a natural statistical correction, in other words that crime rates had been so high for so long that they were bound to come down.
But whatever the national data suggest, the evidence of everyday life in New York City argues that better policing helps. No one who uses the streets and subways regularly can doubt that police are more visible while criminals are less visible and less bold. Citizens and visitors feel a palpable sense of security that was missing five years ago. Something has happened that seems clearly traceable to better law enforcement strategy, higher arrest rates and more certain sentencing.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Will Northeast Utilities survive New Hampshire's rate cutting?

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas

 BODY:
UTILITY deregulation, which has many states scrambling to come up with large rate cuts, has put New Hampshire in a nasty bind. Regulators and politicians have raised hopes that residents will soon see big declines in rates, which are the highest in the nation, but now they are struggling to deliver.
To do so, they run the risk of forcing the state's largest utility, Public Service of New Hampshire, into bankruptcy and giving further shocks to stockholders of its parent company, Northeast Utilities. The troubles are an extreme example of what some other states have in store as deregulation spreads. 
 Northeast's stock had already fallen last year after the Nuclear Regulatory Commission shut down the company's Millstone nuclear plant in Connecticut because of problems with operating procedures. But what sent Northeast Utilities shares plunging this year was the push to force the utility to cut rates in New Hampshire.
An investment adviser to the utility recently warned regulators that unless they backed off, the utility might default on about $500 million of securities that have to be refinanced next spring. The state, the adviser warned, needs to reassure worried stockholders.
In a recent report on Northeast Utilities, Penelope Adelmann, a utility analyst for Gruntal & Company, recommended that any investors without the stomach for risky speculation should sell the stock. She predicted that the state's Public Utility Commission would continue to press for rate cuts and that the utility would continue to use the courts to block them.
Hopes have been raised over the last year as thousands of residents of New Hampshire saw their electric bills cut 15 to 20 percent under the nation's first pilot program to study the impact of opening a state's utilities to competition. New Hampshire has received wide publicity for being the first to give deregulation a try. And local politicians, including the Democratic Governor, Jeanne Shaheen, who pushed for the experiment, have basked in the resulting good will.
But the ability to expand the pilot program has been crippled by past commitments the state made to help put Public Service of New Hampshire back on its feet after it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1988. Just 17,000 customers are now part of the pilot program. But, under pressure to pass the savings on to the rest of the state's 500,000 utility customers, the state's Public Utilities Commission issued an order aimed at deregulating the utility industry by next July 1 and cutting rates across the board by about 20 percent.
Public Service of New Hampshire, which serves more than 80 percent of the state's utilities customers, is bearing the main force of the drive for lower rates. After the commission's order was issued, Northeast Utilities' stock fell 17 percent in two days, from $11.625 to $9.625, a loss of $273 million in market value.
Fearing that the order would erode its revenue and force it to put a lower value on some assets, thus violating some of its agreements with the creditors who had forced it into bankruptcy, the utility filed a suit in Federal court in Rhode Island. A judge there issued a temporary restraining order that threw the whole deregulation experiment into legal limbo.
What becomes apparent in New Hampshire is that even when anyone is allowed to sell power in the state, they can offer customers only relatively small savings -- 5 percent at most. To make the savings significant in a pilot program, then, New Hampshire had to mandate that its utilities provide a 10 percent rate cut to some customers, which means they lost money on those customers.
In the utility's reorganization plan, it is committed to a certain level of revenues and a certain value for its plants. But the utility argues that if New Hampshire insists on similar large savings for the rest of its customers, its revenues would be so low that it would end up in default. The lower value it would have to put on plants that would no longer be economical would also violate the terms of the plan.
During hearings on whether rates should be reduced, the commission heard some sobering testimony from Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the managing director of the investment firm Rothschild Inc., who was acting as a financial adviser to the utility. Continuing pressure to cut rates, he warned, has led investors to view the utility "as a highly volatile, politically charged venture capital situation." While some have blamed the problems at the Millstone plant for the stock's decline, Mr. Ross said the stock market had already discounted those problems.
The warnings that deep rate cuts would financially damage the utility and its investors seemed to have an effect yesterday when the commission ordered a temporary rate cut of a modest 6.4 percent as of Dec. 1. How much utility bills will actually drop remains in doubt, for the utility expects to ask for a rate increase to offset higher fuel costs.
The temporary rates will be in effect until next year, when permanent rates are set by the commission, which is under a deadline to deregulate the industry by July 1.
That the commission apparently heeded the utility's pleas and made no huge rate cuts now helped Northeast Utilities stock price, which gained 12.5 cents, to $10.9375, yesterday.
But the state's pilot program has raised such high expectations for deep rate cuts that the issue of how the state will deliver has not gone away.

HEADLINE: A Self-Made Man Takes On Newark;
Shy Philanthropist Gives His Time And Money to New Arts Center

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

 BODY:
Few have ever heard of Raymond G. Chambers. That's just the way he wants it.
But when the $180 million New Jersey Performing Arts Center opens its doors on Saturday night, everyone there will owe Mr. Chambers a debt of gratitude. The obsessively private, philanthropic Mr. Chambers was not only the first to believe that Newark could be revived through a major cultural arts center, but also the first to pledge money, $12 million in all, and the first to rally other wealthy businessmen and public officials to the cause. 
 But the center is not Mr. Chambers's only achievement. Since he became a full-time philanthropist about a decade ago, he has given away millions of dollars, much of it to charities, schools and nonprofit groups in New Jersey, and has been a mentor to dozens of disadvantaged children.
In a region filled with wealthy and generous people, Mr. Chambers, 55, stands apart. He is one of the few wealthy, self-made Americans who have given up making money, long before retirement, to devote themselves full time to giving it away. What George Soros, the Hungarian-born financier, is to international philanthropy, Mr. Chambers is to New Jersey.
"Newark can and should be a great city," Mr. Chambers said last week in one of his rare interviews. "It's got a seaport, an airport, mass transit and proximity to Manhattan. All it needs is an after-dark life."
Fans and friends who have watched Mr. Chambers applaud his willingness to part so easily with his fortune, which Forbes magazine estimated at $200 million in 1986, the last year he made the list of the 400 wealthiest Americans. But, they add, he has given even more generously of his time, and has skillfully used his own donations to get the most out of the contributions of others.
It is hard to estimate his charitable contributions, since he will not talk about them and has asked his family and friends not to discuss him or his donations. But according to public records, Mr. Chambers has given away either directly or through a network of foundations more than $50 million, probably much more, since becoming wealthy through Wesray Capital Corporation. Wesray is a private partnership that specialized in leveraged buyouts that he formed in 1981 with William E. Simon, who was Treasury Secretary under Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford.
Tax filings at the Foundation Center and its Historical Foundation Collection in Indianapolis show that he has given away more than $30 million through the MCJ Foundation, his family foundation in Morristown, N.J., which is named after his three children, Michael, Christine and Jennifer. Another $10 million endowment pledge created a program called Ready, or Rigorous Educational Assistance for Deserving Youth, which has helped thousands of disadvantaged schoolchildren in Newark with money and Mr. Chambers's time.
In 1990, inspired by a speech by President George Bush, he helped finance and found Points of Light Foundation in Washington. The group, on whose board Mr. Chambers sits, provides about $10 million a year in guidance to volunteer organizations throughout the country. And although Mr. Chambers has consistently understated his role, President Clinton described him as the sparkplug of a bipartisan volunteerism summit last spring in Philadelphia. He is also the chief executive officer of America's Promise, the Washington group created to insure that those who attended the summit fulfill their pledges.
"I can't think of anyone in New Jersey who gives more than he does," said James C. Kellogg, president of the Community Foundation of New Jersey, a major charity in the state.
The son of a steel warehouse office manager, Mr. Chambers was born and raised in the West Ward of Newark. He worked his way through Rutgers University in Newark, playing the piano and keyboards in a band. He remains close to his fellow band members, formerly the Ray-Tones, now the Accidentals. He still plays with them occasionally.
He became a tax accountant with the Newark office of Price Waterhouse in the mid-1960's and started a nursing home care company in 1968. By the time he was 25, he had made his first $1 million. The millions multiplied with Wesray.
But as his earnings accumulated, Mr. Simon said, his partner seemed to grow increasingly dissatisfied with wealth, ever more eager to begin paying back, as he now calls it. There were rumors that his partnership with Mr. Simon, who is as extroverted as Mr. Chambers is shy, was marked by great friction, which both men deny. They still have investments together, dine often with each other's families and call each other friend. But Mr. Chambers ended active participation in the firm by the late 1980's.
It was about that time that Gov. Thomas H. Kean was having trouble generating corporate support for what was then just a dream of reviving riot-torn Newark by building a major performing arts center there. Mr. Chambers was the first to pledge $5 million from his Amelior Foundation, Mr. Kean recalled recently. Others say Mr. Chambers then called a few friends and business associates, many of whom were skeptical about the idea, and would not stop pressing them until they came on board.
Since then, Mr. Chambers has given $7 million more in gifts that honor other donors and performing arts center officials, said Lawrence P. Goldman, the center's chief executive officer. Mr. Chambers recruited Mr. Goldman from Carnegie Hall, and when Mr. Goldman turned 50, gave another $100,000 to the center in Mr. Goldman's name.
Mr. Chambers's shyness evaporates when he talks about Newark. "No city can revive without a middle class," Mr. Chambers said, saying that the city's population of 406,000 before the riots has dropped to 275,000. "And you can't have a middle class without an after-dark life."
That is why it was so important to build a performing arts center in Newark, he continued. "More than 50,000 people commute into Newark every day and leave at night. All of us felt that the center would be a way of keeping them here."
Nothing seems to make Mr. Chambers more uncomfortable than talking about himself. Tall and fit, with silver strands in his neatly combed hair, Mr. Chambers looks like a cross between Robert Redford and Ted Turner. Because his smile is so ready and his enthusiasm for his work so obvious, the equally obvious anguish generated by a personal inquiry is all the more striking.
He would not talk about his wife, Patricia, or their children. Friends say that for such a wealthy man, he lives fairly modestly in Morristown. They joke about his penchant for giving credit to everyone except himself; "Chamberisms," they call his consistent praise of others for what he has done.
He can be relentless in his fervor to get others involved. Chuck Hirsch, a longtime friend and fellow philanthropist-entrepreneur, recalled an incident at his own wedding in Oregon last November. "I was in the midst of a dance with my bride and stepped away to talk to Ray. 'Hey, Chuck,' he told me, 'I'm working on this Presidential summit and I want to talk to you about getting involved.' I told him that I'd love to talk about it, but after my honeymoon," Mr. Hirsch said.
Nor is Mr. Chambers discouraged by occasional failure, like his lost investments in the New Era charity, a Ponzi scheme whose investors claimed losses of $700 million.
Mr. Chambers's other passion is being a mentor to students. "There is nothing that can make a difference in a young person's life as much as the presence, even part time, of a caring adult," he said. Mr. Chambers intends to bring a young man he has long advised to the gala: Atif Crawford, 18, who was born not far from where Mr. Chambers was born and whose tuition at the Salisbury School, a private school in Connecticut, he has helped pay.
Mr. Chambers beams with parental pride when speaking about Mr. Crawford, who is the quarterback on his school's football team. They met, Mr. Chambers said, when Mr. Crawford was 8 years old at a Newark Boys Club during a Ready board meeting. "Atif looked us over and said that he wanted to compliment the board on how well we looked that day," Mr. Chambers said.
Mr. Crawford, whose father died when he was young, says that there is no man he admires more than "Mr. C," as he calls his mentor. "He never yells," he said. "He's so calm. He's a father to me."
Newark has thousands of young men and women just like Mr. Crawford, Mr. Chambers said. "All they need is a break."
The best way of helping disadvantaged children and the needy, Mr. Chambers said, is through the "public-private partnerships that we've seen at the Philadelphia summit and now at the performing arts center." While the private sector cannot replace government, or substitute for its resources, he said, "government alone cannot work without private, caring people."
The greatest threat to America's democracy and economic vitality, he added, "is the ever-widening gap between the haves and have-nots."
As for his passion for privacy about his giving, much of which is done anonymously, Mr. Chambers had a ready and compelling explanation. "When one gives to help others, the greatest satisfaction comes from getting nothing in return."
 
What They Gave, and What They Got
Here are some of the largest gifts from corporate sponsors to the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark and what the sponsors are receiving in return, according to M. John Richard, the center's senior vice president for development and public affairs.
 
Prudential
The insurance company, which employs 7,000 people in Newark, donated a total of $6.5 million to the capital campaign in 1990 and 1996, taking advantage of what Mr. Richard called a naming opportunity. The center's biggest theater is being called Prudential Hall. The company also contributed a separate $250,000 donation in June to be one of four co-sponsors of the grand opening gala on Saturday.
 
Pepsi
In exchange for a $500,000 contribution in cash and free advertising, Pepsi will be the "official soft drink" of the Performing Arts Center. Only Pepsi products will be served at the center's bars and restaurants for five years. The company is also producing more than six million commemorative cans of Diet Pepsi.
 
Continental Airlines
The airline gave $250,000 worth of free and subsidized seats on its domestic and international flights for three years for the center's architects, consultants, performers and other associates. In exchange, the center will promote Continental, which has a hub at Newark, as its "official airline."
 
The CIT Group
CIT, a $1 million capital campaign donor, is also the $250,000 title sponsor of the new center's International Orchestra Series, which includes six now sold-out performances. It will be able to use its seats and boxes to entertain clients at the center, a common corporate practice at sports events.
 
Chase Manhattan Bank
The bank contributed $600,000 to the capital campaign. In return for a $400,000 commitment, Chase will sponsor for seven years the center's electronic billboard welcoming guests and publicizing coming performances. The bank has also pledged $50,000 to sponsor a concert by Mandy Patinkin, and will be the host for a reception for clients before the performance.
 
A Hall for Newark

TOMORROW -- Newark hopes to use the arts center to reverse the tide of urban blight.
FRIDAY -- Herbert Muschamp reviews the architecture of the new arts center, in Weekend.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Restoring a French Antique;
New Wave Chief Brings Life to a Creaky Conglomerate

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
When Jean-Marie Messier was tapped 16 months ago to run Compagnie Generale des Eaux, he was taking charge of the top dinosaur in the Jurassic Park of French industry.
A sprawling conglomerate that outgrew its beginnings as a water utility to become the country's biggest private employer, Generale had its hands in everything from casinos and parking lots to telecommunications and real estate. But as the paradigm of a French big business culture that has long been unfocused, inward-looking, paternalistic and enamored of bureaucracy, not to mention just plain stodgy, Generale was a dinosaur in distress. When Mr. Messier took over, it had piled up $9.6 billion in debt and recently finished 1995 with its first loss ever, $624 million. 
 Mr. Messier, a perfect example of the young (he is now all of 40), modern manager on the move in Europe, has managed to hold off extinction. He quickly rid Generale of $5.3 billion of nonessential assets, trimmed the work force 10 percent, to 200,000, and sealed a series of alliances, many with non-French companies that brought $3 billion into Generale's depleted coffers. The company was in the black again last year, with net profits of $320 million on revenues of $28.5 billion, about the size of Motorola.
"We had to reform strongly and abruptly," Mr. Messier said in an interview in his office here. "Now, we are in a position to be more aggressive."
Whether he can continue to teach his dinosaur new tricks has ramifications that go far beyond Generale. Managers like Mr. Messier are struggling throughout France and much of Europe to join the new world economic order at a time when the old order is not quite yet ready to give up the ghost. The old ways have left Europe with a stagnant economy, marked by painfully high unemployment rates and an urgent need to go abroad to grow.
Steeped in the Continent's traditions but also comfortable with the brasher business practices of the United States, Mr. Messier and his peers are racing the clock to wean their companies from their ossified ways as Europe itself races toward full economic union to meet the growing challenge of foreign competition. The efforts of Mr. Messier and the others could send ripples across the Atlantic, and beyond.
The final verdict is not yet in, of course. But Mr. Messier's accomplishments have already made him "one of the two or three major players in French capitalism," said Elie Cohen, a leading academic economist. Among the others, Mr. Cohen lists Francois Pinault, head of Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, the giant retailing group that recently began a $5 billion takeover bid for a rival, Worms & Compagnie, and Claude Bebear, chairman of the big Axa insurance group.
Mr. Cohen points to Mr. Messier's peculiar weave of French and non-French qualities. Mr. Messier possesses, he said, "the ability to manage political interests, the interests of the company and his personal interests." He added, "This is quite French." But he is also "the first man at Generale to speak in terms of shareholder value," Mr. Cohen said.
Mr. Messier represents a break in matters of style as well as substance. Married and the father of five, he dresses casually and has an easy manner, a firm grasp of numbers and a flair for salesmanship. A fluent speaker of English, he talks readily about globalization and return on equity, terms often absent from the French business vocabulary. And he is chummy with employees, capable of the kind of egalitarian gesture his septuagenarian predecessor, Guy Dejouany, was never guilty of making.
Earlier this year, for instance, Mr. Messier invited 5,000 employees under the age of 30 to a kind of town meeting in Paris, where he explained his goals, fielded questions for more than two hours and then was host of a dinner and dance.
For all his groundbreaking moves, however, Mr. Messier has been careful not to cut off Generale totally from its roots: the company is still landing the kind of big Government contracts that have long been its bread and butter.
Mr. Messier can pull off all these disparate feats because he is a child of the very establishment he is shaking up. Like much of France's business and political elite, he is a graduate of the revered Ecole Nationale d'Administration. As a former aide to the conservative Finance Minister, and later Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur, he had good political connections, and as a partner at Lazard Freres & Company, the venerable investment bank, he came with the right calling card to enter the inner sanctum of corporate decision making.
To be sure, some students of the French economy see a kind of inevitability in what Mr. Messier has achieved at Generale. Helie de Pourtales, a retired Lazard partner in Paris, after praising Mr. Messier as a "very special kind of guy," said, "If I ask the question, 'Where do you think a company like that should go?' most people would give the same answer." There was, he added, "nothing particularly original in that thinking."
Perhaps not, but the execution seems to have been masterful and the payoff substantial.
When Mr. Messier took control of Generale, it was delivering services like water and cable television in cozy relationships with municipal governments across France. Its executives, who saw their business as heavily dependent on political favor, were suspected of making illegal donations to political parties, and Mr. Dejouany, whose reign had endured more than two decades, was under investigation, with a clutch of other Generale managers. (The investigations are continuing, though there have been no indictments.)
And like many French giants, Generale was in abysmal financial shape. Numerous acquisitions had produced a mountain of debt and bad real estate investments had pushed the company into the red. Between the criminal investigations and the financial woes, many began to wonder whether Generale would be able to squeeze the potential from the new businesses it was entering, including TV and telecommunications.
Mr. Messier's youth -- he was 39 when named to the top job, the equivalent of chairman and chief executive -- caused some captains of French industry on Generale's board, like the feisty chairman of Peugeot, Jacques Calvet, to question whether he was up to the task of turning things around.
But Mr. Messier quickly showed just how aggressive he could be. He mopped up the real estate problems, concentrating the company's property holdings in a newly created subsidiary. And he shaved Generale's net debt -- by the end of this year, he hopes to cut it to $5.3 billion.
His goal now is to focus on three core businesses -- water and energy, property development and media and telecommunications -- and to raise shareholders' returns.
Toward that end, the company is tapping its rich experience in the French water and utilities market to expand abroad, where it is carving out a lucrative business in countries that expect shortfalls in water and energy supplies. Alliances will be the key to the effort. For example, Mr. Messier has formed a joint venture with the Marubeni Corporation of Japan to build power plants.
Intensely loyal to his predecessor, Mr. Messier believes the foundations for future growth were set by Mr. Dejouany in the early 1990's, when Generale acquired shares in Havas, a leading French media group, and in the television network Canal Plus, as well as a stake in Air and Water Technologies. Yet Mr. Dejouany, who was 75 when he retired, "knew he was not the one to be able to make the changes," Mr. Messier said. "So he chose someone from the outside."
Mr. Messier long showed a penchant for getting things done, and often in new ways.
After getting his degree at the Ecole Nationale, he went to work for Mr. Balladur, designing and putting into effect the first plans for privatization in France since the postwar nationalization of major industries.
In 1988, after the conservatives lost control of Parliament to the Socialists, Mr. Messier moved to Lazard, which sent him to New York for five months. On returning to France, he became a general partner in Lazard's Paris operations, where his clients included Generale and Mr. Dejouany. He joined Generale in 1994 as chief executive, taking over the chairman's spot as well in June 1996.
Mr. Messier brought with him a keen understanding of how French business works. He used his ties to Lazard and his connections to Mr. Balladur, who become Prime Minister when the conservatives briefly regained power in the 1990's, not only to arrive where he is, but also to make the changes he felt were necessary. He insisted that decisions regarding Generale were made on their financial and industrial merits and pointedly noted that he was skiing in the Alps the day last February when the Government awarded Generale the French national railway's 5,160-mile fiber optic network. Generale is to use the network to create the country's second wired phone system, to compete with the national system run by France Telecom. But others point out how much of Mr. Messier's time is spent massaging politicians.
Havas is a case in point.
In 1986, Mr. Messier helped privatize Havas, which he has since taken into the fold by raising Generale's holdings to a controlling stake. Now, he must use his political strength to influence legislation proposed by the Socialist Government that in effect would lessen corporate control over broadcasters like Canal Plus, which Havas controls.
In some ways, the pressures to change Generale are the same as those pushing the entire French economy to overhaul itself. With the stagnation of France's utilities sector, where annual growth is 3 to 4 percent, Mr. Messier is forced to reduce Generale's reliance on domestic public contracts and to go to Latin America and Asia, where the market is expanding by up to 20 percent. Overseas revenues now account for roughly one-third of the company's total, against one-fourth five years ago, and continue to rise. To pay for the expansion, Mr. Messier must raise capital, and he has lured international investors into the shareholder circle. Now, almost 40 percent of the shareholders are from abroad, mainly large American and British investment funds, compared with 30 percent two years ago.
Bankers say it is their presence that is driving the new focus on core businesses. When buying a French stock, fund managers "will penalize conglomerates that do not represent a brand name," said Arnault de Torquat, managing director of Salomon Brothers in Paris.
Certainly, Mr. Messier knows his strategy is not without risk. Numerous large companies with considerable experience in utilities and water management are jockeying for shares of the international market, for example. And for all of Generale's new-found strength in telecommunications, the full opening of the European market, which takes effect on Jan. 1, could spark cut-throat pricing and a collapse of revenues.
Pierre Coiffet, an analyst at the financial services group Paribas, says this uncertainty contributed to a weakening of Generale's share price in recent months, following a surge after Mr. Messier's appointment. Still, Mr. Coiffet recommends Generale for its long-term prospects.
"The story," he said, "is continuing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jean-Marie Messier. (Morris/Sipa Press)
 
Charts: "Down to the Essentials
At 40, Jean-Marie Messier is one of Europe's most prominent young, modern managers. Since becoming chief executive of France's Compagnie Generale des Eaux 16 months ago, he has turned around a huge company known for its mounting debt and for dabbling in everything from casinos to telecommunications. He has sold off about $5.3 billion in less essential sectors, reducing the number of employees and Generale's overall debt. At the same time, Mr. Messier has acquired big stakes in companies more closely related to its focus on utilities and telecommunications.
 
GETTING OUT
 
Real estate -- On Jan. 3, the company sold $1.58 billion of real estate in Europe.
 
Food -- On June 23, it sold its stake in Generale de Restauration, Europe's third- largest catering company.
 
Health care -- On July 23, it sold Generale de Sante, a health care management company, for $1.44 billion.
 
Laundry business -- On Sept. 9, it sold laundry management companies in France and the Czech Republic, reducing its debt by $98.4 million.
 
Cable TV -- Also on Sept. 9, it sold a majority stake in its cable television company.
 
GETTING IN
 
Audio-visual -- On Feb. 6, in a stock swap, it increased its stake in Havas, a communications company, to 30%.
 
Telephone -- On May 14, it completed a deal in which British Telecom, Mannesmann and SBC Communications acquired 26%, 15% and 15% stakes, respectively, in the company's telecommunications subsidiary, Cegetel.
 
Waste management -- On Aug. 29, it bought Leigh Interest, a British waste management company, for $187.4 million.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Hostile Bids And Mergers Rise in Europe

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Europe became the staging ground today for a burst of mergers and hostile takeover bids potentially worth more than $100 billion, as corporate buccaneers from France to Italy to Britain were pitted against each other in at least three different industries.
In the insurance industry, Italy's largest insurer, Generali, announced a $9 billion hostile bid for AGF of France. Just two weeks ago, AGF had teamed up with the Agnelli family of Italy to hammer out a $5.4 billion "friendly" takeover of a separate French insurance company that was the target of Generali's desires. Generali's offer was almost immediately rebuffed. 
 Generali's surprise offer today came just one day after the Zurich Group of Switzerland and B.A.T. Industries of Britain announced that they were in "advanced" talks about merging their insurance and financial service businesses into a new company worth more than $30 billion.
In the beverage industry, Guinness and Grand Metropolitan moved closer to their planned $20 billion merger by cutting a deal with the luxury goods conglomerate LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, which had vowed to block the marriage. The head of LVMH, Bernard Arnault, had been pushing for its own big stake in the combined company.
Meanwhile, the British-Dutch publishing company, Reed Elsevier, announced a merger with a Dutch publisher, and two northern European banks proposed a $10.7 billion merger.
As if that were not enough, the French cement maker Lafarge announced a $2.8 billion hostile bid for Redlands, a British manufacturer of building materials.
While there was no connection between any of these deals, at least part of the driving force, analysts said, was Europe's accelerating push toward a single currency in 1999, the increasingly transparent flow of goods and services across national borders and the growing trend toward global markets. As Europe moves closer toward a single economy, the national fiefs are rushing to shore up their European position.
The extraordinary gyrations highlighted the tough new brand of empire-building that has seized European industry, where hostile takeovers were rare until recently in any place outside Britain.
That is particularly true in the staid insurance industry, now at the center of a cross-border pileup featuring executives who would have fit in with some of America's legendary corporate combatants: a French corporate raider reminiscent of T. Boone Pickens; a "white knight" company that rode in to to fend off the raider, and a surprise attacker with sights on the white knight.
But it also reflects the growing influence of a more bare-knuckled American approach to mergers and acquisitions. American investment banks have been advisers on many of Europe's biggest mergers over the last few years, and their tactics have been embraced by European institutions like Lazard Brothers, which had a role in several deals today, and Banque Paribas of France and Credit Suisse First Boston.
"The investment bankers have been working very hard to fan the flames of the perception that action is required," remarked Jonathan Lawlor of HBSC James Capel in London. "The sequence of transactions has been remarkable."
For those in search of corporate intrigue, it would be hard to match the frenzy of machinations that have swept through Europe's insurance industry in recent days.
In one corner is a maverick French entrepreneur named Francois Pinault, who has amassed a sprawling conglomerate of companies include the American luggage manufacturer Samsonite. Mr. Pinault began a $5 billion hostile bid several weeks ago for Worms et Cie of France. Worms, itself a product of a recent merger, has a prized asset named Athena. But with Worms's stock languishing, analysts say Mr. Pinault wanted to break up Worms and unlock the real value in Athena.
It was the kind of move that brought both fame and notoriety to people like T. Boone Pickens, who wanted to break loose the value of Gulf Oil and other petroleum companies with huge oil reserves.
But the family heirs of Worms fought back by enlisting a white knight to make a rival bid, financed by Italy's pre-eminent Agnelli family, which is also a Worms shareholders. By teaming up with the French insurer AGF, the Agnellis would control Worms and AGF would control Athena, thereby thwarting the unwelcomed bid from Mr. Pinault. AGF, formally known as Assurances Generales de France, already owned 7 percent of Worms and had wanted to acquire the Athena insurance company for well over a year. The Agnelli family, whose members are the major stockholders in Fiat, already owned 20 percent of Worms and agreed to take control.
But today's offer by Assicurazioni Generali tried to upend all that. Generali signaled its interest in Athena probably because the company had little presence in France and wanted to expand its Europe-wide position. By moving in on AGF, Generali could conceivably end up in control of both it and Athena.
Analysts say that the competition for Athena was merely the latest move toward consolidation in Europe's insurance industry. Less than one year ago, France's two biggest insurance companies -- Axa S.A. and Union Assurances des Paris -- united in a $10 billion merger.
"With the European Monetary Union coming along and national boundaries coming down, major insurance companies want representation across Europe," said Derek Elias, an insurance industry analyst at Banque Paribas. The problem, he added, is that there are only a small number of companies available for those who want to expand rapidly outside their own country.
That pressure has also been behind the Zurich Group's headlong expansion. Zurich bought the Kemper Corporation, a life insurance and mutual fund company for $2 billion in 1995. (The Kemper Insurance Companies of Long Grove, Ill., including four mutual property and casualty companies, were not a part of the acquisition.) Several months ago, Zurich began to negotiate on taking control of the insurance operations of London-based B.A.T. Industries.
On Sunday, after two British newspapers reported that the talks were taking place, the two companies acknowledged that they were discussing a merger of their insurance and financial-service businesses that analysts say would be worth from $32 billion to $35 billion.
Investors reacted jubilantly to the disclosure today, bidding up the stock of both companies. B.A.T., which would effectively liberate its insurance businesses from their linkage with its big tobacco operations, saw its shares climb 10 percent, or 58 pence, to 609 pence. The Zurich Group's stock jumped 7 percent, or 41 Swiss francs, to 641 francs. Analysts said the company's biggest gain would be acquiring a sales force of more than 14,000 people in the United States through B.A.T.'s American insurance subsidiary, the Farmers Insurance Group.
