HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
LVMH Now Backs Merger Of Grand Met And Guinness

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
Ending a messy war over the future of the European spirits business, Guinness P.L.C. and Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said yesterday that they would forge ahead with their $20 billion merger, this time with the blessing of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., which had said it would try to block the deal.
For his concessions, LVMH's chief executive, Bernard Arnault, is to gain control of most of the drinks distribution network of the new company, which will be known as GMG Brands, as well as a seat on its board. LVMH is also to receive 500 million, or about $810 million, split evenly between cash and a special dividend that would be distributed to all GMG shareholders. 
 Investors applauded the news, seeing savings, economies of scale and the end of what had been expected to be a protracted battle. In London, the shares of Guinness rose 28.5 pence, to 605.5 pence, and those of Grand Met were up 21 pence, to 604 pence; in Paris, LVMH stock rose 25 francs a share, to 1,248.
The news came as a surprise to many analysts, because Mr. Arnault has previously shown a taste for lengthy fights.
Guinness and Grand Met said in May that they intended to merge their drinks and foods businesses, which together make up the lion's share of the European spirits business, as well as Guinness beer and Grand Met's Burger King restaurants and Pillsbury food units.
Mr. Arnault, who owns stakes in both Guinness and Grand Met and whose luxury-goods company owns several high-end spirits, including Moet et Chandon and Hennessy Cognac, opposed the merger, lest he end up a lesser player in liquor.
Mr. Arnault instead proposed that Guinness, Grand Met and LVMH merge their drink businesses, that Grand Met spin off its food entities and that Guinness get rid of its breweries. He also sought a 35 percent stake in that merged company.
Guinness and Grand Met took a dim view of Mr. Arnault's proposal. He then began to increase his stake in Grand Met, raising it to 11.1 percent. Though he cut his position in Guinness, he kept an 11.47 percent stake. That gave him more than the 10 percent needed to call a special shareholder meeting at each company.
Eventually, the parties came to the bargaining table. Under yesterday's 10-year agreement, the current drinks distribution ventures of LVMH and Guinness in the United States, Asia and France are now to include Grand Met brands. LVMH is to retain the 66 percent it owns in its own drinks business, Moet Hennessy, and the 34 percent that Guinness owns will go into GMG Brands.
It was not immediately clear yesterday whether there were three moderate winners or three partial losers emerging from the deal. "It was a good settlement for both sides," said Russell Duckworth, an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in London. "Guinness and Grand Met have come to an agreement with LVMH and reduced the risk of them disrupting the deal. But they paid for it by giving up their side of the benefits of distribution."
The merged parties estimate that the reconfigured distribution network will save them about 20 million each annually in costs. But there is some question as to how much that savings may be worth, since Mr. Arnault's support came at so high a price. And while Mr. Arnault expressed pleasure in the deal, it is not as sweet as the one he had proposed.
"It is disappointing to see that LVMH is not coming in 100 percent," said Martin Hawkins, an analyst at Greig Middleton in London. "It would have been unusual if Grand Met didn't go through with Guinness anyway, so this added nothing to the merger but cured what would have been a lingering aggravation."
Mr. Arnault may have conceded earlier than he would have liked because he had trouble convincing investors that his alternative proposition was worth the end result.
LVMH shares have suffered recently as sales of its luxury fashion, leather and spirits businesses have been sluggish, in part because of a weaker yen which has limited spending overseas by Japanese travelers.
Some of Mr. Arnault's biggest shareholders may well have been clamoring for results. "I thought he would fight it out," said Cedric Magnelia, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in London. "But a lot of large institutional investors would not support his proposition."
On the other hand, Mr. Arnault may use his new board seat, his hand in distribution and his generally aggressive nature to push for the break of assets he has sought.
"Both managements have looked in the past and wondered if the groups together make sense," said an investment banker who worked on the deal and spoke on the condition of anonymity. "If it makes sense from shareholder viewpoint, I am sure they will consider it."
Regulatory agencies in the United States and Europe have yet to sign off on the merger. The European Union has already expressed some concern about GMG's possible dominant market position in Greece, Spain, Belgium and Ireland. European regulators may force the new company to shed some holdings; in that case, it would most likely get rid of secondary brands.
Some analysts said they thought that regulators would cause little trouble, but others worried that selling pieces of the company would erode the point of the merger, which was to dominate all aspects of the spirits business.
"The story of the late 80's was spirits companies wrestling back control of third-party distribution," Mr. Hawkins noted. "Now, the regulatory authorities are trying to push back the clock by removing vertical integration."

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Networks and N.F.L.: Heading North Again?

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
Pat Bowlen tried not to sound boastful. But you couldn't fault him if he bragged a smidgen thanks to the leverage the National Football League has on its TV "partners." Bowlen, who owns the Denver Broncos and heads the N.F.L.'s broadcasting committee, reckons that very soon, the networks will agree to pay "somewhere north of 50 percent" more than they are paying now.
The league is in the final season of being paid $4.38 billion over four years by ABC, NBC, Fox, ESPN and TNT. A new deal worth $6.6 billion isn't bad. 
 "This is a good position," Bowlen said yesterday from Washington, where N.F.L. owners will meet today and tomorrow. "I wouldn't want to characterize it that we have great leverage and we want to hold a gun to their heads. But N.F.L. programming is very important to the networks."
On the surface, a 50 percent-plus raise seems antithetical to logical economics. The league's overall trend in Nielsen ratings is downward. NBC's has fallen from a 12.5 in 1994 to an 8.6 so far this year. After a 17.8 in 1994, ABC's "Monday Night Football" is down to a 14.8 through this season.
However, Fox is up a bit to a 10.4 so far this season, but still down from a 12.5 for all of 1995. TNT is up to a 6.3 from a 5.4 at this time last year.
Why pay more for a product with diminishing results, and one that has lost its presence in Los Angeles, Houston and Cleveland since the current deal began? Because demand outstrips supply. CBS wants in, to avenge being deposed by Fox. And even at a reduced rating, the N.F.L. is the mightiest of all sports. And no network would spurn a chance to broadcast a Super Bowl.
"The ratings don't matter," said Bowlen. "I really think they don't impact us at all." He said that even a rising ratings trend would not affect the N.F.L.'s anticipated booty. It's the N.F.L. Just pay, baby.
Lower ratings "give the networks ammunition to talk about the problems they're having, and how advertisers are beating them up on ratings," said Neal Pilson, an industry consultant, who ran CBS Sports when the Laurence Tisch regime bid adieu to its National Football Conference package. "The league listens to them, and says, 'O.K., here's your number.' "
Serious discussions between the N.F.L. and the networks won't begin until after Nov. 1, when the incumbent networks' exclusive negotiating period ends. After that, CBS can enter on the broadcast side to challenge ABC, Fox and NBC, and Fox Sports Net on the cable side, to vie against ESPN and TNT. The money dance -- all orchestrated by the N.F.L. -- may drag on until January.
Bowlen would not speculate on the specifics of what each network must pay to keep its package, but he said Fox must pay "more than a token increase" above its $395-million-a-year fee for the N.F.C. "They're adamant at keeping what they have at their price," he said, "which is easy to say at their level."
The league seems to have the most leverage with ABC, which has paid $230 million a year since 1994 for the struggling network's highest rated show, after a 2 percent increase from the previous contract.
Sounds like real leverage. "You said it," said Bowlen. He would not say whether NBC has to leap up from $217 million a year to $330 million or more. But a 50 percent increase would mean $325 million.
"I can't speak for the networks' agendas," he said. "I can't get inside their heads or their businesses, but we know that all the networks consider our product important to their business strategies. We know why Fox did it, and even though their agenda is different now, they're not backing away."
In 1993, NBC loudly carped about its losses, but, faced with losing its A.F.C. package, it anted up. Now, no one is publicly complaining about losses or ratings, a sign that nobody wants to end up like CBS. The new CBS, looking to return, doesn't want to end up like the old CBS either.
"The landscape has changed since the Fox deal," Bowlen said. "We saw what the N.F.L. has done for Fox and for Fox's position in television."
Said Pilson: "The N.F.L. says, 'The values of carrying the N.F.L. are so high that you don't even have to make a profit on it -- other things in your company can make money.' " Gone are the days when the three networks could bargain a rights-fee reduction, as they did in the late 1980's. "The league had no leverage without a willing fourth party," Pilson said.
The N.F.L. is perceived to be so crucial, post-CBS, that Bowlen anticipates that Fox would like more than the N.F.C. package it has. "They'd like to add, take your pick, cable, or another broadcast package," he said. "They could take a swipe at the whole thing on Sunday afternoon. I don't know if that's in our best interest, but there's been conversation about it."
He doubted that the league would carve a new Thursday night package to accommodate CBS, thus providing something for everybody. "Creating a new package dilutes the current packages too much," he said.
But for a whopping, eye-popping sum? "Anything's possible," he said.
Pilson figures that CBS will target "Monday Night." He added: "If they want to pay, they have to lose $50 million to $100 million a year. I think CBS would pay $350 million now to get 'Monday Night Football.' "
Sweet, lush music to Bowlen's ears.

HEADLINE: How to Make Big Rubles? Invest in a Comrade's Debt

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
Stanislav Baranov sat in the computer-filled trading room at Rossiisky Kredit Bank, barely able to contain his glee.
He had made a big investment in Almazy Rossii-Sakha, Russia's biggest diamond-mining company, at a time when its outlook was shaky. Now, less than six months later, people were clamoring to buy him out at a big profit. "I'm holding it," he said with a roguish trader's grin. "We're not selling until it becomes worth more." 
 Victories like this are the bread of life for securities traders on Wall Street -- except that Mr. Baranov doesn't invest in stocks or bonds. He trades in unpaid bills. Hundreds of millions of dollars in unpaid, overdue bills.
He is not alone. Russia's mountain of overdue debt has spawned one of the biggest and strangest developments yet on this country's rocky road to capitalism: a $15 billion market in i.o.u.'s. Known here as "veksels," many are redeemable for cash, as the diamond company's are. Others are good for oil, electricity, tires, chemicals or cement.
Whatever their form, the use of veksels has exploded in the last year. Companies issue them to pay their suppliers, which barter them for other goods or resell them to speculators for cash.
Banks and brokerage companies trade more than $100 million worth of them each month, and post prices for them on the Internet. Even a few American investors are snapping them up, viewing them as a Russian variant on American high-yield junk bonds.
The trade in veksels is a very primitive version of a corporate bond market, though one that is largely unregulated and often informal. In some cases it is similar to the practice in the United States of bundling mortgages, car loans or even troubled loans from distressed companies into securities that are sold to investors.
In many respects, swapping veksels is the financial equivalent of keeping the Mir space station in orbit. Overdue bills in business have tripled in the last two years, to $123 billion -- equal to more than one-quarter of the country's annual economic output, the Russian Government estimates.
Unpaid bills pervade Russian life. Companies cannot pay their suppliers; suppliers cannot pay their workers; workers cannot pay their utility bills or their rent, and almost everybody holds back on paying taxes.
The vicious cycle of nonpayment has become particularly acute in the last 18 months, thanks largely to the Russian Central Bank's get-tough policies on fighting inflation. Those policies abruptly choked off the money supply and brought inflation below 15 percent, from more than 200 percent in 1994. But the other result is that people literally do not have any money.
Many other countries have endured similar travails, and some have also resorted to high-level bartering as a solution. Indeed, the word veksel is a borrowing of the German "wechsel," for "exchange." Germany resorted to i.o.u.'s for a brief period after World War II. Several other former Soviet republics are using them today, and Mexican banks have developed something similar as well.
But few have responded on as large a scale and with such sophistication as Russia, blending the swagger of Chicago commodities traders, Internet technology and the hand-to-mouth survival schemes of companies in daily danger of collapse.
Typically, a company issues i.o.u.'s to its suppliers instead of paying cash. The suppliers can then either hold the i.o.u's and wait for them to be paid by an agreed-upon date, or try to cash them in immediately by selling them or exchanging them at a discount from their face value. The bigger the discount -- and they can be substantial -- the greater the risk that the i.o.u. will not be paid off on time -- or at all.
The market is a fragile one built on the idea that the securities will either be held or continue to be transferred.
Consider the case of Gazprom, the company that distributes natural gas across Russia as well as to much of Western Europe. Gazprom is one of Russia's strongest companies, one whose shares and i.o.u.'s are heavily traded around the country.
Like many other companies, Gazprom is caught in the middle of Russia's nonpayments crisis. Moscow's electric utility, Mosenergo, owes the company about three trillion rubles, or $512 million. Mosenergo's problem is that the Moscow city government, which subsidizes residential electric bills, owes it two trillion rubles, or $342 million. Part of the government's problem, in turn, is that neither businesses nor residents are paying their taxes.
Enter veksels. Gazprom has issued its suppliers about $170 million worth of i.o.u.'s, which are redeemable primarily for natural gas. Because Gazprom is big and credible, brokers say that its i.o.u.'s are always in popular demand among both investors and companies looking for natural gas. In fact, many Gazprom veksels ultimately end up in the hands of its debtors, who use them to offset their own overdue bills.
Whether the i.o.u.'s get swapped for natural gas or for money, they are valuable. Analysts at Renaissance Capital Group, a Moscow-based investment firm, calculate that Gazprom veksels yield a profit of roughly 25 percent a year. Conventional government bonds in Russia yield about 18 percent a year.
But investors with cast-iron stomachs say the returns on less familiar companies can climb to more than 65 percent. That was the case with Almazy Rossii-Sakha, the Government-owned producer of nearly one-third of the world's crude diamonds.
Almazy and the Russian Government had been close to cementing a lucrative contract with the De Beers, the South African diamond producer. But the two sides have been haggling for more than a year, which left Almazy almost drained of cash. So the company has issued more than $100 million in i.o.u.'s, many of them due to be paid in cash in 1998.
Now Almazy i.o.u.'s are suddenly hot -- so hot they are almost impossible to buy. The reason: Almazy and De Beers plan to sign a final contract later this month. As a result, the i.o.u.'s are now likely to be paid off on time, so their value has nearly doubled since last year. People who bought Almazy i.o.u.'s early are now likely to make a profit of 65 percent at the time of payoff, according to Renaissance Capital Group, a Moscow-based investment firm.
Numbers like that are attracting serious foreign investors, including Americans. "This is the first stage toward developing a corporate bond market," said Kyle Brandon, a partner at Orion Capital Advisors, an investment fund here that focuses on Russian securities and began buying i.o.u.'s a few months ago. What is the lure? "Sixty-five percent returns," said Ms. Brandon bluntly.
But the risks can be huge. The International Monetary Fund has been critical of veksels, saying they distort the true indebtedness of the country and the companies, and give companies a way to avoid taxes -- as the profit on i.o.u.'s is generated almost entirely outside the official economy and is generally not taxed.
The i.o.u.'s are also notoriously intricate, each tied to the bill-paying problems of a particular company and many loaded with quirky conditions. Many i.o.u.'s never even trade in the open market, and are simply swapped between companies that regularly do business.
Some electric utilities and power plants coordinate their unpaid bills. Kursk Atomic Power Station, a government-owned nuclear plant, has been left with millions in unpaid bills by local electric utilities across central Russia. So instead of promising to pay off its suppliers itself, Kursk Atomic pays off its own bills with i.o.u.'s that companies can redeem in the form of electricity at local utilities that owe Kursk Atomic money.
"You can talk about these things for weeks and never get a thing done," laughed Mr. Baranov, who heads Rossiisky Kredit's veksel-trading operation.
Though all i.o.u.'s are theoretically redeemable for cash at some date in the future, many of them end up as means of facilitating bartering.
Krasnoyarsk Tire Company in Siberia now relies on i.o.u.'s and bartering for almost all transactions.
"Only 3 to 5 percent of the money flow of the company is carried out in cash," said Sergei Chirkasov, who heads Krasnoyarsk Tire's i.o.u. activities. Over the last 18 months, he said, the company has more than doubled its use of i.o.u.'s. It plans to use them to pay its workers' wages.
Because Krasnoyarsk i.o.u.'s are generally redeemable only for tires, they are transformed into money through the alchemy of trading. The chain can take the i.o.u.'s across the country and back.
Krasnoyarsk, for example, uses tire i.o.u.'s to buy raw materials from Rosshina, a Moscow company. Rosshina exchanges them for electricity with a Siberian electric company called Tyumenenergo, part of Russia's nationwide power distributor, Unified Energy Systems. The electric company then trades some of the tire vouchers with Gazprom, to which it owes money for raw fuel.
At some point, the tire i.o.u.'s end up in the hands of a company that takes them back to Krasnoyarsk Tire and uses them to buy tires.
Serious investors say they usually trade only in i.o.u.'s redeemable for cash. Many big issuers of i.o.u.'s are banks, which sell their own to raise short-term capital for lending. But even those can be enormously risky.
In July 1996, a Moscow bank called Tveruniversalbank abruptly went bankrupt because it had issued far more i.o.u.'s than it could afford to pay off. When it collapsed, it left about $160 million in obligations.
Earlier this month, the daily Izvestia reported that counterfeiters in the Russian Far East had begun selling fake i.o.u.'s. The paper said the swindlers had produced convincing copies of i.o.u.'s issued by Sberbank, one of Russia's biggest banks, and were planning to sell more than $40 million worth. The gang, which included Defense Ministry workers, was caught when Sberbank officials spotted early forgeries.
Hoping to avoid further catastrophes, the Russian Central Bank has clamped down on the volume of i.o.u.'s that banks can issue. Meanwhile, companies that issue i.o.u.'s have formed a self-regulatory organization called Auver, which has created more formal ground rules and is trying to develop a system like those used to trade stocks and bonds.
Many experts predict that i.o.u.'s will fade into disuse as Russia's economy becomes more stable and as companies learn to borrow money in more conventional ways, by getting bank loans or by selling bonds.
But that may take years. Until then, or until another scandal erupts, veksels are moving full speed ahead.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "FOR EXAMPLE: I.O.U.'S Instead of Rubles"
With too little cash to go around, Russians are issuing and accepting billions of dollars' worth of i.o.u.'s in exchange for goods and services. Here is a recent chain of transactions that started with a shipment of rubber worth one billion rubles (about $170,000) to a tire factory in Siberia.
1 -- The Krasnoyarsk tire factory pays for rubber with an i.o.u.
2 -- Rosshina, the Moscow-based rubber supplier, settles a debt with a Siberian business partner by using the i.o.u. to pay the partner's electricity bills.
3 -- The electric com-pany uses the i.o.u. to buy natural gas.
4 -- With the i.o.u., the natural gas company buys tires for its fleet of trucks.

HEADLINE: Hospital Deals Raise Concern On Abortion

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN

 BODY:
When Northern Dutchess Hospital and Kingston Medical Center merged last year, they began the kind of streamlining and emphasis on preventive care that keeps hospitals afloat in the era of managed care.
But now the two hospitals -- situated on opposite sides of the Hudson River in upstate New York -- are merging with a third hospital, a Roman Catholic competitor in Kingston, N.Y., and this partnership will involve more than a mere re-engineering. The two secular hospitals are agreeing to follow Catholic doctrine practiced by the third partner, Benedictine Hospital, and will stop offering contraceptive counseling, abortions, tubal ligations and vasectomies. 
 They have also precluded the possibility of ever offering in vitro fertilization or artificial insemination to infertile couples -- procedures that are explicitly banned by the church.
The scenario upstate is repeating itself across New York State, the region and the country as health care institutions scrambling for economic security join forces with Catholic organizations, abandoning reproductive services in exchange for financial solvency.
Last year, there were 29 mergers or affiliations nationally involving Catholic hospitals, according to Catholics for a Free Choice, a nonprofit group that supports abortion rights. The group's figure would indicate that mergers have been on a sharp upswing. A total of 57 alliances with Catholic hospitals took place from 1990 to 1995.
"We are doing this for the survival of all three hospitals," said Anthony Marmo, chief executive of Kingston Hospital, which together with Northern Dutchess Hospital is now known as the Cross River Health Company. "Together, we create a large patient base and efficiencies we couldn't achieve on our own. It makes business sense."
Family planning advocates and women's rights groups say they are frightened and appalled by this trend. The Roman Catholic Church, they note, is already the largest nonprofit health care provider in the country, accounting for about one in six of all hospital admissions. If the church's presence increases through mergers with secular organizations, they say, options for reproductive services will shrink.
"This is not a classic pro-life, pro-choice abortion debate," said JoAnn Smith, executive director of Family Planning Advocates of New York State, a research and advocacy group. "We're talking about everyday reproductive care, like contraception. We're talking about adequate H.I.V. and AIDS counseling. We're talking about the morning-after pill for rape victims. Deals like these undermine the basic availability of quality, convenient health care for women."
Just a glance at some recent mergers in New York show how common the trend has become.
*In Troy, N.Y., the once nonsectarian Leonard Hospital merged with St. Mary's Hospital and became a Roman Catholic institution. Initially, doctors there could not perform abortions, nor even make referrals for patients, nor offer any kind of advice on contraceptives. Only after a lawsuit was filed did the combined hospital agree to provide referrals for such care.
*Fidelis Care, a Catholic-sponsored health maintenance organization serving Medicaid patients only in New York City, tripled its enrollment by purchasing the nonsectarian Better Health Plan, a statewide Medicaid-only H.M.O. Although it serves largely young, poor women of childbearing age, Fidelis refuses to provide coverage or referrals for significant family planning services like birth control, abortions, tubal ligations and comprehensive H.I.V. and AIDS prevention counseling.
*The only two hospitals in Batavia, N.Y. -- Genesee Memorial Hospital and St. Jerome Hospital, which is Catholic -- announced their intent to consolidate operations and abide by Catholic doctrine, banning abortions, tubal ligations, vasectomies and family planning.
Although they promised to build an independent, freestanding health clinic for women so that reproductive health services in the area would not be lost, those plans are stalled.
There have been similar results nationally in mergers or other partnerships in cities like Sacramento, Calif., Indianapolis and West Palm Beach, Fla. Hospitals in those cities stopped performing abortions when they affiliated with a Catholic institution. All three, however, continue to offer sterilization.
 
Priorities Made Clear During Negotiations
Executives for Catholic health care organizations said that there was nothing subversive about their business strategies and that they make their priorities clear when they begin negotiations to ally with secular institutions.
"Our beliefs are our beliefs," said Thomas A. Dee, chief executive officer of Benedictine Hospital. "We make no secret of them. Hospitals may choose not to join with us as a result, but our belief system is firm."
In many cities around the country where mergers between Catholic and nonsectarian hospitals have been planned, local residents have banded together in opposition. In some cases, their resistance has helped to kill deals.
Two years of negotiations to merge St. Peter's Medical Center with the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J., were quelled in June, because the two sides could not resolve their differences over reproductive services.
In Poughkeepsie, N.Y., negotiations to merge Vassar Brothers Hospital, a secular hospital, and St. Francis Hospital, which is Catholic, were scuttled when community pressure mounted after the hospitals revealed that Catholic doctrine would be followed.
And three secular hospitals near Hartford -- including the state-run University of Connecticut Medical Center -- announced in July that they were joining forces with a Catholic hospital to build an ambulatory care center that "respects Catholic health care principles." But the deal fell apart after community protests.
In a time of rising costs, shorter hospital stays and more specialized outpatient clinics, hundreds of hospitals struggling for survival have merged or affiliated with larger institutions that give them more bargaining power with health maintenance organizations and allow them to eliminate some duplicate and expensive medical departments and to consolidate services like billing and laundry.
 
Partnerships Needed To Assure Survival
Given the current tumultuous health care environment, executives involved in the deal between Kingston and Northern Dutchess Hospitals and Benedictine say they do not have the luxury of spurning attractive financial partnerships that they need to survive for the sake of preserving a relatively small corner of their business.
"Yes, there are emotional issues involved here and we are determined to see that these services be provided in another setting in the community," Mr. Marmo, the Cross River chief executive, said of the reproductive procedures his organization is planning to abandon when it merges with Benedictine. "But you have to remember that this is a very small portion of our business right now. And in terms of proportionality, there are so many more benefits to the community with this merger despite the unfortunate loss to some. Imagine the economic damage if these hospitals closed."
Cross River officials have promised that they will help build a freestanding women's health clinic where elective abortions and sterilizations could be performed and where advanced infertility treatments currently not available at either hospital could be added.
But many local residents remain unconvinced that such a care center would be either practical or financially viable. They fear, for example, that such a site could become a target for anti-abortion activists, who might harass and threaten patients and staff members.
They also contend that even with such a clinic, women who are in the hospital giving birth could not choose to have their tubes tied at the same time, thereby avoiding a second hospitalization, and that they could not get uncensored advice about their own health care.
"From a dollars-and-cents point of view, I see where this merger is a winning proposition for the hospitals," said Dr. Dean Bloch, an obstetrician and gynecologist at Northern Dutchess Hospital, who noted that the medical staff at that hospital had voted unanimously against incorporating Catholic doctrine. "But from a philosophical point of view, this is a dramatic difference. It's health care being ruled by something other than what's best for the patient."
In other proposed mergers, community outrage has forced the hospital partners to come up with creative solutions that allowed alliances between secular and Catholic entities to go forward while safeguarding reproductive services. When John P. Mather Memorial Hospital and St. Charles Hospital and Rehabilitation Center in Port Jefferson on Long Island formed a joint venture recently, they excluded from their alliance services unacceptable to the Catholic Church: abortions, vasectomies and in vitro fertilization. Mather continues to perform those procedures on its own premises outside its agreement with St. Charles.
Rather than merging, St. Mary's Hospital and Horizon Healthcare Inc. in Wauwatosa, Wis., affiliated instead, a looser partnership that allows Horizon to continue offering sterilizations and in vitro fertilization, with St. Charles forgoing a share in any revenue from those procedures.
 
Rallies and Petitions To Protest a Merger
Aware of the success of other opposition efforts, people in Dutchess County have been organizing, hoping that their voices will help redefine the planned partnership between Cross River and Benedictine, which does not have a name yet. They have held rallies, sponsored community meetings and gathered nearly 2,000 names on petitions protesting the merger.
"We're not against an affiliation," said Mernie Dempster, a retired school librarian who helped lead the antimerger petition drive, standing outside the grocery store in downtown Rhinebeck collecting signatures. "We know hospitals are facing tough times. But there are many models where the nonsectarian hospital doesn't have to follow the dictates of the church. We want them to find a way to do both. We don't want services to be lost."
Opponents of the proposed merger were looking at the deal through very narrow lenses, said Mr. Dee of Benedictine. Over all, he said, medical services in the area would increase.
"It's very parochial to look at the effect of this merger on just two or three services," he said. "We see this as being all about growing services, about increasing trauma care, getting a Level 2 neonatal nursery and more rehabilitation services. We're looking to add high-end oncology. Whenever you have a merger, there are always some reductions."
In this case, Mr. Dee acknowledges, the cutbacks are directly in response to church doctrine. And many people who oppose mergers between Catholic and nonsectarian hospitals in which church law is adopted across the institutions say their position is one that is also based on religious freedom.
"There are many members of the clergy, even some who are opposed to abortion, who are very concerned that the ethical and religious directives of one church are being imposed on people of other religions," said the Rev. Tom Davis, a minister in the United Church of Christ, who retired as a chaplain and professor of religion at Skidmore College and now lives in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.
"It used to be understood that if you went to a Catholic hospital, you knew that the doctrine of that church prevailed there," he said. "But these mergers are of grave concern because even hospitals that do not agree to become Catholic hospitals agree in these deals to abide by Catholic rules."

HEADLINE: In New Orleans, the House Loses

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Back in the early 1990's, when the Louisiana Legislature legalized casino gambling, it seemed to many New Orleanians that their city was the odds-on favorite to become the next Las Vegas or Atlantic City.
This is, after all, the "Big Easy," the city whose unofficial motto is "let the good times roll," the vacation destination every year of close to 10 million people. 
 What better way to sweeten the allure, and the take, than to add slot machines and gaming tables to the indulgent mix of crawfish etouffe, hot jazz down on the levee and boozy arm-in-arm strolls through streets that could be in Paris?
Alas, for all the high hopes and sure-thing conviction, the city rolled snake eyes.
Over the past three years, all three downtown riverboat casinos have foundered on economic, regulatory and legal difficulties, the last one shutting down just over a week ago. Worse, the city's only land-based casino has folded, too, and a gambling pleasure dome that was to replace it, a block-square structure designed to compete with just about anything in Las Vegas or Atlantic City, sits half completed on the edge of the French Quarter, mired in bankruptcy, its developers desperately searching for a way to head off liquidation and salvage their $830 million investment.
Unless owners of the newly beached riverboat and the all-but-liquidated land project come up with new operating plans within the next few weeks, particularly a new financing plan for the land project, gambling in downtown New Orleans in the foreseeable future is likely to be limited to a few electronic poker machines and betting parlors.
The Flamingo, the shut-down riverboat, could become just another faux paddle-wheeler hauling camera-toting day-trippers on the Mississippi. The empty shell of the French Quarter pleasure dome could be abandoned to the stray cats and foraging rats that have already taken up residence there, or it might fall to the wrecker's ball.
What happened?
What put an end to the hit-me-one-more-time talk of five years back, when the newly legalized casinos were just opening their doors and the promoters were projecting an annual economic infusion of $3 billion in gamblers' cash, with $300 million of that thrown off in taxes? What happened to the 50,000 new jobs promised on the bumper stickers plastered about by the promoters when the city was still staggering from the last national economic recession?
"Mistakes were made -- economic, political, sociological, legal, some just dumb," Mayor Marc Morial said. "I still believe casino gambling can be a viable business in New Orleans, though not our economic be all and end all as some predicted. The big question is: Can those mistakes be undone? I wouldn't hazard a guess on the odds."
Other cities and other casino operators have also made mistakes and experienced failure with gambling enterprises. What sets New Orleans apart is that the odds for success seemed all but unbeatable.
Both critics and proponents of casinos generally agree that the major blunders here were an overly optimistic promotion of the city's potential as a gambling center, a faulty structuring of licensing and operating requirements for casino owners and the imposition of unrealistically high taxes on casino receipts.
The most striking mistake was overestimating of the city's potential as a gambler's mecca.
Though some local residents have shown a penchant for playing the slots and tables, as have some tourists, New Orleans has yet to be viewed as a gambling center by anybody other than gambling promoters. The number of players on any given day and the amount they gamble have never reached the levels needed to cover casino operating costs here, the highest in the nation, and still leave a healthy profit.
Most disturbing of all, surveys of tourists arriving in New Orleans have found that two of every three have little or no interest in spending their limited time here bent over a craps table or transfixed before a slot machine when there is so much else to see and do.
"Ten million visitors coming to New Orleans every year doesn't work out to 10 million gamblers," said C. B. Forgotston, a lawyer who opposes efforts to turn the city into a major gaming center. "Proof of that is that we've had four casinos fold here while casinos over in Mississippi and up the river and over on the lake are doing just fine -- because gambling is all that they've got, all they do. That's where you go if gambling is what you want."
Jason Ader, a Wall Street analyst who follows gambling stocks for Bear Stearns, said that with the right regulatory and tax climate in the city, the flow of local and out-of-town gamblers into casinos, while still not a flood, would nevertheless be sufficient to keep gambling operations in the black.
"If they ran things in New Orleans like they do elsewhere, without all those high taxes and fees, you could do all right with a casino," Mr. Ader said.
But Louisiana legislators were so confident that casinos would rake in earnings by the millions upon millions that they rushed to enact taxes two and three times higher than other states impose on such earnings. And prospective casino operators were so certain of the big earnings that they readily agreed to pay the taxes and then -- this being Louisiana, where money often talks -- some even boldly offered, publicly, to pay premium fees in order to win licenses to operate.
Further, the cocksure prospective operators also went along with another potentially crippling regulation. Prodded by the powerful New Orleans restaurant and hotel lobby, the state ordered casinos not to lavish as many free rooms, meals and drinks on gamblers as do casinos in other states.
"The cost of running a casino in Louisiana is higher than just about anywhere else," said Timothy Ryan, the dean of the economics department at the University of New Orleans and a close student of gambling economics. "Most states put about a 7 percent tax on a casino's gross. Louisiana taxes at 18.5 percent. Some Louisiana casinos also impose a head tax on gamblers, whereas everywhere else gamblers are welcomed with open arms. I figure the riverboat that just shut down was paying about a 35 percent tax over all at the end. Who can stand that very long?"
The boat's operators, the Hilton Corporation and some Louisiana partners, are torn about whether to try to reopen in New Orleans and again risk not only the onerous tax but also cutthroat competition should the casino on land somehow eventually open. Alternatively, Hilton and its partners wonder whether they should try to move to some other, possibly more lucrative, river site in Louisiana.
In the meantime, as talks about what to do with the boat have dragged on, the boat's license to operate within the city has expired, which the operators said doomed the boat, whatever else might have happened.
The boat also faces another problem; the city treasurer contends its owners owe some back taxes and other fees, a contention the owners strongly dispute.
"Gambling is a business and if it makes economic sense, we'll go anywhere to operate," said Tom Gallagher, the executive vice president and general counsel of the Hilton Corporation. "From the early days, we've been concerned about the New Orleans operation because our numbers never were as good as we wanted and we worried about land competition down the road. I'm not sure what's next."
The operators of the half-completed land casino, Harrah's Entertainment Inc. and some local partners, have even more serious problems.
Not only are they being squeezed by cost overruns and huge payments on their debts, but as they seek new financing for the project, they are encountering resistance because of a promise they made earlier when they won their operating license. They agreed to guarantee the state a minimum $100 million tax payment each year of operation, even if receipts fell short and did not justify a payment that large.
"That promise is a big hurdle in finding new financing and time is running out," said Billy Patrick, the casino operators' chief lawyer. "The bankruptcy court wants some action by early November -- or else."
Might the state lighten up the terms of the tax payment guarantee? Or is that precluded by a growing frustration among Louisiana voters with the economic confusion, back-room dealing and rancorous wrangling that thus far has been the hallmark of gambling in the state?
"A guarantee is a guarantee," said Hillary Crain, chairman of the State Gaming Control Board. "When you face something like that, your best bet is to come up with some creative financing. It's up to them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Flamingo was among three floating casinos that have closed in New Orleans. High expectations for revenue led to high taxes, but the city never lived up to its early promise as a magnet for gamblers. (Alex Brandon for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: AIDS Drugs Elude the Grasp of Many of the Poor

SERIES: LEFT BEHIND: The Destitute

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
The doctor's chicken scratch is barely legible, but to Luis Figueroa the scribbles on the little white slips of paper are precious. They are prescriptions for powerful new AIDS medications that once miraculously revived Mr. Figueroa, who was so close to death last year that his parents brought in a priest in case he needed last rites.
But there is a problem with the prescriptions. Mr. Figueroa cannot afford to fill them, and the government cannot afford to fill them for him. 
 The three-drug cocktail costs nearly $12,000 a year -- a sum that is beyond the reach of Mr. Figueroa, an unemployed 33-year-old printer who recently moved here from Washington, leaving his health insurance behind. On a recent morning, he went looking for help at a social service agency for people infected with H.I.V., but he found little solace.
There, a counselor told him that the Federal-state partnership that pays for AIDS drugs for the indigent was broke in Florida, as it is in 25 other states. It can pay for two of his antiviral medications, but not for the protease inhibitor, the most powerful drug in his combination.
"It's a matter of waiting and hoping," the social worker, Gilberto Robledo, said as Mr. Figueroa tapped his feet nervously on the floor. Mr. Robledo told Mr. Figueroa that his name would be placed on a waiting list. He did not tell him that the Florida list had 600 names.
So did Mr. Figueroa fall through the cracks of the AIDS drug revolution, and he is one of many. It has been 18 months since protease inhibitors came into widespread use in this country, helping to transform AIDS from a death sentence to a chronic but treatable disease for many patients, Mr. Figueroa included.
But the new drugs are expensive, and experts say tens of thousands of people who could benefit from state-of-the-art AIDS therapy do not receive it.
The reasons are varied. Some people with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, do not seek treatment. Others have yet to learn of combination therapy. And because the protease-inhibitor regimen is complex -- up to 30 pills a day, some with food, some without -- some doctors are purposely withholding the drugs from unstable patients, fearing they will miss their doses and, as a result, help the virus become resistant.
But as H.I.V. continues to spread among the poor, experts say, the main obstacle is increasingly money.
"I call it the therapeutic haves and the therapeutic have-nots," said Dr. Arthur Ammann, president of the American Foundation for AIDS Research. "Anybody who walks into a pharmacy in a poor neighborhood and looks at the line of people who are trying to negotiate which drugs they can or cannot get understands this."
 
Longer Lives for Some, No Benefits for Others
The problem is generating a host of complex public policy issues as well as anxiety for patients like Mr. Figueroa, who is hoping that his doctor will persuade a drug company to give him the medicine free.
As word of the benefits of the new medications spreads, clinics are jammed with patients who, imbued with a sense of hope, are eager for the drugs. Many are poor, and many have shunned treatment in the past.
At the same time, the fact that protease inhibitors have helped keep so many people alive is depriving others of benefits.
Enrollment in the AIDS Drug Assistance Program, the Federal-state partnership that provides the drugs to the needy, has exploded with the arrival of protease inhibitors. The rosters in some states have climbed as much as 2,000 percent, said Richard Jefferys of the AIDS Data Treatment Network, an advocacy group in New York.
And as patients live longer, there is barely any turnover in the program. In many parts of the country, precious slots are full, and state officials, short of cash, are faced with a wrenching problem: whether to cover all the drugs for some patients or some drugs for all.
"People are not dying as rapidly, so they are not opening up spaces," said Dr. Patricia Hawkins of the Whitman-Walker Clinic in Washington, which treats and counsels people with AIDS. "There is so much hope in these medications, and then you have to tell people they can't get on it yet. It's very frustrating."
The problem is particularly acute in Florida, the state with the third-highest AIDS caseload, after New York and California. As Mr. Figueroa tries to remain calm -- "If I worry, I get stressed, and it's no good for me," he said -- he knows that the longer he goes without his medicine, the worse his condition is likely to become.
Other patients are growing angry.
"I feel stuck," said Mica Paris, 28, who is also on the Florida waiting list.
Ms. Paris was tested for H.I.V. as part of an outreach program run by the Health Crisis Network, the same agency where Mr. Figueroa sought assistance. Medicaid turned her down, and she says she has no money to fill her prescription.
"The whole purpose of me getting tested was to get treatment and help," Ms. Paris said. "I guess I'm not going to get help until I'm damn near dead."
According to the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 750,000 Americans are infected with H.I.V., and fewer than 1 in 5 of them have private health insurance. Roughly half are insured by Medicaid or other government programs, but 29 percent have no insurance at all.
 
'Greyhound Therapy' And Red Tape's Toll
Access to the drugs varies from state to state and even from county to county, contributing to what one expert called "Greyhound therapy," a tendency of some patients to move to where the drugs are.
If a patient and his doctor are aggressive, experts say, they can generally find a way to get the protease inhibitors through a patchwork of government assistance, clinical trials or, as a last resort, the pharmaceutical industry, which donates drugs through its "compassionate use" programs.
But sometimes the red tape proves overwhelming, and patients give up.
At the same time, drug companies, which say the high prices are necessary to recover millions of dollars that they are spending on research, are themselves feeling squeezed. They are inundated with requests from doctors and even state governments for free medicine.
The North Carolina drug program, for instance, closed to new patients at the beginning of October. And the Colorado program will run out of money in December, three months before the end of its fiscal year; after that, Colorado will ask drug companies to pick up the cost of medications for the 720 patients enrolled.
"We need to bear in mind that there are limits," said Joy Schmitt, a spokesman for Agouron Pharmaceuticals, which makes nelfinavir, a protease inhibitor. Another manufacturer, Hoffmann-La Roche, a subsidiary of Roche Holding Ltd., has closed its compassionate use program to patients in Florida, in an effort to press the state to pay for more.
"The state was zapping so many resources," said a Hoffmann-La Roche spokesman, Jeff Winton, that "some of the other states weren't able to put their patients in."
The Clinton Administration is considering a pilot program to expand Medicaid so that additional people with H.I.V. can get the drugs. Medicaid covers the protease inhibitors, but at present only people who are disabled by AIDS are eligible.
That policy flies in the face of what doctors know about the drug cocktails: that patients benefit the most when they begin taking them in the early stages of the disease.
"You've got to get yourself really sick so you can qualify to be totally disabled so you can get the medicine that might have been able to save you," said Dr. Hawkins, of the Whitman-Walker Clinic in Washington. "It's a crazy system."
It was into this bureaucratic netherworld that Mr. Figueroa plunged when he decided over the summer to leave Washington for a warmer region. His predicament illustrates the stresses that uninsured, often desperately ill patients face as they struggle to get medications.
Mr. Figueroa, who was born in Honduras, immigrated to the United States with his parents 11 years ago and worked as a printer. In 1989, he found out that he was H.I.V.-positive. His employer covered his medical care.
But in 1995 he developed AIDS-related pneumonia and had to quit his job. He has no idea whether he is eligible for Medicaid; he says he never realized that he could apply.
Instead, he sought help from a friend who owned a business and who included Mr. Figueroa in the company's insurance plan, as an employee. Looking back, Mr. Figueroa acknowledges that the arrangement was not quite legitimate, and says he was never comfortable with it. But he was desperate.
By February 1996, the normally stocky young man was thin and wasting away. His count of T cells, which are crucial to fighting off infection, had fallen to 7. A normal count is more than 500.
He did not have the strength to rise from his bed to go to the bathroom. Thrush, a yeast infection, coated his throat, making it impossible for him to eat. "Basically," Mr. Figueroa said, "I was dying."
Then indinavir, a new protease inhibitor manufactured by Merck & Company, was approved by the Food and Drug Administration. His doctor prescribed the drug in a cocktail with two other antiretroviral medications, and before long Mr. Figueroa had become another AIDS miracle, one of legions of patients whose health was seemingly restored by protease inhibitors.
His viral load dropped to 4,000 copies per cubic milliliter of blood, from 49,000. But by this summer, after he had spent more than a year on the drug, the numbers had started creeping up again.
It was about this time that Mr. Figueroa decided to move. The decision to give up his health insurance was not easy, but he feared another cold winter in Washington. He knew of patients who were receiving their medicine through government programs, and he thought he could do the same.
Had he moved to New York or California, he might have had an easier time. Those states, with the largest AIDS caseloads in the nation, have vastly increased their contributions to the AIDS Drug Assistance Program to cover all poor patients.
But Florida, which this year received $27 million in Federal money for the program, has not been so generous: the state contributes $2 million, while state health officials estimate the need at $12 million.
As a result, said Thomas Liberti, who runs the AIDS program at the State Health Department, Florida recently capped enrollment. Those who are already receiving the protease inhibitors may continue, but no new patients are being added.
"All you have to do is look at the math," Mr. Liberti said, "to know that we don't have enough money to go around."
That was a surprise to Mr. Figueroa, but it is no surprise to the doctors at the AIDS clinic at South Shore Hospital, the small community hospital in South Beach where he is being treated. About 85 percent of all the patients there lack health insurance. The Federal Government pays their medical bills with money from the Ryan White Care Act.
Most South Shore patients in combination therapies receive their drugs free from pharmaceutical companies, said Dr. Jose Hernandez, who treats Mr. Figueroa. But getting approval takes time.
"The patient has to go see his case manager," Dr. Hernandez said. "The case manager fills out the report. It comes back to me. I fill out my part. I give it back to the case manager. I'm writing prescriptions that I know are not going to be immediately filled."
Although his doctor is optimistic that he will eventually get the drugs, Mr. Figueroa is growing weary of the wait. It has been nearly a month since he picked up his prescriptions.
When he visited Mr. Robledo at the Health Crisis Network in late September, Mr. Figueroa says, he expected to receive his medication right away. He left three hours later empty-handed, with instructions to ask his doctor for a copy of the test showing his viral load -- the H.I.V. level -- and a letter explaining the need for the medicine.
"It's a runaround situation," Mr. Robledo acknowledged, "a back-and-forth kind of thing."
Early in October, Mr. Figueroa returned. He came away discouraged. He was not feeling well, he said, and was starting to worry about his health.
"Gilberto tried to help me," Mr. Figueroa said, "but we just filled out more forms. I have a cold, and I can't sleep thinking about all these things."
 
Left Behind
This is the last of three articles that have appeared since Aug. 22 on AIDS patients who have not fully benefited from the discovery of a powerful new class of drugs, protease inhibitors, that has revolutionized the treatment of AIDS.

HEADLINE: As Election Approaches, City Is Flush With Cash

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
New York City took in $150 million to $200 million more in taxes from July through September than officials had projected, which could allow Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to channel more money into popular programs in the weeks before Election Day.
The additional revenue in the first quarter of the fiscal year came largely from the same source that flooded the city's coffers with tax revenue last year: Wall Street. The city ended its last fiscal year with a $1.3 billion surplus because of a boom in financial services, providing a respite from the hard times early in the Mayor's tenure, when the economy soured and the city's budget suffered as a result. 
 The Giuliani administration had predicted in the new $33.4 billion budget that Wall Street would have an average year, an assumption that independent budget analysts called prudent. But this sector continues to generate strong profits, so revenue from income, business and other taxes are greater than projected, officials said.
There was some disagreement yesterday between the Giuliani administration and the Democratic-controlled City Council over the amount of additional revenue in the first quarter. The administration put it at $150 million, while the Council said it was $200 million or possibly more.
Whatever the figure, the extra money could be a boon for Mr. Giuliani and his re-election campaign. The Mayor acknowledged in an interview that he might use a portion of the extra revenue to finance new programs that he would announce before Election Day. But he said he would allocate the money judiciously, saving some to deal with the city's long-term financial problems, which include large projected gaps in future budgets.
"We will not do it in a way in which we will spend all of the surplus," he said. "At this point, that is not our priority. Our priority is to really point out how the policies and programs that we have put into effect are working better than people expected."
Aides to the Mayor's Democratic opponent, Ruth W. Messinger, accused the Mayor of pillaging the budget in recent months, seeking to finance programs to address what the aides said were deficiencies in his record. They asserted that he would spend any unexpected revenue from the first quarter in the same way.
"I wouldn't be surprised if the symptoms of incumbent-itis which he has so exuberantly exhibited persist between now and Election Day," said Leland T. Jones, a spokesman for Ms. Messinger. "He certainly has a bad case of it."
Mr. Giuliani had already taken advantage of the city government's relatively robust fiscal health by announcing some new programs. His anti-drug initiative, for example, is to cost the city at least $80 million that was not allocated in the budget that the Council approved last June. He would have had more difficulty finding that money earlier in his term, when he had to cut some programs and reduce the rate of growth of others.
Despite the good news in the short term, the city is still facing large projected budget gaps over the next few years, so any additional money that Mr. Giuliani spends will not be available to reduce the city's long-term fiscal troubles. In the 1999 fiscal year, which begins next July 1, the city has a projected gap of $1.8 billion between revenue and expenses.
The new revenue was first disclosed by Thomas L. McMahon, the Council's finance director, after he was asked for an evaluation of the city's performance in the first quarter. The administration then confirmed that revenue was higher than expected, though it issued somewhat more conservative figures.
According to the Council's estimates, the city received $45 million more than projected in the first quarter from the general corporation tax; $42 million more from the personal income tax; $12 million more from the banking tax, and $11 million more from the unincorporated business tax, which many small businesses pay.
It also reaped $175 million more from the property tax, though Council officials cautioned that about half of that stemmed from early payment of tax bills, so it could not be considered additional revenue.
Mr. Giuliani also said some of the new revenue may have come from early payment of property taxes. Even so, the city is doing better than it did last year, he said.
"This really allows us politically to say that we are right about the economy and budget, and Ruth is very wrong about it," he said. "She has tried to create the impression that the city is in some kind of fiscal hole."
But the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said the city's budget and economy are not as strong as they seemed. He pointed out that the city's unemployment rate remains stuck around 9.5 percent, about double the national average.
"The good news is that a strong financial services sector continues to drive our budget," Mr. Vallone said. "The long-term concern for both the economy and the budget is that we are not adding enough jobs for New York City residents. That is a serious problem that needs to be addressed."

HEADLINE: As Washington's Attention Wanders, Brazil Plays a Quiet Catch-Up Game

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Three years after he corralled other leaders in the region into charting a Free Trade Area of the Americas, President Clinton stepped off Air Force One tonight to encounter a far more worldly and assertive Brazil, posing the first serious challenge to undisputed American leadership in the hemisphere.
While Mr. Clinton has been busy elsewhere since the December 1994 summit meeting in Miami, where the free trade area was discussed, Brazil has been quietly playing a skillful diplomatic game, strengthening its own regional trade group, Mercosur, and building ties with the European Union and Japan as a counterweight to United States dominance. 
 "I think the U.S. Government is coming into an awareness of great change worldwide a bit late," said Amaury de Souza, a political analyst at Brazil's Institute of Economic, Social and Political Studies. Citing "a shift of power and economic relations going on worldwide," Mr. de Souza said that these days Brazil is seizing the opportunity to grow "not only economically, but to become an important player in international relations."
Behind the fanfare and the optimism surrounding Mr. Clinton's whirlwind appearances here in Brasilia, in Sao Paulo and in Rio de Janeiro, is the glaring sense that South America has been a sorely neglected backyard.
Mr. Clinton is the first President in a quarter-century to put off his first visit to South America until his second term. Political analysts here said that even though it now appeared that he might well win fast-track authority -- which would allow him to negotiate trade agreements that Congress must vote on without amendments -- little progress toward creating a free trade area is likely by next year's economic summit meeting in Santiago.
Argentina, where Mr. Clinton goes after leaving Brazil, has been without a United States ambassador for six months, and no one has been nominated. The American Ambassador to Brazil, Melvyn Levitsky, will be going home a few months after Mr. Clinton's trip, and no successor has been announced.
For much of the century, the only serious challenge to Washington's dominance in South America came from the Soviet Union. Brazil was easily overlooked. Despite a population of 160 million, abundant natural resources, and territory nearly the size of the continental United States, the old saw about Brazil's being the country of the future, though the future never comes, held true. Internal disarray characterized by a roller-coaster economy, a 21-year military dictatorship and weak government institutions kept Brazil from assuming what would have appeared to be its natural role.
To be sure, despite impressive starts in reforming primary education, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has made only slight dents in many of his country's deep domestic troubles: rampant corruption, unchecked burning of the Amazon rain forest, police violence, lack of a credible judiciary, labor conditions that are tantamount to slavery in some parts of the country and vast disparities in the distribution of land, wealth and power.
The end of 2,500 percent annual inflation, however, has taken some of the lunacy out of everyday life in the country with the world's eighth-largest economy and opened the way for greater trade and investment. In just two years, direct foreign investment in Brazil has soared from $1 billion to $16.5 billion, thanks largely to the privatization of vast government-run industries in mining, electricity and telecommunications.
The regional grouping's trade has grown to an estimated $17 billion this year from $6.2 billion five years ago. And Brazil has become an important customer to its neighbors, spreading its purchasing power around by buying $1 billion a year in oil from Argentina and another $1 billion from Venezuela, purchasing electricity from Paraguay and, in the future, Bolivia.
The trade grouping, Brazilian officials point out, has become an important stepping stone to free trade, opening Brazilian industries to limited foreign competition and broadening their markets. Riordan Roett, director of the Latin American Studies program at Johns Hopkins University's School of International Affairs, said that Brazil now is eager to leave itself a free hand in forging economic relations. But, he said, "The United States is still thinking back in '93 and '94, when it could dictate politics in the hemisphere. The U.S. just doesn't get it."
For the most part, the rivalry is being played out sotto voce, with occasional slips and indirect maneuvers.
One apparent slip occurred last week, when the Brazilian Ambassador in Washington, Paulo Tarso Flecha de Lima, was quoted as saying that Brazil would be "relieved" if Congress did not give President Clinton fast-track negotiating authority. The Ambassador later said he was quoted out of context. Nevertheless, the comments reflected the tone of Brazilian leaders in a series of interviews here last week, avoiding any claims to rivalry or leadership, while pushing forward their country's trade agenda.
President Cardoso appeared to soften Brazil's widely publicized push for a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council, which the United States has opposed. Washington favors expanding the Security Council, with a permanent seat for Latin America, leaving the Latin Americans to decide who should fill it.
"We are not anxious to have a specific seat at the Security Council," said President Cardoso. "What is important is to reorganize the whole international system." He said relations with the United States had never been better, though he added that with Brazil coming into its own, conflicts were inevitable.
American officials have diplomatically avoided public comment on the fate of regional trade organizations once the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas is built. But when pressed, they generally say that all regional blocs, Nafta included, would be subsumed by the greater Free Trade Area and follow its rules. Brazilian officials, however, make clear that they have no attention of letting the trade group disintegrate. To Mr. Roett, the wisest course the United States could follow would be to accept the Brazilian-led trade bloc.
"I really think we have to think of the Brazilians as the British thought of us at the turn of the century," Mr. Roett said. "They bet on us being an important country. We can't go on treating Brazil the way we treat Paraguay or Ecuador."

HEADLINE: Clinton Says He'll Win New Powers For Trade

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Oct. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton predicted today that he would ultimately win enhanced authority from Congress to negotiate free trade deals here in Latin America and around the world.
"It's a tough fight, but I think we'll win it," he said of the debate over whether his so-called fast-track negotiating power should be renewed. "It's a debate over principle with me." 
 He suggested that the country's international standing was at stake. "The United States has to send a signal to our allies, particularly in this hemisphere, and our allies in Asia and in Africa, that we know we are in a new world," Mr. Clinton said, "and it's a world in which we are interdependent."
He made the remarks on his plane as he flew here from Caracas tonight for the second stop of his Latin American tour, discussing his difficulties persuading Americans to embrace his vision of a hemispheric free trade zone, which he hopes to see established by 2005.
He said his visit to Venezuela showed that Democratic critics of his free trade goals, who worry that new treaties will not protect labor or the environment, could rest easy.
The Venezuelans, he said, "understand that they can't preserve their democracy in a free-market economy unless they try to strengthen their social compact." As a result, he said, "we're going in the right direction -- the direction the opponents of fast track want us to go in."
Working toward his goal of economic integration, Mr. Clinton spent his day, in Venezuela and then here, playing to local constituents by complimenting his hosts on their democracies and market economies -- as well as their music and baseball players -- while implicitly illuminating for his home audience the opportunities that await here.
Brazilian news reports have suggested that the United States still expects to dictate terms of its relations, rather than forge a genuine partnership. Almost immediately upon arriving here, Mr. Clinton tried to assuage such fears in an appearance with the Brazilian President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, at Itamaraty Palace, site of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. "Mr. President, as we reach for the future, America reaches out to Brazil with a hand of friendship and a pledge of partnership," he said. "We share a vision of a better tomorrow."
In Caracas today, Mr. Clinton was able to make much the same point against a symbolically potent backdrop: the towering tomb of Simon Bolivar, the hero of Andean liberation and democracy.
"Bolivar belongs to all the Americas," Mr. Clinton said. "He was the first to imagine a hemisphere of democracies, united by shared goals and common values."
In a further effort to play to the local crowd, Mr. Clinton experimented with Spanish, drawing giggles and applause from the crowds. "Todo esta chevere," he declared outside Bolivar's tomb, using a Venezuelan expression to say everything was just fantastic.
The cobbled plaza before Mr. Clinton, ringed with banners in the yellow, red and blue of the Venezuelan flag, was only half full, with perhaps a thousand people. Michael D. McCurry, Mr. Clinton's press secretary, said the Venezuelans allowed entry only to people with tickets, rather than to the general population as the White House had wanted.
Mr. Clinton repeatedly praised the Venezuelans for their efforts to open their economy, permitting private investment in nationalized industries.
In addition to an agreement to cooperate further in the war on drugs, United States officials signed an energy agreement today with Venezuela, which now supplies 18 percent of America's oil, more than any other country. The two countries agreed to exchange scientific and technical information and to conduct joint studies on energy planning.
Venezuela is expected to open its nationalized oil industry to $30 billion in new private investment in the next 10 years, and executives for American oil companies -- some of whom Mr. Clinton met with today -- are eager for a piece.
Venezuela is planning to double its oil production in coming years, to 6.9 million barrels of oil daily. The United States wants to increase its reliance on Venezuela's oil "to be less dependent on unstable parts of the world," in the words of Energy Secretary Federico Pena.

HEADLINE: Goldman, Sachs Invests Time in City Schools

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Thomas B. Lewis said he had butterflies in his stomach as the chartered bus snailed north from Goldman, Sachs & Company's Broad Street headquarters through Manhattan's traffic-clogged streets. As the bus fell ever further behind schedule, his butterflies started kick-boxing.
Small wonder: Mr. Lewis and 105 of his colleagues were on their way last Thursday to teach basic business concepts at Public School 98 on 212th Street, in a primarily Dominican area of Manhattan that is alien to most Wall Street types. And to Mr. Lewis, a managing director in Goldman, Sachs's equities division, dealing with billion-dollar transactions and millionaire clients paled in intimidation value to his assignment, which was handling 30 fourth graders. 
 But after a few minutes with Class 403, the butterflies were gone.
"With clients, you have to figure out how to speak their language, how to get things going," Mr. Lewis said. "It's amazing how much easier it is to connect with these kids."
Mr. Lewis is one of 2,000 Goldman, Sachs employees, from secretaries through investment bankers, who will each spend four hours this month teaching business and economics at 28 New York City public schools -- and, they hope, demonstrating to the students that successful business people are not that different from them. On Thursday, the Goldman, Sachs volunteers taught students in 55 classes at P.S. 98.
"This shows the kids that they are important," said Lisandro Garcia-Marchi, the school's principal, who said that more than 90 percent of his students are from low-income Hispanic homes. "It gives them a taste of what the business world is about and a sense that they can join it."
The teacher-for-a-day program is a combined effort of Goldman, Sachs and Junior Achievement of New York, which provided a curriculum for the volunteers that ranged from defining producers and consumers to explaining municipal government and calculating profit margins.
Usually, Junior Achievement volunteers sign up for a semester's worth of classes. But the organization has had little luck getting people to travel regularly to the South Bronx or upper Manhattan. Hence, this four-hour program.
"In a lot of these neighborhoods the most successful business person is the local drug dealer," said Peter Mertens, Junior Achievement's executive vice president, who encouraged the volunteers to talk about their own lives as well as teach economics. "Even a one-day visit shows the kids that not all successful white guys grew up rich, that women can get high-level jobs, that poor kids can have opportunities, too," Mr. Mertens said.
From classroom to classroom the volunteers doled out encouragement along with facts. Never was an answer wrong. What is a producer? "A singer," piped up one third grader. "Well, that's another meaning for the word," responded the stock analyst-turned-teacher, before calling on another waving hand.
The children absorbed a lot more than some of the Goldman, Sachs people expected. To make a profit in a yo-yo factory, you have to subtract the cost of wood, string and people from the price, right? Hands shot up. "What about the cost of electricity?" asked one youngster. "Don't you have to pay rent on the building?" asked another. And then, from a third: "My mommy works the second shift. What arrangements would the yo-yo factory make for that?"
In one sense, the lessons were universal business fare. "I learned how we get our resources," said India Dix, a fourth grader, "and how business means getting things from people who have them to people who need them, just like trading baseball cards."
Across the hall, Magda Suriel and Jason Jiminez, also fourth graders, were getting excited about faraway lands during a lesson on global trade -- even if far away just meant Utah. "I'd never heard of the Great Salt Lake before," Magda said.
But in another sense, the lessons were tailored to an urban sensibility. In May, about 125 Goldman, Sachs employees, including Jack L. Kelly, the company's conglomerate analyst, and David J. Kostin, its real estate analyst, tested the half-day format at P.S. 30 in the Bronx. In one exercise, they helped a fifth-grade class staff a hypothetical ball-point pen company.
As part of that lesson, the two analysts took roles in a job interview, with Mr. Kelly playing a high-school dropout who would rather play basketball on Friday than work.
"Most of the class agreed they wouldn't hire me for the obvious reasons," Mr. Kelly recalled. "But one kid, from one of the poorest families, said he noticed that I didn't make eye contact during the interview. That kid understood what we were doing, and realizes he has a shot at being one of us." The experience led Mr. Kelly and Mr. Kostin to lead the effort to sign up their research department colleagues for the trip to P.S. 98.
While the visits were aimed at opening new worlds to the children, they opened more than one pair of eyes at Goldman, Sachs to some new realities, too. First, there was P.S. 98 itself -- a newly spruced-up, sparklingly clean building, peopled with seemingly unharried teachers and well-behaved children, many sporting neat blue uniforms.
"With all this negative press about New York City schools, it's really impressive how interested these kids are in learning," said Mr. Kostin, who taught a third-grade special-education class.
Mr. Marchi, the principal, is hoping that the interest cuts both ways, and that Thursday was not a one-shot deal. "I hope we've established a link with them, that some will want to come back," he said.
If the aftermath of the May pilot teach-in is any indication, they probably will.
"One volunteer sent the school a set of encyclopedias, another took an entire class to see 'Beauty and the Beast,' " said Janice L. Moore, the Goldman, Sachs vice president who runs the company's volunteer program. "I really believe this group will stay in touch with the school, too."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas B. Lewis, a managing director in the equities division of Goldman, Sachs & Company, joined colleagues last week in teaching basic business concepts to students at Public School 98 in upper Manhattan. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)
