HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;
For Jackson and Bulls, One Last Mile Together

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE

 BODY:
David Halberstam asked Coach Phil Jackson over the summer about whether he could chronicle the Bulls' season. Jackson listened and said fine, but warned that a book written about Michael and the Miracles might be in direct competition with some of Jackson's memoirs.
It is not too early for Jackson to break out the quill and inkwell and begin "Dear Diary." 
 After all, as Jackson has said, the Chicago Bulls are about to embark on their last run. A basketball dynasty is a season away from expiring.
The season opener is still more than two weeks away and his team is going to Paris to play several overmatched European teams for the McDonald's Championship this week. Yet speaking to the national news media in a conference call yesterday, Jackson sounded more reflective than rejuvenated.
"We've had a run; it's been a great run," the Bulls' coach said. "We know we can't challenge Boston's incredible run in which they won 9 of 11 championships. But we know what we've done in modern-day sports is a pretty amazing feat."
Before Jackson signed his one-year, $6 million deal in July, he, Jerry Reinsdorf, the Bulls' chairman, and General Manager Jerry Krause agreed that Jackson would not return next season.
With Michael Jordan insisting he will retire if Jackson does not return, Scottie Pippen testing the free-agent market this summer and the Bulls thinking more about reloading than repeating, it is simply a matter of "putting the mantle down and handing it to somebody else," Jackson said.
"For the good of the organization, this team is going to have to move on and start building for the next century," he said.
Jackson took several subtle digs at Krause and Reinsdorf, making sure everyone knew that the fans in Chicago have questioned management's loyalty and commitment to winning in the present.
But he was more subdued and resigned to the fact that the Bulls, who have won five titles in seven years, will never be the same after this season.
Asked about Jordan's assertions, Jackson added, "Yes, I believe him and, yes, I will try to talk him out of it."
 
Attention All Agents
If the National Basketball Association finds itself in the middle of a labor war early next year, Billy Hunter wants to be prepared for the onslaught. Hunter, the executive director of the players association, has called for an agents advisory committee meeting on Oct. 24 in Manhattan to discuss strategy in the event the collective bargaining agreement is reopened in April.
Commissioner David Stern and the deputy commissioner, Russ Granik, reiterated the owners' stance at the league meetings in September: if the high salaries and economic inequities continue, the owners will exercise their right to reopen the agreement.
Twenty of the game's most prominent agents -- representing about 80 percent of the players -- have been invited by Hunter. The meeting will be the first serious attempt the players association has made at planning strategy.
 
To a Speedy Recovery
The worst-case scenario is said to be three months and the best-case scenario is supposed to be two months. But with proper rest and an aggressive rehabilitation employing every nouveau therapy available, Scottie Pippen may be able to return to the Bulls six weeks after undergoing surgery on his left foot.
Pippen had a soft-tissue arthroplasty performed last week in Manhattan by Dr. William Hamilton, who performed similar surgery on Charles Oakley in 1995. The surgery involves creating a new joint to replace a damaged or degenerated one between the foot and the toe.
 
Changing Places
Asked to comment on John Starks's desire to become a coach, possibly on the high school level, after his career is over, Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy could not resist a playful dig at his mercurial shooting guard.
"I just want to be a player on his team," Van Gundy said. "And I will torment him."
The coach added, "I imagine he'll let his players have more of a shot selection than most coaches."

In a Gesture in Ulster, Blair Meets With Adams
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain met with Gerry Adams, leader of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, in East Belfast, where the two reportedly shook hands. The meeting was the first between a British Prime Minister and a Sinn Fein leader in 76 years. A14 

Clinton Upbeat on Trade
As President Clinton flew from Venezuela to Brazil for the second leg of his visit to Latin America, he predicted that he would ultimately be granted enhanced "fast track" authority by Congress to make trade deals around the world. A6
 
Brazilian leaders have been strengthening their Mercosur regional trade group and building ties with Europe and Japan to serve as a counterweight to any potential American dominance in South America. A6
 
Inauspicious Vote in Cameroon
Government radio in Cameroon reported that President Paul Biya had been re-elected to another seven-year term with 80 percent of the vote. But few Cameroonians bothered to vote, and the West African country's three main opposition parties boycotted the voting after Mr. Biya's Government had refused to allow the creation of an independent board to organize the elections. Many citizens feared their country would join a regional trend of political and economic meltdown or enter a civil war. A3 
 
Prison for Korean Leader's Son
The scope of democratic change in South Korea was emphasized by the sentencing of a son of President Kim Young Sam to three years in prison for bribery and tax evasion. Lawyers for Kim Hyn Chul vowed to appeal, contending that the $6 billion he conceded to having accepted from business executives included no bribes. The sentence did not stir much debate because the President's term ends next year and he is barred from running again. A5

A Reversal by Italy's Far Left
Shortly after bringing down Prime Minister Romano Prodi's Government, Italy's Communist Refounding Party reopened talks that were expected to result in Mr. Prodi's being restored to power with his 1998 budget intact. The small party's gambit, to oppose further cuts to pensions and health care, stalled as a wide spectrum of Italians supported the center-left coalition's stoic resolve to qualify Italy for European monetary union. A10
 
Swiss Find More Accounts
Swiss banking officials said 4,000 more unclaimed accounts belonging to foreigners before and during the Holocaust era had been found in their archives. While twice the number of accounts discovered and published in July, these ones are apparently smaller, containing about $4 million. A list of another 10,000 accounts opened by Swiss citizens prior to 1945, some possibly as proxies for German and East European Jews, will also be published. A12

2-Tier Welfare System Blocked
A Federal judge has ruled that states may not discriminate against new residents by paying them lower benefits than long-time residents with the same income. His decision blocks Pennsylvania's use of a tool given to states by the 1996 welfare law. The decision has broad implications for other states that have adopted similar restrictions. A1
 
Executions Increasing in U.S.
Two decades after the United States Supreme Court reinstated the death penalty, states are executing prisoners at a steadily accelerating pace, and executions are spreading out from their traditional Southern base to states around the country. A1

The Bishop Estate, a massive $10 billion trust that dates to the Hawaiian monarchy, with investments from the Pacific Rim to Wall Street, is drawing unaccustomed scrutiny following allegations of self-dealing and financial mismanagement, among other charges, by its trustees. The sole beneficiary of the trust is the Kamehameha Schools, a 3,200-student school for Hawaiian boys and girls, but it is Hawaiians themselves who have become the most critical of the Bishop Estate. A1
 
Many Lack AIDS Therapies
Experts estimate that tens of thousands of people who could benefit from new state-of-the-art AIDS therapy do not receive it. The reasons are varied: the drugs are expensive and many people can not afford them; some people with H.I.V. do not seek treatment; the new protease-inhibitor regimen is complex, requiring up to 30 pills a day, some with food, some without; and some doctors are purposely withholding the drugs, fearing that unstable patients will miss their doses and the virus will become resistant. HEADLINE: In War Against No-Shows, Restaurants Get Tougher

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
THEY call. They reserve. They don't come.
It's the saddest story in the restaurant business, but it's getting a new plot twist. 
 In coming months, diners all over the United States may find themselves paying for their sins. Like a date who's been stood up once too often, restaurant owners are getting tough with no-shows. Some demand a credit card number to secure reservations for tables of six or more. Others require a deposit of up to $300 and a signed agreement. Now, upping the ante, American Express is going nationwide with a pilot program designed to fight no-shows by dangling the threat of a charge, just like hotels and car-rental agencies.
The American Express initiative, called the Guaranteed Restaurant Reservations Program, allows restaurants to impose a penalty of $60 to $300 on diners who make a reservation for a party of six or more and then fail to cancel the reservation by a specified time, or, Heaven forbid, do not show up at all.
The growing reliance on penalties opens up a new front in an ever-expanding war between shellshocked restaurant owners, who can experience no-show rates of 40 percent on a Saturday night, and outlaw diners who, in some cases, reserve tables at several restaurants, eat at one, and leave the other restaurants hanging.
Calls to 20 of New York's fancier restaurants revealed a variety of enforcement policies, ranging from the old-fashioned honor system to tough requirements for up-front money. The Union Square Cafe and Le Perigord, for example, simply take a telephone number and ask customers to confirm the reservation the day before. Other restaurants ask for a credit card number to hold a large-party reservation, but enforcement varies. Lespinasse takes a credit card number for parties of six or more but does not threaten any charge for a no-show. Montrachet takes a credit card number and will impose a $25-a-person penalty, but allows customers to wait until 4 P.M. to cancel a dinner reservation, or 11 A.M. to cancel lunch.
"It discourages people from making reservations at seven or eight restaurants and deciding at the last minute which one to go to," said John McFadden, the general manager of the River Cafe in Brooklyn, which takes a credit card number for parties of eight or more, with a $25 penalty for each diner. "It doesn't look good to have a large table in the middle of the room that doesn't get used."
Some restaurant owners say they use the credit card tactic purely as a psychological weapon, and do not really intend to impose the fee. Merely taking the number, they say, reduces the no-show rate.
But some restaurants want their money before the meal, and require a deposit of $200 or $300 before guaranteeing a reservation. Callers wanting a table for six or more at Le Bernardin receive a form by fax that asks for their name, address, telephone number, credit card number and signature. Callers must fill out the form and refax it to the restaurant, along with a photocopy of both sides of their credit card. A $200 charge is applied to the credit card and deducted from the bill for the meal. Diners who do not want to deal with a credit card can drop by the restaurant and leave a cash deposit.
Windows on the World, Palio and Les Celebrites also require a deposit for larger parties. Les Celebrites is particularly strict. It requires a $300 deposit for parties of seven or more, and reservations must be canceled at least three days in advance.
American Express has tested its guaranteed reservation concept for three years in two pilot programs involving 44 restaurants across the country, 11 of them in New York, including Aureole, Sign of the Dove and TriBeCa Grill. It is now making the program available to the more than 150,000 restaurants that accept its card. Although the company said it could not predict what the response would be, about half the New York restaurants in the test said they would sign up for the program.
The company zeroed in on large parties because an empty table of six or more causes the most economic damage and is the hardest to fill on short notice. The no-show charge shows up on the customer's monthly American Express bill. Unlike the airlines, which require documentation like a doctor's note before issuing a refund for an unused ticket, American Express has no formal policy on how restaurants should deal with diners who plead illness or an emergency.
Some diners shrug off the new requirement as a minor inconvenience or even welcome it as a way to get an iron grip on a top table, especially if it is out of town. Others rebel. "I've had people laugh in my face, scream at me, or simply say, 'I will not give you my credit card number,' " said Isma Pulaos, the reservations clerk at Aureole. "Most people are nice, though." Some restaurateurs say they suspect that the outbursts and the hang-ups come from diners who have been foiled in attempts to book multiple tables.
To punish or not to punish, that is the question, and it is a divisive one for restaurant owners. In its research, American Express found that owners split three ways when asked if they wanted a program that would let them impose charges on no-shows. One-third liked the idea, one-third hated it and another third wanted more information. At bottom, restaurants want to please, not to discipline, and the idea of slapping fines represents a cultural change that makes many owners queasy.
"Restaurants are not in the business of charging fees," said Lloyd M. Wirshba, the general manager for restaurants at American Express. "They are in the business of providing service and a fine dining experience."
"If I charged one of my customers $50 for a no-show, I'd never see them again," said Raymond Buckler, the maitre d'hotel at Felidia, who said the restaurant looked into the American Express program but decided not to sign up. "It's just not friendly."
American Express started its program after restaurateurs began asking for the kind of guarantees that hotels and car-rental agencies take for granted. In a survey of 1,200 restaurants in 1993, the company found that half reported a no-show problem. Of that number, 65 percent had an overall no-show rate of 10 percent, 15 percent had a rate of 20 percent to 30 percent, and 3 percent had a rate of 30 percent to 40 percent. The problem was most acute on Saturday night, with Friday night a close second.
Gordon Sinclair, the owner of Gordon restaurant in Chicago, had an epiphany about 10 years ago when he began adding up the cost of no-shows and found that the grand total was $900,000 a year, a figure that got him thinking, fast.
He made a change in the restaurant's procedure that underlines the curious moral status of a restaurant reservation, which is less than a contract but something more binding than "let's have lunch."
He instructed his receptionists to stop saying, "Please call us if you change your plans," and start saying, "Will you call us if you change your plans?" His no-show rate dropped from 30 percent to 10 percent. In other words, by asking a question and eliciting a response, he created a sense of obligation.
Ten percent still represents a lot of money, and the hard-core malefactors have proven difficult to root out. They will confirm, reconfirm and still not show. Hence, the American Express program. Under the plan, a restaurant agrees to put into effect the kind of record-keeping procedures that are standard at hotels and car-rental companies and that protect the card holder. Customers making a reservation for six or more people are told that they must use the American Express card and that if they cancel after a set time or do not show up, a per-person charge will appear on their monthly bill. Restaurants may charge either $10 or $25 a person, with a maximum of $300.
If the customer violates the agreement, the restaurant must send him a letter within 48 hours, stating that it intends to impose the agreed-upon penalty.
In January, 18 months into the pilot program, 10,000 reservations had been taken and only seven no-show penalties had been imposed. Although the program ran until May, Mr. Wirshba said the company stopped compiling data.
"For smaller parties, who are not guaranteed, we have a 15 to 20 percent no-show rate," said Henny Santo, an owner of the Sign of the Dove, which took part in the pilot. "For guaranteed reservations, we had a total of six no-shows in three years. The program brings the no-show rate down to zero, virtually. The downside is that it is very time-consuming on the restaurant's part."
American Express said the program, like the cruise missile, is intended to wipe out specific targets rather than wreak mass destruction.
"We believe that this is not going to be used for dinner for two on a Tuesday night, but on an as-needed basis in those instances where the no-show rate has been high, such as holidays and weekends," Mr. Wirshba said.
It may work out that way in most parts of the United States, but in New York, "as needed" means every day. Many of the New York restaurateurs who took part in the pilot program said they plan to use it routinely.
If parties of six require a deposit today, can parties of four be far behind? For the moment, it seems unlikely. With four diners, the trade-off between paper work and indemnity against a no-show becomes a different equation, largely because a popular restaurant can rely on walk-in business to fill an empty table for four. It has become quite common, however, for top restaurants to demand that diners call back and reconfirm the day before a reservation, and some call up diners themselves the day before.
For large parties, a new world looms, with a new etiquette. "Party of six? No problem. Would you like to apply for a reservation?"

HEADLINE: A Dissertation on Mr. Ed?;
New Scholarly Center to Study Pop Television Culture

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN

 BODY:
As a typically compulsive undergraduate at the University of Chicago, Bob Thompson used to allow himself just one half-hour of television viewing a week, on Sunday night. And no matter how hard he tried to watch PBS, he always succumbed to "CHiPS," the drama about California motorcycle cops starring Larry Wilcox and Erik Estrada.
This disturbed him. Why, Mr. Thompson, a budding political scientist, asked himself, do smart people love to watch dumb television shows? 
 From that query came a quixotic academic career. Now Dr. Robert J. Thompson, a 38-year-old Syracuse University professor, he is one of the nation's leading scholars in television studies, a relatively new and still formless discipline. This weekend, he will take charge of a new academic research center at the S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse, to be christened the Center for the Study of Popular Television -- emphasis on the word "popular."
Television, even television that appeals to the lowest common denominator, can still be great art, Professor Thompson contends, a sort of visually enhanced form of literature. Shakespeare, as people are so often reminded, was a popular artist. Jazz, once dismissed as popular, is now recognized as a discipline worthy of serious study.
Indeed, in a statement announcing the creation of the research center, the dean of the Newhouse School, David Rubin, declares that it will "study television entertainment programs with the same care and passion as musicologists study Mozart and Ellington, or professors of English study Melville and Pynchon."
Poppycock, some other scholars say.
"There's a fallacy there, in assuming that the common run of literature is comparable to Melville, or that the musical norm is comparable to Mozart's work," said Mark Crispin Miller, a leading media scholar who is soon to leave Johns Hopkins University to join New York University. "Those were the greats, who stood out. In the Renaissance, you'd have a hard time finding a play that's even readable other than Shakespeare's plays."
While conceding that the best television programs merit academic attention, Professor Miller said Syracuse's emphasis on the word "popular" concerned him.
"The fact is that most TV drama is esthetically appalling, and most TV comedy is too," he said. "For the most part it's utterly derivative, a pale imitation of whatever seemed to sell six months ago."
Such attitudes drive Professor Thompson to become "even more zealous," as he put it, in defense of his research. He calls such criticism "belle-lettristic apartheid, much of it plain old-fashioned cultural elitism," mostly from people who have scant knowledge of popular television.
"Just because television is filled with bottom-line-oriented profits and is generated by 500 people's hands, we shouldn't be reduced to silence about it," he said.
Professor Thompson in fact admires Professor Miller's work. But he said he believed that enough academic research was being done on subjects like television news coverage; television's influence on politics, violent behavior or sexual mores, and the economic forces behind mass media. What is missing, he said, is the "art appreciation" aspect.
"It is tragic and in many ways dangerous that we are so ignorant as intellectuals about a medium that has such a profound effect on us," he said. "How we perceive art and storytelling is infected and affected by the television era. Look at any modern novel after the year 1960 -- look at Don DeLillo's new book -- and you can't help but see how much television has moved in."
Horace Newcomb, a communications professor at the University of Texas at Austin who was one of the first scholars in this field, as early as 1970, agreed.
"Popular television has been the central storytelling system of our time," he said. "To say it's not important to study that is like saying one shouldn't have studied Dickens or Scott Fitzgerald. I happen to think fiction is crucial to people's lives, and if they're experiencing it this way, or through literature or the stage or the big screen, all are equally deserving of study.
As for Professor Thompson's own research, his most recent book was "Television's Second Golden Age: From 'Hill Street Blues' to 'E.R.' " (Continuum Press, 1996); his next, due next year, is "Good TV: The 'St. Elsewhere' Story."
"I think 'St. Elsewhere' is probably the best show ever on American prime-time TV," Professor Thompson said, because of the intricacy of its writing.
After switching from political science, his undergraduate major, Professor Thompson earned a doctorate in film and television studies from Northwestern University. He taught there and at the State University of New York at Cortland before moving to the Newhouse School at Syracuse seven years ago.
Along the way, he became convinced that "there was enormous vacuum to be filled" in terms of "inventing the discipline of television studies as a serious academic pursuit."
His dream of creating a center for such work was endorsed by Dr. Rubin, the Newhouse School dean, who helped raise more than $430,000 to start the new center.
 
Encouraging Books About TV
In addition to being a locus for scholarly research and teaching, the center will encourage publication of books about television by the Syracuse University Press, expand Syracuse's collection of scripts and videos, create an academic journal on television and continue an oral history project that Syracuse lured away from the University of California at Los Angeles.
That archive attracted the bulk of the center's financing, $300,000 from the Steven H. and Alida Brill Scheuer Foundation. Mr. Scheuer wrote a series of television and video guidebooks and was the host of a public television program, "All About Television," in the 1970's and 80's.
His patronage in this case benefits David Marc, who had been compiling an oral history archive on television pioneers who were Jewish and how Jewish culture was reflected in television. At Syracuse, the project is being expanded to capture as many early television pioneers as possible. More than 70 interviews are already on file, from Steve Allen to Betty White.
The question persists as to whether, aside from the nostalgia value, these people and the shows they worked on deserve academic study.
"Every new creative medium gets dismissed," said Robert M. Batscha, the president of the Museum of Television and Radio in New York, , which opened a branch in Los Angeles last year. "Film was dismissed, photography was dismissed, modern art, modern theater -- all were dismissed at first. When the Museum of Modern Art began to look at this new art form, nobody understood it. It took a while before the museum began to educate people. Then MOMA and the Eastman House did the same with film."
But, said Dr. Batscha, who is a political scientist and communications scholar, many of the country's most creative young people now go into television. And he said he believed that this trend might feel threatening to "the establishment, to people who have dedicated their careers to other art forms."
A pillar of the establishment begs to disagree. Stephen H. Balch, the president of the tradition-minded National Academy of Scholars, said it would take 30 or 40 years before scholars know what television programs are worthy of academic study. "With art, particularly the art we study in the academy, we have greater confidence in its inherent greatness by the fact that much time has passed, and many people have sifted through it, and still the appreciation for it continues," he said.
 
A Familiar Part Of Their Lives
Unlike most other art forms, television for most of today's students is a familiar and integral part of their lives. Professor Thompson sees in that fact a potential educational benefit.
"When I was at Cortland, I taught a course in the history of television from Milton Berle to 'The Simpsons,' and you can't help talking about all kinds of American traditions that go into that," he said. "You talk about 'The Beverly Hillbillies' and 'Andy Griffith' and you get into the celebration of the rural in American life, the emphasis on nature, from Thoreau to Melville's noble savages to Emerson's Walden Pond. Invariably, students would come to me afterward and say, 'Where can I read this stuff?'
"It's a connection for them, using television to teach the liberal arts notion that human endeavors are all part of a great cultural conversation. We turned them into good old-fashioned, critical-thinking intellectuals better than many English or philosophy classes were doing on that campus, because in those classes, they never felt invited into the conversations."
Dr. Balch called that theory "dumbing the intellect down," a phrase he attributed to Daniel Patrick Moynihan. "Rather than bring the students up to the level where an educated person should be," he said, "we're bringing education down to their level, and filling it up with things that are already part and parcel of their daily life, instead of with new challenges."
And Professor Miller, who has written in praise of Hitchcock as well as Shakespeare, could not accept Professor Thompson's cultural continuum argument.
"You can find some sort of tradition for any piece of garbage that's out there, whether musical or cinematic or literary," he said. "Everything has forebears. But to claim any meaningful connection between 'The Beverly Hillbillies' and 'Walden' is just silly."
Dr. Batscha, of the Museum of Television and Radio, admittedly has a different bias. But he recalled that at the turn of the century teaching popular novels was considered silly in an academic tradition that emphasized the classics.
"You wouldn't think of teaching culture in the United States now without studying the novel, or films," he said. "And hopefully a few years from now you wouldn't think of studying 20th-century culture without studying television."

HEADLINE: Restrain Inflation Genie

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Robert Eisner (Op-Ed, Oct. 11) misses a major issue in regard to inflation: inflation psychology, the greatest danger. I am in the real estate and construction business, which is highly sensitive to interest rates. I would much rather that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, tinker with interest rates in quarter-point increments to keep the genie of inflation psychology firmly in the bottle than take any chance that it gets out and be forced to go back to the days of Paul Volcker, when the prime rate was allowed to go up to 21 percent to get inflation under control. 
 In spite of what Mr. Eisner says, there are inflationary pressures in the economy. You have only to look around in daily life to feel this -- go out to dinner, go to the movies, fill the gas tank, buy a home or rent an apartment.
 
RICHARD N. FISKE
Cheshire, Conn., Oct. 14, 1997

LENGTH: 650 words

HEADLINE: A Rain Forest Imperiled

 BODY:
The issue that most Americans identify with Brazil -- the destruction of the Amazon rain forest -- did not occupy a prominent role in the talks between President Clinton and Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso. The issue deserved better, though neither man is comfortable with the subject. Washington still subsidizes logging in America's temperate rain forests. Brazil has abandoned some of its worst policies in the Amazon, yet it is not enforcing its laws and seems oblivious to a range of new and insidious threats from timber and agricultural interests.
The state of the world's rain forests is particularly distressing now that global warming has again become a major international concern. Growing forests help absorb the gases that warm the atmosphere. Burning those forests, of course, adds to the problem. 
 More of Brazil is on fire right now than ever before. The fires are not as widespread as they are in Indonesia, where smoke has spread to neighboring nations, nor is commercial logging the main culprit. Brazil's fires are largely the handiwork of agricultural interests that clear land for cattle ranching, with a modest assist provided by subsistence farmers who engage in small-scale slash-and-burn tactics. This year, cities like Manaus that have gone unscathed in the past have been blanketed with smoke. Manaus has also reported a 40 percent increase in respiratory illnesses.
The fires are increasing despite Brazil's efforts in the past few years to protect the forest. The Government ended its ruinous subsidies to the cattle ranchers, and now requires that settlers keep 80 percent of their land forested. Brazil has also set aside about 20 percent of the forest as parks, protected areas and indigenous reserves.
But the ranchers keep on burning, and the laws are not enforced. Brazil's environmental protection agency has only about 80 enforcement officers in the whole of the Amazon. Worse, Brazil's courts have ruled that the agency does not have the authority to enforce the law, which means that it cannot even collect the fines it levies. A bill giving the agency authority to punish environmental criminals has passed the senate and is now before Brazil's lower house. It is a bill the Amazon obviously needs.
Tough enforcement is especially important now. There could be a major drought this year or next, leading to widespread fires, if the climate-altering weather pattern known as El Nino strikes as expected. A graver danger may come from industrial interests. President Cardoso favors cutting roads and blasting waterways through large swaths of the forest. This could provide a new transportation network for big farmers who want to clear land to grow soybeans for export to Europe.
New roads could also lead to increased logging. Already companies from Malaysia, China, Korea and other nations, many of which use clearcutting in Asia, are beginning to log part of the forest. As these companies pave roads deeper into the jungle, cattle ranchers may follow. The roads may make clearcutting economically viable and tempt Brazil to sell off the rain forest for hard currency.
Although a muscular environmental agency is Brazil's most pressing need, it is not the only one. If Brazil goes ahead with the plan to improve Amazon transportation, it must simultaneously address environmental concerns and earmark more land for conservation. A worthy program to set aside indigenous areas, which both preserves the forests and protects Indian tribes, is only half-completed. Brazil must finish the job, which would protect 10 percent more of the Amazon.
The country also needs to develop zoning laws for the forests and to adopt sustainable logging practices. More broadly, Brazil, like the United States and Asia's forested nations, must abandon the view that the rain forest is only a commodity to be exploited for private gain.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Foreign and Fed Buying Aids Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Treasury securities advanced yesterday as investors returned from a long holiday weekend to find that overseas bargain hunters had pushed up prices.
Gains were extended after the Federal Reserve entered the market, buying Treasuries on what is known as a coupon pass. And there was buying on relief that the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, did not sound more inflation warnings in a talk at the annual monetary conference of the Cato Institute in Washington. 
 "In fact," said Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif., "Mr. Greenspan was probably telling the markets a whole lot more last week, that he will raise rates, but that the timing was not clear. There was nothing market-moving in his speech today, only relief that he did not mention tight labor markets again, which produced a quick spike in bond prices."
A survey from last week taken by Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, showed no significant changes in Fed policy expectations despite Mr. Greenspan's warnings, according to Kim Rupert, an economist there.
"A tightening is still not generally expected until the Feb. 3 and 4 Federal Open Market Committee meeting," Ms. Rupert said. "A move at the Dec. 16 F.O.M.C. is still a close call, with about 58 percent expecting no tightening."
The 30-year bond gained 29/32, to a price of 100 9/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 6.35 percent, from 6.42 percent on Friday.
Bonds were also buoyed when the Fed entered the market to buy securities. The central bank bought $1.4 billion of securities with maturities that ran from November 2002 through August 2027, in a process commonly called a coupon pass, which permanently adds reserves to the banking system without a change in policy.
Citing speculation that today's retail sales report for September may suggest the economy is slowing, some analysts said the Fed could delay any rate increase a little longer. Some economists are expecting that retail sales to be unchanged, after gaining four-tenths of a percent in August.
Tomorrow the Government is to release the Consumer Price Index for September, with the report expected to show a gain of three-tenths of a percent excluding volatile food and energy costs.
Ms. Rupert said the data on retail sales should be friendly, but the Consumer Price Index could be ugly. "If retail sales are soft and the C.P.I. later in the week does not surprise, the market could see a relief rally," Ms. Rupert said, adding, however, "It is doubtful whether the highs reached the day of the employment report on Oct. 3 can be revisited anytime soon."
Results at the Treasury's weekly bill auction, which was held yesterday because Monday was a Federal holiday, were called good, with the rate for a three-month bill going to 4.98 percent from 4.93 percent last week. The six-month bill rate also climbed, to 5.12 percent from 5.01 percent.

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Filing Off 4%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Personal bankruptcies fell in the third quarter as the result of an expanding economy and steady job growth.
The number of people filing for bankruptcy protection declined 4 percent, to 335,218, according to CDB Infotek of Santa Ana, Calif., which provides on-line access to records. In the second quarter, applications reached a high of 349,281. 
 "Since bankruptcies are a lagging indicator, we could see further declines," said Rick Rozar, CDB's president.
While the number fell, it was still up 9.7 percent from the third quarter of '96, CDB said.
In the 12 months ending on Sept. 30, bankruptcies declined the most in North Carolina, Iowa, Kentucky and Arkansas; they rose most in Utah, Maryland and New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Class Notes

BYLINE: By Ethan Bronner

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The concept of a new Middle East has taken such a thrashing in the past year or two that, when a glimmer of it appears, the natural tendency for many is a roll of the eyes. Lately, every time there is talk of the children of Abraham joining hands for a better future, someone blows himself up in a crowded market or bulldozers break ground on disputed land. Threats are voiced, guns are raised and hopes fade yet again.
But the eye rollers would benefit from sitting in on the weekly meeting of the energetic board of directors of what has been optimistically named the University of the Middle East. 
 At the meeting, typically held on Sundays around a supper table at an Italian restaurant in the North End of Boston, the skeptics would find Hala Taweel, the disarming sister-in-law of Yasir Arafat, breaking bread with Ron Rubin, an Israeli-American physicist. There are Camelia Anwar Sadat, daughter of the former President of Egypt Anwar Sadat, and Walid Chamoun, whose Maronite Christian family went to war to rid its native Lebanon of Mr. Arafat's forces in the 1970's, thereby helping begin a civil war.
At the meetings, the jokes fly, the camaraderie is easy.
The plan they share is this: to build, over the next 30 years, a university with campuses across the Middle East and North Africa to promote coexistence and economic development. The first branches would be in Israel, the Palestinian areas and probably Egypt. Students and faculty would be required to spend time at one another's campuses, bringing Israelis and Arabs, Christians and Muslims, into scholarly and social contact.
Elie Wiesel, the Nobel peace laureate, has written a letter endorsing the project, as has Lea Rabin, widow of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel. Diplomats from Spain, Japan and Britain have expressed their governments' support.
Peace through education may sound quaint in the rough-and-tumble world of Middle Eastern politics, but to the participants it is the most natural thing in the world. Many of them first came into contact with their putative enemies on a university campus.
"I had never had any real contact with an Israeli until I came to the Kennedy School at Harvard and 18 of my fellow students were Israelis," recalled Ms. Taweel, 32, the president of the board and a doctoral candidate in higher educational administration at Boston College. Her sister, Suha, is married to Mr. Arafat. "Not only that, they were all military officers. By the end of the year, we became very good friends."
Mr. Rubin, 27, who came up with the idea for the university after Mr. Rabin's assassination, said he first met Palestinians and other Arabs while an undergraduate at Princeton and decided that an academic environment was ideal for breaking down traditional barriers.
The project, which operates out of donated offices here with donated furniture and equipment, has raised $50,000. The plan is to raise $500,000 and begin feasibility studies in three countries and a pilot summer course in Morocco or Egypt.
"We hope to begin real classes in five years," Mr. Rubin said.
If it all sounds a bit utopian, it might be worth listening to Kanan Makiya, an Iraqi dissident author in Cambridge and a supporter of the project, who said, "Peace in the Middle East, real peace, will come as an effort of the heart or it will not come at all."

HEADLINE: 3 More Brokerage Houses Post Income Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch & Company, the Bear Stearns Companies and Paine Webber Group Inc. yesterday became the latest big brokerage houses to report healthy quarterly earnings on the strength of the bull market and record merger activity.
They join Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company; Goldman, Sachs & Company; Lehman Brothers Holdings; Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., and Smith Barney in reporting large gains. 
 Merrill, the No. 2 securities firm behind Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, said profits rose 49 percent. No. 5 Bear Stearns said profits rose 49 percent and No. 6 Paine Webber said profits rose 41 percent.
The rising demand for stocks coupled with low interest rates have encouraged many companies to raise cash by selling both stocks and bonds -- businesses that earn investment banks big underwriting fees. In addition, global consolidation in many industries has helped generate significant revenues for Wall Street firms that provide advice on mergers and acquisitions.
Merrill Lynch earned $494 million, or $1.25 a share, in the third quarter ending Sept. 26, compared with $331 million, or 84 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.
The results beat Wall Street expectations of $1.21 a share, according to a survey by I.B.E.S. International Inc. Nevertheless, Merrill's stock was down $1.44 at $75.56 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.
Merrill said revenues after interest expenses rose to $3.9 billion from $3.1 billion. The company said it set revenue records in commission, investment banking and asset management fees.
Merrill was No. 1 in the United States in merger and acquisition deals completed, with 30 percent of the market, and No. 2 globally, with 20.3 percent, according to the Securities Data Company, which tracks the performance of Wall Street firms. Bear Stearns earned $161.6 million, or $1.11 a share, in its first fiscal quarter ending Sept. 26, compared with $108.8 million, or 72 cents a share, a year ago.
The results were in line with analysts' forecasts of $1.10 a share. Bear Stearns stock was down 25 cents at $44.50 on the Big Board.
The company said revenues after interest expenses rose to $996.1 million from $688.7 million, led by gains in underwritings, stock and bond trading, and fees from mergers and acquisition advice.
Paine Webber said quarterly profits rose to a record $112.8 million, or $1.11 a share, compared with $80.2 million, or 79 cents, a year ago.
The results exceeded analysts' forecasts of 87 cents a share. Paine Webber's stock was up $1.5625 at $50.75 a share on the Big Board.
Revenues after interest expenses rose 23 percent, to $1.08 billion from $883 million, led by gains in the firm's brokerage, trading, asset management and investment banking businesses.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

G.M. Has Strong Profit, But Parts Unit Suffers
General Motors reported earnings above expectations, but the company's stock fell anyway as analysts focused on a deterioration in profitability at the auto parts division, Delphi Automotive Systems.
Delphi's profits were crimped as its customers, including the biggest, G.M., demanded lower prices. The results suggested that a planned spinoff of 20 percent of the unit might have to be delayed. Page D2. 

Another Weak Quarter for Kodak
Kodak, whose digital photography business continues to run up losses, said that its sales and earnings had declined for a second consecutive quarter. But the company had warned of the trouble, and its shares rose after the report. D2.
 
2 Phone Companies Are Spared
Sprint reported earnings below estimates, and Frontier, a smaller telecommunications company, said it would do so, too. Yet Sprint's stock soared, and Frontier's was unchanged. Why? Perhaps because both companies are now being judged more on their long-term potential and they persuaded Wall Street that they were on the right track. Market Place. D10.
 
Wall Street Pours It On
Merrill Lynch, Bear Stearns and Paine Webber joined the list of big brokerage firms reporting double-digit percentage gains in earnings for the latest quarter. D6.
 
Stocks Mixed on Earnings News
Strong earnings from the brokerage houses and from banks helped blue-chip stocks rise. The Dow industrials finished 24.07 points higher at 8,096.29. But worries about earnings for technology companies pushed the Nasdaq composite down 9.33 points, to 1,732.79. D10.
 
As trading resumed after the Columbus Day holiday, bonds rose strongly, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury dropping to 6.35 percent from 6.42. D20.
 
Toyota Hybrid Car Is Ready
Toyota rolled out the first gasoline-electric hybrid car ready for market, beating its rivals to a complex technology that offers better mileage and can run more cleanly than regular gasoline engines. D20.
 
I.B.M. to Revamp Its PC Business
I.B.M. will restructure its personal computer operations and could lay off or transfer hundreds of employees as part of an effort to halt the sales erosion of the Aptiva brand, which faces increased competition. D21.
 
Zell Cruise Monopoly Avoids Veto
A provision in an appropriations bill giving a monopoly on the cruise business in the Hawaiian islands to a company controlled by Sam Zell, the billionaire investor, survived a line-item veto by President Clinton. D22.
 
Oil Falls as Gulf Tension Eases
Petroleum prices fell sharply for a second day on reduced tensions in the Persian Gulf, where fears of a United States-Iran military confrontation had helped the energy market rally last week. D17.
 
Dollar Higher vs. Yen
The dollar rose against the yen, helped by a rally in Treasury bonds, concern about the fragility of Japan's economy and remarks by an influential Japanese monetary official who said he was satisfied with current exchange rates despite the yen's slide this year. D17.
 
High-Technology Playthings
As the price of computer chips has plummeted, interactive toys -- like "virtual pets" housed in hand-held devices -- have grown more popular. The M.I.T. Media Lab and four toy and entertainment companies plan a five-year research project to design more such high-technology toys. D10.

HEADLINE: Moody's Warns That New York State's Budget Could Spawn Gigantic Deficits

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 14

 BODY:
A major Wall Street rating agency is warning that New York State's budget, with its commitments to deep tax cuts and big increases in school spending -- and what the agency sees as a risky reliance on a continued bull market -- is a prescription for enormous budget deficits in a few years.
The report by Moody's Investors Service echoes criticism already heard from State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, independent budget watchers like the Citizens Budget Commission, and others. But the warning carries particular weight coming from Moody's, whose judgments are closely watched in the financial markets. The report is to be released later this week. 
 Moody's did not change its credit rating for New York, the lowest for any state, and it predicted that the state's finances will remain stable for at least another year, and probably longer. In other words, things are likely to remain fine past November 1998, when Gov. George E. Pataki will stand for re-election.
But the report criticizes the $67.4 billion budget negotiated by the Governor and legislative leaders, and enacted in August, for making five-year commitments to phasing in tax cuts and broad new education programs, which together will cost the state more than $6 billion a year. The budget allowed lawmakers to go into an election year boasting of the politically popular cuts and programs, but most of the bill will not come due until 2001 and 2002.
The report asserts that the budget includes "deep backloaded tax cuts and multiyear spending obligations requiring future, unspecified spending cuts."
But administration officials insist that the budget will not result in a retreat from the long-term commitments or in serious program cuts. The Governor and his aides have often noted that, defying doubters' predictions, the state has been able since he was elected to cut taxes and increase spending at the same time.
"We've been getting this kind of criticism for three years," said Donna Arduin, first deputy budget director. She noted that the first two fiscal years under Mr. Pataki ended "not just with balanced budgets but with large surpluses."
But that has happened during the historic Wall Street boom, which has sent the state's personal income tax collections soaring. Moody's, like most other budget-watchers, argues that the state appears to be counting on a continued bull market, despite the historic volatility of financial markets and the possibility of a recession over the next five years.
"If this level of growth and prosperity continues," said Robert Kurtter, senior vice president of Moody's for state ratings, "it is possible for the state to grow its way out of the long-term budget gaps, but that's not a prudent thing to plan on."
The reliance on Wall Street is particularly risky, the report says, because the boom there has masked sluggishness in the underlying economy, with New York lagging well behind the rest of the country in job growth.
But Ms. Arduin insisted that the budget does not depend on a continued stock market boom to remain balanced.
Moody's also took issue with the budget for increasing spending more than 5 percent, much faster than inflation, after two years of relative restraint with Mr. Pataki in office, and for increasing New York's debt load, already the highest by far of any state.

 BODY:

CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN
During a visit to the Summit Child Care Center yesterday, she spoke of her commitment to issues concerning women.

HEADLINE: Unions Flexing Muscles For McGreevey Campaign

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Hundreds of union members rallied at the foot of the State House steps today, cheering as their leaders vowed to unseat Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in what they say will be their largest political effort in decades.
An estimated 400 people, most of them state workers, cheered wildly as Mrs. Whitman's Democratic opponent, State Senator James E. McGreevey, took the stage. But the crowd's energy seemed to stem not so much from their support for Mr. McGreevey as their anger at Governor Whitman, a Republican who has cut the state work force by 3,300 jobs and hired private companies to replace some of those workers. 
 While several small labor unions have endorsed Mrs. Whitman, the spirited crowd today made it clear that it would be Mr. McGreevey who would soon benefit from the statewide unions' plan to run a coordinated "get out the vote" effort involving hundreds of labor volunteers and paid for with hundreds of thousands of dollars of union dues.
"The labor movement in this state has never been together like this before," said Charles Wowkanech, president of the state's A.F.L.-C.I.O. "And let me tell you something: On Nov. 4, we're going to have a Governor that the labor force supports."
While Mr. McGreevey basked in his labor support, Mrs. Whitman spent much of her day and evening courting women's votes. Tonight, 1,500 women paid $100 each to attend a fund-raiser at the East Brunswick Hilton. At the gala, the Governor recounted how she had delivered on her earlier promises to create jobs, cut taxes and make the streets safer.
"We've been trying to deliver on those promises," she said, "and we've been shattering the glass ceiling as we've been doing it."
Mrs. Whitman said that 37 percent of her political appointments were women. "I didn't appoint them because they were women," she said. "I appointed them because they were the best."
Earlier in the day, she went to a child-care center in Summit to highlight the endorsements she has received from women's political advocacy groups. She toured the center with United States Senator Olympia J. Snowe, a Republican from Maine.
Jeanine LaRue, the founding president of the New Jersey Women's Summit, said, "In record numbers, this Governor has appointed women to cabinet positions, exploding the myth that it's difficult to find qualified women to perform in high-level positions in government." The Summit had endorsed Mrs. Whitman's opponent, Gov. Jim Florio, in 1993.
Mrs. Whitman also received the endorsement of the Medical Society of New Jersey. It was the first time the group had endorsed a candidate for Governor in its 231-year history.
Mr. McGreevey started his day with a fund-raiser in Philadelphia and a speech at a breakfast meeting with 100 Jewish leaders from across the state in Livingston, before heading to the labor rally in Trenton.
In recent years, labor unions in New Jersey and across the country have become increasingly active in political campaigns. Organized labor spent millions of dollars across the nation last year, hoping to help Democrats regain control of Congress. In New Jersey, for example, organized labor helped put Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, just over the top in his race against Richard A. Zimmer for United States Senate.
Already, the Communications Workers of America Local 1032, which represents 2,500 state transportation workers, has paid for radio ads attacking Mrs. Whitman for cutting back on the maintenance of state highways and for hiring a private company to count state-owned billboards.
Other radio ads are likely, union leaders said today. But they said that they could not afford to pay for television commercials and that most of their effort would go into organizing volunteers to run phone banks and get voters to the polls on Election Day. National labor organizations are also lending support to Mr. McGreevey's campaign.
"TV commercials won't win this thing," Mr. Wowkanech said. "Our strength is here today," he said, waving out toward the crowd. "What you will see on Nov. 4 is the best labor operation the state has ever known."
Not all union workers support Mr. McGreevey. On Monday, the former president of the state's A.F.L.-C.I.O., Charles H. Marciante, endorsed Mrs. Whitman. Mr. Marciante said today that the Governor had helped workers across the state by creating jobs, especially in southern New Jersey, where a new $330 million tunnel and road project will soon be built in Atlantic City. The project, which will be partly paid for with state funds, will provide access to planned casinos in the Marina district.
Mrs. Whitman has also been endorsed by several smaller unions representing thousands of law enforcement officers, nurses and construction workers across the state.
The Governor says her 30 percent cut in the state income tax rate has spurred the state's economic recovery and created thousands of jobs. Indeed, the state has its lowest unemployment rate in seven years and its job growth is now outpacing that of New York and Connecticut.
But many of the state's new jobs do not pay as much as the manufacturing jobs that were lost during the recession. And a recent Rutgers University study found that the average wages for most jobs in the state did not keep pace with inflation from 1990 to 1995.
When asked why he did not support the Governor, Jim Marketti, the president of Local 1032, responded with a question: "She created jobs? For who? Hamburger flippers?"

Christine Todd Whitman, a Republican, reading to children at a day-care center in Summit. (James Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Newark Hopes for Revival Far Beyond Arts Center

SERIES: DOWNTOWN GAMBLE: A special report.

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
Gloria F. Cohn, a widow from Middlesex County, N.J., has not ventured into this battle-scarred city for years. But she recently sent in $108 for tickets for herself and her granddaughter to a series of Sunday afternoon family dance programs and plays in the heart of downtown.
The lure is the new $180 million New Jersey Performing Arts Center, a glimmering glass-shelled structure that is opening on Oct. 18 on a formerly desolate renewal tract in sight of the towers of Manhattan, across the bleak industrial flats and the Hudson River. 
 In one of the country's great urban gambles, Newark is pinning a good part of its battered hopes for a comeback on the arts, specifically on this arklike complex of concert hall and theater, rehearsal space and food concessions. Planners hope it will set off a downtown commercial and residential revival in a city still struggling to recover from the shattering riots of 30 years ago.
"Those who said the performing arts center could never be built are now squabbling over tickets," said Lawrence P. Goldman, the center's president and guiding force, who came from the vice presidency of Carnegie Hall in 1989 to steer the project through the crucial last eight years of arduous conception and on-time construction.
Newark is hardly alone in seeking a salvation through the arts. With mixed results, dozens of cities, from New York with its emblematic Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, to San Jose, Calif., have built or are planning major arts projects in hopes of improving civic fortunes and polishing civic images. Every one of the nation's 50 largest cities, in fact, uses the arts to support community development, the National Endowment for the Arts recently reported.
But Newark may be asking more of the arts than anyplace else. There is little new besides the performing arts center to draw people like Ms. Cohn downtown, although 85,000 people commute here each day for jobs and higher education programs. The city continues to suffer from a reputation as a dangerous place of intractable problems where each succeeding mayoral administration seems to attract its own Federal and state investigations.
Yet the smooth completion of the project and extensive efforts to knit it into the fabric of the city have raised hopes that Newark, using the arts to create a critical mass to set off further development, may finally be turning around. Significantly, the effort is being pushed not only with city, state and Federal money, but also by a loyal band of hometown boosters, powerful philanthropists like Raymond G. Chambers, and corporate citizens like the Prudential Insurance Company of America, whose fortunes have been bound up with the city's for 120 years.
"A city doesn't function if it's open only eight hours a day," said Arthur F. Ryan, Prudential's chairman and chief executive officer.
 
The Audience
Attracting Crowds, By Careful Design
Perhaps the biggest unanswered question is whether the arts center's audiences will come in just for performances and then head home again or be enticed to linger and spend money. To improve the odds, the arts center, paneled by its architect, Barton Myers, in pearwood that glows warmly through the see-through facade, was situated to foment milling crowds, a bustle that planners say translates to safety.
The design does not rely on bridges, flyovers or tunnels to channel pedestrian flow; from the renovated 1,100-car underground parking garage beneath Military Park, patrons will have to ascend to the street and cross to the arts center. Inside, in broad and detailed ways, efforts were made to attract and appeal to a wide spectrum of patrons. Bathrooms were tiled in interpretations of African kente cloth patterns. Moneymaking catering areas were included: the first bat mitzvah service has already been booked, for $10,000, for a board member's daughter, in 1999.
A new 10-stop, $1 bus loop was created, linking the arts center to attractions like the Newark Museum, the Newark Public Library, Pennsylvania Station and restaurant-lined Ferry Street in the heavily Portuguese Ironbound district. Streets and highways were festooned with hundreds of directional signs to prevent what Mr. Goldman called " 'Bonfire of the Vanities' syndrome," the terror of being lost in an ominously derelict neighborhood.
"This is the big idea: to change the way people think about Newark," said Mr. Goldman, 51. "It's not the place where you get your car stolen; it's where you go to concerts."
The programming, too, was blended to the presumed tastes of a broadly diverse audience of 4.6 million New Jerseyans within 25 miles of Newark, the Portuguese of the Ironbound, suburban professionals and inner-city workers, blacks and whites, serious music lovers and schoolchildren. Classical stars booked for the premiere season include Jessye Norman, Midori, Yevgeny Kissin, Andre Watts, the Tokyo String Quartet, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra.
The opening-night gala will feature the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, which is the center's resident company, the soprano Kathleen Battle, the American Ballet Theater and the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Savion Glover, Chita Rivera and others. The program will be taped by PBS for a national "Great Performances" broadcast, perhaps in February. The debut concert of the New Jersey Symphony on Oct. 21 will also be taped by PBS for national broadcast later.
 
The Plans
Sharing Hopes And Burdens
Like projects in other cities around the country, this one began with a study of the needs of arts organizations, commissioned in 1986 by Gov. Thomas H. Kean. After considering suburban sites, consultants at C. W. Shaver & Company recommended Newark, a decision lobbied for by the new administration of Mayor Sharpe James. The original plan for the 12-acre downtown renewal site called for three arts buildings -- a concert hall, a theater and a smaller stage for dance -- as well as a hotel-office complex.
Instead, the project was reconfigured as one building containing a hall of up to 2,750 seats, named Prudential Hall for its largest donor, a 514-seat theater endowed by the Victoria Foundation, and rehearsal spaces, community rooms and reception areas.
Mr. Goldman has taken pains to announce that any effort to win contracts through political connections would be met by disqualifications. In fact, nothing has emerged to cast doubt on the propriety of any part of the project, no small victory, perhaps, in a city where the top officials have frequently been tainted by scandal.
Of the center's $180 million cost, the largest share, more than $100 million, came from the state, with the city giving $10 million, the Federal Government almost $5 million, and corporations, individuals and foundations contributing $20 million, $18 million and $15 million respectively. The $180 million includes $6 million of the first season's $20 million operating budget that is not covered by projected revenues from ticket sales, parking, concessions and gift shop purchases. The $20 million is the seventh largest arts center operating budget in the country.
A week before the opening, the center had sold nearly 91,500 individual and subscription tickets of the 350,000 available for the season through June, Mr. Goldman said, although not all the performances had yet been put on sale. The symphony in particular has benefited, with subscription sales nearly quadrupling to 10,000 from last year, when it performed in Symphony Hall, a former 1920's Shriners' temple on Broad Street in a frayed part of town.
Mayor James said the success stands to reason. "We have the best mousetrap, and when you build the best mousetrap, people will come," he said.
But others have their doubts. One persistent skeptic has been Msgr. William Linder, director of the New Community Corporation, a nonprofit public development effort that has built 3,000 units of housing in Newark since 1973. "It's taking a lot of resources," he said of the arts center, contending that the $180 million might have been better spent on neighborhoods and on the city's schools, which have been taken over by the state after persistently poor performance.
 
The City
Hoping the Glow Will Radiate
David Nasaw, chairman of the history department at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York in Manhattan and an expert on urban entertainment, said that whether the center fostered further development depended on its environment.
"What's around it?" he asked. "If nothing, nothing's going to happen."
For now, the landscape around the arts center is bleak, a vista of parking lots and yawning open tracts an uninspiring 10-minute walk from Pennsylvania Station and the Gateway Towers office complex that marks the very heart of downtown.
Still, Charles F. Cummings, assistant director for state outreach at the Newark Public Library, and the city historian, said: "I feel the electricity. I'm not a civic booster. I'm a historian, and I can tell the difference between truth and farce."
One truth, say city officials, is that crime is down, as elsewhere in the country. The drop in crime here has been 17 percent over the last two years, they said, adding that car theft, in which Newark long led the nation, has particularly plummeted in response to a police crackdown.
There have been some promising signs of downtown real estate activity, although some projects would probably have gone ahead anyway without the promise of the center. Within half a mile, at Broad and Bridge Streets, the city has committed itself to building a new $22 million minor league baseball stadium of 6,000 seats for its revived Newark Bears. Nearer by, Rutgers University recently broke ground for a new $55 million law school building.
Some long-empty landmark buildings may also be stirring to life. Miles Berger, a developer who began assembling a portfolio of venerable downtown properties before the arts center took form, said he planned to put a 200-car garage in the basement of the former Hahne's department store, dating from 1901, and remodel the upper four floors for retail, office and perhaps residential use.
"We already see what the art center can do here," he said, citing the excitement of a pre-opening street party. "Crowds like that haven't been in Newark on a Sunday in 30 years."
The challenge of reviving Newark becomes clear within blocks of the old commercial hub at Broad and Market Streets, itself a pentimento of urban decline. Along Broad Street, near the incongruously gilded dome of the Beaux-Arts City Hall, stands the shell of Newark Renaissance Mall, mired in bankruptcy and illusory as the 121-story building that its developer, Harry Grant, promised Newark more than a decade ago before dropping out of sight. Steel-shuttered liquor stores, furniture-for-credit outlets and storefront churches line the forlorn grid of streets off Springfield Avenue.
It was here, starting on July 12, 1967, that long simmering racial grievances boiled over at the sight of two white police officers dragging a black cabdriver into a Central Ward precinct house. For the next five days, rioters battled more than 6,000 National Guard troops and state police officers in one of the deadliest outbreaks in the nation's summer of violence. Twenty-six people died here, hundreds were injured and 1,500 were arrested before order was restored.
The psychic damage ran deep, a harsh blow for a once thriving city known for its industrial muscle and swinging jazz clubs. The population, which stood at just over 400,000 in 1967 dwindled over the years by almost 150,000, as blacks and whites decamped for suburbia. Today, Newark's population is about 58 percent black, according to city figures, and the fastest-growing ethnic group is Hispanic.
 
The Inspiration
Following the Lead Of Other Cities
For inspiration on renewal in recent years, Newark looked principally to Cleveland and Pittsburgh, two former industrial engines that had fallen into decline and cast their hopes on a cultural renaissance.
In Cleveland, the first American city to go bankrupt since the Depression, the downtown revival began slowly in the 1970's thanks to the Playhouse Square Foundation. It refurbished three 1920's theaters into a new performance center that soon drew other arts groups into its orbit, including, today, the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame and the Great Lakes Science Center, as well as a Riviera of shops and cafes on the once dispiriting Cuyahoga River waterfront.
Pittsburgh, having suffered the decline of its steel industry, followed a similar trajectory, with the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust kicking off a revival by purchasing an old movie palace. Converted into the Benedum Center for the Performing Arts, it became, in 1987, the $42 million home for the city's ballet, theater and opera companies.
Closer to home, the Brooklyn Academy of Music is shoring up its long-depressed Fort Greene neighborhood. For years, arts-savvy New Yorkers thronged to the academy's Next Wave productions, then streamed home again. Now, however, two fancy new restaurants are being planned, a shopping mall called Atlantic Center is flourishing, and a development corridor has begun to grow toward the Metrotech commercial complex about five blocks away in downtown Brooklyn.
Harvey Lichtenstein, the academy's president, said Newark might succeed faster, because "they have the whole city behind them."
His only advice, he said, is to be progressive and "establish an identity," not just present what others do. "Do things that bring in younger groups," he said. "Keep alive."
The regenerative power of arts projects has not been lost on other cities. But not all projects have been unmitigated successes.
"It fails when cities just declare an artificial art district," said Samina Quraeshi, former head of the design program of the National Endowment of the Arts and now a consultant in Boston.
What are Newark's chances?
"We Are Building It, They Will Come," read the T-shirts of construction workers putting the final touches on the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. But will they?
One market singled out is the thriving Portuguese community along Ferry Street in the rail-encircled district known as the Ironbound, south of the arts center. Planners hope that the new bus loop will bring patrons of the street's many Portuguese restaurants the half mile or so to the arts center, in part through ethnic programming like the Gulbenkian Orchestra of Portugal and the mournful Cape Verdean singer Cesaria Evora. But Licinio Cruz, a Portuguese lawyer and contractor is skeptical. "I don't know," he said. "Portuguese are not art center types."
Gloria Cohn, too, is taking a cautious approach. The 71-year-old widow from Monroe Township, N.J., said she had not had an opportunity to take the hour's drive to Newark in many years. When she and her granddaughter attend those Sunday-afternoon performances, "we may go in a little early and go to one of the restaurants on the premises," she said. "And then we'll probably go home right afterwards."
Emanuel S. Kan of Teaneck said, "I'll still go to New York for the plays." But he expects to spend plenty of time at the new center, he said. He not only bought tickets for six musical performances with his wife, Helen Karls-Ruher, but invested $10,000 in bonds that financed the center's construction. For Mr. Kan, 70, who is president of Olde Dutch International, a decorative housewares company in Saddle Brook, there are no compunctions about visiting Newark. The couple already dine regularly in the Ironbound.
Earl D. Shaw, a physics professor at the Rutgers-Newark campus, and his wife, Erin, a state employee, had no qualms about signing up with friends for a six-show dance series at $170. Mr. Shaw, 60, said he felt comfortable downtown and often met his wife after work for dinner in the Ironbound before returning to their home in Harding Township in Morris County.
"I am an emotional supporter of this project," Mr. Shaw said. "I have great hopes for Newark, and I am hoping the center will have the kind of success that Newark deserves and needs. The riots were 30 years ago. It's time to move beyond that."
 
A Hall for Newark

HEADLINE: AIDS Experts Leave Journal After Studies Are Criticized

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
Two internationally recognized AIDS experts are resigning from The New England Journal of Medicine's editorial board over the content and handling of articles criticizing the ethics of Federally financed studies of AIDS treatments in third-world countries.
The countries seek a drug regimen less costly than those used in the United States to thwart transmission of the AIDS virus from mothers to infants. In trials involving more than 12,000 infected pregnant women in Africa, Thailand and the Dominican Republic, some women receive the drug AZT, which has worked in studies in the United States, while others receive dummy pills. 
 The journal's attack on the studies, which compares them to the infamous Tuskegee experiment, has led to wide discussion, including harsh criticism of the journal itself, and focuses attention on the role of the 25-member board and the two who are resigning in protest, Drs. David Ho and Catherine M. Wilfert. The two objected to not being consulted before publication of an attack on research that could save lives, and Dr. Ho worried that the attack itself could jeopardize future research on experimental AIDS vaccines.
Dr. Jerome P. Kassirer, the journal's chief editor, said that the board's function was to give advice on broad issues and suggestions of authors for editorials and reviews, but that the board was not routinely consulted.
Dr. Ho, a virologist at the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center in Manhattan, and Dr. Wilfert, a pediatrician at Duke University in Durham, N.C., are the board's chief advisers on AIDS.
A third board member, Dr. Richard P. Wenzel, chairman of medicine at the Medical College of Virginia in Richmond, said in an interview that he agreed with much of Dr. Wilfert's criticism but was withholding a decision about resigning until after the issue was discussed at the board's annual meeting in December.
Drs. Ho and Wilfert said in separate interviews that they had resigned independently largely because the journal had not consulted them before publishing an editorial that likened the new experiments to the Tuskegee experiment, in which poor black men suffering from syphilis were left untreated.
Dr. Ho, Dr. Wilfert and others have taken issue with the Tuskegee comparison in part because the subjects in the AZT studies were told that some would get dummy pills. In the Tuskegee study the men were not told that penicillin had became available while the study was under way, and so did not know that effective treatment was being withheld.
A full-time staff of editors produces the weekly journal, but Dr. Ho said that "the reason you have an editorial board to help with policy is to get some input when you have major issues like this one, and that clearly did not take place."
In the editorial process, "it was clear that my role was not crucial," he said.
Dr. Ho said he was deeply concerned about how the critical editorial would affect the future of studies to evaluate experimental AIDS vaccines in developing countries.
Dr. Wilfert said she was resigning because the journal published the editorial and another critical article on Sept. 18 without presenting the other side.
Because her name was on the masthead, "it implied that I agreed with it when I didn't," she said.
"It is an error and bad policy" and "a grievous misuse of the journal's power," Dr. Wilfert said.
"Those are not decisions that a few people in the editorial office ought to feel comfortable with, because no one small group of persons, no matter who they are, can cover the waterfront well enough" in translating health policy and practice in developed countries to those in developing countries, Dr. Wilfert said.
Dr. Wilfert said she was resigning effective Dec. 31 in order to "vent my spleen" at the annual meeting. She said she feared that if she resigned sooner "the issue might not be discussed at the meeting."
The journal published a rebuttal two weeks after its attack. It was written by Dr. Harold Varmus, the head of the National Institutes of Health, and Dr. David Satcher, the head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and would not have been printed so quickly had not Dr. Varmus received a leaked copy of the editorial before publication, those involved in the dispute said.
Dr. Marcia Angell, the journal's executive editor, wrote the editorial.
Dr. Wenzel said that if the authors of the critical articles "really knew the facts they would have done a better job."
Dr. Kassirer said he regretted Dr. Ho's and Dr. Wilfert's decisions to resign and was unaware of any similar resignations at the journal, which was founded in 1812.
The editorial board members, who have no set term, Dr. Kassirer said, are named by the chief editor, who can elect not to renew them as members and has done so.
Dr. Kassirer said that Dr. Wilfert "wanted to have prior consultation of the material in the journal, which is just not acceptable to me because prior consultation is not what the editorial board is for."
He said the journal intentionally did not strive to present all sides of an issue "because if you did you would end up with a kind of Talmudic discussion in which readers could end up having no particular view one way or the other and it would be rather boring."
Dr. Varmus, the National Institutes of Health director, said that "The New England Journal of Medicine is trying to attract more attention by making political, ethical, philosophical and economic statements that have traditionally not been in that journal in such an inflammatory way."
But he also said that "before you inflame the public and attract so much attention, you might want to ask experts on the editorial board what they think."
The Massachusetts Medical Society owns The New England Journal of Medicine. Dr. Ronald A. Arky, a Harvard Medical School professor who heads the society's publications committee to which Dr. Kassirer reports, said he learned of the resignations last Friday.
"The committee will want to hear from the editor about the resignations" at their next meeting in early November, Dr. Arky said.
