HEADLINE: Council Votes to Increase Fines Sharply for Excessive Noise

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY

 BODY:
For New Yorkers who have long complained about noisy nightclubs, jackhammers on overtime, shrieking car alarms and howling dogs, the City Council offered a remedy yesterday that members said they hoped would provide more relief than even a good set of earplugs.
Calling their measure a quality-of-life victory that should lower the volume in many neighborhoods, Council members voted to double and triple the fines handed out to repeat offenders among the city's noisemakers. 
 A dog that will not stop barking could cost its owner up to $525, while the proprietor of a noisy bar could face a $24,000 fine after repeated violations of the city's noise code.
Bar and cabaret owners said the increased fines were onerous and could sound the death knell for many businesses. Some Council members opposed the measure, saying it was too broad and could result in unfair summonses.
But residents of some of New York's noisiest neighborhoods said it might provide a chance for them to get a good night's sleep. Rhonda Santamour, who lives on the Upper East Side, said there were nights when music from a bar across the street was so loud that "it's as if the drummer was in my living room up here on the seventh floor."
The bill, which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to sign, increases fines for repeated noise violations. The code covers noise offenses that range from barking dogs and cranked-up stereos to motorcycle exhaust pipes and thumping music from dance clubs.
Fines for first-time violators will remain the same, but for repeat offenders, the fine would double for a second violation and triple for a third or subsequent violation.
The law will continue to be enforced by inspectors from the Department of Environmental Protection and police officers, who respond to citizen complaints and measure noise levels with noise meters.
"New York City is never going to be a sleepy town where you hear the crickets chirping," said Councilman A. Gifford Miller, who introduced the bill and drafted it with the Department of Environmental Protection. "But I think we can make it a little quieter, a little saner."
Mr. Miller, who represents part of Manhattan's Upper East Side, said his office had fielded numerous complaints from residents who were fed up with noise from local bars and large heating and air-conditioning units that emit loud hums.
Mr. Miller said that many businesses consider the existing fines a cost of doing business but that he hoped the higher fines would encourage businesses to address complaints seriously and pay for necessary renovations to insulate neighbors from the noise.
Christine Pellicano, who in the last decade has watched her neighborhood at Second Avenue and 89th Street evolve from a relatively quiet residential area to a booming bar scene, applauded the bill.
Ms. Pellicano said she hoped that the higher fines would force bars to lower the volume and eventually defuse some of the rowdiness that spills onto the sidewalk.
"I don't think people really grasp the severity of this," she said. "We're not just saying 'shush!,' like we're in a library, because it's not just the noise that's a problem, it's the crowds that it generates and the kind of environment that it creates."
Mike Cafey, the manager of Kelly's Korner, a bar down the street from Ms. Pellicano's home, said the increased fines could shut down small businesses like his. "In order to keep people here and have a good time, you've got to have music," he said. "This is just going to kill business."
Members of the New York Nightlife Association, a coalition of about 50 licensed cabarets and music clubs, said they objected to the bill because it did not differentiate between clubs in residential areas and ones in manufacturing or commercial areas.
"We're not saying nightclubs should be exempt from noise codes," said Robert Bookman, the association's lawyer. "But there has to be a certain amount of tolerance to industries that are important to New York's economy. The city that never sleeps gets its name from licensed nightclubs."
Mark Linial, the owner of Reminisce Bar and Lounge at 73d Street and Second Avenue, said he feared that the new law would "give people a simple way to make a complaint about us even if the complaint has nothing to do with the noise level."
Ms. Santamour, who lives on 73d Street across from Reminisce, said that the bar's managers had been dismissive about her complaints and that she had filed a formal complaint with the city.
She said she had high hopes for the increased fines. "If the pocketbook is where it hurts, then that's what we have available to us," she said. "I think it's a great start."
Mr. Linial said he had spent more than $25,000 on soundproofing measures, like hanging a floating ceiling and installing insulated doors. "This law gives people who are out to hurt us, people who maybe just don't like the kind of people who come to our reggae parties, a new weapon," he said.
The noise code generally limits construction noise to daylight hours, except in emergency situations. It also specifies that burglar alarms must stop ringing after 15 minutes and car alarms should wail for no more than 5 minutes.
The Council voted, 44 to 4, for the higher fines, which will take effect 60 days after the Mayor holds a public hearing and signs the bill. The members who voted against the bill were Herbert E. Berman, Stephen DiBrienza, Una C. Clarke and Annette M. Robinson, all from Brooklyn.
Mr. Berman said he felt the bill was oppressive because it encompassed some situations that could not be helped, such as car alarms that sound off when the owners are not nearby.
"We can't guarantee people that their cars won't be broken into, but now we're going to punish people for trying to protect their cars," he said.
Ms. Robinson said she feared that selective enforcement would unfairly target businesses in her district, which includes Bedford Stuyvesant and Crown Heights.
Who determines what's excessive?" she said. "Standards sometimes can vary based on culture and I'm worried about inspectors or police officers who aren't familiar with the community practicing unequal distribution of the fines."
Randy M. Mastro, Deputy Mayor for Operations, said fears about uneven enforcement were unfounded. "This is an important quality-of-life issue and we intend to fairly, responsibly and comprehensively enforce the law throughout the city."

HEADLINE: Teamsters' Union Staff Members Cite Pressure For Donations

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Several members of the teamsters' union told a Congressional subcommittee today that union officials engaged in an array of questionable tactics to help re-elect President Ron Carey, including pressuring union staff members to make donations to his campaign.
Three staff organizers for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters testified that they were pressured to give more than $1,000 each last year to the Carey campaign or face possible loss of their jobs. Describing another practice barred by Federal labor law, a teamsters' member from Texas said he saw a half-dozen staff organizers doing campaign work for Mr. Carey during their regular work hours. 
 Vincent R. Hickman, a staff member in the union's airline division, said he was asked to donate $100 a month. "I didn't appreciate being told how much I had to donate, but I didn't say anything because of the fear of retaliation, and of course I needed my job." he said.
Although accusations of improper fund-raising have swirled around the election of Mr. Carey almost from the moment he defeated James P. Hoffa, the statements by the three aides today mark the first time union members have testified publicly that they were pressured to donate to Mr. Carey's campaign. Labor experts said it was common for union officials to urge staff members to contribute to their campaigns. These experts noted that last year's teamsters' campaign was by far the most expensive in union history.
At the hearing of the oversight subcommittee of the House Committee on Education and the Workforce, Republican lawmakers sought to explore improprieties in last year's teamsters' election that went beyond the much-publicized diversion of money from the union's treasury into Mr. Carey's campaign.
For much of the hearing, Representative Peter Hoekstra, the Michigan Republican who heads the subcommittee, faulted the Federal Government for failing to adequately supervise the election, conducted with $17 million in Federal money.
The Government agreed to finance the 1996 election as part of its long-standing effort to make the teamsters' union more democratic and eliminate mob influence.
In August, a Federal election overseer ordered a new election because of improper fund-raising for Mr. Carey's campaign.
Nancy Coleman, a teamsters' spokeswoman, called the Congressional hearing an effort to discredit the labor movement. "This is a circus for anti-labor Republicans," she said. "I felt there was an unfounded understanding by these people that if they didn't give money, they'd be retaliated against. That's ridiculous, because none of these people have been retaliated against."
But Barbara Dusina, an organizer with the teamsters, asserted that she has not received a raise recently because she donated less to the Carey campaign than she had been asked. Ms. Dusina said she contributed $50 a month, even though she had been urged to give $100 a month as well as pay $250 for a fund-raiser and $150 for a Carey rally.
"There was an unspoken message that if any staff person did not contribute, they would be unemployed after a Carey victory," she said.
The union released a letter sent by Mr. Carey to Rep. Hoekstra, that said, "If these people say that they fear retaliation, they are not telling the truth -- and it calls into question the reliability of any information they could give your subcommittee."
Another subcommittee witness, Dane Passo, a Chicago truck driver, testified that he was was badly beaten by a Carey supporter who operates runs a large teamsters' local in Chicago. Mr. Passo faulted Mr. Carey for not removing that official from office. Teamsters' leaders said Mr. Carey was waiting for the official to exhaust appeals of his assault and battery conviction.
To end the four-and-a-half hour hearing, the committee interrogated the former supervisor of the teamsters' political action committee in an effort to prove that Mr. Carey knew about or cooperated in illegal fund-raising schemes. But the witness, Gregory Mullenholz, did not provide any solid proof of that.
Mr. Mullenholz, who said he was fired for cooperating with the F.B.I., an assertion denied by Mr. Carey's aides, said he found several of the union's donations to other groups suspicious. He said he questioned why the union contributed $475,000 to a get-out-the-vote drive by Citizen Action, a liberal grass-roots group, when shortly beforehand the union's political action committee borrowed $300,000 from a bank.
When three former Carey campaign aides pleaded guilty in court last month, they described a scheme in which the union gave money to Citizen Action and some of that group's donors contributed to the Carey campaign.
Mr. Mullenholz said he also questioned donations that the union made to Project Vote and the National Council of Senior Citizens, two groups that helped Democratic get-out-the-vote efforts in last year's Congressional elections. He said William Hamilton, the union's political director, had recommended those contributions, but Mr. Carey's executive assistant had rejected them.
Mr. Mullenholz said he understood that Mr. Hamilton then went directly to Mr. Carey to gain approval. Mr. Mullenholz stopped short of saying Mr. Carey was familiar with any scheme to contribute money to other groups in exchange for having their donors give to the Carey campaign.
Mr. Mullenholz testified that he saw notes that Mr. Hamilton sent to persuade Mr. Carey to donate to Project Vote and the senior citizens' group. But Mr. Mullenholz declined to say whether those notes showed that Mr. Carey had been informed of any improper scheme.
Denying any wrongdoing, Mr. Carey has said he was a victim of his aides' misdeeds. Mr. Hamilton has also denied any wrongdoing.

HEADLINE: U.S. Respects Brazil, Clinton Assures Latin Giant

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Oct. 14

 BODY:
President Clinton had a simple message for Brazil today, and he delivered it over and over, in several different ways: The United States takes this country seriously. Really. It doesn't want to dictate relations in the hemisphere, but just to do more business.
Appearing at a joint news conference here with the Brazilian President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, Mr. Clinton tried repeatedly to dispel longstanding Brazilian suspicions of American attitudes. In answer to a Brazilian journalist's question, he said that he did not feel threatened by the emergence of Brazil as a hemispheric powerhouse. 
 "I actually support the emergence of countries to a greater role of influence and responsibilities, as long as they share our basic values," he said, citing commitments to democracy, open trade and environmental protection.
This is the first visit of his Presidency to Brazil, and Mr. Clinton appeared anxiious to play catch-up. He and his aides have repeatedly noted that the European Union is rushing in to capitalize on Brazil's economy.
But Mr. Clinton did not only play the supplicant. He gently nudged Brazil toward joining an effort to reduce greenhouse gases. As nations prepare for an international conference on global warming in December, a central dispute is whether developing countries should share the burden of cutting emissions when developed ones have enjoyed most of the benefits of profligately polluting.
Still, while he said that "we must all participate" in reducing such gases, Mr. Clinton emphasized that he did not expect Brazil's efforts to interfere with its economic growth. "The United States would never knowingly make any suggestion that would undermine the growth of Brazil or any other country," he said.
For his part, Mr. Cardoso repeatedly praised his relations with Mr. Clinton and Brazil's with the United States, updating the American saw about General Motors: "We feel what's good for Brazil is good for the United States, and what's good for the United States is good for Brazil as well."
But he made clear that Brazil would continue expanding trade with all comers, whether or not Mr. Clinton ultimately wins so-called fast-track authority from Congress to conduct trade negotiations. "If there is going to be this sort of a policy or not is the United States' problem," Mr. Cardoso said.
Not all Brazilians were as welcoming as Mr. Cardoso, however. A handful of protesters here pelted the President's limousine with manure.
Mr. Clinton, bowing to a point of Brazilian pride, made the clearest statement to date that the United States recognizes the importance of Mercosur, a regional trade bloc in which Brazil is the biggest member. "I support Mercosur," Mr. Clinton said, adding that any new free-trade zone would be "consistent with Mercosur and the leadership and role of Brazil."
Mr. Clinton said he expected Brazil to sell more to Europe. "I don't feel threatened by it, I just want to make sure we're fully competing," he said. "And if we don't fully compete, it will be our fault, not yours and Europe's." But he took a dig at the Europeans, noting that the United States had lower tariffs than the European Union.
The two leaders said today that, three years after Mr. Clinton won agreement from Latin American leaders for a hemispheric free trade zone by 2005, the two countries would finally begin negotiations toward that goal next year.
But Mr. Cardoso and other Brazilian officials indicated that they wished to move slowly in lowering some barriers to foreign competitors. "We are not prepared to go for a new round of tariff reduction commitments by 2000," said Pedro Malana, the Finance Minister.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 4; Dining In, Dining Out/Style DeskSection F;Page 1;Column 4;Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk

LENGTH: 1631 words

HEADLINE: In War Against No-Shows, Restaurants Get Tougher

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
THEY call. They reserve. They don't come.
It's the saddest story in the restaurant business, but it's getting a new plot twist. 
 In coming months, diners all over the United States may find themselves paying for their sins. Like a date who's been stood up once too often, restaurant owners are getting tough with no-shows. Some demand a credit card number to secure reservations for tables of six or more. Others require a deposit of up to $300 and a signed agreement. Now, upping the ante, American Express is going nationwide with a pilot program designed to fight no-shows by dangling the threat of a charge, just like hotels and car-rental agencies.
The American Express initiative, called the Guaranteed Restaurant Reservations Program, allows restaurants to impose a penalty of $60 to $300 on diners who make a reservation for a party of six or more and then fail to cancel the reservation by a specified time, or, Heaven forbid, do not show up at all.
The growing reliance on penalties opens up a new front in an ever-expanding war between shellshocked restaurant owners, who can experience no-show rates of 40 percent on a Saturday night, and outlaw diners who, in some cases, reserve tables at several restaurants, eat at one, and leave the other restaurants hanging.
Calls to 20 of New York's fancier restaurants revealed a variety of enforcement policies, ranging from the old-fashioned honor system to tough requirements for up-front money. The Union Square Cafe and Le Perigord, for example, simply take a telephone number and ask customers to confirm the reservation the day before. Other restaurants ask for a credit card number to hold a large-party reservation, but enforcement varies. Lespinasse takes a credit card number for parties of six or more but does not threaten any charge for a no-show. Montrachet takes a credit card number and will impose a $25-a-person penalty, but allows customers to wait until 4 P.M. to cancel a dinner reservation, or 11 A.M. to cancel lunch.
"It discourages people from making reservations at seven or eight restaurants and deciding at the last minute which one to go to," said John McFadden, the general manager of the River Cafe in Brooklyn, which takes a credit card number for parties of eight or more, with a $25 penalty for each diner. "It doesn't look good to have a large table in the middle of the room that doesn't get used."
Some restaurant owners say they use the credit card tactic purely as a psychological weapon, and do not really intend to impose the fee. Merely taking the number, they say, reduces the no-show rate.
But some restaurants want their money before the meal, and require a deposit of $200 or $300 before guaranteeing a reservation. Callers wanting a table for six or more at Le Bernardin receive a form by fax that asks for their name, address, telephone number, credit card number and signature. Callers must fill out the form and refax it to the restaurant, along with a photocopy of both sides of their credit card. A $200 charge is applied to the credit card and deducted from the bill for the meal. Diners who do not want to deal with a credit card can drop by the restaurant and leave a cash deposit.
Windows on the World, Palio and Les Celebrites also require a deposit for larger parties. Les Celebrites is particularly strict. It requires a $300 deposit for parties of seven or more, and reservations must be canceled at least three days in advance.
American Express has tested its guaranteed reservation concept for three years in two pilot programs involving 44 restaurants across the country, 11 of them in New York, including Aureole, Sign of the Dove and TriBeCa Grill. It is now making the program available to the more than 150,000 restaurants that accept its card. Although the company said it could not predict what the response would be, about half the New York restaurants in the test said they would sign up for the program.
The company zeroed in on large parties because an empty table of six or more causes the most economic damage and is the hardest to fill on short notice. The no-show charge shows up on the customer's monthly American Express bill. Unlike the airlines, which require documentation like a doctor's note before issuing a refund for an unused ticket, American Express has no formal policy on how restaurants should deal with diners who plead illness or an emergency.
Some diners shrug off the new requirement as a minor inconvenience or even welcome it as a way to get an iron grip on a top table, especially if it is out of town. Others rebel. "I've had people laugh in my face, scream at me, or simply say, 'I will not give you my credit card number,' " said Isma Pulaos, the reservations clerk at Aureole. "Most people are nice, though." Some restaurateurs say they suspect that the outbursts and the hang-ups come from diners who have been foiled in attempts to book multiple tables.
To punish or not to punish, that is the question, and it is a divisive one for restaurant owners. In its research, American Express found that owners split three ways when asked if they wanted a program that would let them impose charges on no-shows. One-third liked the idea, one-third hated it and another third wanted more information. At bottom, restaurants want to please, not to discipline, and the idea of slapping fines represents a cultural change that makes many owners queasy.
"Restaurants are not in the business of charging fees," said Lloyd M. Wirshba, the general manager for restaurants at American Express. "They are in the business of providing service and a fine dining experience."
"If I charged one of my customers $50 for a no-show, I'd never see them again," said Raymond Buckler, the maitre d'hotel at Felidia, who said the restaurant looked into the American Express program but decided not to sign up. "It's just not friendly."
American Express started its program after restaurateurs began asking for the kind of guarantees that hotels and car-rental agencies take for granted. In a survey of 1,200 restaurants in 1993, the company found that half reported a no-show problem. Of that number, 65 percent had an overall no-show rate of 10 percent, 15 percent had a rate of 20 percent to 30 percent, and 3 percent had a rate of 30 percent to 40 percent. The problem was most acute on Saturday night, with Friday night a close second.
Gordon Sinclair, the owner of Gordon restaurant in Chicago, had an epiphany about 10 years ago when he began adding up the cost of no-shows and found that the grand total was $900,000 a year, a figure that got him thinking, fast.
He made a change in the restaurant's procedure that underlines the curious moral status of a restaurant reservation, which is less than a contract but something more binding than "let's have lunch."
He instructed his receptionists to stop saying, "Please call us if you change your plans," and start saying, "Will you call us if you change your plans?" His no-show rate dropped from 30 percent to 10 percent. In other words, by asking a question and eliciting a response, he created a sense of obligation.
Ten percent still represents a lot of money, and the hard-core malefactors have proven difficult to root out. They will confirm, reconfirm and still not show. Hence, the American Express program. Under the plan, a restaurant agrees to put into effect the kind of record-keeping procedures that are standard at hotels and car-rental companies and that protect the card holder. Customers making a reservation for six or more people are told that they must use the American Express card and that if they cancel after a set time or do not show up, a per-person charge will appear on their monthly bill. Restaurants may charge either $10 or $25 a person, with a maximum of $300.
If the customer violates the agreement, the restaurant must send him a letter within 48 hours, stating that it intends to impose the agreed-upon penalty.
In January, 18 months into the pilot program, 10,000 reservations had been taken and only seven no-show penalties had been imposed. Although the program ran until May, Mr. Wirshba said the company stopped compiling data.
"For smaller parties, who are not guaranteed, we have a 15 to 20 percent no-show rate," said Henny Santo, an owner of the Sign of the Dove, which took part in the pilot. "For guaranteed reservations, we had a total of six no-shows in three years. The program brings the no-show rate down to zero, virtually. The downside is that it is very time-consuming on the restaurant's part."
American Express said the program, like the cruise missile, is intended to wipe out specific targets rather than wreak mass destruction.
"We believe that this is not going to be used for dinner for two on a Tuesday night, but on an as-needed basis in those instances where the no-show rate has been high, such as holidays and weekends," Mr. Wirshba said.
It may work out that way in most parts of the United States, but in New York, "as needed" means every day. Many of the New York restaurateurs who took part in the pilot program said they plan to use it routinely.
If parties of six require a deposit today, can parties of four be far behind? For the moment, it seems unlikely. With four diners, the trade-off between paper work and indemnity against a no-show becomes a different equation, largely because a popular restaurant can rely on walk-in business to fill an empty table for four. It has become quite common, however, for top restaurants to demand that diners call back and reconfirm the day before a reservation, and some call up diners themselves the day before.
For large parties, a new world looms, with a new etiquette. "Party of six? No problem. Would you like to apply for a reservation?"

HEADLINE: A Dissertation on Mr. Ed?;
New Scholarly Center to Study Pop Television Culture

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN By LAWRIE MIFFLIN

 BODY:
As a typically compulsive undergraduate at the University of Chicago, Bob Thompson used to allow himself just one half-hour of television viewing a week, on Sunday night. And no matter how hard he tried to watch PBS, he always succumbed to "CHiPS," the drama about California motorcycle cops starring Larry Wilcox and Erik Estrada.
This disturbed him. Why, Mr. Thompson, a budding political scientist, asked himself, do smart people love to watch dumb television shows? 
 From that query came a quixotic academic career. Now Dr. Robert J. Thompson, a 38-year-old Syracuse University professor, he is one of the nation's leading scholars in television studies, a relatively new and still formless discipline. This weekend, he will take charge of a new academic research center at the S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse, to be christened the Center for the Study of Popular Television -- emphasis on the word "popular."
Television, even television that appeals to the lowest common denominator, can still be great art, Professor Thompson contends, a sort of visually enhanced form of literature. Shakespeare, as people are so often reminded, was a popular artist. Jazz, once dismissed as popular, is now recognized as a discipline worthy of serious study.
Indeed, in a statement announcing the creation of the research center, the dean of the Newhouse School, David Rubin, declares that it will "study television entertainment programs with the same care and passion as musicologists study Mozart and Ellington, or professors of English study Melville and Pynchon."
Poppycock, some other scholars say.
"There's a fallacy there, in assuming that the common run of literature is comparable to Melville, or that the musical norm is comparable to Mozart's work," said Mark Crispin Miller, a leading media scholar who is soon to leave Johns Hopkins University to join New York University. "Those were the greats, who stood out. In the Renaissance, you'd have a hard time finding a play that's even readable other than Shakespeare's plays."
While conceding that the best television programs merit academic attention, Professor Miller said Syracuse's emphasis on the word "popular" concerned him.
"The fact is that most TV drama is esthetically appalling, and most TV comedy is too," he said. "For the most part it's utterly derivative, a pale imitation of whatever seemed to sell six months ago."
Such attitudes drive Professor Thompson to become "even more zealous," as he put it, in defense of his research. He calls such criticism "belle-lettristic apartheid, much of it plain old-fashioned cultural elitism," mostly from people who have scant knowledge of popular television.
"Just because television is filled with bottom-line-oriented profits and is generated by 500 people's hands, we shouldn't be reduced to silence about it," he said.
Professor Thompson in fact admires Professor Miller's work. But he said he believed that enough academic research was being done on subjects like television news coverage; television's influence on politics, violent behavior or sexual mores, and the economic forces behind mass media. What is missing, he said, is the "art appreciation" aspect.
"It is tragic and in many ways dangerous that we are so ignorant as intellectuals about a medium that has such a profound effect on us," he said. "How we perceive art and storytelling is infected and affected by the television era. Look at any modern novel after the year 1960 -- look at Don DeLillo's new book -- and you can't help but see how much television has moved in."
Horace Newcomb, a communications professor at the University of Texas at Austin who was one of the first scholars in this field, as early as 1970, agreed.
"Popular television has been the central storytelling system of our time," he said. "To say it's not important to study that is like saying one shouldn't have studied Dickens or Scott Fitzgerald. I happen to think fiction is crucial to people's lives, and if they're experiencing it this way, or through literature or the stage or the big screen, all are equally deserving of study.
As for Professor Thompson's own research, his most recent book was "Television's Second Golden Age: From 'Hill Street Blues' to 'E.R.' " (Continuum Press, 1996); his next, due next year, is "Good TV: The 'St. Elsewhere' Story."
"I think 'St. Elsewhere' is probably the best show ever on American prime-time TV," Professor Thompson said, because of the intricacy of its writing.
After switching from political science, his undergraduate major, Professor Thompson earned a doctorate in film and television studies from Northwestern University. He taught there and at the State University of New York at Cortland before moving to the Newhouse School at Syracuse seven years ago.
Along the way, he became convinced that "there was enormous vacuum to be filled" in terms of "inventing the discipline of television studies as a serious academic pursuit."
His dream of creating a center for such work was endorsed by Dr. Rubin, the Newhouse School dean, who helped raise more than $430,000 to start the new center.
 
Encouraging Books About TV
In addition to being a locus for scholarly research and teaching, the center will encourage publication of books about television by the Syracuse University Press, expand Syracuse's collection of scripts and videos, create an academic journal on television and continue an oral history project that Syracuse lured away from the University of California at Los Angeles.
That archive attracted the bulk of the center's financing, $300,000 from the Steven H. and Alida Brill Scheuer Foundation. Mr. Scheuer wrote a series of television and video guidebooks and was the host of a public television program, "All About Television," in the 1970's and 80's.
His patronage in this case benefits David Marc, who had been compiling an oral history archive on television pioneers who were Jewish and how Jewish culture was reflected in television. At Syracuse, the project is being expanded to capture as many early television pioneers as possible. More than 70 interviews are already on file, from Steve Allen to Betty White.
The question persists as to whether, aside from the nostalgia value, these people and the shows they worked on deserve academic study.
"Every new creative medium gets dismissed," said Robert M. Batscha, the president of the Museum of Television and Radio in New York, , which opened a branch in Los Angeles last year. "Film was dismissed, photography was dismissed, modern art, modern theater -- all were dismissed at first. When the Museum of Modern Art began to look at this new art form, nobody understood it. It took a while before the museum began to educate people. Then MOMA and the Eastman House did the same with film."
But, said Dr. Batscha, who is a political scientist and communications scholar, many of the country's most creative young people now go into television. And he said he believed that this trend might feel threatening to "the establishment, to people who have dedicated their careers to other art forms."
A pillar of the establishment begs to disagree. Stephen H. Balch, the president of the tradition-minded National Academy of Scholars, said it would take 30 or 40 years before scholars know what television programs are worthy of academic study. "With art, particularly the art we study in the academy, we have greater confidence in its inherent greatness by the fact that much time has passed, and many people have sifted through it, and still the appreciation for it continues," he said.
 
A Familiar Part Of Their Lives
Unlike most other art forms, television for most of today's students is a familiar and integral part of their lives. Professor Thompson sees in that fact a potential educational benefit.
"When I was at Cortland, I taught a course in the history of television from Milton Berle to 'The Simpsons,' and you can't help talking about all kinds of American traditions that go into that," he said. "You talk about 'The Beverly Hillbillies' and 'Andy Griffith' and you get into the celebration of the rural in American life, the emphasis on nature, from Thoreau to Melville's noble savages to Emerson's Walden Pond. Invariably, students would come to me afterward and say, 'Where can I read this stuff?'
"It's a connection for them, using television to teach the liberal arts notion that human endeavors are all part of a great cultural conversation. We turned them into good old-fashioned, critical-thinking intellectuals better than many English or philosophy classes were doing on that campus, because in those classes, they never felt invited into the conversations."
Dr. Balch called that theory "dumbing the intellect down," a phrase he attributed to Daniel Patrick Moynihan. "Rather than bring the students up to the level where an educated person should be," he said, "we're bringing education down to their level, and filling it up with things that are already part and parcel of their daily life, instead of with new challenges."
And Professor Miller, who has written in praise of Hitchcock as well as Shakespeare, could not accept Professor Thompson's cultural continuum argument.
"You can find some sort of tradition for any piece of garbage that's out there, whether musical or cinematic or literary," he said. "Everything has forebears. But to claim any meaningful connection between 'The Beverly Hillbillies' and 'Walden' is just silly."
Dr. Batscha, of the Museum of Television and Radio, admittedly has a different bias. But he recalled that at the turn of the century teaching popular novels was considered silly in an academic tradition that emphasized the classics.
"You wouldn't think of teaching culture in the United States now without studying the novel, or films," he said. "And hopefully a few years from now you wouldn't think of studying 20th-century culture without studying television."

HEADLINE: Restrain Inflation Genie

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Robert Eisner (Op-Ed, Oct. 11) misses a major issue in regard to inflation: inflation psychology, the greatest danger. I am in the real estate and construction business, which is highly sensitive to interest rates. I would much rather that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, tinker with interest rates in quarter-point increments to keep the genie of inflation psychology firmly in the bottle than take any chance that it gets out and be forced to go back to the days of Paul Volcker, when the prime rate was allowed to go up to 21 percent to get inflation under control. 
 In spite of what Mr. Eisner says, there are inflationary pressures in the economy. You have only to look around in daily life to feel this -- go out to dinner, go to the movies, fill the gas tank, buy a home or rent an apartment.
 
RICHARD N. FISKE
Cheshire, Conn., Oct. 14, 1997

HEADLINE: Give Judges a Raise

 BODY:

To the Editor:
An Oct. 11 news article on President Clinton's veto of the late-term abortion measure included a one-sentence paragraph on his approval of a spending bill that will permit members of Congress to receive a long-overdue 2.3 percent cost-of-living adjustment raise for next year. 
 Federal judges are the only Government employees who have not been granted a COLA for 1998. This is a result of an obscure law commonly known as Section 140, which requires Congress to vote to grant judges a COLA.
If Section 140 is not repealed, judges will be denied a COLA for the fifth consecutive year. Congress should repeal this unfair provision.
 
ALAN H. NEVAS
Pres., Federal Judges Association

HEADLINE: A Rain Forest Imperiled

 BODY:
The issue that most Americans identify with Brazil -- the destruction of the Amazon rain forest -- did not occupy a prominent role in the talks between President Clinton and Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso. The issue deserved better, though neither man is comfortable with the subject. Washington still subsidizes logging in America's temperate rain forests. Brazil has abandoned some of its worst policies in the Amazon, yet it is not enforcing its laws and seems oblivious to a range of new and insidious threats from timber and agricultural interests.
The state of the world's rain forests is particularly distressing now that global warming has again become a major international concern. Growing forests help absorb the gases that warm the atmosphere. Burning those forests, of course, adds to the problem. 
 More of Brazil is on fire right now than ever before. The fires are not as widespread as they are in Indonesia, where smoke has spread to neighboring nations, nor is commercial logging the main culprit. Brazil's fires are largely the handiwork of agricultural interests that clear land for cattle ranching, with a modest assist provided by subsistence farmers who engage in small-scale slash-and-burn tactics. This year, cities like Manaus that have gone unscathed in the past have been blanketed with smoke. Manaus has also reported a 40 percent increase in respiratory illnesses.
The fires are increasing despite Brazil's efforts in the past few years to protect the forest. The Government ended its ruinous subsidies to the cattle ranchers, and now requires that settlers keep 80 percent of their land forested. Brazil has also set aside about 20 percent of the forest as parks, protected areas and indigenous reserves.
But the ranchers keep on burning, and the laws are not enforced. Brazil's environmental protection agency has only about 80 enforcement officers in the whole of the Amazon. Worse, Brazil's courts have ruled that the agency does not have the authority to enforce the law, which means that it cannot even collect the fines it levies. A bill giving the agency authority to punish environmental criminals has passed the senate and is now before Brazil's lower house. It is a bill the Amazon obviously needs.
Tough enforcement is especially important now. There could be a major drought this year or next, leading to widespread fires, if the climate-altering weather pattern known as El Nino strikes as expected. A graver danger may come from industrial interests. President Cardoso favors cutting roads and blasting waterways through large swaths of the forest. This could provide a new transportation network for big farmers who want to clear land to grow soybeans for export to Europe.
New roads could also lead to increased logging. Already companies from Malaysia, China, Korea and other nations, many of which use clearcutting in Asia, are beginning to log part of the forest. As these companies pave roads deeper into the jungle, cattle ranchers may follow. The roads may make clearcutting economically viable and tempt Brazil to sell off the rain forest for hard currency.
Although a muscular environmental agency is Brazil's most pressing need, it is not the only one. If Brazil goes ahead with the plan to improve Amazon transportation, it must simultaneously address environmental concerns and earmark more land for conservation. A worthy program to set aside indigenous areas, which both preserves the forests and protects Indian tribes, is only half-completed. Brazil must finish the job, which would protect 10 percent more of the Amazon.
The country also needs to develop zoning laws for the forests and to adopt sustainable logging practices. More broadly, Brazil, like the United States and Asia's forested nations, must abandon the view that the rain forest is only a commodity to be exploited for private gain.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Foreign and Fed Buying Aids Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Treasury securities advanced yesterday as investors returned from a long holiday weekend to find that overseas bargain hunters had pushed up prices.
Gains were extended after the Federal Reserve entered the market, buying Treasuries on what is known as a coupon pass. And there was buying on relief that the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, did not sound more inflation warnings in a talk at the annual monetary conference of the Cato Institute in Washington. 
 "In fact," said Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif., "Mr. Greenspan was probably telling the markets a whole lot more last week, that he will raise rates, but that the timing was not clear. There was nothing market-moving in his speech today, only relief that he did not mention tight labor markets again, which produced a quick spike in bond prices."
A survey from last week taken by Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, showed no significant changes in Fed policy expectations despite Mr. Greenspan's warnings, according to Kim Rupert, an economist there.
"A tightening is still not generally expected until the Feb. 3 and 4 Federal Open Market Committee meeting," Ms. Rupert said. "A move at the Dec. 16 F.O.M.C. is still a close call, with about 58 percent expecting no tightening."
The 30-year bond gained 29/32, to a price of 100 9/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 6.35 percent, from 6.42 percent on Friday.
Bonds were also buoyed when the Fed entered the market to buy securities. The central bank bought $1.4 billion of securities with maturities that ran from November 2002 through August 2027, in a process commonly called a coupon pass, which permanently adds reserves to the banking system without a change in policy.
Citing speculation that today's retail sales report for September may suggest the economy is slowing, some analysts said the Fed could delay any rate increase a little longer. Some economists are expecting that retail sales to be unchanged, after gaining four-tenths of a percent in August.
Tomorrow the Government is to release the Consumer Price Index for September, with the report expected to show a gain of three-tenths of a percent excluding volatile food and energy costs.
Ms. Rupert said the data on retail sales should be friendly, but the Consumer Price Index could be ugly. "If retail sales are soft and the C.P.I. later in the week does not surprise, the market could see a relief rally," Ms. Rupert said, adding, however, "It is doubtful whether the highs reached the day of the employment report on Oct. 3 can be revisited anytime soon."
Results at the Treasury's weekly bill auction, which was held yesterday because Monday was a Federal holiday, were called good, with the rate for a three-month bill going to 4.98 percent from 4.93 percent last week. The six-month bill rate also climbed, to 5.12 percent from 5.01 percent.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Filing Off 4%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Personal bankruptcies fell in the third quarter as the result of an expanding economy and steady job growth.
The number of people filing for bankruptcy protection declined 4 percent, to 335,218, according to CDB Infotek of Santa Ana, Calif., which provides on-line access to records. In the second quarter, applications reached a high of 349,281. 
 "Since bankruptcies are a lagging indicator, we could see further declines," said Rick Rozar, CDB's president.
While the number fell, it was still up 9.7 percent from the third quarter of '96, CDB said.
In the 12 months ending on Sept. 30, bankruptcies declined the most in North Carolina, Iowa, Kentucky and Arkansas; they rose most in Utah, Maryland and New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Class Notes

BYLINE: By Ethan Bronner By Ethan Bronner

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The concept of a new Middle East has taken such a thrashing in the past year or two that, when a glimmer of it appears, the natural tendency for many is a roll of the eyes. Lately, every time there is talk of the children of Abraham joining hands for a better future, someone blows himself up in a crowded market or bulldozers break ground on disputed land. Threats are voiced, guns are raised and hopes fade yet again.
But the eye rollers would benefit from sitting in on the weekly meeting of the energetic board of directors of what has been optimistically named the University of the Middle East. 
 At the meeting, typically held on Sundays around a supper table at an Italian restaurant in the North End of Boston, the skeptics would find Hala Taweel, the disarming sister-in-law of Yasir Arafat, breaking bread with Ron Rubin, an Israeli-American physicist. There are Camelia Anwar Sadat, daughter of the former President of Egypt Anwar Sadat, and Walid Chamoun, whose Maronite Christian family went to war to rid its native Lebanon of Mr. Arafat's forces in the 1970's, thereby helping begin a civil war.
At the meetings, the jokes fly, the camaraderie is easy.
The plan they share is this: to build, over the next 30 years, a university with campuses across the Middle East and North Africa to promote coexistence and economic development. The first branches would be in Israel, the Palestinian areas and probably Egypt. Students and faculty would be required to spend time at one another's campuses, bringing Israelis and Arabs, Christians and Muslims, into scholarly and social contact.
Elie Wiesel, the Nobel peace laureate, has written a letter endorsing the project, as has Lea Rabin, widow of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel. Diplomats from Spain, Japan and Britain have expressed their governments' support.
Peace through education may sound quaint in the rough-and-tumble world of Middle Eastern politics, but to the participants it is the most natural thing in the world. Many of them first came into contact with their putative enemies on a university campus.
"I had never had any real contact with an Israeli until I came to the Kennedy School at Harvard and 18 of my fellow students were Israelis," recalled Ms. Taweel, 32, the president of the board and a doctoral candidate in higher educational administration at Boston College. Her sister, Suha, is married to Mr. Arafat. "Not only that, they were all military officers. By the end of the year, we became very good friends."
Mr. Rubin, 27, who came up with the idea for the university after Mr. Rabin's assassination, said he first met Palestinians and other Arabs while an undergraduate at Princeton and decided that an academic environment was ideal for breaking down traditional barriers.
The project, which operates out of donated offices here with donated furniture and equipment, has raised $50,000. The plan is to raise $500,000 and begin feasibility studies in three countries and a pilot summer course in Morocco or Egypt.
"We hope to begin real classes in five years," Mr. Rubin said.
If it all sounds a bit utopian, it might be worth listening to Kanan Makiya, an Iraqi dissident author in Cambridge and a supporter of the project, who said, "Peace in the Middle East, real peace, will come as an effort of the heart or it will not come at all."

HEADLINE: 3 More Brokerage Houses Post Income Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch & Company, the Bear Stearns Companies and Paine Webber Group Inc. yesterday became the latest big brokerage houses to report healthy quarterly earnings on the strength of the bull market and record merger activity.
They join Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company; Goldman, Sachs & Company; Lehman Brothers Holdings; Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., and Smith Barney in reporting large gains. 
 Merrill, the No. 2 securities firm behind Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, said profits rose 49 percent. No. 5 Bear Stearns said profits rose 49 percent and No. 6 Paine Webber said profits rose 41 percent.
The rising demand for stocks coupled with low interest rates have encouraged many companies to raise cash by selling both stocks and bonds -- businesses that earn investment banks big underwriting fees. In addition, global consolidation in many industries has helped generate significant revenues for Wall Street firms that provide advice on mergers and acquisitions.
Merrill Lynch earned $494 million, or $1.25 a share, in the third quarter ending Sept. 26, compared with $331 million, or 84 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.
The results beat Wall Street expectations of $1.21 a share, according to a survey by I.B.E.S. International Inc. Nevertheless, Merrill's stock was down $1.44 at $75.56 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.
Merrill said revenues after interest expenses rose to $3.9 billion from $3.1 billion. The company said it set revenue records in commission, investment banking and asset management fees.
Merrill was No. 1 in the United States in merger and acquisition deals completed, with 30 percent of the market, and No. 2 globally, with 20.3 percent, according to the Securities Data Company, which tracks the performance of Wall Street firms. Bear Stearns earned $161.6 million, or $1.11 a share, in its first fiscal quarter ending Sept. 26, compared with $108.8 million, or 72 cents a share, a year ago.
The results were in line with analysts' forecasts of $1.10 a share. Bear Stearns stock was down 25 cents at $44.50 on the Big Board.
The company said revenues after interest expenses rose to $996.1 million from $688.7 million, led by gains in underwritings, stock and bond trading, and fees from mergers and acquisition advice.
Paine Webber said quarterly profits rose to a record $112.8 million, or $1.11 a share, compared with $80.2 million, or 79 cents, a year ago.
The results exceeded analysts' forecasts of 87 cents a share. Paine Webber's stock was up $1.5625 at $50.75 a share on the Big Board.
Revenues after interest expenses rose 23 percent, to $1.08 billion from $883 million, led by gains in the firm's brokerage, trading, asset management and investment banking businesses.

HEADLINE: 2 Get Nobel for a Formula at the Heart of Options Trading

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Two North American scholars won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday for work that enables investors to price accurately their bets on the future, a breakthrough that has helped power the explosive growth in financial markets since the 1970's and plays a profound role in the economics of everyday life.
Robert C. Merton of the Harvard Business School and Myron S. Scholes, a Canadian-born professor emeritus at the Stanford Business School, will share the $1 million award for helping devise a mathematical formula that provided the answer to a simple but seemingly insurmountable problem confronting Wall Street: how to measure the worth of an option. 
 Their solution helped lay the basis of today's vast global options marketplace, where the trading affects everyone with a stake in the financial markets, from employees who receive stock options as part of their pay to mutual fund investors who use options to hedge interest-rate risk.
An option is a type of investment that allows, but does not require, an investor to buy an asset, like stocks or bonds or wheat or pork bellies, at a prearranged price during a preset period of time.
Until 1973, when Mr. Merton and Mr. Scholes published their analysis, it was extremely difficult to assess all the variables that could affect the price of an option. Their work overcame that difficulty, which had limited the growth of the options markets.
"Such rapid and widespread application of a theoretical result was new to economics," the prize committee wrote. "Nowadays, thousands of traders and investors use the formula every day" -- making it easy for businesses and individuals to hedge risks in the incredibly complex world of modern finance.
 The announcement of the Nobel in economics, which has been awarded annually by the Bank of Sweden since 1969, excites the academic community, but usually ignites little genuine enthusiasm on Wall Street. Not so this year. "I'm thrilled," said William Brodsky, chairman of the Chicago Board Options Exchange, which owes a large part of its growth to the Nobel winners. "This Nobel not only recognizes Merton and Scholes's accomplishments, it underscores the importance of options in the world of finance."
The analysis the two worked out has been successfully applied not only to pricing options but also to numerous other "derivative" securities, so named because their value is determined by fluctuations in the value of other assets.
Using derivatives is now a common way to redistribute the risks of doing business. Although in recent years derivatives have been associated with some financial disasters -- they played a role in the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., and the demise of Barings, Britain's oldest investment bank -- derivatives are widely regarded as beneficial.
Farmers, for example, use derivatives when they sell crops on the futures markets even before the planting has been finished. By locking in a price, they protect themselves if prices fall, although they also give up the chance of a windfall if prices surge. By the same token, grain dealers, bakeries and other big purchasers often buy grain futures to hedge against the risk of rising crop prices.
 But what is the real worth of, say, an option to buy 100 shares of Intel at $105 each before next April or the right to borrow 400 million French francs at 9 percent by next Tuesday?
By the early 1960's, a handful of economists had both an interest in the puzzle and the advanced mathematical tools to solve it.
"We knew the answer was there, and that someone was going to find it," recalled Paul Samuelson, an economist at M.I.T. who later won a Nobel for work in other areas of economics.
 The breakthrough came from three researchers, each under the age of 30 -- and one not even an economist. Fischer Black, a mathematician with Arthur D. Little consultants in Boston, discovered that an acquaintance, Mr. Scholes, then a professor of finance at M.I.T., was also fascinated by the question of options value. They enlisted the help of an assistant to Professor Samuelson at M.I.T., Mr. Merton, who is the son of the famous Columbia University sociologist Robert K. Merton.
 Together they devised a mathematical formula, known as the Black-Scholes model, that took into account a variety of variables.
Mr. Black and Mr. Scholes had considerable difficulty finding a publisher. Their paper languished for three years before the prestigious Journal of Political Economy printed it in 1973. Mr. Merton walked an easier path, but only because he was a friend of the editor of the new Bell Journal of Economics. "Finance just wasn't part of the economics mainstream," Mr. Merton recalled in an interview yesterday.
 The Chicago Board Options Exchange, the first devoted to options trading, opened just as the Black-Scholes theory was published. Although complicated, the computation involved could be easily -- and virtually instantly -- done on the pocket calculators that were just becoming popular.
 Soon traders were valuing options on the floor of the exchange, punching half a dozen numbers into electronic calculators hard-wired with the formula. This not only meant quicker and more accurate pricing, it also increased the volume of options markets and reduced the cost of using options.
 Mr. Black and Mr. Scholes became so highly regarded at the exchange that when they visited, traders would give them a standing ovation.
Thanks to extensions suggested by Mr. Merton, uses for the formula have been found in virtually every nook and cranny of finance.
Mr. Merton, who earned his Ph.D. from M.I.T in 1970, taught there until 1988, when he moved to the Harvard Business School. The Nobel caps a long career in helping to transform corporate finance from a backwater to the hot zone of economics. "Bob Merton is the Isaac Newton of his field," Mr. Samuelson said.
 In 1973, Mr. Scholes went back to teach at the University of Chicago Business School, where he had earned his Ph.D. In 1983 he moved on to the Stanford Business School, where he taught until retirement in 1996. That was hardly the end of his career, though. He and Mr. Merton are principals in Long Term Financial Management, the immensely successful multibillion-dollar private investment fund formed by John Meriwether when he broke with his partners at Salomon Brothers.
"These guys can do finance both ways: high theory, or down and dirty," Stephen Ross, an economist at the Yale School of Management, said of the new Nobel recipients.
And Peter L. Bernstein, a consultant to institutional investors and a historian of the securities industry, said yesterday, "All I can say is: What took the Nobel committee so long?"
 Mr. Merton said he had no particular plans for the $500,000 that he will receive at a ceremony on Dec. 10.
"It's all been a blast," he said. "My only regret is that Fischer Black isn't here to share the prize." Mr. Black, a partner in Goldman, Sachs and a former president of the American Economic Association, died in 1995 at the age of 57.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Nobel award in economics was given to Myron S. Scholes, left, professor emeritus at the Stanford Business School, whose daughter Ann hugged him as his daughter Sara looked on, and Robert C. Merton of the Harvard Business School. (Peter DaSilva for The New York Times, left; Agence France-Presse)
; Chart: "How to Price a Hunch"
For centuries, market traders relied on instinct and gut feeling to decide how much to pay today for something whose value depends on an uncertain future; an example would be an option contract, which confers the right to buy or sell a security or commodity at a set price for a set time. But economists who tried to develop mathematical methods for valuing options struggled vainly until three young researchers -- Fischer Black, Robert C. Merton and Myron S. Scholes -- hit upon a formula in the late 1960's that substantially solved the problem. Their big breakthrough came in realizing the role played by volatility.
 
The algebra looks complex, but the concept is straightforward. Most of the hard work comes in determining what expected means.
 
In the form above, the formula gives the value today of a call option, represented by the letter C. A call option is the right to buy a stock at a set price called the strike price (L) before a fixed future date called the maturity (time to maturity is represented as t). The letter d stands for a combination of the formula's other variables; it relates movements in the stock price to movements in the option's value.
 
The formula assigns a higher value to the option if today's share price (S) is high, if the share price is very volatile (s, the price's standard deviation) and interest rates in general are high (r is the risk-free return available on Treasuries). Similarly, the longer the time to maturity, the lower the strike price, and the greater the likelihood that the option will be worth more at maturity (N is the normal distribution function).
 
The method is now so commonplace that pocket calculators are available with the formula built in: A trader or investor can punch in S, N, L, r and t and price an option contract in seconds. With minor variations, the formula can also be used to price many things whose value depends on events yet to come, like other kinds of options, futures, derivatives, and insurance policies.
 
(Source: Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences)(pg. D4)

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief Seeks Peace Force to Dampen the Brazzaville Flames

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 14

 BODY:
With a sudden intensification of civil war in the Congo Republic threatening to engulf several West African nations in a regional conflict, Secretary General Kofi Annan asked the Security Council tonight to impose sanctions on the country and to prepare to send a peacekeeping force there.
He described the Congo Republic as a battlefield on which Angolan troops with tanks, soldiers from the neighboring Congo, formerly Zaire, and various mercenary armies were all involved. The battle began earlier this year with a rivalry between current and past presidents. 
 The Congo Republic's capital, Brazzaville, lies across the river from Kinshasa, the capital of Congo.
Shells have been falling on Kinshasa for more than a week, with more falling as the Brazzaville presidential palace came under attack in the last 24 hours. In effect, diplomats said today, President Laurent Kabila of Congo, facing rebellion in the eastern part of the country, now has a war on two fronts.
In what diplomats described as a spirited two-hour meeting with the Council, Mr. Annan asked for the authority to send an advance team of about 160 military experts to set up a headquarters in Libreville, Gabon, to prepare for action in the Congo Republic, where the United Nations has been trying to broker a cease-fire with the help of the Gabonese President, Omar Bongo.
Mr. Annan met resistance from only the United States, officials said after the meeting. Under an agreement with Congress, the Clinton Administration must notify legislators 15 days before a mission and can delay Security Council action indefinitely.
Mr. Annan challenged the United States not to block this mission as it has been blocking other peacekeeping plans in Africa in recent years, rendering the United Nations powerless in a series of crises.
"Given the urgency of the situation, I hope the agreement of Washington will be forthcoming," Mr. Annan said. "I don't think anyone would want to be responsible for holding back international action in this difficult situation."
Mr. Annan said that according to letters he received today from the Brazzaville and Kinshasa Governments and information from independent sources, it appeared that Angolan troops had seized two southern towns in Congo Republic and were involved in fighting in the capital.
Diplomats said there are credible reports that President Kabila of Congo has sent hundreds of troops across to the neighboring country. The Congo Republic Government asserted today that there were at least 1,000 Angolans also involved in the war.
The war in Congo Republic began in June, when forces loyal to President Pascal Lissouba surrounded the home of the political rival and former president, Gen. Denis Sassou-Nguesso. In recent weeks, the fighting has increased in intensity, with General Sassou-Nguesso fighting back, apparently with Angola's help.
Today, Secretary General Annan, a Ghanaian, said the expanding war was a serious threat to peace in west-central Africa. "Given the involvement of neighboring troops, given the possibility that this will spill over to other countries in the region," he said, "if we do not act to put pressure on them and show action, it may be much worse later on."
If the members act, it would be the first peacekeeping operation that the council approved in the past two years.

HEADLINE: Moody's Warns That New York State's Budget Could Spawn Gigantic Deficits

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 14

 BODY:
A major Wall Street rating agency is warning that New York State's budget, with its commitments to deep tax cuts and big increases in school spending -- and what the agency sees as a risky reliance on a continued bull market -- is a prescription for enormous budget deficits in a few years.
The report by Moody's Investors Service echoes criticism already heard from State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, independent budget watchers like the Citizens Budget Commission, and others. But the warning carries particular weight coming from Moody's, whose judgments are closely watched in the financial markets. The report is to be released later this week. 
 Moody's did not change its credit rating for New York, the lowest for any state, and it predicted that the state's finances will remain stable for at least another year, and probably longer. In other words, things are likely to remain fine past November 1998, when Gov. George E. Pataki will stand for re-election.
But the report criticizes the $67.4 billion budget negotiated by the Governor and legislative leaders, and enacted in August, for making five-year commitments to phasing in tax cuts and broad new education programs, which together will cost the state more than $6 billion a year. The budget allowed lawmakers to go into an election year boasting of the politically popular cuts and programs, but most of the bill will not come due until 2001 and 2002.
The report asserts that the budget includes "deep backloaded tax cuts and multiyear spending obligations requiring future, unspecified spending cuts."
But administration officials insist that the budget will not result in a retreat from the long-term commitments or in serious program cuts. The Governor and his aides have often noted that, defying doubters' predictions, the state has been able since he was elected to cut taxes and increase spending at the same time.
"We've been getting this kind of criticism for three years," said Donna Arduin, first deputy budget director. She noted that the first two fiscal years under Mr. Pataki ended "not just with balanced budgets but with large surpluses."
But that has happened during the historic Wall Street boom, which has sent the state's personal income tax collections soaring. Moody's, like most other budget-watchers, argues that the state appears to be counting on a continued bull market, despite the historic volatility of financial markets and the possibility of a recession over the next five years.
"If this level of growth and prosperity continues," said Robert Kurtter, senior vice president of Moody's for state ratings, "it is possible for the state to grow its way out of the long-term budget gaps, but that's not a prudent thing to plan on."
The reliance on Wall Street is particularly risky, the report says, because the boom there has masked sluggishness in the underlying economy, with New York lagging well behind the rest of the country in job growth.
But Ms. Arduin insisted that the budget does not depend on a continued stock market boom to remain balanced.
Moody's also took issue with the budget for increasing spending more than 5 percent, much faster than inflation, after two years of relative restraint with Mr. Pataki in office, and for increasing New York's debt load, already the highest by far of any state.

HEADLINE: University for Working Adults Shatters Mold

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER By ETHAN BRONNER

DATELINE: PHOENIX

 BODY:
Just off the shimmering asphalt ribbons of Interstate 10, minutes from the Phoenix airport, in a zone of windshield and transport companies, sits a set of brick office buildings that contains what many view as the biggest challenge to higher education in the United States today.
The name on the unassuming structures, the University of Phoenix, suggests a local college. But, like its setting, that is deceptive. 
 With 40,000 students, the University of Phoenix has grown into the largest private university in the nation, galloping ahead of such powerhouses as New York University and the University of Southern California.
But more significantly, it has done so using a new model consonant with the times, turning itself into a kind of H.M.O. of education: It is run as a for-profit business, paying taxes rather than accepting public subsidies; it rents space rather than buying buildings for its makeshift campuses across a dozen states; and its courses are standardized in shrink-wrap packages.
Phoenix has also chosen to do something else unusual. It accepts no one under the age of 23 and only those gainfully employed. Since 45 percent of higher-education students are 24 or older, Phoenix is tapping into an exploding and lucrative portion of a $200 billion higher-education market where costs have been widely seen as out of control.
"This is a very significant time in higher education," said Timothy J. McDonough, vice president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities. "Adult learning is skyrocketing. People don't understand that there is a market out there. Phoenix has grasped that very well."
It is unlikely that the Phoenix model will soon dominate higher education since there will long be a place for residential institutions for 18- to 22- year-olds where instruction is blended with socialization. But there is little doubt that Phoenix's practices, like keeping virtually no full-time faculty and stocking no libraries, are spreading and are a source of great worry to many colleges that benefit from tax subsidies yet still struggle financially.
"I was asked to speak at Rutgers recently about what we do and the response among the assembled faculty was telling," said Laura Palmer Noone, vice president for academic affairs at the University of Phoenix. "The reaction was divided into three groups. A few found what we do exciting, a second group dismissed us as a passing fad, and the last group looked at me like I was the antichrist, spelling the doom of life as they know it."
The University of Phoenix, which has been accredited for 20 years, is not a place to discover the eternal verities of the Western tradition. It offers B.A.'s and M.A.'s, mostly in business and in fields like information technology, health and education. While it is a leader in distance education, meaning course work over the Internet, most of its classes involve working professionals teaching other working professionals in classrooms.
Phoenix sets itself apart with its unwavering corporate orientation. Its advocates say that when, in the 1970's, the nation's economy began a shift to one based on information, corporations came to universities asking for help in updating and retraining employees but that the universities were slow to respond.
Many companies took matters into their own hands, setting up corporate universities of which there are now some 1,200. But none of them are accredited: they cannot offer degrees. The University of Phoenix, whose regional accreditation is accepted nationally, has therefore been able to sell itself as the best of both worlds.
Some 75 percent of Phoenix students are at least partly reimbursed by their companies for tuition, which, at about $6,500 a year, is somewhat higher than public universities but lower than most private ones. Classes are limited to 15 to 20 students, and there is a great deal of work in small groups.
Some of this has recently been going on at other universities as the need for income from adult students has become more pressing. But most extension programs tend to be institutional stepchildren. At Phoenix, it is all the university does.
"When I was looking around to get my M.B.A. in 1992, Arizona State did not offer evening classes the way the University of Phoenix did," said Ike Schneider of Alliant Food Service in Phoenix, who got his master of business administration there with an emphasis in technology management. "I went one evening a week, worked in small groups and was very satisfied."
The university is the creation of John G. Sperling, 76, a restless, plain-talking contrarian. Born to a Missouri sharecropping couple, Mr. Sperling discovered books while at sea as a merchant marine, returned to college in Oregon and ultimately earned a doctorate in economic history from Cambridge University in England. He started an academic career only to find it stifling.
While teaching at San Jose State University in the late 1960's, Mr. Sperling became involved in a project on juvenile delinquency, in which he brought teachers and police officers to campus for courses.
"We worked with them in small groups," he recalled in an interview, "and since these were adults with little patience for lectures, the instructors had to act more as facilitators than traditional professors. The students had a great deal to offer not only to one another but to the instructor. The students loved it and asked if they could turn the seminars into vehicles for obtaining B.A.'s and M.A.'s."
By 1973, Mr. Sperling had 2,500 paying students at several universities. But the regional accrediting body accused him of running a diploma mill and shut him down.
He moved to Phoenix which falls under a different regional accrediting body and started over, gaining accreditation within five years.
The University of Phoenix has functioned largely in the West and Southwest. But that began changing rapidly after the December 1994 public offering of shares of its parent company, the Apollo Group, on the Nasdaq exchange. Started at $2 a share, it is today trading at over $40. As a result, Mr. Sperling, as Apollo's chairman and chief executive, is worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
Driven by Mr. Sperling's vision of a national for-profit university, Phoenix campuses have recently opened in Florida, Louisiana, Michigan, Oregon and Washington.
"We're moving inexorably eastward," Mr. Sperling said. "As you go east, the barriers against outside universities get higher until you get to New York, where they are nearly insurmountable. But we'll overcome them, too."
Last summer, after a lobbying campaign, Apollo persuaded the Pennsylvania Legislature to revoke its ban on for-profit universities. It will soon apply for licensing in the state.
"Other institutions perceive them as aggressive, in-your-face," said Dr. Steven Crow, executive director of the Commission on Institutions of Higher Education of the North-Central Association of Colleges and Schools, the Chicago group that has accredited Phoenix since 1978.
"They are also not very collegial, bashing traditional education," Dr. Crow said. "They move into places real fast and real hard, and all of a sudden everyone is trying to maintain a niche."
Sometimes that can backfire. In Michigan last year, the University of Phoenix asked the Ford Motor Company for space in its training quarters.
Peter Stockmann, who runs the quarters, said he was happy to rent to Phoenix as he had done to other companies. But within a few months, he said, advertisements run in the area made it look as if the university was being sponsored by Ford, rather than simply renting space from it.
Ford executives felt used, Mr. Stockmann said, and severed the relationship.
The head of Phoenix in Michigan, Sarah Serra, said there had been no effort to imply a relationship that did not exist.
The contretemps does not seem to have hurt Phoenix's expansion in Michigan, where it has nearly 2,000 students after only 18 months. In Florida, the university has found quick success partly because the population growth of the state has overburdened state universities unable to handle the demand.
The evidence around the country and a visit to several classes suggest that while Phoenix may not be a beacon of scholarship or a leader in community service, it takes its product -- adult education intended to serve corporations -- seriously. Students seem satisfied and instructors return frequently.
Dr. Crow, the accrediting officer, said that traditional criteria for judging universities, like the percentage of full-time faculty members, the breadth of its libraries and the number of seat hours per course for students, might be outdated, especially for institutions that cater to working adults.
All of which pleases Phoenix officials who have even begun acquiring a touch of academic credibility by bringing on board a few more traditional academics.
One such professor is Jorge Klor de Alva, an anthropologist and philosopher who left a professorship at Princeton University for an endowed chair at the University of California at Berkeley and is now leaving there to become a vice president at Apollo.
Dr. Klor de Alva said it was not money but a new frontier that drew him to Apollo.
"Academia is a calling, a closed system," Dr. Klor de Alva said. "But at Apollo we are seeking to address real needs in the real world. We're erasing the moment in life when you either make it as a student or you don't. This is a second-chance outfit geared to an expanding world economy. Right now there are not many second chances offered out there. The University of Phoenix is at the very center of a new frontier of redefining higher education. And I think it is unstoppable. The genie is out of the bottle."

 BODY:

CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN
During a visit to the Summit Child Care Center yesterday, she spoke of her commitment to issues concerning women.

Those are issues that are not just of interest to women, they are of interest to everyone in the state of New Jersey."
