HEADLINE: Unions Flexing Muscles For McGreevey Campaign

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN By MELODY PETERSEN

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Hundreds of union members rallied at the foot of the State House steps today, cheering as their leaders vowed to unseat Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in what they say will be their largest political effort in decades.
An estimated 400 people, most of them state workers, cheered wildly as Mrs. Whitman's Democratic opponent, State Senator James E. McGreevey, took the stage. But the crowd's energy seemed to stem not so much from their support for Mr. McGreevey as their anger at Governor Whitman, a Republican who has cut the state work force by 3,300 jobs and hired private companies to replace some of those workers. 
 While several small labor unions have endorsed Mrs. Whitman, the spirited crowd today made it clear that it would be Mr. McGreevey who would soon benefit from the statewide unions' plan to run a coordinated "get out the vote" effort involving hundreds of labor volunteers and paid for with hundreds of thousands of dollars of union dues.
"The labor movement in this state has never been together like this before," said Charles Wowkanech, president of the state's A.F.L.-C.I.O. "And let me tell you something: On Nov. 4, we're going to have a Governor that the labor force supports."
While Mr. McGreevey basked in his labor support, Mrs. Whitman spent much of her day and evening courting women's votes. Tonight, 1,500 women paid $100 each to attend a fund-raiser at the East Brunswick Hilton. At the gala, the Governor recounted how she had delivered on her earlier promises to create jobs, cut taxes and make the streets safer.
"We've been trying to deliver on those promises," she said, "and we've been shattering the glass ceiling as we've been doing it."
Mrs. Whitman said that 37 percent of her political appointments were women. "I didn't appoint them because they were women," she said. "I appointed them because they were the best."
Earlier in the day, she went to a child-care center in Summit to highlight the endorsements she has received from women's political advocacy groups. She toured the center with United States Senator Olympia J. Snowe, a Republican from Maine.
Jeanine LaRue, the founding president of the New Jersey Women's Summit, said, "In record numbers, this Governor has appointed women to cabinet positions, exploding the myth that it's difficult to find qualified women to perform in high-level positions in government." The Summit had endorsed Mrs. Whitman's opponent, Gov. Jim Florio, in 1993.
Mrs. Whitman also received the endorsement of the Medical Society of New Jersey. It was the first time the group had endorsed a candidate for Governor in its 231-year history.
Mr. McGreevey started his day with a fund-raiser in Philadelphia and a speech at a breakfast meeting with 100 Jewish leaders from across the state in Livingston, before heading to the labor rally in Trenton.
In recent years, labor unions in New Jersey and across the country have become increasingly active in political campaigns. Organized labor spent millions of dollars across the nation last year, hoping to help Democrats regain control of Congress. In New Jersey, for example, organized labor helped put Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, just over the top in his race against Richard A. Zimmer for United States Senate.
Already, the Communications Workers of America Local 1032, which represents 2,500 state transportation workers, has paid for radio ads attacking Mrs. Whitman for cutting back on the maintenance of state highways and for hiring a private company to count state-owned billboards.
Other radio ads are likely, union leaders said today. But they said that they could not afford to pay for television commercials and that most of their effort would go into organizing volunteers to run phone banks and get voters to the polls on Election Day. National labor organizations are also lending support to Mr. McGreevey's campaign.
"TV commercials won't win this thing," Mr. Wowkanech said. "Our strength is here today," he said, waving out toward the crowd. "What you will see on Nov. 4 is the best labor operation the state has ever known."
Not all union workers support Mr. McGreevey. On Monday, the former president of the state's A.F.L.-C.I.O., Charles H. Marciante, endorsed Mrs. Whitman. Mr. Marciante said today that the Governor had helped workers across the state by creating jobs, especially in southern New Jersey, where a new $330 million tunnel and road project will soon be built in Atlantic City. The project, which will be partly paid for with state funds, will provide access to planned casinos in the Marina district.
Mrs. Whitman has also been endorsed by several smaller unions representing thousands of law enforcement officers, nurses and construction workers across the state.
The Governor says her 30 percent cut in the state income tax rate has spurred the state's economic recovery and created thousands of jobs. Indeed, the state has its lowest unemployment rate in seven years and its job growth is now outpacing that of New York and Connecticut.
But many of the state's new jobs do not pay as much as the manufacturing jobs that were lost during the recession. And a recent Rutgers University study found that the average wages for most jobs in the state did not keep pace with inflation from 1990 to 1995.
When asked why he did not support the Governor, Jim Marketti, the president of Local 1032, responded with a question: "She created jobs? For who? Hamburger flippers?"

HEADLINE: Newark Hopes for Revival Far Beyond Arts Center

SERIES: DOWNTOWN GAMBLE: A special report.

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
Gloria F. Cohn, a widow from Middlesex County, N.J., has not ventured into this battle-scarred city for years. But she recently sent in $108 for tickets for herself and her granddaughter to a series of Sunday afternoon family dance programs and plays in the heart of downtown.
The lure is the new $180 million New Jersey Performing Arts Center, a glimmering glass-shelled structure that is opening on Oct. 18 on a formerly desolate renewal tract in sight of the towers of Manhattan, across the bleak industrial flats and the Hudson River. 
 In one of the country's great urban gambles, Newark is pinning a good part of its battered hopes for a comeback on the arts, specifically on this arklike complex of concert hall and theater, rehearsal space and food concessions. Planners hope it will set off a downtown commercial and residential revival in a city still struggling to recover from the shattering riots of 30 years ago.
"Those who said the performing arts center could never be built are now squabbling over tickets," said Lawrence P. Goldman, the center's president and guiding force, who came from the vice presidency of Carnegie Hall in 1989 to steer the project through the crucial last eight years of arduous conception and on-time construction.
Newark is hardly alone in seeking a salvation through the arts. With mixed results, dozens of cities, from New York with its emblematic Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, to San Jose, Calif., have built or are planning major arts projects in hopes of improving civic fortunes and polishing civic images. Every one of the nation's 50 largest cities, in fact, uses the arts to support community development, the National Endowment for the Arts recently reported.
But Newark may be asking more of the arts than anyplace else. There is little new besides the performing arts center to draw people like Ms. Cohn downtown, although 85,000 people commute here each day for jobs and higher education programs. The city continues to suffer from a reputation as a dangerous place of intractable problems where each succeeding mayoral administration seems to attract its own Federal and state investigations.
Yet the smooth completion of the project and extensive efforts to knit it into the fabric of the city have raised hopes that Newark, using the arts to create a critical mass to set off further development, may finally be turning around. Significantly, the effort is being pushed not only with city, state and Federal money, but also by a loyal band of hometown boosters, powerful philanthropists like Raymond G. Chambers, and corporate citizens like the Prudential Insurance Company of America, whose fortunes have been bound up with the city's for 120 years.
"A city doesn't function if it's open only eight hours a day," said Arthur F. Ryan, Prudential's chairman and chief executive officer.
 
The Audience
Attracting Crowds, By Careful Design
Perhaps the biggest unanswered question is whether the arts center's audiences will come in just for performances and then head home again or be enticed to linger and spend money. To improve the odds, the arts center, paneled by its architect, Barton Myers, in pearwood that glows warmly through the see-through facade, was situated to foment milling crowds, a bustle that planners say translates to safety.
The design does not rely on bridges, flyovers or tunnels to channel pedestrian flow; from the renovated 1,100-car underground parking garage beneath Military Park, patrons will have to ascend to the street and cross to the arts center. Inside, in broad and detailed ways, efforts were made to attract and appeal to a wide spectrum of patrons. Bathrooms were tiled in interpretations of African kente cloth patterns. Moneymaking catering areas were included: the first bat mitzvah service has already been booked, for $10,000, for a board member's daughter, in 1999.
A new 10-stop, $1 bus loop was created, linking the arts center to attractions like the Newark Museum, the Newark Public Library, Pennsylvania Station and restaurant-lined Ferry Street in the heavily Portuguese Ironbound district. Streets and highways were festooned with hundreds of directional signs to prevent what Mr. Goldman called " 'Bonfire of the Vanities' syndrome," the terror of being lost in an ominously derelict neighborhood.
"This is the big idea: to change the way people think about Newark," said Mr. Goldman, 51. "It's not the place where you get your car stolen; it's where you go to concerts."
The programming, too, was blended to the presumed tastes of a broadly diverse audience of 4.6 million New Jerseyans within 25 miles of Newark, the Portuguese of the Ironbound, suburban professionals and inner-city workers, blacks and whites, serious music lovers and schoolchildren. Classical stars booked for the premiere season include Jessye Norman, Midori, Yevgeny Kissin, Andre Watts, the Tokyo String Quartet, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra.
The opening-night gala will feature the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, which is the center's resident company, the soprano Kathleen Battle, the American Ballet Theater and the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Savion Glover, Chita Rivera and others. The program will be taped by PBS for a national "Great Performances" broadcast, perhaps in February. The debut concert of the New Jersey Symphony on Oct. 21 will also be taped by PBS for national broadcast later.
 
The Plans
Sharing Hopes And Burdens
Like projects in other cities around the country, this one began with a study of the needs of arts organizations, commissioned in 1986 by Gov. Thomas H. Kean. After considering suburban sites, consultants at C. W. Shaver & Company recommended Newark, a decision lobbied for by the new administration of Mayor Sharpe James. The original plan for the 12-acre downtown renewal site called for three arts buildings -- a concert hall, a theater and a smaller stage for dance -- as well as a hotel-office complex.
Instead, the project was reconfigured as one building containing a hall of up to 2,750 seats, named Prudential Hall for its largest donor, a 514-seat theater endowed by the Victoria Foundation, and rehearsal spaces, community rooms and reception areas.
Mr. Goldman has taken pains to announce that any effort to win contracts through political connections would be met by disqualifications. In fact, nothing has emerged to cast doubt on the propriety of any part of the project, no small victory, perhaps, in a city where the top officials have frequently been tainted by scandal.
Of the center's $180 million cost, the largest share, more than $100 million, came from the state, with the city giving $10 million, the Federal Government almost $5 million, and corporations, individuals and foundations contributing $20 million, $18 million and $15 million respectively. The $180 million includes $6 million of the first season's $20 million operating budget that is not covered by projected revenues from ticket sales, parking, concessions and gift shop purchases. The $20 million is the seventh largest arts center operating budget in the country.
A week before the opening, the center had sold nearly 91,500 individual and subscription tickets of the 350,000 available for the season through June, Mr. Goldman said, although not all the performances had yet been put on sale. The symphony in particular has benefited, with subscription sales nearly quadrupling to 10,000 from last year, when it performed in Symphony Hall, a former 1920's Shriners' temple on Broad Street in a frayed part of town.
Mayor James said the success stands to reason. "We have the best mousetrap, and when you build the best mousetrap, people will come," he said.
But others have their doubts. One persistent skeptic has been Msgr. William Linder, director of the New Community Corporation, a nonprofit public development effort that has built 3,000 units of housing in Newark since 1973. "It's taking a lot of resources," he said of the arts center, contending that the $180 million might have been better spent on neighborhoods and on the city's schools, which have been taken over by the state after persistently poor performance.
 
The City
Hoping the Glow Will Radiate
David Nasaw, chairman of the history department at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York in Manhattan and an expert on urban entertainment, said that whether the center fostered further development depended on its environment.
"What's around it?" he asked. "If nothing, nothing's going to happen."
For now, the landscape around the arts center is bleak, a vista of parking lots and yawning open tracts an uninspiring 10-minute walk from Pennsylvania Station and the Gateway Towers office complex that marks the very heart of downtown.
Still, Charles F. Cummings, assistant director for state outreach at the Newark Public Library, and the city historian, said: "I feel the electricity. I'm not a civic booster. I'm a historian, and I can tell the difference between truth and farce."
One truth, say city officials, is that crime is down, as elsewhere in the country. The drop in crime here has been 17 percent over the last two years, they said, adding that car theft, in which Newark long led the nation, has particularly plummeted in response to a police crackdown.
There have been some promising signs of downtown real estate activity, although some projects would probably have gone ahead anyway without the promise of the center. Within half a mile, at Broad and Bridge Streets, the city has committed itself to building a new $22 million minor league baseball stadium of 6,000 seats for its revived Newark Bears. Nearer by, Rutgers University recently broke ground for a new $55 million law school building.
Some long-empty landmark buildings may also be stirring to life. Miles Berger, a developer who began assembling a portfolio of venerable downtown properties before the arts center took form, said he planned to put a 200-car garage in the basement of the former Hahne's department store, dating from 1901, and remodel the upper four floors for retail, office and perhaps residential use.
"We already see what the art center can do here," he said, citing the excitement of a pre-opening street party. "Crowds like that haven't been in Newark on a Sunday in 30 years."
The challenge of reviving Newark becomes clear within blocks of the old commercial hub at Broad and Market Streets, itself a pentimento of urban decline. Along Broad Street, near the incongruously gilded dome of the Beaux-Arts City Hall, stands the shell of Newark Renaissance Mall, mired in bankruptcy and illusory as the 121-story building that its developer, Harry Grant, promised Newark more than a decade ago before dropping out of sight. Steel-shuttered liquor stores, furniture-for-credit outlets and storefront churches line the forlorn grid of streets off Springfield Avenue.
It was here, starting on July 12, 1967, that long simmering racial grievances boiled over at the sight of two white police officers dragging a black cabdriver into a Central Ward precinct house. For the next five days, rioters battled more than 6,000 National Guard troops and state police officers in one of the deadliest outbreaks in the nation's summer of violence. Twenty-six people died here, hundreds were injured and 1,500 were arrested before order was restored.
The psychic damage ran deep, a harsh blow for a once thriving city known for its industrial muscle and swinging jazz clubs. The population, which stood at just over 400,000 in 1967 dwindled over the years by almost 150,000, as blacks and whites decamped for suburbia. Today, Newark's population is about 58 percent black, according to city figures, and the fastest-growing ethnic group is Hispanic.
 
The Inspiration
Following the Lead Of Other Cities
For inspiration on renewal in recent years, Newark looked principally to Cleveland and Pittsburgh, two former industrial engines that had fallen into decline and cast their hopes on a cultural renaissance.
In Cleveland, the first American city to go bankrupt since the Depression, the downtown revival began slowly in the 1970's thanks to the Playhouse Square Foundation. It refurbished three 1920's theaters into a new performance center that soon drew other arts groups into its orbit, including, today, the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame and the Great Lakes Science Center, as well as a Riviera of shops and cafes on the once dispiriting Cuyahoga River waterfront.
Pittsburgh, having suffered the decline of its steel industry, followed a similar trajectory, with the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust kicking off a revival by purchasing an old movie palace. Converted into the Benedum Center for the Performing Arts, it became, in 1987, the $42 million home for the city's ballet, theater and opera companies.
Closer to home, the Brooklyn Academy of Music is shoring up its long-depressed Fort Greene neighborhood. For years, arts-savvy New Yorkers thronged to the academy's Next Wave productions, then streamed home again. Now, however, two fancy new restaurants are being planned, a shopping mall called Atlantic Center is flourishing, and a development corridor has begun to grow toward the Metrotech commercial complex about five blocks away in downtown Brooklyn.
Harvey Lichtenstein, the academy's president, said Newark might succeed faster, because "they have the whole city behind them."
His only advice, he said, is to be progressive and "establish an identity," not just present what others do. "Do things that bring in younger groups," he said. "Keep alive."
The regenerative power of arts projects has not been lost on other cities. But not all projects have been unmitigated successes.
"It fails when cities just declare an artificial art district," said Samina Quraeshi, former head of the design program of the National Endowment of the Arts and now a consultant in Boston.
What are Newark's chances?
"We Are Building It, They Will Come," read the T-shirts of construction workers putting the final touches on the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. But will they?
One market singled out is the thriving Portuguese community along Ferry Street in the rail-encircled district known as the Ironbound, south of the arts center. Planners hope that the new bus loop will bring patrons of the street's many Portuguese restaurants the half mile or so to the arts center, in part through ethnic programming like the Gulbenkian Orchestra of Portugal and the mournful Cape Verdean singer Cesaria Evora. But Licinio Cruz, a Portuguese lawyer and contractor is skeptical. "I don't know," he said. "Portuguese are not art center types."
Gloria Cohn, too, is taking a cautious approach. The 71-year-old widow from Monroe Township, N.J., said she had not had an opportunity to take the hour's drive to Newark in many years. When she and her granddaughter attend those Sunday-afternoon performances, "we may go in a little early and go to one of the restaurants on the premises," she said. "And then we'll probably go home right afterwards."
Emanuel S. Kan of Teaneck said, "I'll still go to New York for the plays." But he expects to spend plenty of time at the new center, he said. He not only bought tickets for six musical performances with his wife, Helen Karls-Ruher, but invested $10,000 in bonds that financed the center's construction. For Mr. Kan, 70, who is president of Olde Dutch International, a decorative housewares company in Saddle Brook, there are no compunctions about visiting Newark. The couple already dine regularly in the Ironbound.
Earl D. Shaw, a physics professor at the Rutgers-Newark campus, and his wife, Erin, a state employee, had no qualms about signing up with friends for a six-show dance series at $170. Mr. Shaw, 60, said he felt comfortable downtown and often met his wife after work for dinner in the Ironbound before returning to their home in Harding Township in Morris County.
"I am an emotional supporter of this project," Mr. Shaw said. "I have great hopes for Newark, and I am hoping the center will have the kind of success that Newark deserves and needs. The riots were 30 years ago. It's time to move beyond that."
 
A Hall for Newark

HEADLINE: AIDS Experts Leave Journal After Studies Are Criticized

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
Two internationally recognized AIDS experts are resigning from The New England Journal of Medicine's editorial board over the content and handling of articles criticizing the ethics of Federally financed studies of AIDS treatments in third-world countries.
The countries seek a drug regimen less costly than those used in the United States to thwart transmission of the AIDS virus from mothers to infants. In trials involving more than 12,000 infected pregnant women in Africa, Thailand and the Dominican Republic, some women receive the drug AZT, which has worked in studies in the United States, while others receive dummy pills. 
 The journal's attack on the studies, which compares them to the infamous Tuskegee experiment, has led to wide discussion, including harsh criticism of the journal itself, and focuses attention on the role of the 25-member board and the two who are resigning in protest, Drs. David Ho and Catherine M. Wilfert. The two objected to not being consulted before publication of an attack on research that could save lives, and Dr. Ho worried that the attack itself could jeopardize future research on experimental AIDS vaccines.
Dr. Jerome P. Kassirer, the journal's chief editor, said that the board's function was to give advice on broad issues and suggestions of authors for editorials and reviews, but that the board was not routinely consulted.
Dr. Ho, a virologist at the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center in Manhattan, and Dr. Wilfert, a pediatrician at Duke University in Durham, N.C., are the board's chief advisers on AIDS.
A third board member, Dr. Richard P. Wenzel, chairman of medicine at the Medical College of Virginia in Richmond, said in an interview that he agreed with much of Dr. Wilfert's criticism but was withholding a decision about resigning until after the issue was discussed at the board's annual meeting in December.
Drs. Ho and Wilfert said in separate interviews that they had resigned independently largely because the journal had not consulted them before publishing an editorial that likened the new experiments to the Tuskegee experiment, in which poor black men suffering from syphilis were left untreated.
Dr. Ho, Dr. Wilfert and others have taken issue with the Tuskegee comparison in part because the subjects in the AZT studies were told that some would get dummy pills. In the Tuskegee study the men were not told that penicillin had became available while the study was under way, and so did not know that effective treatment was being withheld.
A full-time staff of editors produces the weekly journal, but Dr. Ho said that "the reason you have an editorial board to help with policy is to get some input when you have major issues like this one, and that clearly did not take place."
In the editorial process, "it was clear that my role was not crucial," he said.
Dr. Ho said he was deeply concerned about how the critical editorial would affect the future of studies to evaluate experimental AIDS vaccines in developing countries.
Dr. Wilfert said she was resigning because the journal published the editorial and another critical article on Sept. 18 without presenting the other side.
Because her name was on the masthead, "it implied that I agreed with it when I didn't," she said.
"It is an error and bad policy" and "a grievous misuse of the journal's power," Dr. Wilfert said.
"Those are not decisions that a few people in the editorial office ought to feel comfortable with, because no one small group of persons, no matter who they are, can cover the waterfront well enough" in translating health policy and practice in developed countries to those in developing countries, Dr. Wilfert said.
Dr. Wilfert said she was resigning effective Dec. 31 in order to "vent my spleen" at the annual meeting. She said she feared that if she resigned sooner "the issue might not be discussed at the meeting."
The journal published a rebuttal two weeks after its attack. It was written by Dr. Harold Varmus, the head of the National Institutes of Health, and Dr. David Satcher, the head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and would not have been printed so quickly had not Dr. Varmus received a leaked copy of the editorial before publication, those involved in the dispute said.
Dr. Marcia Angell, the journal's executive editor, wrote the editorial.
Dr. Wenzel said that if the authors of the critical articles "really knew the facts they would have done a better job."
Dr. Kassirer said he regretted Dr. Ho's and Dr. Wilfert's decisions to resign and was unaware of any similar resignations at the journal, which was founded in 1812.
The editorial board members, who have no set term, Dr. Kassirer said, are named by the chief editor, who can elect not to renew them as members and has done so.
Dr. Kassirer said that Dr. Wilfert "wanted to have prior consultation of the material in the journal, which is just not acceptable to me because prior consultation is not what the editorial board is for."
He said the journal intentionally did not strive to present all sides of an issue "because if you did you would end up with a kind of Talmudic discussion in which readers could end up having no particular view one way or the other and it would be rather boring."
Dr. Varmus, the National Institutes of Health director, said that "The New England Journal of Medicine is trying to attract more attention by making political, ethical, philosophical and economic statements that have traditionally not been in that journal in such an inflammatory way."
But he also said that "before you inflame the public and attract so much attention, you might want to ask experts on the editorial board what they think."
The Massachusetts Medical Society owns The New England Journal of Medicine. Dr. Ronald A. Arky, a Harvard Medical School professor who heads the society's publications committee to which Dr. Kassirer reports, said he learned of the resignations last Friday.
"The committee will want to hear from the editor about the resignations" at their next meeting in early November, Dr. Arky said.

HEADLINE: Council Votes to Increase Fines Sharply for Excessive Noise

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY By VIVIAN S. TOY

 BODY:
For New Yorkers who have long complained about noisy nightclubs, jackhammers on overtime, shrieking car alarms and howling dogs, the City Council offered a remedy yesterday that members said they hoped would provide more relief than even a good set of earplugs.
Calling their measure a quality-of-life victory that should lower the volume in many neighborhoods, Council members voted to double and triple the fines handed out to repeat offenders among the city's noisemakers. 
 A dog that will not stop barking could cost its owner up to $525, while the proprietor of a noisy bar could face a $24,000 fine after repeated violations of the city's noise code.
Bar and cabaret owners said the increased fines were onerous and could sound the death knell for many businesses. Some Council members opposed the measure, saying it was too broad and could result in unfair summonses.
But residents of some of New York's noisiest neighborhoods said it might provide a chance for them to get a good night's sleep. Rhonda Santamour, who lives on the Upper East Side, said there were nights when music from a bar across the street was so loud that "it's as if the drummer was in my living room up here on the seventh floor."
The bill, which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to sign, increases fines for repeated noise violations. The code covers noise offenses that range from barking dogs and cranked-up stereos to motorcycle exhaust pipes and thumping music from dance clubs.
Fines for first-time violators will remain the same, but for repeat offenders, the fine would double for a second violation and triple for a third or subsequent violation.
The law will continue to be enforced by inspectors from the Department of Environmental Protection and police officers, who respond to citizen complaints and measure noise levels with noise meters.
"New York City is never going to be a sleepy town where you hear the crickets chirping," said Councilman A. Gifford Miller, who introduced the bill and drafted it with the Department of Environmental Protection. "But I think we can make it a little quieter, a little saner."
Mr. Miller, who represents part of Manhattan's Upper East Side, said his office had fielded numerous complaints from residents who were fed up with noise from local bars and large heating and air-conditioning units that emit loud hums.
Mr. Miller said that many businesses consider the existing fines a cost of doing business but that he hoped the higher fines would encourage businesses to address complaints seriously and pay for necessary renovations to insulate neighbors from the noise.
Christine Pellicano, who in the last decade has watched her neighborhood at Second Avenue and 89th Street evolve from a relatively quiet residential area to a booming bar scene, applauded the bill.
Ms. Pellicano said she hoped that the higher fines would force bars to lower the volume and eventually defuse some of the rowdiness that spills onto the sidewalk.
"I don't think people really grasp the severity of this," she said. "We're not just saying 'shush!,' like we're in a library, because it's not just the noise that's a problem, it's the crowds that it generates and the kind of environment that it creates."
Mike Cafey, the manager of Kelly's Korner, a bar down the street from Ms. Pellicano's home, said the increased fines could shut down small businesses like his. "In order to keep people here and have a good time, you've got to have music," he said. "This is just going to kill business."
Members of the New York Nightlife Association, a coalition of about 50 licensed cabarets and music clubs, said they objected to the bill because it did not differentiate between clubs in residential areas and ones in manufacturing or commercial areas.
"We're not saying nightclubs should be exempt from noise codes," said Robert Bookman, the association's lawyer. "But there has to be a certain amount of tolerance to industries that are important to New York's economy. The city that never sleeps gets its name from licensed nightclubs."
Mark Linial, the owner of Reminisce Bar and Lounge at 73d Street and Second Avenue, said he feared that the new law would "give people a simple way to make a complaint about us even if the complaint has nothing to do with the noise level."
Ms. Santamour, who lives on 73d Street across from Reminisce, said that the bar's managers had been dismissive about her complaints and that she had filed a formal complaint with the city.
She said she had high hopes for the increased fines. "If the pocketbook is where it hurts, then that's what we have available to us," she said. "I think it's a great start."
Mr. Linial said he had spent more than $25,000 on soundproofing measures, like hanging a floating ceiling and installing insulated doors. "This law gives people who are out to hurt us, people who maybe just don't like the kind of people who come to our reggae parties, a new weapon," he said.
The noise code generally limits construction noise to daylight hours, except in emergency situations. It also specifies that burglar alarms must stop ringing after 15 minutes and car alarms should wail for no more than 5 minutes.
The Council voted, 44 to 4, for the higher fines, which will take effect 60 days after the Mayor holds a public hearing and signs the bill. The members who voted against the bill were Herbert E. Berman, Stephen DiBrienza, Una C. Clarke and Annette M. Robinson, all from Brooklyn.
Mr. Berman said he felt the bill was oppressive because it encompassed some situations that could not be helped, such as car alarms that sound off when the owners are not nearby.
"We can't guarantee people that their cars won't be broken into, but now we're going to punish people for trying to protect their cars," he said.
Ms. Robinson said she feared that selective enforcement would unfairly target businesses in her district, which includes Bedford Stuyvesant and Crown Heights.
Who determines what's excessive?" she said. "Standards sometimes can vary based on culture and I'm worried about inspectors or police officers who aren't familiar with the community practicing unequal distribution of the fines."
Randy M. Mastro, Deputy Mayor for Operations, said fears about uneven enforcement were unfounded. "This is an important quality-of-life issue and we intend to fairly, responsibly and comprehensively enforce the law throughout the city."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Surge in Growth Predicted for Europe

BYLINE: Bloomberg News Bloomberg News

 BODY:
European economic growth will surge in 1998 to the fastest pace in nearly a decade, putting most European Union countries on course to adopt the planned common currency, the European Commission said yesterday. The forecast showed the economy of the 15-nation union expanding 3 percent next year, beating the 2.6 percent pace of the United States, according to its own predictions, for the first time since 1991.

HEADLINE: Teamsters' Union Staff Members Cite Pressure For Donations

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Several members of the teamsters' union told a Congressional subcommittee today that union officials engaged in an array of questionable tactics to help re-elect President Ron Carey, including pressuring union staff members to make donations to his campaign.
Three staff organizers for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters testified that they were pressured to give more than $1,000 each last year to the Carey campaign or face possible loss of their jobs. Describing another practice barred by Federal labor law, a teamsters' member from Texas said he saw a half-dozen staff organizers doing campaign work for Mr. Carey during their regular work hours. 
 Vincent R. Hickman, a staff member in the union's airline division, said he was asked to donate $100 a month. "I didn't appreciate being told how much I had to donate, but I didn't say anything because of the fear of retaliation, and of course I needed my job." he said.
Although accusations of improper fund-raising have swirled around the election of Mr. Carey almost from the moment he defeated James P. Hoffa, the statements by the three aides today mark the first time union members have testified publicly that they were pressured to donate to Mr. Carey's campaign. Labor experts said it was common for union officials to urge staff members to contribute to their campaigns. These experts noted that last year's teamsters' campaign was by far the most expensive in union history.
At the hearing of the oversight subcommittee of the House Committee on Education and the Workforce, Republican lawmakers sought to explore improprieties in last year's teamsters' election that went beyond the much-publicized diversion of money from the union's treasury into Mr. Carey's campaign.
For much of the hearing, Representative Peter Hoekstra, the Michigan Republican who heads the subcommittee, faulted the Federal Government for failing to adequately supervise the election, conducted with $17 million in Federal money.
The Government agreed to finance the 1996 election as part of its long-standing effort to make the teamsters' union more democratic and eliminate mob influence.
In August, a Federal election overseer ordered a new election because of improper fund-raising for Mr. Carey's campaign.
Nancy Coleman, a teamsters' spokeswoman, called the Congressional hearing an effort to discredit the labor movement. "This is a circus for anti-labor Republicans," she said. "I felt there was an unfounded understanding by these people that if they didn't give money, they'd be retaliated against. That's ridiculous, because none of these people have been retaliated against."
But Barbara Dusina, an organizer with the teamsters, asserted that she has not received a raise recently because she donated less to the Carey campaign than she had been asked. Ms. Dusina said she contributed $50 a month, even though she had been urged to give $100 a month as well as pay $250 for a fund-raiser and $150 for a Carey rally.
"There was an unspoken message that if any staff person did not contribute, they would be unemployed after a Carey victory," she said.
The union released a letter sent by Mr. Carey to Rep. Hoekstra, that said, "If these people say that they fear retaliation, they are not telling the truth -- and it calls into question the reliability of any information they could give your subcommittee."
Another subcommittee witness, Dane Passo, a Chicago truck driver, testified that he was was badly beaten by a Carey supporter who operates runs a large teamsters' local in Chicago. Mr. Passo faulted Mr. Carey for not removing that official from office. Teamsters' leaders said Mr. Carey was waiting for the official to exhaust appeals of his assault and battery conviction.
To end the four-and-a-half hour hearing, the committee interrogated the former supervisor of the teamsters' political action committee in an effort to prove that Mr. Carey knew about or cooperated in illegal fund-raising schemes. But the witness, Gregory Mullenholz, did not provide any solid proof of that.
Mr. Mullenholz, who said he was fired for cooperating with the F.B.I., an assertion denied by Mr. Carey's aides, said he found several of the union's donations to other groups suspicious. He said he questioned why the union contributed $475,000 to a get-out-the-vote drive by Citizen Action, a liberal grass-roots group, when shortly beforehand the union's political action committee borrowed $300,000 from a bank.
When three former Carey campaign aides pleaded guilty in court last month, they described a scheme in which the union gave money to Citizen Action and some of that group's donors contributed to the Carey campaign.
Mr. Mullenholz said he also questioned donations that the union made to Project Vote and the National Council of Senior Citizens, two groups that helped Democratic get-out-the-vote efforts in last year's Congressional elections. He said William Hamilton, the union's political director, had recommended those contributions, but Mr. Carey's executive assistant had rejected them.
Mr. Mullenholz said he understood that Mr. Hamilton then went directly to Mr. Carey to gain approval. Mr. Mullenholz stopped short of saying Mr. Carey was familiar with any scheme to contribute money to other groups in exchange for having their donors give to the Carey campaign.
Mr. Mullenholz testified that he saw notes that Mr. Hamilton sent to persuade Mr. Carey to donate to Project Vote and the senior citizens' group. But Mr. Mullenholz declined to say whether those notes showed that Mr. Carey had been informed of any improper scheme.
Denying any wrongdoing, Mr. Carey has said he was a victim of his aides' misdeeds. Mr. Hamilton has also denied any wrongdoing.

HEADLINE: U.S. Respects Brazil, Clinton Assures Latin Giant

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Oct. 14

 BODY:
President Clinton had a simple message for Brazil today, and he delivered it over and over, in several different ways: The United States takes this country seriously. Really. It doesn't want to dictate relations in the hemisphere, but just to do more business.
Appearing at a joint news conference here with the Brazilian President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, Mr. Clinton tried repeatedly to dispel longstanding Brazilian suspicions of American attitudes. In answer to a Brazilian journalist's question, he said that he did not feel threatened by the emergence of Brazil as a hemispheric powerhouse. 
 "I actually support the emergence of countries to a greater role of influence and responsibilities, as long as they share our basic values," he said, citing commitments to democracy, open trade and environmental protection.
This is the first visit of his Presidency to Brazil, and Mr. Clinton appeared anxiious to play catch-up. He and his aides have repeatedly noted that the European Union is rushing in to capitalize on Brazil's economy.
But Mr. Clinton did not only play the supplicant. He gently nudged Brazil toward joining an effort to reduce greenhouse gases. As nations prepare for an international conference on global warming in December, a central dispute is whether developing countries should share the burden of cutting emissions when developed ones have enjoyed most of the benefits of profligately polluting.
Still, while he said that "we must all participate" in reducing such gases, Mr. Clinton emphasized that he did not expect Brazil's efforts to interfere with its economic growth. "The United States would never knowingly make any suggestion that would undermine the growth of Brazil or any other country," he said.
For his part, Mr. Cardoso repeatedly praised his relations with Mr. Clinton and Brazil's with the United States, updating the American saw about General Motors: "We feel what's good for Brazil is good for the United States, and what's good for the United States is good for Brazil as well."
But he made clear that Brazil would continue expanding trade with all comers, whether or not Mr. Clinton ultimately wins so-called fast-track authority from Congress to conduct trade negotiations. "If there is going to be this sort of a policy or not is the United States' problem," Mr. Cardoso said.
Not all Brazilians were as welcoming as Mr. Cardoso, however. A handful of protesters here pelted the President's limousine with manure.
Mr. Clinton, bowing to a point of Brazilian pride, made the clearest statement to date that the United States recognizes the importance of Mercosur, a regional trade bloc in which Brazil is the biggest member. "I support Mercosur," Mr. Clinton said, adding that any new free-trade zone would be "consistent with Mercosur and the leadership and role of Brazil."
Mr. Clinton said he expected Brazil to sell more to Europe. "I don't feel threatened by it, I just want to make sure we're fully competing," he said. "And if we don't fully compete, it will be our fault, not yours and Europe's." But he took a dig at the Europeans, noting that the United States had lower tariffs than the European Union.
The two leaders said today that, three years after Mr. Clinton won agreement from Latin American leaders for a hemispheric free trade zone by 2005, the two countries would finally begin negotiations toward that goal next year.
But Mr. Cardoso and other Brazilian officials indicated that they wished to move slowly in lowering some barriers to foreign competitors. "We are not prepared to go for a new round of tariff reduction commitments by 2000," said Pedro Malana, the Finance Minister.

HEADLINE: University for Working Adults Shatters Mold

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER

DATELINE: PHOENIX

 BODY:
Just off the shimmering asphalt ribbons of Interstate 10, minutes from the Phoenix airport, in a zone of windshield and transport companies, sits a set of brick office buildings that contains what many view as the biggest challenge to higher education in the United States today.
The name on the unassuming structures, the University of Phoenix, suggests a local college. But, like its setting, that is deceptive. 
 With 40,000 students, the University of Phoenix has grown into the largest private university in the nation, galloping ahead of such powerhouses as New York University and the University of Southern California.
But more significantly, it has done so using a new model consonant with the times, turning itself into a kind of H.M.O. of education: It is run as a for-profit business, paying taxes rather than accepting public subsidies; it rents space rather than buying buildings for its makeshift campuses across a dozen states; and its courses are standardized in shrink-wrap packages.
Phoenix has also chosen to do something else unusual. It accepts no one under the age of 23 and only those gainfully employed. Since 45 percent of higher-education students are 24 or older, Phoenix is tapping into an exploding and lucrative portion of a $200 billion higher-education market where costs have been widely seen as out of control.
"This is a very significant time in higher education," said Timothy J. McDonough, vice president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities. "Adult learning is skyrocketing. People don't understand that there is a market out there. Phoenix has grasped that very well."
It is unlikely that the Phoenix model will soon dominate higher education since there will long be a place for residential institutions for 18- to 22- year-olds where instruction is blended with socialization. But there is little doubt that Phoenix's practices, like keeping virtually no full-time faculty and stocking no libraries, are spreading and are a source of great worry to many colleges that benefit from tax subsidies yet still struggle financially.
"I was asked to speak at Rutgers recently about what we do and the response among the assembled faculty was telling," said Laura Palmer Noone, vice president for academic affairs at the University of Phoenix. "The reaction was divided into three groups. A few found what we do exciting, a second group dismissed us as a passing fad, and the last group looked at me like I was the antichrist, spelling the doom of life as they know it."
The University of Phoenix, which has been accredited for 20 years, is not a place to discover the eternal verities of the Western tradition. It offers B.A.'s and M.A.'s, mostly in business and in fields like information technology, health and education. While it is a leader in distance education, meaning course work over the Internet, most of its classes involve working professionals teaching other working professionals in classrooms.
Phoenix sets itself apart with its unwavering corporate orientation. Its advocates say that when, in the 1970's, the nation's economy began a shift to one based on information, corporations came to universities asking for help in updating and retraining employees but that the universities were slow to respond.
Many companies took matters into their own hands, setting up corporate universities of which there are now some 1,200. But none of them are accredited: they cannot offer degrees. The University of Phoenix, whose regional accreditation is accepted nationally, has therefore been able to sell itself as the best of both worlds.
Some 75 percent of Phoenix students are at least partly reimbursed by their companies for tuition, which, at about $6,500 a year, is somewhat higher than public universities but lower than most private ones. Classes are limited to 15 to 20 students, and there is a great deal of work in small groups.
Some of this has recently been going on at other universities as the need for income from adult students has become more pressing. But most extension programs tend to be institutional stepchildren. At Phoenix, it is all the university does.
"When I was looking around to get my M.B.A. in 1992, Arizona State did not offer evening classes the way the University of Phoenix did," said Ike Schneider of Alliant Food Service in Phoenix, who got his master of business administration there with an emphasis in technology management. "I went one evening a week, worked in small groups and was very satisfied."
The university is the creation of John G. Sperling, 76, a restless, plain-talking contrarian. Born to a Missouri sharecropping couple, Mr. Sperling discovered books while at sea as a merchant marine, returned to college in Oregon and ultimately earned a doctorate in economic history from Cambridge University in England. He started an academic career only to find it stifling.
While teaching at San Jose State University in the late 1960's, Mr. Sperling became involved in a project on juvenile delinquency, in which he brought teachers and police officers to campus for courses.
"We worked with them in small groups," he recalled in an interview, "and since these were adults with little patience for lectures, the instructors had to act more as facilitators than traditional professors. The students had a great deal to offer not only to one another but to the instructor. The students loved it and asked if they could turn the seminars into vehicles for obtaining B.A.'s and M.A.'s."
By 1973, Mr. Sperling had 2,500 paying students at several universities. But the regional accrediting body accused him of running a diploma mill and shut him down.
He moved to Phoenix which falls under a different regional accrediting body and started over, gaining accreditation within five years.
The University of Phoenix has functioned largely in the West and Southwest. But that began changing rapidly after the December 1994 public offering of shares of its parent company, the Apollo Group, on the Nasdaq exchange. Started at $2 a share, it is today trading at over $40. As a result, Mr. Sperling, as Apollo's chairman and chief executive, is worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
Driven by Mr. Sperling's vision of a national for-profit university, Phoenix campuses have recently opened in Florida, Louisiana, Michigan, Oregon and Washington.
"We're moving inexorably eastward," Mr. Sperling said. "As you go east, the barriers against outside universities get higher until you get to New York, where they are nearly insurmountable. But we'll overcome them, too."
Last summer, after a lobbying campaign, Apollo persuaded the Pennsylvania Legislature to revoke its ban on for-profit universities. It will soon apply for licensing in the state.
"Other institutions perceive them as aggressive, in-your-face," said Dr. Steven Crow, executive director of the Commission on Institutions of Higher Education of the North-Central Association of Colleges and Schools, the Chicago group that has accredited Phoenix since 1978.
"They are also not very collegial, bashing traditional education," Dr. Crow said. "They move into places real fast and real hard, and all of a sudden everyone is trying to maintain a niche."
Sometimes that can backfire. In Michigan last year, the University of Phoenix asked the Ford Motor Company for space in its training quarters.
Peter Stockmann, who runs the quarters, said he was happy to rent to Phoenix as he had done to other companies. But within a few months, he said, advertisements run in the area made it look as if the university was being sponsored by Ford, rather than simply renting space from it.
Ford executives felt used, Mr. Stockmann said, and severed the relationship.
The head of Phoenix in Michigan, Sarah Serra, said there had been no effort to imply a relationship that did not exist.
The contretemps does not seem to have hurt Phoenix's expansion in Michigan, where it has nearly 2,000 students after only 18 months. In Florida, the university has found quick success partly because the population growth of the state has overburdened state universities unable to handle the demand.
The evidence around the country and a visit to several classes suggest that while Phoenix may not be a beacon of scholarship or a leader in community service, it takes its product -- adult education intended to serve corporations -- seriously. Students seem satisfied and instructors return frequently.
Dr. Crow, the accrediting officer, said that traditional criteria for judging universities, like the percentage of full-time faculty members, the breadth of its libraries and the number of seat hours per course for students, might be outdated, especially for institutions that cater to working adults.
All of which pleases Phoenix officials who have even begun acquiring a touch of academic credibility by bringing on board a few more traditional academics.
One such professor is Jorge Klor de Alva, an anthropologist and philosopher who left a professorship at Princeton University for an endowed chair at the University of California at Berkeley and is now leaving there to become a vice president at Apollo.
Dr. Klor de Alva said it was not money but a new frontier that drew him to Apollo.
"Academia is a calling, a closed system," Dr. Klor de Alva said. "But at Apollo we are seeking to address real needs in the real world. We're erasing the moment in life when you either make it as a student or you don't. This is a second-chance outfit geared to an expanding world economy. Right now there are not many second chances offered out there. The University of Phoenix is at the very center of a new frontier of redefining higher education. And I think it is unstoppable. The genie is out of the bottle."

LENGTH: 1179 words

HEADLINE: 2 Get Nobel for a Formula at the Heart of Options Trading

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Two North American scholars won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday for work that enables investors to price accurately their bets on the future, a breakthrough that has helped power the explosive growth in financial markets since the 1970's and plays a profound role in the economics of everyday life.
Robert C. Merton of the Harvard Business School and Myron S. Scholes, a Canadian-born professor emeritus at the Stanford Business School, will share the $1 million award for helping devise a mathematical formula that provided the answer to a simple but seemingly insurmountable problem confronting Wall Street: how to measure the worth of an option. 
 Their solution helped lay the basis of today's vast global options marketplace, where the trading affects everyone with a stake in the financial markets, from employees who receive stock options as part of their pay to mutual fund investors who use options to hedge interest-rate risk.
An option is a type of investment that allows, but does not require, an investor to buy an asset, like stocks or bonds or wheat or pork bellies, at a prearranged price during a preset period of time.
Until 1973, when Mr. Merton and Mr. Scholes published their analysis, it was extremely difficult to assess all the variables that could affect the price of an option. Their work overcame that difficulty, which had limited the growth of the options markets.
"Such rapid and widespread application of a theoretical result was new to economics," the prize committee wrote. "Nowadays, thousands of traders and investors use the formula every day" -- making it easy for businesses and individuals to hedge risks in the incredibly complex world of modern finance.
The announcement of the Nobel in economics, which has been awarded annually by the Bank of Sweden since 1969, excites the academic community, but usually ignites little genuine enthusiasm on Wall Street. Not so this year. "I'm thrilled," said William Brodsky, chairman of the Chicago Board Options Exchange, which owes a large part of its growth to the Nobel winners. "This Nobel not only recognizes Merton and Scholes's accomplishments, it underscores the importance of options in the world of finance."
The analysis the two worked out has been successfully applied not only to pricing options but also to numerous other "derivative" securities, so named because their value is determined by fluctuations in the value of other assets.
Using derivatives is now a common way to redistribute the risks of doing business. Although in recent years derivatives have been associated with some financial disasters -- they played a role in the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., and the demise of Barings, Britain's oldest investment bank -- derivatives are widely regarded as beneficial.
Farmers, for example, use derivatives when they sell crops on the futures markets even before the planting has been finished. By locking in a price, they protect themselves if prices fall, although they also give up the chance of a windfall if prices surge. By the same token, grain dealers, bakeries and other big purchasers often buy grain futures to hedge against the risk of rising crop prices.
But what is the real worth of, say, an option to buy 100 shares of Intel at $105 each before next April or the right to borrow 400 million French francs at 9 percent by next Tuesday?
By the early 1960's, a handful of economists had both an interest in the puzzle and the advanced mathematical tools to solve it.
"We knew the answer was there, and that someone was going to find it," recalled Paul Samuelson, an economist at M.I.T. who later won a Nobel for work in other areas of economics.
The breakthrough came from three researchers, each under the age of 30 -- and one not even an economist. Fischer Black, a mathematician with Arthur D. Little consultants in Boston, discovered that an acquaintance, Mr. Scholes, then a professor of finance at M.I.T., was also fascinated by the question of options value. They enlisted the help of an assistant to Professor Samuelson at M.I.T., Mr. Merton, who is the son of the famous Columbia University sociologist Robert K. Merton.
Together they devised a mathematical formula, known as the Black-Scholes model, that took into account a variety of variables.
Mr. Black and Mr. Scholes had considerable difficulty finding a publisher. Their paper languished for three years before the prestigious Journal of Political Economy printed it in 1973. Mr. Merton walked an easier path, but only because he was a friend of the editor of the new Bell Journal of Economics. "Finance just wasn't part of the economics mainstream," Mr. Merton recalled in an interview yesterday.
The Chicago Board Options Exchange, the first devoted to options trading, opened just as the Black-Scholes theory was published. Although complicated, the computation involved could be easily -- and virtually instantly -- done on the pocket calculators that were just becoming popular.
Soon traders were valuing options on the floor of the exchange, punching half a dozen numbers into electronic calculators hard-wired with the formula. This not only meant quicker and more accurate pricing, it also increased the volume of options markets and reduced the cost of using options.
Mr. Black and Mr. Scholes became so highly regarded at the exchange that when they visited, traders would give them a standing ovation.
Thanks to extensions suggested by Mr. Merton, uses for the formula have been found in virtually every nook and cranny of finance.
Mr. Merton, who earned his Ph.D. from M.I.T in 1970, taught there until 1988, when he moved to the Harvard Business School. The Nobel caps a long career in helping to transform corporate finance from a backwater to the hot zone of economics. "Bob Merton is the Isaac Newton of his field," Mr. Samuelson said.
In 1973, Mr. Scholes went back to teach at the University of Chicago Business School, where he had earned his Ph.D. In 1983 he moved on to the Stanford Business School, where he taught until retirement in 1996. That was hardly the end of his career, though. He and Mr. Merton are principals in Long Term Financial Management, the immensely successful multibillion-dollar private investment fund formed by John Meriwether when he broke with his partners at Salomon Brothers.
"These guys can do finance both ways: high theory, or down and dirty," Stephen Ross, an economist at the Yale School of Management, said of the new Nobel recipients.
And Peter L. Bernstein, a consultant to institutional investors and a historian of the securities industry, said yesterday, "All I can say is: What took the Nobel committee so long?"
Mr. Merton said he had no particular plans for the $500,000 that he will receive at a ceremony on Dec. 10.
"It's all been a blast," he said. "My only regret is that Fischer Black isn't here to share the prize." Mr. Black, a partner in Goldman, Sachs and a former president of the American Economic Association, died in 1995 at the age of 57.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Nobel award in economics was given to Myron S. Scholes, left, professor emeritus at the Stanford Business School, whose daughter Ann hugged him as his daughter Sara looked on, and Robert C. Merton of the Harvard Business School. (Peter DaSilva for The New York Times, left; Agence France-Presse)
 
Chart: "How to Price a Hunch"
For centuries, market traders relied on instinct and gut feeling to decide how much to pay today for something whose value depends on an uncertain future; an example would be an option contract, which confers the right to buy or sell a security or commodity at a set price for a set time. But economists who tried to develop mathematical methods for valuing options struggled vainly until three young researchers -- Fischer Black, Robert C. Merton and Myron S. Scholes -- hit upon a formula in the late 1960's that substantially solved the problem. Their big breakthrough came in realizing the role played by volatility.
 
The algebra looks complex, but the concept is straightforward. Most of the hard work comes in determining what expected means.
 
In the form above, the formula gives the value today of a call option, represented by the letter C. A call option is the right to buy a stock at a set price called the strike price (L) before a fixed future date called the maturity (time to maturity is represented as t). The letter d stands for a combination of the formula's other variables; it relates movements in the stock price to movements in the option's value.
 
The formula assigns a higher value to the option if today's share price (S) is high, if the share price is very volatile (s, the price's standard deviation) and interest rates in general are high (r is the risk-free return available on Treasuries). Similarly, the longer the time to maturity, the lower the strike price, and the greater the likelihood that the option will be worth more at maturity (N is the normal distribution function).
 
The method is now so commonplace that pocket calculators are available with the formula built in: A trader or investor can punch in S, N, L, r and t and price an option contract in seconds. With minor variations, the formula can also be used to price many things whose value depends on events yet to come, like other kinds of options, futures, derivatives, and insurance policies.
 
(Source: Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences)(pg. D4)

HEADLINE: Havana's Day-Glo Dreams of Old Glory

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

 BODY:
AS A CLASH of cultures and ideologies, few experiences compare with that of rounding a corner in the heart of Old Havana, its crumbling baroque buildings adorned with the exhortations of Fidel Castro or Che Guevara, and coming face to face with a gleaming 1955 Thunderbird that looks as if it had just been driven off the lot. Chevrolets, Buicks, Cadillacs, Fords, Chryslers -- all the automotive relics of the Eisenhower era seem to have found a lasting home in the most resolutely anti-American society in the Western Hemisphere.
Not that these are the only cars on Cuba's streets. In reality, they are vastly outnumbered by the boxy Lada and Volga sedans that embody three decades of "socialist solidarity" with Moscow. There are new cars, too, mostly Japanese and belonging to the tour agencies and rental companies catering to tourists. But something about the plumage of a vintage American car -- that chrome, those fins and brilliant colors -- seems especially alluring to tropical tastes. 
 Like so many of the other contradictions of Cuban life, the presence of these vehicles is largely a result of politics. After Mr. Castro took Cuba down the Communist path nearly 40 years ago, the United States retaliated with an economic embargo that made it impossible for Cubans to indulge their craving for American goods. Mr. Castro abolished most manifestations of a consumer society. But out of sheer necessity American cars were allowed to linger, regardless of how gaudy they might be.
In Cuba's case, necessity has proved to be the mother of invention. Though a showroom for luxury imported cars has opened on Havana's main seafront promenade, the vast majority of Cubans have been forced to get around by bicycle ever since the Government declared a "special period" of austerity after the Soviet Union collapsed and oil supplies dried up. So anyone lucky enough to still own an automobile, some of which are handed down like heirlooms, had better take very good care of it.
That task is probably more delight than drudgery for most owners of vintage American cars, who spend hours applying waxes and polishes, basking in the praise and admiration of passersby. Others brag of the hours they spend searching for spare parts on the black market or trying to find an ingenious mechanic who can contrive a replacement. And some, when prompted, will even reminisce about a time when their cars were new, and life itself seemed brighter and as inviting as an open highway.

HEADLINE: Moods of 5 Decades, Color by Color

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
HENRY Ford wouldn't get away with telling customers today what he did in the early days of the Model T: they could buy any color -- as long as it was black.
American car buyers demand wider choices today, and if they don't see the color they want, they won't buy the car. 
 In a study conducted last spring by the polling firm of Yankelovich Partners, nearly a third of those questioned said they would switch vehicle brands if they couldn't get the color they wanted. In another survey, conducted by an auto maker, nearly half the respondents said they would switch cars if they couldn't find their first color choice.
"When we ask people the most important factors in their purchase, they mention resale value, quality, reliability," said Alan Eggly of the Ford Motor Company's color-and-trim design department. "Color ranks around 20th on their list. But when they talk about their vehicles, they talk about their red Mustang or their white Lincoln Town Car. They'll wait to get the color they want in a vehicle."
Color has probably always been important to car buyers. The trouble was, for many years the choices were pretty drab, like gray and off-white. That changed in the 1950's, when a technological breakthrough created a pure, durable white, which led to the proliferation of two-toned cars, like white with pink, turquoise or baby blue.
Current events and the mood of the nation strongly affect car color choices.
For instance, green, with yellow hues, became a favorite color during the Vietnam War. It re-emerged in the early 90's as the United States grappled with a recession and corporate downsizing.
Green, a symbol of harmony, counteracts emotional stress, said Robert Dailey, the automotive color and styling manager for Du Pont. That company, which sells paints and fabrics to auto makers and textiles for home furnishings and apparel, has studied color trends for 45 years.
"In distressing times, people have a need to look to nature for a calming effect to offset events like the Vietnam War," Mr. Dailey said.
"Over the years, we have found designer fashion is a key indicator of consumer trends, like car colors," Mr. Dailey noted. In fact, clothes dictate car colors that will appear four years from now, the average time it takes to develop a new car.
What's the prediction for the car color of 2000? "We'll see an evolution of what's out there now," Mr. Dailey said.
New earth tones, like gold, copper, bronze and brown, will be popular. Breakthroughs in pigment technology will deliver browns in the next century with the "depth and inner life of mahogany," Mr. Eggly said.
He also predicted a resurgence of classic navy blue. "Ask Americans what their favorite color is, and many will say blue," he said.

Blacks and grays yield to reds and blues; 1997 Buick PARK AVENUE 1990's: Quiet elegance -- green, gold, copper.

HEADLINE: Computers Take a Byte Out of the Design Process

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.

 BODY:
SLAM the hood. Slam the hood. Slam the hood. Silently.
Sitting before a glowing screen hooked to a basement full of Cray supercomputers, a Chrysler engineer designing the new Concorde sedan ran dozens of simulations of that simple act. He was trying to create a car hood that would fit to a hair's breadth -- and stay that way. 
 It is not the kind of detail that jumps off a showroom floor. But it is an example of how the world's largest manufacturing industry is being transformed, part by part, by what is now known as paperless engineering.
The Chrysler Corporation's two newest sedans, the 1998 Dodge Intrepid and the Chrysler Concorde, which arrive in showrooms this fall, share the distinction of being the first fully digital cars -- that is, designed and engineered entirely on computer. Competitors are only a mouse-click behind. Soon, the auto industry will be pumping out digital cars and trucks by the millions.
Experts in and outside Detroit say digital vehicles herald a new era in manufacturing, in which better cars can be designed faster and cheaper. "You're taking knowledge that traditionally has been embedded in mechanical things and making it much more easily transferable," said Marco Iansiti, an associate professor of technology at Harvard Business School. "The paperless cars are an example of a trend that I think is bigger than steamships."
Thomas C. Gale used to be one of Chrysler's most innovative designers, but is now the executive vice president for product development. Mr. Gale said the higher standards established by computers mean that everything is so much more exacting. He added that sometimes in the past "we'd get the parts back, and we didn't even recognize them."
The essential shapes and styles of cars are still born on sketchbooks or in watercolors. But at Chrysler, the cars now gestate in mathematical equations spooled out by computers at the Chrysler Technology Center in the company's headquarters here in this Detroit suburb.
Designers hand off their three-dimensional work to mechanical engineers, who can then open a car's virtual hood and design what is needed underneath -- not just the engine and radiator but every hose and screw. When the car is ready to be built, the same computer programs can be used to design the giant machines that stamp steel into doors and trunks and roofs.
Computers are helping engineers choose the best designs for the car as well as for its parts. For instance, the complicated and time-consuming process of designing engines historically meant that no more than five could be thoroughly tested before one was chosen for a new model. But advanced computer simulation programs allowed engineers to run through 1,500 designs for the Intrepid and Concorde engines; perform on-screen tests that normally must wait for physical models to be built, and choose the best engines from a wider field.
THE process was repeated with the 5,000 and more separate parts, then with the connections between them.
Years before any physical models of the new cars were built, Mr. Gale and other Chrysler executives watched simulated light play off colorful, three-dimensional models of the new sedans rotating on the computer screen. "You had to keep saying to yourself, 'This really doesn't exist,' " Mr. Gale said.
Robert M. Trecapelli, a Chrysler research engineer who worked on the new cars, said, "We actually build the entire vehicle on the computer before we make it."
The hundreds of people who designed everything from the engine to the taillights updated their designs instantly in a 3-D computer model that other designers used as if sharing a single blueprint.
"It is almost like a living, breathing entity -- the digital vehicle -- you watch it change," Mr. Trecapelli said.
Engineers argue that a car becomes more reliable when each of its thousands of parts is slightly better designed and connects more smoothly to the next part. Take the Concorde's hood. Each time a car hood is slammed shut, it can change shape slightly, bending by a few microns.
Car engineers have got a pretty good idea of how steel reacts to that stress. In the past, if a problem developed once production was under way, they could correct it, more or less, by adjusting the hulking machines that stamp out hoods.
But the Concorde's designers wanted to make its hood out of aluminum to save on weight and improve fuel economy and they wanted a fit that was better than pretty good. Yet they weren't sure how aluminum would bend.
The computer simulation allowed them to watch the metal bend dozens of times, and then allowed them to work backward -- "reverse engineering" -- to keep out unwanted bends.
The 3-D programs even allow engineers to watch a sheet of steel be virtually cut and pressed in the innards of giant factory stamping machines, before the machines are actually built. Using this software, engineers can anticipate and correct real-life problems on screen, thereby avoiding costly changes after the machines are built.
Chrysler said the faster design processes shaved eight months off the development of the Intrepid and Concorde, saving the company about $80 million.
Ford and General Motors, along with Toyota, Honda, BMW and other large auto makers, already sketch designs for new cars and trucks on computer. Many also use computers to design stamping machines, presses and other large pieces of factory equipment. The largest companies are now requiring suppliers to link their computers with the car manufacturers' to design auto parts that fit precisely and allow the performance of the entire car to be accurately simulated.
FORD used extensive computer-assisted design and engineering programs to build a small car called the Puma, which went on sale in Europe in July. But, unlike Chrysler's new cars, the Puma used many components developed for other Ford models that were not engineered on screen.
Ford is far along in developing computer models that measure the effects of auto crashes, which the company hopes will replace many costly Government-required crash tests. The company now spends between $350,000 and $550,000 to crash a hand-built prototype. But it costs about $200 to run a computer-simulated crash test, a tab expected to drop to $10 in three years.
The General Motors Corporation won't have a digital car until the turn of the century. But it will soon use computers so that designers in say, Detroit and Tokyo, can hand off work for round-the-clock development of the same car.
Not everyone is sold on computers, however. "The computer isn't necessarily always the best way," said Jerry P. Hirshberg, the president of Nissan Design International, the American design arm of Nissan. "Not quite as much is possible on a computer as is possible in your mind." Mr. Hirschberg worries that computerized design will result in too many cars that are wonderfully efficient but boring.
"I fear the downside of the computer as a creative crutch, rather than a really helpful pencil with a good memory," he said. But he added that the best designers would continue to find inspiration off-screen -- with chalk and clay and metal and balsa wood.
But even Mr. Hirshberg admits that computers have their place. "I'm designing cars halfway around the world," he said. "The computer makes that all possible at the speed of light."

HEADLINE: Pollution Record Is Far From Black

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
JUST AS every car has a tailpipe, the internal combustion engine under every hood is a pollution machine. But in some ways the American car has been getting strikingly cleaner over the years, while in other ways its environmental record remains troublesome.
That's because some pollutants are tightly controlled, as when the Federal Government required catalytic converters, or when the recipe for gasoline was rewritten to reduce harmful emissions. Other pollutants, however, have gone mostly unregulated, notably carbon dioxide, which is the inevitable byproduct of burning gasoline. 
 Emissions of carbon dioxide go up as fuel use increases. This gas then traps the heat of the sun like a blanket and warms the planet -- the so-called greenhouse effect. Carbon dioxide emissions from cars will only decrease if people drive less or use more efficient cars. But the Government has not tightened fuel-efficiency standards for years. And consumers have been buying more sporty trucks and other gas guzzlers and have been driving them farther.
But during the same period, since the 1970's, the Government has repeatedly tightened the limits on emissions of unhealthy pollutants like carbon monoxide, volatile organic compounds and nitrogen oxides (a main ingredient in smog). A car built in the mid-1990's produces about one-tenth the pollution per mile traveled as one built two decades ago. And there are new inspection rules that force drivers to keep their cars well-tuned.
There is one large unknown in predicting how much pollution cars will cause in the years to come: How long will the increase in driving last? People cannot expand the time they spend behind the wheel indefinitely. And if there is a significant increase in fuel prices, either through taxation or a shortage, driving could decline abruptly, taking pollution down with it.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Out of the Tailpipe"
The Clean Air Act of 1970 imposed tight controls on certain types of emissions but left others unregulated. As a result, progress in cutting pollution has been uneven. Graphs show regulated and unregulated emissions from 1970 to 1995.
 
America's fleet of cars is more fuel efficient now because of another set of regulations; trucks are not covered by the rules, but have been made somewhat more efficient. The steady increase in the number of miles Americans drive, however, have swamped such improvements driving up overall gas consumption. Graphs show fuel economy, total miles traveled each year and total fuel consumption for America's fleet of vehicles, from 1970 to 1995.
