HEADLINE: Movies Were Better, and So Were the Skid Marks

BYLINE: By JEFF MacGREGOR; Jeff MacGregor is a writer living in Manhattan.

 BODY:
FOR a 13-year-old American boy riding around town in a poorly carbureted Volkswagen Squareback, the chase scene in "Bullitt" was an epiphany, a worshipful awakening to the glorious transcendence of speed and anarchy and appetite. Its potboiler complications and existential antiheroism were lost on me, but the glass-packed V8 exhaust obbligato of genuine Detroit iron was like music. I remember liking the turtlenecks, too.
By 1968, the year of "Bullitt," I had already seen a thousand other actors driving a thousand other cars in a thousand other movies. They drove fast or they drove far or they drove funny, but they never drove like they meant it. Hotshoe Steve McQueen and his Ford Mustang GT fastback, rumbling bayward down the face of San Francisco as choreographed by the director Peter Yates, certainly changed that. 
 A chase scene is a storytelling imperative as old as Moses. When automobiles and moving pictures came along a hundred years ago, the wedding of our century's dominant technologies produced the car chase, a cinematic hybrid we have been refining ever since.
The earliest examples are mostly lost to us, victims of volatile nitrate film stock and the economy of forgetfulness. Stay up late enough though, and between infomercials for Abdominizers or Holistic Prostate Reduction Systems, you'll probably find snippets of our first generation of cars on film.
The best of these revel in our always ambivalent relationship to mechanization. Movie cars were mostly amiable (if mule-stubborn), but prone to instantaneous and nearly molecular disintegration. A Model T in a Mack Sennett comedy could shake itself like a wet spaniel, then drive away on its rims and good intentions. A chase was played largely for laughs way back when, and the undercranked, hyperkinetic Keystone Kops spent more time running after their cars than they did riding in them.
Our ideas, fears and fantasies of "The Car" weren't fixed yet either, hadn't been narrowed by familiarity or contempt. In "Sherlock Jr." (1924), Buster Keaton deadpanned his way up and down a sun-shot and dusty La Brea Avenue on the handlebars of a riderless motorcycle until he caught up with a driverless touring car that, once he put the top up, became a rudderless sailboat. The freewheeling brilliance of invention like that is matched only by the balletic stunt work it took to make it happen.
The 30's and 40's offered little in the way of that kind of novelty. The effervescence of the comic pursuit (Laurel and Hardy notwithstanding) gave way to the grim routines of the gangster chase, in which evil men wearing sharkskin suits and dark fedoras clung to the running boards of monstrous Packards while they were tommy-gunning hatless G-men in their honest tweeds.
Around this same time began a more widespread use of rear-projection process shots. These allowed the studios to shoot automotive sequences indoors against a filmed background. It was cheap and fast, and savings in location expenses were substantial. Degrading reality in the pursuit of money is what Hollywood does, after all, and for years, the standard auto shot was often a fedora head framed in a skeletonized car interior, both rocking pacifically in the gentle mitts of two off-camera stagehands.
Through the postwar years, into the 50's and 60's, there was more of the same, albeit with fewer and fewer hats.
Elvis chasing Ann-Margret in his streamliner fanjet bubble-top coupe, or James Dean being chased by the demons of suburban adolescent angst were about as good as things got. Even James Bond was a desultory driver back then; smoothly outrunning Smersh with one hand on the wheel, checking the DB5 glove box for his jar of cocktail onions with the other. It all looked pretty fake to me.
When "Bullitt" crashed into theaters, though, the effect was riveting. A return to the risks and realities of location shooting, married to technologies of smaller cameras and mounts, it was an ideal synthesis of traditions and experimentation. It also proved that a chase must be integral to the story: about running from, or to, something.
Three years later, to the delight of moviegoers and auto insurance executives everywhere, "The French Connection" was released, and I was granted a learner's permit. What Steve McQueen started, Gene Hackman was happy to finish. His 1971 chase under the elevated train tracks of Brooklyn was my graduate seminar in the quantum mechanics of driving, proving as it did that matter can be converted directly into energy if you just give it enough gas.
For the next few years, I corroborated his findings at every opportunity, using the family's groaning Econokarton as a kind of personal particle accelerator. Scientific curiosity aside, if we'd had a cooler car, I'd probably still be in prison.
In those days, I was the most malevolent flying object in the galaxy, a turtlenecked suburban bad boy with a full tank of gas, an eight-track recording of "Radar Love" and a movie-inspired fantasy life that began at the end of our driveway.
Since then, movie car chases have been made a commonplace, deadened by their lower-case repetitions on television, made superfluous by high-concept, computer-generated intergalactic tong wars and rendered unbearable by seriatim "Smokey" sequels.
The completely forgettable blockbuster summer of 1997, during which we saw spaceships and ocean liners and planes (lots of planes) chasing only box-office receipts, makes me wonder if today's 16-year-olds go to bed dreaming of becoming flight attendants or cruise directors.
If that's the case, we're all a lot safer, I think. But perhaps a little poorer, too.

HEADLINE: For Russians, to Own a Car Is to Fix a Car, Again and Again

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
AFTER a year in which American correspondents, including this one, have written endlessly and obsessively about the many horrifying flaws of the Russian space station Mir, we ought to be fair and also tell you this: Nobody in this country pays the slightest attention to the troubles of the Mir.
It's not that Russians are callous toward their heroic cosmonauts. It's not even that people here are too preoccupied with their own problems to worry about the cosmos. It's just that things in Russia break every day, and every day somebody fixes them. There is no society on earth that falls apart so often or is more adept at gluing itself back together. 
 "Why do these malfunctions happen?" Vladimir Solovyov, Mir's mission control director, responded in exasperation to a recent question about the string of problems the space station has faced this year. "Do you know why your car breaks down? It's hard to say what the reason might be."
Actually, in Russia that's not really true. Cars may be the essential accessory for any adult American, but they are intimate apparel in Russia, particularly for men. (Women are too busy working, raising families, trying to keep their husbands alive and in all other ways keeping the nation in one lumbering piece.)
Russian men are by nature and necessity incredible mechanics. And they are deeply in love with movement -- which, even more than in America, symbolizes not just economic independence, but the type of personal freedom that even 10 years ago could hardly have been imagined by anyone except the communist elite.
For a person who has spent his life standing in dark lines to ride on overcrowded trolleys, there is just no freedom like the freedom of going where you want when you want. The new rich in Russia -- with their armor-plated Mercedeses, Chevrolet Blazers, smoke-colored windows and bodyguards -- get most of the press and all the attention. But normal people are far more visible on the road.
"My car means everything to me," said Vladimir Potanov, a Moscow lawyer who finds it so pleasant driving to work each day in his brand-new Volvo that he doesn't even mind the crippling traffic in a city whose automotive population has grown from about 400,000 to more than 2.5 million in the last decade. Many of those cars are new and flashy -- an enormous number of Mercedeses were sold here last year -- but most were 20-year-old clunkers that had sat rusting in lots and garages for years. As with so much of life in Russia now, if you have it, you can finally flaunt it.
"When I am in the car, I am doing exactly what I want to do," Mr. Potanov said. "And I am doing it on my own schedule. I almost can't wait for something to go wrong with the thing because I know it will be easy to fix."
During the war in Chechnya, Russian tanks broke down so often that at least one person who knew how to fix a carburetor was placed inside each tank. It was almost impossible to drive down any road on the way to Grozny without seeing the central symbol of today's Russian army: a young man doubled over the engine of a truck or a tank.
This is not simply an urban or a military phenomenon. I was once about 10 miles from a tiny village in central Russia when a priest whom I had interviewed offered to drive me back to the house where I was staying. I was greatly relieved because walking would have been the only alternative. Then we discovered that the priest's brother had taken the priest's jacket by mistake and, with it, the keys to the pickup truck. The priest shrugged and started to rip pieces of metal paneling out of the steering column. Within minutes, he had hot-wired the car, and we were on our way.
Of course, some of this is survival instinct. Few Russians can afford to pay a mechanic to fix a car. (They save that money to bribe inspectors so that badly broken automobiles can pass muster.) The difference between knowing how to change spark plugs and not knowing is often the difference between driving and taking the slow train.
"You find pretty quickly that most of these repairs are simple enough," Mr. Potanov said. His previous car was a Russian-made Lada, which lasted a decade. "Why pay for something you can do yourself?"
But Russia's emerging car culture isn't just about making do. It's about being proud of making do. The Russian health care system is often derided for good reason -- it's a mess. Yet a good Russian surgeon can take a hot plate, boil water and sterilize instruments on it and operate without a flaw. I have seen it happen. Same with the much-maligned Aeroflot pilots. They are handy and fully qualified. It's the metal they fly around in that has the problems.
So the Russian love of cars -- many surveys list them as the first thing a man with money would buy -- is not hard to understand. This is a bunch of people delighted with the fact that they can actually make something work. In Russia, it would be hard to overstate how exciting that is.

HEADLINE: Get Ready for the Past: Beetles, Hot Rods and Fins

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
A DECADE after trying to persuade the world that their cars were not your father's Oldsmobile, auto makers from around the world have decided that the past is way cool.
Some cars are recreations of classic shapes, like the Plymouth Prowler, which is a modern version of a 1950's-era hot rod. In other cars, the retro rage appears in subtle touches, like round analog clocks on dashboards. Volkswagen is even bringing back the Beetle in the spring. 
 Some here say they believe the retro designs are part of the wave of nostalgia sweeping across consumer culture.
"It is just a trend that we're walking through right now -- I think that accounts for their liking of retro furniture, retro architecture and even in some cases retro clothing," said Jack Telnack, the vice president of design for the Ford Motor Company. "I guess some people would rather live in the past."
Some blame the baby boom generation looking back wistfully on its youth. Others say the glance backward is prompted by the onset of a new century. Whatever the reasons, old styles are reappearing.
In addition to the Prowler, which went on sale this summer and is offered only in an outrageous shade of purple, there is the Dodge Viper, which recalls the venerable Shelby Cobra race cars.
And many of the latest luxury cars are backward-looking in less obvious ways. The Jaguar XK8 is reminiscent of the Jaguar E-type of the 60's and early 70's. The Mercedes SLK roadster takes its cues from the Mercedes SL line of classic roadsters, and the Porsche Boxster is meant to remind car lovers of the Porsche 550 Spyder race cars of the 50's.
But the new Beetle is expected to really tap into the retro craze, and the former Beetle has been around long enough to find its way into the memory of several generations. The first one was sold in the United States in 1949, and by the 70's it was so popular it starred in a movie called "The Love Bug" and later a television show.
The new Beetle is perhaps the most direct attempt to recapture the past, at least as far as the exterior goes. Look at it from the side, and you'll see the three familiar intersecting circles -- the two fenders and the arch of the roof. But underneath the ladybug shape, much has changed.
THE AIR-COOLED engine, housed in the rear of the old Bugs, is now water-cooled, and it has been uprooted and moved to the front of the car. The Beetle now has front-wheel-drive and is considerably larger than the tiny Beetles of the past -- which were once best known for posing a challenge to college students intent on cramming as many people as possible inside one.
Despite its retro look, the Bug is an up-to-date car with all the latest safety features, including side air bags. And it will carry Volkswagen's reliable engine, the modern kind that seldom breaks, but is hard for shade-tree mechanics to repair.
Some people may be disappointed by that fact, since the old version -- underpowered, cheap and easy to fix -- created a sort of love-hate relationship with its owner. A Beetle often became more like a pet or a member of the family, not just a mode of transportation.
Some believe the 1999 Beetle will be appealing because it is so different from all the look-alike sedans on the road. The Beetle and other retro cars are also enticing because they recall an era when cars were more like rolling sculptures, not bland exercises in wind resistance.
Car buyers "were getting a little bit tired of the wind-tunnel shapes -- very logical shapes which will work very well" in terms of aerodynamics and fuel economy, said Charles W. O. Ellwood, the director of Volkswagen's design center in Simi Valley, Calif.
HOWEVER groovy the new Beetle's shape, past Bug buyers might be put off by the price. While Volkswagen is keeping the exact amount under wraps, the Beetle is expected to cost $15,000 to $18,000 -- less than the average price for a new car, but expensive relative to what people remember paying for their Beetles in the past. Indeed, the price might be all the more shocking because everyone somehow seemed to buy used Beetles, not new ones.
But the Beetle -- the best-selling car of all time with 21.3 million sold -- has earned a soft spot in the hearts of those who have owned a model in the decades since it was first manufacturere in 1938.
Later, The New York Times described the car as a "beetle," and the name stuck.
"It is an icon," Mr. Ellwood said.

HEADLINE: Nouvelle Detroit? Global Growth Brings Changes at Home

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
PEOPLE around the world think they know what Detroit is like. The common mental picture is of a huge, dirty city of factories where burly men labor on assembly lines, turning steel skeletons into gigantic cars and trucks. This industrial reputation has spread so widely that some street vendors in Europe do a brisk business in T-shirts with scenes of machinery and the city's name in huge letters on them.
Yet that gritty image is dated. Many auto factories closed in the 1980's, never to reopen, while others have been renovated to use the latest technology and fewer workers. New factories were opened in the South to avoid powerful unions, or overseas. 
 The Detroit area is slowly changing from an auto manufacturing center into a white-collar capital of immense global business empires. And as the American auto industry expands, its culture and the culture of Detroit are changing, too.
It is hard to overstate the sheer size of the American auto industry -- or, these days, its reach. General Motors and the Ford Motor Company are now the world's two largest companies in sales and in share of global economic output. Both are building new factories in fast-growing markets like China and Poland, while simply renovating factories at home to stay competitive in the stagnant United States market. Even Chrysler, a runt by Detroit standards, but still five times the size of the Microsoft Corporation in sales, is expanding rapidly in Brazil.
The current international expansions are not entirely new. The Big Three had huge operations in Europe and shipped cars to East Asia and Latin America during the 50's and 60's, before retrenching in their struggles for survival from the late 70's through the early 90's. But the auto makers are now moving into far more countries, with more daily contact between executives in the home office and in the field.
Detroit remains an insular, racially divided city where almost any criticism of automobiles represents a serious social gaffe, but it is showing signs of becoming cosmopolitan. Just as houses in affluent Washington suburbs change hands every few years as diplomats come and go, palatial homes in wealthy Detroit suburbs like Grosse Pointe, Birmingham and Bloomfield Hills are occupied by a constant parade of executives rotating on foreign assignments. While many managers still prefer to vacation at fishing cabins in northern Michigan, some are beginning to take holidays overseas. Even Detroit's restaurants are improving, with a more eclectic cuisine slowly crowding out steak with gravy.
With hundreds of managers shuttling to places like Bangkok, Shanghai and Sao Paulo, Brazil, business meetings and cocktail parties in Detroit are turning into informal geography lessons. "When I first arrived here, and I said I was born and raised in Chile, they would say, 'Where is that?' " said Dario Verdugo, Chrysler's business development executive for Latin America, who came to Detroit in 1969. "Now people say, 'I understand they're doing pretty well with a market-driven economy.' "
Even the tone toward foreign rivals has changed. Lee A. Iacocca vehemently criticized Japanese competitors during a speech here in 1992, before he retired as chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation. "They say all of our problems are our fault -- that's like blaming our Army and our Navy for Pearl Harbor because they weren't ready," Mr. Iacocca said, drawing cheers from a hall full of local business executives.
TODAY, Mr. Iacocca is in a partnership with the Kwang Yang Motor Company of Taiwan to develop and market electric scooters. A new generation of auto executives here talks about East Asia, particularly China, as a potential market, not a threat. And the number of Japanese citizens living in the Detroit region has soared to 4,000 as dozens of Japanese auto-parts companies have opened offices here, seeking contracts from the Big Three. Saturday classes for children of Japanese managers draw 967 students, compared with 221 a decade ago.
Takanori Sonoda, Honda's chief representative in Detroit, recalled the animosity on his first trip to the city in 1987. "I was sitting at a bar in the Omni Hotel," he said. "One of the old guys came to me and said, 'You guys are buying up our country.' "
But while working here for the last three years, he has not encountered any hostility, said Mr. Sonoda, whose children attend public school in the suburb where he lives. "They are really enjoying their life, and there is no discriminatory attitude at all."
Over the last decade in particular, jokes and slurs about foreigners and minorities have become socially unacceptable, said Gerald Meyers, the former chairman of the American Motors Corporation. "The ethnic jokes are gone, the racial hatred has either gone underground or been fried out -- it just isn't accepted as a valid attitude any longer," he said. "In the locker room, there's nobody talking about 'the foreign automobile people.' "
But while race relations have been improving in the auto industry and in Detroit, they are still more acrimonious than elsewhere. The Justice Department continues to file more housing discrimination lawsuits in the nearly all-white Detroit suburbs than anywhere else in the country. There are virtually no blacks -- or women, for that matter -- among the leaders of the Big Three auto makers. And only last winter did the favorite country club of auto executives agree, after considerable controversy, to admit its second and third black members.
Longstanding racial tensions between Detroit, the nation's largest black-majority city, and its nearly all-white suburbs have hurt the metropolitan region's cultural life. Remarkably few suburbanites travel downtown to take advantage of the city's cultural treasures, survivors from Detroit's glory days before the 1967 riots and the 1973 oil crisis. It's possible on a Sunday morning to find a parking spot on the street in front of the Detroit Institute of Arts, the nation's fifth-largest art museum. Tickets are easy to get to the Detroit Symphony and the Detroit Opera, which occupies a magnificent, recently renovated hall. (An important addition to the cultural scene here was the opening last spring of the huge Museum of African American History, which has drawn large crowds so far.)
The auto makers' difficulties in hiring the brightest from East Coast and West Coast business schools have prompted them to donate heftily to the arts and try to revive downtown Detroit. The Chrysler Corporation, which gave little money during its years of financial troubles, has been particularly generous lately. G.M. decided last year to move its headquarters from midtown Detroit to the skycraper Renaissance Center skyscraper downtown, instead of to the suburbs.
SOME civic leaders remain worried that suburban residents lack the enthusiasm and commitment to downtown Detroit. "Culturally, it's still a brackish backwater," Mr. Meyers said.
Because foreign nationals still make up no more than 1 percent of the managers here, the perspective remains very American. "Things are very often seen from what I would call a North American view," said Jean Mallebay-Vacqueur, a Chrysler engineer who grew up in former French colonies in West Africa and came here in 1979. "There may not be a recognition of how powerful China is becoming, or India."
Yet, with time, even this might change. In the late 70's, "if you were hearing someone speaking French, you were likely to be walking with the person," Mr. Mallebay-Vacqueur said. Now, "people are not very fluent, but much better than they were 20 years ago."

HEADLINE: Three Guesses: The Fuel of the Future Will be Gas, Gas or Gas

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NEARLY 20 years after the last gas crisis, auto makers are finally confident that they can produce cars that are durable, reliable and powered by something cleaner than gasoline.
But don't expect to drive them. For a tangle of commercial and economic reasons, the fuel of the future still appears to be plain old unleaded regular. 
 The most fervent wishes of policy makers, engineers, environmentalists and businesses ranging from corn growers to drillers for natural gas all seem to have been washed away by the continuing tide of cheap gasoline. The best that they can hope for, many years from now, is cars that use gasoline in a different way, perhaps in combination with an electric motor.
The first hurdle for those who want to use substitutes like ethanol, methanol or natural gas is finding a pump. Government officials, industry executives and other experts refer to "the chicken or the egg" problem -- that a fueling system will not exist without a large customer base --, and no one will buy such cars until a system is set up. For private use, a vehicle is not going to be popular unless it runs on gasoline.
In California, where clean-air regulations have sparked remarkable technical progress, refiners and car manufacturers have cooperated to change both the fuel and the cars so that nearly all the pollution standards can be met on gasoline.
In the long term, some auto makers are putting money into fuel cells, a NASA invention that makes current directly from hydrogen-rich fuel. Others are working on hybrids, a combination of a small internal-combustion engine and an electric engine. In a hybrid, a gasoline engine, slightly larger than a go-cart's, charges batteries for electric motors that turn the wheels.
There are simpler solutions, but they have not caught on. Consider natural gas, which requires less refinery work than gasoline does and is already widely distributed around the continental United States, where it is produced in abundance. It is also much easier to burn cleanly than gasoline.
But it doesn't sell. Amoco, which has the largest natural gas reserves among the major oil companies, built 37 fueling stations, basically compressors that would fill a tank to the required pressure, at a cost of $250,000 to $300,000 each. The company has closed all but 4 and will shut the remainder as soon as contracts expire.
"We truly were acting in economic good faith toward our part of the chicken or the egg evolution," said Neal Geary, a company spokesman. But each pump sold only about the equivalent of 20 gallons a day. None of the pumps came close to doing enough business to repay its installation cost, and only one pump came close to paying the cost of maintaining it -- the one in Atlanta during the 1996 Olympics, when natural-gas vehicles were brought in for show.
"The average-Joe passenger car just isn't ready," Mr. Geary said. The tanks are still bulky, the range is still shorter and the continuing low price of gasoline provides no incentive to switch. Amoco sold natural gas at a discount of about 30 percent compared with gasoline. But the company figured that for a vehicle that used the natural gas equivalent of 1,000 gallons of gasoline a year -- about double the national average -- the annual savings would be only about $300, and the cost of converting the vehicle to run on gas could cost up to $4,000.
Chrysler was producing a natural gas version of its Dodge Ram pickup truck until the end of last year, when its tank supplier went out of business; the company is still looking for a new supplier. Ford has had more success, with six natural-gas vehicles in its 1998 model year, including the Crown Victoria. And in August, for the first time, a natural-gas Crown Vic entered service as a New York City taxi. Many cities are running big fleets of buses on natural gas.
Liquid fuels also have drawbacks. Methanol exacts less of a range penalty than natural gas but has even less of a cost advantage. It is not widely available, either.
"We've been pretty discouraged with the acceptance of methanol vehicles," said Ross P. Witschonke, the Ford Motor Company's director of technical affairs for a joint Government-industry "Next Generation Vehicle" project.
ETHANOL, made from corn, is also hard to find. According to the National Ethanol Vehicle Coalition in Jefferson City, Mo., there are just 35 service stations that sell ethanol, and they average only about 2,000 gallons a month each. (A big station sells hundreds of thousands of gallons of gasoline a month.)
Fords plans to build 250,000 cars, mini-vans and pickup trucks in a four-year period that can run on ethanol mixtures. Mr. Witschonke conceded that it is an "open question" how many of them will actually do so. But thanks to a paradoxical provision of Federal law, the vehicles can be a boon to the company even if the vehicles never touch a drop. The law, meant to reduce the demand for gasoline, allows Ford to sell more cars with poor fuel economy for each "flexible fuel" vehicle it sells.
The great success in alternative-fuel vehicles is propane. According to the Energy Department, about 386,000 alternative-fuel vehicles are in use in the United States, and 71 percent of those use propane. But propane is a bit like oil because domestic supplies are limited, in contrast with natural gas or electricity, which can be produced in vast quantities.
For cleanliness and efficiency, electric vehicles have a clear edge. The utility plants that convert coal, gas or oil into electricity tend to be far cleaner than any under-the-hood power plant. (When used in the car, electricity is completely clean.)
The Northeast Sustainable Energy Association in Greenfield, Mass., which conducts an annual electric car race, ran a 348-mile course this year, using two Toyota RAV4's and two Geo Metros, each in a gasoline and an electric version. The electric Toyota got the equivalent of 39 miles per gallon versus 16 in the gasoline version; the electric Geo Metro got 59 miles per gallon versus 32 for the gasoline version.
But for now, the appeal of electric vehicles is limited by their price. In California, General Motors is leasing its two-seater EV1 for $399 a month, the same price it charges for a Cadillac Catera.
Engineers say, though, that existing electric cars may be a technological warm-up act for a hybrid, a vehicle that runs on electricity and a liquid fuel, probably using the liquid to make the current.
IN an ordinary car, the power plant must operate at many different engine speeds, giving adequate efficiency and acceptable emissions at all levels. And the engine must be big enough for quick starts, even if the average power demand is much lower.
In a hybrid, a small engine can run in a narrow range of r.p.m.'s, where it is designed to be clean and efficient. Connected to an electric generator, it dumps excess energy into the batteries until they are full. Then it shuts down, which is infinitely cleaner and more efficient than idling.
But such an engine has double the parts -- and possibilities for failure -- than the engine of an existing car.
At the Frankfurt Auto Show in Germany last month, two companies displayed cars that use fuel cells, devices that make electric current without combustion. Fuel cells mix oxygen from the air and hydrogen from any available source to make water; that chemical reaction generates electricity. Utility companies are working to make giant fuel cells commercially productive.
Daimler-Benz put electric motors and a fuel cell in the body of a Mercedes-Benz A-Class, its new subcompact. It gets the hydrogen it needs from methanol carried on board.
Mercedes is working with Ballard Power Systems, a Canadian company that has built several fuel-cell-powered buses, to make fuel cells for cars. The two companies are investing $325 million in the technology.
The Frankfurt show also exhibited Toyota's fuel-cell-powered RAV4, which ran on hydrogen derived from methanol as well.
Although not shown at Frankfurt, Chrysler is developing a "proof of concept vehicle" powered by a fuel cell that gets its hydrogen from gasoline. This is harder and less efficient than using methanol, but gasoline is universally available.
"If we could start with a clean slate and not have a gasoline industry, we wouldn't be looking at gasoline," said Christopher Borroni-Bird, Chrysler's program manager. "We have to look at the world the way it is."

HEADLINE: Ford or Honda, New or Used, He Wants to Sell It

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

 BODY:
IF every car salesman, especially every used-car salesman, were honest, sensitive, patient, fair, tactful and caring, then Wayne Huizenga's whole plan to revolutionize the $700 billion business of buying cars wouldn't stand a chance.
But as a founder of the Autonation chain of used-car marts and the nation's largest seller of new cars as well, Mr. Huizenga (pronounced HI-zing-uh) is betting that the chance to buy a car with no haggling will have limitless appeal. 
 Fixing the car sales business could prove far more complicated than building WMX, the nation's largest trash hauler, and Blockbuster, the largest video-store chain, which is how Mr. Huizenga earned most of his billion-dollar-plus fortune.
While executives at his Republic Industries holding company admit they are still learning how to steer their new business, Mr. Huizenga has roared off at 90 miles an hour. In just one year of operation, he has built 15 Autonation used-car marts from scratch with lots the size of six Manhattan blocks, while buying 200 new car dealerships and the National and Alamo rental agencies.
His vision: beyond the factory gates, link together every aspect of the auto business, new or used -- selling, buying, leasing, financing, renting, repairing -- in ways that bring untold benefits to consumers and untold profits to him.
Many in Detroit cheer the prospect of more efficient distribution and improved service. But some auto makers, long used to telling dealers what cars to sell and on what terms, fear the rise of the first dealer powerful enough to challenge them.
By the end of 1999, Mr. Huizenga plans to have a presence in the nation's 50 largest markets with 90 Autonations, each surrounded by clusters of new-car dealers, which will operate under their own names. His full-speed approach may be a product of character, but it's also an effort to beat out other new, publicly traded companies bent on expansion.
"We want to have the best Ford dealer and the best Chevy dealer and the best Toyota dealer in every market," he said during a recent interview at a penthouse office suite here.
Mr. Huizenga says that through volume and corporate ownership, he can trim $1,000 -- in advertising, inventory and interest charges, reconditioning costs and the like -- off the cost of the average used car.
He has hired a manager from the Saturn plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., to bring assembly-line techniques to the refurbishing of used cars. At a reconditioning center near here, cars are routed to about half a dozen different lines, depending on how much body work they require, with other lines for mechanical repairs. Fixing up cars so they don't need return trips to reconditioning centers is among the lessons his company is still learning, Mr. Huizenga said.
At age 59, H. Wayne Huizenga, who founded his empire with a single garbage truck, remains burly and determined.
In South Florida, he already possesses the visibility Ted Turner has in Atlanta or Donald J. Trump has in New York, largely because he owns three professional sports teams here: the Florida Marlins, the Florida Panthers and the Miami Dolphins.
To most challenges, he has blunt and ready answers. An eventual recession? "That's when the strong get stronger," he said, his narrow, blue eyes narrowing further. "There would be a lot of dealers that want to sell."
Efforts by Toyota and now Honda to curb his purchases of their dealers? "The bigger, more sophisticated manufacturers recognize that this is an advantage to them," he said, describing how closer ties to dealers like him can help auto makers know which models to produce.
But changing car dealer culture will take more than money. For one, Mr. Huizenga's company will have to teach salespeople, called "sales guides," a new language.
"We don't want to call it a 'lot' and a 'deal,' " said Lynn Fernandez, a manager at the first Autonation, near Fort Lauderdale. "It's an 'outdoor display area' and a 'transaction.' You're not an 'up,' as in 'next up,' you're a 'guest.' "
The showroom includes a snack bar and a shop with auto supplies and Autonation shirts and caps. Shoppers can leave their children in a monitored playroom, then scan the inventory on touch-screen computers. They can print out a page of data, including a picture and location for each car, then roam the outdoor display area by themselves or with a sales guide in a golf cart.
Greg Meurrens and Yolanda Ramos were peeking inside a late-model Toyota Tacoma and other light trucks when a salesman -- make that a sales guide -- rolled by on a cart. "Need some help?" he asked. When they shook their heads, he rolled on.
At other dealerships, Mr. Muerrens said, "they're on top of you." He bent his knees and clawed the air to imitate a wild, hungry animal. "Here they ask. You can think before you say anything."
But the more he thought, the less certain he became about buying: "$26,490?" he asked, looking at the sticker in the Tacoma's window. "That's a lot of money."
"For the year and model, you could probably get it cheaper," Ms. Ramos said. "That's why I would want to try to bargain."
 OTHERS who were beginning their hunt for a car at Autonation were far from sure it would end there. Frank and Helen Bonfiglio printed out sheet after sheet to find reasonably priced midsized cars for a daughter in New Paltz, N.Y.
"This is a good place to start," Ms. Bonfiglio said. "You can get a sense of what the inventory is, what prices would be." But the Bonfiglios said they might send their printouts to their daughter, and let her shop in her own town.
In taking the used-car business corporate, Mr. Huizenga's leading rival accuses him of imitating.
"They've been doing this for about nine months, and we've been doing it for six years," said W. Austin Ligon, the president of Circuit City's Carmax used-car chain.
Carmax offers services comparable to Autonation's, but with lower prices, Mr. Ligon said, citing Wall Street studies to support him. Since the first Carmax opened in 1993, the chain has doubled in size annually, to 17 by the end of this year, as fast as staff members can be trained, Mr. Ligon added.
Instead of becoming the Wal-Mart of the car market, Mr. Ligon predicted that Mr. Huizenga would become the Robert Campeau, whose flamboyant, and hellbent, purchases of the nation's major retailers a decade ago ended up in bankruptcy courts.
Mr. Huizenga points out that his company's finances remain strong and disagrees that Carmax is beating him on price, especially considering Autonation's refurbishing and other services. "When we put $400, $500 or $600 into a car, it's a different car," he said. "You could charge a little extra, if you could explain it to the consumer." He says his plans for linking the industry's elements are far broader than Carmax's. As an example, he said trade-ins at his new-car dealerships would give him a better supply of used cars than Carmax could find.
If Autonation aims to reinvent used-car sales, Mr. Huizenga's new-car dealers are more traditional. The Maroone (pronounced ma-ROON-ee) Auto Plaza that he bought, along with Michael Maroone's other South Florida dealerships for $216.7 million in February, looks like a couple of airport terminals linked by a long, four-level garage. Maroone ranks first in the nation in sales of Isuzus, and at least third in Dodges, fourth in General Motors over all and fifth in Chevrolets, with several other divisions selling a variety of vehicles, even garbage trucks.
Sales people at the dealership attribute their success to long-term relationships. They frequently make as many as 30 calls a day to achieve the 8 to 10 required contacts from computer-generated lists of past customers who might be ready for new cars, current customers who came to shop but didn't buy or recent customers who might appreciate the follow-up.
 MR. Huizenga wants Maroone and his other new-car dealers to introduce no-haggle pricing. Otherwise, he regards the Maroone operations as so exemplary that he has chosen Mr. Maroone to run his company's new- and used-car sales.
Though they are far from unanimous, industry experts said Mr. Huizenga could at least provide a jolt to an industry much in need of one. "It will be the first time someone has put all the pieces of the business together," said Martin L. Anderson, who teaches management at Babson College in Wellesley, Mass. "He will be able to cut a lot of costs out of the system and offer a lot more choice."
These, Mr. Huizenga affirmed, are his long-term goals. His short-term advice is embodied in the way he says goodbye. His parting words are "Buy a car."

HEADLINE: A Bucolic Nightmare: Gridlock in Suburbia

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: CORTLANDT, N.Y.

 BODY:
AT 7:20 on a misty workday morning, like soldiers mustering at dawn reveille, commuters in this suburb 45 miles north of New York City assembled in long snaking lines leading to a Y-shaped intersection.
The cars inched along the narrow, tree-lined roads, with 20 or so squirting ahead from each arm of the Y as the light went through its cycle, only to stack up at the next light, just 200 yards ahead. "If you don't get here by 7, it takes a half-hour to go four miles," said Kathy Goldstein, an accountant who has stoically driven the route for six years. The light changed, and she crawled on her way -- not to the metropolis to the south, but to her job 40 miles east, in the satellite city of Stamford, Conn. 
 In an informal survey of several dozen of her fellow commuters, no one was headed into the heart of the region, New York City. They all lived and worked in the periphery, in what urban planners call "edge city."
This congestion scene is the same in suburban fringes of big cities coast to coast. A new kind of traffic jam has emerged that bears little resemblance to the stereotype of the twice-daily tide of cars and trucks stewing in their own exhaust on the Santa Monica Freeway or on the New Jersey Turnpike.
Every morning and evening -- and increasingly in the middle of the day -- an overloaded network of small local roads clogs with traffic as commuters, shoppers, truckers and other drivers try to crisscross a landscape of dispersed neighborhoods, shopping centers and office parks.
The crush is a fundamental consequence of millions of workers and jobs migrating in recent decades from urban downtowns to outlying regions, drawn by cheaper housing and the prospect of a patch of lawn.
Suburb-to-suburb commutes have quadrupled since 1960, now accounting for 44 percent of all commuting in the United States, according to a 1996 study by Alan E. Pisarski, a transportation consultant for the Eno Transportation Foundation, an independent consulting firm in Virginia.
In essence, suburban sprawl has created something that might be called "suburban crawl" -- a chronic, creeping congestion.
This widespread slowdown is costing tens of billions of dollars in lost productivity annually, economists say, as workers, goods and materials are delayed, although it is hard to obtain firm estimates because the phenomenon is so dispersed.
Even worse, transportation experts say this traffic is likely to be far more difficult to untangle than the old-fashioned highway backup.
While travel into city centers can be eased potentially by trains, buses and other ways, planners are not finding simple solutions to moving people around the periphery efficiently. And this traffic problem is growing far faster than congestion on city-bound highways.
All told, 13 million out of the 19 million new jobs born in the United States between 1980 and 1990 were in the suburbs. "If anything, that trend is growing," Mr. Pisarski said. "The organizations move where the people are and where the pool of skills is. But, of course, as things get crowded, then the people move out farther."
The cycle repeats, and the traffic grows and spreads.
Despite half-hearted efforts in some regions to organize car pools or other alternatives, almost all these new suburban jobs have been filled by people who drive to work alone. With gasoline nearly as cheap as it has been in years, there is little incentive to change. Partly as a result, the number of trips made on public transportation in the United States declined by more than 10 percent during the 1980's.
The problem extends to the exurbs, regions that had been rural but are now growing more populated by people who work in the suburbs and want cheaper housing.
"We've created places where the only option is the automobile," said Jeffrey A. Zupan, a senior transportation analyst at the Regional Plan Association, a private group that has for decades studied long-term environmental and transportation issues around New York City.
Complicating the congestion are unpredictable driving patterns created by people who, pressed for time, combine chores into extended trips. On the way to or from work, a typical suburban commuter is very likely to drop a child at a day-care center, pick up groceries or stop at a bank or a gas station, each time exiting or entering the flow of traffic from a side street or a parking lot, resulting in what transportation engineers call interference. Or what drivers call a stop-and-start nightmare.
 THE OVERBURDENED roads, designed for a fraction of the traffic they are now bearing, are crumbling prematurely, causing new delays as "Road Work Ahead" signs sprout.
Transportation engineers see some hope for improvement in simple acts like reducing the number of places where cars can enter busy suburban arteries.
For example, adjacent shopping malls could be linked by side roads so that cars do not repeatedly exit and enter major streets, said William L. Schwartz, a transportation planner at Cambridge Systematics, a Massachusetts consulting firm. Another weak spot is officials' slow responses to traffic accidents or breakdowns that block streets, with a small disruption often leading to extensive delays, Mr. Schwartz said.
But re-engineering malls or cleaning up accidents is outside the purview of state and local transportation departments, and so these aspects of the congestion problem rarely get the necessary attention or money.
Improving the timing of traffic signals and using sensors embedded in roads to monitor buildups can help, Mr. Schwartz noted, but too often these innovations are overlooked in favor of the usual response -- lay more blacktop.
Other ways "to nibble at the problem," Mr. Zupan said, include reviving the suburban downtowns that have shriveled in the face of Wal-Marts and movie multiplexes. He added that the increase in flexible work hours and telecommuting could help.
Nevertheless, the fundamental shape of suburbia is the major challenge. The sprawling geography encompasses many counties, towns or villages, each with separate governments and transportation bureaucracies -- and agendas. Mr. Zupan said that a result is "one small office building after another, each with its own parking lot, separated by a quarter-mile, with no bus possible. This is the biggest single evil in perpetuating the suburbs."
It may still be possible for a region to shift toward the old model of focal points for living, shopping and working, Mr. Zupan said, raising the chances that buses or light-rail lines could be attractive and profitable. Eventually, the old system of transportation spokes leading into a city hub could be combined with a rim around the perimeter.
"It sounds like heresy," he said, "but suburban centers may end up part of the solution instead of the problem."
Others are not as optimistic. Timothy Lomax, a research engineer at the Texas Transportation Institute in College Station, run by Texas A & M University, compiles an annual congestion index, which has shown no signs of the trend easing. Mr. Lomax said that creating urban-style hubs might end up driving people farther out, to a new frontier of settlement and long-distance commutes. "It's not clear you can have your cake and eat it, too," Mr. Lomax said.
In the traffic trenches are people like Richard A. Peters, a planner for the New York State Department of Transportation. At his Poughkeepsie office, 70 miles north of New York City, Mr. Peters laid out a map showing several dozen suburban traffic bottlenecks he was trying to fix in the seven counties of the lower Hudson River Valley.
 PURPLE and red squiggles and dashes represented roads or intersections where the "vehicle hours of delay per mile" -- kind of a driver's pain index -- was off the scale.
Here and there around the region, Mr. Peters said, commuters were being enticed to take buses or ride in van pools. But at a growing number of spots, he said, "there's really not much we can do." Many roads can not be widened. Neighborhoods and jobs are spread out. Mass transit can nibble only at the edges of the problem.
And people seem willing to endure remarkable daily marathons to achieve the dream of a decent house and a good job -- no matter how many miles apart those two goals might be.
When Mr. Peters and other transportation experts attended a meeting with some of the region's suburban commuters last summer, they were startled at how much traffic people were willing to withstand, he said.
"You do everything you can, except knock drivers over the head and throw them on a bus," Mr. Peters said. "It's hard to get people to change."

SECTION: Section G; Page 7; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1548 words

HEADLINE: How G.I. Joe's Little Jeep Grew Into a Yuppie Hunk

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
IN THE beginning, there was the jeep: Spartan transportation based on the tough "general purpose" vehicles that jarred and jolted the Allies to victory in World War II. But like some alien life form introduced into a poorly defended environment, sport utility vehicles have evolved and multiplied, crowding out indigenous species.
Three-ton monsters like the Lincoln Navigator and GMC Suburban rumble through the asphalt jungles, intimidating lower-caste people movers. Pared down "mini-sport utes" like the Subaru Forester and the Honda CR-V dart from lane to lane, symbols of freedom in a world choked by traffic and dentist appointments. Medium-size sport utilities, veterans of the S.U.V. revolution, including the Jeep Grand Cherokee and the Land Rover Discovery, proclaim that today's 40-somethings have nothing in common with their Oldsmobile-driving fathers except a love of eight-cylinder engines, plush leather and a pillowy ride. 
 Much ado about what Keith Martin, the publisher of Sports Car Market magazine, dismisses as "mini-vans with nose jobs." Perhaps. But there's something about S.U.V.'s that inspires flights of pop sociology. Besides, the phenomenon really does mark a new direction for the industry that Henry Ford and Alfred Sloan built.
Make that new directions.
For one thing, S.U.V.'s symbolize the latest stage in the transformation of cars from transportation to fashion statements. "The baby boomers discovered health clubs and plastic surgeons," said Christopher W. Cedergren, the president of Nextrend, a California marketing research company. "Buying S.U.V.'s to match their Timberlands and 501 Levis fits a vain and image-conscious generation."
The S.U.V.'s also mark the victory of time and marketing over any lingering anxiety from the oil crises of the 1970's. "S.U.V.'s are Enemy No. 1 to energy conservation," lamented Bill Magavern, the director of Critical Mass, an arm of Public Citizen.
Most important, surely, they have given America's largest industry a fresh lease on life. Never mind that drivers under the age of 60 have deserted Cadillac and Lincoln for Mercedes and Lexus. Never mind that the Big Three must sell subcompact cars at a loss to induce Americans to drive them. Chevy Tahoes, Ford Expeditions, Jeep Wranglers and their ilk earn enough to cover the United Automobile Workers' still-generous wages, with plenty left over for shareholder dividends. "One hundred percent of Detroit's profits now come from trucklike vehicles," reckoned David B. Healy, an analyst for Burnham Securities.
The origins of the S.U.V. craze go back to the 1970's, when the California youth culture discovered that new pickup trucks could be had for the price of used Pontiacs. Put a cover on the back, along with some rudimentary seats, and voila: the sport utility vehicle, ready to boogie.
In the 1980's, the truck evolved as fashionable transportation along twin paths: the mini-van and S.U.V. When suburbia began to rebel against the mini-van image, Detroit was ready with a bevy of macho boxes that would never be mistaken for a Chrysler Town & Country.
No need to give up the space of a van to shed the soccer-mom label, auto makers explained. Buy an armor-clad, four-wheel-drive S.U.V., perfect for running the Baja or (infinitely more likely) hauling cartons of Huggies home from Costco. Better yet, buy a nine-passenger hulk like the Suburban and, in the words of a General Motors copywriter, "subdue the road through sheer size and strength."
Have you grown accustomed to the captain's chairs, cup holders and numerous small luxuries that turned mini-vans into scaled-down Winnebagos? Real men can use a comfortable seat, too. And for just $37 more each month (after an initial $995 "capital cost reduction"), the factory will be happy to add leather, dual air-conditioning controls and a compact disk changer.
Federal fuel economy standards, which put Detroit at a nearly fatal disadvantage against Japanese auto makers in the early 1980's, now began to work in the American industry's favor. The average mileage of each company fleet of cars must top a legal minimum. So to sell high-margin gas guzzlers, G.M. and Ford must use discounts to persuade often-reluctant consumers to buy Cavaliers and Escorts with raspy four-cylinder engines.
But sport utility vehicles hardly existed when the fuel economy laws were passed. They were lumped with light trucks, with separate standards set at the discretion of the Federal bureaucrats rather than cast in legal concrete. The current light-truck standard is just 20.7 miles per gallon -- 6.8 m.p.g. less than the car standard.
That has made it kosher to sell as many midsize S.U.V.'s, like the Jeep Grand Cherokee, GMC Jimmy and Ford Explorer, as Detroit could churn out. And it opened the door to the really big wheels, like the Expedition, which barely manages 15 m.p.g.
 THERE IS more than regulation and its twists, though, behind the Detroit renaissance led by S.U.V.'s. Both standard and full-size sport utilities are built on truck frames, and they share many other components with their truck counterparts.
But the Japanese sell very few full-size trucks in America, in part because imported trucks face a 25 percent tariff and in part because they do not mass-produce the V8 engines needed to power 5,000-pound road hogs. "It's an enormous barrier to entry," said David M. Garrity, an auto industry analyst for Smith Barney.
While car companies are loath to disclose profits on a model-by-model basis, the difference between the dealer invoice and the cost of manufacturing an extra Ford Expedition runs between $10,000 and $15,000. By comparison, The Detroit News estimates that the markup on a Dodge Neon is just $2,500, which probably translates into a loss when the associated overhead is included.
That's not the whole story. The fastest-growing S.U.V. segment is mini-sport utilities. Small models like the Suzuki Sidekick and Chevy (previously Geo) Tracker have been around for a while. Sales exploded, though, with the arrival of the Toyota RAV4, Honda CR-V and Subaru Forester, all of which ride like cars because they are built from compact-car components.
The Big Three may yet join the fray. "We're looking at a number of car platforms," said Dave Hansen, the category director for the Chevrolet Truck division.
But not with enthusiasm. Detroit cannot match Japan's costs on small vehicles; those low costs allow Honda to assemble a four-wheel-drive truck around the guts of a Civic and make oodles of money on a sticker price of $20,000. Nor can Detroit afford to cannibalize sales of the small, fuel-efficient cars that permit it to sell luxury cars.
The one segment of the S.U.V. market where Nissan, Toyota, Chrysler, G.M., Ford, Isuzu, Mitsubishi, Honda and Land Rover all do battle is in the middle. But even here, demand has remained sufficiently ahead of capacity to sustain generous markups. According to The Detroit News, Chrysler's net on the hugely successful Grand Cherokee is reported to run $9,000 a copy.
The prospects for the next few years, then, are for a mutually profitable standoff in which Detroit waxes fat on big S.U.V.'s and leaves mini-sport utes to Japan. Neither fuel economy nor safety issues -- a 5,600-pound Navigator can do a lot of damage when it plows into a 2,000-pound Toyota Tercel -- seem likely to spoil the party. But "it would be naive for us to assume that the business will last indefinitely," Mr. Hansen argued.
Indeed, straws already in the wind suggest how the good times will ebb.
Mercedes-Benz is producing the most sophisticated midsize S.U.V. ever and has priced it to compete with the Grand Cherokee, Explorer, Mitsubishi Montero and assorted company. Lexus is about to pull a similar trick with an S.U.V. built on the platform of a Camry. Subaru, Audi, Volvo and (soon) Volkswagen all make four-wheel-drive station wagons, which raise the bar on comfort and handling and can be trimmed to look as tough as trucks.
 BY THE same token, Chrysler is introducing the Dodge Durango, a less expensive if somewhat smaller truck alternative to the Suburban and the Navigator. And Toyota, the world's most efficient car producer, is also expected to make the investment in engine and chassis capacity needed to produce a full-size S.U.V. in America.
So, sooner rather than later, Detroit and Japan will have to cut prices. Or, more likely in view of consumers' apparent desire to treat S.U.V.'s as status symbols, they will have to add costly nontruck features, like four-wheel independent suspensions.
Surely the greatest threat, though, to the reign of the sport utility vehicle is the inherently fickle nature of fashion. Few city or suburb dwellers buy S.U.V.'s for their off-road abilities. Nor, as the novelist Richard Ford sarcastically put it in an op-ed piece in The New York Times, do many buy the cavernous boxes to haul "several sets of bagpipes or a pair of Scottish deerhounds."
Mr. Cedergren, the Nextrend president, said, "Americans make up all sorts of excuses -- they like sitting up high, they want all-wheel-drive for bad weather.
"But they really want S.U.V.'s for one reason," he went on. "They're cool."
And what's cool today is unlikely to be cool much longer.

HEADLINE: Big, Bigger, Biggest: Rolling Reports From Across the Country;
Four-Wheel Ice Follies

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
"IT could snow any time" an electronic message board has blinked since late September on Interstate 70, at the point where the plains meet the mountains.
As Colorado's main east-west highway climbs into the Rockies, it becomes the Main Street for the state's ski areas from Loveland to Vail. It also becomes an icy, double-diamond race course, scary to this driver at least, steeled after six years of negotiating the lunging traffic of Rio de Janeiro. 
 Colorado car dealers say the state has the highest per-capita number of sport utility vehicles of any state in this country. But in this kingdom of four-wheel drive vehicles (not including trucks), many drivers, either transplants from California or suburbanites who rarely see mud on their radials, do not understand that four-wheel drive offers no protection against a downhill skid.
In reality, drivers of 4-by-4's on I-70 charge easily over snow and ice on their way up to the Continental Divide, but coming down the other side, they slide in a way that looks pretty only on the slopes. Indeed, two tons of out-of-control steel is an ugly sight.
The perception that 4-by-4 drivers are lulled into a false sense of security was confirmed by a Denver Post study published in December 1995, which found four-wheel drives were more likely than normal passenger cars to cause crashes on Colorado's portion of I-70. That year, the newspaper studied all accidents reported on I-70 from Kansas to Utah during March, traditionally the region's snowiest month. Of 513 reported accidents, 43 percent, or 223, involved utility vehicles. In contrast, Colorado car dealers estimated that these vehicles accounted for fewer than one-quarter of all sales.
With Denver's economic boom, highways are clogged, and the problem seems fated to worsen.
Since 1980, the number of vehicles registered in the Denver metropolitan region has increased by 50 percent, to 2 million. During that time, the number of vehicles crossing the Continental Divide on I-70 has doubled, to about 9 million vehicles this year. Seizing a chance, the airport near Vail doubled its flights last winter, allowing skiers to fly over the Divide.
 JAMES BROOKE

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: COLORADO, USA (94%); UTAH, USA (79%); CALIFORNIA, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: Auto Makers See Nothing but Trouble in a Warmer World

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR more than a decade, the auto industry has pretty much got what it wanted in this town. Tighter fuel standards? Forget about it. New safety standards? Small potatoes only, please.
But suddenly, Detroit is finding a new reason to worry about Washington: global warming. Industry officials say there is no greater threat to the American auto industry than a concerted worldwide push to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and other so-called greenhouse gases, the suspected culprits in long-term global climate change. 
 Asked to rank the industry's major policy and regulatory concerns over the next few years, a senior representative of the Big Three answered, "Global warming is No.1, and everything else is very far behind."
No, Congress has not slipped out of Republican hands, and the Sierra Club's lobbyists are still outnumbered on K Street. But Mike Stanton, the chief Washington lobbyist for the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, said the industry is watching with great trepidation as officials debate the Government's position on a proposed global climate-change treaty.
With a prod from Vice President Gore, who sounded an early alarm about possible global warming, the Administration is expected to endorse some form of binding international emissions standards when representatives of 180 nations gather in December in Kyoto, Japan, for a conference on global climate change.
It is not surprising then, that when the President met with the chief executives of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler at the White House earlier this month to discuss trade policies, what he heard instead were complaints about emissions control.
The Kyoto conference will lay the road map for the next five years on how the world begins to cope with carbon emissions and their effect on climate and health.
The proposal that frightens auto makers most is one that will impose strict emissions standards on the developed nations but exempt the developing world, where the growth in greenhouse gas emissions is expected to be much more rapid.
Carbon dioxide occurs naturally in the atmosphere, but it is also emitted by cars, factories and the burning of carbon-based fuels like oil, coal and wood. Levels of this and other greenhouse gases are rising and thought to be warming the planet by trapping sunlight that otherwise would be reflected back into space. The automobile is a chief source of these gases. To environmental advocates, it is also one of the easiest to control.
"The reason they think it's such a threat is that the biggest single step we can take to prevent it is making our car go farther on a gallon of gas," said Dan Becker, the director of the Sierra Club's global warming and energy program. "So we are advocating higher-mileage cars."
Mr. Becker said a car that gets 27.5 miles a gallon produces 38 tons of carbon dioxide gas over a 10-year lifetime. A 45-mile-per-gallon car emits 23 tons.
That is what worries auto makers. One of their least-favorite pieces of legislation over the last 20 years is the law imposing corporate average fuel economy, or CAFE standards, forcing them to sell two or three economy cars for every low-mileage, high-profit car they produce.
THERE is no known way to eliminate carbon dioxide emissions from the burning of gasoline. Mr. Stanton said there are only two ways to reduce such emissions: drive less or drive in cars that burn less gas. That means either raising gasoline prices, imposing transportation-control measures like car pooling or alternate-day driving, or raising CAFE standards.
Each of these steps would impose huge costs on the industry -- and thus car buyers -- with uncertain benefits, Mr. Stanton said.
"The truth of the matter is there are lots of questions on the science of global warming," he said. "We don't think the state of knowledge justifies spending $200 billion to $300 billion a year to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels."
Mr. Becker scoffed. "The industry has shown an unwillingness to improve economy without CAFE standards," he said. "Our conclusion is that we can't rely on the environmental views of Detroit to improve the global warming pollution picture."
The Republican Congress has twice barred the Administration from taking steps to increase fuel efficiency standards.
While the possibility of new fuel-economy rules is the industry's major concern, there are several other significant issues before Congress and the regulatory agencies.
The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is about to rule on consumer requests to disable air bags in cars, vans and light trucks. The agency is expected to approve on-off switches for passenger air bags that would address concerns for the safety of children, the elderly and short adults.
Views are mixed within the industry, with Ford and General Motors preparing to install on-off switches for customers who ask for them, while Chrysler, Honda and others are reluctant to offer the choice of disengaging the life-saving devices.
All auto makers agree that the preferable solution to the few cases of fatal air-bag deployment is not deactivation, but "smart" air bags with sensors that can reduce the explosive power of the bag when a seat is occupied by a child or a small adult. But auto makers are uncertain customers would be willing to pay the extra cost, about $250 a vehicle.
Another issue is international trade, which is splitting auto makers and their unions, who are shoulder to shoulder against radical steps on global warming.
"Trade liberalization has contributed greatly to the strong performance of the United States economy," said Shirley Zebroski, a senior Washington representative for G.M. "Our focus remains on getting improved access throughout the world for our products."
The United Automobile Workers and other unions are skeptical about President Clinton's call for "fast-track" authority to negotiate trade agreements. They say that such deals encourage American manufacturers to build plants overseas to take advantage of lower wages and looser environmental standards.
Also on Congress's auto agenda this fall is renewal of the nation's transportation financing program, the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act, better known as Istea. Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, introduced the six-year, $145 billion bill in September, saying it would assure the quality and safety of the nation's roads into the next century.
MR. CHAFEE said he expected the auto makers' support in getting the bill through Congress, despite the fact that it contains a number of safety and environmental provisions that will cost the industry money.
"There's plenty in it for the auto companies," the Senator said. "Literally billions of dollars are going to be spent making our roads even better and maintaining them, which is terribly important to them."
In summing up the political climate for the auto industry, David Cole, the director of the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan, calls it a "mixed bag."
"The Republicans are much more friendly to market-based approaches, rather than command and control from Washington," Mr. Cole said. "For labor and the Democrats, their issue is jobs. Then there are the big regional differences, the Midwest where the plants are and the Northeast, where the pollution is.
"When you look at nitty-gritty," he said, "it cuts across both parties pretty evenly."

LENGTH: 1215 words

HEADLINE: A Show House That Smiles? Eh Bien!

BYLINE: By MITCHELL OWENS 

 BODY:
IT is impossible to climb the stairs of the 1997 French Designer Showhouse and not imagine that you have stepped into a three-dimensional version of a brain-teaser cartoon for Sunday-bored children.
Remember, this is a show house, so what is wrong with this picture? Con-Tact paper posing as bird's-eye maple. Place mats turned into lampshades. Terrazzo floor tiles on a kitchen counter top, and Corian, that ubiquitous counter material from Du Pont, transformed into Mondrian-mosaic walls. And what about that bed in Jane Victor's and Jennifer Ellenberg's fifth-floor aerie, a steel platform eerily suspended by industrial-strength cables like something out of "2001: A Space Odyssey"? 
 The French Designer Showhouse, running today through Nov. 16, is not the typical show house. Mind you, it is not the most influential showcase for interior design in the country. That is firmly the preserve of the annual Kips Bay show house, renowned for grand rooms by august professionals. But if Kips Bay is the Metropolitan Opera, its French rival, which has appeared in New York every two years since 1989, is BAM: provocative and contrary.
The trompe l'oeil finishes alone tell the story. Unlike the laborious fool-the-eye surfaces that have been a show house cliche, the "tortoise shell" pilasters in Odile de Schietere's dining room are not trying to fool anyone. Though wonderfully executed, their essential humbleness is front and center: quarter-inch wood boards casually tacked into place. This straightforward application gives Ms. de Schietere's room -- where a wrinkly, rudely nailed canvas floor cloth cuts the Russian neo-classical chairs and marble-top consoles down to size -- an appealingly temporary, degage air, like a party tent pitched for just one night. It is a neat trick, and more important, an apt symbol for a show house that is perhaps the most innovative in America, where fantasy and accessibility come together in one tidy inspirational package.
First, an explanation. The title of the show house, held this year in an 1878 town house at 49 East 67th Street (between Madison and Park Avenues), is somewhat misleading. Of the 20 designers and 17 artisans, only 3 -- Jacques Grange, Odette Boulenger and Paul Mathieu -- live and work in France. The rest are Americans, though some are French-born. The cultural designation of the show house derives largely from the name of its beneficiary: the American Hospital of Paris Foundation. But then there is the invention that the word "French" implies. These designers seem well aware that a majority of show house visitors never hire decorators -- magazines, not show houses, attract more new clients -- and so they have tried nothing blatantly commercial. Which means no chintz, no antiques with stellar provenance, no robber-baron grandeur. Instead, the designers have had fun, offering settings, details and solutions that ought to remind decorators and clients alike that the designer worth hiring is the one with a nimble mind, not just a business card.
In fact, two participating designers, Mr. Grange and Nancy Corzine, have stocked their rooms with furniture that visitors can actually go out and buy. The salon by the celebrated Mr. Grange has woven straw walls and billowing curtains of moss-green and cherry-red silk taffeta, with eclectic chairs, tables and sofas that he designed for the John Widdicomb company of Grand Rapids, Mich. And Ms. Corzine's ground-floor space -- cool, beige and vaguely 1940's -- is a showcase for her new upholstered pieces and case goods (available to designers and decorators at her Third Avenue showroom).
What these shopper-friendly settings mean to the rarefied genre of decorator show houses will cause serious debate in some circles, outrage in others. But the ramparts have been breached: merchandising in show houses is here. Get used to it.
Fortunately, the ideas outnumber the product plugs. Saddled with an outmoded, age-battered kitchen? "Paint, paint, paint," Jamie Drake said. "Short of demolition, it's the only solution." On the ceiling, walls and metal cabinets of the kitchen and breakfast area, Mr. Drake applied an icy pastel he called "angora sweater blue" -- Benjamin Moore's No. 792 -- transforming the dreary space into something sleek and modern for a few hundred dollars.
The breakfast area's awkwardly placed street-front windows were masked with a floor-to-ceiling curtain and, Mr. Drake proudly explained, the recessed fluorescent lights glow behind Coretex panels of milky corrugated plastic that cost $3 each at places like Home Depot.
High style through the sensitive use of bargain goods is a motif. The gridlike wainscoting in Christopher Coleman's bathroom and dressing room is made of white strips of wood and squares of mirror from a hardware store. To block the dispiriting view of a construction site from the balcony off the sleek Lucite-and-oak bedroom designed by Jeanne-Aelia Desparmet-Hart, the artisans Philippe Soule and Donna Gutkin of Escabelle Design created a sculpture-cum-shield of autumn leaves glued to undulating frosted Lucite.
"Before, it was like a tomb," Jean-Pierre Dovat said of his cellar-level room, which encloses an L-shaped pool. He vanquished the claustrophobic effects of the long, low, narrow room with cleverly angled mirrors -- along the walls as well as underwater -- and then used Con-Tact adhesive paper to give the changing room's sliding door and handrail the look of bird's-eye maple.
"If you use them properly, in the right way, cheap things can be so beautiful," Mr. Dovat said. He also came up with the show house's best example of inspired recycling. Matchstick place mats from Gracious Home, bent into wide U shapes and lined with white paper, were turned into shades for the pool area's garish crystal light fixtures.
Other staples of late 1960's and early 70's decor -- silver Mylar, layer-cake banquettes, massive Lucite -- are ubiquitous. The Gucci-and-Furstenberg wrap-dress revival has much to answer for here. The glossy brown hall by Myles Scott Harlan and Douglas Wilson, with its Lucite banister and stair treads encased in stainless steel, recalled such period night spots as Regine's.
"Not all cheap things are bad," said Robert Couturier, a designer whose flamboyant impishness conceals a scholar's knowledge of 18th-century French decoration and architecture. Which explains why his room, a great salon tented with black-and-white cotton printed with iguanas and artichokes, contains wonders of every economic origin: a Louis XIV sofa in worn silk velvet flanked by flea-market tables topped with Bakelite; a folk-art bird sculpture made of buttons with African statues; a grand Roman Catholic reliquary alongside 1940's lawn chairs by Jean Royere. For the floor, Mr. Couturier created an area rug with copies of 18th-century maps of Paris covered with a Plexiglas sheet.
A big mix, but, Mr. Couturier said, that's how people live today. "Haphazard is the most fulfilling kind of decor," he said, plopping down on the sofa and looking alarmed as it slid a few inches on the Plexiglas.
"If you like something, then that is enough for it to be in your life," he continued, quickly regaining his composure. "That is the thread that holds your things together."
