SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 5; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1650 words

HEADLINE: Orchestras Welcome Corporate Overtures;
Concerts Raise Funds, and Questions

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Usually, when shareholders leave the annual meeting of RPM Inc. in Cleveland, they are clutching five-gallon buckets filled with samples of Rust-Oleum, Mar-Hyde windshield cleaner, Chemspec carpet cleaner and other products from the company's industrial repertory.
Tomorrow, they will be getting a different treat: a serenade from the Cleveland Orchestra, hired for $100,000 to mark the company's 50th anniversary. "My goodness," said David W. Smith, president of the American Society of Corporate Secretaries, whose members are generally responsible for organizing annual meetings. "It's quite amazing. I've never heard of any company doing that before." Nor have other corporate experts. 
 But RPM, whose sales and earnings have been climbing for a half-century, is in a jubilant mood. "There isn't another publicly owned manufacturing company that's had 50 consecutive years like that," said Thomas C. Sullivan, the chief executive. "So we thought we must celebrate. And why not with the Cleveland Orchestra?" More than 4,000 of the company's shareholders have R.S.V.P.'d yes, quadruple the usual attendance.
RPM's concert, an hourlong performance of works by Tchaikovsky, presents an intriguing opportunity for the nation's financially precarious orchestras, not to mention a painless way for corporations to support the arts, because the costs of annual meetings are fully tax-deductible.
The Cleveland's gig for RPM is also a musical milestone because of the audience. Many orchestras accept and even solicit the occasional private engagement, but they are usually hired to play for high-profile listeners at formal charity benefits or meetings of public policy groups like the International Monetary Fund or the National Governors' Conference. RPM's concert has a more populist cast, more brown suit than black-tie.
The Cleveland Orchestra "doesn't need to beg for money," said Charles S. Olton, president of the American Symphony Orchestra League. "The more interesting aspect is the social purpose of carrying music to people who might not come into your concert hall. If they see you in one place, they might be more likely to come to the concert hall."
But these private concerts also raise questions. The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, for example, recently performed for the Promise Keepers, the evangelical Christian men's movement whose rally on the National Mall on Oct. 4 was described by many people who oppose its agenda as having a conservative Republican tinge, though its leaders deny any political motives.
Generally, orchestra officials said, their organizations have no set policy about who they will or will not play for; they make decisions on a case-by-case basis. The Atlanta Symphony's general manager, George Alexsovich, compared the situation to a newspaper's accepting advertising, which does not imply an endorsement of the product.
As for the Promise Keepers, he noted that many orchestras, including the Atlanta, play for various religious groups. In any case, no official of the orchestras questioned recalled having turned anyone down if an invitation meshed with their concert schedules.
Private concerts are part of a mounting commercialism that has crept into many corners of the arts world, raising concern in some quarters. Over the years, museums and arts organizations have become increasingly reliant on corporate dollars, through partnerships, awards programs and events underwritten by sponsors.
Twenty-five years ago, for example, Philip Morris began giving grants to dance, reaching a total of more than $25 million to companies like American Ballet Theater and Dance Theater of Harlem and to the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. In 1995, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum announced a five-year, $5 million partnership with Hugo Boss, easing its budget and putting the German men's wear company in the spotlight.
 
'It Makes Good Business Sense'
No question, private concerts make a lot of sense for orchestras. Though their financial status has improved with the economy, and bankruptcy filings are yesterday's news, nearly 40 percent of the nation's orchestras still operate in the red, according to the symphony league.
"I don't know of an orchestra in the country that wouldn't sell a service if they are available," said Mr. Alexsovich, who has worked for a half-dozen orchestras. "It makes good business sense," he said, since all or most of the fee can go directly to the orchestra's bottom line.
Typically, an orchestra contracts with musicians for a set number of so-called services, said J. Thomas Bacchetti, an orchestra consultant based in Atlanta. These services, averaging about eight a week, can be concerts or rehearsals. If an orchestra does not use up all eight on its own, it can schedule a private concert without adding to payroll costs. "So you do make some money from it," Mr. Bacchetti said.
Orchestras try to fill in blanks in their schedule with out-of-town engagements or with "runout concerts," in which they are hired by arts organizations in nearby communities to give what are essentially public performances. Private concerts come next. Sometimes, orchestras will even pay musicians for services beyond those required by their contract to take a job, although the profit is lower.
All of the orchestras questioned offered examples of their own private concerts or, like the Philadelphia Orchestra, said they would consider them.
"We don't have much time for them," said Deborah Borda, the executive director of the New York Philharmonic, which accepts one private concert a year. "But when we do them, we want complete artistic control of the program. And then the basic rule is that we consider it a way to raise money." The philharmonic charges a little more than $100,000.
The Boston Symphony, too, performs privately about once a year, for a negotiable charge in the "low six figures," said Mark Volpe, the managing director. (The symphony's sister organization, the Boston Pops, plays perhaps 20 times a year for private groups, about half in front of business-related audiences.)
At the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Vanessa Moss, a vice president, said that her orchestra regularly performed at benefits, but did a few private concerts for conventions or business groups. "We might have done three in the last five years," she said, for a charge of $100,000 and up.
As for the Atlanta, which charges a fee that varies from $15,000 to $50,000 for a concert, the orchestra played at the opening ceremonies of the 1996 Olympic Games, as well as for the Promise Keepers.
 
Special Place In the Community
The Cleveland Orchestra, which also performs for benefits and high-toned private groups a few times a year, seems to be the only one that was called for duty by people outside the black-tie set. That, city residents said, is a reflection of its position in the community. In recent years, for example, it has played concerts for the employees of B. F. Goodrich and of Society Corporation (renamed Keycorp after a merger).
RPM was partly inspired by a gala concert celebrating the 125th anniversary of The Cleveland Plain Dealer in 1991 at which the Cleveland Orchestra performed. RPM also considered other ways to celebrate its anniversary, including a theater production at the Cleveland Playhouse and commissioning some music for recording by the Cleveland Chamber Orchestra.
The Cleveland Orchestra won out because of its prestige, Mr. Sullivan said. Though RPM has never underwritten any of the orchestra's concerts, the orchestra's donor list shows that it contributed between $10,000 and $15,000 to the orchestra last year, and that James A. Karman, the company's president, is a trustee of the orchestra who contributed between $15,000 and $20,000 last year. Mr. Karman, who joined the orchestra's board in 1992, is the founding chairman of its corporate council.
Mr. Sullivan, RPM's chief executive, called the concert idea a classic, especially since the $100,000 cost has been offset by scheduling the company's annual meeting of managers from around the world at the same time and by eliminating the annual bucket of samples. "We had a few shareholders call in and complain about that," he said.
But they seem to be in the minority. Shareholders are traveling to Cleveland for the concert "from 30 states, from Maine to Alaska," Mr. Sullivan said.
 
Reserving A Bigger Hall
RPM was surprised by the response. Originally, it had rented Severance Hall, the orchestra's home, along with three satellite areas that would receive a video feed, for a total of 2,800 seats. But that plan was quickly outgrown, and two weeks ago, RPM rented Cleveland State University's convocation hall, which seats 13,000. At the time, the arena was reserved for a recruiting event by the university's basketball team, which agreed to postpone it.
As a result, at around 5 P.M. tomorrow, the orchestra will play four pieces: the Polonaise from "Eugene Onegin," excerpts from "Swan Lake," the overture from "Romeo and Juliet" and "Marche Slav," Op. 31, under the baton of the resident conductor, Jahja Ling. (Christoph von Dohnanyi, the music director, is in Paris, rehearsing the opera "Hansel and Gretel.")
"We chose the composer, Tchaikovsky, because I love him," Mr. Sullivan said. "And they chose the program. We'd be very foolish to presume to tell the Cleveland Orchestra what to play."
If the current enthusiasm is a guide, there will be calls from shareholders for an encore. But it remains to be seen whether or not RPM will inspire other companies to follow its lead.
"I don't think it'll be a trend," said Mr. Smith of the corporate secretaries' group, "though it very much depends on the C.E.O. The trend is to keep annual meetings lean, to go through the business boom, boom, boom. But this is an anniversary, and therein lies the difference."

LENGTH: 1384 words

HEADLINE: Must-Have Label

BYLINE: By JULIE V. IOVINE 

 BODY:
BUYERS of handmade imported rugs are used to petting the plush, appraising the pattern and checking the dimensions. But not until now have so many buyers been inspecting a rug's flip side, searching out a little tag that says the rug was made without child labor.
With the new ban on imports of goods made by children in bondage, signed by President Clinton last Friday, it has become the latest must-have label. 
 "Our customers are really aware," said Kimberley Aylward, the spokeswoman for Garnet Hill, a mail-order catalogue that sells $1 million in imported rugs each year. "They want assurances even before they place an order that no kids were involved."
Accurate numbers do not exist for the number of children working in servitude in the making of rugs in South Asia, said Darlene Atkins, the public policy coordinator at the Child Labor Coalition in Washington. Estimates range from 300,000 to one million, the latter figure provided by the South Asian Coalition on Child Servitude. Most of the children working in the rug industry are in India and Pakistan, Ms. Atkins said.
Although Congress passed the new law, it did not appropriate any additional money for the Custom Service to monitor imports or track violators. Retailers and manufacturers in the imported carpet business, estimated at $1.3 billion a year, are aware of the risk to their image in selling items made by children and are looking for ways to market their awareness to concerned customers. These range from self-monitoring -- Ikea and Pottery Barn are among the stores that hire agents to inspect looms periodically -- to labeling programs, of debatable efficacy, that monitor production and use the fees they collect to set up schools.
Frank Hagemann, a policy analyst at the International Labor Organization in Geneva, said that the number of rug manufacturers signed up for programs worldwide is too small to measure. But "awareness is increasing rapidly," he said. Five years ago, he pointed out, there were no programs at all.
Right now, the most visible marketing tool is labeling. The international labor group says six labeling programs currently operate in India, Germany, Switzerland, Brazil and the United States. The two largest programs are Rugmark and Kaleen.
Rugmark, an international nonprofit organization that has enlisted 145 manufacturers from India and Nepal, monitors production and uses fees paid to it to finance three schools in Nepal and India. Kaleen, which is promoted by the Government of India in collaboration with the carpet industry, requires that every exporter contribute 0.25 percent of the export price of each rug to the program and register every loom in return for the Kaleen label. The money raised is used for schools.
Only the winsome, smiley-face Rugmark label certifies that products are made without child labor. "We guarantee to the public that we have done a thorough inspection," said Terrence Collingsworth, the general counsel to the International Labor Rights Fund in Washington and a member of the Rugmark board, adding, "if you want to sell rugs in the United States, you're going to need some kind of certificate."
Ike Timianko, the owner of the Central Carpet in Manhattan, said: "If I don't see a tag, I don't buy the rug. My customers want to know."
But effective monitoring remains the biggest snag. Critics say that any retailer offering a blanket guarantee is being naive -- at best -- given the workload of inspectors.
Rugmark, despite its $1 million budget, has only 18 inspectors who are supposed to make surprise visits to 18,636 looms. Kaleen turns the work of monitoring looms at 2,400 carpet export houses over to an independent Indian research organization with 18 inspectors.
"Labeling programs are futile," said Chris Walter, the project director at Cultural Survival, a nonprofit human-rights organization in Boston. "Labels can and will be bought."
Elliott Schrage, an adjunct professor at Columbia University's business school who has helped coordinate an effort by the sports equipment industry to stop using children to stitch soccer balls in Pakistan, says that passing laws and affixing labels may not be the best way to help exploited children. "Without a video camera on every loom in every home where rugs are made," he said, "there's no way you can know if children were involved."
James Tufenkian, an American rug manufacturer who employs some 6,000 weavers in Nepal and who is a board member at Rugmark, says that while Rugmark's heart is "100 percent in the right place, it's difficult to know what's really going on when production is so spread out in the weavers' homes."
Dan Hodges, the president of Pande Cameron & Company, a Manhattan importer of rugs from India, contends that all labeling programs are vulnerable to corruption. He said that opportunities are abundant for inspectors to demand bribes in return for lying about the involvement of children.
Ikea does not place any tags on its rugs because "we would have to have people out there all the time watching, and without that, we cannot make a real guarantee," said Marianne Barner, a manager at Ikea headquarters in Almhult, Sweden. She added that the Ikea chain pays another company to make random visits to looms.
At Pottery Barn, "our position is that child labor is an issue that we cannot afford to be associated with," said Patrick Connolly, a vice president. Some Kaleen rugs are evident in its stores, but he said, "Our goal is not to get a label on every rug but to make sure there has been no illegal use of children."
ABC Carpet and Home in Manhattan, with annual sales volumes in rugs of $60 million, has so far refused to affix any labels to the rugs they manufacture in South Asia. It employs 6 inspectors for 1,000 looms.
"The tags are a joke," says Graham Head, managing director at ABC. "The only ones profiting from them are the makers of the tags themselves."
THE new law specifically bans imports by children in bondage, estimated at $100 million worth of goods each year, for the most part rugs and carpets. ABC claims that not enough of a distinction has been made between bonded, or indentured labor, which all agree is intolerable, and cottage labor, where a group of people, often related and perhaps including children, all contribute to piece-work production. IKEA, for example, favors banning all children having any role in the making of the carpets they sell. Making a distinction between family work and bonded labor, said Ms. Barner, is too complicated. "We say 'No child, period,' " she said.
Mr. Head of ABC Carpet and many others say the impact of such blanket prohibitions go against the natural rhythms of rural-based economies and could be damaging if they don't offer children the all-important alternative of an education. "If you want to really tackle the problems of poor countries, don't take away one of the only forms of income they have," said Mr. Head.
Mr. Walter agrees. "Just not working doesn't solve anything," he said. "In a single family some of the children may be working so that others can go to school."
Referring to cottage industries, Mr. Walter and many observers are sensitive to the issues of Western values applied to foreign cultures. "I see it as an issue of cultural domination," said Carol Bier, curator of Eastern Hemisphere collections at the Textile Museum in Washington. "In many cultures the economies are very different from our own, many are family-based and the set-ups are very different from documentable child abuse. Rug weaving is one of the most perfect examples of a sustainable economy in developing countries. In Turkey virtually every living room will have a loom in it.
" There is pride and delight felt by the whole family with their rugs," she added, noting that a child well-versed in the art of weaving often has a highly sophisticated grasp of complicated mathematics. "To ban all that could have a devastating effect."
With time, the mounting concern of consumers may be seasoned with a commitment to programs that really help children. With cottage labor so important to the survival of developing economies, Mr. Hodges, the Manhattan rug importer, said, "I just hope the new ban leaves plenty of room for exceptions."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Weaker on Hint Of Another German Rate Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the mark on speculation that German interest rates might rise sooner than rates in the United States.
While an unexpected gain in American retail sales fanned talk that the Federal Reserve might raise rates as soon as next month, German central bankers are dropping hints that they might follow up last week's rise in a money market rate with another increase. "German rates will probably rise before ours do," said Bill Bertha, foreign-exchange manager at Mellon Bank in Boston. "And as far as magnitude is concerned, it's all in Germany's court." 
 The mark got help late in New York trading after the Bundesbank's chief economist, Otmar Issing, said that central bankers were concerned about rising prices in Germany. "We need to be hawkish on inflation," Mr. Issing said in a speech in Paris. "Our decision of last Thursday was directed at that." Traders took the comment as a signal that the bank might raise the securities repurchase rate again soon, and bought marks.
Mr. Issing's remark heightened speculation on Tuesday after a Bundesbank council member, Helmut Hesse, said the bank would "review interest rates every two weeks," a reminder that it could increase lending rates at any point.
The mark was also helped when the Russian Parliament postponed a confidence vote on Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin's Cabinet. Turmoil in Russia weighs on the mark as Germany is Russia's largest trading partner and a big lender.
The dollar was held back against the yen as trade concerns offset expectations of continued weakness in the Japanese economy.
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.7475 marks, down from 1.7523 on Tuesday. It fell to 121.16 yen from 121.65. The British pound rose to $1.6239 from $1.6207.
In other currency trading, the Indonesian rupiah tumbled as much as 2.8 percent against the dollar on worries that the Government would not reach agreement with the International Monetary Fund on conditions for an assistance package to restore confidence in the economy.
The Thai baht and the Malaysian ringgit also tumbled on concerns that those countries' governments would not take the right steps to revive their ailing economies.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Palladium and Platinum Rise In Concern on Russian Supply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Palladium and platinum prices rose sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid persistent concern that Russia would sharply reduce shipments to Western users in coming months, causing a scramble for industrial metals.
On other markets, corn prices rose as commercial users rushed to lock in prices on the expectation of tight supplies in coming weeks. 
 Russia and Japan are set in early December to begin negotiating contracts for shipments in 1998 of palladium and platinum, which are used in jewelry, cars, computers and other electronics. Russia is the largest producer of palladium, accounting for about 70 percent of the world's supply, and is the second-largest producer of platinum behind South Africa. Japan is the world's largest user of the metals.
There are fears that internal political and economic turmoil within Russia will again cause shipping delays, much like those that held up transportation of the metals for seven months earlier this year, sending prices rocketing to 12-year highs.
Many in the market expect that there will be glitches in the talks, said David Rinehimer, an analyst with Smith Barney Inc., who noted that prices had remained high despite recent shipments from Russia to meet current demand. "Russian exports might not much exceed the levels that we had this year, which are very low," he said.
Palladium for December delivery rose $6, to $215.45 an ounce, the highest since early August on the New York Mercantile Exchange, and closing in on 12-year highs. January platinum rose $6.70, to $439.90 an ounce.
Corn futures prices rose on the Chicago Board of Trade as users took advantage of the recent price declines to buy heavily.
World demand for the United States crop could reach record levels this year, causing a 9.312-billion-bushel crop, the third largest on record, to dwindle rapidly. Some buyers believe now is the best time to buy before prices rocket higher, analysts said.
The concern about supply helped overcome selling pressure tied to forecasts for nearly perfect harvesting weather over the next week in the Midwest. December corn rose 4.25 cents, to $2.90 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Little Travel Agency That Could;
Rosenbluth's Key to Growth Is Corporate Business

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
When Rosenbluth International opened an office in Atlanta 12 years ago, it heralded its arrival with a billboard proclaiming, "Rosenbluth has landed!"
"We landed all right -- with a thud," said Hal F. Rosenbluth, the 45-year-old chairman of the giant travel services company. "As far as I know, nobody in Atlanta knew or cared what Rosenbluth was." 
 Not many Atlantans know even today, nor many Philadelphians, for that matter, though Rosenbluth has been here for more than a century, giving it seniority over such other home-grown institutions as the Eagles football team and Tastykakes.
Indeed, Rosenbluth is the travel agency the public hasn't heard of -- and that has turned out to be just fine. Faced with yawns in the streets of Atlanta and elsewhere, the company redoubled its efforts in the nation's executive suites. Putting together one of the most high-tech reservation and pricing systems in the industry, it worked hard to attract corporate customers with promises of big savings and smooth service. The effort has paid off: still relatively obscure, Rosenbluth is thriving as a travel agent to big business -- with clients like DuPont, Wal-Mart Stores, Nike and Chevron -- and pretty much ceding the leisure market to the rest of the industry.
Rosenbluth's corporate focus and cutting-edge information systems have paid off in another way as well. The company has managed to ride serenely above the changes roiling many other agencies. These include changes wrought by reduced airline commissions, by travelers making end runs around agents by booking through the Internet and with E-mail -- and by the need for better equipment to keep up with the Rosenbluths of the world.
From a handful of offices in Philadelphia 20 years ago, Rosenbluth is now in 46 states. But in recent years it has also become a power abroad, with operations in 43 countries, from Chile to China. Its 1996 gross sales of $2.5 billion in the United States tied it with BTI Americas for third place in Travel Weekly's ranking of travel agencies, behind only American Express ($9.1 billion) and Carlson Wagonlit Travel ($3.2 billion). Its worldwide sales last year totaled $3 billion, and this year the privately held Rosenbluth is projecting revenues of $3.5 billion.
Few of Rosenbluth's 1,260 offices are walk-in operations -- almost 98 percent of the company's revenue derives from managing the travel needs of its 1,500 or so corporate clients, which include some smaller businesses and a number of law firms. Its advertising budget, a paltry $150,000 this year, is directed not at consumers but at executives and corporate travel managers who read trade publications.
Rosenbluth says it has a client retention rate well over 90 percent. But it still suffers the occasional defection, losing the Pittsburgh Pirates and the General Electric Company, among others. And as big as it now is, it continues to cast itself as the scrappy upstart -- as its icon, it has held on to the salmon, battling its way upstream against the odds.
Mr. Rosenbluth periodically invites thousands of employees to get-togethers that resemble a blend of pep rally, corporate retreat and revival meeting. At one such gathering in the Pennsylvania Convention Center here two months ago, and with American Express and Carlson Wagonlit clearly in mind, he told a cheering crowd of 4,500, "None of our competitors thought we could build a global company so fast and so focused." Quickly warming to the subject, he added: "You know why they didn't believe we could do it? Because they knew they couldn't do it themselves."
Not quite, said Travis Tanner, the chief executive of Carlson Wagonlit, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. "They have one office in London; we have 45 in the U.K.," he said. "Having an office in a market doesn't make you global -- geographical dispersal makes you global."
Mr. Tanner also said that when G.E. put its travel account up for bids in 1992, after having been with Rosenbluth for almost two decades, it asked bidders to submit outlines of their vision of the travel agency of the future. "They chose us," Mr. Tanner said, "because they thought we were the best strategic partner to take them where they wanted to go."
Truly global or not, Rosenbluth has come a long, long way from its beginnings in 1892, when Marcus Rosenbluth, the founding great-grandfather, hit on the idea of charging European immigrants $50 for steamship passage to New York and transportation from Ellis Island to Philadelphia.
The agency stayed close to home for three generations, booking the usual range of cruises and plane trips for customers, until Hal Rosenbluth became president in 1985.
An admittedly indifferent student at the University of Miami, Mr. Rosenbluth joined the agency after graduation in 1974 and began working his way up the family corporate ladder.
But in 1978, the year airlines were deregulated, he wandered into the area where reservation agents were working on the company's few corporate accounts, which represented just $5 million or so in bookings. In that pre-computer era, booking flights meant having to talk on two telephones at once, one with the client, the other with the airline, while also writing orders and putting them into slots on a lazy susan to be delivered as tickets the next day.
Impressed by the agents' esprit de corps, Mr. Rosenbluth pulled up a chair, picked up a phone -- and remained there for several years.
"After a couple of days," he said, "I demoted myself from vice president to reservations agent and went into business travel full time."
Landing the Bethlehem Steel account in 1982 allowed Rosenbluth to add an office in Allentown, Pa., and signing up DuPont in 1985 gave it a national presence.
But the key to Rosenbluth's success was a mastery of computers. After buying its own mainframe, it developed a reservation data system that listed flights by price, thus enabling the company to guarantee corporate travel managers the lowest fare on every route.
Next, it promised to reduce corporate travel budgets in return for fees from clients instead of commissions from airlines. Then, as its technological sophistication grew, it demonstrated how airlines could increase revenues by lowering fares to Rosenbluth clients on certain routes, in return for the clients' guarantee to fill more seats on those routes.
Since then, the technology department, which now accounts for one-fifth of the 500 employees here at world headquarters, has turned out an array of software wizardry.
This includes an on-line reservations system that allows travelers to book flights, hotels and rental cars from their personal computers, using a list of options that ranks the best deal for the company and insures compliance with corporate policy on costs and other travel concerns. Another program enables employees to submit expense reports using a company's existing E-mail network.
What's more, management says, Rosenbluth is the only travel company that links all of its offices electronically through the same information system, an advantage, it insists, that guarantees seamless, consistent service.
For much of the last year, the company has added new business at the rate of $3 million a day, including almost $100 million in revenues from such big new customers as the News Corporation, Nike Europe, USX's Marathon Oil, Gateway 2000, the University of California at Los Angeles, the Rock-Tenn Company and the Canadian National Railway.
By opening an office at the London headquarters of Western Geophysical, the Houston-based provider of services to the oil industry, Rosenbluth said it was able to save its client more than $109,000 in the first quarter of this year alone. It did so through negotiated fares and a careful analysis of where it would be most economical to purchase tickets, based in part on such factors as currency fluctuations, local price controls and a constant shuffling between American and British fare tables.
Just this year, Rosenbluth opened offices in Argentina, Brazil, Costa Rica, Germany, India and Switzerland, and in December it will open an office in Vienna to service its $40 million account with the International Atomic Energy Agency.
Rosenbluth owns and manages the agencies in 25 countries, and has forged partnerships in 18 others -- mostly countries that prohibit foreign ownership. In the United Arab Emirates, it has a partnership with the Kanoo Group of Bahrain, a diversified company with operations throughout the Persian Gulf region. Its alliances with Government-owned partners in China, where it has agreed to open offices in more than a dozen cities, have already made it the biggest travel company in Shanghai and will soon make it the biggest in Beijing.
Given the company's current size and reach, it is somewhat surprising to hear Mr. Rosenbluth say that there is still a future for mom-and-pop travel agencies. (His own mom, Frances, and pop, Harold, who remains co-chairman with his cousin, Eugene Block, still work at the company, as does his sister, Amy. His brother, Lee M., is president of Rosenbluth Vacations, a separate company that concentrates on the leisure business and has annual sales in excess of $90 million.)
Small agencies have "an opportunity to use their expertise in travel, including making house calls and acting as consultants," Hal Rosenbluth said, toward the end of a recent long day. "But they'll probably have to have tickets and such processed by somebody else."
Before a visitor could ask if "somebody else" meant him, Mr. Rosenbluth said he was thinking about taking the company public. It would make it easier to expand, he said.
Then he excused himself. There was an urgent phone call to take, and final preparations to attend to for a trip the next day. The chairman of obscure Rosenbluth International was going to sail down the Amazon, then visit his offices in Brazil and Argentina. There wasn't going to be a company billboard in sight.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hal F. Rosenbluth, chairman of Rosenbluth International, has taken a steamship ticket office his great-grandfather founded in 1892, depicted on a mural in his office, and made it into a giant travel company for corporate customers. (Tim Shaffer for The New York Times)(pg. D1)
 
Chart: "A Road Warrior's Best Friend"
With clients like DuPont, Wal-Mart, Nike and Chevron, Rosenbluth International has built its travel business -- and its reputation -- by catering to industry and ignoring the leisure market. It also has developed a corporate culture where employees (er, associates) speak a different language.

HEADLINE: An Arts Center for New Jersey

 BODY:
The New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark will open on Saturday to expectations that will be a challenge to meet. No development can single-handedly restore life to Newark's downtown, but this $180 million facility -- financed with state and Federal money and more than $50 million in private contributions -- offers more promise than many past urban renewal efforts.
The Performing Arts Center will be home to the New Jersey Symphony and several New Jersey-based theater and dance companies. The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will also be a resident affiliate. The inaugural season will present dozens of the world's great artists in classical music and jazz, as well as performances of ballet, contemporary dance, world music, opera and plays. The point is not to duplicate Lincoln Center, but to offer a compelling and convenient alternative, especially for residents of New Jersey who might prefer not to cross the Hudson. 
 The idea of putting a grand arts facility in the middle of Newark's desolate downtown seemed hopelessly optimistic when it was first proposed by Gov. Thomas Kean a decade ago. Poverty, crime and middle-class flight after the 1967 riots made Newark a forbidding place.
Yet it was not an illogical choice. The city is accessible from highways, rail lines and Newark Airport. Several higher-education institutions are based there, making the creation of a cultural district possible. More than four million people live in the surrounding New Jersey suburbs, providing a huge potential audience.
Ten years of work and the support of three Governors, the state's largest corporations, private philanthropists and local political leaders have now made that vision a reality. The Performing Arts Center's leaders have faith in the power of art to heal a troubled community and confidence that easy parking and good shows will bring suburbanites back.
From the beginning the project was meant to be more than just a beautiful building. Part of its mission is to be an arts education mecca for the whole state. The center will run workshops for teachers, a schooltime theater series, a dance academy, after-school training for young musicians and arts camps to serve thousands of students from the city and its suburbs. Another of its announced purposes is to be a catalyst for commercial and residential development. That will take longer to achieve and is more problematic, although new arts developments in cities such as Cleveland and Pittsburgh have in fact encouraged development by attracting visitors day and night.
The streets around the center have been repaved. The old Military Park garage across the street has been renovated. Signs to the center on all the nearby highways are in place. The gleaming structure, housing the 2,750-seat Prudential Hall and the 514-seat Victoria Theater, already dominates the corridor between downtown and the Passaic River waterfront. But the success of this hugely ambitious venture will be apparent only when platoons of school buses line the streets by day and audiences fill the sidewalks at night.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Home Mortgage Defaults Are Still Rising in Region

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Signals abound in the New York metropolitan region that the economy has heated up, especially in the last year. One indicator, however, still looks like the bad old days of the recession and appears to be getting worse: more homeowners in the region are defaulting on their mortgages than at any time since at least the late 1970's, and in higher numbers than in the rest of the nation.
Through the first six months of this year, Connecticut had the second highest percentage in the nation of its total household mortgages in foreclosure, according to the most recent figures from the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. New Jersey ranked third. New York State was fourth. Only California was higher than Connecticut. 
 But economists and bankers say the numbers do not suggest an economic downturn so much as a new rhythm. One reason, they say, is that walking away from debt through bankruptcy, which often goes hand in hand with foreclosure, has lost much of its stigma in recent years.
In the three states in the region -- and in much of California -- home prices in many areas have never recovered the heights reached in the late 1980's. People who might have struggled on for years in hope of recapturing some equity in their homes have given up.
The economic recovery in the region has also been uneven, leaving some pockets in all three states -- the Hartford area, parts of upstate New York, and the rural southern areas of New Jersey in particular -- in continued economic stress.
And bankers admit that they are not trying as hard to keep people in their homes. The ambitious programs begun in the early 1990's to help people through tough times and to keep banks from being overwhelmed by repossessed property have been quietly shelved. The recent rise in foreclosures, unless it continues and worsens, does not justify reviving programs that were costly to run and were created to solve a one-time crisis, bankers say.
"We're at a permanently higher level," said Dorothea E. Brennan, senior vice president for residential lending at People's Bank in Bridgeport, Conn. "There will always be a certain level of foreclosures that in our past did not exist. There's been a change in attitude, a change in the marketplace and a change in the fundamental economic decisions that people are making."
A Westchester County family, for example, bought a home in the late 1980's at the cusp of the market. The home's value plummeted soon after in the recession. The husband was laid off. Now he is working again, but the home is still worth about $30,000 less than the couple paid for it and spent on improvements. Their lawyer, Barry G. Bell, said he would probably advise them to pull the plug. "In some cases, you must counsel them to stop beating a dead horse and let it go," he said.
Through the mid-1990's, the old rhythm held: foreclosures fell steadily as the region worked through the effects of the recession earlier in the decade. Then, about three years ago, foreclosures began rising again, even as the pace of economic recovery, measured by things like job creation and unemployment, improved.
In Connecticut and New York, the percentage of properties in foreclosure was higher in the middle of this year than at any period during the recession, or any period since the Mortgage Bankers Association began tracking such foreclosure numbers in 1979. New Jersey's foreclosure rate has not returned to its recession-era levels, which peaked in 1992 at 2.44 percent of all loans -- about one in 40 properties in the state -- but it has climbed from its post-recession low point, set in late 1995.
Some analysts say this is all just hard-nosed self-interest at work. If a homeowner has no equity in a house, meaning that the selling price on the market would be less than the amount owed on the mortgage, then throwing one's family into personal bankruptcy is not a sign of household stress but of cunning. That is a more common scenario in the New York region and in California than elsewhere in the nation because of the sharp run-up in prices a decade ago and the bear market that followed.
"It's actually the rational choice," said Asieh Mansour, an economist at Standard & Poor's DRI, an economic research concern.
In the Northeast, in particular, housing has been more closely linked to bankruptcy than elsewhere in country. A survey of 50,000 debtors who had filed for bankruptcy in 1996 and 1997, released earlier this year by Visa U.S.A., said a higher proportion of people in the Northeast than anywhere else in the country identified foreclosure as the "last straw" that led to their bankruptcy filing.
Ms. Brennan at People's Bank said that for about five years, from the onset of the recession in the late 1980's until about 1995, the No. 1 causes for foreclosure were economic, especially a lost job. But in the last year, some old, historically important social causes for foreclosure have re-emerged. Divorce and its consequences, she said, have once again become the most commonly cited reason why payments can no longer be made. And the pain and economic hardship of those cases is often as great as ever.
Melitta Strebel was in Germany, settling her family's affairs after the death of her father and going through a long-distance divorce when she got a mortgage foreclosure notice last year. She was able to refinance the loan and save her property in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., and another piece of land in upstate New York, but just barely, she said.
"It was more than a nightmare," she said. "When someone is trying to take your property away, the pressure is so tremendous that you feel helpless. You do not know where to turn."
But the figures from the Mortgage Bankers Association show that while more properties may be in foreclosure in the region than elsewhere, the percentage of people who are behind on their payments -- an indicator of future foreclosures -- has significantly improved.
New York and New Jersey are still above the national average of about one in 25 mortgages having a payment overdue by 30 days or more, but they are nowhere near the worst performers -- Mississippi holds that distinction. And Connecticut had a better on-time payment rate than the country as a whole through the first half of this year.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Increased 0.3% in September

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Shoppers increased spending for the fourth straight month in September, but much of the gain appeared to reflect higher automobile prices and masked sales declines at clothing and department stores, Government figures showed today.
Analysts said the three-tenths of 1 percent increase in September retail sales reported by the Commerce Department, combined with upward revisions for July and August, portrayed an economy that clearly was decelerating. "As the third quarter progressed, things were slowing down," said L. Douglas Lee of HSBC Securities in Washington. "And I think the fourth quarter will be a slower quarter than the third." 
 But the data still surpassed expectations and helped send a slight chill through the financial markets, which have been especially edgy about any hint of inflationary pressure since Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, spoke last week about "unsustainable" economic growth. Retail sales account for one-third of national output.
Nor did the markets take much comfort when the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, in a possible harbinger of broader trends, reported declines in its September indexes of regional manufacturing activity and prices. Interest rates climbed along a broad front in the bond market and stock prices closed moderately lower.
The rise in consumer spending last month was the slimmest of the string of gains that began in June and was suppressed by big declines at department stores and apparel stores. These outlets were said to suffer from unseasonably warm weather that curbed demand for autumn clothes. Some analysts also said sales fell because potential shoppers were absorbed in television coverage of the death and funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales.
"September is iffy" in terms of consumer demand, said Raymond A. Worseck, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. "There was some softening."
Automotive dealers posted a six-tenths of 1 percent revenue increase last month, a result seemingly at odds with earlier reports that dealers sold fewer vehicles. But analysts accounted for the discrepancy by citing a jump in prices, which showed up in the Producer Price Index.
Among other categories of durable goods -- those intended to last at least three years -- merchants selling furniture and other equipment for the home also enjoyed a six-tenths of 1 percent sales increase while those whose business is building materials, hardware, garden supplies or mobile homes endured a five-tenths of 1 percent decline.
For nondurables, there were advances of 1.4 percent at food stores, eight-tenths of 1 percent at drugstores and -- owing much to higher prices -- 1.5 percent at gasoline service stations.
These were largely offset, however, by declines of seven-tenths of 1 percent at stores selling apparel and accessories, four-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and bars and six-tenths of 1 percent at department stores and other outlets that sell general merchandise.
As for revisions, the July advance is now put at 1.2 percent instead of the nine-tenths of 1 percent previously reported while August now shows a six-tenths of 1 percent gain instead of four-tenths of 1 percent.
"Over all, these data indicate that consumer spending during the third quarter was relatively healthy but has slowed more recently," Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said in an advisory to clients.
Last month's sales total of $215.5 billion, seasonally adjusted, was 5.2 percent above that of September 1996 but this was without any allowance for inflation, which at the consumer level has run a bit above 2 percent over the last year.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Bond Act Has Unsafe School As a Backdrop

BYLINE: BY ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
THERE are few better arguments for spending more on school construction than the brief, unhappy life of Public School 141.
District 6 in Washington Heights was so desperate for space that it built a new elementary school in an old dry-cleaning plant. Since the school was evacuated last week, after levels of perchloroethylene that exceeded state guidelines were found, its 500 students have been shuffled from one overcrowded classroom to another in a system with no space for error. 
 At the same time, there are few better arguments against simply spending more money on school construction than the debacle of P.S. 141.
As the school's short, expensive history has been investigated, one egregious error after another has been exposed, starting with the initial decision to place a school on a potential Superfund site. Neither the Board of Education, which approved the project, nor the School Construction Authority, which is supposed to keep an eye on the board, appears to have heeded strong indications that the project was plagued by incompetence, exorbitant costs and potential conflicts of interest.
So what's a voter to do? On Election Day, New Yorkers will get a chance to approve or reject a bond issue that would allocate $2.4 billion for school construction and rehabilitation throughout the state.
The bond act's stated purpose is to address just the kinds of health and safety problems so painfully dramatized by P.S. 141. But it offers few details to suggest that this new money will be spent any more effectively than the old. Indeed, it offers no details whatsoever.
WHENEVER bond issues come before voters, something that happens about once every two years courtesy of New York's never-met-a-debt-it-didn't-like Legislature, only the briefest and generally most incomprehensible description appears on the ballot. But usually behind these enigmatic descriptions stand fairly specific plans about how the money will ultimately be spent.
In the case of School Facility Health and Safety Bond Act of 1997, however, no such plan exists.
The Legislature, in a final rush to pass a budget after four months of delay, threw together the bond act mainly as a way to end a political impasse. In the bill authorizing it to be placed on the ballot, there is only the vaguest description of what sort of projects the bond might support or, perhaps just as significantly, what the criteria would be for choosing them. From its language, one can just as easily imagine bond money being used to purchase computers in Scarsdale or repair boilers in Buffalo as to build classroom space in Queens.
Of the last 10 bond acts to come before New Yorkers, only one, according the city's Independent Budget Office, was as short on details as this year's. Voters rejected that one, the Economic Action Program of 1977, by a margin of 3 to 2.
CRITICS have many compelling arguments why such a vaguely defined bond act is a bad idea. For one thing, they argue that the funds will go to districts with the most political clout rather than those with the most pressing needs. For another, they worry that bond money will be devoted to projects that would have otherwise been financed with local money, thereby simply shifting costs rather than increasing education spending.
The bond act was conceived as a way to improve the desperate condition of many New York City schools. Its main backer was Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Democrat of Manhattan, who insisted on it as the price of his support for a property tax cut favored by the Governor and a business tax cut favored by the State Senate.
But critics say the city will be hard pressed to spend its share of the money, thought to be $1 billion, effectively. Whatever construction money the city gets, they point out, will still be funneled through the same group that created P.S. 141.
"For every school that is improved by the proceeds of the bond act," said Cindy Green, vice president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group that has come out against the bond, "another will fall into disrepair."
Its supporters, meanwhile, acknowledge the hazards of such an open-ended bond, but argue that the need is pressing enough to justify the risk. If voters don't seize this opportunity, they say, they may not get another one. And whatever errors may have been made in creating P.S. 141, those children still need a school.
"The Board of Education is certainly not a model of managerial success," conceded Robert R. Kiley, president of the New York City Chamber of Commerce, which favors the bond act. But, he said, "you've got to fight for that $1 billion while it's out there."

HEADLINE: Stocks Lower, With the Dow Falling 38.31

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stock prices moved modestly lower yesterday in light trading on weak demand for technology issues and rising interest rates in the bond market.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 38.31 points to close at 8,057.98, and the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index lost 4.56 points, to 965.72. 
 Broader indexes also suffered. The Nasdaq composite index fell 9.42 points, to 1,723.37, and the Russell 2000 index of smaller company issues lost 1.23 points, to 462.74.
"It was just a choppy day," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer at John Hancock Funds in Boston. "It's the kind of day where stocks and bonds react to individual pieces of news."
Much of the day's activity came in the technology sector, which was weakened after Intel, the world's largest semiconductor maker, reported slightly disappointing earnings results after the close of trading on Tuesday.
Investors, some of whom react quickly to an earnings report, buying or selling shares of companies in the same sector on the belief that they will post similar results, sacked Intel yesterday, along with a host of other semiconductor issues.
Intel fell 5 1/8 points, to 86 11/16, and Motorola Inc. -- another semiconductor issue -- was down 2 1/16, to 70 1/2. In fact, four-fifths of the issues in the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index lost ground yesterday, as the index fell 1.2 percent.
The market was also weakened by a rise in interest rates, which came after the Government reported yesterday that retail sales rose three-tenths of 1 percent in September, more than the expected two-tenths of 1 percent. The Government also revised upward retail sales figures from July and August, making investors a little more nervous that inflationary pressure could be building.
As a result, the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.39 percent, from 6.35 on Tuesday.
Hank Herrmann, the chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed in Overland Park, Kan., said that even though the market had the strength to go higher, the late year surge that he had expected to erupt as bonuses and extra cash flowed into the market, might be tempered both by rising interest rates and the heightened fears that developed after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned last week that inflation could be on the horizon.
"We were thinking it would be a positive tape through the end of the year," Mr. Herrmann said. "But that just got sidetracked because of Greenspan, who put a little scare into the market. So the market will be a lot choppier."
Despite yesterday's setbacks, several analysts said that the market might easily bounce back when better earnings reports are released. Yesterday, for instance, Dell Computer and Compaq -- two of the best- performing issues of the year -- rose sharply. Compaq is expected to release third-quarter earnings today.
Dell rose 3 7/8, to 102 7/8; the company's shares are up 287 percent this year, and Compaq soared 3 5/8, to 77 1/4. For the year, shares of Compaq are up 158 percent.
Transportation issues also soared yesterday, led by airline stocks. The Dow Jones Transportation Index, up 49 percent this year, rose 1.3 percent yesterday, led by shares of the UAL Corporation, up 5 7/16, to 99 13/16, and Delta Air Lines, up 2 5/16, to 106 15/16.
Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, 20 lost ground yesterday, led by I.B.M., which fell 1 5/8, to 101 3/4, and Eastman Kodak, which fell 1 7/16, to 62 15/16, one day after the company reported disappointing earnings.
For the last two months, the Dow has languished. Although there have been some sharp rises and falls, the blue-chip average has actually moved very little. In early August, the Dow closed at a record 8,259.31. Yesterday, the Dow closed 2.4 percent below that level.
But Mr. Freedman at John Hancock said there was little reason for worry. The market could pick up steam in the last few months, and even if it does not, the gains this year have been tremendous. The Dow is up 25 percent.
"I think most investors would be happy with the kinds of returns they've had this year, if they can keep them," he said. "There's no catalyst to drive the market dramatically higher, but there's also no catalyst to drive it dramatically lower either."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Falter a Bit On Sales Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities slipped yesterday after a Commerce Department report indicated that retail sales last month were stronger than expected. The prospect of new corporate supply later this week also weighed a bit on the market.
Investors feared that the surprisingly strong retail data -- a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent over all, and two-tenths of 1 percent excluding autos -- could be a precursor of inflation that might prompt the Federal Reserve to raise rates. Traders were nervously awaiting today's release of the Consumer Price Index to see if it brings a similar surprise. 
 The risk of an unfriendly price index caused investors to seek a higher return yesterday, spurring the selloff. Traders see a potential for a relief rally if the consumer report comes in as expected: a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent for both the overall number and the core rate.
The 30-year bond fell 16/32, to a price of 99 25/32 yesterday; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, rose to 6.39 percent, from 6.35 percent on Tuesday.
Issuance of corporate debt, which competes with Treasuries for investor capital, also affected the market in a number of ways. Often securities firms involved in underwriting these corporate issues sometimes sell Treasury securities as a hedge until the deal is complete. That created some selling pressure yesterday, mostly in the shorter maturities.
"Today's retail report does little to reduce the chances of Fed tightening before year-end," said Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities.
"U.S. retail sales remained firm in September despite early indications of a spending lull," Ms. Cooper said. She noted that in addition to the September rise, "the two prior periods were revised higher, confirming that consumption was robust for the third quarter as a whole at a 5 percent annual rate."
The core gain of two-tenths of 1 percent that excluded auto sales was close to expectations. Sales were bolstered by outsized gains in food stores and service stations, where higher gas prices caused the rise.
"Consumer spending in the third quarter was even stronger than initially estimated, but the growth will not be sustained in the current quarter," Kenneth J. McCarthy, who heads the Economic Intelligence Company, an economic consulting and forecasting firm, said.
"If we view consumer spending over a longer time frame, the pattern is one of steady, but not excessive, growth," Mr. McCarthy said. "Compared to a year ago, retail sales in September were up 5.3 percent, and sales growth has averaged between 4 percent and 6 percent for most of the past two years. Given a 1.5 percent inflation rate for consumer goods, that means that inflation-adjusted retail sales are running at annual growth rates of between 2.5 percent and 4.5 percent -- healthy, but not excessive."
Still, Mr. McCarthy said that the Fed would watch the strength in retail sales closely, even if it is not enough to prompt an immediate tightening. Strong retail sales growth in January and February prompted the Fed to raise the Federal funds rate. But Mr. McCarthy expects the economy to slow on its own.
Not all the news was stacked against the bond market. Ms. Cooper noted that the first results for October suggest that spending is tapering off. The Johnson Redbook weekly retail survey showed a decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the first week of October, and auto sales in the first 10 days of the month also trailed levels of a year ago.
Separately, the Atlanta Fed's index of national business activity eased in September to a reading of 9.0 from 15.8. And while new orders shot up, production moderated and all inflation components eased.
Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said that prior to the retail-sales report people had come into the market aggressively long, mistakenly anticipating a rather benign number.
"Many of those long quickly reversed those positions," Mr. Regan said, "sending the market down to the lower trading bands that lasted most of the day."
He said that with more data coming this week, last week's bullish tone had been very much modified. He expects the new trading range for the yield on the 30-year bond at between 6.30 percent and 6.45 percent.

HEADLINE: Malaysian Premier Sees Jews Behind Nation's Money Crisis

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Confronted with an economic crisis that has taken this rapidly developing nation by surprise, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has unleashed a series of verbal attacks on everyone from Jews to currency traders to unidentified "sinister powers."
"Many people say that I often shoot from the hip," he said last Thursday in what seemed to be a light-hearted mood. "Some say I'm a loose cannon. Perhaps they are right." 
 But he did not stop there. The next day, addressing a rally of predominantly Muslim villagers, he suggested that Malaysia's troubles might be the result of a Jewish "agenda" to weaken the economy of this country of about 20 million people.
"We may suspect that they have an agenda, but we do not want to accuse," Dr. Mahathir, who has made anti-Jewish statements in the past, was quoted as saying by the official Bernama news agency. "And incidentally we are Muslims, and the Jews are not happy to see the Muslims progress. The Jews robbed the Palestinians of everything, but in Malaysia they could not do so, hence they do this, depress the ringgit."
The Malaysian currency has lost up to 30 percent of its value in recent weeks, part of a regional epidemic that has also seen a sharp decline in the Thai baht, the Philippine peso and the Indonesian rupiah.
The currency crisis, accompanied by a sudden volatility in stock markets, has thrown the region's thriving economies off balance. Thailand and Indonesia have called on the International Monetary Fund for help.
Of all the regional leaders, Dr. Mahathir has been the loudest in voicing his frustration at this sudden burst of the bubble. His statements seem only to have heightened the air of crisis here.
At a World Bank seminar in Hong Kong last month, he accused the American financier George Soros of single-handedly causing the fall of the ringgit. Mr. Soros responded by calling Dr. Mahathir "a menace to his own country" and saying, "He is using me as a scapegoat to cover up his own failure."
The Malaysian leader then startled the gathering of financiers with a suggestion that currency trading be outlawed as "unnecessary, unproductive and immoral."
In recent days he has leveled attacks on the Western press and on "modern sinister powers" that have "pressured our currency to make us poor again."
His continuing aggressiveness has begun to arouse concern among some Malaysians and foreigners that the architect of Malaysia's prosperity might be putting his own achievements at risk.
In the face of criticism, Dr. Mahathir acted over the weekend to soften his statement about Jews, saying he had only been repeating what he had "been told by certain people."
But the damage had been done, and the backlash continued this week.
"Once again, Prime Minister Mahathir has shown himself to be a classic anti-Semite," said Rabbi Abraham Cooper, associate dean of the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, a city Dr. Mahathir recently visited in his campaign to attract high-technology investment.
Criticism also came from Australia, a country with which the Prime Minister has had an on-again, off-again war of words.
"Dr. Mahathir sounds as out of control as his currency," said Diane Shteinman, president of the Executive Council of Australia Jewry.

HEADLINE: A Coastal War Flares Over a Supertrawler

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 14

 BODY:
It has been nigh on a generation, some in this salt-scented town say, since so many fishing folk from Maine to New Jersey were last so united in a single cause.
Back in the 1970's, the cause was a law that pushed hundreds of gigantic, foreign-owned factory trawlers out of a zone extending 200 miles from American shores, away from the Georges Bank areas once considered the richest fishing grounds in the world. 
 Now the target is only a single factory trawler: the Atlantic Star. And she is American-built and 51 percent American-owned.
In towns like Gloucester, where old seagoing dynasties have been battered by the ravaging of fish stocks that was brought on by overcatching and pollution, the dominant theme seems to have become, Let us not repeat our mistakes.
"None of the fishermen wanted this thing, from Gloucester to Maine to Rhode Island to New Jersey," Joe Sinagra, a 43-year-old fisherman here who has been going to sea since he was 6, said of the Atlantic Star. "The whole damned New England fisheries was against it."
Indeed, her owner's plans for the 369-foot Atlantic Star to begin hunting herring and mackerel on Georges Bank have sparked such vehement opposition from potential competitors, fishing groups, environmentalists and politicians that the issue has reached all the way to Congress.
Any week now, possibly any day, Congressional aides say, the Senate is to pass a measure similar to one that has already sailed through the House, placing a one-year moratorium, at a minimum, on trawlers the size of the Atlantic Star.
The Senate measure, sponsored by Senators Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, and John Kerry and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrats of Massachusetts, would forbid boats of more than 165 feet or 3,000 horsepower to fish for herring and mackerel until a plan to manage herring fishing is put into place by regional fishing authorities next year. At present, there are no limits on herring catches.
Sponsors of the measures in both houses maintain that lessons must be learned from the overfishing of the past and that the supertrawler could hammer the herring and mackerel stocks, now abundant.
Environmentalists say such supertrawlers, some able to catch 500,000 pounds of fish in one tow of the net, are contributing perilously to a global overfishing crisis. More than 50 American factory trawlers are now operating, primarily in the Bering Sea, and hundreds of their foreign counterparts, barred from American waters, work around the globe.
Here in Gloucester, home of some of the strongest resistance to the Atlantic Star, the proposed Federal moratorium is cause for rejoicing among a coalition of fishermen, their wives, seafood sellers, Greenpeace campaigners and even clergy, all joined in the ad hoc Gloucester Initiatives to fight the big trawler and her owner's plans to build a freezer plant at the state fish pier here.
"We haven't had a critical mass of people come together like this before," said one coalition member, Al King, a Gloucester lobster dealer. "They came together because herring is of prime importance to every fishery," serving both as natural prey to many other species and as bait.
To the Gloucester coalition, the central issue is "sustainable fishing," which, its members say, requires making sure that limits are in place, in time, to keep herring fishing viable.
"Factory trawlers and sustainable fishing just do not mix," said Steve Parkes, a seafood processor here.
While everyone in Gloucester agrees that fish stocks should be kept vibrant, however, not everyone sees the Atlantic Star as a great menace.
Vito Calomo, executive director of the Fisheries Commission of Gloucester, says he would never want to see a fleet of factory trawlers back devouring the fish of Georges Bank. But he thinks the Atlantic Star, as the only supertrawler allowed in -- she already has her permit from regional fishing authorities -- could provide useful research on herring stocks and much-needed fishing and shore jobs as well.
Gloucester's Mayor, Bruce Tobey, believed at first that the Atlantic Star and the shoreside plant her owners have proposed could help Gloucester enter the international herring market.
But, he said, "the notion got run up a flagpole, and it did not withstand scrutiny."
"The history is so strong," the Mayor added, referring to townspeople's fears that just as herring and mackerel stocks are finally showing signs of a powerful recovery, they will be overfished again.
One American co-owner of the Atlantic Star, Mike Love, a longtime Maine fisherman, says it is not so much history that is strong as economic interests that compete with his.
The complaints presented publicly about the supertrawler have focused mainly on the environment, but as Mr. Love sees it, 10 or so of his competitors, mainly in Rhode Island and New Jersey, got the opposition going.
"They got the environmental gun and aimed it our way and supplied the spark and stood back and covered their ears," he said.
In reality, he said, boats small enough to escape the legislation's ban -- of 155 feet in length, say -- can catch more fish in a day than the Atlantic Star; they simply bring their catch to shore for freezing rather than doing it on board.
"What's going on here," Mr. Love declared, "is competitors saying, 'O.K., we put you out of business, and now we can build an unlimited number of shore plants and 155-foot boats,' " along with "a few Congress people who get a chance to grab a headline that they're saving the fish. That's how it works."
He said he and his partners, which include a Dutch company, Parlevliet & Van der Plas, as minority owner, were "exploring all of our legal options."
About $40 million has been invested in the Atlantic Star project, Mr. Love said. The ship is now in Norway being outfitted with refrigeration equipment suitable for herring and mackerel. It was originally built as an ocean incinerator but was never used for that purpose.
Perhaps the most powerful argument Mr. Love has on his side is that American fishing authorities have said, in so many words, that herring and mackerel stocks have reached record levels and that they are, in fishing parlance, "underutilized" -- as in, "Go get 'em, boys."
Further, fishing in American waters is far more regulated now than it used to be, he added. A system of local and regional councils oversees it, created by the Magnuson Act of 1976, which changed many of the ground rules for American fishing. Limits on catches of most species are now far more stringent.
But members of the Gloucester Initiatives like Niaz Dorry, the Greenpeace coordinator here, question whether the stocks are as abundant as often-uncertain scientists maintain. These advocates are pushing for an entirely new paradigm of fishing, one in which regulators would concentrate on creating habitats where fish as a whole can thrive rather than simply setting quotas on single species.
"I always joke that it takes an ecosystem to raise a fish," Ms. Dorry said.
And some of the bigger optimists in Gloucester believe that the coalition could presage a new era in which such a sophisticated approach will be encouraged, one in which a new breed of fisherman, more focused on the long term, might replace the every-man-for-himself breed of the past.
"There's no question that people are so much wiser now," said Joe Garland, who for decades has been a Gloucester historian of the fishing industry.
That such concerted opposition to the Atlantic Star should come from Gloucester, Mr. Garland said, is notable.
"It shows there is a real sea change going," he said. "It really is a sign of hope."

HEADLINE: In Brazil, Clinton Urges the Rich to Share Gains of Free Trade

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Trying to reassure the poor in Brazil and the Democrats in Congress about his hopes for free trade, President Clinton visited a school and sports complex in a slum here today to issue a stark warning about the potential social damage of open markets.
"It is wrong for only a few to reap the benefits of the wonderful changes going on while the many remain mired in poverty," Mr. Clinton said. "That is a betrayal of our values of individual integrity and equal opportunity." 
 On his first trip through Latin America, President Clinton has been advocating a sort of enlightened capitalism, under which businesses, recognizing that increased wages and improved education are in their interests, would work with governments to make good on what he calls the "social compact."
As he seeks increased power from Congress to negotiate trade deals, Mr. Clinton is mindful of Democrats' concerns that, in the hemispheric free-trade zone he longs for, American wages could fall while working and environmental conditions in Latin America could deteriorate.
In a speech this morning to the American Chamber of Commerce and other business people in Sao Paulo, Mr. Clinton took on such fears by urging his audience to help "bridge the gap between the haves and have-nots."
"The age-old curse of Latin America -- the constant undercurrent of all advanced economies of the last 20 years -- has got to be dealt with more seriously not only by government, but by people in the private sector working in partnership with government," he said. "We have to give everyone who will work for it a place in the future we are trying to build."
Borrowing the language of those who oppose increasing his freedom to negotiate trade treaties, Mr. Clinton said he believed in "insisting on worker protection so that trade enhances working conditions and living standards instead of undermining them."
Mr. Clinton's aides have complained that reporters have paid more attention to the fund-raising investigations back home than to Mr. Clinton's arguments for freer trade. But in his airport greetings, speeches and toasts, Mr. Clinton has doggedly pounded away at his case on trade.
This afternoon Mr. Clinton illustrated his argument for public-private partnerships with his visit to the Mangueira school, which offers schooling, sports training and health care to 2,000 children. The school has benefited from the support of Pele, the soccer star and Brazilian Minister of Sports, who also spoke here today. But it has also benefited from hundreds of thousands of dollars from the Xerox Corporation.
At the school, Mr. Clinton delivered an unusually explicit corporate plug. "Xerox is a good citizen of Brazil and a good citizen of the United States," he said.
Indeed, the event seemed at times like a rally for Xerox. Hundreds of children wore pink or white gym shirts advertising Xerox, and an English-language banner in easy camera range of the President's podium proclaimed: "Ten years ago Xerox believed in this dream."
The school may fit Mr. Clinton's vision for the new economy, but it is an isolated example in this country of 160 million. As Mr. Clinton's critics on trade are quick to point out, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, Brazil's reform-minded President, has barely dented the rampant corruption and disparities of wealth here, or mitigated labor conditions that constitute virtual slavery in some parts of the country.
