HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A new look at why the U.S. outdoes Europe in job creation.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IN 1994, Paul Krugman, an economist at M.I.T., concluded that "growing U.S. inequality and growing European unemployment are different sides of the same coin."
The issue has only sharpened since then: America's ability to employ millions of unskilled workers -- and thereby reduce unemployment to less than half the rate in Europe without causing inflation -- is widely attributed to competitive (meaning wretched) low-end wages. But Alan Krueger, a labor economist at Princeton University who never misses a chance to debunk conventional wisdom, wonders whether economists have been too quick to buy the latest dismal science. 
 His fresh examination of "the U.S. employment miracle," written with Jorn-Steffen Pischke of M.I.T. and available (at www.nber.org) as National Bureau of Economic Research Working Paper 6146, is no defense of rigid European labor policies. But it does suggest that the success of the Great American Jobs Machine has as much to do with the vitality of small and medium-size business as it does with low wages.
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development estimates that unemployment in France reached 12.6 percent in September, almost triple the United States rate. Germany (9.7 percent) and Sweden (10.5 percent) weren't much better. Spain tops the dishonor role with 19.9 percent unemployment -- a rate not seen in America since Franklin D. Roosevelt was in office.
The standard explanation is that minimum wages, which exceed $10 an hour in affluent Northern Europe when social insurance taxes are included, deter employment of the inexperienced and unskilled. If the minimum wage does not scare off employers, powerful unions do.
Outside of Britain and the Netherlands, free-market-minded politicians despair of breaking labor market rigidity, and for good reason. The majority, who are employed, are unwilling to accept pay cuts for full employment. The substantial minority who are shut out have been pacified with generous welfare checks and free public services ranging from high-quality child care to pensions at age 60.
But Mr. Krueger and Mr. Pischke point out that the evidence linking regulation to unemployment is weaker than the common-sense appeal of the hypothesis. Until the 1970's, unemployment was generally lower in Europe than in America, they note, despite far tougher labor market restrictions. Besides, unemployment among highly educated European workers, whose compensation is less likely to be regulated, has risen roughly in proportion to unemployment at the bottom.
By the same token, the two economists argue there is scant -- and contradictory -- evidence that the American labor market adjusts to changes in the supply of workers by raising and lowering wages. Unskilled wages were, as expected, depressed by the flood of baby boomers into jobs in the 1970's. But the "baby bust" of the late 1980's, which many economists expected would elevate wages, actually coincided with a steep decline in low-end compensation.
This does not mean that America could eradicate poverty the Northern European way, raising minimum wages, mandating health insurance and giving unions the legal tools to organize skeptical workers. But Mr. Krueger is not convinced that the key to full employment in Europe is American-style labor policy. Indeed, he conjectures that a different strength of American capitalism helps explain job growth.
In Europe, he suggests, jobs are created from the top down as big business and big government mobilize scarce capital and expand production capacity. In America, where virtually all employment growth in recent decades has come from small and medium-size service businesses, the key to expansion has been individual enterprise.
Do Europeans lack entrepreneurial skills? Entrepreneurs certainly aren't honored in classrooms or glorified in the media the way they are in America.
More tangibly, Mr. Krueger says, American entrepreneurs face lower hurdles. Shops and other small businesses are less likely to be hemmed in by regulations -- zoning, licensing, hours of operation -- designed for the most part in Europe to guarantee incumbents a comfortable living. Venture capital is easier to obtain in America for small businesses. Banks and specialty lenders in America are more likely to provide credit for businesses with strong track records.
The hypothesis -- Mr. Krueger more modestly labels it a conjecture -- is good and bad news.
On the one hand, there may be softer variations on the American capitalist model that generate higher employment and stable prices without shredding the safety net. On the other, individual initiative is not so easily grafted onto old corporatist welfare states. "Shedding regulation might not get Europe where it needs to go," Mr. Krueger concludes.

HEADLINE: When Sex Is Just a Matter of Fact;
To High School Students, Free Condoms Seem Normal, Not Debatable

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
On some days, Kelly Bunkley, a prim 17-year-old, slips into the health-resource room at Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn, where she quietly asks for a free condom.
She says her visits to the room on the second floor, where condoms are kept locked in a file cabinet, give her a powerful weapon she can pass along to help a former schoolmate avoid AIDS. "I tell her that she has to be careful," said Kelly, a senior who just last year watched another friend, an energetic young man from her neighborhood in East New York, dying of AIDS in a hospital bed. "I tell her to wait." 
 At Murrow High School, where Kelly is among 4,100 students in a building that fills an entire city block, students have been getting free condoms since 1991. Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez started the program then throughout the system as a way to reduce the spread of AIDS, but it was so vigorously denounced by opponents as promoting adolescent promiscuity that it contributed to his ouster about two years later.
In fact, condoms and AIDS education have been the subjects of vociferous debate in New York and across the country, dividing parents and educators along philosophical, political and religious lines. Opponents' fears of increased promiscuity were countered by a recent publicized study by New York University researchers finding that free condoms did not increase sexual activity but did increase the use of condoms.
At Murrow High, though, there is virtually no rancor on the topic, students say. The general view among dozens of students interviewed was that it makes sense to deal with such matters in the place where they go every day to learn about life.
The students were in elementary school when Chancellor Fernandez first proposed the free condom program, and have never been in a high school without having access to free condoms. To some of them, the program is as normal as milk in the cafeteria, and about as likely to be the subject of debate. They say that such questions as whether the program contributes to promiscuity are misguided, and that the attitude behind the question fails to reflect the realities of high school life.
Free condoms are part of a broader high school program that includes six lessons of AIDS education each year. In contrast to the often sharp tones of adult advocates or critics of the program, the students at Murrow say it creates barely a ripple there.
Asked about the free condoms, Shauna Ling-Choung, a 16-year-old student, said: "We know it's there. We know how to get it. But we don't discuss it that often. It just doesn't come up."
On a recent afternoon at Murrow High, in a wide corridor where cliques of students gathered to flirt, read and kill time during free periods, Sabrina Mendola, a junior, described the school condom program as "a good thing." She would not say whether she was sexually active, but she did say she knew of at least four students who have obtained condoms through the program.
"They had no money, and if they didn't get condoms from school, they would have had unprotected sex," said Sabrina, a 16-year-old from Sheepshead Bay. "Thank God for the school's having it. It's a learning center. Where else are the kids going to learn if their parents don't talk to them?"
Shauna, sitting next to her, chimed in: "You can't prevent teen-agers from having sex, no matter what you preach." She said she could think of at least seven students who had requested condoms at school. "If students are having sex, they might as well do it the safe way," she said. "It's a way for schools to show that they actually care."
Murrow High, in Midwood in central Brooklyn, is regarded as one of the top public high schools in the city. It sends more than 90 percent of its graduates to college and draws students from across the borough to magnet courses in communications and drama. But the students are ordinary teen-agers, and the school population roughly reflects Brooklyn's racial, ethnic and economic composition.
There is a Russian club, a Middle Eastern culture club, a Jewish heritage club, two Chinese groups, a Korean club and an African Renaissance Coalition that includes blacks who are native-born, Caribbean and African. There are also groups for Roman Catholics, nonsmokers and gay and lesbian students.
Last week, in the bare asphalt courtyard of the school, where students play handball and a few roguish teen-agers sneak a smoke underneath the rumbling, elevated D train, a group of boys discussed condoms and sex. One teen-ager said he did not use condoms because they spoiled his pleasure. But Tony Romano, 17 and one of the handball crowd, said firmly that he had consistently used condoms in the two months he had been having sex. He doesn't use the ones they hand out at school, though, he said, because he heard a rumor that they are shoddy. (They are donated by the maker of Trojan condoms.)
"That's what people say; they're cheap and defective," Tony said, shrugging his shoulders. "But if schools want to do it, it doesn't bother me. Schools are like your mother. They take care of you. They teach you. They feed you. They are looking out after you."
Not far away from the discussion in the courtyard, Daniel Goldberger, 16 years old, stood with his own gaggle of friends, many of whom have a creative bent. He is preoccupied these days with after-school rehearsals for two plays, "Oliver" and "The Importance of Being Earnest."
Daniel said that he was a bit annoyed when students didn't seem to understand the consequences of unprotected sex, but that he didn't want to lecture them, ad nauseam, like a grown-up. His own uncle, a man in his early 30's, died of AIDS several years ago.
"I feel like when you have a family member or even a friend who has died, you tend to be more aware of the AIDS virus," said Daniel, who is a member of the school's H.I.V.-AIDS awareness club, which raises money for charity and does volunteer work in hospitals. "You're not as oblivious to it. You realize, like wow, it could happen to you."
Daniel said many students at Murrow High were curious about AIDS, but he said teen-agers seemed to think they are invincible until their own lives have been touched. His views echo the New York University study's finding that 91 percent of the city's high school students believe they are either "not at all likely" or "unlikely" to get H.I.V. in the next five years.
"It's not a reality for a lot of people," Daniel said. "We're still young. We're going through a lot of changes. Right now, we're still learning a lot of things."
When Murrow High formally opened in 1974, Saul Bruckner, who has been its principal since then, used an allusion to "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" when he compared his new school to a tree that would bear "healthy fruit." The other day, Mr. Bruckner said with a touch of exasperation that providing condoms to youths was not exactly what he had in mind. He admitted that he started the required condom program only grudgingly. He said he thought it bizarre that schools could hand out condoms but not Tylenol.
In the resource room, Room 285F, the drab beige walls are covered with AIDS awareness posters. Leaflets on subjects like the benefits of abstinence and H.I.V. prevention are neatly stacked. A schedule of the hours when specific teachers are available is posted outside the door.
Michelle Lieberman, an English teacher who received training through the Board of Education to become an H.I.V.-AIDS resource teacher, said she received from one to 10 condom requests in the one hour a week she staffs the room.
Unlike the students, Ms. Lieberman says she knows well that the program is troubling to many people. "It's extremely controversial," she said. "It's a hot topic right now because where does the school draw the line between being a social institution and an educational institution? But if we don't move toward becoming more of a social institution, we are going to lose our kids to various possible diseases and to pregnancy."
Students have to state their identification numbers in order to get condoms, and if their parents have refused permission, the teachers have to refuse them. Fewer than 2 percent of parents citywide exercise that option, according to the New York University study.
Ms. Lieberman said students were given three condoms and a slip of paper explaining how to use them. She occasionally gives demonstration lessons, using fingers, if students ask for them.
"I tell them to not use it more than once," she said.
In a class where students work on writing for the Scholastic Assessment Tests and college-level vocabulary, Jamie Smerina, a junior, said recently that many of her girlfriends in Bay Ridge became "un-virgins" between the ninth and 10th grades. Jamie said she had been upset to learn that a particularly close friend who lived down the block was one of them.
"We had this bond," she said. "We used to say, 'We're never going to do it.' I had to hear from somebody else that she did it. I confronted her and she said yes. She said she was pressured into it. I guess she was afraid to tell me. We don't talk anymore."
As a 16-year-old, Jamie said, pressure to have intercourse is intense, but she plans to abstain anyway. "My mother would beat the hell out of me," she said.
Jamie is not opposed to free condoms at school, but she has mixed feelings about the school's role. She said discussions about sexuality and condoms should start at home, not school. "For me, it's so strong at home," she said.

HEADLINE: Likely Cause of Yonkers Tanker Fire Was Pointed Out in '89

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: YONKERS, Oct. 15

 BODY:
The deadly inferno that closed one of the busiest highway links to New York City a week ago after a car hit a gasoline tanker appears to have been caused by a preventable problem pinpointed in 1989 by Federal transportation officials and warned of by the New York City Fire Department in 1994.
The problem occurs when small amounts of gasoline or other hazardous cargo sit in unprotected pipes tucked under the belly of tanker trucks, which carry more than 100 billion gallons of gasoline to service stations around the country each year. 
 In collisions, these pipes, which are used to fill and empty the tank, can break and release their contents -- even if the main tank is not punctured.
In 1989, the Transportation Department published a new regulation aimed at eliminating the problem in tankers hauling hazardous liquids. It proposed either protecting the pipes with metal shields or flushing the liquid. But the petroleum industry said the risk was too small to justify the cost of such measures for gasoline, and the Transportation Department granted an exemption.
A Brooklyn company has said it has a system that would flush the pipes at a cost of $2,500 per truck.
Fatal fires from such a release are rare, according to Federal transportation statistics. But that worst-case scenario appears to be what unfolded when a car struck the right side of a gasoline tanker in an underpass beneath the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway here, investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board and the Yonkers Police Department said.
Kenneth Suydam, the lead investigator for the safety board, said that many tests must be run on the wreckage before final conclusions were drawn, and that other factors might have played a role. But the police and Federal officials said there were few other explanations for how an initial small fire, probably fed by the contents of the broken pipes on the truck's belly, grew into a destructive pillar of flame shortly after midnight last Thursday.
The driver of the car, Dr. Alessio Matera, died of burns and smoke inhalation, the Westchester County Medical Examiner said. The truck driver, Frank Gangone, tried to rescue Dr. Matera, but was driven back by rising flames, said Lieut. Thomas LaGala of the Yonkers police.
The highway remained closed today as workers prepared to install a temporary bridge to replace an overpass that buckled in the intense heat of the fire.
The crash and fire in Yonkers, and the possibility that the fire was preventable, renewed debate today over safety regulations for gasoline tankers.
William Feehan, the First Deputy Commissioner of the New York City Fire Department, said that the department had pressed the Federal Government for nearly a decade to keep its own, stricter standard for fuel trucks within New York City limits, but that the city was defeated in Federal Court, with the Federal rule taking precedence. "It's a very crowded urban area here," Mr. Feehan said. "We still think we know more about what's safe than the bureaucrats in Washington."
In 1994, the department sent a letter to Federico F. Pena, who was then Secretary of Transportation, warning that the design of the large gasoline tankers posed a serious fire risk.
Mr. Feehan said the Yonkers fire fortunately happened "in the middle of the night, under a bridge." He added, "That guy could've been delivering gasoline to a gas station on Avenue A and Second Street and turned over in Little Italy or something and the results would have been catastrophic."
Senior Transportation Department officials and representatives of the petroleum and trucking industries defended the existing standard, saying that more than 50,000 truckloads of gasoline move on American roads every day and that fewer than a dozen people die in incidents involving the tankers in a typical year.
The kind of incident that may have led to the blaze in Yonkers is even rarer, said Alan I. Roberts, the associate administrator for hazardous materials safety at the Research and Special Programs Administration, a branch of the Transportation Department.
"You're talking about tens of millions of trips made without facing this consequence," he said. "We're certainly not happy about it, but we need to take into account the costs of what we would do relative to the benefit."
For example, flushing the pipes would involve an extra few minutes for each delivery, adding considerably to the cost of transporting fuel, he said.
At the heart of the ongoing debate is the design of the long, cylindrical aluminum tankers that are a familiar sight on the roads. The tanker that caught fire, owned by Mystic Bulk Carriers Inc. of Astoria, Queens, is one of tens of thousands of similar vehicles.
Catastrophic accidents involving these rigs mainly occur when a tanker rolls over or strikes a barrier like a bridge abutment at high speed, according to Federal transportation statistics.
Even so, when the Department of Transportation was updating its regulations for tankers in 1989, hazardous materials experts at the agency's Research and Special Programs Administration identified the piping system on the underside as a vulnerable spot.
The vulnerability evolved in the early 1970's, after passage of the Clean Air Act ended the old industry practice of loading gasoline or other contents from the top of a tanker and emptying them from the bottom, according to Transportation Department documents. Ever since, tankers have been both loaded and unloaded through the same pipes leading from the bottom of the tank, to prevent the buildup and escape of polluting vapors.
In 1989, the Department of Transportation said that after a tanker was filled, up to 50 gallons of the loaded material often remained trapped in pipes tucked along the belly of the vehicle. In a collision, the unprotected pipes could break, releasing their contents. If the load was hazardous or flammable, this would create an "unnecessary risk" of fire or other calamity, transportation officials reported in the Federal Register.
The Transportation Department issued its rule, with the exemption for gasoline haulers.
Shortly afterward, under pressure from the petroleum industry and other businesses, the rule was further restricted so that it applied only to the most poisonous or corrosive substances carried in tankers, according to Transportation Department officials.
Donal Vierimaa, vice president for engineering at the Truck Trailer Manufacturers Association, an industry group, said the shift in loading techniques that filled the pipes and created the potential problem also helped solve other problems. It cleaned the air, made loading safer for truckers by eliminating the need to climb on top of a 12-foot-tall tanker, and allowed fuel depots and gas stations to standardize their equipment, he said.
"It's a matter, like most things, of balancing the pros and cons," Mr. Vierimaa said.
Several years ago, a company in Brooklyn, Cargo Tank Concepts Ltd., demonstrated for the American Petroleum Institute a patented device that can flush the contents of a tanker's pipes up into the tank, eliminating the hazard at a cost of about $2,500 per truck, said Ron Andenmatten, the company's president. But once the Federal rule on the pipes was relaxed, there was little incentive to adopt the new technology, he said.
Over all, the petroleum industry has said it sees no need to spend money on a new system. Michael Shanahan, a spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, which represents several hundred petroleum companies, said that no alternatives had emerged that would make sense economically or would measurably cut risks in an industry that is already very safe.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: "Tankers: A Hidden Weakness"
The explosion of a gasoline tanker last Thursday under a Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway overpass in Yonkers may have been caused by spilled fuel from pipes that broke away from the tank at impact.
 
1. Before a full gasoline tanker has unloaded its cargo, up to 50 gallons of fuel can be trapped in the pipes connecting the tank to the fuel hoses.
 
2. In an accident, the pipes break off from the tank valve to prevent the fuel tank from rupturing and exploding. But this can allow trapped fuel inside the pipes to spill and ignite.

HEADLINE: On Russian-Iranian Oil Deal, U.S. Sanctions May Backfire

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
In the next few weeks the Clinton Administration will face the first test of its willingness to make good on a threat to punish foreign companies that invest in Iran.
But the State Department is not exactly leaping at the chance to teach a lesson to Russia's premier private company, Gazprom, for a $2 billion deal with French and Malaysian companies to pump natural gas off the Iranian coast. 
 Instead, officials are discovering anew that imposing sanctions on foreign companies that defy American policy -- in this case by doing business with a country that supports terrorism -- raises numerous unforeseeable problems.
The issue is not whether Washington can stop the investment in Iran. That is clearly beyond its reach. Instead, it is whether Gazprom should be allowed to raise $1 billion in world financial markets, including the United States, next month -- money that will go right into the company's coffers just as it is preparing to write the Iranians a fat check.
But stopping that deal threatens to unravel delicate negotiations with European allies over United States sanctions policy, and to interfere with Washington's efforts to stabilize the rickety Russian economy. And, to make matters worse, it could also mean going up against one of President Clinton's biggest financial supporters in last year's campaign: Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The Wall Street firm, whose former co-chairman is Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, is underwriting the Gazprom bond offering. The company fought long and hard to get Gazprom's business, and many European investment houses would dance with glee if Washington were to get in Goldman's way.
Even Stuart Eizenstat, the Undersecretary of State for economic affairs, concedes that if the United States tried to aim at Iran, the bullet would ricochet everywhere.
"This is a matter which has important implications for our policy to deter Iran from acquiring weapons of mass destruction and supporting terrorism," he said today. But it quickly becomes enmeshed, he added, in "our broader relationship with our European allies, the Russian Government and the Government of Malaysia," to say nothing of the impact on Wall Street. The origins of the current diplomatic morass are relatively simple. When Conoco Inc. attempted to invest in an Iranian oil field two years ago, the Clinton Administration stepped in, issuing an order barring American companies from major investments in Iran as long as Teheran sponsored terrorism and was attempting to acquire nuclear weapons. Then France's Total swept in and signed the deal Conoco was forced to abandon.
The outrage in Congress over Total's action led to the passage last year of the Iran and Libya Sanctions Act. Like the Helms-Burton Act, which is aimed at companies investing in Cuba, the law laid out sanctions that the President can impose against foreign firms that invest more than $20 million in Iran's oil and gas industries, its main source of revenue.
They range from minor punishments -- cutting off low-cost loans through the Government's Export-Import Bank -- to far nastier sanctions, including cutting off American bank loans exceeding $10 million, in an effort to make sure that companies flouting the investment ban in Iran do not raise their funds in America. Until now, the law has never been tested.
But two weeks ago, Total announced that it was teaming up with Gazprom and Malaysia's state-owned oil firm, Petronas, in the $2 billion project in Iran.
It was an important step: Iran's proven gas reserves represent about 15 percent of the world's total, second only to Russia's reserves.
"Clearly, this is a big test for us," one senior Administration official said recently. "If Total and its partners get away with it, every non-American energy firm on the globe is going to race in after them."
The Administration's reaction was deliberately muted. Mr. Eizenstat -- fully aware of the explosive nature of any sanctions threat in Europe -- said that the State Department would take time to "gather all the facts" on the gas deal.
Others hinted that sanctions might be waived if France and the other countries made other commitments to fight Iranian terrorism. A team of experts was sent to Paris, Moscow and Kuala Lumpur.
Meanwhile the Iranians declared that the gas field will earn them $450 billion over the next 30 years, and said that the contract with Total, the lead partner, went into effect Oct. 7.
The State Department's caution is understandable: If it acted quickly against any of the three firms, it would almost certainly sink the delicate negotiations with Europe over sanctions on companies that invest in Cuba. Today's deadline for those negotiations to conclude passed with no agreement.
But now the $1 billion bond offering seems likely to force the State Department's hand. The transaction is Gazprom's first venture into the world's capital markets with a major bond issue, though it has sold its stock on markets around the world and borrowed from Western banks.
Goldman says the $1 billion it is raising is for "general purposes," chiefly a major pipeline project already under way in Russia. But clearly, any cash the company can raise frees up money it can invest in Iran.
While Goldman will say nothing publicly about the debt offering, a company official said that "this is a very important deal for us," and that Goldman's lawyers believe that the bond offering does not violate the Iran-Libya sanctions act, which makes no specific mention of debt offerings.
"We are assuming it is not going to be an issue," the official said.
The author of the sanctions act, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, says he plans to make it an issue. To his mind, he said today through a spokesman, the law is intended to "prevent foreign firms that trade with Iran from obtaining funding in American financial markets."
"I will be holding hearings in the Senate Banking Committee on Gazprom's debt offering soon," said Mr. D'Amato, the committee chairman.
The political complications of this deal are not eased by the fact that Gazprom is hardly an ordinary company. Not only is it the most powerful corporation in Russia, it was once headed by Russia's Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin. He and his family are thought to be major shareholders, but their exact role is a mystery. It did not help that Mr. Chernomyrdin apparently made no mention of the Iran investment last month when he met Vice President Al Gore in Moscow, in one of a series of discussions to promote Russia's conversion to a market economy.
Any step to interfere with Gazprom's access to world capital markets would constitute a major setback to American participation in that effort, and would undoubtedly anger the Prime Minister.
For its part, Gazprom has no intention of backing down. The company has said repeatedly that it would ignore American "threats" and declared that the financial losses incurred by breaking its deal with Iran "would be greater than those incurred by sanctions against us."
For Goldman, however, the controversy could be costly. Even if the United States did not attempt to block the debt offering, it could create enough uncertainties about possible sanctions that investors would be scared off -- meaning that the bond may have to be offered at a higher interest rate. Administration officials have made it clear they would not be upset by that outcome.
The bond will be convertible into American depository receipts, which would allow American investors to purchase the equiavlent of Gazprom stock.
The issue is also a delicate one for Mr. Rubin. In one other major issue involving Goldman, he recused himself. The sanctions question is primarily an issue for the State Department, but whenever a question of high finance and foreign policy rises to the White House, Mr. Rubin is usually central to the discussion.
Mr. Rubin's spokesman, Howard Schloss, noted today that while the Treasury Secretary still has a financial interest in Goldman, it is held in a blind trust. The trust is arranged so that Mr. Rubin can neither profit nor lose from changes in the value of his interest in the partnership, Mr. Schloss said.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 596 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

GTE Joins Chase for MCI With $28 Billion Cash Bid
GTE added its name to the list -- it now stands at three -- of companies pursuing MCI in the richest takeover battle in American history, making an unsolicited offer of $28 billion in cash.
MCI, which already has an agreement to be acquired by British Telecom for $19 billion in cash and stock, and which is studying an all-stock offer of $30 billion from a smaller telecommunications company, Worldcom, said only that its board planned to meet again soon to weigh its options. Page A1. 

Sales Rose in September
Retail sales rose last month but the gain partly reflected higher automobile prices, Commerce Department figures showed. Though the increase was unexpected and sent inflationary chills through the securities markets, economists said it did not alter their view that the economy was decelerating. D4.
 
Treasury securities prices slipped on the report, and the prospect of new corporate issues, which compete with Treasuries for investors' money, also weighed on the market. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.39 percent from 6.35. D17.
 
Stock prices were pushed down by the rising interest rates and by weak demand for technology issues. The Dow industrials fell 38.31 points, to 8,057.98. D10.
 
Time Warner Cheers Investors
Time Warner reported strong gains in its third-quarter results, sending a message to investors that the company's core businesses were healthy and reassuring them that it had gotten religion and was rigorously monitoring its spending. In response, they sent Time Warner's stock up to an all-time high. Market Place. D10.
 
Sun Expands Microsoft Suit
Sun Microsystems made additional charges in its lawsuit against Microsoft over the Java programming language, and both sides, jockeying for position, made public the contract that they are disputing. D2.
 
Lucent to Add Networking Company
Lucent Technologies said that it would buy Livingston Enterprises for $650 million in stock, adding a new arm to its aggressive move into computer networking. D7.
 
Bre-X Suit Is Allowed to Proceed
A Canadian court permitted a shareholder lawsuit to proceed against officials of Bre-X Minerals to reclaim profits they made by selling shares before the company collapsed in a gold-discovery fraud earlier this year. D22.
 
Complications in Sanctions Threat
The State Department is not exactly leaping at the chance to seek sanctions against Gazprom of Russia over its plan to invest in Iran with French and Malaysian partners. Among other complications, doing so could mean going up against one of President Clinton's biggest financial supporters: Goldman, Sachs, which is underwriting a $1 billion bond offering by Gazprom. A1.
 
High Court Hears G.M. Case
In a product liability case against General Motors, the Supreme Court is exploring the question of whether the courts of one state must always honor judgments from another state, even when they conflict with the first state's laws. The question centers on an expert witness in the case, a former G.M. engineer who had testified against the company in similar situations in other states. A25.
 
A Big Competitor Unites Fishermen
Fishermen from Maine to New Jersey are protesting plans for a big new factory trawler to start looking for herring and mackerel. The issue has made its way to Congress, and the Senate, as the House already has, is expected to pass a measure that would place a moratorium on trawlers the size of the new one, the Atlantic Star. A14.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: WHAT ABOUT MISSISSIPPI?: A special report.;
Welfare Law Weighs Heavy In Delta, Where Jobs Are Few

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, Miss.

 BODY:
While President Clinton has flatly declared "the debate is over -- we know now that welfare reform works," the hard-luck counties of the Mississippi Delta show the difficulties that can emerge when tough laws collide with a weak economy.
The welfare rolls have fallen sharply across this 200-mile stretch of cotton fields and catfish farms, as they have in most of the country. But with unemployment rates hovering at 10 percent or more, many of those leaving the rolls are failing to find jobs. Indeed, during one recent period, the families dropped for violating the new work rules outnumbered those placed in jobs by a margin of nearly two to one. 
 And the penalties in Mississippi are the nation's toughest. Those who miss appointments or decline work assignments surrender not only their entire cash grant, but all their family's food stamps and the medical insurance of adults. Across the Delta, mothers dropped from the welfare rolls are now turning to relatives, boyfriends or other Federal programs -- most notably disability payments -- or traveling long distances in search of work.
Maggie Miller lost her benefits and moved in with her sister, raising the number of children in the two-bedroom house to 15. Patricia Watson worked a day at a distant catfish-processing plant but quit after returning home to discover that her baby-sitter could not find her 6-year-old daughter.
Curley Barron threw up her hands and returned her niece and nephew to foster care. Busy caring for her ailing mother, she refused to join a work program and therefore lost the $435 in cash and food stamps she was receiving for the children's monthly support.
It was scenarios like these in places like this that critics of last year's landmark law feared. The landmark measure ended a 61-year-old guarantee of Federal aid and transferred money and authority to the states. While some states might make good use of their autonomy, the critics said, said, others would prove unwilling or unable to construct safety nets of their own. Mindful of this state's many last-place rankings on socioeconomic scales, they summarized their fears with a frequent refrain: "What about Mississippi?"
The same could be asked of other states, particularly in the South, that combine high poverty rates with low spending. But the poverty here has historically run highest, and the spending levels lowest. Mississippi's Republican Governor, Kirk Fordice, is known for the vehemence of his anti-government views. And with black families making up more than 80 percent of the caseload, the welfare reductions inevitably remind critics of the state's difficult racial past.
For all its unique regional features, the Mississippi Delta -- the poorest region in the poorest state -- may offer broader lessons for the nation's great welfare experiment.
Though many states are boasting of early success in a robust economy, they could find themselves in related struggles should their job markets falter.
Mississippi officials blame the old system for letting joblessness and teen-age parenthood become a subculture's norm, especially in the Delta, and almost everyone agrees that the program needed to change. Officials here say the tough new rules now properly discourage those who do not really need the help.
And not all the state is down-in-the-mouth like the Delta. The Gulf Coast and Tupelo are booming, and the statewide unemployment rate has averaged just 5.6 percent this year, only slightly higher than the national rate of 5.3 percent.
Mississippi also boasts a bureaucratic advantage over other states, like Arkansas and Louisiana, that are trying to put the welfare poor to work in rural, depressed areas. Unlike its neighbors, Mississippi has run experimental programs for several years, accumulating what officials call a wealth of important lessons.
Even in the Delta some women say the new work rules gave them the push they needed to find employment. "I thought it was going to be hard, but it wasn't," said Felicia Fields, 22, the new receptionist at Cunningham's Insurance in Greenville, who landed her position after a few weeks in a job-search class.
Still, the difficulty of converting "work" from a slogan to a program is particularly evident in a region like this, where jobs and child care are scarce, education levels are low, distances are great, and public transportation does not exist. Though the new watchword is self-sufficiency, the region's plantation economy was originally built on the opposite premise. Hugely profitable to a handful of white planters, it rested on a subjugated army of black sharecroppers kept dependent by design.
A poverty belt this large would prove vexing under any circumstances. But Mississippi's program also receives the nation's smallest Federal investment. The annual Federal subsidy of about $2,100 per family is just over half the national average of $4,100. And it is less than a third of the $7,200 per family taken in by the nation's most heavily subsidized state, Wisconsin. That is because under the new Federal program, called Temporary Assistance to Needy Families, Federal subsidies are tied to past state spending levels, and Mississippi's have been the nation's lowest. The state offers a mother with two children just $120 a month.
Donald R. Taylor, executive director of the state's Department of Human Services, said the program has all the money it needs. The Federal grant, though less than what other states receive, actually represents a per capita increase over what Mississippi has received in the past.
Mr. Taylor said the real problem resides with "the old system, which told the poor, 'We know you're not capable of making it; here are a few crumbs.' " After decades of policy failure, he said, "the problems we have stem more from behavioral poverty than material poverty."
But he speaks more cautiously about the 11 Delta counties, which account for a quarter of the state's caseload. He warns that some of the 8,000 welfare families there may just have to move to places that have jobs. "If you've seen 'The Grapes of Wrath,' that's what it was all about," he said. "But you've got some people in rural Mississippi who are tied to the land, and I can understand their reluctance."
"That area's going to be our biggest problem," he said.
 
The Experiment
Starting Strong, Losing Steam
Mississippi began its welfare experiment in the fall of 1995, operating a trial program called Work First in six counties. The program, run with Federal permission, placed about 7,000 recipients in job-search classes. It offered substantial subsidies to businesses that hired them. And it withheld benefits from recipients who did not attend the classes or accept offers of employment.
About 42 percent of the participants found jobs. But only half of those -- or 21 percent of the total -- were still working after the program's 15th month. "The retention rate is a huge problem," said Bill Brister, a researcher at Millsaps College in Jackson, who evaluated the program.
Meanwhile, penalty rates were high. About 19 percent violated the rules and lost all cash and food stamps. (Most had their benefits restored within two months, after complying with the program's rules.) That is, almost as many people temporarily lost their benefits as landed and kept jobs.
And that ratio worsened as the program went on. That was especially the case in Greenville and surrounding Washington County, the only Delta county in the experiment. In the fifth quarter of the program, 72 families landed jobs, while 130 lost their benefits.
Larry Temple, the state official who ran the Work First program, attributed the fall-off to an autumn economic decline. "That's deer-hunting season -- nobody's hiring then," he said. But the flagging results could also suggest that the program, having placed the most job-ready clients, might not succeed with the more troubled clients still on the rolls.
Mr. Temple, who recently took a top job with the Texas welfare program, describes the Mississippi experiment as "wildly successful," especially in reducing caseloads. The rolls in the Work First counties fell 19 percent in the first year, compared with 6 percent in the rest of the state, and new applications in the Work First counties fell by a remarkable 65 percent.
Pointing to those numbers, Mr. Temple said the burden of meeting a work requirement leads people to explore other options.
"For the first time in many years, we're getting down to a legitimate caseload," he said.
But he also acknowledged that people who land jobs "are not staying on to the degree we'd like." To address that problem, Mississippi has no longer provides job-placement services itself but hires private companies through competitive bids. And it pays them their full fee only if a client stays at work for six months.
The experiment ended last year with the passage of the Federal law giving new authority to the states. Given Mississippi's political climate, its detractors feared the state would lead a "race to the bottom" characterized by dwindling support of the poor. Mr. Fordice's distrust of government programs seems pronounced even by Mississippi standards, and he has a penchant for the provocative move.
He staged an upset victory in 1991 in part by running a stark anti-welfare commercial. He once threatened to call out the National Guard if the United States Supreme Court ruled the state's universities were illegally segregated. And he wore a necktie bearing a confederate flag to a recent hearing on minority set-asides.
So far, though, the critics' fears have been only half-realized. Mr. Fordice has essentially adhered to the outline set by Work First: with few exceptions, recipients must spend 35 hours a week in a job-search class or a work program, or face the loss of all their benefits. That alone makes the program one of the nation's toughest. But sobered by some of the lessons from Work First, the state did not take several steps that could have made it tougher still.
With Mississippi's economy strong, for instance, officials did not reduce state spending as critics feared they would. And, significantly, they did not shorten the Federal time limit, which restricts most recipients to five years of lifetime aid.
In a 1995 interview, Mr. Fordice insisted that two years would be "the absolute outside limit" the state would allow. But Mr. Temple said the experiment showed, "you can't get to everybody in that short a period -- that was a great lesson learned."
 
The Delta
A Long History Of Difficult Times
When it comes to the Delta, the state may need all the time it can get. The region has been suffering high rates of joblessness for at least a half-century, since farm mechanization displaced many thousands of uneducated laborers. They escaped in droves to the industrial cities of the North, leaving behind a string of impoverished hamlets. The poverty rate of 41 percent is nearly three times the national average, and nine of the region's 11 counties rank among the nation's 50 poorest.
Frank Howell, a researcher at Mississippi State University, recently examined the job prospects of welfare recipients in the five-county area surrounding Greenville, the Delta's most populous town. He projected the development of one new job for every 254 families leaving the rolls. "There's just a very bleak economic outlook," Mr. Howell said.
Still the rolls have shrunk under the tough new rules. In Washington County, they have fallen 26 percent in the last year alone, despite an average unemployment rate of 9.7 percent. And the pattern holds true for the five contiguous counties, where the unemployment rate has averaged 13.2 percent but caseloads have fallen by a fifth.
Many of the jobs that do exist are distant and difficult. Of the 27 Greenville women placed in jobs last month, 10 went to a single catfish plant, Springwater Farms, in Eudora, Ark. To get there, recipients make an hour-long commute on a school bus that leaves Greenville at 6:30 each morning.
Arriving at the plant, they don hairnets, earplugs and steel-lined safety gloves to work along the clattering saws and conveyer belts that process 100,000 catfish a day. Noting that turnover runs more than 300 percent a year, Donald Taylor, the plant's comptroller, acknowledged the unappealing nature of the minimum-wage work. "You work in the cold, you work in the wet -- and of course you're around guts," he said.
But Mr. Taylor, who also hires welfare recipients from Arkansas and Louisiana, praised the Mississippi program for withholding benefits from those who quit. "If they can go back to Uncle Sam, you can't keep them in the plant," he said.
To raise the prospects of welfare clients, the state is offering deep subsidies to businesses. Employers pay just $1 an hour for the first six months, while the state provides $4.15 to bring clients up to the minimum wage. (The subsidy comes in part from money that would have gone toward welfare and food stamps.)
But the results have so far have proved disappointing. Of the 1,299 Work First clients in Washington County, only 61 got subsidized jobs and just 15 kept them -- about 1 percent of the caseload. Many employers remain reluctant to deal with welfare recipients, and with unemployment rates so high, they can afford to be choosy.
Kevin Cunningham was wary about hiring Felicia Fields even at $1 an hour. Mr. Cunningham is a gregarious Greenville insurance agent with a tie clip shaped like a golf club. "This could be stereotyping on my part," he said, but he worried her friends might say, "Hey, Felicia works up there at Cunningham's office -- she knows where the cash drawer is." And when Ms. Fields, who is black, arrived for work, Mr. Cunningham, who is white, said he warned her that "business language isn't Ebonics."
The comment points at the racial and class tensions that the work program must confront. Almost all the Delta's recipients are black, and most businesses are run by whites. In the case of Mr. Cunningham, he was reassured when he learned that Ms. Fields played the piano in church. And Ms. Fields said that working for Mr. Cunningham was "not as bad as dealing with the church people." The $190.46 she earns each week is more than twice the $309 package of welfare and food stamps she used to receive each month.
"And I can say I earned this money," she said.
 
The Penalties
Habits and Duties Collide With Rules
Ms. Fields represents one of the region's easier cases: she has a high school diploma, just one child and a mother willing to baby-sit. Maggie Miller had eight children by six men, no diploma, no work history and no interest in the work program. She lost her check and moved in with her sister, Debbie, who is unmarried, pregnant and has seven children of her own.
Now Debbie Miller, 37, supports the combined family with $324 in food stamps, $484 in Supplemental Security Income for a disabled daughter, and $744 in Social Security benefits for two sons whose father has died. Plus, she added, "I got a man -- somebody's helping me with the kids."
Barbara Petty, another difficult client, took a more promising step. Notorious in the Greenville office for her disdain for the work program, Ms. Petty, 34, buried her caseworker with medical excuses and complaints, and even appealed to her congressman. Finally, she just gave up, and surrendered the $96 she received each month for one of her children.
"It was just too much hassle to go through," Ms. Petty said, especially when her two other children received a total of $968 a month in supplemental security payments.
But then Ms. Petty did something that surprised even herself: she got a job, providing adult day care to an ailing man. "I wasn't looking for a job," she said. "But with all those hassles with the welfare, I started asking people, 'Do you need any help?' "
Mr. Temple, the former Mississippi official, points to cases like Ms. Petty's in arguing that the penalties are a key to making the program work. "They are tough," he said. "But they are for people who are absolutely refusing to go to work to feed their children."
But circumstances often fall into a gray zone. The attempt to work can sometimes conflict with the attempt to be a good parent, especially for single mothers traveling long distances with uncertain child care and transportation. The state is promising to reimburse recipients for their child care expenses. But many women still find baby-sitters unavailable or undependable during the hours they need.
Among those referred to the Springwater catfish plant was Patricia Watson, a 34-year-old divorced woman who adopted her niece, Jasmine, at birth. Since Ms. Watson had to catch the 6:30 bus, she entrusted a teen-age relative to take 6-year-old Jasmine to school and watch her afterward. When Ms. Watson returned late in the afternoon, the teen-ager had not even realized the child was missing. "I was scared to death," Ms. Watson said. "I said, 'Oh, Lord, somebody's walked off with my baby!' "
Ms. Watson began a house-by-house search, and discovered her daughter a half-hour later, playing with a friend down the block. She quit the plant, lost her welfare benefits and is relying on her mother for now.
A lost check brought more immediate upheaval to the family of Curley Barron. She was already caring for a mother with emphysema and a brother with a rare bone disease when she took in her brother's two children last year. The children -- James, 9, and Joel, 7 -- had been placed in foster care after their mother developed a drug habit.
Ms. Barron, 44, began receiving $435 in cash and food stamps for the children's support. She was incensed when she received a notice last spring saying she would have to perform 35 hours a week of community service to maintain her benefits. "The kids were a ward of the state -- they weren't mine," she said. "So I don't feel like I should have to go out and work for free, just for food stamps." Plus, Ms. Barron said, "I'm not going to neglect my mother."
Saying she could not support the children without the state aid, Ms. Barron returned them to foster care, where they are costing the state $510 a month -- more than the cash and food stamps Ms. Barron received. She cannot qualify for payments as a foster parent unless she completes a licensing course. "It doesn't make any sense at all," she said. "I'm going to take care of them better than some stranger."
 
The Outlook
In One Small Town, Future Holds Little
Pessimism about the Delta's prospects runs especially deep in Glendora, 90 minutes east of Greenville. The town made a cameo appearance in civil rights history as the place where a black teen-ager, Emmett Till, was beaten in 1955 after he was accused of whistling at a white woman. He was then killed, and his body was thrown in the Tallahatchie River.
"Not much has changed, except for the worse," grumbles the mayor, Johnny Thomas, speaking of the town's shrinking economy. Of the town's 88 households, Mr. Thomas speculates that all but three receive public assistance at some time of the year. Industry is all but nonexistent in Tallahatchie County, and the nearest place hiring is a poultry plant in Water Valley, about 70 miles away. Even by the standards of the region, "Tallahatchie's a challenge," said Jean-Marie Hill, who runs the state's job-placement program in the Delta. Mr. Thomas's main hope for the town now resides with a quixotic plan to build a plant that would slaughter and process goats.
On a recent afternoon, he assembled a half-dozen residents who had lost their benefits after declining work assignments in distant towns. One had moved in with a boyfriend. Another was getting food packages from a private agency. A third was living on her children's disability checks, after turning down a night job in a neighboring county.
Among those dropped from the rolls this year was Carrie Ann Bridges, a 26-year-old mother of four. "She had been cut off cause she wasn't working," said her father, Elijah Bridges. "She had to get a job." She found one on the second shift at the Water Valley plant, sharing the round-trip drive of three hours with her aunt, Geneva Bridges. The two were driving home after midnight in July when Carrie Ann fell asleep and drove into a ditch, killing them both.
Accidents happen everywhere, of course. But the long, late-night commute highlights the added challenges that work programs face in a region starved for jobs. Mr. Bridges now receives $72 each in Social Security payments for his daughter's four children, whose ages range from 11 to 1. A genial man who supports himself with seasonal work at a cotton gin, Mr. Bridges agreed the old welfare system needed to change. But he also warned, "some people really need the help."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Finance Deal Luring Company to Bronx

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In a small victory in New York City's efforts to stem the decline of manufacturing jobs, a food processing company that fled Queens for New Jersey in 1993 is expected to accept a package of financial incentives to move back to the city, this time to the Bronx.
The company, the Paradise Products Corporation, which processes olives, cherries and other specialty foods, is to meet today with the city's Industrial Development Authority to complete an agreement in which Paradise would receive $5.6 million in tax-exempt financing to buy a large warehouse in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx and convert it to a processing plant. 
 The company, based in Hawthorne, N.J., would complete the renovation and move all its 45 employees to the Bronx plant sometime next year, according to Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Commission. The company would be required to hire at least 60 more workers in the Bronx over the next three years.
David Lax, the company's founder and chief executive officer, said yesterday that Paradise had moved to New Jersey because it had outgrown its plant in Jamaica, Queens, and wanted a site in an area with less crime. The company's growth forced it to seek an even larger plant over the last year, he said. It chose the Bronx because of its access to rail connections and interstate highways, and improvements in security that have accompanied the city's lower crime rate, Mr. Lax said.

HEADLINE: Messinger And Sharpton Show Warmth At a Rally

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Ruth W. Messinger and the Rev. Al Sharpton campaigned together enthusiastically last night at a rally at a Democratic clubhouse in Queens. Mr. Sharpton gave Ms. Messinger a rousing endorsement and she praised him in return, saying that because of Mr. Sharpton, "We are able to create a unified Democratic party."
In contrast to their rather stiff appearances together at two churches in Manhattan and Queens on Sunday, during which Mr. Sharpton seemed to measure his remarks even as he was endorsing Ms. Messinger, the former competitors for the Democratic mayoral nomination showed only warmth toward each other last night. 
 They also loudly voiced their disdain for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican, much as they had done during their primary debates when they directed attacks at the incumbent instead of one another. But Mr. Sharpton went further, saying at one point, "It's not just voting against Giuliani; it's voting for someone."
Ms. Messinger and Mr. Sharpton arrived separately at the rally at the Guy R. Brewer United Democratic Club in St. Albans. But they entered the hall together, and Mr. Sharpton, in a gesture of courtesy, extended an arm directing Ms. Messinger to walk ahead of him down an aisle to their seats next to each other on the dais.
Mr. Sharpton, called on by City Councilman Archie Spigner, a leader of the club, to introduce Ms. Messinger, quickly began an angry attack on Democrats who had defected to support Mr. Giuliani. One such Democrat, Representative Floyd H. Flake, who was not at the rally, has an office across from the Brewer Club on Linden Boulevard.
"It is a serious matter to me," Mr. Sharpton said, "when we are faced with the last municipal election of the century and there are those in certain pockets of this city that for personal reasons and, in my judgment, personal gain have decided to abandon the principles that we have fought for all of this century. This is not just about party or race. This is about what you believe in and this about who you are. Who you support and what you support defines who you are."
Mr. Sharpton again rejected suggestions that his endorsement of Ms. Messinger on Sunday had been half-hearted. "They said, 'Well, why don't you all come down the aisle of the church together?' I said, 'We are forming a political alliance; we are not getting married.' "
After the rally, Mr. Sharpton said that he had waited until last night to expound on his support for Ms. Messinger's candidacy because "it would have been a mockery of the church," adding that, "If I had done that Sunday, others would have said I am politicizing the pulpit."
While Ms. Messinger needs the backing of Mr. Sharpton's supporters, she has faced questions from Jewish voters about her ties to him. At a Jewish forum on Monday, she defended her unwillingness to denounce Mr. Sharpton, who has been accused of straining relations between blacks and Jews.
Mr. Sharpton used the rally last night to offer his strongest words yet in support of Ms. Messinger. "For 20 years, Ruth Messinger has been consistent on issues that are important," he said. He also pledged to campaign for her, beginning Monday, at "two subway stops a day."
He closed saying: "I grew up in a single-parent home, so I know when we would get in trouble we'd go to our mother, because sometimes, the woman, the mother was all we had. This city is in trouble. We look to a mother, a grandmother who will be the first woman Mayor of the City of New York."
Ms. Messinger, clearly energized by Mr. Sharpton's address, gave a lively version of her stump speech, pushing education as her top priority. She also talked about reducing unemployment and fighting police brutality. Her remarks, too, were met with loud applause.
Outside, Mr. Sharpton responded coyly when asked whether he would run for Congress against Representative Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn, one of the Democrats who endorsed Mr. Giuliani. At first, he pretended not to hear the question, then said, "Well, I do live in that district."
Before leaving, Mr. Sharpton poked his head in Ms. Messinger's van and told her, "I don't want them to say that I didn't say good night."

HEADLINE: Mercedes-Benz Grows By Adding Smallness

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: STUTTGART, Germany

 BODY:
THE three-pointed star of Daimler-Benz stood for land, air and sea when it was introduced in 1909, a symbol of the German company's interests in cars, planes and ships. Since then, it has become an emblem for other things: riches, refinement, reliability and the steep price tag on a secondhand Mercedes. Of course, the star has adorned taxis and trucks as well as the contemporary conveyances of popes, kings, playboys and Balkan strongmen. But a belching Mercedes cab in Istanbul never impinged much on the image. Mercedes is to cars what Cartier is to jewelry.
So, standing beneath the steep, vine-clad hills that surround this southern German town, in the midst of the sprawling Mercedes headquarters, it is a surprise to see several small, squat, wedge-shaped vehicles nosing around with the famous star emblazoned on their grills. 
 The first impression is of a bad joke, an insidious Fiat- or Renault-led invasion of high-class motoring's inner sanctum. The upstart is short -- almost two feet less than a subcompact; it stands oddly, high off the road, because it is based on a new engineeering concept -- passengers on top, the works underneath. And its color schemes and idiot-proof, minimalist dashboard are painfully trendy. The vehicle has strong claims to originality but stands squarely at the antipode of Mercedes elegance. Viewed from almost any angle, it is graceless.
This little machine with the chutzpah to call itself a Mercedes is the new A-Class, which the company is introducing this year only in Europe. It appears to break new and perhaps treacherous ground in the leveraging of trademarks by doing something akin to attaching a Jaguar emblem to a Mini. "The car is quite unnecessarily ugly," said Chris Will, an auto analyst at Lehman Brothers in London. "If you, as a man, drove down a trendy London street, say the King's Road, in an A-Class, don't you think people would laugh at you?"
Mercedes is ready to take that risk. Indeed, risk taking has abruptly become the preferred approach of the most buttoned-down of auto makers. In the last five years, Mercedes has embarked on a startling diversification of both its range and image that has led it to forsake the shibboleth of "made in Germany" and the well-trodden ground of luxury sedans.
It has built factories in America and Brazil; produced a new sport utility vehicle, the M-Class, at its $300 million Alabama plant; replaced the 16-year-old rectangular headlight housings on its classic E-Class with four protuberant oval eyes that give the model a new edge; introduced an uncompromisingly sporty SLK roadster with a retractable hard roof; readied a new two-seater "smart car" for the harried urban commuter who wants low gas consumption and easy parking and, not least, invented the A-Class. All this for an investment conservatively estimated at $10 billion.
"Lexus and Infiniti taught us a tough lesson in the early 1990's," said Jurgen Hubbert, the head of the passenger-car division and a member of the board of Daimler-Benz. "A lesson in value-for-money and not resting on your laurels. We saw that if we went on as before, we'd soon be dead, the next Rolls-Royce. So we decided to defend ourselves by going on the offensive."
That offensive rested on a simple analysis. Mercedes was focusing almost exclusively on the premium-car segment, which was stagnating, increasingly contested by newcomers like Lexus and, in the United States, shifting rapidly toward sport utility vehicles. Mercedes was thus confined to about 8 percent of the 40-million-car world market -- the part that starts with a global price tag of $25,000 -- even as it offered cars that new tastes and Japanese competitiveness challenged. Moreover, the company was building its cars in a single country, Germany, whose labor costs are still among the highest in the world.
The shake-up that Mr. Hubbert pushed through involved the classic turnaround methods of cost cutting and job reductions. Mercedes now produces 645,000 cars a year with 80,000 employees, compared with 581,000 cars in 1991 using 100,000 employees. But the changes went much further.
They involved a shift in culture: accepting the notion that Mercedes had to widen its client base by building small cars for the first time, taking on the American "sport ute" challenge and making automobiles outside Germany that conformed to the legendary Mercedes standards. The simultaneous emergence onto the market this fall of the M-Class, built in rural Vance, Ala., and the A-Class, built in Germany but soon to be manufactured in Brazil, is a measure of how far the company has traveled.
To illustrate the change in culture, Mr. Hubbert went to his closet, pulled out a green sweatshirt with his name, Jurgen, printed on it and held it over his impeccable double-breasted suit. He keeps the sweatshirt in the closet, he explained, so he doesn't forget it when he goes to Alabama.
At the American factory, which produced its first M-Class vehicle in February, the dress codes and formal divisions between management levels that characterize German business are anathema. When in Vance, Mr. Hubbert eases out of his suits and cruises the factory in his sweatshirt.
"Of course, if I went around in this thing here, people would think I'm crazy," he said. "But we've tried to bring some of the American management culture to Germany, the sense that we are all in this together, that we all have the responsibility of bringing the company to a strong position with the right products and the right productivity." So, the Stuttgart plant's three canteens -- one for workers, one for middle management and one for top management -- were replaced by a self-service cafeteria for everyone.
In Alabama, the careful selection of a mixed German-American management team, the training of many new employees in Stuttgart and the painstaking inculcation of Mercedes values have so far produced a surprising harmony. Mercedes has found it likes the freewheeling culture. Approval of the plant by the state's Governor, James E. Folsom Jr., took five months in 1993, whereas a similar project might have taken years to get going in Germany's tightly regulated environment. Detroit is not about to move south, but a cottage industry of suppliers has already brought something new to deepest Dixie.
The made-in-America Mercedes M-Class "all-activity vehicle" went on sale last month for about $35,000. For now, production capacity is about 70,000 vehicles annually -- of which about 40 percent will be exported to Europe -- and demand is already overwhelming.
WHERE the design of the A-Class is at best controversial, that of the M-Class is strong and sleek, neatly combining understated elegance with the off-road machismo that even the most staid buyers seem to want in their sport utilities. An economical V6 engine, a spacious interior, an innovative traction-control system that brings power to the right place when one or several wheels are spinning and that relatively low price tag plus the Mercedes star all seem to insure that market winners like the Ford Explorer and the Jeep Grand Cherokee Limited get a run for their money.
The Mercedes revolution has so far produced generally favorable results. Helped by its productivity gains and recently by a stronger dollar, which means its German-produced cars are cheaper in America, Mercedes has responded successfully to the Japanese challenge. While Lexus and Infiniti sales fell last year in the United States, Mercedes increased its American sales in 1996 to 90,844 from 76,752 in 1995.
Like Audi and its archrival BMW, referred to in Stuttgart only as "our competition in Munich," Mercedes has successfully given German engineering and styling a new competitive edge, while the cachet of Japanese luxury cars has faded. John Lawson, an auto analyst at Salomon Brothers in London, expects Mercedes to show an operating profit of about $1.9 billion this year, compared with $1.5 billion in 1996. The crisis that prompted the upheaval at Mercedes already seems fairly distant.
Still, the true test lies ahead. In essence, Mercedes has made a bet that, even over time, its image will not be compromised by the presence of the three-pointed star on a subcompact car and the introduction of production operations throughout the world. BMW has responded very differently to the same challenges Mercedes faced, and some analysts prefer its approach. By buying the Rover Group of Britain in 1994, BMW acquired the most famous of all sport utilities, the Land Rover, and perhaps the strongest trademark for a subcompact car, the Mini.
"BMW has widened its footprint in the car market, but without sullying its principal brand," said Mr. Will of Lehman Brothers. "The risk for Mercedes is that they're going to have some guy with his S-Class waiting for service behind a student with an A-Class. That's not going to make the S-Class clientele very happy."
The initial response to the A-Class has, however, been enthusiastic. Mercedes has already received 70,000 orders for the car, and the clients are mostly new ones -- only 20 percent currently own a Mercedes -- suggesting that the company may lure a new generation of buyers.
Mercedes has successfully marketed the car's new "sandwich-floor concept" -- a space-saving and safety-enhancing device that puts a lot of parts in a "basement" of the body. As a result, the engine is not pushed into the interior in the event of a front-end crash, but slides back into the chamber beneath the interior's floor.
As small as it appears, the car's interior is only four millimeters shorter than that of the C-Class (once known as the Baby Benz). It also has 72 different seat variations. Such features have allowed Mercedes to boast that the A-Class is a city car, a family car, a station wagon and a mini-van rolled into one. Priced at about $17,000 for the basic model, the A-Class is only marginally more expensive than the Volkswagen Golf. Hedging its bets, as it has with the M-Class, Mercedes plans to produce only about 200,000 units a year.
BUT the question remains: Does the initial wave of buyers represent a mad, ephemeral rush by people who haven't been able to afford a Mercedes until now? Or will the A-Class, as Mr. Hubbert insists, "prove itself a true Mercedes for its comfort and its driveability" that the company may eventually bring to the American market?
Those questions may take several years to answer. What is clear now is that the Mercedes subcompact is a strange creation. Its doors give a nice Mercedes-like thunk, and the ease with which the seats fold or are removed is remarkable. The car's engineers are obviously fiendishly ingenious. To drive it, however, is to feel perched in the midst of a raised fishbowl, one that accelerates niftily and holds the road well, but whose claim to that three-pointed star on the grill seems more than a little tenuous.
