HEADLINE: Few Buy Autos on the Web, but Many Start Their Research There

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
WHEN Rod Bowles and his wife, Mary Terwiske, of New Market, N.H., decided it was time to replace their 1982 Pontiac Bonneville station wagon with 140,000 miles, they sat right down and logged onto the Internet.
"We used the Internet to research our car purchase because we lead busy lives," Mr. Bowles said. "It allowed us the freedom to do our research at our convenience, often at night. We found lots of objective and subjective information available at our pace and in the privacy of our home. We shopped price and product of all vehicles and models." 
 It also allowed him to avoid what Mr. Bowles called "the hype of a dealership." Those same reasons apply to many of the 1.5 million new-vehicle buyers who will use car-shopping services on the Internet to help them select a car this year.
Only a small number of buyers are actually purchasing cars on the Internet, but many more are using the resources available to Web browsers who want to arrive at a car lot feeling well informed. They have plenty of places to search: more than 200 sites with automotive information already exist, and the number is increasing rapidly.
According to Jon Osborn, the manager of auto sales research at J. D. Power & Associates, the market research firm, the percentage of new-vehicle buyers turning to sources other than dealers for shopping assistance has jumped from 11 percent to more than 20 percent over a year, largely because of that surge in Web services.
"This is just the beginning of vehicle shopping outside the showroom," Mr. Osborn said.
Mr. Bowles and Ms. Terwiske were not sure what model they wanted to buy when they began their search. Mr. Bowles entered the Internet via America Online's automotive service, which gave him free access to Car and Driver buyer's guide. It provides information on hundreds of new cars and trucks, rates them and identifies the best models in categories, like highest fuel economy, most interior space, lowest price.
In addition, the buyer's guide showed which vehicles were basically the same, but sold under different names. For instance, Mr. Bowles learned that the Chrysler Town and Country mini-van is the same as the Dodge Caravan, just more expensive.
Mr. Bowles also chatted with owners of other vehicles through cybermessage boards, like Car and Driver's, for "emotional" information -- what people liked and didn't like about the cars.
The Bowles family ultimately selected the Mercury Villager, which is virtually identical to the Nissan Quest, because it met their needs for passenger and cargo capacity. They also liked the fact that while it was designed and engineered by Nissan, it was built by Ford in the United States.
At the other end of the country in Seattle, George Eng used the Internet to find a replacement for his 1991 Ford Taurus with 157,000 miles.
PASSING BY a used-car lot one evening, Mr. Eng spotted a car he didn't recognize, a Mitsubishi Galant. He liked what he saw, but didn't know anything about the car. So he logged onto the Internet and began gathering information, specifically what price he should pay based on the car's features and mileage and condition, all material from the on-line used-car price guides. He posted bulletins on message boards asking Galant owners what they liked and didn't like about their cars, how much they paid for them, what kind of maintenance they had required and if they preferred the four- or six-cylinder version.
"I was deluged with responses," he said, "and people were fairly honest."
He was less fortunate in researching what price his Ford Taurus should bring as a trade-in. He collected prices from the on-line used-car price guides, but when he went to the dealerships the prices they offered were far lower. The dealers told him they didn't use the price guides. "It was a waste," he said, "but it gave me a base to work with."
There are other problems for Internet car shoppers, starting with the quality and accessibility of Web sites, which run the gamut from poor and slow to excellent. And Mr. Eng discovered that on some sites, retail car dealers are posing as wholesalers.
Indeed, the Internet is proving to be a good place for dealers to lure customers. A survey by the National Automobile Dealers Association, the industry trade group in McLean, Va., representing more than 20,000 car dealers nationwide, showed 30 percent of all dealerships report an average of 43 sales leads a month from the Internet, a new source of potential buyers. But some of the unsavory practices that can occur in the showrooms -- bait and switch, for instance -- are turning up in cyberspace as well.
Although the number of people buying cars via the computer remains low, a growing number of buying services are offering on-line financing. Typically, buying services are aligned with a limited number of dealers who pay a subscription fee and list their inventory. If shoppers are interested, they can obtain price information from the dealer by submitting an electronic request. They ultimately make the deal and take delivery of the car at a dealership.
ANALYSTS say this reflects the problems of on-line commerce in general, which has yet to overcome consumer hesitations over security and other issues. And some car shoppers doubt that a middleman -- the buying service -- can provide the best price.
Men are more apt to buy on the Internet than women, who typically do more on-line research, but only as preparation for the traditional trip to the dealer.
Mr. Bowles tapped into one of the largest buying services, Autovantage, a division of CUC International, a membership-based consumer services company in Stamford, Conn. After he paid the $50 search fee, the service found the Mercury Villager he wanted, but it was at a Massachusetts dealership, far from his New Hampshire home. Mr. Bowles ended up finding the same model at a better price on his own at a dealership nearby in Portsmouth, N.H.
So, for all its advantages, Mr. Bowles concluded, the Internet is no panacea.
"You still have to go to the dealership to touch the car and drive it," he said.
 
Where to Go on the Web
Car sales may have hit a plateau in the United States, but automotive Web sites are a growth industry. There are buyer, pricing and finance guides, and almost all manufacturers have sites, generally found at http://www.theirname.com. Here are a few of the more popular car sites on the Internet:
General Interest
http://www.caranddriver.com/hfm/ index.html
Car and Driver magazine buyer's guide.
The Car and Driver car buyer's guide provides information on manufacturers and models and which are the best in various categories.
http://carpoint.msn.com
Microsoft Carpoint
Microsoft Carpoint is an on-line automotive buying guide, with color photographs, offering details on virtually every model of car and truck sold in the United States.
http://www.autodirectory.com
All Things Automotive Directory
The All Things Automotive Directory site covers all aspects of automotive information and links up to Automobile magazine and its buyer's guide.
Pricing Guides
http://www.edmund.com
Edmund's Automobile Buyer's Guides
Edmund's, a pricing service, supplies information on vehicles, prices and incentives like cash rebates and advice on how to negotiate a good price at dealerships.
http://www.kbb.com
Kelley Blue Book
New- and used-car pricing.
Car Buying Services
http://www.autobytel.com
Auto-by-Tel
Auto-by-Tel is an on-line buying service to which dealers subscribe and list their cars. Consumers are contacted by dealers after submitting a request on a car.
http://www.autoweb.com
Autoweb Interactive
Autoweb works much like Auto-by-Tel.
http://www.autovantage.com
Autovantage
Autovantage offers reviews and car prices. The consumer can submit a price request via the Web by calling a toll-free number. Autovantage responds with a preferred price honored by one of its dealers.
Financing information
http://www.leasesource.com
Leasesource
Leasesource gives the pros and cons of leasing. Using on-line work sheets, it helps you decide whether you should buy or lease.

 CORRECTION:
A front-page table of contents in the special Cars section on Thursday misspelled the surname of the author of an interview with the hosts of the radio program "Car Talk." He is Jim McCraw, not McGraw.
An article in the section about buying automobiles on the Internet misstated the fee schedule of Autovantage, an on-line service. Searches for new cars on the service are free. The $50 fee is for a membership that provides additional benefits.

PUB-DATE: October 16, 1997

SECTION: Section G; Page 10; Column 1; Automobiles

LENGTH: 2141 words

HEADLINE: Milestones and Potholes on a Well-Traveled Road

 BODY:
Today, there are $60,000 off-road vehicles that never leave the pavement, pop-up cup holders and eight-way power seats with electric lumbar supports. Japanese cars are made in Kentucky; German trucks are built in Alabama, and American vehicles are assembled in Mexico. But before there were hideaway headlamps, tailfins and push-button transmissions, before even the electric starter, there were mechanically inclined folks who tinkered with motors and gears in out-of-the-way barns. Few died rich and fewer left their names to posterity in chrome script on trunk lids. Here are some highlights, lowlights and sidelights - by no means a comprehensive history - of what they have wrought.
 
1769
France's Minister of War authorizes a steam-powered truck to carry cannons. Essentially a huge tricycle, it was designed by Nicolas-Joseph Cugnot. It could carry four people at 2.5 miles an hour, but the boiler had to be refilled every 15 minutes.
 
1771
The first motor accident occurs when Cugnot's second steam truck hits a wall at the Paris Arsenal. Excessive speed was not the cause.
 
1824
Samuel Brown fits an engine that burns coal gas to a carriage. The vehicle manages to climb Shooter's Hill in Blackheath, England.
 
1862
Alphonse-Eugene Beau de Rochas of France writes a paper describing the principles of a four-stroke engine in which fuel and air would be compressed before ignition.
 
1883
Gottlieb Daimler, a German, develops the first high-speed engine suitable for motor vehicles.
 
1886
Karl Benz, another German, patents the first practical internal-combustion automobile.
 
c. 1908
Fashionable headgear for the motoring lady.
 
Sept. 15, 1908
Intent on acquiring auto companies, William Crapo Durant, who had made Buick a success, forms a holding company he calls General Motors. By 1909, he controls 8 parts companies and 13 auto makers, including Oldsmobile and Cadillac. He enters talks to buy Goodyear and strikes a deal to acquire Ford, but bankers refuse to lend him the money.
 
1905
The first car theft is reported, in St. Louis.
 
1908
Henry Ford offers the Model T, below, for $850. Lightweight, durable and affordable, it will transform America.
 
1903
An Alabama woman, Mary Anderson, receives a patent for an automobile windshield wiper. *Dr. H. Nelson Jackson and Sewell Crocker complete the first transcontinental auto trip in a Winton. The journey takes 63 days, 19 of them spent waiting for replacement parts.
 
1901
New York City requires owners to display their initials on their cars. These first license plates are usually metal letters affixed to leather pads. Two years later, Massachusetts issues the first state plates.
 
1897
Ransom E. Olds forms the Olds Motor Vehicle Company in Lansing, Mich. Four years later, the Oldsmobile Curved Dash Runabout makes its debut; the price, $650. With 425 produced, the gasoline-powered Curved Dash proves the feasibility of mass-producing simple cars.
 
1896
Henry Ford hits the road in his Quadricycle, a modified horse buggy steered with a tiller and initially lacking brakes. Ford has to demolish part of his rented shop to get the contraption out, and it breaks down a few blocks away, to the amusement of passersby.
 
1911
Ray Harroun wins a $10,000 purse in the first 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. A rear-view mirror, believed to be the first, is bolted to his winning car, a Marmon Wasp.
 
1912
Cadillac offers electric starters and electric headlights, making nighttime driving less dangerous.
 
1913
On April 1, Ford's magneto assemblers are positioned side by side, and each is given a small task in a 29-step process - the first large-scale industrial assembly-line operation. By year's end, Ford sells 189,088 Model T's.
*For the first time, more autos than horse buggies are manufactured.
 
1914
Henry Ford announces that he will pay factory workers $5 for an eight-hour day, about twice the going rate. Southerners begin a mass migration to Northern cities.
 
1916
Durant reacquires G.M. He loses control again in 1920 to the DuPont family and J.P. Morgan.
*Ford's Model T sales reach 585,388.
 
1915
Durant, having lost control of General Motors in 1910, starts Chevrolet.
 
1918
Vogue Tyre and Rubber Company offers the white sidewall tire.
 
1920
New York City gets an impressively large traffic light at 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue. A year earlier, the first such signal turned green in Detroit.
 
1921
The Federal Highway Act creates a national network of roads.
 
1923
Alfred P. Sloan Jr. becomes president and chief executive of G.M. and revamps its muddied businesses, creating a model for modern corporations. G.M. markets a car for "every purse and purpose" and ushers in the practice of changing models every year.
 
1934
The Chrysler Airflow, with styling based on aerodynamic principles, is introduced. It is too radical for the public.
 
PUB-DATE: May 16, 1934
John Dillinger, above, drops a note to Henry Ford to rave about the "wonderful car" he is driving - a 1934 Ford V8, which he had stolen. Not to be outdone, Clyde Barrow sends his own testimonal, writing, "I have drove Fords exclusively when I could get away with one."
 
1932
Ford introduces its legendary flathead V8, bringing power to the people.
 
1930
The Dodge DB Senior Six comes with a factory-installed radio two feet wide, 8 inches high and 16 inches deep.
 
1931
G.M. passes Ford in sales for the second time. This time, it keeps the lead.
 
1928
The Duesenberg Model J, precursor to some of the most elegant cars ever made, is displayed at the New York Automobile Salon. Clark Gable, above, owned a 1935 convertible coupe.
 
1927
Having finally realized that the Model T's appeal had faded and alarmed by Chevrolet's soaring sales, Henry Ford unveils the Model A. Within a day and a half, 8.5 percent of the nation's population lines up to see the new car, which starts at a reasonable $495. Half a million Americans put down deposits.
 
1926
Harley Earl styles his first car for G.M., the 1927 LaSalle. He goes on to become the dean of auto design and makes styling the driving force in car sales before he retirees in 1958.
 
1937
After a 44-day sit-down strike in Flint, Mich., G.M. and later, Chrysler sign contracts with the United Automobile Workers.
 
c. 1937
Adolf Hitler unveils the "people's car" that he had long envisioned, the Volkswagon. The designer: Ferdinand Porsche.
 
PUB-DATE: May 26, 1937
Thugs working for Ford beat Walter Reuther and other U.A.W. organizers at the "Battle of the Overpass." Ford resists union efforts until 1941, when the United States Supreme Court orders it to rehire illegally dismissed workers and it agrees to a union election.
 
1940
America's first superhighway - 160-mile stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike - opens.
*Oldsmobile offers cars with fully automatic transmissions as a $57 option.
*The meter starts running on the first air-conditioned taxi in New York City, a 1940 Packard.
 
1942-1945
With the nation at war, auto assembly lines are halted by Government order and converted to military production, Willys-Overland and Ford produce 650,000 jeeps.
 
1947
The Tucker Torpedo, a futuristic design with a pivoting center headlight, is unveiled. Only 51 cars are built. The car's developer, Preston Tucker, was portrayed by Jeff Bridges, above, in a 1988 movie.
 
1948
Cadillac sprouts nascent fins, inspired by the P-38 Lightning fighter plane.
 
1949
A Dutchman, Ben Pon, is met with indifference and derision when he tries to interest American dealers in the Volkswagen. He sells only two, including his sample.
 
1953
Responding to a surge of interest in European sports cars like the MG from Britain, Chevrolet introduces a two-seat, fiberglass-body car, the Corvette.
 
1964
The Ford Mustang is a hit at the New York World's Fair. The personal pony car becomes the rage.
*At Pontiac, John Z. DeLorean defies G.M. policy by cramming a 389-cubic-inch V8 into the lightweight Tempest and calling it a GTO. The muscle-car revolution begins.
*Prodded by laws in 23 states, auto makers install front seat belts in all new cars.
 
1960
With imports capturing nearly 10 percent of the American auto market, and sales of American compacts like the Rambler and Studebaker Lark surging, the Big Three offer compacts: the Chevrolet Corvair, Ford Falcon and Chrysler's Valiant.
 
1959
G.M., having lost its edge in styling to Chrysler's big fins of 1957 and 1958, strikes back. The flamboyant new Cadillac takes the gimmick about as far as it will go.
 
1957
Toyota comes to America. By the end of 1958, it sells 288 cars.
 
Sept. 4, 1957
Ford introduces the ill-fated 1958 Edsel. It is put out of its misery in November 1959 after sales of only 110,847 and losses of $250 million.
 
1956
While Chevrolet pushes speed, Ford promotes safety features including seat belts, double-grip door latches and padded dashes. The public chooses speed.
 
PUB-DATE: June 29, 1956
President Eisenhower signs the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways Act, creating a 38,000-mile network of superhighways.
 
1955
Chevrolet's first "small block" V8 appears, producing impressive power for its size. The engine is still in production. Ford offers a sporty two-sealer, the Thunderbird, which is discontinued in 1997.
 
1965
Ralph Nader writes "Unsafe at Any Speed," excoriating Detroit for selling dangerous cars and singling out the Corvair. The book does not sell well until it is revealed that G.M. hired detectives to investigate Mr. Nader. G.M.'s president publicly apologizes, and the company pays $425,000 to settle an invasion-of-privacy suit.
 
1966
Congress passes laws that result in mandatory safety features like padded dashboards, emergency flashers and shoulder belts.
 
1970
President Nixon signs the Clean Air Act, requiring a 90 percent reduction in carbon monoxide and hydrocarbon auto emissions by 1975 and a 90 percent drop in nitrogen oxide emissions by 1976.
 
1973-74
The Arab oil embargo, a reaction to the Arab-Israeli war, results in long lines for suddenly expensive gasoline. Big-car sales are dead; small Japanese imports get a boost.
 
Jan. 12, 1975
Chrysler offers rebates up to $400 in Super Bowl halftime commercials. The three other American auto makers follow suit, and buyer incentives become a fixture of the car business.
 
PUB-DATE: July 13, 1978
Henry Ford 2d, above right, dismisses Ford's president, Lee A. Iacocca, saying, according to Mr. Iacocca, "Sometimes you just don't like somebody." A few months later, Mr. Iacocca becomes president of Chrysler.
 
Jan. 16, 1979
The Shah of Iran is overthrown and Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini soon cuts oil exports. The United States economy stumbles, gas lines return and Japanese car sales soar.
 
Dec. 19, 1979
Congress approves $1.5 billion in loan guarantees to avert the bankruptcy of Chrysler. The loans are paid back in 1983, seven years early.
 
1997
The number of cars in the United States has grown seven times as fast as the human population since 1969. With vehicles on the verge of outnumbering drivers, an automated highway experiment in California features driverless cars. What's next?
 
1994
Import quotas, imposed to protect the American auto industry from the Japanese, are phased out after 12 years.
 
1996
With outdoor gear in vogue and sport utility vehicles rolling through suburbia, light trucks account for 44 percent of American vehicle sales.
 
1992
With G.M.'s sales slumping, its stock price falling and its credit rating cut, several top executives, including the chairman, Robert C. Stempel, are forced out by a newly activist board.
 
PUB-DATE: June 17, 1994
In the most-watched and possibly slowest car chase ever, the police pursue O.J. Simpson and his friend, Al Cowlings, in a white Ford Bronco after Mr. Simpson is charged with the murder of his ex-wife and her friend. The 50-mile drama is played out before a national television audience.
 
1987
Chrysler buys American Motors, including the Jeep franchise that becomes a gold mine.
 
PUB-DATE: July 30, 1990
Seven years after G.M. announced its plan to form the Saturn Corporation to build import-fighting small cars, Roger B. Smith drives the first Saturn off the line in Tennessee. He retires as G.M. chairman the next day.
 
1983
The mini-van, a concept reject by Ford, is introduced by Chrysler and embraced by suburban parents. Another mini-van breakthrough: the modern auto cup holder, which spreads to virtually every make and model and makes traffic jams easier to swallow.
 
Nov. 1, 1982
In Marysville, Ohio, a Honda Accord rolls off the assembly line as the first Japanese car made in America.
